HEADLINE: Salvaging Public Housing

 BODY:
Public housing started in New York as a transitional stop for poor families on the way up. But Federal rules that discriminate against working tenants have turned once-glistening housing projects in many cities into gang-controlled dumping grounds for the poorest of the poor and the long-term unemployed. In New York, advocates for the homeless have long opposed a plan for preserving public housing's stability by setting aside at least some apartments for people who work. But now that both the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development and a Federal court have approved the plan, Ruben Franco, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, is free to proceed with what is essentially a common-sense arrangement.
Public housing in New York City is orderly and livable compared with such housing in cities like Chicago and Newark. The difference lies in the fact that New York City's tenants have historically consisted largely of working families who lived orderly lives and maintained coherent communities. This started to change when the Housing Authority dropped its meticulous screening procedures -- and adhered to Government regulations stipulating that 90 percent of public housing be set aside for the very poor, among them the homeless. 
 At the start of the 1980's, more than half the public housing tenants had jobs. By the mid-1990's, less than a third of households contained a working adult. Among families on the waiting list, less than 10 percent did. As the working population disappeared, the projects became less desirable and more dangerous, forcing out stable families.
Mr. Franco's plan would still preserve the bulk of public housing for the poorest of the poor. In the coming year, some 10,000 vouchers will go to the very poor, among them people from homeless shelters, to pay for housing in private buildings. Of the 8,000 apartments in public housing itself, half will be earmarked for the working poor -- families of four with a median income of $24,500 -- and half for the very poor.
This could make the wait for public housing longer. But those who do gain admittance will benefit from more orderly communities. By bringing middle-class normalcy to public housing, working families could make Federal support more palatable to taxpayers.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan, Economic Power Aside, Seems Paralyzed by Asia Crisis

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN with NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 17

 BODY:
As a financial crisis sweeps through Asia and provokes fears of a global downturn, Japan is the one economic force powerful enough to pull the region back to vitality.
The catch, however, is that Japan, the world's largest creditor nation, with an economy twice as large as all the rest of Asia, is not part of the solution but a major part of the problem. 
 Japan's leadership is in disarray, and has dithered for the last seven years of its own downturn. Many economists say that the Japanese Government -- by denying its problems or even dissembling about them -- has prolonged its own economic torment and contributed to the Asian financial crisis.
Today Japan announced $16 billion in tax cuts and later in the day plans to formally unveil a $77 billion bailout of its own financial mess -- a package bigger than the $57 billion International Monetary Fund rescue for South Korea. The scale is inevitable: the assets of a single Japanese bank, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, are roughly 10 times the size of the entire South Korean stock market.
Despite such plans, few analysts expect Japan to move decisively to address its own problems or Asia's.
"The extent of Japanese mismanagement of its own economy in the last seven years, particularly under Herbert Hoover Hashimoto, is one of the overwhelming themes of the modern era," said William H. Overholt, a managing director at Bankers Trust Company in Hong Kong.
While the parallel between Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto and President Hoover may seem overblown, it is heard increasingly often these days among Mr. Hashimoto's foreign critics. Like Hoover in the beginning of the Great Depression, Mr. Hashimoto has adopted what some regard as a contractional fiscal policy in the face of a banking crisis and an overall economic slowdown.
And, as with Hoover's America, the downturn in Japan is not just a domestic problem; it is also slowing growth around the world. As the largest creditor nation, Japan is far and away the most important source of capital around the globe, and it helps feed America's enormous appetite for funds on a daily basis.
"The U.S. needs to borrow a billion dollars every day the markets open," said Kenneth S. Courtis, chief economist at Deutsche Bank Group Asia-Pacific. "And Japan is the principal supplier of that capital. If Japan gets knocked out of that equation, and instead of exporting capital it imports it, who could replace Japan? What would happen to the U.S. bond market? What would happen to Wall Street?"
One of Japan's biggest challenges is a vacuum of leadership. Mr. Hashimoto barely has command of parliament and his saving grace is only that the opposition is even more dispirited than he is. The Finance Ministry normally sets economic policy, without paying much attention to the Prime Minister, but lately the ministry has been under assault as well and is distracted by efforts to curb its power and break it up.
One of the most catastrophic missteps was the decision to emphasize fiscal austerity and raise the national sales tax this spring from 3 percent to 5 percent. The result was that the economy plunged at an annual rate of 11 percent in the second quarter, the worst figure in nearly 25 years, and economists are warning that Japan may now be on the brink of a recession.
It is not that no one warned Japan. Private economists there and the United States Government protested repeatedly that the tax increase would be more than the fragile economy could withstand.
 
A Mistaken Belief In Economy's Health
But Japanese officials were adamant, particularly those in the Ministry of Finance at the pinnacle of the nation's bureaucracy. They mistakenly believed that the economy was strong enough to tolerate the tax increase. Eisuke Sakakibara, a Vice Minister of Finance, as well as other officials, including Yasuo Matsushita, Governor of the Bank of Japan, repeatedly offered upbeat assessments of the economy that, in retrospect, could not have been further off the mark.
Mr. Sakakibara and Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka declined to be interviewed for this article. But the Government early this month formally acknowledged that the economy is not recovering after all, and that it is at a "standstill."
For now, Japan's most pressing problem is its banking crisis -- heightened by the risk of defaults in the coming weeks by South Korean banks. Japanese institutions have lent South Korea $24 billion, a monstrous sum that seems modest only when one compares it with the hundreds of billions of dollars in dubious loans within Japan.
"We're talking about the Asian financial crisis, but the biggest one is right here in Japan -- by far," said Richard Koo, an economist at Nomura Research Institute in Tokyo.
Japan's banks have been in trouble for seven years now, but they and the Government alike have yet to tackle the problem aggressively. Instead, the wounded banks have limped along, as Japanese officials played down the problems. But now some financial institutions have reached the end. One of Japan's 20 largest banks collapsed in November, and Yamaichi Securities, one of the "Big Four" securities firms, toppled a few days later.
What was particularly worrisome was not just that Yamaichi collapsed, but the way it fell. It kept insisting that it was solvent, and then after collapsing it turned out that it had an extra $2 billion in hidden losses. The Finance Ministry closely monitors the securities industry, and it either knew or did not know of these off-book losses; it is unclear which prospect is more alarming.
Even as the International Monetary Fund is urging Japan's neighbors to trim their growth, President Clinton has urged Japan to boost its economy from within. Such a policy could reduce the risk of a global financial meltdown and help the entire region emerge from its crisis.
This domestic boost could come in a couple of ways. Japan could try a fiscal stimulus, cutting taxes or raising Government spending, or it could deregulate the economy in hopes of generating an explosion of private spending. There is some evidence that concerted deregulation could set off a new Japanese boom.
 
Time May Be Right For Deregulation
In 1994, for example, Japan reluctantly agreed, under enormous American pressure, to deregulate its cellular telephone industry. A result was that the number of handsets increased more than 10-fold and cellular operators invested $13 billion in new systems. Moreover, Japan's engineers began to design more innovative telephones, including a Dick Tracy-like model built into a wristwatch.
Enthusiasts argue that if Japan could just muster the political will to address its bad-loan problems instead of letting them fester, if it could deregulate transportation, retailing, finance, agriculture, pharmaceuticals and other industries, one result would be a burst of energy that would revitalize Japan and stimulate all of Asia.
To be sure, Mr. Hashimoto has pledged to achieve far-reaching economic and governmental reforms or else "burn up in flames," and he is presiding over preparations for a "Big Bang" that would introduce greater competition into finance. But the pattern has been that far-reaching deregulation is proposed, debated, opposed by entrenched interests, and then emasculated by Mr. Hashimoto's colleagues in the ruling Liberal Democratic Party.
This has frustrated foreigners and Japanese alike.
"With Japanese politics, people will very often say they're going to do it, but it takes a long time before they reach a final conclusion," said Minoru Makihara, president of Mitsubishi Corporation. "However, I think time and speed is of the essence."
Prime Minister Hashimoto is reluctant to stimulate the economy the other way, by cutting taxes or increasing Government spending, because of a profound commitment to fiscal prudence and aversion to deficit spending. Mr. Hashimoto argues that deficit spending would be particularly irresponsible now because Japan's population is aging rapidly and will require enormous spending in the decades ahead.
 
A Declining Yen Might Hurt All Asia
The slowdown in Japan and the risk of a steeper recession are central to the current Asian economic crisis. Japan's position as the leading source of capital around the world means that if Japan's banks continue to falter, the pipeline of loans and investments could collapse. Nations in Asia need to export to Japan to boost their economies, but a depressed Japan is not in a position to buy those goods.
A continued fall in the yen could harm the competitiveness of products from elsewhere in Asia, creating a risk of competitive devaluations in the region. If Japan now allows the yen to fall further, so that its exports can compete against those from South Korea, then China and other countries might be tempted to follow, setting off a dizzying downward spiral.
A related risk is that Japan and others will try to export their way out of the crisis. But this strategy would produce a torrent of imports in the United States just as there are signs that the American consensus in favor of free trade may be eroding.
"I'm hopeful we will not have a repetition of the 1920's and 1930's, Smoot-Hawley and the beggar-thy-neighbor trade policies, but human beings are imperfect," said Michel Oksenberg, an Asia expert at Stanford University.
 
Failure by Tokyo To Take Larger Role
One of the central ironies is that Japan has long yearned for a larger role in Asia. So, this should be Japan's big moment, an occasion when it could win Asia's gratitude for rescuing the region from economic turmoil. But instead, Japan is too mired in its own problems to be of much help.
"Japanese people are worried about Asia, but they are more worried about Japan itself," said Yoshihide Soeya, a scholar of international relations at Keio University in Tokyo. "Instead of helping Asia out, Japan itself wants to be helped out."
Prime Minister Hashimoto himself recently expressed the nation's mood when he announced that Japan was "certainly not arrogant enough to think that we can take the role of locomotive for Asia."
One result is that Japan's role in the Asia crisis has been largely as banker and follower, taking the roles assigned by the United States Treasury Department. Japan put up $10 billion for the South Korean rescue package, twice as much as the United States, but the rescue was orchestrated from Washington.
"There's an increasing tendency to look to the U.S. and the I.M.F. as the savior, rather than to Japan," noted Muthiah Alagappa, a specialist on Southeast Asia at the East-West Center in Hawaii.
To be sure, Japan did try to take on an important role as organizer of a proposed "Asian Monetary Fund," intended to help bail out troubled Asian economies. Some countries welcomed that idea, but the United States squashed it out of concern that the fund would tread on the turf of the International Monetary Fund.
During the last couple of years, Japan has set what is generally regarded as a miserable example, allowing huge speculative bubbles and enormous bad loans to accumulate without anyone paying much attention.
Moreover, for nearly a decade into the mid-1990's, as the yen strengthened under the backing of officials in Washington and Tokyo, Japanese loans and investment poured into Asian countries, boosting local economies but also sending stock and property markets soaring. A result was that Japan's bubble floated across Asia.
Then back home, Japan's financial crisis led the Government to strike a deal with the United States to allow the yen to drop, and as a result the yen has lost about 60 percent of its value since its peak in 1995. As the yen dropped, Asian exports began losing out to cheaper Japanese products. Trade deficits yawned, and then this year the crisis hit when currencies tumbled and countries found it difficult to pay back foreign currency loans to Japanese and American banks.
The underlying lesson from Japan's missteps in handling its own economic crisis may be that markets have become too large and global to be managed by Japanese Government bureaucrats. For seven years, Japan's bureaucrats have been wrestling with market forces, trying to force them into submission, but the recent bankruptcies in Japan -- which the Finance Ministry could do little to prevent -- suggest that it is the bureaucrats who are now at the mercy of the market.
Some say that the bureaucrats may now learn the lesson and reluctantly bow to market forces, allowing Japan and the rest of Asia to boom again.
"This is the revolt of the market against Government," Takeshi Sasaki, a political scientist at Tokyo University, said of Asia's crisis. "It will be the only good historical opportunity to integrate politics and the market, to show politicians that they should not ignore the market."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Asia's Faltering Giant"
As currency and financial crises roil its smaller Asian neighbors, Japan and the shaky health of its economy loom ever larger in calculations of the region's chances of righting itself.
 
Measured in yen, the Japanese economy has been growing in fits and starts since early 1993, but viewed in dollar terms, the total value of Japan's output of goods and services has fallen by more than a fifth since the summer of 1995. Chart tracks gross domestic product, in dollars, quarterly at annual rate, adjusted for Japanese inflation, since 1989.
 
A group of indicators that are supposed to presage turns in the economy nine months to a year ahead, have been giving pessimis-tic readings all year. Thus, even without the recent turmoil in Asia, Japan could not expect robust growth in 1998. Chart tracks index of leading indicators, monthly, since 1989.
 
Japan remains a major net exporter of capital, meaning it is lending vast sums to other nations, mainly the United States. Some analysts worry that the cost of restor-ing Japan's banks to financial health may crimp future capital flows out of Japan. Chart tracks net capital outflows, balance of payments basis, average of latest 12 months, since 1989.

INTERNATIONAL A3-15
 
Clinton Warns Hussein On U.N. Inspectors
President Clinton, ruling out nothing, warned Saddam Hussein that he would consider other options for United States actions if the Iraqi president continued to obstruct United Nations inspectors, who have been barred from so-called Presidential sites in Iraq. A1
 
Mandela Critical of Whites
President Nelson Mandela of South Africa gave a robustly critical appraisal of his country's white population in a speech to delegates of the governing African National Congress party, who were gathered to choose a new party president to replace Mr. Mandela. A3 

Mass Graves in Afghanistan
A team of United Nations investigators, looking into reports that more than 2,000 Taliban prisoners were killed by rival factions in Afghanistan, said they found hundreds of bodies, including victims who had been thrown alive into wells near the northern town of Mazar-i-Sharif. A14
 
Concern Over Hong Kong Flu
Health authorities in Hong Kong charged with stopping the spread of an influenza virus that ran through Hong Kong's chickens and those brought in from elsewhere in China released case histories of the human victims -- at least nine so far, some of whom seemed to be linked. That posed once again the crucial public health question of whether the flu can be spread from human to human just as it seems to have been spread from chickens to humans. A6
 
Cold Spell Hits Moscow
Five people have died from the cold and 138 others have been hospitalized in Moscow, where temperatures have dropped to minus 26 degrees Fahrenheit. Still more were injured by falling icicles. Schools were closed and vodka sales were up. Russian winters helped defeat Napoleon and Hitler, but this year's cold spell threatens the estimated 300,000 homeless people in the city. A5
 
New Prime Minister for Czechs
The Governor of the Czech National Bank, Josef Tosovsky, was chosen as caretaker Prime Minister to replace Vaclav Klaus, who resigned over a campaign finance scandal. President Vaclav Havel described Mr. Tosovsky as a nonpartisan technocrat with the support of all three parties in the current center-right Government as well as of the opposition Social Democrats. A13
 
Aid Proposed for Bosnia Serbs
Officials in the Clinton Administration neared a decision on a $40 million aid package for the Serbian republic in Bosnia, the first American aid package to the group. It is opposed by some lawmakers, who contend that much of the aid will end up in communities that have harbored war-crimes suspects. The President also said he would announce his decision before the weekend on whether American troops ought to be deployed in Bosnia past June. A4
 
NATIONAL A18-29
 
Clinton Exempts Haitians From Deportation Rules
President Clinton is expected in the next several days to invoke a rarely used executive authority to exempt as many as 20,000 Haitians for at least a year from strict new deportation rules that would make it more difficult for most of them to stay here. A1
 
President Meets Press
President Clinton, during an extraordinary 94-minute press conference, made a passionate and detailed defense of affirmative action, arguing that not merit but differences in academic preparation and business contacts produce racial disparities in the United States. During the press conference, which ranged from the political prospects of Vice President Al Gore to the environmental woes of Los Angeles to the name of the President's new dog (Buddy), Mr. Clinton pointedly passed up an opportunity to express confidence in the F.B.I. Director, Louis Freeh. Mr. Freeh disagreed with Attorney General Janet Reno's decision not to seek an independent counsel to investigate Democratic fund-raising in the Presidential race. A1
 
Nichols Jury Begins Work
A jury began considering the fate of Terry L. Nichols, the second man charged with bombing the Federal Building in Oklahoma City. A18
 
Training Report Criticized
A panel's recommendation that the Army, Navy and Air Force separate men and women during much of their military training faced pointed criticism from some members of Congress and others who said it would undercut the role of women in the military. A26
 
Lion Hunting in Florida
Nala, a 400-pound female lion, escaped from Jungleland Wildlife Park in Kissimmee, Fla., but zoo and law enforcement officials said she was laid back, de-clawed, and posed little danger unless provoked. A18
 
Debris Danger for Shuttle
NASA needs to take the threat posed by space debris and meteoroids more seriously and move ahead with more steps to shield the space shuttles' critical systems, a National Research Council committee said. A22
 
NEW YORK B1-6
 
New York Has Largest Gap Between Rich and Poor
After years of Wall Street setting records while manufacturing jobs slipped away, the income gaps between the rich and poor, and between the rich and the middle class, are now larger in New York than in any other state. A1
 
The Wiz Facing Bankruptcy
The Wiz, the largest consumer electronics retailer in the New York region, said it had filed for protection from creditors under Federal bankruptcy laws, hurt by competition and sagging demand for electronics. B1
 
Pataki Backs Toll Plan
Gov. George E. Pataki gave qualified support for a plan to offer toll discounts for truck drivers who use bridges and tunnels in New York City during off-peak hours. B3
 
Paramount Globe Relighted
The great glass globe atop the Paramount Building in Times Square was turned on for the first time in decades and rooftop loudspeakers will chime "Give My Regards to Broadway" 15 minutes before curtain time at surrounding theaters. The dial of the tower clock will be illuminated, and the 19-foot sphere at its peak will take on a 24,000-watt glow. B3

BUSINESS DAY D1-22
 
Microsoft Facing Inquiries
Attorneys general from some of the nation's most populous states held a secret meeting last week to assess their strategy for a possible antitrust action targeting Microsoft's marketing practices. The joint meeting comes in addition to a Federal antitrust action, government investigations under way in Europe and Asia, a private antitrust suit and the specter of hearings in the Senate. A1
 
Mixed Signs in South Korea
The specter of widespread unemployment is hovering over South Korea, a country that has barely known joblessness since the last oil shock, and one in which workers take pride in their rise from the peasantry to the middle class in a single generation. But the financial crisis that has shaken Korea in the last several weeks also showed some signs of easing as Korea's currency and the stock market strengthened on prospects that the nation would avoid a default on its international debt. A1
 
Japanese Plan Delayed
Japan's governing party delayed the release of a long-awaited economic revival plan but details that leaked out showed it would cut corporate taxes to a postwar low and reduce property and securities taxes. D1
 
Chase Manhattan Reorganizes
Chase Manhattan, the nation's largest bank, announced a major management reorganization, setting up a horse race to determine its next chief executive and imposing a clearer command structure on a company that has been criticized for a lack of cohesion within its senior ranks. D1
 
Fed Leaves Rates Unchanged
The Federal Reserve voted to leave interest rates unchanged, acting after the latest Government reports on the economy showed inflation remains benign despite vigorous economic growth. D1

HEADLINE: Hopping Off Soon in Brooklyn: Tours by Double-Decker Bus

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
With guided tours and scheduled stops along Manhattan's major traffic routes, tour buses have become a popular way for tourists to visit the borough's many attractions, like the Empire State Building, the World Trade Center and Harlem churches.
And soon, double-decker tour buses may also be prowling the streets of Brooklyn, offering stops to enjoy the cheesecake at Junior's restaurant or the permanent collection of ancient Egyptian art in the Brooklyn Museum of Art. 
 New York Apple Tours, the largest double-decker sightseeing company in the city, said it plans to start running tour buses in the borough next year, if it gets the required approval.
"We're going to extend our Manhattan routes so our clients will have a chance to experience a real hidden treasure: the Borough of Brooklyn," said Michael Alvich, who is the vice president of sales and marketing at New York Apple Tours. "It's about time that people learn about Brooklyn."
Mr. Alvich said the route is an extension of the two-day full city tour, which currently costs $30. He said that although the route has not been finally determined and the starting date has yet to be set, the company plans to begin the service at the soon-to-be-completed Marriott Hotel in downtown Brooklyn.
He said the route would include 13 stops and cover major commercial and tourist attractions, like the Metrotech Center, Junior's restaurant, the Middle Eastern stores on Atlantic Avenue, and places like the Brooklyn Museum of Art, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and the Brooklyn Children's Museum in Crown Heights.
In recent years, the number of buses have drawn criticism in some Manhattan neighborhoods, where residents say they add to congestion on small streets and spout exhaust fumes. But so far, there has been little opposition in Brooklyn, where officials have been trying to get in on the city's tourism boom.
"I have fought for more than 20 years to have Brooklyn included as a major tourism destination," Howard Golden, the Brooklyn Borough President, said. "I'm pleased that New York Apple Tours has taken an interest in the borough."
Kenneth Adams, president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, said that the hop-on, hop-off concept was particularly appealing, because it would enable visitors to spend more time in the Brooklyn neighborhoods along the route. He said this would have a ripple effect on the local economy.
"Instead of touring Brooklyn through tinted windows on a moving bus," he said, "this plan will allow them to visit the local shops and spend their money in the borough."
Mr. Alvich said the idea came from Mitchell Heymann, the director of sales and marketing for the New York Marriott Brooklyn. The 374-room hotel will open sometime in the spring. Mr. Heymann said he approached New York Apple Tours because of its tourist-friendly concept.
"Our goal is not only to bring in business clients but also to sell Brooklyn as a tourist destination," Mr. Heymann said.
But not all of Brooklyn's landmark attractions will be included. Coney Island -- with its aquarium, the 85-foot, 76-year-old Cyclone roller coaster and Nathan's hot dog stand -- is notably missing from the plan. Savy Grant, a vice president at New York Apple Tours, said additional sites would be added as demand for them increases.
Ms. Grant said the plan still has to be approved by the City Department of Transportation.

HEADLINE: Panel Seeks to Simplify Grand Jury Duty Vagaries

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
Having improved the lot of New Yorkers called for jury service, court administrators announced this week that they would now train their gaze on a far more miserable civic responsibility -- grand jury duty.
Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye has directed a panel to report by next March on ways to overhaul a system that is inconsistently operated throughout the state and out of step with much of the country. 
 Unlike conventional jury service, where people are screened to sit on a single trial, grand jurors hear evidence for dozens of felonies and vote on whether cases should be indicted. Around the state, the average length of service for a trial jury, formally known as a petit jury, is 3 days; grand jurors typically serve 11 days and service can be as long as 28 days.
In some counties, grand jurors may meet for a full day a week over three months, while in others, they may gather several mornings or afternoons a week. Although the length of service for petit jurors has shrunk in the last few years because of improvements in the system, grand jury service has not changed.
Only 25,000 New Yorkers serve each year as grand jurors, compared with 500,000 who show up for regular jury duty. But grand jury fees account for nearly 20 percent of all juror costs. Stephen Kaufman, a prominent defense lawyer who is chairman of the panel of defense lawyers, prosecutors and judges, said that evaluating efficiency would be a high priority.
"One grand jury was called for July 5 and there were no cases for it," he said. "Other times, jurors can't deliberate because a quorum hasn't shown up." In New York, 23 people are convened for a grand jury and at least 16 have to be present for deliberations and a vote.
According to the State Constitution, the prosecution of a felony must be sanctioned through an indictment by a grand jury, whose institutional purpose is to protect innocent citizens from unjust prosecutions. But two-thirds of the states around the country have eliminated the need for most grand juries out of concern for juror fees, the inconvenience to the jurors themselves and the difficulty in assembling witnesses. Instead, they have adopted simpler methods to screen cases at an early stage.
Robert G. M. Keating, a former judge who is vice chairman of the project, said that the Grand Jury Project would study those alternatives. California uses a preliminary hearing at which evidence is presented before a judge in open court.
This project's predecessor, the 1993 Jury Project, produced recommendations that led to a wholesale revamping of the state's jury system by legislators and court officials. Automatic exemptions for 20 occupations have been eliminated and sources for jurors have been expanded to include not only those once exempted professionals but people on unemployment and welfare rolls. That means people are called less frequently and serve shorter terms.
Their lives as jurors have improved as well. Furniture in jury rooms has been upgraded. And the selection of civil juries, once ruled by lawyers, is now overseen by judges, quickening the pace considerably.
The Grand Jury Project is expected to go about its business in a fashion similar to that of its forebear. Questionnaires will be handed out to grand jurors and public hearings will be convened. And those inspired to comment will be encouraged to call 1-800-NYJUROR.

HEADLINE: Citta di Castello;
White Truffles Are to Die For, but Not Like This

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: CITTA DI CASTELLO, Italy, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Two more truffle-hunting dogs died of poisoning in the wooded hills of northern Umbria on the day that Fabio Petruzzi, out hunting woodcock, almost lost his Lolla.
A spirited 3-year-old English setter, she too had wolfed down some raw meat laced with strychnine, took a few wobbly steps and collapsed to the ground. Mr. Petruzzi was able to carry her a half-mile to his car, and get her in time to Dr. Luigi Bigi, the local veterinarian, to save her life. 
 The other two dogs -- which belonged to a weekend truffle hunter from nearby Perugia -- were not so lucky, and on Dec. 6, became the latest victims in a sinister wave of dog killings that has swept these truffle-rich hills.
No one can say exactly how many dogs have been killed this season but Dr. Bigi -- who has become the local expert on death by strychnine, and metaldeide, a pesticide -- says he has seen 20 to 25 dead or dying dogs, more than twice the number he saw last year during the white-truffle season, which lasts from mid-October to Dec. 31.
"Everyone is afraid for their dogs," Dr. Bigi said. "And there is a lot of anger. Whether you talk to truffle hunters or hunters, everyone is angry. And if they ever catch the guy who's doing this, they will never turn him in -- they'll lynch him. One man whose dog died frightened me: he said he would take care of it himself. So who's to say that he won't go out and put out his own poisoned meatballs?"
There was a time when the pursuit of the white truffle, the popular name for Tuber Magantum pico, prized for its musky, pungent taste, was not such a deadly business. Truffle hunters would scour the woods of the upper Tiber Valley with their dogs, mixed-breeds specially trained to sniff out the misshapen fungi that grow wild among tree roots, and casually sell their finds by the fistful, without even weighing them.
But since the 1980's, the price of white truffles -- found only here and a few other parts of Italy -- has skyrocketed, as middlemen rushed into the market to supply restaurants from Tokyo to New York. This season, after a dry summer that reduced supply, the price jumped again -- some say by 30 percent, and with retail prices locally now at $1,300 a kilo (2.2 pounds), the competition for truffles, already fierce, became even more murderous.
"It is a mathematical question," said Pierluigi Manfroni, owner of a local restaurant called Bersaglio who buys truffles for his house specialities directly from local trufflers. "Truffles are profitable to those who find them, and in the last 15 years, the value has increased incredibly. That is the cause of the rivalry between them. There is no other explanation."
Truffle hunting is a secretive business -- Mr. Manfroni talks of the "omerta of the truffle," borrowing the Sicilian Mafia's term for their deadly bond of silence. "For generations, hunters have known where the truffles can be found," he said. "A truffle hunter doesn't want 10 other hunters in his area."
Not everyone can go truffling: to qualify for a Government license, trufflers must pay $130 a year, and pass an exam that entitles them to hunt year around. The white truffle is the most precious, but there are other varieties, each with its own season -- the "bianchetto," the "scorsone" and then the ordinary black truffle. Of the 7,000 licensed trufflers in all of Italy, 1,832 are here in the upper Tiber Valley, and that, according to some veterans, is too many.
"It used to be that truffle hunting was a matter of time, and passion," said Paolo Puletti, a local journalist who was the first to uncover the trail of the poisoned dogs. "Now it is all economics. People give up their holidays to go truffle hunting: you can earn $12,000 in a good season, equal to an annual salary."
After the rush of international publicity that has followed the spate of dog-poisonings, truffle hunters have become defensive about the implication that the dog-slayer is one of their own, and some are now pointing the finger elsewhere, at local game hunters among others.
"I don't exclude that truffle hunters could be doing this, but it does seem to coincide with the hunting season," said Alessandro Ghigi, president of the local truffle hunters' association.
Vincenzo Bucci, head of the regional forestry preserve, tries to take a balanced position, mindful that the poison set out for dogs could spread to relations among their owners. "We have to isolate these incidents, but not stress the divisions within the community," he said. "It could be someone who has gone crazy -- it could be shepherds trying to eliminate stray dogs, it could be conflicts between hunters and farmers, or it could be control of territory on the part of the trufflers."
Local truffle hunters say they have detected a pattern in the distribution of the poisoned meat patties. "Truffles don't grow everywhere, it is always the same places," said Angelino Marioli, a veteran truffle hunter who spends five or six hours a day in the woods with his dogs. "There are a lot of secret places that people don't talk about, but everyone goes to the best-known places -- which is where all the dogs have died."
To dedicated trufflers, nothing is more precious than their dogs, which they spend four or five years training to seek out a smell that uninitiated hounds, and foxes, naturally turn up their noses at. A good dog can cost $1,300 to $4,000, but the emotional attachment counts even more.
"For me, my dogs are like members of my family," said Sebastiano Adriano, a barber and part-time truffler who lost a dog to poison during last year's truffle season.
"If I knew who was doing it, I wouldn't be here: I'd be in jail, because I would have killed him," he said. "I could understand it if when I took someone else's truffle, they took it out on me. But not my dog."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Umbria, the white truffle region of Italy, the delicacy carries an exorbitant price tag, and now someone is poisoning the dogs that sniff out the fungi in the ground. Italo Bianchini, above, with his dogs, Dick and Leda. (Stefano Amantini)
 
Map of Italy showing location of Citta di Castello: The scramble for white truffles is fierce near Citta di Castello.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Mahathir's Wrath

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN; Bob Herbert is on vacation.

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia

 BODY:
There are many ways to depict Malaysia's economic crisis. My preference would be to stage it as an Off Broadway play. It would be called "King Lear Meets the Hedge Funds."
King Lear, of course, could only properly be played by Malaysia's Prime Minister, Dr. Mohamed Mahathir. Dr. Mahathir has made a career of tweaking the West and America, lecturing them about everything from the superiority of the Asian model to the blatant unfairness of how the great powers have carved up Antarctica. Along the way, Dr. Mahathir has also overseen Malaysia's economic boom, and made his country a model of multi-ethnic harmony and a beacon for how the Muslim world can embrace modernization. 
 But after the Asian market crash spread to Malaysia, Dr. Mahathir went into one of his anti-colonial nationalist rants. He accused the Jews, George Soros and the hedge funds of deliberately wrecking Malaysia's economy. "Jews are not happy to see Muslims prosper," he said.
Global money managers did not take kindly to such talk. They are not like Dr. Mahathir's usual targets of tweaking. They aren't the U.N. or the State Department or the Nonaligned Movement. They don't tell you that you have a point, or that they feel your pain, or that they understand your grievance because of your colonial experience. They listen to what you mean, not what you say, and what Dr. Mahathir's words meant to them was that he was more interested in looking for scapegoats than at the real problems. So the foreign banks and funds, already spooked by Asia's currency crisis, lost even more confidence in Malaysia and began dumping its currency and stocks, sending both to record lows.
But King Lear kept on lecturing. When his Finance Minister announced plans to halt some major showpiece projects, to signal austerity, King Lear said the projects were still on, and he condemned foreign investors for being too greedy. "Will the Milkens and Boeskys and Soroses of the future be any more considerate than the present models?" he said, referring to the financiers Michael Milken, Ivan Boesky and George Soros -- all Jews, none of whom triggered Malaysia's plight.
It's true that Malaysia's fundamentals were not that bad: low inflation, a budget surplus, a well-run central bank and Finance Ministry, high domestic savings, strong export industries. Its weakness was large debts run up by the private sector that produced a real estate bubble. But Dr. Mahathir's tirade turned a small crisis of confidence in Malaysia into a big crisis of confidence. Said one official, "He's Malaysia's I.B.M. -- International Big Mouth."
Veiled criticism has started to appear even in Malaysia's controlled press, and this seems to have prompted Dr. Mahathir to take a vow of silence, for the moment. One commentator, A. Nazri Abdullah, wrote: "Foreign investors recognize Malaysian fundamentals are strong, but they are confused by conflicting statements from our top leaders. If we have the desire to speak out, we need to moderate that desire. . . . There is no point in cheering loudest if your village is then mortgaged. We only have rifles without bullets, so why shoot hot air?"
The sad part is that "Dr. Mahathir has a point -- he just has the wrong target," argued the Harvard economist Jeffrey Sachs. "He's right that there is something wrong if for a decade the market tells your country that it's an economic miracle, and then, with no warning, engages in waves of panic selling that cuts off all your access to short-term credit and causes your currency and stock markets to crash." And he's right that if Malaysia's businesses borrowed too much from Western bankers, that may have been reckless of the Malaysians, but it was equally reckless of the bankers. "For every reckless borrower, there is a reckless lender," said Mr. Sachs.
In short, Dr. Mahathir is right that a system that can be spooked so easily, that can sour on the fundamentals of Southeast Asia so quickly and can overlook its own banking weaknesses so cavalierly, is troubling. But by crudely and stupidly explaining this as a Jewish plot, Dr. Mahathir, the Asian leader who could have most effectively led a discussion about how to reform this system, has discredited himself, hurt his country and only further muddied an already muddled situation.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Lower On Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities traded lower yesterday, pushing the yield on the long bond back up to 6 percent.
Although there were no Government reports, bonds followed the United States dollar down after Japan unexpectedly announced a plan to cut income taxes and the Bank of Japan became a seller of dollars. Investors become jittery when the dollar declines because a strong dollar makes United States Government securities much more attractive to foreign investors, who benefit from potential gains in currency translation as well as generally higher rates. 
 The 30-year bond fell 17/32, to 101 25/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, was up to 5.996 percent, which when rounded off is 6 percent. This is up from 5.96 percent on Tuesday.
Traders said the news of Japan's intention to cut taxes and revive its economy took its toll on the United States bond market because many thought it might end the buying of Treasuries by investors seeking a safe haven from the Asian turmoil. In just over a month and a half bond yields have dropped more than 40 basis points as a result of those Asian troubles. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.)
The Treasury yesterday also announced that it plans to sell $26 billion of two-year and five-year notes next week. The $15 billion in two-year notes will be sold on Monday along with $14.5 billion in three-month and six-month bills normally sold on Monday. On Tuesday the Treasury will sell $11 billion of five-year notes. The note auctions are a day early because next week will be shortened by the Christmas holiday and the start of a long weekend by many.
In when-issued trading, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.67 percent and the five-year at a price to yield 5.74 percent. The possibility of fewer buyers of Treasury securities if the Asia turmoil subsides causes Treasury prices to drop.
Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc., does not think the proposed tax cut in Japan is large enough to stimulate the ailing Japanese economy and thereby keep United States yields low.
Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Securities, believes the lower dollar represents a buying opportunity, saying, "The Bank of Japan foreign exchange intervention, rumored to be $4 billion, has also weighed on the U.S. dollar."
Ms. Cooper said the relief package might keep the Japanese economy from slumping lower, but the gap between United States and Japanese gross domestic product growth should remain wide enough to keep the dollar strong. "With the Bank of Japan on hold for the foreseeable future, short-term interest rate spreads of over 500 basis points between the U.S. and Japanese securities will continue to keep capital flowing to the U.S.," she said. "The U.S. bond market's fundamentals remain strong, especially with Treasury supply dwindling and inflation subdued. While hiccups are bound to occur, decisive moves above 6 percent on the long bond provide attractive buying opportunities."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
South Korea Delays Plans To Inject Money Into Banks

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The Government postponed plans today to inject money into six of South Korea's biggest banks, meeting a demand of the International Monetary Fund one day before the agency was to decide whether to release the second installment of a $57 billion rescue package.
Seoul has promised to let ailing financial institutions fail or be taken over as a condition for receiving loans arranged by the I.M.F. The nation is counting on the next installment of the rescue package signed Dec. 3 to help pay billions of dollars in foreign debt due by the end of the year. 
 The Government had planned on injecting as much as $1.3 billion of capital into the Korea Development Bank, the Industrial Bank of Korea, Cho Hung Bank, Hanil Bank, the Commercial Bank of Korea and Korea Exchange Bank -- the largest borrowers of overseas capital. But in a step viewed as meeting an important I.M.F. condition, that plan was delayed.
"We think these six banks still have the ability to raise more funds overseas if the Government assists them in a proper way," said Choi Joong Kyung, a financial policy director at the Ministry of Finance and Economy.
The I.M.F. has said it wants bondholders and shareholders to feel the pain of poor lending decisions made by South Korean banks before they are offered more capital.
The Government was still proceeding with plans today to provide emergency financing for brokerage firms, which like many banks are swamped in debt. Two of South Korea's 34 brokerage firms failed this month after banks quit lending to them.
It was unclear whether that commitment would be viewed as inconsistent with South Korea's pledges to the I.M.F.
The lending agency was scheduled to meet in Washington on Thursday to decide whether to release the next installment of the South Korea loan package, worth $3.6 billion.
Optimism that the worst of the South Korean crisis may have passed helped its stock market rise 3.5 percent today, the fourth straight increase. But its currency, the won, fell 4 percent, narrowing strong gains made the previous two days.

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall as Lower Earnings Are Expected

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Wall Street quickly brushed aside a rally in Asia yesterday, as news of unexpected fourth-quarter earnings shortfalls pushed most major stock market indexes lower for the first time this week.
The fact that stocks did not respond to positive news from Asia indicates that earnings worries might become a bigger factor in investor decisions in the near term. The recent rise of the dollar and the slower growth expected in Asia are leading many analysts to trim their earnings expectations for 1998. 
 A stronger dollar reduces foreign earnings when they are translated back into dollars. The stronger currency also makes American exports less competitive abroad, cutting sales.
The Asian rally was fueled by news that the Japanese Prime Minister, Ruytaro Hashimoto, unexpectedly called for more than $15 billion in income tax cuts in an effort to stimulate the nation's economy. That move pushed the country's benchmark stock index, the Nikkei 225, up 3.5 percent. Stock markets in Hong Kong, Malaysia, South Korea and Taiwan were also higher.
And in the United States, the American depository receipts of several Japanese companies, including Ito-Yokado, Canon, Matsuhita Electric, Misui, Sony, TDK Corporation finished higher.
Initially, American investors reacted favorably to the news. In early trading, the Dow Jones industrial average rose more than 57 points. But news from the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company that fourth-quarter earnings will be more than 10 percent below the company's current estimates overwhelmed the market and spurred a round of selling that sent the Dow Jones industrial average down 18.90 points, to 7,957.41.
Minnesota Mining, or 3M, which fell 9 points, to 84 7/8, also helped lead the Standard & Poor's 500-company stock index down 2.50 points, to 965.54. 3M was the S.& P. 500's second- largest decliner behind Microsoft, which fell 3 7/16, to 135 5/8.
Meanwhile, the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index slipped for the second time this week, and closed at 1,547.37, down 5.63 points.
A diversified manufacturing company whose products include Scotch tape and Post-it notes, 3M was expected to earn $1.01 a share, up from 90 cents last year, according to analysts' forecasts. But currency declines in Asia, Brazil and Japan are expected to trim fourth-quarter profit by 10 percent, the company said, when those revenue are translated back into a much stronger dollar. Last year, 15 percent of sales and 25 percent of earnings were derived from Asia, analysts said.
Several analysts said that 1998 earnings could also be affected. The company earned $1.05 in the third quarter and $3.63 in 1996.
While 3M's announcement was largely viewed as a sign that other companies with exposure to overseas markets could see earnings shortfalls, its problems extend beyond its exposure to foreign markets, said Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney. "The surprise was the margins in the U.S. business," Mr. Acuff said.
"Profit margins seem to be under pressure from slower growth in the U.S. and higher expenses."
According to a Salomon Smith Barney analyst, Jonathan Rosenzweig, the United States shortfall is due to softness in sectors, including tapes, electrical products, automotive and roofing products.
And although the United States economy is expected to continue to grow in 1998, growth will be slower. As a result, "the margin squeeze will be visible for more companies," Mr. Acuff warned. "That's the irony. On the surface, it looks great, but there's not as much strength as the economy would suggest."
Another warning sign of slower-than-expected growth in 1998 is a larger than expected number of negative earnings pre-announcements for the fourth quarter of this year, said Charles L. Hill, director of research at the First Call Corporation. So far, 288 companies have issued comments about fourth-quarter earnings and 51 percent were negative, Mr. Hill said.
Those announcements and concerns about the impact of Asia's financial crisis have also caused analysts to lower fourth-quarter earnings estimates. In the last four weeks, analysts' revisions have lowered the fourth quarter growth rate for S.& P. 500 companies to 8.8 percent from 12.2 percent. Meanwhile, analysts are forecasting about 17.2 percent growth for the S.& P. 500 in the first quarter of 1998.
"This is certainly more than we normally get," Mr. Hill said of the fourth-quarter revisions. As a result, "it's unrealistic to expect that earnings will be up 17.2 percent if they're only up 8.8 percent in the fourth quarter," he cautioned.

HEADLINE: On the Road to Monterrey;
Success of Mexican Bus Companies Eludes Greyhound

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: SAN MIGUEL DE ALEMAN, Mexico

 BODY:
In the borderland battle of the bus lines, Omar Rendon is the quarry. At 2:30 A.M. on a recent Saturday, he sat on a stoop at a border station here in the Rio Grande Valley, his Igloo cooler by his side as he stoically recounted his nearly weekly migration.
Most Friday nights, Mr. Rendon, who installs insulation at chemical plants in Houston, makes the 9- or 10-hour overnight bus trip to Mexico to see his wife and children in Monterrey, and most Sunday nights returns north. "We want to avoid the drugs and the crime" in the United States, he explained, as the customs inspector taped seals across the luggage compartments of the Adame Tours bus he was about to reboard. "I brought them up to live with me a few years ago, but the neighbors weren't even friendly. We didn't feel safe enough to go for a walk at night. My wife didn't like it at all." 
 So many others want to work in the United States but live in Mexico that the demand for bus seats across the border has reached an estimated four million annually, growing by about 20 percent a year. No American bus line, though, has permission to cross the Texas border and offer direct service to the Mexican interior. The North American Free Trade Agreement ostensibly opened the border to bus traffic last year, but a diplomatic snarl has officially kept it closed.
But while lawyers and diplomats haggle in distant capitals, resourceful immigrants have built bus lines like Adame. Beginning with a few battered vans about two decades ago, they persuaded American authorities to let them stay in business while they grew. Mexican officials, they say, usually let their buses pass -- in return for payments that have become as much a cost of business as gasoline or tires.
Greyhound Lines Inc., now the only coast-to-coast bus system, has thus had to stand by as far smaller competitors came to dominate a promising market. Greyhound, too large and visible to get away with making the payoffs needed to go south, and too clumsy to find other solutions, has been left begging for a deal with Mexico -- or at least tougher enforcement of the laws on both sides of the border.
Having only recently halted a loss of passengers, Greyhound considers a bid for the Hispanic travel market in general -- and cross-border traffic in particular -- so crucial that its chief executive, Craig R. Lentzsch, led his board on a tour of Houston's Hispanic bus stations on Dec. 8. Greyhound is also in partnership talks with the owners of Turismos Rapidos, one of the largest American bus lines serving Hispanic people. In frank imitation, Greyhound is even setting up a Spanish-speaking version of itself, called S.I.T.A. Inc.
A lot is at stake. Frequent, low-cost transportation, often on buses more comfortable than Greyhound's, allows more Mexicans to live and work on opposite sides of the border.
In coming to the United States, Mexicans have brought their bus service with them. With a population only a third as large as America's, Mexicans take 10 times as many bus trips, or more than 250 million trips a year longer than 100 miles.
Forget the stereotypes of rattling Mexican buses with pigs and chickens snuffling and squawking in the aisles. If United States buses are largely for the poor and humble, Mexico's plush, modern buses have become the prime means of long-distance travel. "The Mexican system is moving north," said Earl Shorris, author of "Latinos: A Biography of the People" (W. W. Norton, 1992). "We're importing Mexican cultural values."
The Tex-Mex bus lines are so significant for the Hispanic community that the Commerce Department has given Houston a $75,000 grant to study their potential for furthering economic development.
Houston's old Magnolia neighborhood, a barrio east of downtown, has become the Mexican gateway not only for Texas but also for all the Eastern and Central United States. Hispanic bus and van lines feed passengers from as far away as Chicago, Miami and New York to destinations as distant as Mexico City and Oaxaca, but to Monterrey most of all. The scrap-metal dealers and taco stands along Harrisburg Boulevard are giving way to bus stations, with three of the largest on the corners opposite the Houston Metro bus station. With more than 100 daily departures, the Hispanic bus lines handle more than half as much traffic as the Greyhound station downtown.
Friday nights are busiest. By 7 P.M., the crowds at Adame spill out of the cramped waiting room onto wooden benches outside. A ticket to Monterrey costs only $38, or $60 round trip, for a journey longer than that from Boston to Washington.
At the counter, ticket agents and company officials jostle and untangle the cords to four constantly ringing phones. They tell callers that three, maybe four buses will leave at 8:30 or later, but everyone knows that the first bus usually pulls out closer to 7:30.
Most passengers on a recent Friday were men. Though Mr. Rendon's brother, Beto, goes home as often as he does, most go down about five or six times a year and stay longer.
The first bus had a full load -- 47 passengers, mostly members of a weary but upbeat emerging middle class. With curtained windows and cushioned reserved seats that tilted far back, the nearly new Dina Marcopolo G1000 bus had Mexican films on video monitors every few rows until nearly midnight, then Mexican and Tejano music the rest of the way. There had been coffee and pastries back at the terminal, and on board was a cooler of free soft drinks.
More than half the passengers own cars, Adame's managers say. But only on the bus can travelers get enough sleep to allow a weekend visit. Snapping his flip phone shut after saying goodbye to his wife, Rodrigo Gonzalez, who operates construction machinery, said he visits his parents in Monterrey by himself a few times a year. "The bus is very comfortable, and it costs me less than gas," he said.
When Mr. Lentzsch looked around Harrisburg Boulevard a few hours before the board was expected, he learned more than he had anticipated. Spotting an old Greyhound bus, with only the dog logos removed, at Autobuses Monterrey across the street from Adame, Mr. Lentzsch strode onto the cracked, weed-grown lot for a closer look.
Soon, Walter Price, the operations manager, came over to explain that Autobuses Monterrey had bought four used Greyhound buses. But even with permits to operate in Mexico, which two of the buses already had, crossing the border still required cash. "Mordida," he said, rubbing the fingertips on his right hand together. An Autobuses Monterrey executive said that $50 usually went to Mexican immigration officers, $50 for customs, and $20 more at a second customs checkpoint down the road.
"I've been trying to get those prices for a long time," Mr. Lentzsch said as he walked away. "But what am I going to do? Hand my drivers 100 bucks in cash?"
He grants that Greyhound would be far stronger along the border but for its own faults -- labor strife, management turmoil, a bankruptcy filing and another near-collapse (under previous management, Mr. Lentzsch was quick to point out). In 1990, after Greyhound was hit by a strike, the Houston companies began buying their first buses, however dilapidated.
Esteban Adame may have been the first to carry fellow immigrants back to Monterrey, beginning with a used station wagon in 1977, then graduating to vans. This was frontier capitalism: seldom did the early van owners steer through the maze of permits and licenses they theoretically needed, Federal officials say, although Mr. Adame says he abided by the laws.
Mr. Adame built his van fleet to 15, then, in 1991, bought two 13-year-old buses. A few years later, as interest rates fell and creditors saw that the Tex-Mex bus lines were sound risks, the companies graduated to new models. In 1994, Mr. Adame began buying new buses and now has about 30 and plans to add 20 more next year. In Mexico, he has charter and temporary authority, having formed a Mexican company, El Faisan, to help secure permanent rights.
The van operators that survive are being squeezed by the bus lines. Several blocks from Harrisburg Boulevard, Juan Hernandez has a shack for an office, a cement porch with old van seats for a waiting room. Even for $30 to Monterrey, he has fewer and fewer takers, but stays afloat by carrying packages often filled with merchandise that Mexicans believe is best bought in the United States.
"How much?" asked one Friday night customer, presenting a box with several large coffee cans and bottles of liquid detergent.
Mr. Hernandez counted, pondered, then struck a deal at $15. "I won't keep more than $5," Mr. Hernandez added in an aside, noting the tips needed to get the goods across the border.
While Mexican and American bus companies can already drop passengers just across the border, in California Greyhound joined with a Mexican partner to begin service to the Mexican interior in January. In Texas, though, Greyhound has yet to find a partner.
The Hispanic bus lines' Mexican routes are part of a national network. Adame's buses run from as far away as Atlanta and the Carolinas through Houston on the way to Mexico. New York is linked to the Hispanic network by La Cubana, with daily trips from Broadway and 174th Street in Manhattan to Miami, where the bus line is based, and twice weekly to Atlanta. At these destinations passengers can connect to a Tex-Mex line, El Expreso.
Mr. Adame, confirming the Autobuses Monterrey account of what it costs to cross the border, nodded as an aide reported higher demands before Christmas. Alfonso Euarro, the manager of bus service permits in the Monterrey region, said he had not heard of any such payments.
Greyhound complains that American regulators are selective in their safety enforcement, but regulators disagree. "If you've got 2,000 vehicles out there, you're much more likely to be subject to inspection than if you have one bus," said Nat Jackson, the Federal Highway Administration's chief of bus line regulation for the Southwest. He has given some bus and van lines a few months to shape up and operate safely, but notes that through May this year, more than 19 van lines going between Houston or Dallas and Mexico were fined a total of $33,000.
Adame, fully licensed in the United States, sometimes switches to El Faisan buses at the border, but on a recent Friday night took its own bus straight through, arriving in Monterrey shortly before 5 A.M.
Competition? Mr. Adame notes that Greyhound's past efforts to set up a Hispanic unit have posed no threat. "Greyhound said, 'You are just small ants,' " he recalled with a chuckle.
For even as Adame, Turismos Rapidos and the like have become assimilated in the American legal and economic system, they let their passengers continue living in two worlds.

HEADLINE: Airline Wins Suit on Weight Limits of Attendants

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
New York's highest court ruled yesterday that Delta Air Lines did not violate state law when it refused to hire job applicants who exceeded the company's weight limitations for flight attendants, and said it did not discriminate against the applicants by asking their age and marital status.
But paradoxically, the court suggested that the applicants were not sufficiently overweight to be considered disabled, which would have allowed them legal protections against discrimination. 
 The case stems from Delta's refusal to hire nine job applicants in 1990, on the ground that they were overweight. The applicants -- former flight attendants for Pan American World Airways, each with at least 14 years of experience -- had claimed the company discriminated on the basis of a "perceived disability."
In its unanimous decision yesterday, the seven-member State Court of Appeals ruled that there was no discrimination against the applicants on the basis of their weight because they did not suffer from "gross obesity."
"We are satisfied that weight, in and of itself, does not constitute a disability for discrimination qualification purposes," Judge Joseph W. Bellacosa's ruling said.
According to their lawyer, James Strauss, the job applicants were 2 to 10 pounds over the company's weight limits. "If they were clinically obese," Mr. Strauss said yesterday, "they would have had a better shot."
The plaintiffs had also charged the company with violating state law by maintaining different weight standards for men and women. According to court papers, the company set a maximum weight of 153 pounds for a 45-year-old woman who was 5 feet, 6 inches tall. The maximum weight for a man of the same age and height was 157 pounds.
But the court ruled that the company had used separate weight standards "based on real physiological differences."
Yesterday, a Delta spokesman, Todd Clay, refused to comment on whether the company still maintains weight standards.
But a spokeswoman for the Association of Flight Attendants, the union that represents 42,000 flight attendants but does not represent Delta's, said most airlines had dropped weight requirements in recent years.
"The main question is, can a flight attendant perform their safety duties?" the spokeswoman, Jane Goodman, said. "That's what they are there to do. They are not there to be Barbie dolls."
The nine plaintiffs in the case were among thousands of Pan Am flight attendants left unemployed when the airline declared bankruptcy in 1990. At the time, Delta bought most of Pan Am's assets and hired about 1,800 of Pan Am's 2,600 flight attendants.
The plaintiffs had also charged that Delta violated their rights by asking about their age, marital status and disabilities. State human rights law prohibits employers from asking such questions, according to a spokeswoman for the human rights division, Barbara Klar.
But yesterday, in upholding an earlier ruling by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, the Court of Appeals ruled that there was no proof that those questions had led to the company's decision not to hire the applicants.
Mr. Strauss, the plaintiffs' lawyer, said he feared the ruling would give license to employers to ask invasive questions. "It really erodes the protections afforded by human rights law," Mr. Strauss said.
Mr. Clay, the Delta spokesman, refused to comment on whether the company continues to make such inquiries in screening job applicants.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1392 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Is Japan's Rare, Bold Surprise Sufficient to Revive Economy?

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, facing criticism for sticking to a strategy of fiscal austerity while Japan's economy stands on the brink of recession, stunned his critics today with a surprise package of tax cuts and public spending.
But even as he won praise for changing course, questions quickly arose as to whether his measures were bold enough. 
 The package includes two trillion yen in income tax cuts -- $15.75 billion at current exchange rates, roughly the same amount in spending for public works, and 840 billion yen, or $6.6 billion, in tax cuts for corporations, land owners and investors. In all, the Prime Minister has proposed a stimulus package worth around $38 billion.
It was cobbled together in less than 24 hours, after the Japanese stock market failed to react to leaked reports of a much less ambitious economic plan that would have included just reductions in corporate, land and securities-transaction taxes.
Not all of Mr. Hashimoto's critics, or financial analysts, were mollified by the new package, which includes only about $300 in cuts a year for each Japanese family, and may not be immediately translated into a sufficient stimulus to prime the stalled economy. "It was a necessary step, but it's pretty clear Mr. Hashimoto was dragged to it kicking and screaming," said Alexander Kinmont of Morgan Stanley Japan.
The announcement took bureaucrats here by surprise. Mr. Hashimoto returned to Tokyo late Tuesday evening after a meeting with Asian leaders in Malaysia and began waking colleagues with phone calls to brief them on his plans.
Early today, though, the Finance Ministry seemed to scramble as the announcement was made. "I knew about it at 10:30 this morning -- same as you," said Eisuke Sakakibara, the influential vice minister for international affairs. "We are just petty bureaucrats," he said tonight, perhaps only half in jest.
Still, he called the leadership the Prime Minister demonstrated "brilliant," perhaps an indication that his ministry had, after all, been involved in the new plan's preparation.
Bureaucrats from the Finance Ministry polled economists and journalists on Tuesday to get an idea of how certain proposals might be received. That may have led to the additional two trillion yen in public works spending tacked on late this afternoon, apparently in response to analysts' assessments that even a sizable income tax cut, combined with the lowest corporate tax rates since World War II, was not enough to push the economy into a recovery.
Mr. Sakakibara suggested that the package would increase Japan's gross domestic product by at least 1 percent, given that tax cuts usually have an effect beyond their monetary value.
Private economists were less rosy. They estimated that more than half of the income tax cut would find its way into savings accounts, not store cash registers. In 1994, when the Government cut taxes, the savings rate jumped 14 percent after having been flat for the previous three years.
The tax cut announced today is to be for one year only, as Mr. Hashimoto made very clear. And the $300 it would save each taxpayer is to come next June, curtailing any immediate benefit to the economy from increased consumer demand. "It's not enough to create a self-sustaining recovery or send the stock market soaring to new heights," said Mineko Sasaki-Smith, an economist at Credit Suisse First Boston.
The United States was pleased that Mr. Hashimoto had taken at least some action. The Prime Minister received a call from President Clinton, and Michael D. McCurry, Mr. Clinton's spokesman, praised the measures as a financial package "good for the people of Japan and good for the regional economy of Asia."
Skeptics conceded that any sign of movement on the part of the Government would be greeted with relief.
"It's about 1 percent of gross domestic product, but that's really not the point," said Ronald Bevacqua, a Merrill Lynch economist here. "Given how pessimistic everyone has been, this may actually give people some sense of hope. It's about sentiment as much as anything."
The plans for the two trillion yen in public works, which will be contracted and paid for this year, are likely to be controversial. The Government has come under criticism for spending on unnecessary bridges, tunnels and the like that have kept Japan's bloated construction industry afloat for the last few years.
The Prime Minister succeeded in winning applause from critics for his pluck, and got a somewhat more muted reception for the package itself. "I have to think Hashimoto has been wringing his hands over this one a long time," said John F. Neuffer, a political analyst at the Mitsui Marine Research Institute here. "And his timing was so perfect: he rolls in after the party lackadaisically throws together a package that was sure to be criticized, and steals the show."
In response, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks soared more than 700 points after news of the tax cut got out, and although the index retreated some, it closed the session Wednesday up 3.4 percent. Early Thursday, stocks retreated more, down 245.66 points, or almost 1.5 percent, to 16,295.40 at the midday recess.
The yen, which has slipped substantially against the dollar, rose today as the Japanese central bank moved swiftly, selling dollars and buying yen, to take advantage of the element of surprise.
Mr. Hashimoto came to power promising to overhaul Japan's bureaucracy and to impose fiscal responsibility. His administrative reform plans were taken apart by powerful interest groups, and his adherence to fiscal austerity contributed to a further slowing of the economy.
Last spring, his Government -- demonstrating its seriousness on fiscal restraint -- took back a temporary tax cut, increased the sales tax and eliminated some medical subsidies. The economy, already contending with bad debt and some industry overcapacity, stopped growing.
Still, the Prime Minister stuck to his guns, practicing an ancient Japanese art -- perseverance in the face of extreme adversity.
But in the last month, the economy took a turn for the worse. Four large financial institutions collapsed in November. The yen had its biggest drop in years. Stocks began reaching a level that threatened to bring even more banks to their knees. The United States and the International Monetary Fund politely suggested that while Japan's efforts to get its house in order were admirable, perhaps they were mistimed.
In the last couple of weeks, factions in the ruling Liberal Democratic Party urged Mr. Hashimoto to change his policies. First, Seiroku Kajiyama suggested a huge bond issue, the proceeds of which could be used to spur the economy. Then, earlier this week, even Hiromu Nonaka, deputy secretary general of the party and lieutenant to Koichi Kato, one of the most adamant fiscal hawks, began quietly expressing the view that a change in policy was unavoidable and that further stalling only allowed Mr. Kajiyama, their party antagonist, to steal the thunder.
But stung by charges that he had flip-flopped when he decided to use public money to shore up the financial system, the Prime Minister held steady. Not until a group of young mavericks began suggesting Monday that he could avoid the appearance of going back on his word because the Fiscal Consolidation Law did not go into effect until April did Mr. Hashimoto decide to risk great political trouble by scuttling the commitment to fiscal austerity.
There were signs that for the Prime Minister, the decision had been very difficult. Asked at his news conference this morning whether the Government's fiscal tightening last spring had been a mistake, he replied with irritation, "If you want to say so, please say so."
Nihon Keizei Shimbun, Japan's business daily, reported that when the senior adviser to the Government's tax committee, Sadanori Yamanaka, received Mr. Hashimoto's call and, incredulously, suggested that he must be suffering from jet lag, the Prime Minister snapped back, "No, I am very serious."
Whether Hiroshi Mitsuzuka continues as Finance Minister seemed uncertain. In recent days, he has been mentioned as likely scapegoat for the Government's woes, and his ministry was forced to delay a press briefing this morning because Mr. Hashimoto's announcements took it, too, by surprise.
