HEADLINE: Fleeing Abuse to the Streets;
Shelters Can't Keep Pace With Increase in Runaways

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

DATELINE: HARRISON, N.Y., Dec. 17

 BODY:
She will not go home again, the 15-year-old runaway told her caseworker, her guidance counselor and her therapist, in no uncertain terms.
She has yanked her mother from a bar for the last time, the girl said. Undressed her for the last time because she was too drunk to put herself to bed. Taken the last blow from her grandfather. Heard the last of her grandmother's screaming, so loud that even rap music wouldn't drown it out. 
 "I'll go anyplace but home," said the blond, lanky teen-ager, who arrived at a runaway shelter here bruised but smiling, relieved to be at a secret location where her family could not find her. "If I have to keep running, I'll keep running. I've had enough."
The girl's plight is all too common in an overburdened child-welfare system that focuses its limited resources on the infant who might be shaken unconscious or the toddler who might be starved to death by a parent or guardian, advocates and social service officials agree.
An abused or neglected teen-ager does not claim the same sympathy as a chubby-cheeked baby, these experts say. A teen-ager is also harder to place in foster care and is old enough and strong enough to retaliate or run.
But run where, when there are 30,000 teen-agers who have fled their homes in New York State and only 400 emergency shelter beds, 13,000 runaways in New Jersey with safe haven for only 300, and 10,000 in Connecticut with room for just 115? Even if a runaway finds a bed in a crisis center, where does he or she go after reaching the 30-day Federal limit for sanctuary in an emergency shelter, like the one in Harrison?
Here in Westchester County, 1,883 teen-agers were reported missing in 1996, up from 1,534 in 1995. In the same time, county spending for the one emergency shelter decreased by nearly 40 percent, forcing the agency to make up more of its $330,000 budget from private contributions.
Teen-agers here who do not come to the shelter flee to Getty Square in Yonkers. In New York City, they form raggedy bands in the Port Authority terminal or along the West Side piers. In the tattered upstate city of Jamestown, their home of last resort is Veterans Park, across from the high school they long ago stopped attending.
Flight has its risks, advocates for adolescents say, as demonstrated in dire fashion in Jamestown two months ago. The authorities said nearly a dozen young girls, most of them runaways, were infected with H.I.V. by Nushawn J. Williams, a handsome Brooklyn felon who is accused of luring them into drug dealing and unprotected sex with a warm bed, a square meal, cheap trinkets and smooth talk.
"Where else can they go?" asked Margo Hirsch, executive director of the Empire State Coalition for Youth and Family Services, citing the paucity of emergency shelters and the lack of follow-up services. "The streets start looking pretty good. And in the streets we know who's taking care of them: the pimps and the drug dealers. The ultimate outcome is that too many of them die by proxy. No, the parents didn't kill them. But they're dead just the same."
The Federal Government acknowledged the problem two decades ago with the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act, which financed a national network of call-in lines and crisis shelters, from the cavernous Covenant House on Manhattan's West Side to YMCA basements in Milwaukee and Minneapolis.
Of the estimated 1.3 million American teen-agers who run away or are kicked out of their homes each year, some due to garden-variety teen-age rebellion or the stress of divorce or unemployment, the vast majority eventually find their way back again. But in the last 15 years, shelter directors, researchers and other experts say, a growing number have been fleeing broken families that are not so easily mended. The problem is usually related to adult drug and alcohol abuse, single parenthood and a parade of men in the house with no emotional stake in the children. These cases often end in violence, experts say, with a disturbed teen-ager on the run.
Warm-weather states have substantially more teen-agers leaving home for longer periods than cold-weather states, said Dr. Gerald T. Hotaling, a researcher at the University of Massachusetts in Lowell who has studied teen-age runaways for 15 years, but no region "sticks out in having a really assertive response."
Here at the Sanctuary shelter caseworkers are scrambling to come up with a plan that will keep the 15-year-old girl off the streets.
Her biography, experts say, is typical. Like most runaways, she is a girl in her early teens, living with a single parent, in a family with several generations of alcohol abuse and domestic violence. She has attempted suicide, has mental health problems and has run away before. She is unlikely to meet the county's requirements for foster placement.
"They see so many more severe cases," said Hans J. Schlange, director of the shelter here. "They have to have cutoff points due to the sheer numbers."
Donald J. Wiede, who runs the child welfare arm of the county's Department of Social Services, concedes a dearth of services and a lower rate of placement for adolescents than for younger children. "There is a gap between the expectations and the reality of what we're able to do in terms of resources," he said.
But the 15-year-old girl, who shudders at every mention that she might have to go home, is not interested in the mismatch between resources and expectations. She has had enough. Fresh from a therapy appointment at a Catholic Charities center one recent afternoon, she was asked what finally persuaded her that home was no longer an option.
"I can't say what caused it," she said. "Everything and nothing. I've been shoving it deep down inside, and then something lit the fuse and it just blew up."
The girl arrived last month at the shelter, run by the Children's Village agency in nearby Dobbs Ferry. Her story was pieced together through her own accounts, observations during a half-dozen long visits at the shelter and conversations with staff members, who filed an abuse complaint with the county when she arrived with bruises all over her body.
The girl's mother and grandparents, who share a two-family house in southern Westchester, were not interviewed at the request of her caseworkers here, her guidance counselor at a religious school where she gets mostly A's and B's and her therapist, all of whom fear for her safety. Because of their concern about family retaliation, she is not identified.
These caseworkers and counselors are barred by law from providing details of the case. But all said that her account was credible. Law enforcement officials confirmed police visits to the house "pertaining to the girl."
The girl, who excels in her English and religion classes and hopes to go to college, has hazy plans, beyond counting the months until she turns 16 and can no longer be forced to return home. "I just have to lay low until then," she said.
She likes the workers here at the shelter, who oohed and ahhed at her report card, pretend not to notice when she goes outside to smoke cigarettes and chose her to put the angel at the top of the Christmas tree.
Maybe she can find another shelter if she has to leave this one, the girl said. Or maybe she can live with her boyfriend, who has been in and out of drug rehabilitation. Her therapist and guidance counselor support her decision not to go home, the girl said. But they are dubious about the 16-year-old boy, whose football jersey she wears every day because it carries his scent.
The girl never knew her father because her mother, a construction worker, fled his abuse during pregnancy. Since then, they have lived with the grandparents, except for a brief, happy time when her mother married. The girl glows when discussing her stepfather, who had a house on an upstate lake, played basketball with her, and took her to see "The Phantom of the Opera" on Broadway. Two years ago, he died of a heroin overdose.
Since then, the girl said, her mother's drinking has escalated. Her grandfather lost a job and he, too, took his sorrows to the neighborhood bar. Both pummeled her when they were drunk and angry, she said, usually after finding her boyfriend in the house. Her grandmother does not drink and did not hit her, but never intervened. Her great-grandmother, who calls the shelter nightly to make sure she is eating well and has enough clothes, lives nearby but is drifting into senility.
At 12 the girl ran away, passing one rainy night in a park, a railroad station and a 24-hour laundromat where she dried her clothes. At 14, she tried to commit suicide by swallowing medicine that her grandfather took for diabetes, heart and liver disease. Her mother was summoned from a bar to tend to her semiconscious daughter, the girl said. The girl was hospitalized and then referred to therapy.
Last semester, she was absent from school twice and tardy only once. "When I'm at school I'm happy," she said. "Then I walk through the door at home and I'm a different person.
The girl bolted again last month when her family found her boyfriend in the house. She spent a few nights at the boy's house, where her relatives caught up with her. At the suggestion of her boyfriend's mother, she came here. The staff members who interviewed her said she demonstrated credibility by noting which bruises were inflicted by relatives and which from a fall.
During her stay here, the 15-year-old was a serene island in the storm. One boy was found to be hiding a box cutter in his room and was moved to a psychiatric hospital. A girl, claiming lost bus fare, was late every night. Neither of her squabbling parents wanted her, and so she was shipped to an uncle in Texas. Another girl, a patient in an outpatient drug rehabilitation program became ill after smoking marijuana for 24 hours, and is likely to be placed elsewhere after a court appearance on an earlier assault charge.
The 15-year-old said the chaos here can be "pretty much like home." The telephones constantly ring with new emergencies, parents threatening legal action if their children are not sent home, despite their right to be here under Federal law. But even with these outbursts and a 90-minute trip to school each day on three buses, the girl begs to stay.
At a family meeting on Tuesday, emboldened by the counseling she has received here, the girl confronted her mother about her drinking and abuse. The mother's nasty response disturbed caseworkers. Perhaps the county will be persuaded to remove the girl from her home. Failing that, Mr. Schlange said he plans to use what is left of her time here to broker a solution to keep her off the streets.
In the meantime, after homework and a cup of hot chocolate, she often retreats to the dining room and the twinkling Christmas tree. "I like it in here because it's quiet," she said.

HEADLINE: Clinton on His Foreign Policy: A Rose-Tinted World

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Although he acknowledged that work remained to be done, President Clinton gave a remarkably upbeat assessment of his Administration's foreign-policy achievements at his news conference on Tuesday, a kind of sneak preview of his 1998 State of the Union Message.
The picture was all but unrecognizable to many in Washington foreign-policy circles, including a number of senior Administration officials. Asked what he made of it, one such official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, rolled his eyes and replied, "The President was just having a little political fun." 
 What puzzled many people about Mr. Clinton's words was not their partisan nature but the breadth of the claims he made at a time when the consensus among Western diplomats based here is that American foreign relations have hit a bad patch. They blame not just Mr. Clinton but the intractability of certain problems and the difficulty of formulating policy in an ambiguous era with severely limited agreement on goals, not only across party lines but also within parties.
After a period of relative success in places like Bosnia, where American diplomacy stanched the blood-letting, and Mexico, where a bold American intervention helped solve a financial crisis, the tide seems to many to have slowly turned. United States relations with Russia and China, a pair of insecure giants, remain relatively stable, if full of unresolved questions. But elsewhere, the picture is not nearly so reassuring, diplomats say.
In Iraq, the United States maintains that it has yielded nothing to Saddam Hussein to ease the latest crisis there; indeed, Mr. Clinton said Tuesday that "we stood strong against a rogue regime in Iraq" and insisted that United States allies were less likely than ever to press for easing sanctions.
Yet in the behind-the-scenes maneuvering only Britain among the members of the Persian Gulf war coalition remains steadfast behind the American position, with France, Russia, Germany and most Arab countries favoring a softening of United Nations penalties. If another confrontation with President Hussein develops, furthermore, it appears likely that any military response will be left by the others to the United States and possibly Britain.
President Clinton has agreed in principle to allowing Iraq to sell more oil so that it can use the revenues to buy food. The President suggested that this had been an American idea from the start; the Europeans say that Mr. Clinton has given way only in the face of strong European pressure.
In a way, the two pictures of the situation in Iraq are reminiscent of the conflicting portrayals of the war in Vietnam in the 1960's, by President Lyndon B. Johnson on the one hand and anti-war campaigners on the other.
There were other striking examples of rose-colored glasses.
Mr. Clinton said that "under the Vice President's leadership" conferees in Kyoto this month had taken "an important step" toward protecting the global environment from the climate-warming gases produced by burning fossil fuels. But Vice President Al Gore spent less than a day in Kyoto, and the United States agreed to a last-minute compromise on "greenhouse" gas emissions that was rendered more or less meaningless when Mr. Clinton made it clear that he would not submit the treaty to the Senate unless developing nations made concessions they had refused to make at the conference.
Again, in the Middle East, even the forceful intervention of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright has failed to get peace efforts back on course. Domestic politics in Israel make the necessary concessions difficult to grant, and Arab terrorist attacks strengthen the hand of the hard-liners. Mr. Clinton declined to meet the Israeli President, Benjamin Netanyahu, when he was in the United States recently, an action that many, including Mr. Netanyahu, interpreted as a snub.
The President waved that idea aside with the comment that he had met Mr. Netanyahu five times and would meet with him next year. He said he would never insult Israel or the Israeli people; careful listeners may have noticed that he did not say he would never snub Mr. Netanyahu personally.
On Bosnia, he ducked the question of extending the stay of American troops beyond next year's deadline, apparently because of squabbles on the issue within the Administration. But he said he would state his policy before leaving on a Christmas trip to Bosnia in only three days, and it became evident less than 24 hours after the news conference that he had decided to press for some sort of extension of the American commitment.
Although long accustomed to a Washington policy-making process that is more haphazard than those typical in Europe and Japan, largely because of the divisions of power built into the Constitution, the European and Asian allies of the United States appear bewildered by what is going on now.
"What is the structure? What is the goal?" asked a Western European foreign minister in a conversation this month. "The United States does not seem as deeply engaged as before, and where it is engaged, it seems unsure."
A European diplomat based in Washington commented that even though the United States possessed unmatched military and economic power, neither Congress nor Mr. Clinton seemed clear on exactly how it should be deployed in such places as Iraq and Bosnia. The preference, he said, seemed to be for "second-guessing each other rather than acting."
Mr. Clinton has exhibited great reluctance to commit United States forces abroad, which is not surprising given the Pentagon's considerable skepticism about armed interventions. A case in point has been the attitude of Defense Secretary William S. Cohen, who has only belatedly and reluctantly moved toward accepting the view that American troops should remain in Bosnia after a June 1998 withdrawal deadline.
Ms. Albright has taken a much more aggressive line, pressing within Administration councils and in a major speech at Harvard University for a more activist policy, both diplomatically and militarily. On Bosnia, she appears to be prevailing, but the Administration remains guarded in other areas.
Arguably, the expansion of free trade -- and its corollary, the expansion of the number of market-economy democracies -- has been the most consistent theme in American policy in the last decade.
Among Mr. Clinton's notable successes were the negotiation and approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement and American approval of the Uruguay round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. He had hoped to build on those successes in his second term, but he was handed a bitter defeat by Congress when he sought added authority to conclude future deals.
In some senses, Congress has been the largest impediment to the development of a coherent foreign policy in the period following the cold war, where there is no organizing principle comparable to the long struggle to stem Communist expansion. A majority of House members and 40 percent of the Senators have been elected since the fall of the Berlin wall. A third of all members of Congress are said to lack passports.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Yen Rises On Hope for Japan Growth

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The yen soared yesterday, knocking the value of the dollar down 2.8 percent after Japanese officials surprised the currency markets with a one-two punch.
First, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto included an unexpected, one-time $15 billion income tax cut in an economic-stimulus package. 
 Then, the Japanese central bank sold dollars to buy yen in the market to emphasize the Government's support of the beleaguered currency. It was the first time that the bank had intervened to support the value of the yen in more than five years. Last year, it intervened to weaken the yen -- which suggests how quickly the tables have turned.
The surprise moves sent currency traders scrambling. The dollar has been treated as a one-way bet upward against the yen since the end of October, when Asian financial turmoil intensified. It has risen more than 8 percent in the last month and a half, to five-and-a-half-year highs.
The announcement in Tokyo also helped send United States bond prices lower as investors concluded that an improvement in the outlook for Japan would mean that fewer foreigners would need Treasury securities as a haven.
But beyond scrambling, some traders and strategists were not sure that all that much had changed. While the surprise move could limit further gains for the dollar temporarily, these people look into next year and see the dollar moving higher again.
If that is the case, then a stronger dollar against the yen, and the German mark, could eat into corporate-earnings expectations for 1998 by making American exports less competitive abroad and reducing foreign earnings when the export revenue is translated back into dollars.
The dollar is already up almost 10 percent against the yen and 15 percent against the mark in the last year, which has helped cut Merrill Lynch's earnings forecast for next year to single digits.
The longer-term outlook of further dollar gains helped explain the currency's partial rebound in trading in the United States yesterday. A trader at a prominent hedge fund, which often takes big currency positions, said there would be some "short-term pain." But the decline, the trader added, was seen more as an opportunity to take on bigger positions rather than a setback because the outlook was for a stronger dollar.
Late in New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 127.08 yen, down from 130.78 yen on Tuesday. In Japanese trading earlier, the dollar fell as low as 125.78 yen. This morning, the dollar rose in spot trading to 127.35 yen.
Against the mark yesterday, the dollar traded in New York at 1.7735, down from 1.7822 marks on Tuesday.
Karen E. Parker, a currency strategist at the Chase Manhattan Bank, acknowledged that the Japanese had altered the near-term outlook for the yen. She adjusted her year-end forecast for the dollar down to 128 yen from 130.
"The package definitely goes in the right direction," she said, adding that "we should be watching much more closely to see if this is a harbinger of change" of the tight fiscal policies that have helped restrain the Japanese economy in the 1990's. The decision to support an income tax cut was a reversal of Mr. Hashimoto's previously strong opposition.
The prodding of the Japanese to take such steps by President Clinton also prompted traders to ask if "there is more to come, and whether the United States will intervene in the market" to support the yen. Many of them consider that unlikely and wonder how much the Japanese central bank can achieve alone.
Barbara Levchuk, head of foreign exchange sales at HSBC Midland, said all these factors were putting a hold right now on the dollar. "I thought it was a smart move on the part of the Japanese," she said. "I would sit back and not be too aggressive in buying dollars. Maybe we have put a top on the dollar-yen for now."
In the long run, many currency strategists and traders expect the dollar to move higher because the Japanese economy may not get that much of a lift from the stimulus package. The income tax cut, they note, was proposed as temporary, and a lot of the money can be expected to be saved rather than spent.
In addition, many Japanese investors are looking for better returns from the money they have built up, and the United States is a much more attractive place than Japan to do that. This means that more yen would be sold to get the dollars to buy American stocks and bonds.
"They can't lean against the wind indefinitely," Ms. Parker of Chase Manhattan said. "The fundamentals are not supporting a stronger yen." Her end-of-1998 forecast is for an exchange rate of 140 yen to the dollar, a 10 percent jump from where the dollar ended yesterday.
Carl Weinberg, chief economist of High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y., said that "in the first half of 1998, the dollar is going to be a real strong currency because the U.S. is the one place that works with certainty."
"Where else do you want to put your money?" he added.

HEADLINE: CLINTON TO EXTEND G.I. ROLE IN BOSNIA

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
President Clinton has decided that American troops should stay in Bosnia past their mission's current departure deadline in June as part of an international peacekeeping force, Administration officials said today.
Mr. Clinton, who is planning to visit troops stationed in Bosnia next week, is expected to announce at the White House on Thursday that he has decided "in principle" to extend the mission. About 8,000 Americans are serving in Bosnia, as part of a NATO-led force of more than 30,000. 
 Administration officials said Mr. Clinton was not going to announce the number of troops that will remain, when they might leave or even how the mission might change, since those details are under review in NATO. It is that review, together with the President's coming holiday visit to the troops, that prompted his long-expected decision to extend the mission, officials said.
"None of this planning will ever be real or taken seriously by the Euros unless the U.S. is in," an Administration official said, referring to other members of NATO. "We are the glue that has held this thing together."
Alliance planners are expected to lay out their specific military options in Bosnia by mid-January or soon after. Military officials are looking at a range of options for the American component of the peacekeeping force, including keeping 8,000 American troops in Bosnia, an Administration official said. More likely, other officials have indicated, the force will shrink, perhaps to 6,000.
This will be Mr. Clinton's second extension of a mission that has been controversial since he first ordered ground troops into Bosnia to carry out peace accords negotiated in Dayton in 1995. Mr. Clinton originally said the troops would be there for only one year, through the end of 1996. But days after the Presidential election last year, he said the troops would stay through June 1998.
No American troops have fallen to hostile fire during the Bosnian mission. Despite criticism that key provisions of the Dayton accords -- most notably the repatriation of refugees and the arrest of accused war criminals -- have not been carried out, the international force has successfully secured a fragile peace.
Congressional critics of the Administration's Bosnia policy never believed that a definite "date certain" for the withdrawal was real. "I certainly hope that they don't insult our intelligence again with another date certain," Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican, said today. "I never believed that a date certain was a substitute for an exit strategy."
Mr. McCain said Congress might permit the extension, since its only option is the unappealing one of cutting off money to the troops. But, he said, the Administration's "credibility in my view has been terribly damaged" by officials' testimony that the force would leave by July.
Administration officials said they had learned lessons from the long mission in Bosnia. This time, they said, they are not waiting until the last minute, but seeking support for an extension seven months before the current mission expires.
"The President wanted us to engage early on this," another Administration official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "This is being done in a deliberate way that is not at all hasty."
For weeks, the Administration has signaled that American troops would remain in Bosnia past June. After the President met in early November with Congressional critics of his Bosnia policy, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said "a consensus is developing" between the Administration and Congress that the troops would stay.
Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen, who had declared in March that the United States would withdraw the troops as promised, has only recently come around to supporting an extension. But he, too, has been seeking Congressional support for the Administration's policy. Today, he telephoned Democrats and Republicans in Congress seeking their backing.
The President has invited Congressional leaders to travel with him to Bosnia on Sunday. He plans to give speeches in Sarajevo, the Bosnian capital, and in Tuzla, the headquarters of American forces, and to greet troops at an air base, returning home without spending a night in Bosnia.
An Administration official said Mr. Clinton had decided to announce the extension of the deadline before leaving for Bosnia, in part because the troops there "are entitled to have a general sense of the direction of U.S. policy."
Two prominent Republican members of the Senate Armed Services Committee, John W. Warner of Virginia and and Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, sent a letter to Mr. Clinton today advising him on his trip and saying, "We understand that you plan to announce that continued U.S. participation is necessary."
They wrote that before extending the mission, Mr. Clinton and NATO should address several issues, including finding a way to bring more war-crimes suspects to justice. And, they said, "the European allies must do more in the overall effort -- especially in providing for a more effective police force" to enforce the law.
The Administration has been trying to persuade its NATO allies to give more support to an international police force that would take on more responsibilities of the peacekeepers.
Administration officials said they were working with the NATO planners to define more clearly the American mission in any extended military presence. In that vein, Mr. Clinton is expected to list on Thursday a series of questions he wants answered by the NATO planners, including how the mission will eventually end without inviting a resumption of violence among the Croats, Muslims and Serbs in Bosnia.
But even in the Administration, officials still disagree over the proper size and mission of the American force. "There are some who want to move to a smaller force, for a variety of reasons, whether political or economic or because they want to put pressure on the Europeans to pick up more," an official said.

HEADLINE: South Koreans Vote, Seeking Rescue From Economic Crisis

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Voters began casting their ballots this morning for a new President to rescue this nation from its financial crisis and preside over a far-reaching industrial overhaul during the next five years.
As the candidates finished their campaigning on Wednesday night, bellowing in hoarse voices to shoppers in the markets, the election came to be widely seen as a milestone in Korean history. 
 It is a bit like the American Presidential election of 1932, during the Great Depression, and each candidate is trying to portray himself as a reassuring Roosevelt-like figure able to lead the country to economic recovery.
The two leading candidates, Kim Dae Jung (pronounced kim-day-joong) and Lee Hoi Chang (pronounced ee-hweh-chahng), were neck and neck in opinion polls, but they come from very different backgrounds. Mr. Lee is a former judge and the epitome of the establishment, while Mr. Kim is a legendary democracy campaigner in Asia whom past South Korean Presidents repeatedly tried to kill.
If Mr. Kim wins, it will be the first peaceful transfer of the presidency to the opposition party in modern Korean history. Just 10 years ago, when Mr. Kim was also running, the country was rife with rumors that his victory would provoke a military coup. Now there are no such rumblings.
In any case, this will probably be the closest and most democratic election Korea has ever had, and the dominant issue is simply who will be able to resolve the national crisis and restore South Korea to greatness.
"I ran three times before in presidential elections, and this is surely my last chance," Mr. Kim declared as campaigning ended on Wednesday. "I thank the public for reserving me until today, when the nation truly needs a strong and capable leader."
Mr. Kim also warned that if Mr. Lee was elected, "the nation will plunge into deeper crisis."
Mr. Lee responded by suggesting that the financial markets would effectively punish Korea if it chose Mr. Kim. "If a figure lacking credibility with the international community takes office, there would be a further exodus of our meager foreign capital," Mr. Lee declared, referring to Mr. Kim.
Both Mr. Lee and Mr. Kim have lived in the United States and speak fairly good English, and each portrays himself as the international candidate with the ties to Washington that can help resolve the crisis.
Both candidates now say they favor far-reaching economic changes in accordance with the International Monetary Fund's bailout of South Korea.
Financial analysts said that the stock market would probably react better to a win by Mr. Lee, as he is regarded as more of a pro-business candidate, while Mr. Kim is seen as a populist who might be reluctant to close bankrupt companies and put people out of work.
On the other hand, Mr. Kim has far more credibility with labor unions, and with the poor and disenfranchised. If Mr. Kim backs a far-reaching restructuring program, he may be able to do it more easily than anyone else.
Mr. Lee is gambling that voters will be angry at the governing party but fearful of turning to the untested opposition at a moment of crisis, and he has spoken under the banner of "stability against turmoil."
"Since the economy is experiencing difficulties and the country is unstable, the entire nation must be led by a responsible and stable political force," Mr. Lee declared on Wednesday.
Mr. Kim is hoping that the public will be so disgusted by the Government's mishandling of the crisis that it will punish Mr. Lee and the governing party, and he tells voters, "the country needs a shift of power."
Traditionally, South Korea has been fiercely divided by regional rivalries that go back many centuries but have been exacerbated in recent decades. Mr. Kim is the hero of the Cholla provinces in the southwest, and he normally gets almost all of the votes there but few in the rest of the country, particularly the southeast.
Those rivalries are still evident in this election, but they may have subsided a bit. There is no candidate from the southeast this time, for Mr. Lee was born in what is now North Korea.
In addition, Mr. Lee made a campaign swing to Kwangju, in the heart of Cholla, as a show of broad-mindedness. During his two-hour visit, he was heavily protected by riot-equipped policemen and by guards sent by Mr. Kim's supporters, who feared that any clashes could be used against their candidate. In the end, the visit went smoothly.
"A national leader should not neglect any city or province," Mr. Lee thundered in his speech in Kwangju, which chafes at the neglect it has suffered from the Government for several decades.
The campaign has also been remarkable for its historical ironies. In a tribute to pragmatism or opportunism, depending on one's analysis, Mr. Kim has allied himself with an erstwhile rival who symbolizes the military dictatorship that tried to kill Mr. Kim in the 1970's.
He has struck a deal with Kim Jong Pil, who has strong support in the southeast but was the founder of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency and was a top adviser to President Park Chung Hee in the 1960's and 1970's.
President Park's Government tried to murder Kim Dae Jung several times, and the K.C.I.A. once kidnapped him while he was visiting Tokyo, apparently with the idea of drowning him in the ocean. Western governments intervened, and Kim Dae Jung's life was spared.
Under the agreement between the two men, Kim Dae Jung would become President initially, but South Korea could then move to a parliamentary system headed by Kim Jong Pil.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kim Dae Jung wooing voters in Suwon, just south of Seoul. He and his rival, Lee Hoi Chang, each vowed to lead an economic recovery. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Clinton's Personal Touch in Asian Rescue

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
As Asia's financial crisis has deepened, President Clinton has become personally involved in the effort to persuade Asian leaders to follow American-designed plans to stabilize their economies. In a blitz of phone calls, he has underscored the risks of much broader trouble for the world economy if Japan and South Korea in particular fail to act, American and Asian officials say.
On Thanksgiving evening, for example, Mr. Clinton called Kim Young Sam, South Korea's lame-duck President, to make the case that time had run out on negotiations over the terms of a bailout from the International Monetary Fund. In the days leading up to the call, South Korea's banking system seemed just days away from insolvency, and the President's economic advisers feared that failures in the world's 11th-largest economy could resonate in Japan and around the globe. 
 After several more efforts to ease the terms demanded by the I.M.F., Mr. Kim's Government reluctantly agreed six days after the South Korean leader spoke with Mr. Clinton. But one South Korean official said that some in the Government had "resented the use of Presidential pressure," especially because they believed -- largely accurately -- that some of the toughest elements of the economic prescription were being drafted by Mr. Clinton's Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin.
Last Friday, Mr. Kim called back to announce that he had persuaded all three candidates in the South Korean presidential election, which is on Thursday, to endorse the I.M.F. bailout plan. But he also used the conversation to ask obliquely for faster financial aid from the United States and Japan -- a request that the Korean press reported was accepted and that American officials say was rejected.
The intervention by Mr. Clinton with Mr. Kim and with Japan's Prime Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto carries some political risks.
It is far from clear that this approach to economic restoration will succeed. And even if it does, Mr. Clinton's intercession could allow South Korean labor unions, laid-off workers in Thailand and Japanese politicians to blame the United States for the pain they are enduring.
A growing number of critics in the United States and across Asia argue that the I.M.F. is not only acting at Washington's bidding but that it is protecting foreign investors, including many American banks and businesses, that made foolish investments in Asia. Some argue that the prescriptions the I.M.F. is enforcing in South Korea, Thailand and Indonesia will squeeze the growth out of those countries, touch off unemployment and risk social unrest.
At the Treasury, officials are going to great lengths to make a time of crisis seem like a time of calm, and Mr. Rubin occasionally acknowledges a tinge of self-doubt about parts of the rescue effort.
Mr. Rubin has, for example, often talked of the "moral hazard" created by bailout plans that effectively reduce the risks faced by investors in poorly run economies. If investors become convinced that the I.M.F. always stands ready to forestall default, Mr. Rubin has said, then they will not demand that national leaders enforce economic discipline. He has often repeated that he would like to figure out a way to save countries without also saving those who have invested in them.
"But you have to remember that the crux of our concern is America's interests," he said in an interview on Tuesday. "Our economy can certainly be affected if a sufficient number of emerging nations" head into a prolonged crisis.
And these days, Mr. Rubin is more apt to make use of the leading noneconomic argument in favor of interjecting the President.
"We are convinced that economic stability is important to our national security concerns," especially in Korea, one of the last surviving arenas of cold war conflict, the Treasury Secretary has argued.
The President's phone call to Mr. Kim on Thanksgiving was not disclosed by the White House, in itself a telling sign.
While the Administration has been eager to announce meeting after meeting about the Iraq crisis, in hopes that the attention will frighten Saddam Hussein, it has been loath to reveal Presidential involvement in the Asian financial crisis.
"The worry," one White House official said today, "is that the mere announcement that the President was meeting his advisers about Asia would drive the markets crazy, and that's exactly what we are trying to avoid."
But both American and Asian officials say that Mr. Clinton has increasingly been swept in. In late October, when Indonesia suddenly called for an I.M.F. bailout, he began receiving a daily, one-page report on the Asian crisis, usually sent to the White House by Mr. Rubin or his deputy, Lawrence H. Summers. He was immersed in the issue at a meeting of Asian leaders last month in Vancouver, British Columbia.
But his role expanded as South Korea began to falter, and Mr. Rubin and Mr. Summers argued that failure to stop the Asian panic in Korea could threaten Japanese banks and, eventually, hit American shores.
Mr. Clinton has had a rocky relationship with Mr. Kim, especially in the 1994 crisis involving North Korea's suspected nuclear weapons capability. But in this instance, Mr. Clinton has the advantage because the United States holds tremendous sway over the I.M.F. and could block any bailout package. In fact, the negotiations dragged on for several days because participants were not satisfied with South Korea's commitments to close failing financial institutions. A $57 billion package was announced on Dec. 4.
With Japan, Mr. Clinton has had far less influence. He and Mr. Rubin have argued in phone conversations and meetings with Prime Minister Hashimoto in recent months that Japan needed to stimulate domestic demand, chiefly with a tax cut that would undo the damage done by a tax increase in April. Mr. Hashimoto resisted, saying that Japan's economy was on the way to recovery. At the Vancouver conference, the Japanese Prime Minister changed his position, saying he had been too optimistic. Mr. Clinton raised the pressure, declaring that it was Japan's responsibility to lead Asia out of its troubles.
"It is hard to say how much Hashimoto was influenced by Clinton," a Japanese diplomat said this week. The Finance Ministry had opposed a deep tax cut to stimulate the economy, fearing it would worsen Japan's budget deficit. But Mr. Hashimoto was also under increasing pressure from his Liberal Democratic Party to act decisively after months of promising big steps and delivering small, unsuccessful ones.
"He might have gotten there without Clinton because the markets were pushing him to act," one Japanese official said today. "But the American shove was convenient," one Japanese official said. "It's always safe to declare, 'Washington made us do it.' "

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Weak Earnings Hurt Stocks As Asia News Is Ignored
Stocks in the United States ended mostly lower for the first time this week, hurt by unexpected weakness in quarterly earnings that offset strength from rallies in Asia after Japan's Government proposed a large tax cut.
The catalyst for the Wall Street decline was news from Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing that fourth-quarter earnings would be more than 10 percent below estimates. Its stock fell nearly 10 percent and helped send the Dow Jones industrial average down 18.90 points, to 7.957.41, snapping a two-day rally. Most broader market barometers also ended lower. Pages D12 and D4. 

Bonds fell, hurt by a big drop in the dollar against the yen, which pushed the yield on the 30-year bond back up to 6 percent, from 5.96 percent on Tuesday. D23.
 
Gold, platinum and palladium surged on the news of a possible income tax reduction in Japan, one of the biggest industrial users of precious metals. D10.
 
Internal Rift Threatens Andersen
A feud between the accountants and consultants at Andersen Worldwide threatened to lead to a split-up of the huge firm, as the consultants said they would seek an arbitrator as part of an effort to leave. The 1,100 partners of Andersen Consulting say their counterparts at Arthur Andersen have broken a 1989 operating agreement. D2.
 
Seoul Shelves Bank Rescues
South Korea postponed plans to inject money into six of its biggest banks. The delay satisfied a demand of the International Monetary Fund, which wants Seoul to end its practice of propping up banks that made bad lending decisions. The I.M.F. was to meet today to decide whether to release the second installment of a $57 billion rescue package for the country. D9.
 
President Clinton has become personally involved in the effort to persuade Asian leaders to heed American-designed plans to stabilize their economies, telephoning them repeatedly in recent weeks. D8.
 
While its financial markets have regained some lost ground, South Korea is still facing a number of difficult economic choices.
Peter Passell: Economic Scene. D2.
 
Leo Burnett in British Agency Deal
The Leo Burnett Company of Chicago will acquire 49 percent of Bartle Bogle Hegarty, a feisty British advertising agency regarded as one of the world's most creative independent shops, for an undisclosed amount of cash. The investment comes amid Burnett's continuing ambitious efforts to remake itself.
Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D11.
 
Mistrial in Simmons Family Feud
A Dallas probate court judge dismissed deadlocked jurors and declared a mistrial in a bitter battle between the Dallas billionaire Harold C. Simmons and two daughters for control of his business empire. The judge ordered both sides to negotiate and set March 3 as the date for a retrial. D4.
 
Many Disguises at Columbia/HCA
Columbia/HCA Healthcare repeatedly distorted expense claims to increase Federal reimbursement, according to court records that cut to the heart of a Federal investigation into the world's largest health care company. The distortions included inflated tax claims and illegal tax deductions. A1.
 
Investor Settles Libel Suit
The Wall Street investor Julian H. Robertson withdrew a libel suit against Business Week after it acknowledged there was an inaccuracy in predictions in an April 1996 article regarding the investment performance of Mr. Robertson's Tiger Management. The magazine had said Mr. Robertson's "glory days are over" after he chalked up lackluster results in 1994 and 1995. But the fund reported gains of 48 percent in 1996 and 67 percent for 1997 as of Dec. 11. D11.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Critical-Delivery Loans From the I.M.F.

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund's executive board adopted a short-term loan program today that will rush funds to countries facing immediate debt-repayment problems or low foreign-currency reserves.
The lending mechanism could be used to expedite delivery of a second installment to South Korea worth $3.6 billion -- part of a $21 billion line of credit established for the country -- if the I.M.F. approves of the progress that Seoul has made since agreeing to a rescue package Dec. 3. The fund's executive board is scheduled to review the South Korean situation on Thursday. 
 To determine how much assistance a country needs, the I.M.F. will examine that country's ability to repay, the strength of its economic reform program and the amount already borrowed, the agency said in a statement.
It will also examine the country's "record in using I.M.F. resources in the past and cooperation with the I.M.F. in surveillance, as well as the I.M.F.'s liquidity," the statement said.
Today's action represented a new way to disburse some of the fund's $200 billion in assets and does not represent an increase in money from the United States or other members.
The loan will last for approximately a year, through at least two payments. Borrowers will have to repay the loans within a year to a year and a half from the date the money was given, the agency said.
The new loan program also could be used to accelerate I.M.F. aid to Thailand and Indonesia, which have been suffering from an inability to repay or extend short-term debt and have low foreign-currency reserves.
The Thais and the Indonesians, which were the first two victims of the financial crisis now gripping South Korea, entered into agreements with the I.M.F. to reform their financial systems earlier this year. In exchange, the fund granted Thailand a $3.9 billion line of credit and Indonesia a $10 billion line of credit.

HEADLINE: Money, Not Miracles, Is Reviving South Bronx;
Shortsighted Solution

 BODY:

To the Editor:
As a grant maker to community-based projects, several of which are church based, I find the call by religious groups urging Federal financing for churches as a response to welfare reform naive and shortsighted (news article, Dec. 14). 
 The needs of welfare recipients cannot be adequately addressed by churches unless those churches help provide child care, health care, job training and the counseling so many need to enter the work force. Additionally, the burden of these responsibilities should be picked up by all churches, not just those starved for resources in the inner city. Corporations, foundations and the affluent must also focus resources on the problems of poverty in our country.
Finally, the prospect of finances for churches beleaguered by the fallout from welfare reform may lead to shortsighted policies. Politicians eager to devolve responsibility for complex problems may hand off the task of addressing social and economic poverty to religious organizations, however ill prepared those institutions are. For the churches, the race to the Federal coffers may come at a very high price indeed.
 
PAM SOLO
Newton, Mass., Dec. 16, 1997
 
The writer is president of the Institute for Civil Society.

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
An Asia Sublimely Mixed: Ugly, Lovely, New, Old

BYLINE: By MARGARETT LOKE 

 BODY:
The Magnum photographer Hiroji Kubota doesn't shy away from ambitious projects. For his 1985 book of photographs on China, he crisscrossed that country from late 1978 through early 1984. For a 1992 book commemorating the 500th anniversary of Columbus's arrival in the Americas, he bought an American camper and spent 700 days traveling throughout the United States. For "Out of the East," to be published next spring by W.W. Norton, he spent the last four years photographing in 16 Pacific Rim countries and territories.
A sampling of 95 color photographs, out of the thousands Mr. Kubota took for the Pacific Rim project, is now on exhibit at the Equitable Gallery. And like his earlier transcontinental efforts, this exhibition bears the mark of a superb photographer with an eye for dramatic contrasts as well as for the quietly sublime. 
 Borrowing installation ideas from the 1955 "Family of Man" exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan and from Paul Rudolph of the Bauhaus, the designers of the Kubota exhibition -- Craig Konyk, an architect, and Anthony McCall, a graphic designer -- have created 16 "rooms" in the Equitable Gallery space. The frameless pictures are clustered according to country and held in place at varying heights and angles by wires going from picture to ceiling and from picture to floor. Lengthy captions, accompanied by thumbnail images, are grouped on nearby walls.
Born in 1939 in Tokyo, Mr. Kubota saw his share of death and suffering while growing up in a war-ravaged country. He has said that he is a photographer, not a photojournalist, and that he leaves the coverage of war and mayhem, corruption and repression to others. "Out of the East," therefore, is a vision of Pacific Rim Asia that is both timeless, with its images of gorgeous landscapes and the pervasive influence of Buddhism, and ever-changing, showing the influence of Western architecture and popular culture and Western-style economic development.
When Mr. Kubota visited Pacific Rim Asia in recent years, he was struck by its dynamism. He brilliantly catches the region's vitality in a photograph of youthful motorcycle contestants and observers at the Macau Gran Prix. This is not just an image of vibrant youth but one where the confident, brash postures of the young men and a young woman bespeak a generation that flouts the old stereotypes of quiet, studious, unathletic Asian youth.
A dark side of the Asian miracle-now-mess has been the brutality of governments as they dash headlong down the road of economic development. In a sad but wondrous image, Mr. Kubota shows sand taken from the Irrawaddy River in Myanmar (formerly Burma) to make concrete that would be used to widen a road parallel to the moat around Mandalay Castle. With the widening, people who used to live there were displaced. But in the photograph, peaked mounds of the sand dot a seemingly alien but dreamy landscape, while workers gracefully make their way between the mounds.
The show's most arresting image is not of stunning economic change but of a huge rock, revered by Buddhists and covered in gold leaf, that perches on the edge of a high mountain in Myanmar. Mr. Kubota shows the sheer magic and power of the rock by cropping off its top. This golden precarious wonder sits dead center against a deep blue sky, its imposing size contrasted with six (small by comparison) crimson-robed priests kneeling to one side of it and the low dark hills below.
Scenic spots, though, are occasionally problematic for Mr. Kubota, who produces postcard-pretty images of terraced hillsides in Bali and golden water and shadowy mountains in Luang Prabang, the old capital of Laos. But that chestnut of a picture -- the out-of-a-Chinese-painting mountains of Guilin in Guangxi Province -- is freed from the curse of too familiar loveliness by being paired with the hellish scene of purplish white smoke emanating from black steel mills in Anshan, Liaoning Province.
When Mr. Kubota dabbles in photo reportage, some of the results are, unfortunately, predictable travel pictures. Countries like Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand seem to blur into one another. They have Western skyscrapers, Western leisure pursuits (tennis, swimming) and their variants of the picturesque tribe or ethnic group. Fewer countries and more pictures of each country might have been preferable.
Even when Mr. Kubota photographs a young man standing on one leg on a Phnom Penh street, his other leg having been blown off by a land mine, the image is oddly bloodless. It's as if Mr. Kubota were dutifully taking a representative picture of a victim of land mines instead of coming up with an image that would make the viewer look with fresh eyes at an old scourge.
But where Mr. Kubota is a photographer rather than a recorder of places and peoples, the pictures are mesmerizing. In Guangzhou (formerly Canton), Mr. Kubota happens on card players at two tables beside a high white wall. This would have been an ordinary street scene were it not for beautiful details like the ancient gnarled tree trunks between the tables, their sculptural forms casting impressionistic shadows on the wall.
Like his good friend Andre Kertesz, Mr. Kubota is fond of the surreal. Hong Kong has been famous for airplanes flying low over residential areas, and Mr. Kubota pays tribute to that by showing an airplane looming theatrically in a bit of blue sky between crowded buildings.
In Taiwan's third largest city, Taichung, Mr. Kubota espies the head and shoulders of a huge potbellied Hotei, one of the seven deities of fortune, seemingly plunked down in the middle of palm and pine trees, a skyscraper in the background. A lushly green patch of land in Mindinao, in the Philippines, is crowded with mysterious, small peaked huts, while a man stands, holding a white bird; this is a farm that breeds fighting cocks, according to the caption.
From the show, it seems that Mr. Kubota took some of his best pictures in Vietnam and Cambodia. Among them is a sublime portrait of a Buddhist priest and a young boy in the old Vietnamese city of Hue. Dressed in black and in a room cast in deep shadow, the priest looks gently into the distance while behind him stands a child, a pencil (perhaps) in one hand, the fragile innocence of the very young on his face.
The show's most extraordinary image is taken in the Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh. In a delicately layered picture that brings to mind those taken by Henri Cartier-Bresson, a good friend who has had an influence on his work, Mr. Kubota juxtaposes life and death. On the lower left side of the image are three children playing near the trunk of a big tree, one boy near an old-fashioned Coca-Cola stand emblazoned with the company logo. Dominating the picture is the tree, which is hung with intriguing bottle-shaped woven baskets; they are to protect the fruits from damage. But to the right of the image, through the open window of a well-kept building with intricate architectural detailing on the outside, are shelves and shelves of human skulls.
"Out of the East: Recent Photographs of Asia by Hiroji Kubota" will remain at the Equitable Gallery, 787 Seventh Avenue at 51st Street, Manhattan, through Jan. 3.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
A Spectacle As Sweeping As the Sea

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN 

 BODY:
The long-awaited advent of the most expensive movie ever made, the reportedly $200 million "Titanic," brings history to mind, and not just the legendary seafaring disaster of April 15, 1912. Think back also, exactly 58 years ago today, to the Dec. 19 New York premiere of another grand, transporting love story set against a backdrop of prideful excess, cataclysmic upheaval and character-defining trial by fire.
Recall how that cultural landmark wowed audiences with its bravado, mad extravagance and state-of-the-art Hollywood showmanship, all fueled by one unstoppable filmmaker and his obsessive imagination. Just as David O. Selznick had Atlanta to burn, now James Cameron has a ship to sink, but he also has much more than calamity to explore in this gloriously retrograde new epic. Mr. Cameron's magnificent "Titanic" is the first spectacle in decades that honestly invites comparison to "Gone With the Wind." 
 What a rarity that makes it in today's world of meaningless gimmicks and short attention spans: a huge, thrilling three-and-a-quarter-hour experience that unerringly lures viewers into the beauty and heartbreak of its lost world. Astonishing technological advances are at work here, but only in the service of one spectacular illusion: that the ship is afloat again, and that the audience is intimately involved in its voyage.
What's more, Mr. Cameron succeeds magically in linking his film's young lovers, played enchantingly by Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet, with established details of the "Titanic" story. And let's not forget the offscreen drama: delayed release and outrageous costs made "Titanic" the joke of the summer. Now it's the movie of the year.
Though the tender moments in Mr. Cameron's earlier films have mostly involved Arnold Schwarzenegger, graceful storytelling from this one-man army of a filmmaker (a director, a producer, a writer and an editor) is the biggest of many surprises here. Swept away by the romance of his subject matter, Mr. Cameron rises to the occasion with a simple, captivating narrative style, one that cares little for subtlety but overflows with wonderful, well-chosen Hollywood hokum. In its own sobering way, the film is forward-looking, too, as its early brashness gives way to near-religious humility when the moments of reckoning arrive. Ultimately a haunting tale of human nature, with endless displays of callousness, gallantry or cowardice, it offers an unforgettable vision of millennium-ready unease in the sight of passengers adrift in icy seas on that last, moonless night.
That Mr. Cameron allowed flashlights into what should have been a pitch-black sequence is one of the rare times when "Titanic" willingly departs from established fact. Otherwise, with an attention to detail that goes well beyond fanatical, the film flawlessly recreates its monument to Gilded Age excess. Behind-the-scenes details here, which prove no less fascinating than Selznick's "Gone With the Wind" memos, include Mr. Cameron's having persuaded the original carpet manufacturer to make an 18,000-square-foot reproduction of its "Titanic" weave and his having insisted that every sign, uniform and logo for the Southampton sailing sequence also be created in mirror image, so that the camera could reverse the apparent direction of the nearly life-size model ship.
Sets match old photographs right down to the sculpture and woodwork; costumes incorporate fragments of vintage clothing; even the silver White Star Line ashtrays had to be right. A core group of 150 extras worked with an Edwardian etiquette coach throughout the filming, furthering the illusion that the privileged past had returned to life.
"Titanic" is no museum piece, however. It's a film with tremendous momentum right from its deceptive, crass-looking start. The story opens in the present day, with a team of scientist-cowboys (led by Bill Paxton) hunting for lost treasure amid the Titanic wreckage. Though Mr. Cameron made his own journey to the ocean floor to film amazing glimpses of the ship, he treats these explorers as glib 90's hotshots, the kind of macho daredevils who could just as easily be found tracking twisters or dinosaurs in a summer action film.
"Oops, somebody left the water running," one of them wisecracks about the sunken ship.
Then the film begins, ever so teasingly, to open its window to the past. A 101-year-old woman (played spiritedly by Gloria Stuart, an 87-year-old beauty who appeared in "Gold Diggers of 1935") hears of the expedition and says it has links to her own history. It seems that she, Rose, was the model for a nude sketch found by the present-day fortune hunters in a Titanic safe. It is the only thing of value to be retrieved there. The money in the safe has turned to mud.
But where is the Heart of the Ocean, the egg-size blue diamond Rose wears in the drawing? Rose begins telling her story, and at long last 1912 is at hand. In an introductory sequence mounted on a colossal scale, Mr. Cameron shows the ship being boarded by its full economic range of passengers, from the haughty rich to the third-class passengers being checked for head lice.
Young Rose (Ms. Winslet) arrives at the dock in the show-stopping plumage of Deborah L. Scott's costume designs, and in the unfortunate company of Cal Hockley (Billy Zane), the tiresome snob whom she has agreed to marry, largely at the urging of her impecunious mother (Frances Fisher). The Rose-Cal story line, which is the weakest part of the film thanks to Cal's unwavering odiousness, plays like Edith Wharton Lite.
Meanwhile, in a nearby tavern, adorable Jack Dawson (Mr. DiCaprio) is winning a third-class Titanic ticket in a poker game. It won't be long before Jack is bounding happily into steerage, showing off the boyish adventurousness that makes him such a cure for what's ailing Rose. Aboard the ship of dreams, as the Titanic is often called here, Jack is one serious dreamboat.
A bohemian artist (whose drawings were done by Mr. Cameron) who has spent the requisite time in Paris, he offers all the fun and flirtatiousness that Rose has been missing. This 20-year-old has also shown his share of worldly wisdom by the end of the story. It goes without saying that it's Jack, not Cal, who is the film's true gentleman. And that Mr. DiCaprio has made an inspired career move in so successfully meeting the biggest challenge for an actor of his generation: a traditional role.
Among the many miracles of "Titanic" is its way of creating a sweet, life-changing courtship between Jack and Rose in the course of only a few days. At the risk of turning into a women's picture, "Titanic" brings these two together through a dramatic meeting, an invitation for Jack at a formal first-class dinner, a dancing romp among steerage passengers and even enough intimate moments to give the love story heat. Splendid chemistry between the stars, along with much color from the supporting cast and careful foreshadowing from Mr. Cameron, keeps the romance buoyant even after the dread iceberg gets in its way.
Comfortable even in suggesting that the ship's lookouts missed the danger because they were busy watching lovestruck Jack and Rose, Mr. Cameron lets tragedy strike midway through the film. That way, the disaster can unfold in almost real time, with terrifying precision on a par with all the other details here.
Not for "Titanic" the shrill hysteria of ordinary disaster stories; this film is especially delicate in its slow way of letting the gravity of the situation become clear. Much scarier than any explosion-filled caper film is the simple assessment from the ship's master builder, played with great dignity by Victor Garber: "In an hour or so, all this will be at the bottom of the Atlantic."
As Mr. Cameron joked during production, about a film that pitilessly observes the different plights of the rich and the poor, "We're holding just short of Marxist dogma." (A lavish "Titanic" coffee table book from HarperCollins is filled with fascinating data about the film, from the director's casual asides to accounts of the technological wizardry, like computerized hydraulics, that were devised for repeatedly sinking the ship.) By this point, the audience knows the ship so fully, from Cal and Rose's elaborate suite to the depths of the boiler room, that the film is on shockingly familiar territory as Rose searches every newly waterlogged area for Jack.
Very much to Mr. Cameron's credit is the lack of logistical confusion. Indeed, the film's modern-day characters even watch a computerized version of how the ship split and then rose vertically just before it plunged straight down, events that are later re-enacted with awesome power. Despite all this advance information and the revelation that Rose lives to be 101, "Titanic" still sustains an extraordinary degree of suspense.
Tiny, devastating touches -- how the same doll whose face rests on the ocean floor in 1996 is clutched in the arms of a pretty little girl who idolizes Jack, or a four-hanky coda seen in Rose's dream -- work as well as the film's big spectacle in giving the tragedy of "Titanic" its full dramatic impact. Though many of the story's minor characters are one-note (hardly the case with Kathy Bates's hearty Molly Brown or Bernard Hill's brave captain), the cumulative effect of their presence is anything but shallow.
Beyond its romance, "Titanic" offers an indelibly wrenching story of blind arrogance and its terrible consequences. It's the rare Hollywood adventure film that brings mythic images of tragedy -- the fall of Icarus, the ruin of Ozymandias -- so easily to mind.
The irony is that Mr. Cameron's "Titanic" is such a Titanic in its own right, a presumptuous reach for greatness against all reasonable odds. The film itself gambles everything on visual splendor and technological accomplishment, which is one reason its extravagance is fully justified on screen. But if Mr. Cameron's own brazenness echoes that seen in his story, remember the essential difference. This "Titanic" is too good to sink.
"Titanic" is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). It includes partial nudity, one brief sexual situation, mild profanity and the soul-shaking sight of a great ship going down.

HEADLINE: TV WEEKEND;
Thicker Than Water, Oil, Whatever

BYLINE: By Caryn James 

 BODY:
The full title "Horton Foote's 'Alone' " is the first sign that this Showtime film offers something rare. Writers are not often billed as star creators, and then only if they are commercial behemoths, a Stephen King or a Tom Clancy. But no one deserves top billing more than Mr. Foote, who in his long career as a playwright and screenwriter has never looked down on the movies; he has brought the same honesty and eloquence to films like "To Kill a Mockingbird" and "Tender Mercies" as he has to the theater, most recently in his profoundly moving play "The Young Man From Atlanta" (which won the 1995 Pulitzer Prize).
Like so much of Mr. Foote's best work, "Alone" captures the deep current of emotion beneath day-to-day events in the life of a Texas family. Hume Cronyn, who has fallen into too many cranky geezer roles lately, is unexpectedly endearing as John Webb, a gentle widower who lives alone on his struggling farm. Though the plot concerns the possibility of finding oil on his land, the story is truly about how families stay together and pull apart, as if all the relatives were caught in an elaborate, delicate-looking web made of steel. 
 Mr. Cronyn brings a wise smile to the role of Webb. He is a strong man whose loneliness after the loss of his wife of 52 years surfaces now and then, quickly and briefly in offhand remarks, only to be hidden again. Webb's two nephews and their wives, who own half the mineral rights to the land, are desperate for him to accept an oil company's offer.
The extended family is beautifully cast. Chris Cooper is especially touching and natural as the nephew always called Gus Jr., who is out of work and prone to painful headaches. A lesser writer would have handed Gus Jr. a brain tumor at the end; it is a mark of Mr. Foote's subtlety that those headaches remain as mysterious to us as they do to the family.
Frederic Forrest is Gus Jr.'s brother, Carl. The brothers have no strong feelings for their uncle, but together they attempt, without much success, to be discreet in trying to push the old man around. The wives reflect their husbands' hopes and add flashes of humor. Hallie Foote plays Gus Jr.'s wife, Agnes, impatient with their three surly children. Shelley Duvall is Carl's wife, Estelle, who has recently been told by a fortune teller that she will get rich.
Though Webb's two daughters live a drive away in Houston and are married with grown children, they have not lost their need for their father. It is a bold, revealing touch that Jacqueline (Joanna Miles) has white hair, as well as the hard luck that makes her and her unemployed husband move back to the farm.
Though the refrain heard throughout the story is, "Do you think they'll find oil?," Mr. Foote's dialogue is never portentous; instead it is translucent, allowing us to look below the surface of entirely natural speech and grasp the emotions it masks. "How can I help you children?" Webb asks Jacqueline and her husband, using the ordinary yet powerful phrasing of fathers everywhere.
James Earl Jones has a small role as Webb's friend and contemporary, who understands the way roots and families are made. Flawlessly directed by Michael Lindsay-Hogg (best known for "Brideshead Revisited"), "Alone" captures that poignant balance of friendship and family, of endurance and change. A quiet anomaly among television films, it is also among the year's most bracing achievements.
 
'A Christmas Memory'
CBS, Sunday night
(Channel 2, New York, at 9)
Though Christmas is usually the time for treacly movies and tired music specials, sometimes it brings out fine programs, too. In this lovely new version of Truman Capote's unabashedly nostalgic story "A Christmas Memory," Patty Duke is Sook, the aging, childlike cousin who is the best friend of young Buddy (Eric Lloyd), the autobiographical hero. Set in the Depression, the story focuses on Sook and Buddy's holiday ritual of baking fruitcakes as gifts. This, it turns out, will be their last year together. Buddy will soon be sent to military school, away from the house where he is being raised by his old cousins, including Sook's two sisters (Piper Laurie as the stern Jennie and Anita Gillette as the soft-hearted Callie) and their hypochondriacal brother (Jeffrey DeMunn).
Ms. Duke gives Sook a spirited will to go along with her sensitivity, setting this interpretation apart from Geraldine Page's fluttery version from the 1960's. Though a bit too long, this beautifully textured "Christmas Memory" is wonderfully warm and sweet.
How did the real Buddy become a writer infatuated with his own celebrity? You can find out in the smart, dryly named documentary "Truman Capote: The Tiny Terror" (A&E's "Biography This Week," on Saturday at 8.) It includes a clip from the original "Christmas Memory," with Capote's own drawling narration.
