HEADLINE: For the New Maestro at the Met, A Dashing Career to His Own Beat

BYLINE: By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
Most important musical careers develop progressively, from step to logical next step. Not the career of the dynamic Russian conductor Valery Gergiyev.
In 1977, at the age of 24, he took second prize in the Herbert von Karajan Competition for conductors and led the Berlin Philharmonic in a performance of Tchaikovsky's "Pathetique" Symphony, bypassing the normal route to such a prestigious engagement: years of conducting in the provinces and steady growth. That same year, he began his association with the Kirov Opera in Leningrad, now St. Petersburg, rising in just 10 years from assistant musical director to permanent conductor to artistic director of the entire Maryinsky Theater, home to the Kirov Opera and Ballet. There, he received, essentially, on-the-job training. 
 "My career in opera was totally unprepared," Mr. Gergiyev said the other day, while having breakfast near Lincoln Center before a morning rehearsal at the Metropolitan Opera House. "I arrived at the Kirov with no experience in opera. When I was young, I was not even interested in opera. And I conducted the Berlin Philharmonic before I conducted any serious Russian orchestra."
"My career," he added, "has been not in order."
His career may not have been in order, but it is thriving. At 44, Mr. Gergiyev is one of the most sought-after conductors of his generation. Tonight he conducts the first of seven performances at the Met of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov," his first appearance there since the company announced that, starting next year, he would assume a new position: principal guest conductor. This comes after only three prior engagements.
In 1992, he brought the Kirov Opera to the Met for performances of three Russian works, including "Boris." In 1994, he conducted a new production of Verdi's "Otello" with Placido Domingo in the title role. Mr. Domingo, who had worked with him in Spain, was instrumental in bringing Mr. Gergiyev to the Met. And in the 1995-96 season, he conducted a new production of Tchaikovsky's "Queen of Spades."
Not wishing to be left out, the New York Philharmonic has engaged Mr. Gergiyev for what is in effect a short-term residency, beginning with a New Year's Eve gala, followed by two subscription series programs in the first weeks of January.
What qualities have made him so valued, so quickly? For one, he has the kind of intellect that absorbs everything around him. His English, learned not in the classroom but from travel, is excellent, even eloquent. Citing Beethoven's music as the first to make a decisive impression on him when he was a "young, possibly gifted boy," he speaks of the composer's "clarity of mind" and "imperative energy."
Mr. Gergiyev's own mind, it seems, has been focused on serious matters and high culture. As he talks over breakfast, by chance an acquaintance from the Boston Symphony Orchestra walks past with her friend James Taylor and introduces the two musicians. Afterward, Mr. Gergiyev admits to having never heard of James Taylor.
 
Before the Baton
Another factor in his success is his early musical training, which, however out of order, was rigorous. As a boy, he studied piano seriously, though he was just as interested in soccer and table tennis. But when the conductor Anatoly Briskin heard Mr. Gergiyev perform as a pianist, he took him on as a student, insisting that he would be a conductor.
The initial lessons were not about baton technique. "As the first thing, he asked me to learn to play from memory on the piano every part of Mozart's G minor Symphony, starting with the viola part," Mr. Gergiyev explained. "This was the way he expected me to master scores."
As with all exceptional talents, Mr. Gergiyev's has a large component of intuition, which made him a natural for dramatic music, once he turned to it. The soprano Renee Fleming, who has worked often with Mr. Gergiyev, describes the visceral excitement of his music-making.
"He pulls drama out of every phrase," she said during a telephone interview from Paris. "When he conducts the storm scene in 'Otello,' I feel like I'm caught in a storm."
Ms. Fleming was in the audience at the San Francisco Opera House when Mr. Gergiyev led a performance of Prokofiev's bizarre and musically incandescent opera "The Fiery Angel," and she said she would never forget it. "I was out of my seat," she said. "Valery is a shot in the arm for the opera world."
 
Family and Mountains
Conductors cannot inspire this kind of response with technical brilliance alone. It takes charisma, and Mr. Gergiyev, in his solemn way, has it. Tall and lanky, he is balletic and incisive on the podium. With his shock of thinning black hair and quick intelligence, he exudes energy. But there is sensitivity in his sad greenish eyes and delicate white fingers, which comes through in his work.
Asked to account for his achievements, Mr. Gergiyev places his family and heritage before any teacher. Though born in Moscow, he was raised in Vladikavkaz, the largest city of Ossetia in the northern region of the Caucasus Mountains. Many historians, Mr. Gergiyev explained, believe that the ancient Scythians, possibly the first inhabitants of Russia, came from there.
"Who I am is very much because of my parents," he said. His father, an army enlistee who rose to the rank of major during World War II, took his wife and three children on frequent hiking trips to the rugged nearby mountains, with "their fast rivers and wild animals," Mr. Gergiyev recalled. "You would have to compare these high mountains to Peru," he added. "The Swiss Alps are too mild."
His father died when Mr. Gergiyev was 14, leaving his indomitable mother, who worked in electronics, to rear the family. Today, Mr. Gergiyev, who is unmarried, shares two adjacent apartments in St. Petersburg with his mother, a sister and his sister's family. "I call them three or four times a day when I'm away," he said. "They give me connection and stability."
His mother, Mr. Gergiyev believes, first saw his "destiny" as a musician, and directed him to the Leningrad Conservatory. There, he studied with Ilya Musin, "one of the great teachers of the century," Mr. Gergiyev called him, who, at 94, still conducts major orchestras like the Royal Philharmonic in London.
Mr. Gergiyev's sense of heritage and constancy informs his leadership of the Kirov. During his tenure the company has gained international renown for its authoritative productions of Russian operas, both staples like Tchaikovsky's "Eugene Onegin," and previously neglected works like Prokofiev's "Betrothal in a Monastery," one of four operas that Mr. Gergiyev will conduct when he brings the Kirov Opera to the Met for a two-week festival in the spring.
 
Consistently High Quality
But under Mr. Gergiyev, the Kirov has also excelled in Italian and German opera. Recently he conducted Wagner's "Parsifal" with Mr. Domingo in the title role, a performance taped for video release. And a recent Philips recording of Verdi's "Forza del Destino" in its original 1862 version, which was written for the Imperial Theater in St. Petersburg, was critically hailed. Indeed, the quality of Mr. Gergiyev's work with his company is so consistently high that Philips has produced a continuing series of complete Russian operas recorded live at the Kirov.
"I stay at the Kirov because I believe in the place," Mr. Gergiyev said. "If you change your commitment every few years, you lose concentration."
The sets and costumes for the Met's "Boris Godunov" date from 1974. But everything else about the production will be newsworthy. Except for the American bass Samuel Ramey, who sings Boris, all the lead singers are Russian colleagues of Mr. Gergiyev's, including, in her much awaited Met debut, the mezzo-soprano Olga Borodina, who is to perform Marina despite being almost visibly pregnant.
These performances will also serve as the tryout for a new orchestration of the opera prepared by Igor Buketoff, an American conductor and historian of Russian heritage. Mussorgsky was not well trained in orchestration. Whether his original scoring is crude and uninformed, or spare and striking, has been much debated. For years, the opera was known through the lush orchestration prepared by Rimsky-Korsakov. There have been others, including a beefy, brassy, modernist orchestration by Shostakovich.
Mr. Gergiyev essentially believes in the original version, but acknowledges its shortcomings. "You can achieve about 90 percent of the desired effect with Mussorgsky's orchestration," he said. "But there are passages that are impossible: two trombones alone, nothing else, or soft pizzicato strings and loud brass together."
When he performs the original version, he alters the score without compunction. The new version he will introduce is a pragmatic synthesis, what Mr. Buketoff came up with after "a long, quiet talk with Mussorgsky, Rimsky-Korsakov and Shostakovich," Mr. Gergiyev said. "It is more formal, more polite."
"But," he added, "this may be best for a large house like the Met."
Still, Mr. Gergiyev felt that even Mr. Buketoff's work needed adjustments, and in rehearsal with the orchestra the other day, he was uninhibited about making them.
At one point he said to the brass players: "The trumpets give a nice, bright color when they appear once in a while. But the way it is orchestrated here they become too much a presence in a long passage. So let's cut them."
Later, he asked that a slow, ominous, alternating triplet figure in the lowest range of the basses be more varied. But this could be corrected without changing the orchestration. "Make it sound like a slithering snake," he said.
 
World of the Met
Afterward, explaining his decision to accept the Met post, he spoke of the orchestra, which works, he said, like "a cooperative, responsible, collective friend," and of the company's world-class stature. He is also impressed by the organization of the place, especially compared with the Kirov.
The finances of the Kirov are as shaky as the Russian economy. But the precariousness has an up side: spontaneity.
"At the Kirov I am more or less free," he said. "If I decide next year I want to do, say, 'Pelleas et Melisande,' I can do it. That gives me flexibility. But it creates difficulty."
 
'The Best of Both Worlds'
The Met is the opposite, he said. "I know I am committed to a rehearsal at 11 A.M. on Wednesday in the year 2000," he said. "But that is why the Met is so strong. I hope I will be able to bring some of that organization to the Kirov. But for me now, I have the best of both worlds."
Joseph Volpe, the general manager of the Met, cites Mr. Gergiyev's appointment as a big step in addressing a persistent charge of critics: the lack of big-name guest conductors on the roster.
"People claim James Levine is hogging everything, but that is just not true," Mr. Volpe said. "Most important conductors cannot commit the time required to rehearse and perform an opera here over a period of many weeks. But in bringing Valery to the Met, we are really beginning to get the world's premier conductors into the house. And it's the work that interests him, not some chance to build his reputation."
Mr. Gergiyev agrees.
"I am not coming to the Met for more reviews and more applause. I have already done my third and fourth performances with the major orchestras and companies in the world. That is behind me. But maybe I can bring a certain kind of color, repertory and life to this institution."
 
Where and When Gergiyev Will Conduct
 Valery Gergiyev is to conduct Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov" at the Metropolitan Opera tonight at 7:30. Tickets: $40 to $200. Other performances of the opera that Mr. Gergiyev is to conduct at the Met are Dec. 22, 26, 30, Jan. 3, 6 and 10. Information: (212) 362-6000.
 Mr. Gergiyev is to conduct the New York Philharmonic for the orchestra's New Year's Eve gala starting at 8 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall. The concert, with performances by the bass Samuel Ramey and the mezzo-soprano Olga Borodina as well as the pianist Alexander Toradze, will include selections from Tchaikovsky's "Sleeping Beauty," selections from Bizet's "Carmen" and Ravel's Piano Concerto in G. Tickets: $30 to $125.
 On Jan. 2, 3 and 5, Mr. Gergiyev is to conduct the Philharmonic at Fisher Hall at 8 P.M. in a program featuring Mahler's Symphony No. 6. Tickets: $16 to $70.
 On Jan. 8, 9, 10 and 12, he is to conduct the Philharmonic at Fisher Hall in a program including Tchaikovsky's Piano Concerto No. 1 and Stravinsky's "Rite of Spring." The pianist is Grigory Sokolov. The Jan. 8 and 12 concerts begin at 8 P.M.; the Jan. 9 concert starts at 11 A.M., and the Jan. 10 performance is at 2 P.M. Tickets: $16 to $70.
 Information for the Philharmonic concerts: (212) 721-6500.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Philadelphia Fed Report Lifts Bond Prices

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rallied yesterday, after a report showed a slump in manufacturing in the Philadelphia region and was thought to suggest that Asia's turmoil might be slowing economic growth in the United States.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 30/32, to 102 23/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.93 percent from 6 percent. 
 The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported yesterday that its index of regional manufacturing unexpectedly fell to -1.3 this month from 10.1 in November, the first negative reading in a year. A reading of less than zero means more manufacturers are reporting weaker business than increased activity.
The report "obviously is pretty positive for bonds," said Garth Nisbet, who manages $750 million of bonds at Crabbe Huson Group in Portland, Ore. Thirty-year bond yields could fall as low as 5.5 percent in the first half of next year, he said.
Worries about Asia's impact on the United States economy drove stocks down -- raising the allure of Treasury securities, traders said. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 110.91 points, or 1.4 percent.
"Asia may really be having an impact," said Robert Blakemore, who oversees the management of $200 million of assets at National Bank of Arizona in Phoenix. "With the Philly Fed number this morning, it looks like manufacturing activity could slow."
Bonds also rose as the dollar gained against the yen on speculation that a package of tax cuts will do little to spur Japan's economy.
"The vote in the bond market is that the Japanese plan won't be the watershed event to change the Asian outlook," said Patrick Dimick, a government bond strategist at UBS Securities.
The bond market will next turn its attention to supply as the Treasury sells $26 billion in new notes. The two-year note is to be auctioned on Monday, and the five-year note on Tuesday.
In when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.64 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 5.70 percent.

HEADLINE: Clinton Plans to Lower Another Barrier to Trade With Vietnam

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, citing Vietnam's progress in allowing free emigration, intends to move toward more normal trading relations with Hanoi, officials said today.
President Clinton has notified members of Congress that he expects early next year to grant Vietnam a waiver from the Jackson-Vanik Amendment, which bars full economic ties with nations that restrict travel and emigration. 
 White House and State Department officials said today that Vietnam permits its citizens to leave freely and has assisted in resettling thousands of Vietnamese refugees who had been living in camps elsewhere in Asia.
The Administration's intention to move toward fuller trade ties was first reported today by The Los Angeles Times.
The waiver paves the way for normal trading relations, known as most-favored-nation status. American business groups have been pressing for the waiver because it will permit Government agencies to provide financing and loan guarantees for the purchase of American-made goods by Vietnam.
Trade between the United States and Vietnam last year totaled $1 billion. Business groups expect trade with the rapidly modernizing nation to grow dramatically when all barriers are lifted.
But full economic ties are still probably at least a year away. Even if Congress accepts the waiver, Washington and Hanoi must still negotiate a trade and investment treaty; those talks are in preliminary stages.
Some Congressional opposition is expected from members who do not believe Hanoi has told everything it knows about American servicemen missing in the Vietnam War. But the Administration is likely to prevail because of the large opportunities for American businesses.
The waiver would permit the Export-Import Bank to underwrite loans for American businesses selling goods in Vietnam and lift one barrier to providing insurance against political risk by the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. But the law governing such insurance sets several other hurdles that Vietnam may have trouble surmounting, including a prohibition on the use of forced labor, which human rights groups say exists in Vietnam.
Samuel R. Berger, the White House national security adviser, said today that the Administration is largely satisfied with Vietnam's cooperation on missing servicemen, an issue that for years blocked establishment of diplomatic ties. That came in 1995, two decades after the end of the bitter war.
"In addition, Vietnam has established a very solid record on implementation of emigration policies," Mr. Berger said. Other necessary consultations are taking place, he said, adding, "If those consultations go well, I would expect that we would go forward."
Senator Craig Thomas, Republican of Wyoming and chairman of the East Asia subcommittee of the Foreign Relations Committee, said in an interview that he expected an extensive debate in Congress over the waiver. But he predicted that the Administration and American businesses would ultimately succeed.
"This brings us back to the old question of whether we can best influence their behavior by opening relations further or by standing at arm's length," Mr. Thomas said. "I don't agree that trade is the most important thing in the world. But I do believe that it gives us an entree to make the kinds of changes that are of critical value to us."

HEADLINE: Dollar Is Up Against the Yen and the Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rebounded against the yen yesterday from Wednesday's decline amid questions whether Japan's central bank would keep supporting its currency and concerns that Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto's measures to stimulate the economy might not be strong enough.
The dollar's strength against the yen extended somewhat, as well, to the German mark. 
 In New York yesterday, the dollar moved as high as 129.45 yen before settling at 128.72 yen, up from 127.08 Wednesday. It rose to 1.7757 marks from 1.7735. The dollar declined against the British pound, which settled at $1.6653, up from $1.6521.
Japan's economic troubles could persist despite Mr. Hashimoto's announcement Wednesday that a two trillion yen income tax cut, as well as public works spending and corporate tax cuts, would be included in an economic-stimulus package. Some economists said an income tax cut of five trillion yen, or nearly $40 billion, would have been better.
Analysts said the yen-dollar exchange rate might rise with central bank intervention, but would eventually reflect the state of Japan's underlying economy. They noted some forecasts of 140 yen to the dollar.
Some in the currency market spent the session considering the chance of another intervention by the Bank of Japan similar to its dollar sales and yen purchases on Wednesday, perhaps around $3.4 billion worth. They indicated the central bank would await price weakness to intervene, for maximum effect.
Thin trading ahead of the year-end holidays magnified the dollar's rise against the yen yesterday, leading some to discount its importance. "The lack of liquidity in the market today brought about a very sharp and violent move in dollar-yen," said John McCarthy, senior vice president at ING Barings Capital Markets. "There was no news out."
The dollar got some support from news that the American trade deficit in October narrowed to $9.7 billion, below expectations of $10.8 billion.

HEADLINE: DECISION IN BOSNIA;
In the President's Words: Toward 'a Lasting Peace'

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of the White House news conference yesterday in which President Clinton announced a commitment in principle to extend the stay of American troops in Bosnia and Herzegovina beyond June 1998, the expiration date of the mandate for the NATO peacekeeping force now stationed there. The transcript was prepared by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company.
 
OPENING STATEMENT
I want to speak with you today about the progress we have made toward a lasting peace in Bosnia and the challenges that still must be faced in order to finish the job. 
 For nearly four years, Bosnia was the battleground for the bloodiest war in Europe since World War II. The conflict killed or wounded one out of every 10 Bosnians. It drove half the country's people from their homes, left 9 out of 10 of them unemployed.
We will never be able to forget the mass graves, the women and young girls victimized by systematic campaigns of rape, skeletal prisoners locked behind barbed-wire fences, endless lines of refugees marching toward a future of despair.
The war in Bosnia was abhorrent to our values. It also threatened our national interests. We have learned the hard way in this century that Europe's stability and America's security are joined. The war threatened to explode into a broader conflict in the Balkans, endangering the vital interests of allies like Greece and Turkey and undermining our efforts to build a peaceful, undivided and democratic Europe. Then, two years ago, in Dayton, Ohio, American leadership helped to end the war in Bosnia. With our allies in NATO and others, we launched an extraordinary military and political effort to implement the peace agreement.
Twenty-four months later, by almost any measure, the lives of Bosnia's people are better and their hopes for the future are brighter. Consider what we have achieved together:
We ended the fighting and the bloodshed, separating rival armies, demobilizing more than 350,000 troops, destroying almost 6,600 heavy weapons.
We helped Bosnians to put in place national democratic institutions, including a presidency, a parliament, a Supreme Court, and hold peaceful and free elections for all levels of government, with turnouts exceeding 70 percent.
We've begun to restore normal life, repairing roads and schools, electricity and water, heat and sewage, doubling economic output, quadrupling wages. Unemployment in the Bosnian-Croat Federation has been cut from 90 percent to 50 percent.
We're helping the Bosnians to provide for their own security, training ethnically integrated police forces in the Federation, taking the first steps toward a professional, democratic police force in the Serb Republic.
We've helped to turn the media from an instrument of war into a force for peace, stifling the inflammatory radio and television broadcasts that helped to fuel the conflict.
And we've provided a secure environment for 350,000 displaced persons to return to their homes, while bringing 22 war criminals to justice.
Just a few hours ago SFOR captured and transported to The Hague two more war crimes suspects.
The progress is unmistakable, but it is not yet irreversible. Bosnia has been at peace only half as long as it was at war. It remains poised on a tightrope, moving toward a better future, but not at the point yet of a self-sustaining peace. To get there, the people of Bosnia still need the safety net and the helping hand not only of the international -- that only the international community, including the United States, can provide.
Our assistance must be two-fold. First, we must intensify our civilian and economic engagement. As a result of the progress we've achieved in recent months, we know where to focus our efforts. Civilian and voluntary agencies, working with Bosnian authorities, must help to do the following things:
First, deepen and spread economic opportunity while rooting out corruption. Second, reform, retrain and re-equip the police. Third, restructure the state-run media to meet international standards of objectivity and access, and establish alternative, independent media. Fourth, help more refugees return home. And fifth, make indicted war criminals answer for their crimes, both as a matter of justice and because they are stumbling blocks to lasting stability.
The second thing we must do is to continue to provide an international military presence that will enable these efforts to proceed in an atmosphere of confidence. Our progress in Bosnia to date would not have been possible without the secure environment created first by IFOR, now by SFOR. They've allowed dozens of civilian agencies and literally hundreds of voluntary agencies to do their job in security, laying the foundation for a self-sustaining peace.
In authorizing American troops to take part in the SFOR mission, I said the mission would end in 18 months, in June of 1998. It was my expectation that by that time we would have rebuilt enough of Bosnia's economic and political life to continue the work without continuing outside military support. But following intensive consultations with my national security and military advisers, with our NATO allies and with leaders from both parties in Congress, it has become clear that the progress we've seen in Bosnia, in order for it to continue, a follow-on military force led by NATO will be necessary after SFOR ends. America is a leader of NATO, and America should participate in that force.
Therefore, I have instructed our representative to NATO to inform our allies that, in principle, the United States will take part in a security presence in Bosnia when SFOR withdraws this summer.
The agreement, in principle, will become a commitment only when I have approved the action plan NATO's military authorities will develop and present, early next year, after careful study of all the options. The details of that plan, including the mission's specific objectives, its size and its duration, must be agreed to by all NATO allies.
Without prejudging the details, let me make clear the key criteria the plan must meet for me to approve the United States's participation:
First, the mission must be achievable and tied to concrete benchmarks, not a deadline. We should have clear objectives that when set -- when met -- will create a self-sustaining, secure environment and allow us to remove our troops.
Second, the force must be able to protect itself. Over two years, we have steadily decreased the number of our troops in Bosnia, from about 27,000 Americans in IFOR in 1996 to 8,500 in SFOR today. I hope the follow-on force will be smaller, but I will insist it be sufficient in number and in equipment to achieve its mission and to protect itself in safety.
Third, the United States must retain command. Time and again, events have proven that American leadership is crucial to decisive collective action.
Fourth, our European allies must assume their share of responsibility. Now, Europe and other partners are already doing a great deal; providing three times as many troops as we are, five times as much economic assistance, nine times as many international police; 10 times as many refugees have been received by them. And while Bosnia is a challenge to American interests and values, the longer-term and fundamental challenge is to make Bosnia a genuine part of Europe. And we hope the Europeans will do more.
Fifth, the cost must be manageable.
And sixth and finally, the plan must have substantial support from Congress and the American people. I have been pleased with the spirit and the substance of our consultations with leading members of both parties. As we develop the details of the new NATO mission, these consultations must and will continue.
I am pleased that members of both parties in both houses of Congress have accepted my invitation to go to Bosnia with me when I leave in a couple of days.
All of us have a duty to explain the stakes in Bosnia to the American people, and I will do my very best to shoulder my responsibility for that.
Now some say a lasting peace in Bosnia is impossible, and therefore we should end our efforts now, in June, and/or allow the country to be partitioned along ethnic lines. I believe they're profoundly wrong. A full and fair reading of Bosnia's history and an honest assessment of the progress of the last 23 months simply refutes the proposition that the Dayton peace agreement cannot work. But if we pull out before the job is done, Bosnia almost certainly will fall back into violence, chaos, and, ultimately, a war every bit as bloody as the one that was stopped.
And partition is not a good alternative. It would sanction the horrors of ethnic cleansing and send the wrong signal to extremists everywhere. At best, partition would require a peacekeeping force to patrol a volatile border for years to come. More likely it would set the stage also for renewed conflict.
A lasting peace is possible along the lines of the Dayton peace agreement. For decades Muslims, Croats, and Serbs lived together, worked together, raised their families together. Thanks to the investments of America and others in Bosnia over the past two years, they have begun again to lead more normal lives.
Ultimately, Bosnia's future is in the hands of its own people. But we can help them make it a future of peace. We should finish the job we began, for the sake of that future and in the service of our own interests and values.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
Q. Mr. President, a number of Americans are understandably going to be concerned about an open-ended U.S. military commitment to Bosnia. Can you at least assure the American people that by the time you leave office little more than three years from now, those American troops will be out of Bosnia?
A. Well, in order to answer that, let's go back and see what our experience has been. First of all, the big military mission, IFOR, really was completed within a year. In fact, it was completed in less than a year. That is, the robust, large military presence we needed there -- I think we had over 60,000 total allied troops there -- to end the war, separate the forces, establish the separation zone between the parties, it was achieved quickly and with remarkable peace and remarkably low loss of life for all of our allied forces who were there.
But then we went to the smaller force to try to support the civilian implementation of the Dayton agreement. Now, what has happened? An enormous amount of progress has been made. We don't believe the peace is self-sustaining. I think the responsible thing for me to do, since I do not believe we can meet the 18-month deadline, and no one I know now believes that, is to say to the American people what the benchmarks are.
What are the benchmarks? Let's talk about that. Can they be achieved in the near term? I believe they can. Do I think we should have a permanent presence in Bosnia? No. I don't believe this is like Germany after World War II, or in the cold war, or Korea after the Korean War. This is not what I'm suggesting here. But what are the benchmarks?
First let me say the final set of benchmarks must be developed by our NATO allies working with us. But let me give you just some of the things that I think we ought to be asking ourselves.
Number one, are the joint institutions strong enough to be self-
sustaining after the military operation? Number two, have the political parties really given up the so-called state-run media that have been instruments of hate and venom? Number three, is the civilian police large enough, well-trained enough, well-managed enough to do the job it has to do?
Those are just some of the benchmarks, I think -- when we go through this, I want a full public discussion of it. But I will say again, I understand your job is to try to get the deadline nailed down; but we tried it in this SFOR period, and it turned out we were wrong. I am not suggesting a permanent presence in Bosnia. I am suggesting that it's a more honest thing to do to say what our objectives are and that these objectives should be pursued, and they can be pursued at an affordable cost with fair burden-sharing with the Europeans. If that can be done, we should pursue them.
 Q. Mr. President, the lead prosecutor in the war crimes tribunal says that Mladic and Karadzic can rest easy because the French won't try to capture them. What is the United States willing to do to bring these men to justice?
A. Well, I don't want to comment on what the prosecutor has said about the French. I can tell you this, that, you know, we were involved this morning with the Dutch. And it was in their sector, and they took the lead. They asked us for support, just like we were involved with the British, not very long ago, when they made their arrests.
And we believe that provision of the Dayton agreement is important, as I said again today, and we think that all of us who are there should be prepared to do what is appropriate to implement it. And I think that having said that, the less I say from now on in, the better.
We believe the war-crimes process is an important part of Dayton. The United States, indeed, is supporting an international, permanent war crimes tribunal. Even as we speak, we've got countries working on trying to establish that.
Q. Mr. President, Sir, one of the benchmarks you listed was the willingness of the political parties there, really, to work toward progress. Does that not make us hostages of those political figures there, particularly those who don't want progress? They can simply undermine the attempt to reach that benchmark and keep U.S. troops there forever.
A. Well, let me -- I don't think I was clear about that. But what I mean is the willingness of the political parties, or whether they're willing or not, our capacity to stop them from, in effect, perverting the state-run media and using them as an instrument of violence and suppression. I don't think it's necessary for us to stay until -- until everybody wants to go have tea together at 4 in the afternoon, in a civil environment.
I think it's a -- I do think that there are -- and again, let me say we will -- we will make public a final set of benchmarks before we go forward with this. And our allies have to work on this. I'm just telling what my thoughts are.
But -- but if you look at where we've really had problems -- or let's, let's flip the question, say. Why do we think we still need some military presence there after June? I think because there is -- there -- we believe there is more venom still in the political system than there otherwise would have been if there had been no perversion of the so-called state-run media by the political parties that control them. We believe that if the joint institutions were working a little more effectively, they would -- the people would see the benefits of the joint institutions more than they will by June.
We -- we're grateful that there are 2,000 civilian police working there. And I might say while the United States has put up 90 percent of the money, as I've said, the Europeans have put up 90 percent of the personnel for the training and the preparation of the civilian police. But there should be more.
So I think that's what we have to do. I do not want to hold us hostage to the feelings of the people of Bosnia, although I believe the feelings will change as the facts of life change. But I do think we should stay there until we believe we've got the job done.
 Q. Mr. President, how did you get Secretary Cohen on board on this? And you know, the whole public perception -- unless you go after the highest-profile alleged war criminals, it doesn't have much of an impact. Why the restraint?
A. Well, first of all, the circumstances under which the SFOR troops will apprehend war criminals have been fairly well-defined. We did not send SFOR there to mount major military campaigns. Secondly, I don't want to discuss the circumstances in detail under which we might or might not go after anyone. But let me go to the point underlying your question, I think it is, which is, can this peace be made to work unless Mr. Karadzic is arrested? I mean, let's just sort of get to the bottom line here.
I think the answer to that is, under the right circumstances. That is, if he flees the country, if he's deep enough underground, if he can't have any impact on it, we might make the peace work anyway. After all, a great deal of progress has been made. I would point out that more progress has been made in the Bosnian Croat -- the Muslim-Croat Federation part of Bosnia economically than in the Serbian part, in part because reactionary elements there have resisted doing the right thing across the board in many areas.
Q. Are you considering aid for Serbia in that respect?
A. Well, I'm considering -- what I'm going to do is to work with the allies to implement the Dayton accords. And our position is going to be we're going to support the people that are trying to implement the Dayton framework and we're going to oppose those who are opposing it, in all specifics. If you use that benchmark, I think it will get you there.
Q. Mr. President, just to help wrap up this by asking you the question -- a lot of Republican critics of yours are suggesting that your credibility was undermined on Bosnia by imposing these two deadlines which you failed to meet, and knowing that some of your own advisers at the time were saying don't give these deadlines because they're unrealistic, that the job can't be done within a year or within 18 months.
So how do you answer your critics now, like Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison or Arlen Specter or Newt Gingrich, who say that you have to prove your credibility because you failed to honor these two earlier imposed deadlines?
A. Well first of all, let me say I have a fundamentally different view of the first deadline. I mean, we did -- the mission I defined for IFOR was achieved, and it was achieved before a year was out. And I was -- it's not worth going through and rewriting history there about who said what at the time. I did think that in 18 months -- I honestly believed in 18 months, we could get this done at the time I said it. And it wasn't -- I wasn't right, which is why I don't want to make that error again.
Now, having acknowledged the error I made, let's look at what we were right about. Let's flip this around before we get too much into who was right about what happened on the -- after 18 months.
What has happened? With the leadership of the United States, NATO and its allies, including Russia, working side by side, ended almost overnight and with virtually no bloodshed, the worst war in Europe since World War II. We have seen democratic elections, with 70-percent participation, take place. Hundreds of thousands of people have been able to go home under circumstances that were difficult to say the least. Economic growth has resumed. Infrastructure has been rebuilt. The conditions of normal life have come back for tens of thousands, hundreds of thousands, of people.
So if I take the hit for being wrong about the timetable, I would like some acknowledgment that, in the larger issue here, the United States and its allies were right to undertake this mission and that the results of the mission have been very, very good. They have justified the effort. And the cost of the mission in lives and treasure, to the United States and to its allies, has been much lower than even the most ardent supporters of the mission thought that it would be.
So I think -- I don't mind taking a hit for being wrong about the timetable. But after the hit is dished out, I would like the larger truth looked at; that is: Did we do the right thing? Was it in our interests? Did it further our values? Are the American people less likely to be drawn into some other conflict in Europe 10, 20, 30 years from now, where the costs could be far greater, if we make this work? I think they are.
And I'd like to close, basically, with a conversation I had from my opponent in the last election, Senator Dole. I want to give him -- he said something that I thought was very good and pithier than anything I have said about this.
Now, we had a talk about it the other day on the phone, and he said, he said, "Look," he said, "You know, I didn't necessarily agree with all the details about how you got to where you were." But he said: "What's happened in Bosnia? It's like we're in a football game, we're in the fourth quarter, and we're winning. And some people suggest we should walk off the field and forfeit the game. I don't think we should. I think we ought to stay here, finish the game, and collect the win." And that's a pretty good analogy and would do credit to the Senator. I appreciate it. I wish I'd have thought of it myself.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton speaking with reporters in the White House briefing room yesterday as he argued for keeping American troops in Bosnia. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: South Korean Election Results Hearten Emigres in New York

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
When Joseph Seok left South Korea 19 years ago, democracy and economic stability in the country seemed distant, unattainable dreams. So despite the country's recent economic downturn, yesterday's election of Kim Dae Jung, the longtime opposition leader whom Seoul's ruling party had repeatedly tried to have assassinated, greatly heartened Mr. Seouk.
"This is the first time in Korea that the opposition party won," Mr. Seouk, 49, said yesterday afternoon on a sidewalk in Flushing, Queens, as he devoured results of the presidential election in a special edition of The Chosun Daily. "Democracy in Korea has very much improved." 
 In one of the city's Koreatowns, up and down Union Street in Flushing, most Korean-Americans interviewed yesterday reacted positively to the outcome of one of the most important elections in their country's history. Shoppers snapped up special four-page editions of The Chosun Daily, The Korea Central Daily and The Korea Times at the Canaan Bakery, and digested the information at the Koryodang coffee shop.
Although Seoul does not permit nonresident citizens to cast ballots, many Korean-Americans returned briefly to South Korea to volunteer in campaigns, said Pyong Gap Min, a Korean-born sociology professor at Queens College who has written extensively about Korean-Americans. The economic collapse had heightened interest in the election.
But even more significantly, the closeness of the race between Mr. Kim and Lee Hoi Chang in the days leading to the election raised the possibility of a historic moment: the first peaceful transfer of the presidency to the opposition party in modern Korean history. And that prospect resonated deeply among many Korean-Americans, because many of them had immigrated here decades ago from a very different Korea, one where Mr. Kim seemed forever destined to a seat in the political bleachers. In 1987, in one of Mr. Kim's three unsuccessful campaigns, military officers warned that they might stage a coup or kill him if he were elected president.
James Kim, 50, smoking a cigarette on the corner of Union Street and 37th Avenue, said, "I'm happy because the elections ended peacefully." Of the 18 years since he had left South Korea, Mr. Kim said, he is proudest of the fact that the country has moved away from an authoritarian regime.
So yesterday's results put Mr. Kim in a good mood, even though he said he had backed Mr. Lee and believed that the 72-year-old President-elect is too old. What is more, when asked whether he thought Mr. Kim -- who worried bankers and investors by repeatedly calling for the renegotiation of the $57 billion bailout by the International Monetary Fund -- could lead South Korea back to prosperity, James Kim said, "Umm -- I hope so."
Not surprisingly, the ascendancy of a former political pariah -- who spent the 1970's in prison, house arrest or exile -- carried less symbolic meaning for some younger Korean-Americans. At BL Men's Wear, Sun Park, 33, had no customers. She worried that her business, which depends almost completely on Korean-Americans whose pocketbooks are tied to the economic fortunes of Asia, would not revive under Mr. Kim.
"They're all the same: old men with the same ideas," Mrs. Park said of Mr. Kim and the current President, Kim Young-sam. She said she had backed Mr. Lee, who is 62.
At the Koryodang coffee shop, Tae Joon Park, 40, and Jeung Hwan Kim, 28, were poring over the breakdown of the vote by province in The Chosun Daily and commenting on historic regional divisions. Mr. Kim, a recent graduate of the Pratt Institute, marveled that in the President-elect's home base in the southwest, he had won more than 90 percent of the vote. By contrast, in Jeung Hwan Kim's native city, Taegu, in the southeast, the President-elect had drawn only 12.5 percent.
Still, Mr. Kim was optimistic that the President-elect's slim victory would be good for South Korea. "Even if he was elected by a very small margin, I think he will do a very good job, because he has a lot of political experience for more than 30 years," Mr. Kim said. After a few minutes, he added, more cautiously: "Personally, I liked Lee Hoi Chang. I thought Kim Dae Jung was too old. But since he's elected, I hope he'll do a good job."

HEADLINE: U.S. Effort to Cut Its Dues Dies at an Angry U.N.

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The United States effort to lower its United Nations dues is doomed for now, making it even less likely that Congress will release the more than $1 billion America owes the organization.
For years Congress has objected to paying arrears because of complaints about United Nations operations and the financial burden on the United States. But most recently, Congress has tied paying the debt to a reduction in America's dues, and now the other members of the United Nations have replied by making payments on the arrears a condition for reconsidering the level of the American assessment. 
 With a final decision on the amount of America's dues likely in the next few days, the United States is completely isolated in the General Assembly committee determining the issue.
Even traditional allies are rejecting Washington's demand that it pay less than the current 25 percent of the organization's regular annual budget, an amount based on the American share of the world's economy.
At most, delegations are willing to keep open the option of discussing the issue again next year, but only if the United States significantly reduces its overdue bill.
The United States has also been handicapped in fighting efforts by some developing nations to inflate the United Nations budget, which Congress has demanded show no growth.
The third world has already been successful in drastically lowering the dues paid by the poorest nations -- from about $110,000 this year to less than $13,000 annually over the next three years, a move Washington considers irresponsible.
"By our failure to pay our arrears, we have essentially been wiped out of this debate," said Richard Sklar, the American diplomat negotiating budgetary matters.
American diplomats and State Department officials say there has never been a worse time to represent the United States at the United Nations. The resentment against Washington, once muted, is now openly expressed.
Diplomats from a wide range of countries say they are incensed that Americans should expect the near-bankrupt organization to carry out American policies in Iraq, Haiti or other areas, when the United States is more than $1 billion behind in its payments.
"The position of the European Union," a European diplomat said, "is that if the Congress is willing to recognize the damage that is being done to the United States' position at the United Nations -- and indeed the weakening of the U.N. -- and elects then to pay its arrears, then we are prepared to reopen discussion on the scales of assessment." The assessments are normally set for a three-year period.
"That is a sizable concession under the circumstances," the diplomat added.
Both friends of the United States and nations that have often voted against Washington's interests are unanimous in saying that they feel they have been betrayed by Clinton Administration promises that arrears would begin to be paid this year.
Payment of the debt was supposedly worked out earlier this year under a deal between Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and two influential Senators -- Jesse Helms, the Republican of North Carolina who is chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, and Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the ranking Democrat on the committee.
As part of that deal, the Administration and Congress had agreed that the United States would press for a gradual lowering of America's assessment rate from 25 to 20 percent over the next three years.
But the deal collapsed in November when Congressional Republicans blocked payment of the dues and other measures.
Christopher H. Smith, a New Jersey Republican, attached an anti-abortion rider to legislation in Congress that included money for the United Nations, effectively killing the bill. Secretary General Kofi Annan called the action "unreasonable and regrettable."
Congressional aides say they see little hope for many months of reviving the legislation that was blocked in November.
But Senator Judd Gregg, the New Hampshire Republican who is chairman of the Senate appropriations subcommittee that oversees payments to international organizations, said in an interview today that the deal with the Administration, which he helped draft, was still very much alive.
"That agreement is still in place and will be executed as soon as we clear this ancillary, extraneous issue that has nothing to do with the U.N.," he said, referring to the abortion issue. "That will be cleared up."
A refusal by member nations to lower American dues "would merely throw into jeopardy what we thought was a done deal," he said. "Speaking for myself, I'd say there's a darn good chance the money will never be spent if they take this action."
Alvin P. Adams Jr., a former American Ambassador to Haiti and Peru who is president of the United Nations Association, an independent American research and support group, said that the Administration had in essence lost twice: in Congress, where House leaders refused to detach the anti-abortion amendment, and then in the United Nations, where the standoff has significantly lowered American prestige.
"It's a real disgrace for a country that helped inspire and played such a role in the founding of the U.N. and has been a consistent supporter, that legislation, conditional as it was, failed in Washington due to what we believe is an extraneous issue," Mr. Adams said in an interview.
"I don't know what this says about U.S. leadership in the world these days, and the limit others have when looking at that leadership," he said.
Those who call the shots in Congress are going to be unpleasantly surprised, he said. "It plays right into the hands of those who do not mean us a lot of good."
Mr. Sklar, a former businessman who was in charge of the Administration's reconstruction program for Bosnia, has been negotiating the dues issue virtually around the clock for the last few weeks. He said in an interview today that this is "crunch time" for the United Nations and its relationship to Washington.
If the United Nations budget, now set at about $2.585 billion for the next two years, is allowed to grow because of votes in the 185-member General Assembly, Congressional leaders have said they would withhold the money altogether.
American diplomats have had to defend the action by Congress, which has also cut contributions to the separate peacekeeping budget from 31 percent to 25 percent, against charges by other United Nations members who consider Washington in breach of its treaty obligations.
Mr. Sklar said that Congress's action is, however, the reality everyone has to work with.

HEADLINE: Giving at the Home Office;
Municipalities Set New Charges for In-House Businesses

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: TACOMA, Wash.

 BODY:
After enduring countless difficulties setting up an at-home business in a nearby suburb, Joe and Teri Comroe moved here five years ago so they could repair clocks and watches from their house.
The Comroes paid Tacoma $72 for a basic business license to open their Reliable Time Shop, which they run in two rooms of a small house in a neighborhood where each adjoining house also harbors a home-based business. 
 Two years later, the Comroes' business taxes increased after the Tacoma City Council decided to require home businesses to buy an additional license purely for the privilege of operating out of their home. The $122 a year that the Comroes pay may seem trivial, but it illustrates how Tacoma, like many other cities, has found a new, though still modest, source of revenue from the exploding number of home businesses.
"The city calls it a home-occupancy license," Mr. Comroe said, "but it's really just a tax, just a way to take in more money."
In recent years, as many big corporations have downsized and more people have gone into business for themselves, the home-business phenomenon has emerged from obscurity. And many cities, rather than ignoring or trying to suppress it as they often did in the past, are seeking to exploit the trend to their own advantage.
The first step in this process for many cities has been to revise zoning laws that were drafted to prohibit home businesses in an era when many such workplaces were smelly, messy industrial operations, such as repairing car engines.
After that relatively simple step, the most aggressive of these cities have gone much further, both in seeking to make the cities attractive for home businesses and to tap a little vein of revenue from them. And in hunting for unlicensed businesses, they have uncovered many more than they expected. The extra revenue they get from these previously untaxed companies is helping to hold down pressures to raise taxes elsewhere.
Polly Rumbough, the occupational licensing official in Tampa, Fla., said, "We are taxing, not regulating." Her city, she added, now counts on fees from home-based businesses and professionals for $8 million annually, or 2 percent of the city's general operating budget.
Business license fees are not the only levies that apply to home businesses. In many places a gross receipts tax is charged, one that covers not just profit but all revenue. And there are other ways to increase local revenues. In Colorado, for example, a homeowner who converts a couple of rooms into business space may receive a higher property tax bill. That's because commercial real estate is taxed at three times the rate of residences.
Across the country, municipal tax officials say that they often encounter hostility from home-business owners. Many of them assert that they are exempt from taxes because they work from their homes; indeed, a group of Hollywood screenwriters is making that argument now in Federal court.
Nationwide, about 20.7 million households, or one in five, engage in some form of home business, according to surveys by IDC/Link, a research company in New York. That is a 43 percent increase from the estimated 14.2 million households in 1990, said Raymond L. Boggs, the firm's director of home office research.
The survey is consistent with what municipal tax officials from Santa Monica, Calif., to Roanoke, Va., have discovered. They report that 20 percent to 50 percent of the new business licenses they issue these days are for home businesses.
Mr. Boggs said that about 13 million households rely on a home business as their primary source of income, averaging $80,000 in gross receipts annually. There are also about 9 million households with a part-time home business with average receipts of $10,000, he said. The number of full-time and part-time businesses is greater than the total, he said, because some households operate more than one enterprise at home.
Home businesses are flourishing across the country. In Tacoma there are 14,000 registered businesses. Of those, 3,280 operate out of homes, up from 795 just three years ago, according to Duston J. Jensen, Tacoma's tax manager, whose creative approach to finding new sources of revenue has earned him the admiration of municipal tax and business license officials across the country.
The home businesses bring the city $400,000 in annual revenue, or more than $2 a resident, money that Mr. Jensen said "helps us keep down taxes on all the other businesses."
Many of those businesses are found through the aggressive tactics of Mr. Jensen, who is so proud of his position that he drives around with a personalized license plate that reads, "TAXMAN1."
Not every city is as successful as Tacoma. For instance, Minneapolis, with twice the population of Tacoma, has licensed only 12,000 businesses, said James Moncur, the director of licensing there. It is probably missing hundreds -- if not thousands -- of home businesses, experts said.
Indeed, simply locating these businesses can be extraordinarily difficult."When a home-based business relies on brain power married to a computer, telephone and a fax," said Deborah Crowder, revenue manager for Asheville, N.C., "the hard part is finding them. We license them when we can find them."
Mr. Jensen, Ms. Crowder and others use data that the Internal Revenue Service shares with some of the states. City officials are not permitted to obtain financial data on individual Federal taxpayers, but they are entitled to the name, address and the industrial classification code for a taxpayer's line of business.
The I.R.S. data, however, cover only the limited category of sole proprietorships, or Schedule C businesses, and not another type, known as Subchapter S corporations, which are often used by doctors, lawyers and other professionals.
The latest I.R.S. report shows that in 1995 the number of Schedule C's -- the Federal income tax form used by most home-based businesses -- was 16.4 million, up 11 percent from 1990. These sole proprietorships had net income of $169.3 billion in 1995, up nearly 20 percent from 1990. The average proprietorship took in more than $10,000.
Meanwhile, the number of Subchapter S corporations rose more than 13 percent from 1992 to 1994 and revenue nearly doubled from $46.2 billion to $96.1 billion.
How many home-based businesses evade the taxman's gaze, however, is a big unknown. Because many home-based businesses are paid in cash, or by customers who are not required to report the transactions to the Government, many of these businesses operate under the Government's tax radar.
When they do find home-based businesses, municipal tax officials say, the owners often resist submitting to regulation, licensing and taxing out of a mistaken belief that they are exempt from rules that apply to all business.
"People who work out of their homes think they aren't required to have business licenses," said Marsha Compton Fielder, the revenue commissioner for Roanoke, Va. She started to recount the abusive responses of some people who are told to get a license, but then paused and said, "Some are nicer than others."
The most widely known fight against such municipal licensing is taking place in Los Angeles, where lawsuits have been brought against the city by a group of screenwriters. Earlier this year the City Council changed the zoning ordinance, which had prohibited nearly all home-based businesses, to allow those that are quiet and operate indoors.
The Screenwriters Guild and some journalists' organizations contend that the city is trying to license writers, in violation of the First Amendment. The screenwriters also contend that the city cannot tax them on revenue from their creative work.
The tax, while small, could have a significant impact on some successful freelancers. Los Angeles wants to impose a tax, for instance, of $5,900 on a $1 million payment for a screenplay.
"People believe there is an escape mechanism for them," said Larry Brockman, the president of the American Home Business Association, a Salt Lake City marketing company that operates seminars and sells services to people who want to set up their own businesses at home.
"We tell people that they have to conform, have to get business licenses," Mr. Brockman said, "but the deeper symptom is that Americans are angry about the taxes they pay and so they make themselves believe that they are exempt. But of course, they are not."
Mr. Jensen, the Tacoma tax official, said he was not surprised that efforts to collect a tax on long-established but untaxed business activity provoked litigation.
"The key is to build a tax into the trend early, rather than trying to apply a tax later when there will be much more resistance," he said.
The overall licensing and taxing policies of Los Angeles are driving people in creative businesses, especially those connected to software and the Internet, into the suburbs around Los Angeles, said Joel Kotkin, a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy in Malibu, Calif.
Communities surrounding Los Angeles, like Culver City and Burbank, "have thriving Information Age economies because they do not behave like the City of Los Angeles, a metropolitan area which has more writers than any other place in the world," Mr. Kotkin said.
Judy Carter, a comedy writer, said that to avoid the tax, she promised the city she would write her jokes in her second home, in Big Bear, Calif. "Officially," she said, "I'm not funny in Los Angeles."
Raising taxes, but not enough so that home-business owners are tempted to move, drives the policies of many cities. One subtle way to raise a little extra money, as Tacoma has found, is to impose multiple taxes at very low rates.
While the Comroes must have two licenses for their clock business, their friends, Woodroe and Marjorie Grinstead had to pay for three. The Grinsteads' Action Cycles, a motorcycle engine rebuilding business that they run in a shop behind their home, requires a general business licese, a home-business license and a speciality license for garages. They pay the minimum for all three licenses, a total of $172 a year.
"The principle the city follows," Mrs. Grinstead said, "seems to be to tax the little businesses because they are the least equipped to fight back."
Fees like those imposed in Tacoma, said Paul Reynolds, a business professor at Babson College in Wellesley, Mass., "aren't going to make any difference to how many people start businesses or succeed in them."
"What these business owners do want," added Professor Reynolds, who has studied small businesses for 15 years, "is simplicity and not having to take a lot of time from what they are doing and waste it on compliance with tax laws."
Teri Comroe, the clock repair owner, agreed: "Fighting the city over $50 a year isn't worth our time."

HEADLINE: A Good Month For Trade, With Trouble Ahead

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
In a surprisingly large decline, the monthly trade deficit narrowed to $9.7 billion for October as exports reached record levels, the Commerce Department reported today. Analysts said, however, that they expected the gap to widen considerably in future months as Asian economic trouble squeezed exports and created cheaper imports.
The trade figures, which are published with longer delays than most other economic data, did show that the monthly imbalance with Japan surged to its highest level in October in two and a half years. But the deficit with China shrank, as did the trade gap with South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore. 
 "Anyone hoping to find effects of the recent financial turmoil in East Asia in today's trade numbers should recognize the lags involved," said Lee Price, Acting Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs. "Today's data report the goods and services that crossed our border in October. Most of the business decisions to commit to those transactions had taken place several months before October."
The month's figures did suggest, analysts said, that trade -- a significant drag on economic growth earlier in the year -- would not be so this quarter. As a result, Kenneth T. Mayland, chief economist of Keycorp, said growth could equal the 3.3 percent annual pace of both the spring and summer, which some consider too fast to sustain without a pickup in inflation.
"A lot of trade is contractual," Mr. Mayland said, in contending that Asian turmoil would not make a big impact on American trade flows for a few more months. Currency devaluations and other spurs to exports from the Far East operate "with some pretty long lags," he said.
"The crisis in Asia is not yet reflected in U.S. trade statistics," Stan Shipley, a senior Merrill Lynch economist, told clients. "We expect an ever-enlarging trade deficit in the first half of 1998 as U.S. exports to Asia decline."
Yet October was better than expected, with the overall trade deficit falling from a revised figure for September of $11.228 billion.
The amount by which American imports exceeded sales abroad ran at an annual pace of $114 billion for the first 10 months of the year, compared with $111 billion in the comparable months of 1996.
Exports in October rose 2.4 percent, to $80 billion, in a broad advance paced by motor vehicles and capital goods, the report showed.
Ranking officials of the Clinton Administration, which has kept trying to break down barriers to American products and is mindful of the reduced ability of Asians to buy them, reacted cautiously.
"A single month of good news must not distract us from our commitment to building our exports," Secretary of Commerce William M. Daley said in a statement.
On Capitol Hill, Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, urged the Agriculture Department to use export incentives to prevent losses of wheat sales to Asia.
Imports in October rose a modest four-tenths of 1 percent, to $89.7 billion, with crude oil and capital goods the biggest factors.
The deficit with Japan jumped $800 million, to bring the total for September and October to $1.4 billion, with half the latest rise accounted for by motor vehicles.
But the deficit with China, which has alternated with Japan as the largest source of the American trade gap, narrowed to $5.2 billion from $5.5 billion.
The China imbalance was a record in September. The Japanese deficit in October was the highest since April 1995.
And after doubling in September, the combined deficit with South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong dropped $500 million in October, to $1.5 billion. The deficit with other Pacific Rim countries, including Indonesia, fell to $1.3 billion from $2 billion.
The $9.7 billion imbalance over all reflected a $17.1 billion deficit in goods, offset by the usual American surplus in services -- insurance, tourism and the like -- which in October amounted to $7.4 billion.
The nation's surplus in advanced technology products rose $200 million in October, to $1.6 billion.

Deficit is the excess of imports over exports for goods and servics. Amounts are rounded, in billions of dollars, seasonally adjusted. Chart shows imports, exports, and deficit from May 1996 through October 1997. (Source: Commerce Department)(pg. D11)

HEADLINE: With Approving Nod, I.M.F. Wires $3.5 Billion to South Korea

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund released a further $3.5 billion tonight of the $21 billion it has pledged to keep South Korea afloat, giving its approval to Seoul's handling of the crisis so far and a vote of confidence to the President-elect, Kim Dae Jung.
Officials at the fund insisted that the decision was ordained by a bureaucratic timetable and was not designed to make a political point. But they were clearly aware that the announcement would help reassure jittery investors and lenders wondering whether the new government will be able to keep the nation on a recovery path. 
 Saying he had a sense of "cautious optimism" about South Korea's prospects, Michel Camdessus, the fund's managing director, said Seoul had exceeded the requirements of the bailout package, so far, by opening up its financial markets and cleaning up its banking system.
The fund, Mr. Camdessus said, "is satisfied with the way in which the program has been not only maintained but developed and strengthened" by the government of Kim Young Sam, the outgoing President.
Mr. Camdessus said he believed that Korea's new President and his defeated rivals in the election would honor their public commitments to continue with the politically and economically painful steps necessary to restore confidence in South Korea's financial condition.
The $3.5 billion payment, which will be wired to South Korea by the central banks of the fund's member countries over the next day or two, is the second installment of the I.M.F. package. It follows a disbursement of $5.5 billion two weeks ago.
Investors remain concerned about whether South Korea has turned the corner, and some analysts say they are not yet convinced that the new President will keep his promises to stick to the I.M.F. austerity plan.
Mr. Camdessus said the fund had found no areas in which Korea was not meeting its commitments. Moreover, he said, the Government had taken several steps not specifically mandated by the plan, including its decision this week to allow the currency, the won, to fluctuate in value in response to market forces. He also cited the Government's willingness to raise interest rates more than the plan required and to close more of its ailing merchant banks than the fund called for.
The disbursement approved today was the first under a new formula developed under prodding by the United States, which would have the fund move more aggressively to make loans to nations suffering from acute problems in the financial markets. The policy favors larger loans from the I.M.F. in a shorter time during periods of market crisis, but those loans would carry higher interest rates and shorter repayment periods than traditional I.M.F. assistance.

HEADLINE: Release of Tobacco Memos Brings Lawmakers' Demand for More

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
A new debate over proposed Federal tobacco legislation erupted in Congress yesterday after the release of hundreds of cigarette company documents showing how industry lawyers steered scientific research away from efforts to connect smoking and diseases like cancer.
The more than 800 previously secret documents, released yesterday by the House Commerce Committee, paint a portrait of cigarette industry lawyers working together for decades to generate research to play down the risks of smoking. In one 1968 memorandum, lawyers discussed a strategy to "research the disease" rather than "questions more directly related to tobacco." And two decades later they followed the same tack, by proposing studies that would not identify health problems posed by second-hand smoke but research "their real causes," according to a 1987 memorandum from the Tobacco Institute, a trade group. 
 "As an example, we might envision case studies of two groups of children with and without excessive respiratory problems or developmental retardation, and then study a wide range of hereditary, environmental, economic and social factors which may differentiate them," the memorandum states.
The 834 documents come from the files of the Liggett Group, a cigarette producer that is a subsidiary of the Brooke Group Ltd., and reflect communications between lawyers from other tobacco companies. Legal experts said yesterday that they had been able to read only some of the documents but that they appeared to fill in details about the inner workings of the tobacco industry rather than break new ground.
The documents' disclosure, however, coupled with the earlier release of court papers in Minnesota, produced demands by Democrats and at least one Republican that tobacco companies disgorge thousands of other documents before Congress considers the $368.5 billion settlement proposal reached in June between producers and state attorneys general.
For example, Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who heads the Senate Commerce Committee, which will play a major role in any Federal tobacco legislation, said he would seek far more secret documents than those released yesterday.
"The released papers are but a small fraction of the relevant documentation," Mr. McCain said in a statement. "Without such sunlight and disclosures we can't make informed decisions."
One longtime opponent of the industry, Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, said that in light of the Liggett documents, it would be difficult for Congress to give tobacco companies the immunity from lawsuits and punitive damages they are seeking under Federal legislation.
In a statement, four cigarette producers involved in the June settlement proposal sought to play down the significance of the documents and insisted that Federal tobacco legislation was the only way to resolve a number of regulatory and legal issues involving the product.
"Those who believe that 20- or 40-year-old documents merit continuation of legal and regulatory hostilities in lieu of a national legislative solution fail to see what is at stake," said the companies in a joint statement. "We must learn from, but not be obsessed by, events past."
The statement was put out by the Philip Morris Companies, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation., the parent of R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., the parent of Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, and Loews Corporation, the parent of Lorillard Tobacco Company. Another company, U.S.T. Inc., a producer of smokeless tobacco, was also involved in the June agreement but none of its documents were at issue yesterday.
All of the companies had sought to prevent disclosure of the Liggett documents, which are part of a lawsuit filed against them by Minnesota state officials, arguing that they were protected by attorney-client privilege. But the records, which were found by the Minnesota court to contain evidence of crimes and fraud, were subpoenaed this month by Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., the Virginia Republican who heads the Commerce Committee, which released them yesterday.
Previously disclosed tobacco industry records have shown that cigarette lawyers were involved in selecting research projects that were not designed to find ties between smoking and cancer. And legal experts believe that far more important documents that are part of the Minnesota lawsuit, those from the files of industry giants like Philip Morris and R. J. Reynolds, remain to be disclosed.
But taken together, the Liggett documents provide new details about the degree to which lawyers were involved in directing health research. The documents also show that while cigarette producers publicly stated over decades that they were seriously investigating smoking risks, they were often casting blame for diseases like lung cancer and heart disease on other causes.
At times, the research underwritten by industry lawyers bordered on the absurd. In 1966, for example, they considered financing a study that would try to find high cancer rates not related to smoking in then-polluted areas like Pittsburgh, a document shows. A companion study would have looked for pockets of low cancer incidence not corresponding to smoking based on a survey of desert populations.
A 1967 document also suggested using groups popular among young people, like the rock group the Monkees, as industry spokesmen.
But within the industry, cigarette company officials were acknowledging smoking risks, previously disclosed documents show. On Tuesday, for example, Kenneth J. Fitzpatrick, a Minnesota state judge who is overseeing the state's lawsuit there, ruled that the Liggett documents showed that cigarette companies and their lawyers engaged in a long-running "conspiracy of silence and suppression of scientific research" about the dangers of smoking.
Industry lawyers also put forward experts who they thought would raise doubts about ties between smoking and disease. In a 1971 memorandum, lawyers from Shook, Hardy & Bacon, perhaps the tobacco industry's top law firm, proposed paying $70,000 to a scientist who, they noted, was "convinced that smoking has been given far too much consideration and air pollution too little."
The extent to which tobacco lawyers were involved in selecting research disturbed even some of them, according to a 1981 memorandum. At a meeting of industry lawyers, one lawyer noted they were making "advocacy primary and research secondary." Another lawyer apparently discussed hiding research from regulators at the Federal Trade Commission by claiming it was protected under the attorney-client privilege, the document indicates.
"We wanted to protect it under the lawyers," that lawyer remarked at the time. "We did not want it out in the open."
In 1983, top industry lawyers at the Tobacco Institute in Washington discussed withholding information from legislators who were debating the Drug Abuse Act on the grounds that contributing material to an addiction study was risky if the report reached a "conclusion or conclusions unfavorable to industry.
Other Liggett documents indicate that cigarette companies in the 1960's monitored the number of children who were watching their advertisements on television.
Other documents show that as recently as 1990, industry lawyers were commissioning studies to monitor cancer rates among ethnic groups.
Under a proposed settlement reached in June between the tobacco industry and state attorneys general, producers agreed, among other things, to pay $368.5 billion to settle smoking-related lawsuits.
In return, the proposal would protect the companies against most lawsuits and bar juries from awarding punitive damages.
