HEADLINE: DECISION ON BOSNIA: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Calls for Keeping Troops In Bosnia With No New Exit Date

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Abandoning his June deadline for withdrawing American forces from Bosnia, President Clinton called today for an open-ended commitment of troops in the international peacekeeping mission, arguing that it is helping to rebuild that nation's roads, schools, economy and political system.
Mr. Clinton denied Republican accusations that he and his aides had misled Congress in saying they would meet the June exit deadline. 
 Responding to questions after his announcement at the White House this morning, Mr. Clinton instead made an unusually direct admission of error, saying that he had simply been wrong.
"I wasn't right, which is why I don't want to make that error again," he said.
Mr. Clinton added: "I don't mind taking a hit for being wrong about the timetable. But after the hit is dished out, I would like the larger truth looked at."
That truth, the President said, is that the mission had enforced a fragile cease-fire, had advanced American security and values, and was making it less likely that the United States would "be drawn into some other conflict in Europe 10, 20, 30 years from now where the costs could be far greater." Transcript, page A20.
Mr. Clinton said that he expected American troops to leave Bosnia in the "near term," but he refused to set a new exit date, saying that the mission, which is led by NATO, should instead be defined by "concrete benchmarks," like the creation of an adequate civilian police force.
"I am not suggesting a permanent presence in Bosnia," the President said, in his most detailed comments on Bosnia since his re-election a year ago. "I am suggesting that it's a more honest thing to do to say what our objectives are."
He did not specify the size of the force after June, but said he hoped it would be smaller than the 8,500 Americans who are there now, as part of a NATO-led force of more than 30,000.
Congress's only avenue to block the extension of the mission is the politically unappealing one of cutting off money to the American troops in Bosnia. While they expressed irritation with the Administration's broken deadlines -- Mr. Clinton has now extended the mission twice -- and its still-undefined strategy, Republicans in Congress said they were unlikely to take that step. Mr. Clinton's admission of error appeared to be intended to blunt their anger.
Some said that they were waiting for the President to fill in the details. Sen. John Ashcroft, a Missouri Republican and member of the Foreign Relations Committee, warned that if Mr. Clinton failed to lay out a "crystal-clear exit strategy," he would "work aggressively with other members of Congress to insure the safe return home of U.S. troops." But he did not specify how.
The announcement today had been previewed for weeks in comments by the President's national security aides. Critics of the Administration's Bosnia policy said that the decision to abandon deadlines for withdrawing the troops -- coming as it does seven months before the expiration of the current mission -- demonstrated an improved appreciation of how to enlist Congressional support. They said that it could also help military and civilian planners by better focusing the mission.
"Focusing on goals rather than dates is a big step forward, and it reflects a better understanding in the Administration on how to deal with Congress," said Stephen W. Walker, the director of the Balkan Institute here. Mr. Walker, a former foreign service officer who quit the State Department in 1993 over Bosnia policy, added that "it remains to be seen whether the Administration is going to back up its improved rhetoric with real action."
In applauding Mr. Clinton's announcement, Rep. Lee Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who is the ranking minority member of the House Committee on International Relations, said that it would shift the domestic debate away from the narrow question of meeting deadlines.
"There will be more attention to the so-called exit strategy," he said, "not in terms of a date certain, but more about the conditions that need to exist before we pull out."
The President is planning to leave Sunday on a holiday visit to the troops in Bosnia. He is taking a Congressional delegation that includes opponents of his policy.
While he committed troops "in principle" today, Mr. Clinton laid out six conditions, including clearly defined benchmarks, for American participation in the NATO force past June.
He said that United States must retain command of the mission and that European nations "must assume their share of responsibility."
He also said that the plan "must have substantial support from Congress and the American people."
Mr. Clinton did not define a new mission for the troops. That issue, together with the size of the force, is being debated within the Administration and NATO, with an announcement likely in mid-January.
The number of American troops has already declined from its height of 27,000 in 1996. It may fall still more, to perhaps 6,000, though some Administration officials worry that cuts in the force could hamper, and as a result prolong, its mission.
The first benchmark that the President said should determine the success of the NATO mission is that the joint political institutions created to unify Bosnia must be strong enough "to be self-sustaining after the military operation."
He also said that the political parties there must give up control of the media, which he called "instruments of hate and venom." He called for an adequate police force, and he said that the NATO allies should be confident that the military was under democratic rule.
The President said that he did not entertain utopian visions of creating racial comity in Bosnia. "I don't think it's necessary for us to stay until everybody wants to go have tea together at 4 in the afternoon in a civil environment," he said.
Despite efforts to create a unified government, Bosnia remains split along ethnic lines, without a common flag or an integrated postal service.
The Dayton accords, which ended the war in 1995, were intended to reunify Bosnia but have, in a sense, ratified the boundaries that separated the ethnic groups when the three years of fighting stopped. But the Administration rejects the idea of partitioning Bosnia.
"It would sanction the horrors of ethnic cleansing and send the wrong signal to extremists everywhere," Mr. Clinton said.
Although Mr. Clinton said that his list of benchmarks for the military force was not complete, he disappointed some Bosnia experts by failing to include the return of refugees or the arrest of people indicted for war crimes.
Referring to those two subjects, one senior Administration official said later: "I don't think there's any doubt that, when the final list of benchmarks comes up, they absolutely will be part of it."
But Mr. Clinton said that it might not be necessary to arrest the most prominent suspect, Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb president who remains a powerful nationalist leader. "If he flees the country, if he is deep enough underground, if he can't have any impact on it, we might make the peace work anyway," he said.
Mr. Clinton said that the United States had supported a Dutch-led NATO mission this morning that resulted in the arrest of two Bosnian Croats indicted for atrocities.
The President also praised efforts to return refugees, saying that NATO's success in creating a secure environment had encouraged 350,000 people to return home, out of some 2 million who left the country or fled elsewhere within Bosnia.
Mr. Clinton sketched a portrait today of a recovering Bosnia, where NATO troops had helped separate armies, demobilize 350,000 troops, patch roads and restore electricity, change the media "from an instrument of war into a force for peace," and create a presidency, parliament, and supreme court. "The progress is unmistakable," he said. "But it is not yet irreversible."

HEADLINE: Revision of Earnings Forecasts Sends Dow Lower

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
At the end of November -- even after the stock market's plunge in October and the spread of financial turmoil throughout Asia -- stock analysts were buoyant.
At Merrill Lynch, the company analysts set a record by raising earnings forecasts for 105 more companies than were downgraded in the three months ended in November. 
 It is that kind of optimism that has set up investors and strategists alike for the earnings disappointments in the last two weeks that have sent stocks lower.
The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled yesterday for a second consecutive session, ending down 110.91 points, or 1.4 percent, at 7,846.50.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index continued to outdo the Dow on the downside, falling 24.18 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,523.19. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 10.24 points, or 1.1 percent, to 955.30.
Aetna Inc. dropped 9 3/8, to 69 1/2, after the abrupt departure of a top financial executive suggested that the company might have trouble meeting its earnings estimates. The Plexus Corporation, an electronics company, announced that its earnings would fall short of expectations because customers were delaying orders. Its shares fell 11, or 44 percent, to 14.
And the regulars -- the stocks that have bounced up and down recently as earnings fears waxed and waned -- fell again. J. P. Morgan led the Dow lower, falling 3 1/8, to 118 7/8, and Caterpillar dropped 2, to 48 11/16.
On Wednesday, Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing set the negative earnings tone by announcing that its fourth-quarter earnings would fall 10 percent short of its forecast. Its shares plunged almost 10 percent on Wednesday but rose 11/16 yesterday, to 85 15/16. Last week, Oracle raised the earnings caution flag, and its shares dropped 29 percent. They fell 5/8 yesterday, to 22.
Jeffrey M. Applegate, chief United States strategist at Lehman Brothers, said there was a wide gap developing between current expectations and the revisions that strategists are working on because of the economic drag from Asia and the slower growth expected in the United States in 1998.
Current estimates for 1998 put earnings growth at 13 percent for the companies in the S.& P. 500, but Mr. Applegate said that Lehman Brothers would scale down its forecast to 8 percent if the economic growth rate in Asia fell to zero next year.
"There is a pretty big distance between 13 and 8," he said, adding that there is a risk of the market going lower.
Earnings worries often arise at the end of a quarter because that is when companies begin trying to ease investor expectations.
But adding to the negative atmosphere is the string of 1998 stock market forecasts coming out, many of which are bearish. And while all of the bearish to neutral forecasts for this year have turned out to be wrong, many investors and analysts are skeptical that the stock market can do that well next year.
One of the stock market's better known bulls, Ralph J. Acampora, the director of technical research at Prudential Securities, who had forecast a Dow of 10,000 by June 1998, said yesterday that he had put that forecast on hold until 1999. He now predicts that the Dow will trade between 6,000 and 8,600 in 1998 and thinks that three-quarters of the stocks on the New York Stock Exchange could decline by 20 percent.
Barton Biggs, the global strategist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, said that investors were underestimating the economic effect of the turmoil in Asia and the rising dollar and that both the United States and Europe were likely to experience bear markets next year. But Mr. Biggs has been bearish before and been forced to throw in the towel as the stock market stormed ahead.
Richard Bernstein, the director of quantitative research at Merrill Lynch, said that he expected the pre-announcements of earnings to depress sentiment. But he thinks that when actual fourth-quarter earnings reports come in at the beginning of next year, they may not turn out to be as bad as expected. But then just as investors are brushing off the Asian effect, he expects the bad news to become apparent as the full force of the Asian drag hits and the American economy slows.
In robust trading yesterday, almost two stocks fell for every one that rose. Microsoft was buffeted again in its antitrust battle with the Justice Department and finished at 130 7/8, down 4 3/4. One of the rising stocks was Eastman Kodak, which climbed 1 1/2, to 58, after announcing additional job cuts.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Aetna Stock Falls 10%; Top Financial Officer Exits
Shares of Aetna fell more than 10 percent after the company announced the departure of the chief financial officer of its health care unit. Aetna officials spoke with analysts but provided few details. 
 Analysts speculated that the resignation signaled bigger problems at the company than had earlier been anticipated and that more negative earnings news might be ahead. Aetna, which acquired U.S. Healthcare, is struggling with melding that operation into its operation. Page D2.
 
Japanese Stocks Tumble
Japanese stocks fell sharply after a food-trading company, Toshoku sought court protection from heavy debts, raising fears that more bankruptcies and failures would plague the economy. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks was down 5.7 percent at midday. D4.
 
Korean Investors Wary
Korean stocks opened sharply lower after the election of Kim Dae Jung, a long-time dissident, as President, but recovered somewhat in morning trading. The reaction stems in part from fears that Mr. Kim, a populist with strong support from organized labor, might resist fulfilling the agreement South Korea made with the I.M.F. A10.
 
High Hopes for AT&T
C. Michael Armstrong has not yet disclosed his plans for AT&T, but his actions are speaking volumes to investors. Shares of AT&T have increased 72 percent in the last five months. The $3.5 billion sale of its credit card business to Citicorp is just the most recent component of an aggressive turnaround strategy. Market Place. D4.
 
Sign of Fed Dissent
Minutes from the November meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers show their decision to leave interest rates unchanged was not unanimous. The one dissenter was Alfred Broaddus, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, who cited inflationary pressure from the strong economy as a reason to raise rates. D3.
 
Treasury prices rose, sending its yield down to 5.93 percent from 6 percent. D14.
 
S.E.C. Sues 58 in Penny-Stock Case
The Securities and Exchange Commission charged 58 defendants with penny-stock manipulation. The agency said stock promoters and officials of small brokerage firms bribed brokers to get them to sell certain issues to unsuspecting investors. D3.
 
Light Trucks' Loophole New air-quality rules proposed this week by the E.P.A. would require cars, mini-vans, small sport utility vehicles and small pickup trucks to emit fewer smog-causing pollutants. B10.
 
Tobacco Papers Disclosed
More than 800 previously secret cigarette company documents were released by the House Commerce Committee. The documents show cigarette industry lawyers working together for decades to generate research to play down the risks of smoking. A32.

London Exchange Fines Morgan
J. P. Morgan was fined $577,000 by the London Stock Exchange for a breach of rules that led to a sharp drop in Britain's benchmark stock index last month. D2.
 
Split at Dun & Bradstreet
Dun & Bradstreet, which divided into three companies about a year ago, said it would split up its yellow pages distribution and financial information services businesses. D2.
 
New York Magazine Revives After a rocky year under a new editor, Caroline Miller, New York magazine is now on the right track, advertising executives and others say. B1.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Legislature Votes to Double State Cigarette Tax

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The New Jersey Legislature voted overwhelmingly today to increase the state's cigarette tax by 40 cents a pack, making cigarettes more expensive in New Jersey than in any other state in the region. The proceeds, about $205 million a year, will help pay for hospital treatment for uninsured patients and for school construction.
Both Republicans and Democrats offered unflinching support for the tax increase to 80 cents a pack, saying that they hoped it would curtail smoking, especially among teen-agers. The Senate voted 33-6 to adopt the proposal, while the General Assembly approved it 58-18. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is expected to sign the bill into law, and the increase would take effect on Jan. 1. 
 New Jersey is the 10th state to raise its cigarette tax this year, and the increase, which doubles the tax, is among the steepest. The state will now have the third-highest cigarette tax in the nation, after Alaska, which increased its cigarette tax this year to $1 from 29 cents, and Washington State, at 82.5 cents. In comparison, New York's tax is 56 cents a pack, and Connecticut's is 31 cents.
Lawmakers said they supported the tax increase -- the most significant in New Jersey since former Gov. Jim Florio raised taxes by $2.8 billion in 1990 -- partly because they believed it would decrease smoking.
"If increasing the tax on cigarettes helps discourage people from smoking, it's fine with an overwhelming number of New Jerseyans," said State Senator Richard J. Codey, the minority leader and a Democrat of Essex County.
To complaints that the tax would hit poor smokers unfairly, Senator C. Louis Bassano, Republican of Union, replied: "So quit smoking. That's the whole point."
But even as lawmakers fiercely defended the tax increase, about a dozen smokers said in interviews that it would not make them quit. Most said they would simply pay the higher price in local stores, and a few said they would buy cigarettes in neighboring states. A pack of cigarettes cost about $2.23 in New York last year, $1.77 in Pennsylvania and $1.72 in Delaware, according to the Tobacco Institute, an industry lobbying group in Washington. After the tax increase, cigarettes will cost an average of $2.75 per pack in New Jersey, the institute said.
Anti-smoking advocates said that the broad bipartisan support for cigarette tax increases in New Jersey and other states this year reflects a changing attitude toward the tobacco industry, which donates millions of dollars to political campaigns. They said politicians had become more willing to pass laws that discourage or restrict smoking because of increasing evidence that the industry had long known its products were addictive and had deliberately marketed them to teen-agers.
Mrs. Whitman and legislative leaders have pushed for a cigarette tax increase several times before, but they could never gather enough support. The Legislature has avoided raising any tax since 1990 because the Florio package, which included income and sales tax increases and a 19-cent rise in the cigarette tax, cost many lawmakers -- and ultimately Mr. Florio -- their jobs.
Legislators were far more willing to support a tax increase this time because both teacher unions and the health-care industry were lobbying for it. While most of the revenue will go toward hospital care for the uninsured, 10 cents per pack -- or $50 million a year -- will go toward school construction.
"What put it over the top this time was this masterful combination of these two issues, education and health care," said Curtis Fisher, director of New Jersey Public Interest Research Group Citizen Lobby. "It's probably the most palatable tax increase that exists right now, and you have two significant lobbies crying out for it."
Pete McDonough, a spokesman for Mrs. Whitman, said the Governor was happy about the tax increase, which covers all tobacco products, and he pointed out that she had cut taxes by $4.4 billion during her first term. "She didn't resist this one," Mr. McDonough said. "It's a very narrow tax increase for two very specific problems."
But in interviews this morning, people buying cigarettes in Sayreville, a working-class town in Middlesex County, said they felt unfairly singled out. They said that the new tax would not stop them from smoking, and that every resident of New Jersey should chip in to pay for charity care.
Steve Petner, a technician for a pharmaceutical company who spends at least $20 a week on cigarettes, said he would rather see tobacco companies pay the extra tax.
"You have people who need to keep smoking because they're addicted, and they're going to be forced to spend all this extra money," said Mr. Petner, 46, who has smoked for 29 years. "I can handle it, but I'd like to stop being treated as a second-class citizen."
Meanwhile, owners of convenience stores in Sayreville predicted that the new 80-cent tax would hurt cigarette sales, which they said make up about 30 percent of their business.
"People already complain about the price in New Jersey," said Umesh Patel, manager of the Krauszer's convenient store, who predicted his cigarette sales would drop by as much as 20 percent. "Now they're going to go from town to town, state to state, looking for the cheapest cigarettes."
The legislation approved today will give hospitals $320 million a year to treat the uninsured. Of that, $155 million will come from the cigarette tax, with the rest coming from the state's unemployment fund and the general budget. Urban hospitals will get another $101.5 million to treat hundreds of patients with AIDS and tuberculosis. The new plan will also provide $68 million for two separate health insurance programs, including one for uninsured children and another for people who earn too much to qualify for Medicaid but whose employers offer no health coverage.
The state's current financing system for charity care expires on Dec. 31. Until 1992, charity care was funded by a surcharge on hospital bills; since then, most of the money has come from the state's unemployment insurance fund, a practice that has been harshly criticized by business and labor leaders. That fund is still being tapped to pay for charity care under today's legislation, but its use is to be phased out over five years.
Although legislators have proposed many bills that would discourage or restrict smoking in New Jersey in recent years, most have never come up for a vote, Mr. Fisher said. While New York City and dozens of states have restricted smoking in restaurants or banned it altogether, New Jersey requires only that restaurants post a sign in the window telling patrons whether there are tables for nonsmokers.
Lawmakers proposed banning smoking in day-care centers, restaurants and shopping malls this year, but none of the bills got past legislative committees.
Mr. Fisher said he hoped the strong support for the cigarette tax increase would encourage the Legislature to restrict indoor smoking and advertising by cigarette companies.
"There are critical issues that need to be addressed," he said. "Hopefully, this will open the door."
In Sayreville this morning, one longtime smoker said the higher tax would help him kick the habit. Chris Nogueras, 26, said that he had already made a halfhearted resolution to quit smoking on New Year's Day, and that the prospect of paying an extra 40 cents a pack hardened his resolve.
"It's the best excuse I've heard," Mr. Nogueras said. "Come New Year's, I'll be ready to stop."

INTERNATIONAL A3-21
 
Kim Dae Jung Wins South Korean Presidency
In South Korea, Kim Dae Jung, a legendary pro-democracy campaigner whom past dictators repeatedly tried to kill because of his unwavering struggle for freedom, was elected President. Voters repudiated the ruling party that has presided over an economic crisis. A1 

Clinton Plans for Bosnia
Abandoning his June deadline for withdrawing American forces from Bosnia, President Clinton called for an open-ended commitment of troops in the peacekeeping mission. Mr. Clinton denied Republican accusations that he and his aides had misled Congress by saying they would meet the June exit deadline, saying that he had simply been wrong. A1
 
U.N. Dues Settlement Unlikely
The United States is losing its argument at the United Nations that the dues it owes from past years should be reduced. Even close allies are rejecting Washington's demands. Congress has resisted paying off back dues because of complaints about the organization's operations and the burden on the United States, and it is unlikely that Congress will release the more than $1 billion that America owes. A3
 
Powell Returns to Jamaica
Gen. Colin L. Powell spent a day in Jamaica monitoring the fairness of the vote in the country where his parents were born. Jamaicans were eager to claim the retired general, who was observing the election along with former President Jimmy Carter and boxing champion Evander Holyfield, as one of their own. A4
 
U.S. to Extend Vietnam Ties
The Clinton Administration, citing Vietnam's progress in allowing free emigration of its citizens, intends to move toward more normal trading relations with Hanoi, officials said. President Clinton has notified members of Congress that he expects early next year to grant Vietnam a waiver from the Jackson-Vanik Amendment, which bars full economic ties with nations that restrict travel and emigration. A13
 
Mideast Pressure Increases
After making little progress in another round of meetings in Paris with the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said that President Clinton will meet each side separately next month in Washington to try to break the impasse. The prospect of a meeting should put added pressure on the leaders to revive the peace effort, American officials said. A15
 
Meteor Search Begins
Danish scientists have begun a search for evidence of what they believe was a huge meteor impact in Greenland last week. Three widely separated Scandinavian boats operating near the Greenland coast reported seeing flashes of light, and seismic signals from the area were detected by stations in Scandinavia and Germany. A17
 
NATIONAL A22-37
 
Power Failure Snarls Air Traffic Nationwide
A brief and supposedly impossible power failure at an air traffic control center in Kansas near Kansas City crippled the Federal Aviation Administration's national network for hours, forcing hundreds of planes to be diverted or delayed and inconveniencing thousands of passengers. A1
 
Babbitt Proposes Water Rule
Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, opening the way for a new market in vital water for growing Western states, announced a rule that for the first time would allow interstate sales of water from the Colorado River. A36
 
Author Defends Novel
Barbara Chase-Riboud, the author who in a $10 million copyright infringement lawsuit accused Steven Spielberg's studio of "brazenly" stealing from her work for the movie "Amistad," wrote a 1986 novel containing entire passages that appeared in a scholarly work published 50 years earlier. A1
 
Emissions Rules Exempt Trucks
New air quality regulations proposed this week by the Environmental Protection Agency and the nation's auto makers would require cars, mini-vans, small sport utility vehicles and small pickup trucks to emit even fewer smog-causing pollutants, but would leave untouched the already less stringent rules for big sport utility vehicles and pickups. Big sport utility vehicles and pickups are the fastest-growing segment of the auto industry. A26
 
Infertility Clinics Rated
The Government reported that advanced methods of conception fail 70 to 80 percent of the time, in the first clinic-by-clinic guide to the confusing and often emotionally wrenching world of infertility treatment. A22
 
Renewed Debate on Tobacco
A new debate over proposed tobacco legislation erupted in Congress after the release of cigarette company documents showing how industry lawyers steered scientific research away from efforts to connect smoking and diseases like cancer. A32

A1
 
Guilty Plea in Trinket Ring
A 29-year-old deaf woman pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in Brooklyn to charges that she conspired to bring dozens of deaf Mexicans to the United States to be part of what amounted to a lucrative, often brutal slavery ring selling trinkets in the streets and subways in New York City and other cities. Wrestling Faces Scrutiny

HEADLINE: School Tax Law Splits 'Haves' and 'Have Nots'

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: STOWE, Vt.

 BODY:
Vermont these days is riven by revolution.
Not in a way that visitors to this white-steepled ski town would notice. The snow is deep and sugary this year, the lift lines are long and the torchlight parades march glowingly on. 
 But if, one recent morning, those visitors had stepped off the Currier-and-Ives street and into the Town Hall auditorium -- where the year-round residents gather -- they would have heard voices protesting the pain of sweeping social change.
They would have heard the likes of Alvin Schein, a retired dentist: "People say, 'Now it's your turn to suffer!' And I say, 'Two wrongs don't make a right!' " And John Steel, a house-builder: "We used to be called a ski town. Now we're called a 'gold town.' They're driving a wedge from town to town." And Frank Talarico, a businessman: "It's the haves and the have-nots. I'm dismayed to see this happening in Vermont."
The source of all this agonizing is what many consider the hottest, most divisive political issue to hit Vermont in many years -- an innovative setup for financing the state's schools called Act 60.
The new law is meant to address a knotty problem that has confronted more than half the states since 1971. At issue is this fundamental question: Should a richer community -- called 'gold towns' in this debate -- with the resources to spend more on its pupils have the right to do so? Or is public education such a basic right that the state must make sure access to it is equal for all?
Beginning in California in 1971, more than 30 states have fought court battles over whether the system of supporting schools from local property taxes was constitutional. Though courts have split evenly in their decisions, experts say the trend is decidedly against local taxing and in favor of equalization. Most recently, in a decision that sent shivers of dread through tax-hating New Hampshire, the state's Supreme Court ruled Wednesday that its dependence on local property taxes for nearly 90 percent of its school budgets was unconstitutional.
State responses to such rulings have varied greatly, said Mary Fulton, an expert on school financing at the Education Commission of the States, an advisory group. Some, like New Jersey, have struggled for years without coming up with a workable alternative to local property tax. Only Kansas and now Vermont have promptly passed broad statewide property taxes in response, she said.
Court challenges to school financing systems are currently pending in 15 states, including New York and New Jersey, according to the commission.
Gov. Howard Dean in Vermont said of such court decisions: "The obvious remedy is a statewide property tax. But it's a very difficult thing to do. It's very controversial, and it's been controversial here." In effect, Act 60 says public schools in towns that are rich in property -- like Stowe -- can no longer benefit directly from that wealth; most school money is to come from a statewide property tax rather than a local one, and the tax wealth of the property-rich towns will largely be pooled among schools around the state.
Residents in gold towns, the term for property-rich towns that has arisen during the Act 60 debates, are unhappy, Dr. Dean said, but "they've been essentially driving a Cadillac and paying a Chevy lease price."
"What the court did," he said, "is say that the property-tax base, for the purposes of education, belongs to every child in the state, not just the children in special towns."
The Vermont court ruling came in February. It noted that the tax base and school spending varied wildly from town to town. Richford, for example, had a property tax base of only $140,000 a student in fiscal 1995 and spent only $3,743 a pupil on average, it said, while Peru had a tax base of $2.2 million a student and spent $6,476 on each.
By June, the state legislature, newly dominated by an across-the-board Democratic majority and ready to heed voters' clamor for cuts in property taxes, had passed Act 60.
The law, which also shifts some of the tax burden from the property tax to others, like those on gasoline and hotel rooms, will be phased in beginning next fall.
But its effect is already clear. In 220 Vermont towns, property taxes will drop. But in 40 gold towns, which are largely ski areas and tourist spots with many second homes, property taxes will rise and school budgets will likely shrink.
There is another novel aspect of Act 60: "As far as we can tell, this is the first property tax to be income-based," said State Senator Cheryl Rivers of Stockbridge, a Morgan horse breeder and adroit Act 60 explicator (which is no mean talent with a law so complex that Ms. Rivers compared it to an automatic transmission: you know it works, but not how).
The law puts on cap on the amount of property tax households that earn less than $75,000 -- that is, about 90 percent of Vermont households -- can pay. Most of these households will pay no more than 2 or 3 percent of their adjusted gross income, depending on the town.
The law is also not quite a blanket an equalizer since towns can still vote to spend more than others on their schools.
But when they vote to raise their local taxes, some of that extra money, too, is pooled so as to make equal spending by towns result in equal tax rates. And in gold towns that stand to lose under Act 60, the question of whether to raise local taxes just to keep school budgets level is a thorny one.
In Stowe, for example, some parents worry that taxpayers without many school-age children will not agree to the nearly 40 percent tax hike that would be required to maintain the current budget of the town's excellent school system. Furthermore, businesses are not allowed the same income-based cap as households and might not be happy about big increases for education.
In the current backlash against Act 60, residents from the 40 towns hurt by the law have banded together into a group called Parents for Quality Education that is raising court challenges and trying to influence public opinion. They calculate that the law will hurt 10,000 Vermont schoolchildren out of a total of 105,000, and complain that its equalizing effect will replace excellence with mediocrity.
Some economists, too, question whether centralizing school financing make sense. It is not clear, said William A. Fischel, an economics professor at Dartmouth College and critic of Act 60, that reducing local control over schools helps even the children in property-poor areas as overall support often goes down.
"In some places, certainly in California and in some other places, this has made people at the low end worse off," he said. "It's dog-in-a-manger equality."
But equality is a powerful concept here. At a recent State House round-table discussion about the transition to Act 60, parents who complained that budget cuts would hurt their children's education got little sympathy from parents whose towns have had lower budgets all along.
"We have to talk about the rights of children in this state to equal access to educational opportunity instead of the claims of some towns to advantages to which they've become accustomed," exclaimed Allen Gilbert, from the town of Worcester.
Act 60 has provoked such emotion that some Vermonters say they are appalled at the resentment and envy.
"This is a poor state," said Louis Costanza, a retiree from Long Island who expects the property tax on his three-bedroom house in Winhall to go from $800 to $6,000 a year. "They see the Mercedes and Land Rovers and Wagoneers and say: 'Those yuppies have a lot of money. How am I going to get it? They've been dreaming about this for a long time.' "
The rancor has come to the surface in furious political debates and even in unaccustomed friction between neighbors.
Cameron Page, a Stowe mother and school board member, got a bewildering blast of anti-gold-town sentiment at a recent hockey game. A woman from a neighboring, non-gold town who was sitting near her, Ms. Page said, "actually leaned over to me and said, 'Nyeh, Nyeh.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Alvin Schein, a retired dentist who lives in Stowe, Vt., at the town meeting last week on a new school-financing law that will tend to raise property taxes in wealthier communities to try to equalize spending. (Paul Boisvert for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
On John St., From Offices to Housing

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Five short blocks along John Street in the Manhattan financial district have become a focus for converting old office buildings to housing.
Work is under way or will soon begin at six sites totaling 1,459 apartments in the corridor between Water Street and Broadway. After the pattern of downtown conversions, most buildings will be converted into rentals, ranging from six lofts at 41 John Street to 576 units at 127 John Street, also known as 200 Water Street. 
 One building, 17 John Street, will become a 58-unit loft condominium. It is among the first condo conversions to be announced downtown, where experts expect 7,000 residences to be created by 2002 with the help of city-sponsored tax incentives, according to the Alliance for Downtown Manhattan, a business improvement district.
In the two years since conversions began, 2,382 units have been completed or are under construction, and an additional 1,100 are to start early next year, said the president of the district, Carl Weisbrod.
Nancy Packes, who heads Feathered Nest, a rental brokerage, said downtown could absorb additional rentals, because demand continues to outstrip supply. Although rental projects are planned throughout Manhattan, the level is not close to the 13,000 units built yearly in the 1980's, Ms. Packes said. Because the recession, and not a glut of units, affected prices then, she added, "there is no reason to believe we are anywhere near producing enough units to cause prices to decline, though the rate of increases may slow."
Annual rents downtown are $32 to $35 a square foot, Ms. Packes said, noting that they are 15 percent below rents in more established neighborhoods.
Mr. Weisbrod said John Street caught developers' attention, even though it is not adjacent to an established residential area, because empty or near-empty buildings were available at low prices.
Several developers said many of the buildings were old with small interior spaces, making them easy to carve up into apartments.
John Street was once considered insurance row. The area fell on hard times sooner than other parts of downtown, as many insurers moved operations to less expensive areas outside Manhattan. Then the recession hit, and more tenants left.
The Rockrose Development Corporation initiated the march to John Street in 1995 with its purchase of No. 127. "It was perfect for conversion, because it is on the doorstep of the South Street Seaport and offers magnificent bridge and river views," said Kevin P. Singleton, vice president at Rockrose.
The company is converting the 32-story tower to 576 rentals, from studios to three-bedroom units, with 500 to 1,600 square feet of space each. Leasing is to begin in April, with occupancy to start in June.
Also in the spring, Rockrose will begin renovating 99 John Street into 453 apartments, after the American Insurance Group leaves.
The rents at both sites have not been set, Mr. Singleton said, but he expects them to be comparable to or higher than those at 45 Wall Street, which Rockrose also converted. The 435 studio to three-bedroom units in that building rented for $1,400 to $4,200 a month.
At 80 John Street, leasing began in September, and half of its 147 studio to three-bedroom apartments and lofts have been leased, said Fredric I. Oliver. He is a partner of WSA Equities L.L.C. in Garden City, N.Y., which owns the 24-story building where the Travelers Insurance Company had been a tenant. Rents for the 900- to 1,300-square-foot units are $1,700 to $3,900 a month, he said, adding that "demand is still there."
At 41 John Street, which Time Equities Inc. is converting into six lofts, leases have been signed since October on five one- and two-bedroom units, which average 1,100 to 1,800 square feet. The monthly rents are $2,500 to $5,000.
Work began two months ago at 90 John Street to convert the eighth through 35th floor to 222 apartments, many with terraces. The lower floors are offices. The residential area, with studio to two-bedroom units, with 500 to 1,100 square feet, as well as lofts and penthouses, will have a separate entrance and an address of 100 John Street, said Joseph Moinan, president of the Mazal Group, the developer.
"It is a tight market, and apartments at the right price, with the right layouts and in buildings with the right amenities will rent," Mr. Moinan said. Rents will average $32 a square foot a year, putting the rent for a 750-square-foot one-bedroom at $2,000 a month. Leasing is to begin by midsummer.
But A.J. Developers, which next month will start to convert 17 John Street into condominiums, is betting that some people will want to buy, "given the rise in the price of lofts in TriBeCa and SoHo," said Anthony Fromer, a principal.
Buyers will receive a tax under a city program that waives property taxes for apartment owners for the first eight years and phases them in for the next six.
"The monthly cost of owning an apartment will be less than renting one," Mr. Moinan added.
Prices for the studio to three-bedroom lofts are expected to range from $85,000 to $850,000, with penthouses costing $1.2 million. Sales are to start in February, and occupancy is expected by next winter.

HEADLINE: Angry Koreans Elect Longtime Dissident

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Enraged by the financial crisis that has humbled their nation, Koreans overturned their political establishment on Thursday and elected as their new President Kim Dae Jung, a legendary pro-democracy campaigner whom past dictators had repeatedly tried to murder.
The outcome was all the more surprising because this is the first time in Korean history that an opposition candidate was elected to lead the nation. As in Japan and Taiwan, politics have been dominated here by a single ruling party, and Mr. Kim's victory may help nurture the rise of two-party politics in East Asia. 
 South Korea is the first troubled Asian economy to hold a major election since the financial crisis erupted, and Mr. Kim's victory suggests some of the political repercussions. Mr. Kim was elected in part because of fury at economic mismanagement by the ruling party. But he also won because the ruling party splintered and divided its vote.
While Kim Dae Jung is widely hailed as one of the most courageous campaigners for democracy in Asia, there are also widespread doubts among international investors about whether he is ready to carry out far-reaching economic restructuring, and the Korean stock market's initial reaction today was anxious.
Mr. Kim immediately tried to reassure foreign investors -- who have been profoundly alarmed by his populist instincts and by his closeness to labor unions -- that he will adhere to the conditions of the International Monetary Fund bailout this month.
"I will thoroughly implement a free-market economy, and I will resolutely open Korea's markets," Mr. Kim told a news conference this morning. "I will make this nation a place where foreigners can invest with confidence." Man in the News, page A8.
"We will diligently carry out the terms of the I.M.F.," said Mr. Kim, who had alarmed the markets during the campaign by calling for renegotiations of some of the terms.
To reassure foreign investors, Mr. Kim is hastily trying to arrange a trip to the United States -- particularly to Wall Street -- to reiterate his commitment to the I.M.F. accord and to market economics. Aides have been planning the trip for several days, in anticipation of a victory, and they say Mr. Kim could leave as soon as this weekend.
Final results showed Mr. Kim, whose name is pronounced kim day joong, with 40.4 percent of the vote, compared with 38.6 percent for his main rival, Lee Hoi Chang, a former judge who symbolized the ruling elite. The elections were solely for President; the next vote, for a National Assembly, is scheduled for 2000.
It is difficult to exaggerate the historical resonance of the scenes this morning as Mr. Kim -- the man who was nearly hanged as a traitor -- stood before a forest of microphones and accepted his election.
Mr. Kim, 72, still limps from one botched attempt to murder him, and even in the last few years his telephones have reportedly been tapped and his supporters have frequently been subjected to tax audits. Now he inherits this same powerful state apparatus that as recently as the 1980's was used to imprison him.
"Since the founding of our nation, this is the most historic, most radical day," Mr. Kim said somberly. "The Korean people made their choice and broke all the barriers, transferring power for the first time in our history. Democracy will take root and prosper."
Mr. Kim's advisers hailed their candidate as the man who could transform their nation politically and economically. "This change of Government is significant, but the implications are even more significant," said an exultant Ra Jong Yil, a political scientist who is a close adviser to Mr. Kim, as he helped draft Mr. Kim's acceptance speech at the campaign headquarters. "Our society is ready for change in every respect, including economics."
Mr. Kim will take office in February from President Kim Young Sam, who by law was barred from seeking another term. Kim Young Sam and Kim Dae Jung are former partners in the cause of democracy who later became bitter rivals, and Kim Young Sam is now widely despised by the public because of scandals involving his family and because of the economic crisis.
Kim Dae Jung's victory represents an upset of Korean orthodoxy in part because he comes from the Cholla region in the southwest of the country, an area that is still widely scorned as uncouth and backward. People from Cholla have been largely shut out from prestige and power, and even today many Koreans would be horrified if a daughter began dating a man from Cholla.
In the Cholla city of Kwangju, ecstatic citizens poured into the streets to wave placards with Mr. Kim's face and chant his name. In 1980, in one of Asia's landmark clashes between people and power, the students of Kwangju staged an armed uprising and rallied for Mr. Kim and for democracy, but they were crushed by troops who machine-gunned protesters and killed more than 200.
As recently as the mid-1980's, the United States Embassy in Seoul regularly refused to invite Mr. Kim to its annual July 4 party, because he was regarded as a radical. Western diplomats seriously discussed whether he might be a North Korean agent -- a proposition for which there was never any evidence -- and army generals warned that they would stage a coup rather than allow him to become President.
It is a measure of Korea's growing political maturity that there is no talk of a coup today.
Although he was spurned by the American Embassy at times, Mr. Kim has warm feelings toward the United States. He has met President Clinton and has twice lived in the United States, where he cultivated his conversational English and studied American politics in action.
For many years while he was under house arrest in Seoul, he would invite visiting Americans to his home -- surrounded by other houses occupied by security agents spying on him -- and offer a Korean meal, political analysis and a bit of his Korean calligraphy. A rigorous Roman Catholic, Mr. Kim still has a huge annual Christmas card list of friends in America.
"Foremost in our foreign policy is good relations with the United States," said Professor Ra, who is one of several candidates to be Mr. Kim's Foreign Minister. "We cannot emphasize that too much."
It is not clear how officials at South Korea's Agency for National Security Planning, which has spent a great deal of effort monitoring Mr. Kim over the years, will react to his becoming their boss. Some Koreans argue that Mr. Kim has the same authoritarian instincts as his predecessors, and will now use the state apparatus to help his friends and retaliate against his enemies.
Others argue that Mr. Kim is such an outsider that this is impossible even if he wanted to do so. The security apparatus has never hired people close to Mr. Kim, for example, so he has no buddies to elevate.
Although it is a democracy, South Korea still has many political prisoners, mostly radical students or leftists who sympathize with North Korea's Communist regime. A dissident poet named Park No Hae, for example, is serving a life sentence for leading a socialist group, and it is unclear how Mr. Kim will deal with the national security law that put them behind bars.
In the campaign, Mr. Kim was reluctant to call for freeing those political prisoners, presumably because he could have been called a radical sympathizer. But as a former political prisoner himself, and as a critic of the national security law, he may try to make South Korean society more tolerant of dissent.
Mr. Kim's main rival, Mr. Lee, conceded defeat in the early morning hours, pledging support to "the honorable winner of the presidential election." Mr. Lee continued, "I will not spare my cooperation and support to the President-elect, with a view to overcoming the economic crisis in an atmosphere of stability and reconciliation."
This was Mr. Kim's fourth bid for the presidency, and to compete he broke a promise that the third bid in 1992 would be his last. His entire life has been a series of ups and downs, and it frequently seemed that he was destroyed and would never recover.
The personal cost has also been enormous. Just 10 days after his second wedding, in 1962, the military Government accused Mr. Kim of misconduct and sent him to prison. In all, he has spent five and a half years in prison, three years in exile, and six and a half years under surveillance and frequent detention.
During his first race for the presidency, in 1971, he mounted an unexpectedly strong challenge to President Park Chung Hee and was nearly killed for it. A truck smashed into Mr. Kim's car in a suspicious accident that is widely regarded as an assassination attempt. The accident killed Mr. Kim's driver and left him with a permanent limp.
Two years later, while Mr. Kim was on a trip to Tokyo, the Korean Central Intelligence Agency kidnapped him from his hotel room and smuggled him onto a ship at sea. Mr. Kim's captors chained him to a rock, apparently with the intention of throwing him overboard.
But Japanese and American authorities had discovered what had happened and put enormous pressure on South Korea not to kill Mr. Kim. He was taken back to Korea and eventually released.
In 1980, Mr. Kim came close to being hanged, but in the end the international protests were so great that President Chun Doo Hwan sent Mr. Kim to exile in America.

HEADLINE: One Dissenter At Fed Urged Rate Increase

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers faced with fragile markets, Asia's crisis and concerns about inflation -- had one dissenter in their decision to leave short-term interest rates unchanged at their meeting on Nov. 12.
The Federal Open Market Committee voted 11 to 1 to leave the Federal funds target interest rate for overnight loans between banks unchanged at 5.50 percent, according to minutes of the meeting issued today. The committee also retained its bias in favor of raising interest rates, if necessary, to guard against accelerating inflation, the minutes showed. 
 "In this environment, with markets still skittish, a tightening of U.S. monetary policy risked an oversize reaction" in financial markets, the minutes said.
The dissenter at the meeting was Alfred Broaddus, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, who cited concerns that rapid United States growth would translate into inflation. Mr. Broaddus also dissented at the group's May 20 meeting.
At its latest meeting Tuesday, the policy makers declined again to change interest-rate policy. Minutes of this week's session will be issued Feb. 5, after the session on Feb. 3 and 4.
By changing the interest rates it controls, the Fed's actions translate into lower or higher borrowing costs on everything from credit cards to mortgages and business loans -- and directly influence economic activity, though often with a lag of many months.
The committee last raised the target a quarter-point on March 25, expressing concern that the economy's rapid growth could translate into accelerating inflation.
Since March, the Government's inflation gauges have fallen to their lowest levels in a decade or more, prompting talk about a possible rate cut in 1998.

HEADLINE: U.S. Braces for Wider Trade Gaps and New Confrontations

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
After years in which the strong economy has dampened confrontations over international trade, the issue is set to flare again against a backdrop of turmoil in Asia as imports surge and exporters find it more difficult to sell their goods abroad.
The near-certainty that the United States trade deficit will be driven sharply higher by the economic crisis sweeping through Asia has profound economic and political implications. 
 Some American workers could lose their jobs, and employers could feel pressure to hold down wages. The profits of multinational corporations have already been put under pressure by the downturn in Asia, unnerving investors, and analysts are forecasting more bad earnings news.
On the positive side, a flood of cheap imports could help hold down inflation and obviate the need for higher interest rates. But tensions with large trading partners like Japan could be revived.
The Asian crisis is already altering trade patterns. In South Korea, for example, American goods are nearly twice as expensive, when bought with the country's suddenly devalued currency, as they were at the beginning of the year. That is squeezing American exporters ranging from auto-parts makers to farmers and could imperil the jobs those exports support.
A survey this week by the National Association of Manufacturers found that four out of five manufacturing executives anticipated significantly lower exports next year because of the problems in Asia and the resulting currency fluctuations. Among the industries that the association expects to be particularly hard hit are electronics, telecommunications equipment and capital goods.
At the same time, imports from Asian countries are tumbling in price, reflecting the steep decline in the values of their currencies relative to the dollar -- a boon to consumers and a big help in holding down inflation. Government statistics released last week showed that prices of imports from South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore fell 1.2 percent in November alone, before the most recent round of currency declines.
Economists said the effect would be to drive the trade deficit back to or above the records set in the late 1980's, although it would still be a smaller share of economic output than in the 80's.
Some foreign governments are already maneuvering for what they expect will be an increasingly nasty economic and political battle with Washington. The Japanese, clearly fearful of a backlash in Washington, are already playing down the importance of any big increase in their trade gap with the United States.
"What's the problem?" Keizo Obuchi, the country's Foreign Minister, said during a visit to Washington 10 days ago, departing from the usual Japanese assurances in recent years that the deregulation of Japan's economy will close its trade gap with the United States.
"If you buy Japanese goods, and we use the money to buy oil from Saudi Arabia, and they buy F-16's, there is no real difficulty," Mr. Obuchi said.
In public, Clinton Administration officials say the rising deficit is a sign of economic strength, not weakness, and in any case represents only a tiny fraction of the nation's economic activity. But in private, they are clearly worried.
Organized labor and other opponents of unfettered trade, especially in the liberal wing of the Democratic Party, scored a big victory last month when they blocked President Clinton's request to Congress for a renewal of his trade-negotiating authority.
A sharp increase in the trade deficit would only embolden Mr. Clinton's opponents on trade issues and would further complicate the President's efforts to persuade Democrats to support him in pursuing more market-opening deals.
"People are going to use this as a way to say that the U.S. is losing jobs to these countries and that we shouldn't be so fixated on bilateral and multilateral trade opportunities," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, Democrat of California, who supports Mr. Clinton's trade agenda. "As some of these numbers come out, it could be a problem for us."
Administration officials and many economists say the projected increase in the deficit is nothing more than a reflection of the strong demand for goods and services being generated by a nation growing much faster than its main trading partners.
And there are benefits from the imbalance. American consumers will enjoy lower prices on Sony camcorders from Japan, Hyundai automobiles from South Korea, sneakers from Malaysia and other Asian goods. Because domestic competitors will have to hold down their prices as well, the overall inflation rate should be kept in check.
The flip side is that American companies will have even less ability than they have had in recent years to raise prices in the United States. Combined with their difficulties in exporting, the profit outlook for many companies is worsening. In the last week, companies like Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing and Nike have reported or forecast disappointing earnings results in part because of the problems in Asia, and the stock price of companies like the Dell Computer Corporation have been hurt by concern about earnings.
But even the slowdown in exports will have a positive side. Many economists are forecasting that it will help take some steam out of an economy that has been threatening to overheat, thus reducing growth to a sustainable pace and preventing the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates.
"These rising trade numbers, which scare the American people and bring frothing to the mouths of politicians, are in some ways a sign of the United States doing its job," said M. Carey Leahy, the chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics, an economic consulting firm.
"Clearly no one will complain about an influx of cheap, high-quality Asian goods," Mr. Leahy said. "The joke that no consumer ever died in a price war is certainly true."
But, Mr. Leahy and other economists said, there is clearly a dark side to steep increases in trade deficits. Import competition and slowing exports will cost some workers in the United States their jobs, especially in manufacturing industries, and could put pressure on employers to hold down wages. Some economists think the profits of American corporations will suffer, potentially unnerving stock market investors, who have been betting on continued strong earnings growth.
"It's a serious issue macroeconomically, and it's serious for the incomes of working families," said Thomas I. Palley, the assistant director of public policy for the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
After peaking at $153 billion in 1987, or about 3.3 percent of gross domestic product, during a period of widespread concern that the United States was ceding global economic leadership to Japan, the annual deficit in the trade of goods and services fell sharply in the early 1990's, largely because the United States fell into recession, pushing down demand for imports.
But from a low of $30 billion in 1991, the deficit has bounced back steadily, to $111 billion last year, or about 1.5 percent of G.D.P. The deficit has been running at roughly the same pace for this year but is expected by most economists to soar next year as the United States feels the full effect of the currency devaluations in Asia. Its percentage of G.D.P., however, should remain well below the 1987 level.
"Signs of weaker exports, increased imports, lower commodity prices and lower prices for goods that are subject to foreign competition should increase and intensify in coming months," said Allen Sinai, an economist with Primark Decision Economics.
DRI/McGraw Hill, the economic consulting firm, said that the trade deficit would expand to $150 billion next year and to $170 billion in 1999. The projected rise for next year is $27 billion greater than the firm was projecting just two months ago, before the magnitude of the Asian crisis had become clear.
The effect on the economy could be considerable. Maury N. Harris, an economist at Paine Webber in New York, said he expected the rising trade deficit to cut eight-tenths of 1 percent from growth in gross domestic product next year. The economy has been growing this year at close to 4 percent.
The Administration's biggest trade concern now is that a cycle of "competitive devaluations" will set in, in which countries allow the value of their currencies to decline so that their goods remain competitive with those of their competitors.
That has already happened in Southeast Asia, where there have been at least three major rounds of devaluations, the latest within the last week. Indonesia's currency, the rupiah, is now lower than it has been since 1971. That, in turn, drives the Thai baht lower and puts pressure on the currencies of Malaysia and other economies in the region. Leaders of the Southeast Asian governments, meeting in Kuala Lumpur this week, admitted to feelings of financial impotence.
"When you are up against forces that you can't fight against, there is little you can do," said Mahathir Mohamad, the Prime Minister of Malaysia.
The big worry now is that Japan will also allow its currency to devalue, responding to what has happened in Korea. "That is the scary scenario," one senior Administration official said. "They make many of the same products -- cars, steel, semiconductors. So the pressures in Japan to let the currency go are tremendous."
The yen got some welcome support from the Japanese Government's plan, announced on Wednesday, to lower taxes by $15.3 billion to spur economic growth. The move reversed the yen's steady slide against the dollar, but it is unclear whether the threat of further weakness in the Japanese currency has passed.
So far, Japan's Finance Ministry has publicly threatened to intervene to keep the yen strong, and it made good on that threat this week. But many traders think that eventually Tokyo will bow to pressure from its large manufacturers to allow a significant decline.
Until the last few months, the Administration's chief concern has been the rising trade deficit with China. The imbalance with Beijing had begun to approach the kind of numbers ordinarily seen in trade with Japan, and already American officials were issuing public warnings to the Chinese.
But China's currency is not fully convertible, so it has been left out of the devaluations that have struck the rest of Asia. Still, China is hardly likely to recede as a trade problem.
Administration officials said any downturn in exports to Asia or other parts of the world would be further evidence of why the United States should continue to work aggressively to open foreign markets. But they said there was no quick and simple solution to any rise in the deficit driven by the Asian turmoil.
"Any increase in the trade deficit is not a function of trade policy, and it is not one that changes in trade policy can cure," said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative. "We're looking at a macroeconomic situation of tremendous proportions."

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Climb as Investors Seek Safety of U.S. Bonds

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended higher yesterday as tumbling world stock markets pushed investors to the relative safety of United States securities.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 7/32, to 102 29/32. The bond's yield -- a benchmark for corporate and consumer interest rates -- slipped to 5.92 percent from 5.93 percent. Shorter-term maturities also rose. The yield on the two-year note fell to 5.64 percent from 5.66 percent. 
 Treasury prices began climbing in overseas trading as Asian stock markets slumped.
In the United States, bonds closely tracked the movement of the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average fell as much as 3.4 percent in the morning, helping drive 30-year bond yields as low as 5.86 percent. When stocks recovered, bond prices came off their highs. The Dow industrials ended the day down 90.21 points, or 1.2 percent, at 7,756.29.
"Right now, how equities behave is having the biggest impact on the bond market," said Ken Windheim, who manages $5.5 billion at Strategic Fixed Income in Arlington, Va.
Neil DeSarno, co-head of government bond trading at CIBC Oppenheimer, said: "The flight to quality is continuing. The U.S. bond market just doesn't want to go down."
Many investors and analysts see the Asian crisis shaving a half a percentage point or more off growth in the United States next year, helping keep a lid on inflation. Consumer prices rose at an annual rate of 1.8 percent in the first 11 months of the year, the slowest in a decade.
William Gross, who oversees $110 billion of bonds at the Pacific Investment Management Company in Newport Beach, Calif., said the economy could slow enough next year to prompt the Federal Reserve to lower its target rates for overnight lending, although not for some time. The Federal funds rate is now 5.5 percent, where it was set in March. Fed officials voted not to touch the rate at their final policy meeting of the year on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Dollar Still Up Despite Bank of Japan Sales

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar continued to climb against the yen yesterday despite another round of multibillion-dollar sales by the Bank of Japan in an effort to defend its currency.
 Another failure of a large Japanese corporation, this time the food trader Toshoku Ltd., and more than 5 percent drops in Japanese and Korean stocks also pressured the yen, traders said. 
 The Bank of Japan entered the market to sell dollars for yen for the third consecutive day, but traders said the dollar recovered from the interventions mostly unscathed. They stressed that there was still overwhelming skepticism surrounding Japan's efforts to escape its economic malaise.
 "The market is emboldened based on economic conditions, rather than the gestures of the Bank of Japan," said Kevin Lawrie, global manager of foreign exchange at Mellon Bank. Solid profits from repeated yen sales have, of course, also bolstered the trade, he added.
In late trading in New York, the dollar settled at 128.93 yen, up from 128.72 yen on Thursday. The dollar also traded at 1.7753 marks, barely changed from 1.7757 marks. The pound rose to $1.6681 from $1.6653.
In other trading, the dollar rose to an 11-year high against the Canadian dollar after the Bank of Canada left interest rates unchanged. The slide came despite repeated sales of the United States currency by the Canadian central bank. The Canadian dollar settled at 69.86 United States cents, down from 70.3 Thursday.

HEADLINE: Newfangled Idea For Old-Fashioned Toy;
These Next-Generation Jigsaw Puzzles Take Off in a Direction All Their Own

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: VILLE ST. LAURENT, Quebec

 BODY:
When he stumbled on a simple way to make jigsaw puzzles in three dimensions, Paul E. Gallant knew he had a good idea.
When he looked at the cost of developing that idea, though, he concluded that the Canadian market was just too small -- that his only hope of turning a profit would be to focus on exports. 
 That is what he did, and while he might have made it even if he had been content to stay north of the border, the route he took transformed his small Quebec company into a global success story, and his simple idea has made its mark in the toy industry.
Go near a toy display anywhere in North America this Christmas and there is a good chance of running into one or more versions of Mr. Gallant's good idea. His company, Wrebbit Inc., along with his new United States partner, Hasbro Inc., will turn out more than 10 million three-dimensional puzzles this year of buildings like the Taj Majal and the Tower of Pisa, as well as contemporary icons, like the Millennium Falcon from "Star Wars."
And all this started with a toy industry novice. Most of Mr. Gallant's prior career was devoted to marketing and distributing records. Even as a child, he did not particularly enjoy doing puzzles.
In a high-tech age of electronic toys and whiz-bang video games, Wrebbit's Puzz 3D puzzles are resiliently old-fashioned, even if they are a true innovation. Jigsaw puzzles, developed in the 1700's, have had their ups and downs, with their appeal enhanced occasionally by, say, presenting a mystery whose solution is found by completing the puzzle.
But the toy industry is as cutthroat as Captain Hook and more capricious than Miss Piggy. One season's hits may bring yawns a season later, so it could be tough keeping Puzz 3D puzzles from becoming next year's Cabbage Patch doll.
"We've seen a lot of one-hit wonders," said Frank Reysen Jr., editor of Playthings magazine. "The shelf life of even the best toys is notoriously short-lived. The challenge for a manufacturer is figuring out how to keep a toy alive for two to three years."
The other problem for a popular toy is a rash of lower-priced, typically lower-quality knock-offs. Wrebbit's busy legal department has already fought, and won, three patent infringement cases in Canada and the United States.
"Me-too products are very common in the toy business," said Jill S. Krutick, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney. Ms. Krutick said that even though lookalike puzzles were likely to siphon away some of Wrebbit's and Hasbro's sales, "Hasbro has maintained its dominant position in puzzles and games."
Wrebbit's puzzles -- made of the type of foam used to insulate airliner cockpits, and selling for an average of about $30 -- have quickly become a hit, with worldwide sales this year expected to surpass $100 million. Yet without Mr. Gallant's pursuit of the export market, the puzzles might not have grown much beyond the modest samples he had with him when he showed up at the Manhattan office of F.A.O. Schwarz on a September day in 1991.
"I had read in a toy magazine that if you ever had your product exposed in a Christmas window at F.A.O. Schwarz, you had an international window and most of the time that product would become a hit," Mr. Gallant, 53, said in an interview at Wrebbit headquarters in this industrial suburb of Montreal.
Mr. Gallant drove down from St. Laurent for a 2 P.M. meeting with Ian McDermott, the store's long-time game and puzzle buyer, who has since died. But Mr. McDermott was running late, and at 7 Mr. Gallant was still waiting.
When Mr. McDermott finally peeked out from behind his office door, Mr. Gallant reached into a box and pulled out a two-foot-high, three-dimensional assembled replica in foam and paper of a well-known Victorian mansion in Montreal.
"I took the puzzle and I threw it in the air," Mr. Gallant said. It flipped over, but remained in one piece. "I said, 'No glue, no pins, no nothing, it just stays like this interlocking.' And I pushed the wall off and I separated the pieces and showed him this was really a puzzle. And he said, 'Wow, where did you get that?' "
Mr. McDermott placed an immediate order for 72 puzzles, and they have been stocked in most of the company's 38 stores ever since.
In 1994, Wrebbit's success attracted the attention of Milton Bradley, the games division of Hasbro. A deal was made giving Hasbro the rights to manufacture for the mass market in the United States, while Wrebbit, which is privately owned, handles the specialty market and Canada.
"This takes puzzles to a whole new level," said Wayne Charness, a Hasbro spokesman.
What makes Wrebbit's success even more striking is that not many new toys succeed. According to Gary Jacobson, an analyst at Jefferies & Company, three out of five new toys fail and the big manufacturers are introducing fewer and fewer new toys and games.
"Toys 'R' Us is reducing the number of products they carry," he said. "They are sticking with what is tried and true."
While big toy companies spend millions on research and development, Mr. Gallant is very much a toy industry outsider. He spent 17 years marketing and distributing records in Montreal, then moved to the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, where his responsibility was to make Canadian symphony orchestras known around the world and do tie-in merchandising.
In 1989, with cuts looming in federal support for Canadian Broadcasting, Mr. Gallant decided to scratch his entrepreneurial itch. He had done some television tie-ins, including a successful puzzle of "Anne of Green Gables."
But he knew he needed a gimmick. "I started thinking about puzzles, and how they hadn't changed much since the 1700's," he said. He thought of laminating a holographic image, but that would have been too big and too costly. He wondered why no one had ever made a true three-dimensional puzzle, but a few experiments showed that traditional cardboard pieces just fell in on themselves.
He eventually realized he needed something rigid but light. He tried polyethylene foam, but paint did not adhere to it, so he laminated a sheet of paper to the shapes.
At his kitchen table that night, he cut the foam into the shape of traditional puzzle pieces. To his surprise, he found that the foam pieces compressed slightly when joined together, and then expanded, forming a tight connection with enough rigidity to build a miniature wall.
"It was like a click, bang," he said. "My puzzle."
He formed a partnership with Rene Binette, who owned an air-conditioning and heating company in the Montreal area, and raised $250,000 in start-up money. They wanted to name the company after a regional animal or flower, but every one they liked was taken. "After two months I just said as a joke, 'Don't tell me we'll have to call ourselves the frogs,' " Mr. Gallant said, using the derogatory term for the French. They settled on Wrebbit, their phonetic spelling of a frog's call.
Focusing on exports is fairly typical at ambitious Canadian companies, with trade now accounting for 40 percent of Canada's $576 billion (Canadian) gross domestic product.
And although the free trade agreements of the last decade have been hugely unpopular with unions and some businesses, Mr. Gallant is an outspoken cheerleader. "In the business I'm in," he said, "the trade agreement has been fantastic."
The United States market has been vital to Wrebbit, which says American sales made up 85 percent of the $100 million total this year. Wrebbit also recently started selling in Europe, and next year expects to be in Asia as well.
Manufacturing costs are about the same in Canada as in the United States, with a weakened Canadian dollar compensating for the difference in transportation costs and slightly higher wages in heavily unionized cities like Montreal. But until the trade pact lowered or eliminated tariffs, exports to the United States carried a premium. And Canada's smaller market put restraints on local manufacturers.
"We were assuming 20,000 to 25,000 units" a year if the puzzles were released just in Canada, Mr. Gallant said. But at that volume, the puzzles would have cost twice as much.
Hasbro now manufactures many of the puzzles sold in the United States, but at peak times, like the pre-Christmas rush, Wrebbit's 340 workers turn out more than 30,000 puzzles a day to help meet demand.
"In my sweetest dreams," Mr. Gallant said, "I had not expected something like this."
Mr. Gallant admits that as Wrebbit's success attracted attention, he had to figure out answers to reporters' questions about why the puzzles are so popular. One explanation, he thinks, is "cocooning" -- families seeking entertainment in the house rather than outside.
And the process of assembling the puzzle is different, he explained. "When you see walls going up, the motivation to finish is stronger," Mr. Gallant said. "With regular puzzles, once you've done the horses and are into the blue skies, the motivation is not the same."
Not every model the company produced was a success. Wrebbit made a 1,038-piece version of the Muslim shrine of Mecca, but got into trouble when Saudi Arabia placed a large special order. After seeing a sample, the Saudis felt it was too realistic. The Mecca puzzles were never openly sold in the Arab world, and they are being removed from the company's catalogue.
"What Paul did was revolutionize the industry," said Jean Theberge, Wrebbit's vice president for corporate and legal affairs. "What everybody else is trying to do is to benefit from that." Wrebbit's success has indeed drawn imitators. The company has won recent suits against Telebrands, of New Jersey, and two Canadian companies.
Mr. Gallant says he is well aware that unless Wrebbit continues to innovate, its puzzles could end up in the discount bin. The Wrebbit lines now includes simpler puzzles of giraffes and elephants for young children. And the adult puzzles are moving away from famous buildings to cultural icons, like the Titanic, the CN tower in Toronto, and even a 3-D version of Monopoly.
Wrebbit has put some of its puzzles on CD-ROM. The three dimensions are all visual, as images of individual pieces are assembled on the computer screen. Once complete, the assembler gets to tour the interior of Notre Dame Cathedral, meet Quasimodo, and take in the view of Paris from the cathedral's roof.
The company has also moved into what Mr. Gallant calls Built Art, a cross between a puzzle and a model. At next year's New York Toy Fair, Wrebbit will display an intricate paper carousel powered by a counterweight that twirls and plays a European lullaby.
"People with computers and all their high-tech things get a chance to look at a basic mechanism," said Benoit Roberge, a member of Wrebbit's creative department who worked on the carousel. "They really are amazed when they see the simplicity."

But games and puzzles make up a relatively small share of the toy market, and future growth for Wrebbit could be difficult because of the risk of cheaper knock-offs.
