HEADLINE: In U.S. Notes of Praise, Quavers of Doubt on Kim

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Just a few months ago, the election of South Korea's best-known dissident as President would have been greeted in Washington with unbounded joy, the culmination of a quarter-century of efforts to coax one of America's closest Asian allies toward true multiparty democracy.
But even as President Clinton telephoned the President-elect, Kim Dae Jung, on Thursday night for what aides described as a warm 15-minute congratulatory call, many of his aides were developing strategies to insure that the transition over the next three months does not send South Korea's battered economy over the cliff. 
 "It's an astounding, Mandela-like moment," one top foreign policy adviser said shortly after the results were in. "We've got the man who can probably do more than anyone else to deal with North Korea. We've got the chance for a dynamic partnership.
"But first, he needs to understand that if the economic situation isn't solved" his first year "could be a nightmare."
Mr. Kim's two biggest problems -- managing the economy and managing North Korea -- are related.
Mr. Kim suggested today that he was ready to hold talks with Kim Jong Il, the North Korean leader. But his negotiating leverage with the North will clearly be constrained if Seoul is still fighting its way through its greatest economic crisis since the end of the Korean War. South Korea's strategy for bringing about gradual, peaceful unification with the North has always hinged on its economic strength, and the promise of investments in new factories, roads and ports north of the Demilitarized Zone.
Even when South Korea was booming, officials blanched at studies suggesting that the cost of unification could run into the hundreds of billions of dollars. But now, with South Korean companies unable to borrow money on international markets, any promises of investment in the North would ring hollow.
Before Mr. Kim tackles those issues, though, he must negotiate a politically tricky transfer of power. For the first time in Korean history, the ruling party -- a descendant of four decades of military governments -- is surrendering control. The transition is further complicated by the fact that the incumbent President, Kim Young Sam, and the President-elect have a strong personal animosity that has poisoned their relationship for a decade.
The Clinton Administration's fear is that a rough transition could project an image of continued infighting, disagreement and disorganization in the South Korean Government, just when the world's financial markets are looking for signs of stability. Those fears seemed borne out on Friday, the day after the election, when the Korean currency dropped 9.5 percent in relation to the dollar.
So far, investors seem unimpressed with Kim Dae Jung's sudden backing of the International Monetary Fund's austerity program for South Korea; only two weeks ago he was vowing to renegotiate the terms of the $57 billion rescue package.
But over the past few days, Mr. Kim has sounded like a man who understands that the markets could make or break the first year of his presidency. His aides are already saying a visit to Wall Street could precede one to the White House.
And Mr. Kim is already talking the bond markets' language: "Only the business that can adjust to market economy and international competition will survive," he said just after he won. "Those which cannot shall surely perish because that is the cold, harsh reality of globalization."
While heartened by Mr. Kim's recent change of tone, American officials wonder whether his ties to the labor unions will cause him to hesitate at plant closings and bank shutdowns, which are bound to cause rising unemployment and, potentially, social unrest.
"The question is where he reaches for his economic advice," one senior Treasury Department official said. And ever so gently, American officials are trying to steer the new President toward economic advisers who embrace the American and Monetary Fund strategies, mainly economists who were trained in the United States and returned to Korea.
"I know there are doubts," said Donald Gregg, the former American Ambassador to South Korea and now president of the Korea Society in New York. "But Kim has several hidden advantages in dealing with the economic issues. The first is that there are low expectations of what he can accomplish. But he is both very smart and very tough, and he has more credibility with the unions than any other candidates would have enjoyed."
Under that theory, Mr. Kim may be in a good position to convince his followers that they need to endure a year or two of pain to return the country to an era of rapid growth.
"The second advantage he has," Mr. Gregg continued, "is that the fiscal problems undercut the hardliners in South Korea who say that the way to deal with the North is confrontation."
Mr. Kim's third advantage may be that during his years as a dissident, and in exile, he made broad contacts in the United States. He studied at Harvard (he keeps a collection of university mugs over the dining room table in his small house), and has visited Washington regularly in recent years. President Clinton has met him several times, though never for lengthy conversations.
"The trick is to build the kind of relationship we never had with Kim Young Sam," one senior Administration official said. "It's a big opportunity."

HEADLINE: Stocks Plunge But Then Trim Their Losses

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Stock prices plunged early yesterday but later regained much of the lost ground after Wall Street absorbed news of a big bankruptcy in Japan, a series of stock market declines around the world and a few earnings disappointments among American companies.
The quarterly expiration of stock options and futures contracts also contributed to the volatility in what was the second-busiest day ever on the New York Stock Exchange, with 793.2 million shares changing hands; a billion shares were traded on Oct. 28, the day stocks rebounded from a 550-point drop. 
 The latest symptom of the Asian malaise was the failure of a Japanese food trading company Toshoku Ltd., which sent world markets reeling early on Friday amid fears of further corporate and banking collapses in Japan.
The country's benchmark stock index, the Nikkei 225, fell 5.24 percent, to 15,314.89, it lowest level in more than a month.
When the day began on Wall Street, Treasury bonds were much in demand as investors sought safety, and stocks became hot potatoes. At one point, the Dow Jones industrial average was off as much as 269 points, or more than 3 percent, almost eclipsing last week's entire 310-point dive.
Then bargain hunters stepped in to help stocks recover somewhat. The Dow finished down 90.21 points, or 1.15 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 8.52, to 946.78.
But a late rally among technology shares, so beaten down in recent trading sessions, pushed the Nasdaq composite index into positive territory. It closed up 1.55, at 1,524.74, led by gains in Intel, up 7/8, to 70; Applied Materials, 1 7/8, to 30; Sun Microsystems, 1 5/8, to 38 11/16, and Ascend Communications, 3 1/16, to 27 5/16.
Sharp swings in the market were to be expected for a while, said Abby Joseph Cohen, co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "This is how it's going to be until we begin to know more" about Asia's impact on American companies and about fourth-quarter earnings, she said, adding that she considered yesterday's early selloff overdone.
Despite the market's partial comeback, some stock analysts were beginning to wonder if investors would continue to rush in on bad news and snap up stocks at lower prices, as they have done repeatedly.
In late October, the mantra "was that fundamentals are good," said Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney. But now, the outlook has dimmed.
"All of a sudden, you hear companies saying growth is slower," he said. "And it's not the Far East -- it's the United States. Under the surface there's increasing recognition that corporate profit growth is slowing after what had been a very good year."
The 3Com Corporation joined the disappointment club. The computer networking company, which reported results after the market closed on Thursday, turned in a slight profit, consistent with its previous warning, for its fiscal second quarter ended Nov. 30. It fell 1/2, to 32 5/8. Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing lost 2 5/16, to 83 5/8, and Oracle, dropped 3/8, to 21 5/8; both have also warned in recent weeks that profits would be below expectations.
Universal Forest Products lost 21/32, to 12 29/32; Bell & Howell dropped 9/16, to 22 5/16, and Briggs & Stratton lost 3 3/16, to 49 1/16; the companies all said yesterday that quarterly earnings might not meet expectations.
Nike said after the market closed on Thursday that it would have a 20 percent decline in earnings for its second quarter and warned of further problems related to Asia. But after a sharp decline early in the day, its shares closed at 40 1/8, up 1/8.
Optimism on Wall Street has not been dashed for the long term, but it is moderating. Stock analysts' earnings forecasts for the fourth quarter slipped for the fifth week in a row, said Charles Hill, director of research at First Call.
The average earnings gain projected for the S.& P. 500 is now 8.3 percent, down from 8.8 percent last week. In spite of this, Mr. Hill said, forecasts for growth next year remained relatively high, at 14.1 percent.
The gyrations in stocks were good for bonds yesterday. As stocks plunged, the bond market rallied, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury falling to 5.88 percent at one point, the lowest since Oct. 20, 1993. Later Treasury prices retreated modestly as stocks recouped some of their losses.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond gained 7/32, to 102 27/32, pushing its yield down a basis point, or hundredth of a point, to 5.92 percent. The yield is down more than half a percentage point from mid-October, when turbulence in Asian financial markets sent international investors in search of the guaranteed returns of Government-backed debt.
"Lower bond yields just tell how pessimistic people are getting about growth," said Robert Brusca, chief economist at the Nikko Securities Company International. "If you really want to buy stocks you have to be bullish on earnings."
As has been the case through several plunges this year, investors seized the moment to pick up some stocks at lower prices.
"We felt there were opportunities created for anyone willing to look past the end of their nose," said Alfred Goldman, director of market analysis at A. G. Edwards. "The fears have been way overdone. We have been living with the problems in Southeast Asia for almost three months."
Mr. Goldman said he was buying shares of companies whose earnings should be largely unaffected by Asia's economic slowdown. Yesterday, he said he was buying Reading & Bates, Nationsbank, Banc One and Schering-Plough.
He also bought Compaq.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 606 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

A Few Clicks, and Microsoft Is in a New Fight on Browser
Earlier this week, Microsoft talked tough: Remove its Internet browser from the latest version of Windows, as a Federal judge had ordered, and the operating system would be crippled, the company said. Not so, say computer experts -- and computer amateurs, including the judge hearing the Microsoft antitrust case, who demonstrated removing the browser in court.
 
 While the demonstration appeared to demolish a central defense of the company, Microsoft said the judge's experiment was not meaningful because it did not remove all the browser's program codes and files from the computer, as the Justice Department and the judge's order had sought. Page A1.
 
Pessimism Revisits Seoul
A day after opposition leader Kim Dae Jung won the South Korean presidential election, the nation's financial crisis resurrected the specter of default and sent its stock market and currency plunging. The Government took new emergency steps, hiring Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Smith Barney as advisers and announcing it would guarantee up to $20 billion in loans sought abroad by cash-starved banks. A6.
 
Even as President Clinton called Kim Dae Jung to congratulate him, many White House aides were devising strategies to insure that the transition of power in South Korea does not wreck its battered economy. A6.

Harrah's to Acquire Showboat
Harrah's Entertainment plans to acquire Showboat for $519 million in cash, strengthening its hold on the gambling markets in Atlantic City and the Chicago area. Harrah's said the deal would make it the world's biggest gambling company. D3.
 
Deal to Sharpen Occidental's Focus
Occidental Petroleum's agreement to sell its Midcon gas pipeline unit to KN Energy for $3.49 billion will help move Occidental further into its core oil business. The deal, announced late Thursday, will quadruple KN's assets. Midcon owns one of the largest transporters of natural gas into the Chicago area. D5.
 
Mixed Reviews for Chiron Drugs
An Food and Drug Administration panel recommended that a Chiron drug be approved to treat metastatic melanoma, a fatal skin cancer. But the same panel did not recommend approval of another Chiron drug, Depocyt, for use in patients with neoplastic meningitis arising from solid tumors. Shares of Chiron fell 2.4 percent, while shares of Chiron's partner in Depocyt, Depotech, plunged 68.3 percent. D2.
 
Bonds Rally on Stock Drop
Investors retreating from a worldwide drop in stock prices sought the sanctuary of Treasury securities, pushing bond prices up and yields down. The 30-year bond yield fell to 5.92 percent from 5.93 percent. D2.
 
Dollar Rises on Japan Weakness
The dollar climbed further against the yen, overcoming attempts by the Bank of Japan to defend the Japanese currency by selling dollars. In New York the dollar settled at 128.93 yen, up from 128.72 yen Thursday. D4.
 
Coffee Tumbles on Supply Forecast
Coffee futures prices fell 3.9 percent to the lowest level in more than five weeks on news that a prominent forecaster had predicted a bountiful 1998 crop for Brazil. D4.
 
Merger of Home Builders
D. R. Horton agreed to buy the Continental Homes Holding for $305 million, creating the nation's fourth-largest home builder. D3.
 
Big Board Short Interest Rises
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose 3.1 percent, to a record 3.67 billion shares in the month ended Dec. 10. On the American Stock Exchange, short interest fell 1.8 percent. D15.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From White House Meeting With Conservatives on Race

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a discussion of racial matters held in the Oval Office today between President Clinton, Vice President Al Gore, former Gov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey, Ward Connerly, Linda Chavez, Thaddeus Garrett, Representative Charles Canady of Florida, Elaine Chao, Lynn Martin and Abigail and Stephan Thernstrom, as transcribed by the White House:
MR. CLINTON. The reason I wanted you to come here today is that I hope there will be another series of meetings where we'll get an even more diverse group -- I mean, diverse by opinion. Because what I'm trying to get to is -- here's my theory about this -- I think if we could ever get to the point where we would ask ourselves, can we agree on the objective, and then talk about what means will work, and then look at the things we don't like and say, well, do they do any good; and what harm did it do. 
 For example, what I think about affirmative action, a lot of these economic ----. Let's just take economic affirmative action. What I honestly believe is that it did a profound amount of good for the people who got into the programs who might never have had a chance to be successful businessmen or women. But I believe the problems with it are twofold. No. 1 is, once you get in and you start doing it, it's hard to graduate out. This whole theory about graduating out and moving through, going out into the private sector, that theory never really worked very well. And we ought to fess up; those of us who were for it ought to say that's one of the problems that didn't work.
The other problem is it doesn't reach the vast majority of the people who have a problem because it doesn't reach down into basically the isolated urban areas with people in the economic underclass. . . .
Let me go back to what Steve said about the composition of the police force when you got into the tete-a-tete with the Vice President. Let me just mention three things because Governor Kean mentioned this. The seven white septuplets were delivered by two African-American women doctors. Two days later, two black kids were rescued in a Chicago fire by a white fireman. Nobody feels anything but good about that. Why is that? Or why do all these rich white Republicans pay to go down and watch some black guys play basketball at the MCI Center? I would argue there is something that all these things share in common that don't necessarily get answered in the police ----.
One is, in the case pro basketball, here I am, I don't have a doubt in the world that if I'd been good enough I could have played pro basketball. I know it. If I'd been good enough, by God, I could have played. I was short, fat, and slow by today's standards. I couldn't play. Doesn't have anything to do with my race. I don't have a doubt in the world. If I have a child, I don't have a doubt in the world that my child can play if he or she is good enough. So that's the first threshold. . . .
The second thing is, in the case of the black women doctors who delivered the septuplets -- which is not always the case in the case of police -- which is why I agree with the Vice President -- the community, which was of a different race -- there was no question about whether they could do their job in a way that would be fair to everybody. In the case of the white fireman who risked his life to go in an get the last two black kids in the Chicago fire -- he made a statement that was louder than any words I will every utter, that he was in tune with the people in that community. He was in tune enough that he was willing to lay his life down to save those two little children. Nobody will ever care again whether that guy is on their fire or sitting idly out in front of the fire station, as I hope he will be.
So there's two criteria. One is can you play if you're good enough, whatever the thing is. Two is, does everybody in the community have confidence that the people in the position, whatever they are, have sufficient concern about them, are consistently involved with them, that whatever is supposed to be done is going to get done.
I think in the case of the fireman, and the doctors and the basketball players, the answer is yes. I think in the case -- huge numbers of urban police departments, huge numbers of the business sector, huge sections of higher education -- you can't say that the answer is yes. That's why I'm hung up about it. But I don't think that -- I think the reason that I'd get frustrated if the debate is only about affirmative action is, if we win 100 percent of the debate, we're talking about 10 percent of the people. If you win 100 percent of the debate, we're still just talking about 10 percent of the people. What about everybody else? . . .
MS. THERNSTROM. But, why don't you have confidence that we can train policemen the way we train firemen so that when a policeman shows up at the door, it doesn't matter what the race of that policeman is?
MR. CLINTON. What I don't have confidence in is that in the police departments where there is not affirmative action that there is a selection process that is not race-based.
MS. THERNSTROM. Why not go after the problem instead -- it's like college admissions -- instead of going after the problem of the failure of our schools in the K-12 years, we say, O.K., we're going to shut our eyes to that problem and we're going to preferentially admit them in hope something --
MR. CLINTON What about all the people who are sitting around waiting for that to happen? Are we just going to let them drift away?
MS. CHAO. -- very complicated, and there is really a problem on both sides. I think you and the Vice President obviously have demonstrated you care deeply about this problem. And I think you should be applauded, from my point of view, in terms of showing that you care, offering some leadership, and talking about this issue. I think it's enormously complicated. But I do want to say you, as the President of this country, have an enormous opportunity to really lead this country on a new millennium, as you put it, of race relations, and that is that people are judged by the content of their character and not by the color of their skin.
What has bothered me so far about the debate is that it's very much a monochromatic kind of debate. It has been about African-Americans, and it's been about whites. And certainly there has been a great deal that has contributed to the current status of these two races, but if we really talk about a diversified nation, in which there is richness and diversity, we have to talk about other people. And I'm not pushing for Asian-Americans or Latino-Hispanic Americans, but that's what you get pretty much into when you start talking about color. . . .

HEADLINE: The New York State of Mind Is Wreathed in Good Cheer

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
Jennifer Calhoun has driven a carriage in Central Park for 15 years, and not since the boom years of the 1980's has business been so good. And it seems that everyone who steps into her white carriage, festooned with red bows, is laden with Big Brown Bags from Bloomingdale's or bags with the wooden-soldier emblem of Saks Fifth Avenue.
"People seem to be spending more freely," said Ms. Calhoun, who is 35. With a good economy fostering good cheer, she said she also was receiving far more generous tips, many in the $50 range. "The mid-80's were great," she said. "It's coming close to that. People are better dressed. They have more money to spend." 
 As a Brazilian family boarded Ms. Calhoun's carriage, a group of preschoolers marched along Central Park South singing "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer." Even a homeless man picking through trash barrels at the Central Park Zoo hummed along as the bells of the Delacorte Clock chimed "Silent Night."
No one keeps definitive state-of-mind statistics, but random interviews, street-corner observations and a smattering of hard facts suggest that there is more jolliness than usual in the city this season. Crime is down, tourism is up, the economy is better, temperatures are mild and the throngs seem thicker than ever. According to the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, the city is expected to play host to 31.9 million tourists this year, a record number, and by the end of the year, they are expected to have spent $13.7 billion.
Of course there are overt reminders of the time of year: the Brobdingnagian boxwood candy canes hanging from the Solow Building on West 57th Street, or a ponytailed, bandanna-wearing Santa astride a revolving Harley atop the entrance of the Harley-Davidson Cafe on the Avenue of the Americas.
But there are more subtle clues as well: people actually holding doors open for strangers, and smiles on the faces of otherwise stone-faced department store clerks. Many tourists say they are finding New York more pleasant and New Yorkers more hospitable than on previous visits.
Chris and MaryJane Mudd of Houston were waiting for a taxi outside the New York Hilton, where they were staying during what they called a combination business trip and second honeymoon. Mrs. Mudd, a public relations director, last visited New York in 1988. "On this visit, the airport was cleaner and it's easier to get around," she said. "Our taxi had seat belts. I don't know if it's the Mayor or what."
Mr. Mudd, a commercial manager at Dow Chemical Company, concurred. "The city is cleaner and safer," he said, "and there are not as many angry, weird people walking around."
Daniel English was spending his first visit to New York City ringing a bell outside Macy's on 34th Street and Seventh Avenue. As a cadet for the Salvation Army, Mr. English, 33, and his fiancee, both from Pittsburgh, were dispatched to what they believed would be the most inhospitable place in America to stand in the cold asking for charity.
They were pleasantly surprised. "I think people here are better than the stereotypical image of New Yorkers that you see on TV," Mr. English said. "You know, hardened, miserable, always swearing at you. People will come up to us and ask for directions and someone else will walk up and start telling them the way." Well-heeled businessmen, he added, discreetly slip $20 bills into the red kettle and walk away silently, not wanting to call attention to their deed.
Barbara and Lincoln Howell and their daughter Alisha, 6, who flew from San Francisco to take in the Radio City Music Hall Christmas Show and to shop, queued up with others to see the Saks Fifth Avenue Christmas windows, a mini-theater of animated wooden figures that tell the tale of the Nutcracker. "Christmas in San Francisco is nice," Mrs. Howell said. "But Christmas here is more traditional." She paused. "This is New York, you know what I mean."
Inside Saks, standing at a jewelry case, under a canopy of fake evergreen boughs touched with fake snow and lights, Robert Cordes, 35, an entertainment accountant, considered the attitude of New Yorkers this Christmas and concluded that people are much more comfortable parting with their money and are doing so cheerfully.
"I definitely think people are in better spirits," he said. "The economy is fueling upscale shopping. People are opening their pocketbooks a little more. I definitely am. I just waited 45 minutes at Tiffany's to get service."
Outside the Plaza Hotel, Edward Trinka, a doorman for 35 years, offered his observations as he lugged bags. "New York is very festive," he said. "Everybody's happy, in a good mood. The police are present everywhere. Tips are better. I started working here in 1962. It's getting back to those days, the good old days."
Richard Brown, 49, a venture capitalist, stood outside the Wollman Rink in Central Park waiting for his son to finish skating and offered a bottom-line explanation. "The interest rate is down," he said. "The market is up. In New York City, the home of capitalism, when the economy is strong, things always seem better. I hate to put it in pure economic terms, but that's New York."
Of course, this is still New York, so it stands to reason that someone must be miserable. Perhaps the most determined holdouts against the seasonal cheer are the cabbies. In contrast to doormen and hansom drivers, the cabdrivers interviewed unanimously declared that tips were just the same as always. Except for one driver who insisted that people were getting stingier.
"On a $7 fare, I sometimes get 50 cents," said Alexis Pichardo, a native of the Dominican Republic and a New York cabdriver since the late 1970's. "I tell them to keep it. Save it for the next taxi driver. At least give the guy a dollar."
And the crowds vexed some locals. "If I can help it, I stay away from Fifth Avenue this time of year," said Maria Torresy, a resident of the Upper East Side, standing on the corner of 57th Street and Fifth Avenue after eating lunch with a friend at Doubles, a private club. "I forgot who said it, but a friend told me they were looking forward to a recession, so that they could find a cab."
And one shopper, applying maroon-brown lip liner in the ladies room at Saks, snapped when approached by a reporter. "Don't ask!" she said, her dark hair falling past her hips. "This is not my time of year. I'm suicidal."

HEADLINE: Pressed by Environmentalists, Pataki Drops Prison Plan

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
Under intense pressure from some of the state's largest environmental groups, the Pataki administration said yesterday that it had abandoned plans to build a 750-cell maximum-security prison in the quaint Adirondack hamlet of Tupper Lake.
Instead, the State Department of Correctional Services is considering building the prison on a 110-acre site in the town of Malone just outside the northern boundaries of Adirondack Park, the largest state park outside Alaska with six million acres of remote lakes, mountains and forests. 
 The plan to put the new prison in Tupper Lake had sparked a furious debate in the North Country over the future of the park, which is both a prime vacation spot and one of the state's most economically depressed regions. Local business leaders and correctional officers had contended that the prison would create jobs and invigorate the local economy. But vacation homeowners and several environmental groups had charged that the prison would severely pollute Tupper Lake and the town's water supply, and they vowed to file suit to block construction.
The fight also threatened to spill over into next year's gubernatorial race, when Democrats were expected to use the prison proposal to attack Gov. George E. Pataki's environmental record.
State officials cited concerns about lawsuits and the construction delays they might cause in announcing their change of plans yesterday, saying the Tupper Lake site posed environmental and legal problems.
"From the beginning, our public position has been that the process of siting the prison must accommodate both environmental protection and public safety," said Glenn S. Gourd, Commissioner of the Department of Correctional Services. "Public safety requires that we move ahead quickly and identify a new site."
The state opened its last maximum-security prison in the mid-1980's, and the system has for years suffered from serious overcrowding that has heightened the risk of inmate violence, state officials say. For that reason, the Pataki administration has been rushing to open the new prison, which would house 1,500 inmates two to a cell by the middle of 1999.
The order to withdraw the Tupper Lake plans came from Katherine N. Lapp, Mr. Pataki's director of criminal justice services. It was not clear whether Mr. Pataki himself had told Ms. Lapp to issue the order. The Governor's office did not return repeated calls this evening.
Opponents of the prison, many of whom said they had been harassed by prison supporters, expressed relief with the state's decision.
The fight had "turned neighbor against neighbor, and friend against friend," said Nellie Staves, a Tupper Lake resident who said her laundry was taken from the line and thrown in the mud the day after a local newspaper printed her criticisms of the prison. "It really has caused an awful lot of bitterness here in Tupper Lake," she said, "and it will be a while before it passes on."
John Sheehan, a spokesman for the Adirondack Council, a nonprofit environmental group, said the prison would have been located over two underground aquifers and along the shores of a pond that feeds directly into Tupper Lake. Pollution from the construction site and rainwater runoff from the prison's parking lots would have ruined wells, fueled algae growth and killed off a huge number of fish, he said.
Mr. Sheehan said his group, and probably most other environmental groups, would not object to the prison being built in Malone, which is about 40 miles north of Tupper Lake. Malone already has two medium security prisons, and correctional department officials said the leading site would be adjacent to one of those, the 1,739-inmate Bare Hill prison.
But proponents of the prison, who just a few months ago had been toasting their town's good fortune after the Legislature approved the Tupper Lake site, expressed fury with environmentalists for thwarting what they called the best economic development opportunity the area had seen in years. The $130 million prison was expected to provide 367 permanent jobs and pump tens of millions of dollars into the local economy annually.
"It would have been a good economic shot in the arm," Paul Maroun, a Franklin County legislator, said. "People feel tricked by the environmentalists."
Among the strongest advocates of the Tupper Lake site was a group of as many as 200 correctional officers living in the area who have been commuting long distances to other prisons and had been counting on the new prison to shorten their travel. Yesterday, some of those officers bitterly accused Mr. Pataki of caving in to the demands of environmentalists.
"He has to continue to travel, and that's very hard on the family," said Becky Moeller, referring to her husband, Richard, who works in Utica, which is a two-hour drive away. "We have a 4-year-old and I'm pregnant and it's just really hard."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Whitman Signs Bills Doubling Cigarette Tax

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Ushering in the first tax increase of her administration, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed two bills into law yesterday that would double the state's cigarette tax to raise $205 million a year to help pay for hospital care for the uninsured and for school construction.
Flanked by legislative leaders of both parties, the Governor said the new laws "establish a permanent solution to charity care that everybody said we couldn't do." 
 Lawmakers approved the bills on Thursday, in time to meet a Dec. 31 deadline, when the current system of charity-care financing is set to expire. Under that system, money from an unemployment insurance fund is used to pay the estimated $400 million annual cost of hospital care for the state's uninsured.
Under the new laws, the state will gradually reduce its reliance on the fund over the next five years, thereby cutting employers' unemployment insurance taxes by about 15 percent, Governor Whitman said.
The smokers' tax -- which will jump to 80 cents a pack on Jan. 1 -- will generate about $205 million a year in revenue, making New Jersey's cigarette tax the third highest in the nation, after Alaska and Washington State, and bringing the average cost of a pack of cigarettes to $2.75.

HEADLINE: Scholars Fear 'Star' System May Undercut Their Mission

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
Collectors bid on Picassos, baseball teams bid on batters, television networks bid on prime-time shows. Now, in the era of academic free agency, a few dozen top universities vie with increasing intensity for much admired, much resented "academostars."
Bidding wars break out regularly over molecular biologists, African-American historians, mathematicians, whoever university administrators believe possess the reputation and scholarly heft to lift a department or a school up a rung in the national rankings. 
 They cast their bids in the arcane currency of academic compensation: not just salary, but also course load, research assistance, laboratory space, semesters off, housing subsidies, travel budgets, jobs for spouses (and even, in one case, a job for a former spouse in a joint-custody divorce).
"It's very much a part of the late 20th century, this celebrity-itis," said Joyce Appleby, a professor of history at the University of California at Los Angeles. "It is the academic aspect of the fascination with instant gratification, competition and races for prestige and celebrity status."
Consider the middle-aged associate professor at a reputable state university, earning a perfectly respectable $43,000 a year. When his book became a finalist for two of the top prizes in his field, he was catapulted into the giddy world of academic stardom.
First, even before the book was out, his university promoted him and gave him a $10,000 raise. Then a top private university offered him an additional $25,000, a reduced teaching load, tuition for his children and guaranteed paid leave if he would defect.
His university countered, more or less matching the offer. So the professor decided not to leave. The next year, two Ivy League schools approached him, promising $15,000 more. Again, his university matched the offers. After some soul-searching, he stayed, feeling exhilarated but guilty.
"I'm simultaneously proud and embarrassed," said the professor, who spoke on condition that he not be identified. "You can't double your salary in two or three years and not think, 'Am I that much smarter than I was two or three years ago?' "
There is nothing new, of course, about academics with national reputations. What has changed is the competition for their services. Top universities have stepped up their longtime efforts to lure good people from lesser schools, while upwardly mobile, lesser schools have joined the fray.
What they are hunting for are scholars with big names in their field, people who win fellowships, publish prize-winning books, redefine their subjects, professors like Edward Said at Columbia, Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Cornel West at Harvard, or Judith Butler at the University of California at Berkeley.
Now Ms. Appleby is one of a number of scholars who have begun making the case in recent months that the star system is poisoning academic life, widening the gulf between the haves and have-nots and undermining the ideal of parity they say is basic to building community and morale.
The system rewards trendiness over less flashy virtues, critics say; it devalues the more ordinary hard work of academic life; it adds pressure on universities to do even more fund-raising, subtly eroding their independence, and it diverts attention from scholarship to the prestige attached to it.
Now that outside offers have become the route to a pay raise at home, some professors seem to flirt perpetually with suitors. That practice, critics say, breeds disloyalty, alienation and an insidious form of keeping up with the Joneses.
"There is a lot of low-level complaining and bitterness on many campuses about stars," said Cary Nelson, a professor of liberal arts and sciences at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, who published an article about academic superstars in the magazine Academe earlier this year. "But academia has not found a good way to discuss them openly. There's a tremendous amount of ill will but not a lot of open confrontation."
At the same time, many scholars concede that the star system can work. They say most stars are brilliant and highly productive; they have the power to attract gifted graduate students, reinvigorate departments, improve rankings, make alumni proud and make it easier to raise money.
 
A Flood of Celebrities Raises Duke's Rating
The classic case in point is literary studies at Duke University, which was transformed after the arrival of Prof. Frank Lentricchia in 1985 led to the hiring of two big stars, Stanley Fish and Fredric Jameson, to head the English department and the program in literature, respectively.
Their coming brought others, including Barbara Herrnstein Smith, Eve Kosovsky Sedgwick and Mr. Gates (whom Harvard then lured away to do for African-American studies what Mr. Fish had done for English, and who has since become arguably the best-known academic celebrity of all).
The Duke department skyrocketed to near the top of the national rankings. According to Mr. Fish, the number of graduate-student applications rose by 300 to 400 percent over six or seven years. Now, he said, newly minted Duke Ph.D.'s regularly get jobs at Yale, Harvard and the University of California at Berkeley.
"The sheer number of academic stars is the principal determinant of the public's assessment of the quality of a department," said Jonathan Cole, the Columbia University provost. "In academic life, you're known for your best, not for your average."
The star system can be traced, in part, to economic pressures squeezing universities and the pervasiveness of marketing in American life. Some specifically blame the preoccupation of administrators with rankings done by academic groups and publications like U.S. News & World Report.
But something else has changed, too. David R. Shumway, an associate professor in the English department at Carnegie Mellon University, says that the rise of the conference and lecture circuits has helped create a new form of academic celebrity akin to movie and rock stardom.
In a paper published in January in the journal Publications of the Modern Language Association, Mr. Shumway described Jacques Derrida, the father of deconstruction, as "the jet-set academic, a professor who seems to spend more time in the air between gigs than on the ground at any particular job."
Long magazine profiles illustrated with photographs of tousled scholars in black turtlenecks have helped personalize their images, Mr. Shumway suggested. And recent trends in scholarship have placed issues like gender and sexuality at the center of certain fields..
"One might hazard a guess that the public visibility of the stars in some ways came about because it was the way the press preferred to deal with them," Mr. Shumway said, "rather than to engage the difficult and arcane matters that they actually write about."
Who becomes a "poster professor," as the new breed has been called by Jeffrey Williams, a professor of English at East Carolina University who also coined the term academostar? Most tend to be in their 40's and 50's and in mid-career; their research is cutting-edge; many are in trendy fields like environmental history or ethnic studies with a lot of student interest and not enough teachers.
Visibility helps. Stars write articles that regularly make a splash. They appear at conferences, where they are often used to draw a crowd. Some write for mainstream publications like The New Yorker, The New Republic and The New York Review of Books. Their books win important prizes.
Alan Taylor, a 42-year-old professor of history at the University of California at Davis, was approached by several universities, including Harvard, in the first six months after his book "William Cooper's Town" won the Pulitzer, the Bancroft and other top prizes last year.
Harvard offered Mr. Taylor a raise if he would come. U.C. Davis matched the offer and gave him a research fund of about $5,000. In return for deciding to stay, Mr. Taylor also got U.C. Davis to create fellowships to support three graduate students in American history.
"I have to recognize that what I'm being paid to do is in some ways different than most faculty," Mr. Taylor said. "In part, I'm being paid to be something of a marquee name that the university can use for its development as an indicator of the overall quality of the university.
"So I have certain responsibilities: to be available to speak on public occasions, to speak to alumni groups, to cooperate with the development office and the public relations office. I am being rewarded in part for being this sort of figure on the campus."
Richard White, a 50-year-old professor of history at the University of Washington who specializes in environmental, Native American and the "new Western history", won a MacArthur "genius" grant in 1995 and has since been offered jobs by Yale, Harvard and Stanford.
"There can be a usual-suspects syndrome," he said. "People consult me all the time about who they should recruit if they have an endowed chair. The same names come up over and over. So there is a sense of chasing the same people. And in some cases, while these people might talk, they aren't movable."
The pursuit of superstars happens at particular moments, when, for example, several big-name professors are retiring and need to be replaced, or when a new administration comes in and opens a campaign to jump-start a school or improve its rankings.
Allen L. Sessoms became president of Queens College in 1995 and set about trying to push the college into the top 1 percent of colleges by the year 2000. One short-term strategy, he said in an interview, was "to pull in a star who makes a statement about the quality of the institution."
So he began looking for donors to endow chairs, a popular method of drawing in the money needed to snare a high-priced star. Then, the college recruited Luc Montagnier, a co-discoverer of the AIDS virus, to fill the college's first fully endowed chair.
Mr. Montagnier's salary will be 50 percent higher than the usual $100,000 salary for distinguished professors at the college. Mr. Sessoms said that he would receive another $100,000 to cover expenses; that he would help fill five new faculty positions, and that he would have a $30 million AIDS research institute built for him.
One of the most widely criticized perks that some stars receive is a reduced teaching load. Arnold Weber, a former president of Northwestern University, recalls a faculty member's asking him to match an outside offer he had received that included not only a pay increase but also five years without teaching.
"In one of our finer moments, we said no," Mr. Weber recalled. And, he said, the professor left.
Thomas Bender, dean for the humanities at New York University, said that deals of that sort were "a real corruption that cannot be defended." He continued, "It makes one ask why are you recruiting a person of this quality if you are not then going to have them in the classroom."
 
Questioning A Market Model
A More than any other reaction, the star system engenders mixed emotions. More power to anyone in a captive labor market who ends up well paid, some professors say; if stars bring a university fame, energy, better graduate students and good faculty, everyone benefits.
At the same time, many wonder whether the market is the wrong model for faculty recruiting. As Ms. Appleby put it, the market ignores qualities that universities value, like the nurturing of talents over a lifetime and the development of certain intellectual values.
"By adopting the market as a model, universities have turned recruitment into a national competition, much like college sports," she wrote in a recent column in a newsletter published by the American Historical Association, the historians' organization of which she is president.
"Where once universities relied upon their location, reputation, facilities and student body to attract new faculty members," she continued, "today they are spending university money on 'off-scale' salaries, negotiated promotions and reduced teaching loads that will drain budgets for years to come."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 26; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1078 words

HEADLINE: Marked-Down Medicine

BYLINE: By H. Jack Geiger; H. Jack Geiger is the Arthur C. Logan Professor emeritus of community medicine at the City University of New York Medical School.

 BODY:

DEMANDING MEDICAL EXCELLENCE
 Doctors and Accountability
 in the Information Age.
 By Michael L. Millenson.
 433 pp. Chicago:
 University of Chicago Press. $24.95. 
 American medicine is in the throes of two great and wrenching transformations. The first -- the shift to health maintenance organizations (H.M.O.'s) and for-profit managed-care corporations -- is well known. But to most people the second may come as a total surprise. It is the systematic attempt to make doctors, hospitals and other medical-care organizations practice medicine consistently on the basis of the best scientific evidence, set up systems to measure the quality of what they do, analyze the outcomes to determine what really works and then share that information with patients and the public. It is a process without a convenient label, but Michael L. Millenson sums it up in a handy phrase: "doing the right thing and doing the right thing right."
But isn't that what doctors and hospitals have always done? Well, not exactly. Millenson, a science journalist who is now a senior analyst with the consulting company William M. Mercer Inc., begins "Demanding Medical Excellence" by taking us back to the bad old days before managed care, when the more health providers did -- the more operations, the more procedures, the more tests, the more hospitalizations -- the more money they made and the more the nation's health-care bill soared. The crisis in costs came recently. As Millenson reminds us, it was at least 30 years ago that a greater danger to patient care began to draw attention: the astonishing variability in doctors' everyday practices. (In one study, doctors were found to recommend 180 different treatment regimens for the same garden-variety urinary tract infection). For the patient, geography (and the "practice style" of the physician) was destiny. Citizens in northeastern Pennsylvania were 25 percent more likely to have surgery than the average state resident. In one part of Minnesota, 9 percent of births were by Caesarian section; in another, 48 percent. Worse, Millenson shows, even as recently as five years ago many doctors were not employing (or did not even know about) proven treatments for life-threatening illnesses, things as simple as using clot-busting drugs at the onset of a heart attack and prescribing aspirin thereafter. (In smaller hospitals and even in renowned medical centers, hospital-caused infections still result in nearly 20,000 deaths a year.)
By the mid-1980's, big corporations were insisting that they got more -- and better quality -- when they bought health insurance for their employees, driven both by the need to control costs and by the belief that costs could be cut safely if good medical science were the central focus. To take the reader, step by step, from the bad old days to the present, Millenson mixes patients' case histories, accounts of struggles with reluctant doctors to reform care in hospitals, explanations of the computer-based revolution in gathering information and analyzing data, and exhaustive citations from medical journals. Quality assurance systems and clinical practice guidelines are clearly, even vividly, explained, as are systems to insure public accountability -- since the early 1990's, New York State, for example, has been collecting data on the death rates, hospital by hospital, for heart bypass surgery, and releasing the information for publication in the press.
This is an exciting and important story -- and I wish it had been told more swiftly and economically. The reader has to get through this forest one tree at a time, and what is exhaustive ultimately becomes exhausting. There are also some serious omissions. This exuberant and optimistic report deals only glancingly with the fact that what the author describes as "a gathering revolution" has little relevance to the 41 million Americans who lack health insurance and have great difficulty in getting any medical care at all.
Finally, when Millenson turns to the advent of for-profit H.M.O.'s and hospitals -- that is, to health care as a marketplace commodity -- his analysis, in my view, is seriously flawed. He notes the criticisms of managed care -- 24-hour "drive-through deliveries," restrictions on choice of physician, denials of referrals to specialists -- and then dismisses many of them as "knee-jerk" and sensational journalism. He acknowledges that in many managed-care systems, "unknown to patients, the more care they get, the more money their doctors can lose," but argues that that this arrangement can "produce dramatic results" in cost containment.
But what about the fact that the salaries of the chief executive officers at the nation's 35 largest for-profit H.M.O.'s increased 32 percent in 1996, to an average of $1.3 million (not counting another $70 million in stock options)? What about the share of the health insurance premium that goes to stockholder profits rather than medical care?
Is marketplace medicine "an example of compassionate capitalism"? To his credit, Millenson does not think it is, though on occasion his corporate language can be jarring. While he characterizes as "penny pinching" the proposition that "an H.M.O.'s putting up bureaucratic barriers to needed medical care is little different in kind from an auto insurer's mandating that accident damage be repaired with inexpensive replacement parts or a home insurer's paying only for cheaper building materials," I find the formulations chilling, as a physician and as a sometime patient.
On balance, however, there is everything to applaud in the many-faceted efforts to ground every physician's practice in sound medical science, to monitor the quality of performance meticulously, to measure the results and to make that information widely available. Achievements like these require organizations; there are more than 2,000 medical research studies published each month, and no doctor can single-handedly review -- let alone apply -- all the new knowledge even in a small subspecialty. But there is more than one avenue to change. As Millenson himself briefly notes, the quality-control techniques that he hails are in use in other countries -- countries that have universal health insurance coverage and major government roles in health care. The two transformations -- better medicine at lower cost, on the one hand, and market-driven managed care, on the other -- are not inevitably linked.
