PUB-DATE: December 21, 1997

SECTION: Section 6; Page 46; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 5709 words

HEADLINE: Washington Discovers Christian Persecution

BYLINE: By Jeffrey Goldberg; Jeffrey Goldberg is a contributing writer for the Magazine. His last article, about the Palestinian secret police force, appeared in September.

 BODY:
The sour expression on his gray and lined face suggests that His Eminence Lufti Laham, the visiting patriarchal vicar for the Orthodox Melkite Church in Jerusalem, disapproves of Nina Shea -- her message, her demeanor, even her presence on the same dais.
Shea is a stone-serious conservative Catholic, the religion expert at the human rights group Freedom House and a leader in the fight against the persecution of Christians overseas. Archbishop Laham represents a group of West Bank Christians who are experiencing growing discrimination from their fundamentalist Muslim neighbors. And yet Laham appears physically pained each time Shea mentions the word "persecution." 
 Shea is speaking to the Sovereign Military Order of the Temple of Jerusalem, a group of self-described knights who claim spiritual descendance from the infidel-smiting Crusaders of yore. They have invited her to their annual international convention, in a suburban hotel in Washington, to educate them about human rights. Her message is straightforward: Millions of Christians are now facing horrible persecution, most notably in many Muslim countries and in China, but American human rights advocates are blinded to this by their secular-humanist impulses. The American Government, meanwhile, seems far more interested in opening new trade markets than in defending human rights.
Shea belongs to a new and potent political coalition that includes Reaganite conservatives, labor activists, veterans of the Soviet Jewry movement and, most important, evangelical Christians. These unlikely partners are united by their desire to "remoralize" American foreign policy. Within the past year, they have seized an issue, Christian persecution, that existed on the margins of the human rights agenda and yanked it to the center of America's foreign policy debate. They are now focused on passing the Freedom From Religious Persecution Act, which is opposed by the White House, big business and, surprisingly, several Christian groups.
"On a demographic scale, Christians are the most persecuted religious group in the world today," Shea now tells the knights. "I'm talking about the most egregious violations known to man. I'm talking about slavery, torture, arrest, imprisonment, even martyrdom."
When Shea mentions martyrdom, Archbishop Laham lets out a sigh. It is not that he objects to the notion of martyrdom. ("Martyrdom is glorious," he later tells the knights.) He does object to Shea's confrontational tone. He, after all, is the one living with the possibility of persecution at the hands of intolerant neighbors. As Laham steps up to the podium, he makes a detour to a table laden with books. He picks up Shea's recent book about Christian persecution, "In the Lion's Den," and another book on the subject, "Their Blood Cries Out." The archbishop turns to the audience, theatrically mournful. "These titles," he says, "are not helpful."
By the time the meeting ends, Shea is quietly steaming. We have a lot of opposition," she mutters as she moves toward the door. And this" -- she nods in the direction of the archbishop, a man she believes needs her help -- "is the sort of thing we're up against."
The idea that Christians are the subject of persecution is difficult to grasp at first. After all, there are more Christians in the world than members of any other faith, and Christianity has historically (witness the Inquisition) and recently (think Bosnia) been more closely associated with the persecutors than with the persecuted. But Christians have, of course, been brutalized in the past (the Roman Colosseum comes to mind). And today, in countries where Christians are in the minority, they often face all manner of oppression. On this point, at least, there is wide agreement among church and human rights groups.
"To suggest that the persecution of Christians is not a serious problem is nonsense," says William F. Schulz, the executive director of Amnesty International U.S.A., in a rebuke to anyone who might suggest otherwise.
It is difficult, though, to quantify a problem that takes different forms in different countries. Unlike a tightly focused human rights campaign -- the movement to force the Soviet Union to let Jews emigrate, for instance -- this is a diffuse cause. Activists say that as many as 200 million Christians in at least 35 countries live under governments that abet persecution.
The persecution of Christians is said to be especially ferocious in the Islamic world. In Pakistan, churches have been burned and Christians have been jailed on charges of blasphemy and beaten to death by Muslim mobs. The most dangerous country in the world for Christians is surely the Sudan, where the Christians of the south are targets of a near-genocidal campaign by Muslim northerners. Paul Marshall, author of "Their Blood Cries Out" and a senior fellow at the Institute of Christian Studies in Toronto, estimates that 700,000 Christians have died in the eight years since Muslim fundamentalists seized power in the Sudan. "More die from hunger than from bullets," Marshall says, but adds that armed Government militiamen often surround villages on horseback, kill the men and kidnap the children to forcibly convert them to Islam. Even in countries that are strong U.S. allies, Christians often face brutalization. Human rights groups have accused the Government of Saudi Arabia of beheading Christians; in Egypt, Coptic Christians are not allowed to build or repair churches without the permission of President Hosni Mubarak. Not that Muslim countries are the only ones charged with Christian persecution. According to Human Rights Watch, the leading U.S. human rights group, Communist officials in China have been shutting down Protestant and Catholic churches that refuse to affiliate with the Government and arresting ministers and priests.
To suggest, however, that Christian persecution is the most egregious human rights problem in the world is simplistic hype. Religious persecution seldom takes place in a vacuum. Countries like the Sudan, China and Cuba, all of which oppress Christians with vigor, regularly violate almost every recognizable human right. How, then, does one categorize a Catholic priest who is thrown in jail for attacking the government: as a religious martyr or a political prisoner -- or both?
Several of the countries accused of persecuting Christians dispute the human rights groups' charges, and some see a pro-Israel plot behind Washington's sudden interest in the plight of Middle East Christians. Abdelaleem El-Abyad, a spokesman for the Egyptian Embassy in Washington, noted that several of the politicians and activists at the forefront of the movement are Jewish. "This crusade is like a jihad," says El-Abyad. "These Jewish extremists think they can help Israel by tarnishing Islam."
It is not only Arab publicists who are finding secret plots behind the campaign against Christian persecution. At the moment, the main target of the pro-Christian campaign is China. Beijing's advocates in the U.S., including many Fortune 500 companies, see distinctly political, and not humanitarian, motivations behind the evangelical right's interest in China. "I suspect that there are those in this town who think, incorrectly, that China is the new evil empire," says Willard A. Workman, the vice president for international affairs at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. "China is not unique in the world in having some interesting views on religious-freedom issues."
"Interesting views" is, charitably, an understatement, but the extent of Chinese persecution of Christians is nevertheless a matter of debate. Even the number of Christians in China is a matter of debate. (Estimates range from 14 million to 100 million.) When asked to describe the state of religious freedom in China, John Shattuck, the Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, said bad. Then Shattuck, who is the White House's point man in its effort to defeat the Wolf-Specter bill, quickly added: "But it has been bad for some time." In fact, Human Rights Watch recently reported that incidents of long-term imprisonment and physical violence directed against religious activists are less frequent in China today than in years past.
Nina Shea puts little stock in this sort of report. "Human Rights Watch has no contacts in this community," she says. "They don't know what's going on." She then offers up a bundle of internal Chinese Government documents detailing Beijing's belief that underground Christianity is a serious threat to the leadership's ideology.
Shea often claims that more Christians have suffered persecution in this century than in all previous centuries combined. Such statements leave Shea's more analytical -- and secular-minded -- colleagues somewhat discomforted. "It's a great one-liner," says Kenneth Roth, the executive director of Human Rights Watch, "but I'm not sure it's true."
Shea dismisses Roth's criticism as the bitter plaint of a man who failed to predict the next great human rights battle. "No one is paying attention to anything they say or do or write anyway," she says about Human Rights Watch. "I've got the numbers, I've got the endorsements in all the Christian communities. I've got the power. It's our side that is setting the agenda now."
Christian persecution should not, by rights, be an issue of great controversy. After all, no one favors the persecution of Christians, in the same way that no one opposes clean water or supports nuclear warfare. But the unlikely coalition that Shea has helped put together is plainly working on some powerful political and commercial nerves, and has run into fevered opposition from another unlikely coalition. Besides the leaders of China and several Muslim countries, this coalition includes the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, the liberal National Council of Churches and several Christian leaders who believe that martyrdom, like the everlasting presence of the poor, is biblically preordained.
These forces are all fighting the proposed Freedom From Religious Persecution Act, which would create an office to monitor religious persecution and sanction countries that systematically persecute any religious group (including Iranian Bahais and Tibetan Buddhists). Opponents of the bill, which is sponsored by Senator Arlen Specter, the Pennsylvania Republican, and Representative Frank Wolf, a Virginia Republican, managed to keep it from coming to a vote in the last session of Congress. But its sponsors promise to push it hard after Congress reconvenes in January.
With thousands of lay Catholics and Protestant ministers having joined the fight against Christian persecution, it might be seen as a genuinely mass movement. But it's hardly a movement that arose by spontaneous combustion in some church basement. Midwifed by a handful of veteran organizers, this is an issue manufactured in the mile-square section of Washington that produces the most priceless of political commodities: the wedge issue. It is a process of political manufacturing that Washington seems to have perfected, the taking of a simple, transparently righteous issue and turning into a political football.
For the Republican Party, the Wolf-Specter bill sets up a potentially calamitous gunfight between the party's social conservatives (millions of Christian foot soldiers) and its economic conservatives (big-business supporters). This new movement also threatens to put the President in a political squeeze. His State Department opposes Wolf-Specter, primarily because the bill calls for the automatic trigger of sanctions, and because of fears that an office devoted to religious persecution would create what Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright calls "an artificial hierarchy of human rights," the elevation of one class of persecuted people over another. So if the legislation does make it through Congress, the President might risk alienating a wide swath of Christian America with his veto.
All this angst, generated by a political issue that barely existed a year ago.
To the extent that the cause did exist, it existed in nina Shea's briefcase. Shea first came to the human rights movement in the late 1970's. She was, by all appearances, a typical activist. She served as a program director for the International League for Human Rights, a group founded by the impeccably liberal Roger Baldwin, who also founded the A.C.L.U. In the early 80's, Shea, a lapsed Catholic, became increasingly interested in the human rights abuses committed by the Sandinistas in Nicaragua, especially toward priests.
"I tried to interest the human rights community in the situation in Nicaragua, and that's when I got blackballed by them," Shea says now. She is a slight, blond mother of three who seems hardened by years of ideological infighting. "They all but stopped talking to me." In response, Shea and a number of other lay Catholics formed the Puebla Institute, dedicated to advancing the cause of religious freedom. (Puebla was later absorbed by Freedom House, where Shea now works.) "There were already groups set up to do journalists, to do lawyers," she says. "No one was doing religion." Along the way, she says, her work drew her back to her religion. "I was evangelized by the persecuted people. This work really provoked something in me."
It didn't provoke much elsewhere. Puebla and several other groups kept the pilot light lit, but the late 1980's were lean years for Christian human rights activists. The broader human rights movement was preoccupied with apartheid in South Africa, war in Central America and the Soviet oppression of Jews, Poland and the Baltic states. But by 1991, Shea says, "the bottom had begun to fall out" on each of those issues. And yet, while disparate historical forces were helping clear the table of traditional human rights concerns, the issue of Christian persecution stayed on the margins. To Shea, this was evidence of class bias. She believes that the mainstream human rights groups, and their foundation backers, exhibit a cultural distaste for religious people, especially for evangelicals.
"To them, since I focused on Christians, I was a bigot," Shea says, bitterness rising in her throat. "No one would call me a bigot if I decided to commit my life to Tibetan Buddhists. It's a common view of human rights advocates -- they think of Christians as persecutors, not the persecuted."
Michael J. Horowitz believes that one activist alone was responsible for moving the issue of Christian persecution into the mainstream: Michael J. Horowitz. The former general counsel at the Office of Management and Budget under Reagan, he is now a senior fellow specializing in tort reform at the Hudson Institute, a conservative think tank. He is wire-thin, an aerobic talker and an expert self-publicist. "When I came on the scene," he says, "there were groups doing this, but they were going out of business. Puebla was one of those groups that was dying. Nina is good, but it was going out of business."
Horowitz, a self-described "backsliding Orthodox Jew," was alerted to Christian persecution by his Ethiopian housekeeper, who told him stories about the suffering of Christians under Ethiopia's Communist rulers. Those stories, he says, took him to Nina Shea's office one day in late 1995. "Evangelicals were with us on Soviet Jewry, and it was time to pay them back," he says. "You're only allowed to sit out one Holocaust each lifetime."
Shea educated Horowitz about Christian persecution, and it was this collaboration that set into motion much that would follow. Horowitz and Shea's relationship has since deteriorated; Shea has difficulty squelching her apparent distaste for Horowitz's self-promotion, and she resents his backhanded compliments. "Puebla was not dying until Michael came along," she says dismissively. And Michael would have died without this issue. What did he have, tort reform?"
Still, they formed a partnership for a time, and Shea still credits Horowitz with devising a uniquely effective strategy to enlist Christian leaders. "Michael's contribution was that he called these people and said, 'I'm a Jew, I'm interested in this, why aren't you?' " Shea says. "He shamed Christian leaders into action." Horowitz became a tireless spokesman for their cause. The New York Times columnist A. M. Rosenthal, who has returned to the subject of Christian persecution again and again over the past year, wrote that Horowitz "screamed me awake" about Christian persecution.
In January 1996, Shea, Horowitz and several other activists, including officials of the National Association of Evangelicals, convened a conference of Christian leaders. More than 100 came, including many influential evangelists, like Charles Colson, as well as evangelists unknown in official Washington but who reach millions from their televised pulpits. After the conference, the Association released a "statement of conscience," calling on churches across the country to pressure the Administration to combat religious persecution abroad. Suddenly, the movement had found its masses.
The movement has also found its enemies, and not just the ruling cabals in Beijing and Khartoum. The faith-based human rights insurgency sees the liberal human rights establishment, especially Human Rights Watch, as its bete noire. By way of introducing himself, Kenneth Roth, the executive director of Human Rights Watch, hands over a two-inch-thick stack of documents. They detail his group's efforts to expose religious persecution around the world, efforts starting long before Nina Shea and Michael Horowitz cast him as the opposition.
Horowitz dismisses Roth's pile of evidence. "The elitist human rights groups have got it all wrong," Horowitz says. "It's their crowd that has caused more holocausts than the Christian Coalition crowd. They are children of the Enlightenment view that religious people are the ones doing the persecuting. At one point I was talking to Roth and he said, 'Maybe we could have some sort of meeting.' I said, 'Fine, how would you like to meet with Ralph Reed?' On the other end of the telephone, the gulp was so clear that it was if I asked him how he'd like to meet with salmonella. God forbid he should meet with Ralph Reed. He said, 'Well, what's his position on abortion?' Position on abortion? What has that got to do with political oppression?"
Roth, a lanky, earnest man who has run Human Rights Watch for four years, remembers the conversation differently. "I said I'd be happy to meet with him and bring the Christian Coalition into the movement, but not embrace it, because it rejects certain human rights, which is what its position on abortion reflects," he says. "The evangelical right has certain views which are contrary to the views of the human rights movement, around the issue of the rights of women, and around the issue of religious tolerance, but we are here to defend the rights of all, including the intolerant. But Horowitz is on his own thing, and he has a very selective memory."
To the class-centered charges leveled by Shea and Horowitz, Roth responds: "These are self-congratulatory applause lines, to say that we weren't involved in religious rights. But they have chosen to pursue divisive tactics. It gets a rise out of certain constituencies -- I can't imagine they'd be saying this sort of thing if they didn't get a rise."
Gary Bauer, the president of the Family Research Council, is a slight and polite man, as relaxed as Michael Horowitz is frenetic. But his low-key presence belies his influence in conservative Christian circles and his understanding of how evangelical activists can manipulate the legislative levers on Capitol Hill. In the executive suite of the Council's imposing downtown Washington headquarters, Bauer recounts the recent history of evangelical politicization.
"There's a growing awareness by Christians that you can't compartmentalize your faith," he explains. "You've got the Promise Keepers saying that faith has to define what kind of father and husband you are, and now you have the movement to stop the persecution of Christians saying your faith has to define what sort of citizen you are. If that means becoming a human rights activist, so be it."
Bauer, improbably, has become a human rights activist. This activism began a few years ago, during the debate over whether to continue China's most-favored-nation trading status. Bauer is a close friend and ideological soul mate of William Kristol, the Republican theoretician and editor of The Weekly Standard. Both men were disappointed that the Republicans failed to have China punished; the party, they agreed, had been captured by greedy, amoral businessmen. They wondered aloud if it might be possible to restore a measure of Reaganite greatness to the G.O.P. by casting the Communists in Beijing as Soviet-style enemies.
Bauer's interest in confronting China as a Communist enemy coincided with Shea and Horowitz's interest in confronting China as an enemy of Christians. Bauer, who is frequently mentioned in conservative circles as a potential Presidential candidate in 2000, understood that Christian persecution might well be Beijing's Achilles' heel. "I decided to see if I could get my own supporters around the country interested," he recalls, "and if I could gain credibility in Washington on this issue."
Foreign policy, however, had never held much interest for evangelical activists. True, Israel has always been important, for eschatalogical reasons, and the Soviet Union was often seen as a biblically predestined evil empire. (Ronald Reagan quite deliberately introduced this now-iconic expression at an evangelical convention.) But evangelical leaders were primarily motivated by domestic issues. That, however, has been changing. "Twenty years ago," says Kristol, "they focused on the issues most immediate to them -- schools, abortion. But the Republican Party is going to wake up and realize that the dominance of big business has caused great unhappiness under the surface."
Once the National Association of Evangelicals issued its statement of conscience, Bauer and other activists had a surprisingly easy time enlisting evangelical Christians to their cause. "The Republican Party will be forced to make a decision about what it is," Bauer says. "Is it the party of Lincoln and Reagan or the party of Wall Street and the Fortune 500? This issue is creating incredible strains within the G.O.P. alliance."
A particularly striking moment for Bauer came when he read the comments of the chairman and C.E.O. of the Boeing Company, Philip M. Condit, in this magazine last August. Condit was asked his thoughts about human rights violations in China. He responded: "They are the same ones that I have about human rights violations in the United States. . .I happened to be in China during the Rodney King beating. Now, there is a whole bunch of background that goes along with that. But watching that on CNN in China, their perspective was, 'What was that about?"'
"I almost fell out of my chair when I read that," says Bauer. "It's a viciously anti-American statement by a man whose company is on the map because America had the will to arm in order to face down international Communism. It's just astonishing. It will get more amazing if China does what I think it will do over the next 10 to 15 years. And then we'll have Boeing up to Congress demanding a military buildup to counter the Chinese threat that they helped create by sending our technology to them."
Though Bauer refuses to talk about it, he is paying a price for his newfound interest in human rights. His allies say he has come under pressure from his organization's biggest supporters, the DeVos family, one of the founders of Amway. The company did $178 million in business in China last year, and Bauer's friends say he has been asked to tone down his anti-China rhetoric. John Gartland, Amway's director of government affairs, denies that the DeVos family is pressuring Bauer. "We have never told him he has to do this or that," he says, but then adds, "though in this particular case, we've made our views known that we don't agree with him."
Bauer clearly hasn't backed off. Which is what led to a strange sight several weeks ago. During the visit of the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin, to Washington, there stood Gary Bauer alongside Richard Gere and Bianca Jagger, those avatars of the celebrity left, to protest the Administration's red-carpet treatment of a man Bauer calls "the Butcher of Beijing."
"It was a little jarring," Bauer says now, "but throughout American history, great causes have seen the formation of unusual coalitions and the breaking up of other coalitions."
It is difficult to plumb someone else's motives. Michael Horowitz and Nina Shea are obviously moved by the plight of oppressed people. But they make it plain, just as Gary Bauer makes it plain, that their defense of persecuted Christians is a means to an end, the end being to overturn the established -- that is, liberal -- order. When Shea and Horowitz look at Human Rights Watch, the National Council of Churches, even the U.S. State Department, they see organizations driven by a class-based secular humanism. In Shea's view, many in the human rights establishment "buy into the argument put forward by the Chinese Government that religion has to be controlled because it's dangerous and that there are dangerous sects out there."
But some liberal Christians see danger closer to home -- in the movement that Shea and Horowitz have spearheaded. "There is reason to be concerned with this overly muscular Christianity that is being advocated," says the Rev. Joan Brown Campbell, the general secretary of the National Council of Churches. "That's got some history to it. When Christians act like their faith is pre-eminent, it can create problems. I hate to use this example because it's so extreme, but if you look at the Nazi regime, you see in it the philosophy of Christian superiority."
The emphasis on persecuted Christians, suggests Campbell, is theologically arrogant. "We are equally concerned about persecution of any faith," she says. "The persecution of Christians is not a primary concern. If we as Americans are not careful, we will create a more repressive situation for Christians."
To Horowitz, Campbell has it exactly wrong. "When Joan talks about Christianity as a precursor to the Holocaust," he says, "she ignores Nietzsche, who predicted that the Christian God in Europe would be replaced by a secular god and that the totalitarian clergyman would be replaced by the totalitarian politician, and then the blood would really flow. And it did."
Horowitz, like several other conservative Jewish thinkers, has come to believe that Christian anti-Semitism is a less malignant form of the disease. (He and several other Jewish conservatives are pressuring the U.S. Holocaust Museum to soften its depiction of Christian anti-Semitism.) But what does the persecution of Jews have to do with the movement to address the persecution of Christians?
"This issue is not just about saving the lambs," Horowitz says. "The question is, what does religion stand for? Is it a retrograde force of superstition, or is it a source of modernity and democracy and ultimately tolerance? I say the latter, and we're seeing the greatest expansion of Christianity in its lifetime." Horowitz, it turns out, is enthusiastic about the spread of Christianity. "Evangelicals will be the Jews of the 21st century," he says, praising them as carriers of the Judeo-Christian ideal of individual rights and democracy. "The reason we have democracy is that the Judeo-Christian ethic taught the most radical political philosophy of all -- that all men are created equal before God."
Before Horowitz can help plant the flag of evangelism in Tiananmen Square, there are some considerably less philosophical objections he must overcome.
As evangelical Christians began lobbying their representatives to pass the Wolf-Specter bill, a coalition of business groups was already implementing a counteroffensive. Worried about the effect of this and other legislation on trade with China (among other countries), hundreds of corporations had created a lobbying group called USA Engage. To Horowitz's surprise, the lobby was able to persuade many legislators that Wolf-Specter threatened free trade. In fact, the original Wolf-Specter bill proposed in May contained provisions for only limited sanctions. The more significant thrust of the bill was the creation of a White House office to monitor persecution. If that office found evidence of religious persecution, it would call for sanctions against the offending government, including a ban on nonhumanitarian aid.
Business lobbyists, though, convinced some legislators that Wolf-Specter would impose crippling trade sanctions, and Gary Bauer, for one, was feeling the heat of free-trader anger. "I'm understanding the Republican Party a little better after being steam-rollered for the third time on this issue," he says dryly.
But business leaders were not the only ones nervous about the new emphasis on Christian persecution. To the horror of the movement's supporters, the Rev. Billy Graham's son, Nelson, who controls a ministry in Asia, publicly cast scorn on the movement. "As evangelical Christians, we should be about God's work," he wrote to his supporters, "sharing the gospel of God's love in a lost world, being His ambassadors and helping the world see that Christians are spiritual salt and light, not destructive political tools."
According to their critics in the evangelical movement, and there are many, the Grahams have a well-known history of preaching in totalitarian countries without paying too much attention to human rights abuse. Still, the business coalition opposing Wolf-Specter was able to trumpet the Grahams' discontent with the bill as proof that evangelicals are divided on it.
As summer turned to fall, hopes for a quick passage of Wolf-Specter faded. Frank Wolf, eager to see the bill passed in even a compromised form, agreed to water it down, moving the proposed monitoring office from the White House to the State Department. But even with this and other key concessions, Congressional leaders kept the bill from coming to a vote. Now, with the bill coming up again for consideration, Gary Bauer is warning opponents that the price of passing the legislation might ultimately be less than they'd pay for sinking it. "The overall issue is now deeply rooted in the evangelical community," he says confidently. "This issue is not going away, and if the corporate elite wants it to be a major fault line in the Republican Party, then that's what it will be."
In February, around the time Wolf-Specter will likely go before Congress, religious leaders will hold a summit meeting in Washington to kick off a campaign that they promise will outflank the business interests. "There are a lot more churches in this country than there are chamber of commerce chapters," says Michael Horowitz. It will soon become clear if the issue that Horowitz and Shea have championed has truly taken root, if it has moved from the Beltway to the heartland. Even Horowitz wonders: "Is this like 'The Wizard of Oz,' a couple of people speaking into a trick microphone, or is it real?"
By many indications, including the constant discussions about persecution on Christian radio, it is real. Of course, it is a movement shot through with political opportunism, but that does not negate the fact that Christians from China to the Sudan might benefit from an America that is awake to their problem. That, of course, would be something of a miracle: Americans in the 1990's awake to any foreign policy concern. And it would be particularly miraculous for the human rights movement, which, as William Schulz of Amnesty International admits, "has inadequately developed a grass-roots constituency of any kind."
There is a cosmic joke being played on American human rights activists. For years, they have been looking for ways to interest middle America in its causes, not just college activists and the cultural elite. Finally, a mass constituency seems to be coming together, but -- and here's the punch line -- the mass constituency consists primarily of evangelical Protestant Republicans.
Schulz is untroubled by this reality. "I've always believed that the human rights movement is a most non-partisan movement," he says. "Who's in favor of torture, after all?"
Still, many in the human rights community are less than enthusiastic about the Christian right's newfound interest in human rights. This might indeed be the result, as Horowitz and Shea maintain, of cultural distaste. But there are other reasons as well. Many human rights activists cringe at the possibility of a Government-run office to monitor religious persecution, for other movements would surely demand the same treatment and create a bureaucratic morass. There is also the fear that Christian evangelicals, by their sheer numbers, could swamp the mainstream human rights movement.
But this view does not take into account two important facts. The first is that most people are drawn to human rights work by a parochial concern, and then learn -- and often embrace -- the larger cause. It is worth remembering that Gary Bauer, a leader of the Christian right, recently linked arms with robed Buddhists at a White House protest rally.
It is also worth remembering that left-leaning human rights activists and right-wing evangelicals are united, not separated, by another distaste. This distaste is directed toward an Administration and a Congress whose foreign policy seems dictated by trade concerns. "In this Administration," Schulz says, "trade always trumps torture when the two clash, and this causes dissatisfaction on the right and the left." That dissatisfaction may well be a harbinger of a momentous political trend, the creation of a new alliance in which secular liberals and religious conservatives join together to force Washington to worry as much about moral issues as the insatiable demands of turbocharged capitalism.

Tim Hansen

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1225 words

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/Pendleton Place;
3 Houses That Recall 19th-Century Staten Island

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
PENDLETON PLACE, in the New Brighton section of Staten Island, is an unusual street, a curving residential block built by the Pendleton family in the 1850's and 1860's. Three of the family's buildings are left in recognizable form, and in the last two decades different owners have taken each down a different path of restoration. Together, they make an interesting study of varying opinions of what is important about a house.
In the mid-19th century, the north shore of Staten Island saw expanded development as a summer colony and even as a suburban residence for Manhattan commuters. According to research by the architectural historian Barnett Shepherd, director of Historic Richmond Town, in 1852 William S. Pendleton bought a large parcel at the northwest corner of Franklin and Prospect Avenues in New Brighton, and an 1853 land map shows a house where the neo-Gothic 22 Pendleton Place is now. 
 Pendleton, born in New York City in 1795, later became a pioneer lithographer in Boston. Wendy Shadwell, curator of prints at the New-York Historical Society, says that Pendleton's firm was the first successful lithography operation in America. She says that lithography was more flexible, faster and cheaper than reproducing images by engraving, and Pendleton made landscape scenes for framing, book illustrations and copies of famous artworks. He also took as his apprentice Nathaniel Currier, who later established his own lithography firm, Currier & Ives.
Pendleton moved back to New York in the 1840's. He bought other land in Staten Island as early as 1846, but it is not certain whether he ever lived at 22 Pendleton Place. He was involved with various businesses in Staten Island -- Mr. Shepherd's research indicates that Pendleton was also head of a ferry company.
In 1862 the magazine The Horticulturist published a sketch of a new, much bigger house on the Pendleton property, the giant stick-style residence now known as 1 Pendleton Place, designed by the architect Charles Duggin. The article describes it as "erected for renting," one of a group of seven homes put up by Pendleton.
Pendleton leased the large, asymmetrical house to Thomas M. Rianhard, a Manhattan wholesale merchant who left a rowhouse at 49 West 14th Street to move to Staten Island.
By the 1860's Pendleton and two sons were living in one or more houses they built on Pendleton Place, but an 1878 deed shows William S. Pendleton living in Florida. He died the next year. Other Pendleton family members continued to live in houses on Pendleton Place, and the family rented or sold others as circumstances required -- in the 1870's they sold the Gothic-style house at 22 Pendleton Place to William P. Raynor, a Manhattan envelope manufacturer.
Apparently it was the Raynors who installed the elegant Romanesque-style chimney breast in 22 Pendleton Place, a rich and elegant brick and terra-cotta work with round arches and zigzag flame details. Around 1907 Willard Boyd, a mechanical engineer, bought the house and installed a sophisticated arts-and-crafts-style mantelpiece on the second floor, made of green tile and black iron.
But other than that the Pendletons' two biggest houses, 1 and 22 Pendleton Place, remained almost unaltered, unusual in a borough that saw regular visits from aluminum-siding and home-improvement salesmen. Now scattered among later, smaller houses, three Pendleton houses are still evident: the two at 1 and 22 Pendleton Place, and one at 178 Franklin Avenue nearby.
RESTORATION on this last house, by Miller Richardson in the 1970's, began before work on the other two. Mr. Richardson, who studied architecture in the 1930's but hewed to the Classical style, says "there really wasn't much left to restore" in the squarish, shingled house. Vandals had removed the mid-19th-century mantels and other details, and he brought in Greek Revival pilasters and other details he salvaged from a house being demolished at the time.
With great care, he has installed these and other details -- such as a paneled door from an 1890's rowhouse with a lock from Madrid -- but the interior is still largely unfinished, without a final paint job, much furniture, window casings and, in some cases, window glass. The interior is crammed with striking artifacts from long trips -- a fossil from the Atlas Mountains of Morocco, a medieval drinking tankard, a stone fragment from a church in Toledo, Spain -- and those from nearby, like a carved marble ornament from a neo-Gothic Staten Island church and an Indian stone scraping tool he dug out of the garden.
His garden is exquisite, with shaped fir trees that give it an Italian air. But when he talks about finishing the interiors of the 12-room house he pauses and says: "It really could have been great. I've struggled for quality, but I'm 83, and I've slowed down a bit. There's still a lot to be done."
When the Revs. John Walsted and Gerald Keucher, Episcopal priests, bought 1 Pendleton Place in 1983 for $91,000, they got a high-style Victorian house that was largely intact. But, Father Walsted said, "there were mushrooms growing on the walls" because of leaks. Like Mr. Richardson, they cleared away decades of growth around their house, but there was so little damage to the interior they had only to plaster and paint. The downstairs is done in yellow and three shades of plum, with vintage furniture and religious icons. Father Walsted retired in 1994 and now paints icons full time.
The house has its original marble mantels, deeply carved wooden trim and patterned floors in chestnut and black walnut; a fourth-floor eight-sided lookout has wide views of New York Harbor, New Jersey and the ship traffic on the Kill Van Kull. Father Walsted says that he and Father Keucher considered buying 22 Pendleton Place when it came on the market but discovered that the large furniture they had acquired "just wouldn't fit."
It was Edwin Calderon and John Amalfitano who bought 22 Pendleton Place in 1994, and they began an elaborate restoration program that is now about half-finished. A pipe scaffold surrounds the Gothic tower for dormer repairs, and the exterior has been stripped of later shingles and will be repainted the original green in warmer weather.
MR. CALDERON and Mr. Amalfitano, who work for organizations serving AIDS patients, have done much of the outside and almost all of the inside work themselves, to exacting but economical standards. They have finished the parlor, dining room and two bedrooms with a convincing combination of homemade stenciling, sponged paint jobs and a sophisticated color sense.
Although some furnishings, like an upstairs floral carpet, come from inexpensive outlets, nothing looks cheap or half-done. The dining room, a showpiece, took about 50 hours and a few thousand dollars. They truly savor both the original house and the work they have done, and they should -- it could compete with professionally restored Victorian-house museums.
Mr. Calderon and Mr. Amalfitano paid $190,000 for 22 Pendleton Place, after they stumbled on it when at a nearby yard sale. Their house and 1 Pendleton Place are included on a walking tour of Victorian houses today from 1 to 5 P.M. that benefits the Preservation League of Staten Island. Tickets are $12 ($20 for a family) and are available by calling (718) 720-1666.

Restoration of the residence at 22 Pendleton Place has now reached the halfway point. (Photographs by Mary DiBiase Blaich for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 3036 words

HEADLINE: The Arts Find Fertile Ground In a Flourishing Ireland

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: DUBLIN

 BODY:
FOR MOST OF THIS CENTURY IT WAS easier to find Irish artists proclaiming their Irishness in London, Paris and New York than in Dublin. Quite simply, exile was preferable to the poverty, isolation, censorship and self-doubt prevailing at home. No longer. Today, Irish culture is flourishing as never before; impressive new talent is flowering in writing, movies, music, art -- and now it is happening in Ireland.
This cultural renaissance is more than a function of the irrepressible creative gifts of the Irish. It has come about because the country as a whole has experienced a metamorphosis. In barely a decade, the old Ireland that Wilde, Joyce and Beckett were so eager to flee has been replaced by a newly prosperous Ireland, brimming with optimism and self-confidence, in which artists have pride of place. 
 "Ireland in the 1970's bears very little resemblance to Ireland today," said Sebastian Barry, 42, one of several playwrights who has made his name in the 1990's. "It used to be so depressing. Not oppressive like Eastern Europe, just horribly unimpressive. It's almost a new nationality now."
For Irish artists, the change has brought an extraordinary sense of liberation -- from the need to emigrate or the certainty of penury if they stayed home; from the shadow of the Roman Catholic Church and old-fashioned nationalism; from the straitjacket of the past. Today, they feel free to express themselves. They are eager to be heard. And they are being rewarded with growing recognition abroad.
"If you surround huge areas of expression with silence for so long and then a society suddenly opens up," explained Colm Toibin, 42, one of several newly successful novelists, "a lot of people are going to start writing clearly and dramatically. That's what has happened here. When people talk of the death of the novel, I laugh. In Ireland, it's reaching a heroic phase, like in Britain and France 150 years ago."
Yet if this sudden change is celebrated, it has also set many Irish artists brooding over its significance, uncertain if they recognize Ireland in its new attire, confused by the clash of old and new identities. What does it mean to be Irish in an Ireland that is revising its perception of itself and the world? If the country buries its past, what will replace it? Can the Irish become modern without becoming less Irish?
The search for answers runs through much creative activity here today. New Irish novelists, playwrights, moviemakers and visual artists cannot be slotted into a single category because their concerns are so varied. Yet many share an obsessive need to look at Ireland and the Irish through fresh eyes, to explore subjects that were long taboo, to strip "Irishness" of its nationalistic and romantic myths and see what is left.
Plays and movies are daring to examine the civil war that followed Irish self-rule in the 1920's and the "troubles" that have convulsed Northern Ireland for most of the last 25 years. Artists are addressing such sensitive topics as the traditional power of the Catholic Church and the oppression of the Irish woman. But they are not returning to the past. Rather, the past is being dragged into the present to be dissected with today's instruments -- say, the drama of movies, the humor of plays or the symbolism of visual art.
The social upheaval of the last 10 years also poses a challenge to artists. Gone is the old rural Ireland of "cottage, donkey and church," as one painter put it. Today, a newly urbanized country is being bombarded by American popular culture and has become transfixed by money. It is a society where drugs, violence and corruption have taken root. This may provide artists with rich raw material, but it is also disquieting. Where, they ask, is it all leading?
 
Ireland Begins to Examine Itself
 For all the theatricality of its grand entrance, new Ireland has been in the making since 1973 when the country joined the European Community. As the community's poorest member, one that had changed little in generations, the Republic of Ireland began to receive massive aid to modernize its roads, airports and communications. By the mid-1980's, foreign investment was pouring in, attracted by cheap labor and tax incentives. By the early 1990's, Ireland could boast Europe's fastest-growing economy, its per capita income even exceeding that of Britain.
And more than the economy was changing. Increased spending on schools brought a marked rise in educational standards, while depopulation of the countryside accelerated. Meanwhile, the power of the Catholic Church was crumbling, family size was shrinking and divorce was finally legalized. The old political establishment, in power since the 1930's, was losing its hold on the country. Even traditional hostility toward Britain began to wane.
"In the 1970's, we still had an inferiority complex toward the English," explained Michael Colgan, the director of the Gate Theater in Dublin, "and we measured our Irishness by how much we hated them. But in the 1980's, a series of 'accidents,' like winning the Eurovision song contest and beating the English at soccer and U2 being on the cover of Time allowed us to expand our chests. Ireland began to accept its identity, to learn about itself, to discover itself."
A coherent arts policy also emerged under Prime Minister Charles Haughey between 1987 and 1992. Irish and foreign creators were already enjoying tax-free status here and an Arts Council had been in place since 1973. But Mr. Haughey created the Irish Museum of Modern Art and the National Museum, encouraged private investment in movies through tax breaks, multiplied the Arts Council's budget and founded an elite artist's academy called Aosdana (the wise people in Gaelic), its 150 members each receiving a $10,000 annual stipend.
The arts world and its hangers-on were even given their own Left Bank when Dublin's rundown Temple Bar district was renovated. Today it is crowded with studios, art galleries, movie production offices, restaurants and pubs galore. The artists of the 90's are being pampered like princes by a succession of governments that see the arts boom as proof of their own success.
 
Fame Came First Abroad
The boom was not entirely home-grown. In popular music, Ireland already had international stars in U2, Van Morrison, Sinead O'Connor and Elvis Costello. Also, several performers whose names have come to symbolize this boom were first recognized abroad. Perhaps this is inevitable. In a small country like Ireland, only success in London or New York can turn an artist into a celebrity. But the likes of, say, U2 and Mr. Barry also helped convince younger creators that they too could make it without leaving Ireland. In fact, it is now foreign publishers, theater and movie producers and curators who travel to Dublin, Cork and Galway in search of new talent.
"Irish culture is operating as a matter of course internationally," said Garry Hynes, the founder and director of the Druid Theater in Galway. "A play by the Druid in London 10 years ago was very unusual. Now you wonder if there is any theater production that will not move out of Ireland."
The Irish had, of course, never lost their love of language, yet for decades Irish writing was kept alive outside the Republic, notably in Northern Ireland, the birthplace of the 1995 Nobel laureate in literature, Seamus Heaney, the poet and novelist Seamus Deane, and the playwrights Brian Friel and Frank McGuinness. Then, in the late 1980's, a new generation of writers appeared -- this time in the Republic of Ireland itself. Their emergence marked the start of the boom.
Roddy Doyle, still only 39, was the first to be noticed with his Barrytown Trilogy, "The Commitments," "The Snapper" and "The Van," hilarious novels about working-class life that broke with Irish literary tradition in both subject and language. Yet it was only when "Paddy Clarke, Ha, Ha, Ha" won him the Booker Prize in 1993 that he was embraced by Dublin's literary elite. His success drew attention to other Irish novelists, like Pat McCabe ("The Butcher Boy"), Dermot Bolger ("The Journey Home") and Mr. Toibin ("The Story of the Night"). Yet to name some writers is to leave out many others who have already found audiences abroad.
They may not represent a literary movement, but as a pool of new talent, they are hard to match. Many seem equally happy writing novels, plays or movie scripts. And their novels and plays are routinely turned into movies, among them the Barrytown Trilogy. Today, just being an Irish writer almost suffices as a calling card.
 
A Clutch of New Playwrights
As in fiction, the new playwrights were not immediately recognized here. In the late 1980's, Billy Roche, 47, revealed a special talent for dialogue in his Wexford Trilogy, but the three plays about life's ups-and-downs in his hometown were first presented at the small Bush Theater in London. Similarly, Mr. Barry, who began his career at a poet and novelist, only won international acclaim when "The Steward of Christendom," with a memorable performance by Donal McCann as a retired Protestant police chief in Dublin, was presented at the Royal Court Theater in London (and later at the Brooklyn Academy of Music).
Among younger playwrights, Conor McPherson, 27, also first made his mark in London when he took his own production of his play "This Lime Tree Bower" to the Bush in 1996. The Bush commissioned his next play, "St. Nicholas," a monologue by a disillusioned theater critic. (The play, with Brian Cox in the sole role, will be presented by Primary Stages in New York starting in March. )
Mr. McPherson's latest play, "The Weir," in which four men and a woman recount ghost stories in a village pub, was put on by the Royal Court last summer. It earned Mr. McPherson this year's prestigious London Evening Standard Award for most promising playwright. His next play may also premiere in London.
In contrast, Marina Carr, 32, was able to present "The Mai" and "Portia Coughlan," two plays about Irish women, in the small Peacock Theater at the Abbey before both traveled to London. It seems Dublin theaters are now waking up to the new writing.
"In the early 1980's, the prediction was the playwright was dead -- that visual and physical theater was in," Patrick Mason, the Abbey's director, said. "Now there are more young playwrights than ever before."
Their subjects are varied, yet the dialogue, humor and situations are invariably Irish. Some new plays, like Alex Johnston's "Melonfarmer," about wild Dublin 20-somethings and Enda Walsh's "Disco Pigs," about manic teen-age twins, present a fairly bleak image of contemporary Ireland. Yet even when plays are set in the past, as with Mr. Barry's "Steward of Christendom" and two other plays inspired by his ancestors, they are not necessarily about the past.
"My characters were no more than whispers of my childhood, so they are largely invented," Mr. Barry said. "The plays are after-life, made-up worlds. I constructed them with material from my own life, creating my own notion of family and nationality. It became my own idea of Ireland."
Martin McDonagh, 27, the latest sensation of Irish writing, was born and lives in London, but his parents -- and his inspiration -- are Irish. His Leenane Trilogy, about repressed and dysfunctional rural life in western Ireland, was first presented at Ms. Hynes's Druid Theater in Galway last spring and traveled around Ireland before it was acclaimed in London. The Druid production of "The Beauty Queen of Leenane," the first play in the trilogy, will be presented by the Atlantic Theater Company in New York in February. Another McDonagh play, "The Cripple of Inishmaan," part of a second trilogy, had its premiere at the Royal National Theater in London and will be at the Joseph Papp Public Theater in New York in March.
 
Starting Fresh in Film
With no tradition of its own to tap, Irish filmmaking has its roots in Irish writing: of the country's two best-known directors, Neil Jordan was first a novelist and Jim Sheridan began his career as a playwright. Turning to movies in the late 1980's, each now has several successful films to his name. (Mr. Sheridan's latest movie, "The Boxer," starring Daniel Day-Lewis and Emily Watson, opens in the United States later this month; Mr. Jordan's next movie, "The Butcher Boy," adapted from Mr. McCabe's remarkable novel about a child who commits a murder and starring Stephen Rea, Aisling O'Sullivan, Sinead O'Connor and Fiona Shaw, is due in February.
The impact of Mr. Jordan and Mr. Sheridan has been enormous, not least because they have tackled touchy subjects: Mr. Jordan dealt with the Irish Republican Army in "The Crying Game" and Ireland's internecine fight for independence in "Michael Collins"; and Mr. Sheridan's "In the Name of the Father" looked at the unjust imprisonment of a young Belfast man for an I.R.A. bombing in England. These directors, along with Thaddeus O'Sullivan ("December Bride") and Pat O'Connor ("Inventing the Abbotts"), have in turn inspired a new generation of young directors.
Paddy Breathnach, 33, is among them. And he is maintaining links to Irish literature by recruiting the country's new authors to write his screenplays. His first feature film, "Ailsa," was written by the novelist and playwright Joseph O'Connor, while his newly released Irish gangland comedy, "I Went Down," was written by Mr. McPherson. Both writers are working on new screenplays for Mr. Breathnach, while Mr. McPherson is adapting "This Lime Tree Bower" for the screen.
Crucial to the embryonic movie industry are generous government tax breaks to encourage private capital to invest in movies and foreign producers to use Irish locations (as with "Braveheart"). Irish movie directors can turn to the Irish Film Board for seed money for new productions. As a result, at any one time, at least a dozen Irish films are in production.
Ireland's painters and sculptors have had to fight harder to be noticed. The commonplace is that Ireland is not a "visual" country and there are good historical reasons for this.
"Visual culture was linked to the Catholic Church, which the English saw as a supporter of Irish nationalism," explained Declan McGonagle, the director of the new Irish Museum of Modern Art, "so the English destroyed the visual context. From the 17th century, culture had to be carried in people's heads as stories and music. The jump from the oral tradition to fiction was easy, so a literary tradition eclipsed a visual tradition."
Even after independence, the only option for aspiring Irish artists was to move to London to study and work. Irish painting, in effect, belonged to the English school. "I left Ireland at 18 because I didn't think art existed here," recalled Dorothy Cross, 41, a sculptor and installation artist who has worked with unusual material like cows' udders and snakes. "And when I returned nine years later, it was still very, very difficult to live off art. Even now, people are a little uneasy with visual language."
Yet, once again, much has changed in the last 10 years, thanks to economic growth and a new infrastructure of museums, galleries, art schools and studios. Today, artists can stay home and survive.
"New hotels, restaurants and office buildings are buying art, not just one work, but whole series," explained Brian Kennedy, a printmaker. "Ordinary people also have money and have the confidence to buy contemporary Irish art."
While some successful artists like Maude Cotter, a sculptor, and Alice Maher, a painter, have settled in Ireland, several of the best-known Irish artists are still living in Britain, like the well-established Sean Scully and, from the younger generation, Kathy Prendergast. What has changed is that all now exhibit their work in Ireland. And a show, say, in the Kerlin or Green on Red galleries in Dublin, or the Crawford Municipal Art Gallery in Cork often leads to exhibitions abroad.
Still, it is harder to define most Irish art as Irish. Much painting, printmaking and sculpture are abstract. But for Mr. McGonagle, the new work does have "an Irish accent." From Willy Doherty's video art to Ms. Cross's conceptual art, he said, Irish artists can be seen "renegotiating" their relationship with Irish symbols, like women, farming, the seasons and the land.
"A lot of what is being done deals with identity and a search for different kinds of identity," Ms. Maher said. "We're looking for an identity outside the martyred image of Catholic Ireland."
 
Finding a New Artistic Profile
Yet the business of creating a new identity remains complex. If the Celtic language is enjoying new popularity in western Ireland, for example, most Irish still associate Gaelic with the repressive nationalistic Ireland they want to forget.
How Ireland is presented abroad can also be tricky. Not everyone in Limerick was happy with the way it was portrayed in Frank McCourt's best-selling memoir, "Angela's Ashes." And mention of the crowd-pulling Irish song-and-dance show, Riverdance, prompted Peter Murray, the director of the Crawford gallery in Cork, to sniff at "'all those black-clad young people goose-stepping around the stage."
In music, while the fiddle and the jig are still popular, the Corrs, the Cranberries and the mystical New Age singer Enya have perhaps come closer to blending old and new by presenting the traditional sounds of Ireland in modern arrangements.
Still, wherever the current boom may be leading the arts, Ireland's performers and creators are enjoying themselves as never before. There is hype galore about Celtic chic and only a killjoy would caution that the party could end in a terrible hangover if a recession arrived. For now, Irish artists seem hypnotized by the spectacle of an ancient land suddenly infused with youthful energy. And what a topic for conversation.
"I was much happier when this was a backwater," Mr. Toibin, the novelist, said with a laugh, "because you could shuffle around without noticing it. Now you have to interpret everything that's going on to everyone you know. It's so much more exhausting."

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 3; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Q&A/Nancy Hadley;
The Orchestration of 21 Communities

BYLINE: By MELINDA TUHUS 

 BODY:
NANCY HADLEY is the executive director of the Community Foundation for Greater New Haven. With assets of $180 million, it distributes about $5 million a year in grants and other assistance to support education, community and economic development, health, the arts, food and shelter and the environment in the New Haven region. The group ranks first in the nation among community foundations in investment performance in the trust category.
Ms. Hadley previously was the Connecticut director of the Local Initiatives Support Coalition, a national financing organization that helps community development corporations rebuild neighborhoods. Before that she worked in the state's Department of Transportation and Department of Motor Vehicles. 
 In a recent interview in her office at the Community Foundation building on Audubon Street in New Haven, she discussed her work and her plans. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. How have your previous positions prepared you for your current job?
A. I have worked for three governors and three mayors -- in transportation, housing, health, community development -- so I got to look at the issues of Connecticut and the Northeast from many areas, and the Community Foundation really deals with all those areas.
This job was a perfect way to take what I had learned in government -- both good and bad -- and apply it in the philanthropic world.
Q. What's an example of something good that you learned, and something bad ?
A. Over 15 years I gave out about $1 billion in public money for physical projects. If I go back 15 years later and see the project thriving, that means it was a good investment. Where projects were not community-based, I can't find the investment; it's gone. You can apply that to philanthropy: where can we apply resources, and what are the conditions for success?
Q. Many philanthropic institutions have been connected in the public mind with a sense of noblesse oblige, of well-meaning, well-off people bringing their resources to bear on problems that they don't personally experience and understand. Do you think that's true in general and for the Community Foundation as well?
A. I don't know about other foundations but I know about this board. The members made it very clear to me that they wanted the foundation connected with the entire community, across geographic, age and economic boundaries. The directors finished a strategic plan a year before I came that talks about a focused effort on collaboration, that builds on the skills of individuals to take charge of their lives, that says you are going to reach a whole gamut of people. The board hired me to make a partnership between the foundation and business, government and nonprofits. I saw that as a real exciting opportunity.
Q. A few years ago the foundation changed its name from the New Haven Foundation to the Community Foundation for Greater New Haven. What does this shift to a regional focus mean in practice?
A. We serve 21 towns, from Milford to Meriden to Madison, plus the lower Naugatuck Valley. The name change just clarifies what the foundation has been doing all along.
The foundation was founded 70 years ago with four purposes which hold true today: to increase philanthropy, to invest dollars in a way that provides a high return, to distribute the interest from the donations in the most strategic way so that this region can compete in the global economy, and to provide community leadership. We are a regional institution. To some extent we can be helpful in bridging some of the issues that prevent all individuals from competing in a global economy, by convening groups, brokering, putting some issues on the table that people need some focus around.
Q. You are a big supporter of "asset-based strategies," an approach on which Prof. John McKnight of Northwestern University wrote the book. How does this approach differ from the traditional way of looking at communities in need?
A. John McKnight was invited to New Haven by the foundation in the mid-1980's, after which the foundation launched its Neighborhood Program, which includes neighborhood beautification and building efforts -- things like community gardens or assisting block watches. It's a simple application process that spawns leadership in the neighborhoods.
Q. What exactly is an "asset-based strategy?"
A. It looks at the glass as half-full, not half-empty. It says, "God gave each of us strengths and skills. How do we nurture those?" It's looking at what's good about people. I spent years getting government money based on needs and deficiencies; if you focus on what's wrong, you miss the opportunity to see what's right. If you look on the positive side you look at things in a whole different way.
I've been here 10 months. I'm putting a team in place that will strengthen our ability to implement this new model, looking at how to build on the positives. It's not going to happen overnight; it will take many years to accomplish.
Q. The foundation was instrumental in bringing together something called the Arts Coalition. What's the goal there?
A. We are trying to build new networks across special interests, geographic lines and institutional territories. The arts community undertook a more comprehensive assessment of itself as an economic, cultural and educational force. The Arts Council of Greater New Haven, foundations, arts institutions, the business community and the city pooled resources to do what will be a blueprint for the role of the arts in community development, as well as for the future of arts groups themselves.
Q. Your annual report is full of funds: unrestricted, preference, donor advised, designated or field of interest funds. It sometimes seems that would create tremendous confusion among potential donors. What do they all mean?
A. The different kinds of funds give donors flexibility in what they want to do: fund an area of interest, such as kids or arts or health, or give to a specific geographic area, or in trust to the board of the Community Foundation to deal with problems in the future. For example, 50 years ago the issue was polio; now it's AIDS. Who knows what it will be in another 50 years?
Not everyone has $10,000 to start a fund. You maybe have only $1,000 or $500 but you want to do something that will have an impact. For example, the Women and Girls' Fund is donor-advised. Women came together and said, "We will pledge $1,000 over five years." That's doable.
Q. The foundation partnered with the City of New Haven and won a $4.5 million Federal grant to improve health for pregnant women and infants. Is this the kind of collaboration you were hired to do?
A. Yes. It includes a community-based approach. This program has been going for about 5 years in 20 cities. It's been found that in communities that have more involvement the outcomes are better. Our application was a collaboration between the city, the foundation, the Consortium for Substance Abusing Women and Their Children and the Special Commission on Infant Health, which was initially funded by the Community Foundation 10 years ago to address the issue of high infant mortality in New Haven.
We are going to mentor with some of the cities in the first round, to learn from them their best practices and apply them to New Haven.
Q. Do you have any examples of successful practices from other cities?
A. In a city in New Hampshire doctors and other medical people asked the community how to accomplish the goal of reducing teen-age pregnancy. The intervention the community came up with was to get the kids jobs. The adolescent pregnancy rate went down from 22 percent to 6 percent in one year. If they had left it to the medical establishment only, it would have come up with medical interventions.
Q. What are the goals of the grant?
A. To reduce adolescent pregnancy, and to improve health care for women and babies from pregnancy through the first year of life. There are about 2,000 births a year in the city, and about 500 of them are high-risk.
Q. You mentioned a "funder collaborative." What's that?
A. I think it's one of the most important aspects of my job. The foundation must work collaboratively with other funders to ensure outcomes and benchmarks. Our area includes Federal and state government, 21 municipal governments, five United Ways and several private foundations.
Two months after I got here, the foundation board approved our membership in the Coordinating Council of Foundations, a regional association of grantmakers that gets around the table to make sure all the resources are used as effectively as possible. We are forming a New Haven Advisory Committee to the Council.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nancy Hadley, executive director of the Community Foundation for Greater New Haven, presides at a breakfast meeting in Derby. (Michael J. Doolittle for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1383 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
As Retailers Expand, New Shopping Centers Rise

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WITH a healthy retail climate and a roster of national retail chains expanding in or entering New Jersey developers are scrambling to put up new shopping centers to accommodate such tenants as anchors.
Two are power centers -- defined by the International Council of Shopping Centers in Manhattan as open-air centers with 300,000 square feet or more and three or more "big box" specialty outlets. These and four other shopping centers either completed, under way or planned count among their tenants national discounters like Wal-Mart and Target; home-improvement chains such as Home Depot and Lowe's, and Kohl's department store, the latter two new entries in the state. 
 Five of the shopping centers are new, and a sixth is expanding. Collectively, they total 2 million square feet.
The tenants, which are on aggressive campaigns to increase their market share, find the state attractive because of its dense population, large number of high-income residents and heavily traveled highways, retail analysts say. Movie theaters and supermarket chains are also on a growth spree, as are regional retailers such as Bob's Sporting Goods.
"The state's retail market has not been this good in 10 to 12 years and it has been particularly good for developers, who can choose from among a number of tenants," said Ted Kraus, who heads his own retail consulting firm in Mercerville. Rents have risen 10 to 15 percent over the last year while the number of empty stores has decreased, Mr. Kraus said, noting that the statewide shopping center vacancy rate, excluding major cities, was under 3 percent, down from 5 percent the same time last year.
And with national retailers on board as tenants in these centers financing is easier to obtain, added Gene P. Spiegelman, associate managing director at the retail group of Insignia/ESG, the Manhattan brokerage.
What is not easy, he said, and other analysts agreed, is finding suitably zoned sites. That, along with environmental constraints, long approval processes and, in some cases, community resistance will temper the pace of new construction.
While Christmas sales are up 2 to 3 percent over last year's, Mr. Kraus said last week, retailers had anticipated as much as a 5 percent increase. Nevertheless, he added, they expand to remain competitive.
Wal-Mart's expansion and the arrival of Target and Kohl's in the state last March, Mr. Kraus said, are expected to "severely hurt" both Caldor and Bradlees, both of which are undergoing reorganization following Chapter 11 bankruptcy filings in 1995.
So is a glut of space inevitable? "That's always part of the real estate cycle," Mr. Kraus warned. "But for the next six months the retail market, short of a war, should remain on a healthy track."
To feed the prevailing optimism, the developer National Realty & Development Corporation of Purchase, N.Y., has recently completed two projects and has two more in various stages of development in the western and central portions of the state. Each has a Wal-Mart store as an anchor. Other anchors include a supermarket and a movie theater.
The projects -- each costing $20 million to $25 million to develop -- are being financed by conventional bank loans and the company's own equity. Rents for the smaller stores range from $16 to $19 a square foot; the bigger ones are less, and most of the space in all of the centers has been preleased, said Richard A. Baker, National Realty's president.
"We feel the community shopping center is a strong retail concept, for which there will be a long-term need," Mr. Baker said. "No matter what happens in the world people will always get in their cars and go to a supermarket to buy a quart of milk or to a discount store to walk down the aisles."
He said his company also believed that New Jersey's economy had come back "faster and stronger than other parts of the Northeast" and that there were areas within the state that could absorb more stores. One, he said, is the growing Interstate 78 corridor through the western one-fourth of the state, where the company's four projects are situated.
Last October National Realty completed a 332,695-square-foot center on 50 acres along Route 22, just off I-78 in Pohatcong in Warren County. It was designed to serve the greater Phillipsburg area, where commercial growth had been long hampered until the sewer plant in the area was expanded two years ago, said Mr. Baker.
CALLED Pohatcong Plaza, the shopping center is anchored by a 128,212-square-foot Wal-Mart. It will be joined by a 59,111-square-foot Giant Supermarket and a 43,500-square-foot, 12-screen Regal Cinema complex, which are scheduled to open next spring.
In Franklin Township in Hunterdon County, the company completed the renovation of an existing 227,000-square-foot center on 30 acres on Pittstown Road (Route 513), not far from Exit 15 of I-78. A key part of the improvements to the center, which was half vacant when National Realty purchased it in 1996, involved replacing a large amount of vacant space with a 116,000-square-foot Wal-Mart. That store opened last April and anchors the center, now called Wal-Mart Plaza, along with a 60,000-square-foot renovated Laneco supermarket.
Future plans include expanding the Wal-Mart store by 7,000 square feet and developing a 32,000-square-foot, 10-screen movie theater on the site.
Mr. Baker said his company also expected to break ground in the spring on a 268,000-square-foot center in Manville in Somerset County and had state and local approvals for the fourth project, a 286,000-foot center in Mansfield in Warren County.
"We will continue to look for sites in communities where we see a need, and if we can't find that we won't build," Mr. Baker said.
Wal-Mart, based in Bentonville, Ark., also has three more stores in various stages of development elsewhere in New Jersey. If all the new stores are realized they would bring to 21 the number of stores the discounter has opened since it entered the state in 1991 as part of its eastward expansion, said Keith T. Morris, a spokesman. "And we have not completed our expansion here," Mr. Morris said, adding that the company would open more stores in keeping with market demand.
In Piscataway, at Shelton Road and South Washington Avenue, a 421,000-square-foot power center is under construction. It will include as anchors a 134,843-square-foot Wal-Mart as well as the first Lowe's home-improvement store in the state, with 144,700 square feet of space including a garden shop. The company, based in North Wilkesboro, N.C., started its expansion into the New York metropolitan area last year.
Garden Homes Commercial, a division of Garden Homes, both based in Short Hills, is developing the project, convinced that the big-box retailers collected in such centers offer the price and convenience consumers want. It will take 18 months to complete.
The concept also made sense for Hillview Center on Route 38 in Cherry Hill, a 340,000-square-foot power center that opened last October. The developer of the $50 million project is Preit-Rubin of Philadelphia, the development and management arm of the Pennsylvania Real Estate Investment Trust.
Eric M. Mallory, vice president of development at Preit-Rubin, noted that 1.7 million people with an average household income of $42,500 lived within a three-mile radius of the site, that Hillview Center was across Route 38 from the 1.2 million-square-foot Cherry Hill Mall, which already attracts those consumers, and that 45,000 cars pass the site each day.
Kohl's department store is making its first foray into the state with an 86,770-square foot store at Hillview Center. Another anchor is Target, which opened a 130,915-square-foot store.
Target, based in Minneapolis, entered the state as part of its expansion into the Mid-Atlantic region. "New Jersey has great demographics and consumers here fit our customer profile -- young middle-income families who are well educated," said Carolyn A. Brookter, a spokeswoman for Target, discussing the reasons her company had moved into the state. Target is considered a competitor to Wal-Mart
Ms. Brookter said that three Target stores, including the one at the Hillview Center, had opened this year and that three or four more would open next year.
