HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Painting With Wood and Ink, as a Master Did It

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
THE Museum of the American Hungarian Foundation here devotes itself to the work of artists who were born in Hungary but lived and worked elsewhere. The artist currently featured, Joseph Domjan, a virtuoso in the medium of the color woodcut, ideally fits this requirement.
Born in 1907 in Kispest, near Budapest, he made his first woodcut in Sweden in 1947. His art has many affinities with Asian art, links that were strengthened in 1955 when he made a yearlong visit to China. When Hungary's failed uprising against Soviet domination anti-Communist revolution came in 1956, he was exhibiting his work in Switzerland, and from there he emigrated to the United States. Domjan (pronounced DOE-mi-yan) lived and maintained a studio first in River Edge, Bergen County, and then in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., where he died in 1992. 
 His contributions to the art of woodcut are highly original. Woodcuts printed with many colors are central to Asian art but unusual in the West. Domjan, who began his career as a painter, treated the color woodcut like a painting. His carved blocks were covered with thick oil paint instead of the usual printer's ink, and the image was built up in many layered applications of rich, often contrasting colors. The final result often resembles a textured painting more than a print. Most of the prints are shown in frames without glass fronts, so that the painterly surfaces may be appreciated.
Zsuzsanna Szabolcsi, the librarian at the Montclair Art Museum, and Patricia L. Fazekas, curator of the Foundation's museum, organized this retrospective in terms of subject and theme, rather than chronologically. It opens with several pastel portraits and early woodcuts that conform to Stalinist-era conventions. "Pouring Molten Iron/Open Hearth Furnace" is not as dreary as it sounds, for the hot metal is a gleaming yellow that jumps out of the mostly black composition.
Domjan seems to have been at his most inventive and splendid when he was creating animals, as in the sinuous composition titled "Fish Deer," from the early 1970's, which makes the most of the similar curves of a deer's antler, and a fish's tail. His greatest enthusiasm was birds, and peacocks were the perfect vehicles for his love of excess. But there was more: compositions titled "Eternal Peacock" and "Everlasting Peacock" were for him symbols of the ultimate triumph of the human spirit over adversity and also embodied a merging of imagination and reason.
A hallmark of Domjan's style is lacy patterning inside the major contours of an image. Such intricate decorative patterning is a staple of Hungarian folk arts, but Domjan uses it with abandon. In "Fish Deer," for example, the attentive viewer will discover many spectral fish swimming through the bodies of the two central animals. Domjan maintained that this obvious borrowing from folk art allied him with the composer Bela Bartok, who incorporated Hungarian folk tunes into his otherwise very modern works.
Domjan's major style translated easily and well into other media. The Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan used to sell brass Christmas ornaments designed by Domjan in its gift shop, and major tapestry makers understood that the multiple layers composing a Domjan woodcut are analogous to the various colored threads in a rich weaving. His composition "The Big Poppy" was woven at the Royal Tapestry Workshops in Madrid, and "Peacock of Carnations" in Aubusson, France.
When he depicted human figures, it was similarly in a very stylized way. Typically, a person is but a small head and tiny feet at either end of an enormous, curving bell-like shape full of patterning. A viewer realizes how the patterning ennobles and makes charming everyone portrayed. For example, "Red Shepherd" looks like an aristocrat, with a flower-decorated cape and flamboyant feathers emerging from the band of his tall hat. It may take a while to find the two personages of "Mother and Child"; the attention of most viewers will be on the rather angular, even harsh patterning that contrasts with the rounded contours of the woman's dress and veil.
In addition to the technique he developed, Domjan also printed the standard way, with printer's ink, and the curators have assembled a few examples of the same composition made by each process. The contrast is astounding; the viewer's eye notices very different details.
B OTANICAL subjects, from flowers to herbs, were a subject to which Domjan turned consistently during his career, though understandably they lack the ingenious qualities of the animals and the figures. One wall of the gallery is devoted to 22 black-and-white images that illustrate "Toldi," a dramatic ballad written in 1847 by Janos Aranyi. The arrangement is rather like an animator's story board. There's obviously much action, and the display is almost dizzying in its rhythm, as well as in the sharp differentiation between dark and light components. Regrettably, the text of the ballad is not furnished.
It is always satisfying to be given a glimpse of an artist's tools, and several of Domjan's rather large blocks of hard, resistant fruit wood are included; for the sake of economy, he carved on both sides. In a multiple-block woodcut, the key-block is the one containing the outline of the composition and is printed last. Ms. Fazekas reports that Domjan drew the shapes on the key-blocks, but it was his wife, Evelyn, sometimes called his collaborator, who cut them.
 
JOSEPH DOMJAN
Museum of the American Hungarian Foundation
300 Somerset Street, New Brunswick
Through Jan. 25. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 4 P.M.
(732) 846-5777

HEADLINE: Q&A/Dr. Howard M. Newburger;
On the Front Line of Fighting Child Abuse

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
AS a sergeant in World War II, Howard M. Newburger was so inspired by the sense of dignity of concentration camp survivors that he became a psychologist. Today, in his practice, Dr. Newburger seeks to help victims of a different kind of brutality -- child abuse.
The statistics he cites on child abuse are staggering: 3 million children a year across the United States are victims of abuse or neglect, with 1,000 children dying as a result. Dr. Newburger says the blame for the increase in abuse can be placed in part on the dislocation that civilization is going through -- the "Third Wave," which the futurist Alvin Toffler, also the author of "Future Shock," wrote about decades ago. 
 On Feb. 14 in Manhattan, Dr. Newburger, a resident of Harrison, will discuss techniques for treating abused children and sensitizing professionals to the issues at the yearly meeting of the New York Chapter of the American Society of Group Psychotherapy and Psychodrama.
Dr. Newburger, who is trained in psychoanalysis, was formerly chief psychologist for the Annandale prison in New Jersey, an adviser to the United Nations and chairman of the psychology department at New York University before entering private practice in Harrison. He also helped found the Institutes of Applied Human Dynamics for the Severely and Multiply Developmentally Disabled (St. Jude's) in Tarrytown and Pleasantville.
Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Dr. Newburger:
Q. What caught your interest in specializing in child abuse issues?
A. Two things. The first was when I was a psychoanalyst at the United Nations in 1952. One of the problems we had was in northern Burma where there was an enormous increase in child abuse, marital breakdowns, alcoholism, drug addiction. It was embarrassing because millions and millions of dollars were being pumped into northern Burma to permit them to have a developed infrastructure, schools, health, hospitals, housing, and with all this largesse, look at these terrible statistics. It was awful.
So my problem was to help find out why. And the why was that the people were Buddhists, but unlike the Chinese Buddha, who was a fat Buddha, their Buddha was a slender Buddha who didn't need anything more. With all the largesse, they were not prepared. It went against the then existing value system. Whenever there is internal conflict of that sort, we can expect manifestation of disease -- violence , brutality, alcoholism, all those things. We solved the problem: we stopped giving money to northern Burma and the abuse stopped.
I was also influenced because I had been chief psychologist in a state prison, and it seemed to me that most of the people who were involved in violent offenses -- murder and otherwise -- had been physically abused as they were growing up. There seemed to be a linkage.
Q. Tell about what you saw during World War II and how that influenced you.
A. I have some knowledge of German, and I had 72 combat points at the end of World War II, which meant I was eligible to be shipped back early to go home. And then we were going to have a 10- or 15-day furlough, then we'd be trained for the invasion of Japan. However, I came down with sandfly fever, so I missed going back on the boat. I got through that and then instead of going back home they shipped me to Germany. There was a camp there, and I became somewhat involved with the people at the camp. What impressed me enormously was that despite the unspeakable treatment that they had experienced, they still maintained a sense of dignity and self-respect and a sense of humor. I was astounded. I was so impressed with what I saw, the strength of these people, that I wanted to find out more about it. And that's why I went into psychoanalysis.
Q. In recent years, there has been an increase in the attention given to child abuse, but apparently there is an increase in child abuse cases as well. Is there more abuse, or are there just more reported cases?
A. I think it's both. I think that since the Holocaust and since the atomic bomb in Japan people have become more sensitized to humanity and they are more sensitized to abuse and there are more reports. The other thing is this: we're in the third industrial revolution now. And this is enormous. The first industrial revolution was the invention of the wooden hoe in the Mesopotamian crescent. That marked life enormously. It meant people could become food growers and meant there was a surplus and we could then have music, art, literature and we could start to record our history.
This continued until the time that chemical fire was rediscovered. The Greeks had had the turbine, but they used it as a toy. They didn't develop it as a source of power. This introduced the second industrial revolution. Again the complete value system shifted. People now moved to the urban centers and to factories. There was public education and some bills against child labor were proposed.
Now we're in the third industrial revolution.
Q. This is what Alvin Toffler wrote about, correct?
A. Yes. Most of the jobs of today did not exist 30 years ago. We have a situation where the skilled of yesterday become the semiskilled of today, and the semiskilled of yesterday become the unskilled of today.
And with the shift in the moral values that are now associated with these early stages of the third industrial revolution, there is also confusion about what works. These things -- moral values and ethics -- are codes of behavior based upon a person's physical perception of the world about him. This world is changing and there is an enormous shift in the value system.
Some of the manifestations are loss of control, more crazies going out and doing bad things. In spite of the wealth of information that's available about contraception, out of wedlock births are way up. They talk about crime being down -- well not universally. These are symptoms of a society in change. And child abuse is also a symptom.
Q. What does that mean for you as a psychologist?
A. There are certain consequences of that abuse, and I see it in all economic, cultural and educational groups. I'm thinking about my patient load. These are some of the most prominent families in Greenwich and upper and central Westchester. The abuse makes itself felt with a sense of betrayal, distrust and a sense of shame. Now shame is very important because it's cumulative. We used to think it was like playing pool, where the ball ricochets from side to side, and so on. The feeling now is it doesn't ricochet, it becomes cumulative. You know The Saturday Evening Post had this famous cover where the guy is yelled at by his boss and comes home and yells at his wife, who yells at the kids, who kick the dog. That's the old theory.
The current thinking is that shame builds on shame and will become anger and anger can build on anger and become rage, and this is why we have people without obvious histories suddenly participating in very violent acts. My goodness, where did this come from? It came from the cumulation over time.
There are ways to break the cycle and help these people function at a higher level and become more loving and productive. You can relearn the lessons you were taught. Attitudes are not engraved in stone.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Howard M. Newburger, a pyschologist, who treats child abuse victims and sensitizes professionals to the issues, in his Harrison office. (Richard Harbus for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1873 words

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
Shake Hands With a Corporate Recruiter

BYLINE: By CARRIE BUDOFF 

DATELINE: PISCATAWAY

 BODY:
ANY senior at Rutgers University who aspires to work for Hewlett-Packard must first win the approval of Jack Greene, a 54-year-old recruiter for the Fortune 500 computer company.
Without Mr. Greene's nod, a bright-eyed, energetic college student will not get past Phase One: the resume review. If he likes what he sees, the prospective candidate is invited for an on-campus interview. 
 That's when Mr. Greene, in a deep, commanding voice, drills the students about school and work experience. As the students answer questions, he pays attention to their body language and makes quick judgments about their personalities. He likes students who give firm handshakes and look him directly in the eye.
Usually, he takes no more than 30 minutes to determine whether they will fit into his company.
"I'm the first filter," said Mr. Greene. "Recruiting is a filtration process."
To college seniors looking for jobs in corporate America, campus recruiters like Mr. Greene can open doors or slam them shut. As the campus manager who oversees recruiting at Rutgers, he is authorized to slash the candidate pool of more than 300 to about eight dozen. Then, after the best candidates have five interviews with other high-level managers at the company, Mr. Greene and other recruiters help decide who is most qualified to fill 20 openings annually in jobs including sales, consulting and product development.
Job prospects have significantly improved for college seniors graduating in the coming year who can point to good grades and past job experience -- particularly in computer programming, sales and investment banking.
"In the early 1990's, when the job market was truly in a downturn, we were struggling to get 100 employers at our career fair," said Richard L. White, director of career services at Rutgers. More than 250 companies have signed up for the New Jersey Collegiate Career Day on Jan. 7.
"We had to close the door," he said. "It's a very clear, measurable indication that employers are really knocking on the door again."
And companies are getting impatient. They are not waiting until the spring, as they have traditionally done, to kick off their recruitment process, said Minerva H. Reed, director of career services at Princeton University. Recruiters could be found on campus every night last fall, making presentations about their companies or giving receptions for potential employees.
"We are seeing organizations clamoring for students' attention earlier in the year," she said. "The competition is keen. There is an active campaign for students."
At Princeton and Rutgers, the fall term used to be dominated by the science and engineering firms, while the liberal arts majors began interviewing in the spring. That changed last year.
"Now there's almost a complete overlap," said Ms. Reed. "The major organizations, such as financial service concerns, want to visit in the fall and the spring. It's a competitive sector. They want to get their offers out early and get their hiring done earlier."
Many students who were interviewed in October or November received offers and were asked to accept or decline by Thanksgiving vacation -- "exploding offers," Ms. Reed calls them.
"Students are in a quandary," she said.
There are more than 126,000 employees at Hewlett-Packard, and Mr. Greene, who has worked there 25 years, has helped hire 50 to 60 of them since 1983, when he became being the company's recruiting manager at Rutgers. (Mr. Greene, whose official job is national marketing manager, has counterparts throughout Hewlett-Packard who recruit at 63 other schools across the country.)
He estimates that he spends about 25 percent of his time perusing the hundreds of resumes that pour into his electronic mail account, interviewing students, going to career fairs and talking before special interest clubs at Rutgers.
After 14 years on the recruitment circuit, he has become a master of his craft. It takes him no more than 12 seconds to look over a resume. (He prefers a standard resume, but when he has received a nonstandard one -- like one that was printed on pink paper with a color photo of the student, "I tried to look beyond it," he said.)
He zeros in on job experience, campus leadership, projects, grades and hometown. Because Hewlett-Packard has facilities in 30 cities across the United States, knowing where a student comes from "indicates that I probably have a better chance of getting them out of New Jersey," said Mr. Greene, who graduated from Rutgers's College of Engineering in 1966.
About eight dozen students are chosen to interview on campus at the career center, with Mr. Greene and other recruiters, usually young Rutgers alumni, whom he brings with him. Each wears a denim shirt with the Hewlett-Packard and Rutgers logos sewn above the top left pocket.
"We take over the place," said Mr. Greene.
This year he took 14 other recruiters, the most he has ever taken to campus with him. From 1989 to 1992, during the recession, when Hewlett-Packard hired fewer than five people each year, Mr. Greene went alone on these interviewing trips.
As the interviewees arrive, they are ushered into a conference room, where they watch videos on the company and talk with recent Rutgers graduates who work there.
After that, they each move into one of eight interviewing rooms, tiny, sterile boxes that would not be out of place at a hospital.
The student has 30 minutes to sell himself to Mr. Greene, who must also sell the company to the student. Given the time constraints, the little things matter.
So what are the do's of a first interview?
Give a strong handshake. Always be positive and energetic. Stick to the questions that are asked. And maintain good posture.
The no-no's?
Asking about salaries or benefits. Knowing nothing about the company. Being evasive and unpleasant, or downright hostile.
Seconds after the candidate walks out the door, Mr. Greene fills out a form with comments on his Hewlett-Packard laptop computer. Is the person a must hire? A recommended hire? Or does he "lack H-P skills?"
The form is sent via computer to another manager, who will take over the five-step interviewing process. And Mr. Greene's job is over, unless someone elsewhere in the company has questions about a candidate or he believes a candidate is a "must hire." In that case, he may market the student to others in the company.
About 20 percent make it past the initial on-campus interview, but that is not necessarily because the other 80 percent performed poorly. "It's a competitive process," said Mr. Greene. "And we do not have unlimited job openings."
Bringing a new employee into a company carries a certain amount of stress. When asked about hiring mistakes he has made, Mr. Greene replied without hesitating, "I hired someone who was a murderer."
Edwin Snelgrove, who graduated from Cook College in the early 1980's, started with the company right out of school. Six months later, the police considered him a prime suspect in the murder of a 23-year-old woman who was his ex-girlfriend. They were not able to link him to the murder until four years later when he attempted to kill a 44-year-old Elmwood Park woman after the two met at a bar.
All the while, Mr. Snelgrove was working at Hewlett-Packard, selling computers and earning $40,000 a year.
"Looking back on it, there are a couple of things I should've noticed," said Mr. Greene. "He did poorly in his last semester at Rutgers. It should've put me off a little bit. But he had such a strong presence."
When Mr. Greene discusses the incident, it seems as though he feels personally responsible for the hire, even though six other employees also met with him and recommended his appointment.
"If you sat in the room with him, like I did, you would see that he was this all-American college boy -- handsome, polite, friendly," said Mr. Greene, as his mind wandered back to that day in 1983. "His G.P.A. was a 3.8. I can still remember it."
"So you can be wrong," he said. "A mistake like that puts you on your guard. It makes you realize that you are not as good as you think you are."
Mr. Greene and his recruiters are relying more on a new technique called "behavioral interviewing." Employers can probe a job candidate's past actions and behavior by asking him to respond to specific situations. For example, Mr. Greene may ask the student to describe an uncomfortable situation or to tell him about a creative project that student has done.
"It makes it difficult for a candidate to lie," said Mr. Greene.
Mr. Greene has seen the recruiting move from a system where students had to wake up early in the morning to sign up on an interview list posted outside the career services building at Rutgers to one based almost solely on the Internet. Students tap into a web site called Jobtrack, which is where employers post job opportunities. And he receives tons of resumes through his E-mail account.
Despite all the changes, and one or two hiring mistakes along the way, Mr. Greene still smiles when he thinks about why he is still recruiting at Rutgers after 14 years.
"I love the excitement of finding talent," he said.
And he has no plans for leaving that part of his job behind.
"I can't seem to get out of it," said Mr. Greene. "But I'm not in a rush to leave."
 
You Have 30 Minutes. Make Them All Count.
 Here are some interviewing tips from a guide prepared by Greg Sobol, Assistant Director of Career Services on the Douglas-Cook campus of Rutgers University.
 
PLUSES -- Most interviewers look for good communication skills, the ability to interact with others, the ability to handle stress, the ability to solve problems and promotability.
 
MINUSES -- These 10 factors can knock a candidate out of contention:
 
-- Not being prepared for the interview; no research or questions about employer.
-- Inability to express ideas clearly; poor communication skills.
-- Poorly defined career goals; little or no sense of direction.
-- No real interest in the employer.
-- Unhappy personality; disliked former jobs, supervisors, school.
-- Evasiveness; making excuses.
-- Asking too few or poor questions about the job.
-- Interested only in best dollar offer.
-- Lack of confidence or poise; fails to make eye contact, weak handshake.
-- Unwillingness to relocate.

F.Y.I. -- Be prepared for a new technique called "behavioral interviewing." This interview method focuses on the applicant's past actions and behaviors in response to specific situations. For example, the interviewer may state, "Describe a major problem you have faced on the job and how you dealt with it." To prepare for this type of question, think about situations that demonstrate your leadership, problem solving, customer service, teamwork and planning abilities. Prepare short descriptions of each situation and be ready to give specific positive outcomes that reflect well on you.
 
A FINAL TIP -- Good preparation will increase your confidence. Confidence will make you a winner. Like the actor who experiences some nervousness each evening when he goes on stage, but uses it to enhance his performance, you too should let your nervous energy work for you.

HEADLINE: CELEBRATIONS;
It's Solstice, Hanukkah, Kwaanza: Let There Be Light!

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
Today, at 3:07 P.M. Eastern standard time, the northern hemisphere is tilted as far away from the sun as it ever gets, marking the moment called the winter solstice. And many New Jerseyans -- even those still finishing their Christmas, Hanukkah and Kwanzaa shopping -- will be taking note at some point during the weekend.
Richard Clarkson, a 53-year-old delivery-service manager, plans to be in Landing this afternoon, in the middle of a field, standing in a circle with others who belong to a Morris County group called the Center for Spiritual Enfoldment. Lillian Mulligan, who has been a member of a mission church in Camden for 23 years, will be having friends over to her home in Mullica Hill this evening. She and her husband will turn out all the lights in the house, go outside and pray for the light to return. Sister Miriam MacGillis, a Dominican nun, will be leading a private observance at Genesis Farm, the ecological learning center she directs in Blairstown. Brian Wilkes, who is Chief Standing Bear in the American Cherokee Confederacy, expects to be in a fire circle on ceremonial ground, around noon, with a dozen or so other Native Americans. 
 "It will be almost like a welcoming party," he said. "Like we have an important visitor: the sun. So we say, 'Let's get everything together and light a fire so he knows where to come.' "
Early man found his first deities in the rhythms of nature: times for hunting, planting and harvesting and for giving birth. These days people tend to consult the calendar. If it's the 25th day of Kislev (which begins at sundown on Dec. 23 this year), Jews are lighting the first candle of Hanukkah. On the 25th of December, Christians are thinking about the star of Bethlehem. On the 26th, African-Americans are lighting candles for the first day of Kwanzaa.
These celebrations are at least one of the reasons that the candle business is booming. The National Candle Association, a Washington-based trade group, says total retail sales of candles nationwide are growing at an annual average rate of 25 percent, and will reach about $2 billion this year. More than a third of those sales take place at this holiday season.
What is it about the waxing and waning of light that makes it such a peg for celebrations? Part of the answer may lie in its absolute predictability. Ice ages might come and go, rainy seasons might shorten or lengthen. But, at any given latitude, the seasonal change in the length of the day is a rock-steady beat, one that life itself is dancing to in increasingly understood ways.
"From the beginning of life, which goes back three billion years, there have been these seasonal changes in light," said Dr. Thomas Wehr, a research psychiatrist at the National Institute of Mental Health. "It was one of those things that life had to cope with. And when you look across species, you find clocks that respond to daily and seasonal changes in light."
Those clocks, he said, tend to have a common pendulum: the hormone melatonin. "It appears to be very widely distributed," Dr. Wehr said. "It's in mammals, reptiles, birds, insects, algae. Morning glories." And there are other clues, like a clock gene associated with fruit flies that has recently been identified in humans. "What it's telling us," Dr. Wehr said, "is that these mechanisms are very, very old from an evolutionary perspective."
Studies on light's effects have been increasing since the 1980's, when seasonal affective disorder, or winter depression, was first identified. It is a condition that disproportionately affects women. Scientists are testing whether that disparity might be linked to another gender difference. In approximately one out of three women, compared with one out of eight men, a clock in the brain orders a cycle of melatonin production that matches the length of the day, regardless of exposure to artificial light or dark.
Clifford Geertz, a noted anthropologist now at the Institute for Advanced Studies in Princeton, has concluded that man's physical evolution was inextricably entwined with his social evolution. It is no surprise that the cycle of light and dark marked by our bodies is also marked by so many religions.
Before it was Christmas, Dec. 25 was the Birthday of the Inconquerable Son, the Natalis Solis Invicti, in honor of Mithras, a Persian deity absorbed into the Roman world in the first century B.C. The Romans were also celebrating Saturnalia at that time, the winter solstice. (The word comes from the Latin words for sun and still.) Thanks to the vagaries of the earth's orbit and terrestrial calendars, two thousand years ago the solstice usually fell on Dec. 25.
Christianity eventually absorbed many of the traditions of both, including strong nuances of light and dark symbolism -- so much so that popes repeatedly admonished the faithful to abandon rites that seemed too heathen. In the 17th century, English Puritans felt compelled to outlaw the celebration of Christmas, a ban that lasted a bitter 12 years. Even today, some Catholic holidays are transparent adaptations of pagan ones. In Montclair, old Swedish customs prompt an annual celebration of Dec. 13 as St. Lucia's Day, which is, in fact, a pre-Christian Scandinavian solstice rite with a vague Christian overlay.
Rabbi Eliezer Diamond at the Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan, the nerve center of Conservative Judaism, said that Hanukkah, too, most likely builds on a previous solstice celebration, though its narrative roots go to the struggle of fundamentalist Jews against the assimilationist pressures of the Greek Syrian occupiers. The narrative source of the Feast of Lights includes a miracle: a lamp in the purged temple has only enough undefiled oil for one day, but burns for eight.
Dr. Maulana Karenga, a California black studies professor, was therefore following an ancient precedent of piggybacking holidays when, in 1966, he invented the seven-day celebration of Kwanzaa for African Americans and placed it in late December. Intended as a way to dignify black life, the central ritual is, of course, lighting candles. Dr. Karenga's seven candles match seven principles he believed necessary for black Americans to survive in America with their self-esteem intact: unity, self-determination, collective work and responsibility, cooperative economics, purpose, creativity and faith.
The range of interpretations of fire and light that will be invoked this season appears to be endless.
At some, as at Chief Standing Bear's gathering today, the fire is simply practical. "Fire carries smoke into the sky, and it also carries prayers into the sky," the chief said, explaining that the solstice is not counted among the major Cherokee holy days, which have more elaborate rituals. "It's an astronomical term," he said. "You need 15 experts to calculate it. But when God wants to send you a message, you'll know." The prayers, he said, will be straightforward expressions of thanksgiving and requests for guidance. "Basically," he said, "it's 'Let me know what I need to do, and let me have the strength to do it. Just point and I'll do the rest, and thanks for pointing.' "
Pausing to laugh, he added: "It's a little more eloquent in Cherokee."
Mr. Clarkson, who will be in the field in Landing in Morris County, said that being outdoors was important. "We'll find God outside, because that's God's creation," he said. "A church is man's creation. It's a very simple kind of thing."
Mrs. Mulligan's celebration this year, turning all the lights out, is far simpler than some she has enjoyed in the past. Her son, John Hasse, studied in Spokane, Wash., with an Indian leader named Sun Bear who has since died. But for a few years, he turned the Mullica Hills house and its 24 wooded acres into a religious center. Come solstice, and the sweat lodge was packed with believers who wanted to cleanse themselves in time for the new light.
Witches, or Wiccans, tend to be rather circumspect about their observances. Susan Blaustein, 43, said she would decorate the small, private altar in her New Jersey home with a branch from an old sycamore tree that she was fond of, and would surround it with objects that represented earth, air, fire and water, as well as objects that created "beauty and peace."
Practicing an earth-centered religion in an urban setting yields some peculiar twists. The druid group that will celebrate Yule in Bryan Perry's Jersey City loft is named Greenman Grove, after the faces carved into stone buildings. They have often used the nearby Statue of Liberty, with her upraised torch, as a symbol of Brigid, the Celtic goddess of fire. Today's ceremony, said Nancy Hoffman, 40, a New Brunswick resident who is a longtime member of the grove, will include inviting the spirits of significant people and places. Among them will be the spirit of her parking space.
For most of the solstice celebrants, the idea means more than the actual moment. In fact, some people said they would celebrate a tad early.
For instance, the seven members of the Red Oak Grove, a new druid group in Mount Holly, planned to start Friday evening, lighting candles at sunset, and praying, singing, feasting and extinguishing the candles one by one until all was dark at midnight.
Then they planned to light them again one by one, accompanied by more praying, singing and feasting, until dawn, when they would head back outside to greet the sun.
And then, their rituals complete, said their leader, who goes by the name Lion's Dream, "We'll go in and go to sleep!"

GRAPHIC: Photo: The waxing and waning of light governs the lives of everything from fruit flies to human beings. (The New York Times)
 
Chart: "As the World Turns"
The earth, which has a barely elliptical orbit, is closest to the sun (perihelion) in the depths of the northern hemisphere's winter, and the furthest from the son (aphelion) in the midst of its summer. What determines the seasons is the tilt of the earth on its axis.
 
A tilt toward the sun means summer and away means winter, which is why the southern hemisphere has summer while the northern hemisphere has winter, and vice versa. The solstices mark the most extreme moment of tilt, while the equinoxes mark the moment of least tilt. Chart shows the tilt of the earth in different seasons.

HEADLINE: ON THE MAP;
A City and Its River Make a Classroom for Camden Students

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

 BODY:
To Gracelyn Johnson, Camden's best learning environment is its environment. Ms. Johnson, a science teacher at Camden High School, is this year's recipient of the Cartledge Award for Excellence in Environmental Education, presented in Washington earlier this month by the nonprofit Conservation Fund and by Union Camp Corporation of Wayne, the paper products manufacturer.
In a program she began three years ago, 40 Camden seniors are studying the relationship of the Cooper River to the city's economic growth. They gauge water quality, investigate sources of pollution and hear from environmental professionals. Twenty students from the more affluent, suburban Cherry Hill High School West also participate. "One Cherry Hill student said she could not take part because there would be drive-by shootings," said Stanley Krantz, a teacher in Cherry Hill. 
 Ms. Johnson talked about the river as she strolled along its banks.
Q. How is the river related to the city?
A. Historically, the river was very important to farmers and manufacturers upstream. Back in the early part of the century, they wanted to dredge the river and they wanted to get Federal funds for that. And the Federal funds were only available for rivers. It was called Cooper Creek, so they changed the name to Cooper River and then they were eligible for the funds.
Historically, it's been important commercially. In more recent times, no, it's not. It is important in a sense that it's the watershed, and if we don't protect the watershed we have all kinds of problems with flooding and recharging our aquifer. And it's a big recreational thing now. All through Camden County there are parks all along it. There's a yacht club, they scull along the river, you have picnicking and baseball fields.
Q. Is pollution still dumped into the river?
A. Not any more. There were something like 40 sewage plants, and all these little towns and communities were dumping their primary treated sewage, which is just barely treated, into the river. So the river was nasty. But since the early 70's, when the Camden County Municipal Utilities Authority came on line, the river is almost swimmable -- not quite, but almost swimmable. The main pollution you see now is runoff from the oil from cars. Anything in the streets ends up in the river. If they salt streets in the winter, that ends up in the river. Fertilizers that people put on their lawns end up in the river.
Q. What your program like?
A. It's called an integrated environmental study. Integrated in the sense that you're not just using science to teach something. You're using science, math, English, writing, social studies, history. And you can use any environmental topic.
Talking about global warming and endangered species is interesting, but in order to grab their interest and keep students' interest, finding a local issue was real important. And that's what we do in this program; we find something that's in their neighborhood, in their backyard.
 Q. Does poverty hurt the environment?
A. In areas where people are scratching for a living and trying to keep their families fed, protecting the environment is not high on their list. But in this class, we're trying to show students that you don't have to be living in Cherry Hill or Haddonfield or some affluent area to care about your environment.
Q. Do the negative stereotypes about Camden bother you?
A. This happens to me all the time: people say, "Where do you work?" And I say Camden High. And they go, "You work there? Aren't you afraid? Do you feel safe?" I mean, I had two children and worked right up to the end of my pregnancy. Would I go to work pregnant if I was afraid? STEVE STRUNSKY

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
The Sky, and the Moon, for the Most-Frequent Fliers

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
WHEN the 23 million members of United Airlines' frequent-flier program awaken on Jan. 1, they will face not only a new year but also changes in the program's rules. Members who redeem miles for certain free flights will be required to stay over a Saturday night during their travel, and upgrades will be allocated differently.
United's members are not alone. Welcome to the changed -- and still changing -- world of airlines' frequent-flier programs. And while there are more ways than ever to obtain airline miles -- from grocery purchases to tuition payments -- a fundamental shift in strategy is giving new advantages to the airlines' best customers, those who usually travel for business and often pay the highest fares. 
 In many airline programs, the rewards for these big spenders are, well, big. Some of the most frequent travelers are reaping perks like bonus miles, preferred seating, special check-in desks, extra carry-on baggage allowances, early-boarding privileges and exclusive phone lines for reservations or complaints. But that's not all. Some airlines also offer them overnight delivery of award tickets, priority baggage delivery to airport carousels and access to airport clubs.
For people who travel a lot, such perks can help make even a grueling journey tolerable. Of course, the benefits are far from free.
To reach the upper frequent-flier tiers, customers must meet annual mileage minimums. To join United's Premier Executive level, American Airlines' Platinum or Continental's Elite Gold, passengers must fly 50,000 actual miles, or 60 flight segments, on purchased tickets during the year. A segment is industry language for any flight from one city to another; Los Angeles to New York is one segment, and Los Angeles to Chicago to New York is two segments.
One step -- and several perks -- below these categories are United's Premier level, American's Gold and Continental's Elite Silver, each requiring 25,000 miles or 30 segments. Continental also offers an Elite Bronze category, requiring 20,000 miles or 25 segments.
To insure the loyalty of their most frequent fliers, however, some carriers have begun adding even higher reward levels.
Northwest Airlines, for example, recently created an International Gold Elite card for the several thousand passengers -- out of its total of more than 52 million -- who travel frequently to Europe or Asia on first- or business-class fares. Among an array of other perks, these travelers are guaranteed confirmed reservations on any otherwise sold-out flight operated by Northwest.
United offers the Premier 1K level for passengers who fly at least 100,000 miles or 100 segments a year. In addition to most of the perks listed above, Premier 1K members are exempt from the blackout dates that apply to United's free tickets for off-peak travel.
Within the airline industry, the "road warrior," who travels often but sometimes on advance purchase, low-cost tickets, is becoming less important than the "high-yield passenger," "full-fare passenger" or "V.F.F.," or very frequent flier.
Almost without exception, these terms refer to the men and women flying on business who need to get where they are going tomorrow, if not yesterday, and pay for the privilege (through the nose, in the opinion of many travel managers) with high fares. About 25 percent of T.W.A. passengers, for example, account for half the carrier's revenue. Frequent travelers who pay full fare account for only 9 percent of United's passengers but 44 percent of its revenue.
Such figures help explain why American Airlines is giving 40,000 bonus miles to passengers who pay full fare for first- or business-class tickets to Europe and complete their travel by Jan. 31, 1998. That is in addition to the usual award miles for the trip.
The 40,000-mile bonus for travel to Europe is being offered by other airlines, too, with some variations: US Airways is offering it to its business-class travelers until Jan. 31, and Continental will add 10,000 more miles, for a bonus of 50,000, if business-class passengers pay with an American Express card. For business-class travelers on T.W.A., the travel deadline for the 40,000-mile bonus is Feb. 28.
In a departure from the mileage bonuses, British Airways will offer passengers who travel to Europe by Jan. 31 -- in first or business class or on the Concorde -- a free economy-class ticket to any British Airways destination in the world.
On most major carriers, the frequent-flier mileage for first-class passengers is 50 percent higher than for economy passengers (1.5 frequent-flier miles for each mile flown, rather than one for one), and 25 percent higher for business class.
 But airlines have also found other ways to bolster the award mileage for their highest-paying passengers and, in some cases, to deny it to those who pay the least.
T.W.A., which is making an all-out effort to attract the bigger spenders, gives full-fare passengers one mile for each mile flown and an additional mile for each dollar they spend on the ticket.
British Airways and most United States carriers deny frequent-flier mileage to passengers who fly with tickets issued by consolidators, who buy airlines' unsold seats at big discounts and sell them at lesser discounts. Several Asian carriers that fly to and from the United States, including Singapore Airlines and Malaysia Airlines, award frequent-flier miles to first- and business-class passengers but not to those in economy class.
THE same is true of Cathay Pacific, which, for example, awards 24,202 miles to first-class passengers who fly the 16,134-mile round trip between New York and Hong Kong, and 20,168 miles to business-class passengers -- but none to economy passengers. Instead, economy passengers can accrue points, based on miles flown, toward membership in the airline's Marco Polo Club, which has perks like special check-in and access to airport lounges.
Qualifying Cathay Pacific award miles are redeemable on American Airlines, Malaysia miles are redeemable on Delta, and Singapore miles are redeemable on either American or Delta.
But while the mileage gap between the big spenders and bargain hunters has widened, it does not appear to have dampened the latter group's enthusiasm for flying, sometimes with no regard as to where.
When Cathay Pacific recently offered two round-trip tickets from the United States to Hong Kong for $999, including five free nights at a hotel, its phone lines were busy for days on end.
"Some of the people who called," an employee of the carrier said, "didn't know who or what Cathay Pacific was, didn't know where Hong Kong was, but just knew the offer was too good to pass up."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ISLANDS;
Strangers Behind a Counter

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
The store smelled like old chicken. But the poultry and hot dogs were cleared out weeks ago because business has been worse than the stink.
"We've made nothing in four hours," said Damin Kubler, a young man of Puerto Rican descent who is the daytime manager at Savings Food Super Market. "I've got nothing in the till." 
 This bodega could be anywhere in New York, on any nondescript street, on any unlucky corner. But it is on Cross Bay Boulevard in Broad Channel, a small island community built along the waters of the Big Egg Marsh in Jamaica Bay.
Part of the store's economic doldrums can be attributed to the seasonal downturn when the Rockaway beaches close for the winter and few people stop to pick up hot dog buns, baby diapers and cold beer, Mr. Kubler said.
But the merchants say they face another problem: resentment from longtime residents of this cloistered enclave on the city's edge, where according to the 1990 census, 99 percent of the people are white. Many are third-generation Channelites.
"They don't particularly care for black and brown," said Mr. Kubler, who moved to the island from East New York about a year ago. "If you can deal with the taunting, you can stick it out. But it's not so good for business."
The first immigrants to do business on the island were the Germans, who came in the late 19th century and dug for clams and oysters until the open sewers ruined the business.
Broad Channel was incorporated in 1915 and residents leased the land from the city. Hoteliers and Irish rumrunners came during Prohibition, and the area flourished as a resort until the corporation went bankrupt during the Depression.
After World War II, the people who were left on the island, which had no sewers or water mains, were mostly Irish squatters.
"It became insular because nobody wanted to buy a house without the property," said Dan Tubridy, who is from an established Broad Channel family.
Things changed in 1982, when the city finally decided to sell the property to residents. Sewers have been added since then and property values have increased 250 percent, said Daniel Mundy, president of the Broad Channel Civic Association. Some old timers have sold their homes, and immigrants have moved into the community. Seven of 12 businesses counted on the strip are foreign-owned.
Some locals have not bothered to learn the merchants' names, and many residents don't patronize their businesses.
"It's the way it is," said David Muhammed, a native of Saudi Arabia who works at the Cross Bay Delicatessen. "You can't make people like you."
At Eddy B's Tavern, Danny O'Sullivan, 67, talked about the good old days of an island paradise when the bay water was clear and the fishing plentiful.
"In 20 years, either this is going to be another Hamptons or another Shanghai," Mr. O'Sullivan said. "Nothing you can do to stop it." CHARLIE LeDUFF

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ISLANDS;
Gentrification With a Twist: Keeping Nautical Tranquillity

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
Head from the Bronx River Parkway to the Pelham Parkway and cross the City Island Bridge. Abruptly you enter a marine village that seems to belong miles and miles from New York City. At first glance, City Island, a slow-paced community of 4,500, seems to be ruled by the commerce of the sea, with scores of pleasure boats and many seafood restaurants.
But nautical as its economy appears, City Island is becoming increasingly dependent on small restaurants that serve fancy coffee and double-chocolate cake; on galleries like the Focal Point, the Starving Artist and Ciao, which sell crafts, paintings and photographs, and on shops that frame them. Over the last decade or so these goods and services that appeal to day-tripping tourists have replaced the butcher, the shoemaker, the baker. 
 Gentrification has arrived on City Island. Take the reopening of the Black Whale, a gathering place that served richly memorable desserts and closed 15 years ago. Back then, everyone -- tourists, boaters, artists, local residents -- went to the Black Whale. "It was always a take-your-date-to-impress-her kind of place," said Cormac McEnery, a local lawyer. The new owners, John McGowan and Jim Kinny, are "clamdiggers," or natives of City Island. They say the reincarnated Black Whale should be ready by the end of December and they hope for the kind of success that greeted Le Refuge, the island's first bed-and-breakfast, which opened three years ago and has room for 20 guests. It has been followed by the tiny Nautical Museum, which has added hundreds of ship prints to its collection. Last year a $100,000 grant from the state paid for the refurbishing of storefronts along City Island Avenue. And the state is studying how much the island should get of preservation money for 10 Long Island Sound communities.
"It's sort of a renaissance," said Peter La Scala, the president of the City Island Chamber of Commerce. "It has an air of avant-garde. Property values are going up." A two-bedroom house on a very small lot is on the market for $180,000, nearly double what it sold for 10 years ago, said a real estate agent, Betty Esola,
Many people say they moved to the island for its feel of a quiet seaside village, but one within commuting distance of the rest of the city.
But some urban crime remains. A recent drive-by shooting that left one young man dead and another wounded shook some residents' feelings of security. Skippy Lane, a retired sea captain, remembers when the island was a center of custom yacht building. In 1982, the last island-built yacht was put to sea. But unlike some industrial cities that became ghost towns when their factories shut, City Island did not hit the skids, largely because most residents worked off-island in occupations ranging from waitressing to banking. Some boat builders turned to storage and repair, and the biggest boatyard became a condominium complex.
The island's downtown streets did suffer, though. Shops were vacant, their facades ragged. Local boosters plan to use state money on more refurbishing. But, Mr. McEnery insists, gentrification will continue to be atypical -- no Gaps, no Starbucks, no chains stores.
"This is not a pop-out-of-the-box place," he said. "This place makes you tranquil. As soon as you go over the bridge, you go: 'Ahhh.' " BARBARA STEWART

GRAPHIC: Photo: Refurbished storefronts, like the Black Whale, mark a change in City Island, with more places serving tourists. (Susan Farley)

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Pain or Gain From Dental Management?

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
A NEW set of companies is hoping that more dentists will do what many doctors are already doing: have someone else manage their businesses.
Facing a mountain of administrative and marketing tasks, an increasing number of doctors in the last four years have turned to physician practice-management companies, or P.P.M.'s, for help. Now, 3 percent to 10 percent of all doctors use them. 
 So why not a dental practice-management company, or D.P.M.? The thought has occurred to many, with at least two dozen such companies springing up in the last year or two. Five of these concerns have gone public since the beginning of this year and another six hope to do the same in the next few weeks.
But while it does not take a dental mirror to see what is causing the stampede, the risks are high: the companies are tiny, the demand for them is untested and the stocks are volatile. Investors who are willing to court these dangers may choose to jump in now in search of big gains; others may prefer to wait and see how the industry shakes out.
The stakes are huge. Americans spend $46 billion a year on dentistry, and the market is growing about 6 percent a year, thanks to the aging of baby boomers and the development of whitening techniques and other treatments.
But dentistry is also a very fragmented profession, with about 70 percent of dentists, and about 90 percent of orthodontists, in solo practices.
That means that most dentists must do or oversee everything themselves, making them ripe for the services of D.P.M.'s. These enterprises not only rescue dentists from doing paperwork and hiring but they also do the marketing and supply capital for expansion. Some of the management companies sprang from group dental practices, and many have executives with dental and accounting backgrounds.
Such outside management should leave dentists with more time to see patients, which can raise revenues sharply. At Coast Dental Services in Sarasota, Fla., each dentist generates about $600,000 in gross revenues a year, on average, according to Joseph R. Smith, the chief financial officer. The average dentist in a traditional single practice, he said, generates only about $300,000 annually.
Typically in these contracts, the dentists receive a sizable payment up front -- in some combination of the management company's stock and cash -- plus the services. In return, the company receives a percentage of profits from the practice.
The American Dental Association has neither approved nor disapproved of the use of management companies. But some dentists are beginning to embrace them. "There's been a general feeling of adverseness to these companies in the past, but now dentists see the writing on the wall," said Steven Tuen, an analyst at IPO Value Monitor, a research firm in New York. "While there hasn't been any real momentum to get dentists to join up so far, that's starting to change."
And with only about 1 percent of dentists now participating, there is much room for growth.
THE trend toward managed care is another plus. By bringing economies of scale to dentistry, D.P.M.'s can often offer lower prices than traditional practitioners. This has great appeal for cost-conscious providers of managed dental care -- they now cover 23.8 million Americans -- and for the roughly half of Americans without dental insurance.
And by offering such conveniences as Saturday and evening hours and locations in shopping malls, D.P.M.'s can lure people who steer clear of the dentist's chair because they cannot find the time.
There is much to gain by attracting such customers. According to a study by the National Center for Health Statistics in 1993, the most recent year for which data are available, 39 percent of Americans did not visit a dentist in the past 12 months.
Some D.P.M.'s have designed strategies to draw these nonpatients. Coast Dental Services, for example, says its prices are 30 percent to 50 percent lower than those of dentists in solo practices.
Other management companies are separating themselves from the pack in different ways. The Gentle Dental Service Corporation of Vancouver, Wash., for example, is developing practices that combine dentists with periodontists and/or other specialists for one-stop shopping.
And the Monarch Dental Corporation, based in Dallas, pursues large, established dental practices -- a strategy that can be costly but that also provides strong market positions. Monarch also tries to grow internally, not just by acquisition.
These strategies please many investors. Coast's stock has risen from $8 at its offering in February to $24.75 on Friday, while Gentle Dental's stock, which went public at about the same time, has gone from $5 to $9.25.
But some weakness has emerged in the industry, too. Monarch's stock, after shooting up to more than $23 three months ago, closed on Friday at $11.625, less even than its July offering price of $13. And the stocks of two D.P.M.'s that went public this fall -- Castle Dental Centers and Dental Care Alliance -- have sunk below their offering prices.
A big reason for these troubles is typical for budding industries: new competitors. The Monarch, Castle and Dental stocks all declined this fall, when a handful of other D.P.M.'s announced plans to go public. And those companies would be coming on top of several privately held outfits that have also entered the fray.
One risk from such rivalries has already been seen: While dental-management companies have so far been mostly regional players, they are now beginning to step into one another's backyards. That is one reason Gentle Dental recently decided to merge with a private company, GMS Dental; both companies were pursuing dentists in California, Oregon and a few other states.
INVESTORS should also consider a troublesome parallel -- physician-management companies. Because of overly rosy expansion plans, growing competition and difficulties in getting doctors to change their business practices, P.P.M. stocks, as a group, have turned in disappointing results since the middle of last year.
Craig B. Dickson, an analyst in the Chicago office of Everen Securities, said physicians had been consolidating their practices for 25 years, so there was more potential for cutting overhead costs with dentists. He also said dental-management companies typically could generate higher revenues and higher margins than P.P.M.'s could.
Still, dental-management stocks, like the shares of many small growth companies, have shown they can be as jumpy as someone suffering from a crater-sized cavity. And if such stocks drop significantly, the expansion plans so crucial to a start-up sector can be harmed. That is because dental-management companies often offer large chunks of their stocks to dentists to get them to join. If the stocks sink, dentists might hold out.
The small size of dental-management enterprises also raises investor risks. Monarch, with just $24.2 million in annual sales last year, is the largest of the five public companies. The average annual revenue for the group is $12.8 million. (By comparison, the average annual revenues for P.P.M.'s is in the hundred-million-dollar range.)
Finally, there is the specter of a seller's market -- but not the kind that these management companies would like. To keep expansion on track, some of them have begun to pay premium prices to dentists to join their networks.
"This is a long-term fear within the industry," said one Manhattan money manager who holds a sizable position in Coast Dental and who spoke on condition of anonymity. "Dentists are seeing all the money that's flowing to these companies, and they're starting to demand higher prices. In other words, they're getting smart."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Big Stakes, Big Risks"
Management companies are sprouting up to do the hiring, paperwork and marketing for dentists, who preside over a $46 billion-a-year business. As more managers go public -- five have done so this year, and six others hope to do so soon -- some are devising ways to stand out from the crowd. Chart lists three public companies. HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
The Office Phone Vs. the Tug of Home

BYLINE: By JOHN BRAY 

 BODY:
WHEN her father died, Lisa Deuel Lachot had many telephone calls to make at work.
"That's not something you want to be talking about in your cubbyhole," said Ms. Lachot, 37, a secretary in Chapel Hill, N.C. "I knew which offices were open and which phones I could use. I'm not using their phone and charging it to their number. I was just using it to get privacy." 
 Personal phone calls at the office. It doesn't take an independent prosecutor to know that almost everyone makes them if given the chance. Some people have an easier time of it than others.
But even as the technology for monitoring such calls grows more sophisticated, some workplace experts say that letting people have personal phone time may not be a bad thing -- as long as they don't abuse it.
"There is a general trend toward acknowledging that people need to deal with things in order to be productive," said Arlene Johnson of Work Family Directions, a Boston consulting firm. That may include calling home to relieve a worry over the baby sitter, talking to the plumber or dealing with an insurance problem.
"You want to encourage calls so they aren't sitting there stewing," she said.
In white-collar offices with phones on every desk, personal calls tend to be at the worker's discretion, she said. And while companies are increasingly able to police such calls and thus reduce them, it is hard to balance the productivity gains against the losses.
"Obviously, people are making personal phone calls from work," said John Marshall, president of I. S. Associates of Troy, Mich., a telephone accounting system company. "Some companies care to track it and some don't, but the loss of productivity far outstrips the cost of the calls. I can place a call to my wife and it will cost 8.4 cents, but if I talk for two hours, then it becomes a productivity concern."
Personal calls can be more complicated on the shop floor than in an office.
When Levi Strauss & Company surveyed workers in 1990, the company learned that machine operators did not have enough access to telephones, said Margaret Kraemer, the company's employee assistance program leader, based in Knoxville, Tenn.
"What people requested was more phones," she said, noting that it was particularly difficult for parents to call home to check on children, especially during the summer. So the company installed more telephones in break rooms.
"They are pretty heavily used," Ms. Kraemer said. The company did not study the impact on productivity. But, she said, "just the fact that the parents were able to call out alleviated the problem of children calling in on the switchboard."
As a single mother at work 30 years ago, Caroline Lincoln felt compelled to keep from making personal calls, trying to stay in step with the vast majority of her co-workers, who had spouses at home to tend to daily domestic concerns.
"We sort of went to work and put on that work hat, and that's what we were to do," said Ms. Lincoln, who now places temporary workers for Smither & Associates of Chapel Hill, N.C. "We have so many mothers now who are working who need to be in touch with their children. I just think people are more relaxed about it now."
Employers have called to complain about temps making too many personal phone calls, Ms. Lincoln said. But such complaints are rare -- perhaps especially so in this time of low unemployment, when companies are trying to keep workers, not looking for ways to chase them away.
Some companies, however, forbid personal calls, noting the risks of tying up a business line. The phone handsets on the desk at D.L.C. Car Service at Westchester County Airport in White Plains are clearly labeled: "No Personal Phone Calls."
"It could cost us a $100 taxi or limo call because somebody couldn't get through," said Frank Yannuzzie, 70, who was running the desk one recent afternoon.
But for Leonard Johnson, 42, of White Plains, there was time to spare in the "boiler room" at a previous job where he made cold calls as a telemarketer for a home improvement company.
"We were calling girlfriends and friends all over the country," Mr. Johnson said. "When the manager would come in, we'd just pretend we were talking to a homeowner. As long as you were generating sales, they didn't care."
WHAT constitutes abuse of the phone for personal calls? Companies should have clear policies that telephones, like other office equipment, are for business, said Michael Lotito, a San Francisco lawyer who counsels companies on management disputes with labor.
But he said there should be no cause for alarm if a dedicated worker needed to make a personal call from the office for something urgent, or even something mundane.
"Maybe they are trying to see if the dry cleaner is open late because they just worked an hour overtime," said Mr. Lotito, a managing partner at the firm Jackson Lewis. 'To condemn this type of individual for making this type of call is ridiculous."
While there is abuse of business phones, "this isn't keeping corporate America awake at night," Mr. Lotito said.
Although companies may be trusting their workers about personal phone calls, many also have the means to flag calls that may indicate abuse and to produce detailed reports of incoming and outgoing calls.
The systems, which can cost less than $1,000 or hundreds of thousands of dollars, depending on their size and capabilities, can be used to reconcile phone bills or to simply turn up inefficiencies in how calls are routed. But they can also produce detailed reports of calls to and from each extension.
Buyers of such systems rarely cite any concern about personal phone calls, said Tim Stassi, vice president of the Angeles Group, a Westlake Village, Calif., company that develops software for such systems.
"We've never promoted the system as a policing system," he said.
But making employees aware that calls are being tracked can still have a chilling effect. It did at the Sacramento Municipal Utility District.
"Supervisors would pull employees into their office and question them about calls," said Tom Santiago, telephone service superintendent for the electricity supplier. "Word got out and calls started going down."
At Engineering Global Solutions, a consulting firm in Dearborn, Mich., workers pay for their personal calls on an honor system.
"It has been the source of much humor and complaint," said Janis O'Hare, the personnel manager, who distributes the printouts of the calls.
One co-worker, who makes a lot of phone calls for Engineering Solutions, took his printout "and draped it over his body and just looked at us," she said. "Another guy would let them pile up in his drawer until the boss said, 'Just deduct it all from his paycheck.' Mostly people paid them because they know how our boss is."
Yes, people know how most bosses are.
"If I'm working at a desk and the boss is sitting right nearby, I'm not going to just pick up the phone and start doing my errands," said Ms. Lachot, the secretary in North Carolina. "People understand if you need to make a call, but, on the other hand, I don't think they want to hear you making it."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
The Eagle Platinum Coin Is Selling, but Not Soaring

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
THE United States Mint began to sell its first platinum coins in late September, when the white precious metal was in its best rally since 1990.
The spot price of platinum was up almost 18 percent for the year, and the future looked good from several angles. For the first time since 1988, the demand for platinum significantly exceeded the supply. The potential of platinum as a commodity -- not just a precious metal -- seemed higher, too, with more people convinced that its use in catalytic converters and electronics would grow with the economy. The price of spot gold was off by more than 12 percent at the time, and that was also auspicious: It suggested that platinum was loosening its link to the long-falling price of gold. 
 Finally, the mint was expected to sell 100,000 ounces of the coins over the next year -- which would push prices up more.
And sell the mint did. Through last week, the mint had sold more than 108,000 ounces of its American Eagle platinum coins, quickly meeting its one-year sales forecast and ravaging the competition, the Australian Koala and the Canadian Maple Leaf. "Koala sales are down to a trickle," said George Hall, a consultant to the Perth Mint of Western Australia.
But what has been great for the mint has not turned out so well for some investors.
No sooner had the sales started than the price of platinum began to plummet. And because the price the mint charges for the coin tracks the metal's spot price, the early investors lost a bundle. The first 25,000 one-ounce bullion coins, which are marketed to investors rather than collectors, sold for $424 plus the mint's 3 percent markup. On Friday, though, the spot price of an ounce of platinum was just $356.50.
The reversal underscores how volatile investments in precious metals -- even nice stocking-stuffers like coins from the United States Mint -- have been in recent years.
Investors might look at this performance as they think about the new opportunity, beginning next year, to add precious-metal coins and bars to their individual retirement accounts. They should know, too, that most advisers say these metals should be just a small part of a portfolio, and that they have recently failed in their long-promoted role as hedges in bad times.
The nature of the recent downturn in platinum has sorely disappointed those whose aspirations for the metal had soared during its rally. The hope that platinum had broken its link to gold, for instance, has been undermined. The price of gold has fallen 10 percent since late September and has dragged platinum with it, analysts say.
Even more disappointing is that this year's rally -- which sent platinum's price up 29 percent, to $479 an ounce at the peak in June -- may have been just a one-time buying spree rather than a sign of a new, higher, continuing demand for the metal.
In normal times, platinum users borrow the metal at very low interest rates rather than actually buy it outright, which would require a lot more cash. But these borrowers were squeezed this year when Russia suddenly stopped shipping platinum to the West. That shortage of physical platinum sent short-term platinum borrowing costs up to an annual rate of 300 percent, forcing many companies to make large purchases of the metal.
"It was a high volume of purchases, but it was one-time," said a New York trader whose firm has a big stake in platinum and who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
In addition, the economic turmoil in Asia has been cutting into demand from Japan, a large consumer of platinum. A report on Tuesday showing that executives in Japan were pessimistic about the economic outlook sent the price of platinum down 3 percent, although it rebounded the next day on the announcement of a possible income tax cut there.
All told, "The next one to two years are not necessarily positive for platinum," the trader said.
But are things now so bad with platinum that they're good? After all, the 1-ounce price is down more than 25 percent from its June high.
William Nellus, vice president for sales and marketing at the Monex Deposit Company, a wholesaler and retailer of precious metals in Newport Beach, Calif., thinks so. Customers "are looking at the falling price of platinum as an opportunity," he said.
To spur sales, Mr. Nellus said, Monex has dropped its 10-ounce minimum-purchase rule to market a set of the four sizes of the coin: ounce, half-ounce, quarter-ounce and one-tenth ounce, in denominations from $100 to $10.
Jacques Luben, the executive director of the Platinum Guild International, said that although the mint's coin "could not have come out into a worse market," the price would rebound as long as Asia recovered and growth continued in the West.
"I would argue that platinum is doing everything it should be doing -- responding to a strong economy -- except for the last few weeks," Mr. Luben said.
Mr. Luben may be right, or maybe the platinum trader is. But either way, if you want platinum coins for fun -- not profit -- they are surely a better buy now than in September.
