HEADLINE: Old Antagonisms in a New Race

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
No date has been set for the election. But the race to succeed Floyd H. Flake, the minister who represented southeastern Queens in Congress for a decade, has already evolved into a frenzy, inspiring intense backroom wrangling and resurrecting a political feud more than a decade old.
The special election to replace Mr. Flake, who resigned last month to devote more time to the Queens church where he is pastor, has lured a host of candidates. And they have hired a battery of media consultants, pollsters and advisers for a race that will be waged as much among party insiders as in the streets of the Sixth Congressional District. 
 The three candidates seen as most formidable are members of the State Legislature: Senator Alton R. Waldon Jr., Assemblyman Gregory W. Meeks and Assemblywoman Barbara M. Clark, all Democrats.
The race has already fueled antagonisms dating back 11 years, when Mr. Waldon faced Mr. Flake in a heated special election to represent the district in Congress after the death of Representative Joseph P. Addabbo. Mr. Waldon won that contest, but two months after going to Congress, Mr. Flake defeated him in the Democratic primary and went on to Congress in 1987.
That race produced bitterness between the two officials that many Democratic officials in Queens insist still exists. And now Mr. Flake is endorsing Mr. Meeks, who is seen as Mr. Waldon's major opponent.
Because it is a special election, the candidates who appear on the ballot will be selected by the various political parties, by a vote of their district leaders. The Democratic Party will select its candidate through a vote of about 30 district leaders.
Mr. Waldon, 60, is seeking to position himself as the experienced elder statesman. He describes his years in the State Senate, his preceding tenure in the Assembly and his months in Congress as making him the tested, accomplished choice.
"I have the most experience, by far," Mr. Waldon said. "I have done a lot of things in my life that have prepared me for this. And, let's face it, I've already done the job."
He has hired as his campaign manager William K. Banks, a veteran of the campaigns of former Mayor David N. Dinkins and Representative Edolphus Towns. He has also hired as his media consultants Hank Sheinkopf, a pollster and veteran political consultant. Furthermore, he said, he is looking to raise and spend as much as $600,000 for an election that is expected to occur sometime in February.
While Mr. Waldon is presenting the image of experienced political insider, Mr. Meeks is trying with equal fervor to portray himself as the young, energetic upstart.
"In many ways, I represent the future of the party," said Mr. Meeks, who is 44 and is entering his sixth year in the Assembly. "Al Waldon may think he has the party's designation, but I have a substantial portion of the district leaders, too."
"If the undecideds go with me, then the election is over. The way I look at it, I'm Cassius Clay and he's Sonny Liston."
Mr. Flake said Mr. Meeks's age was an advantage. "Greg Meeks has the greatest chance to stay long enough to build seniority if the Democrats win back the House," he said, adding that Mr. Meeks "had a better understanding of the need to develop economic programs in the district."
Mr. Flake said his endorsement of Mr. Meeks was not motivated by a political feud. He said his relationship with Mr. Waldon had been "a professional one."
"I don't think we're enemies," he said.
Mr. Meeks has retained as his media adviser Hank Morris, the political strategist who has worked on a number of Democratic campaigns.
For her part, Ms. Clark, 58, said she had been busy meeting with district leaders, although she declined to say how many have pledged to support her candidacy.
"I'm campaigning. I'm raising money and I have a committee," said Ms. Clark, an 11-year veteran of the Assembly. "I don't know exactly how the prospects are lining up. But I see myself as being as competitive as any other candidate."
The district includes neighborhoods in southeastern Queens, stretching from Jamaica, South Ozone Park, Springfield Gardens and Hollis to portions of the Rockaway peninsula. With a 1990 population that was 22 percent white, 16 percent Hispanic, 6 percent Asian and 53 percent black, it is home to one of the city's largest black middle-class areas.
Because the district is heavily Democratic, the candidates have been scrambling to line up support among that party's district leaders. Not a day goes by, say most district leaders, when they are not the objects of an intensely competitive courtship.
"I am being lobbied on a very, very regular basis," said Juanita E. Watkins, a City Councilwoman who is also a Democratic district leader. "At this point, I have not yet made a decision. And, after all, there is still time."
But there is not likely to be much time. Mr. Flake's resignation took effect Nov. 15, and, under state law, the special election must occur between 30 and 45 days after the seat is declared vacant by the Governor. So far, Gov. George E. Pataki has made no such declaration.
None of the candidates are wasting any time. At a recent holiday party given by the Queens Democratic Party, all three were on hand, in different corners of the room, buttonholing various district leaders and making it clear that the campaign was in full swing.
While Mr. Waldon may have the backing of several prominent Queens politicians and ministers, Mr. Meeks's support is seen as equally formidable. The Assemblyman has been endorsed by both the Rev. Al Sharpton and Mr. Flake, who leads the 8,600-member Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church, half of whose members live in the district. Mr. Meeks said that, like Mr. Waldon, he is being endorsed by several prominent Queens clergymen.
Adding to the sense of free-for-all politics is the fact that the Democratic chairman of Queens, Representative Thomas J. Manton, has declined to state a preference.
"I don't have any intention of making an endorsement," Mr. Manton said. "I'd like to see the process be as open as possible."
Meanwhile, State Senator Serphin R. Maltese, the Queens Republican leader, said his party is planning to be competitive, even though the district has been in Democratic control for decades.
Alfonso C. Stabile, a Republican City Councilman, said he was seriously considering running.
Still, most Queens officials say that the candidate selected by the Democrats will be best positioned to win the special election. Mr. Meeks has made it clear that he will seek another party's endorsement if he is not selected by the Democrats.
"There's no way to know how this will turn out," said Mr. Manton, the Democratic leader. "A lot can happen. But at the moment, what we have is maneuvering, ad infinitum."

HEADLINE: Wiz Is Latest Chain to Fall In Tough Electronics Market

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
When the Wiz Inc. filed for bankruptcy protection last week, it represented the ninth time in recent years that a high-profile consumer electronics chain in New York City had been zapped by a combination of market forces and human errors.
Trader Horn, Newmark & Lewis, Crazy Eddie, Save Mart, Vim, 47th Street Photo, Brick Church, Incredible Universe -- all of them sold high-tech gizmos and gadgets and all faded from the local retailing landscape. 
 "It's a very tough business, and these businesses fail for several reasons," said Kurt Barnard of Barnard's Retail Trend Report, a trade newsletter. "Cutthroat competition, product saturation, overexpansion, changes in the way products are sold, and in some cases, like Crazy Eddie, they were crooked."
Sometimes, too, it is inept management or, as was the case for Incredible Universe, a failed concept. "It was too big; people were overwhelmed," said Bob Gerson, the editor in chief of TWICE (This Week in Consumer Electronics), a trade newspaper.
Thus far, for the Wiz, the largest consumer electronics retailer in the New York metropolitan region, known for its ubiquitous "Nobody Beats the Wiz" advertisements, the official cause of death -- or near-death, as all but 17 of its 52 stores will remain open through the company's reorganization in bankruptcy -- was an expensive expansion into New England over the last three years, compounded by complications like declining prices and a generous policy on returns.
Why is expansion so perilous for retailers? After all, Newmark & Lewis and Crazy Eddie perished after following a similar course. Sometimes, it is desperation to increase sales in the face of shrinking margins. Sometimes, it is simple ambition.
In the case of the Jemal family, which controls the privately owned Wiz, the expansion saddled the company with debt that was increasingly difficult to service as prices for many items fell and sales stagnated.
"The entire consumer electronics industry has been struggling because of price deflation," said Peter Caruso, an analyst with Merrill Lynch.
He added that sales have been flat or have fallen at many stores because there has been no release of a wildly successful new product in years; the industry is pinning its comeback hopes on high-definition television and digital video disks.
Not even the recent boom in computers could help the Wiz much, Mr. Caruso said, since many are purchased directly from manufacturers, like Dell and Gateway, or through mail order or the Internet, where products are often discounted.
Sandy Bloomberg, chief executive officer and founder of New England Audio, which owns 23 Tweeter Etc. stores in New England and 18 Bryn Mawr Audio and Video stores in the Philadelphia area, agreed that falling prices had been a persistent problem in recent years for all consumer electronics chains. He noted that many major department stores, including Macy's, Federated and Filene's, were leaving the consumer electronics business, a notable exception being Sears.
"A 35-inch TV that was $1,500 six years ago is now $799," Mr. Bloomberg said. "A camcorder has come down 35 percent in the same period, a VCR 25 percent. What this means is that you have to sell more units each year to make up for the lower prices and the smaller margins."
Mr. Gerson said: "It's getting like supermarkets, the margins are so slim. You can get a VCR for $100. So you've got to have volume and you've got to have management."
Circuit City, the nationwide chain, recently opened two stores in New York City, and Best Buy is expected to open stores next year. Both are viewed as better managed with a more diversified product line than the Wiz and other consumer electronics stores. For example, Circuit City sells appliances as well as stereos and televisions, and appliances have higher margins and suffer less from price deflation.
Mr. Bloomberg added that Circuit City would not have the huge advertising cost, per customer, that the Wiz had because it could advertise nationally rather than only in selected markets. He said the Wiz spent "well beyond what was logical" on advertising. "In New York, you get a problem with egos," he said. "They think big, and if you don't think with your head then it can get you into trouble."
But analysts say that the Wiz's filing for Chapter 11 was not solely a New York phenomenon. "The struggles of companies like the Wiz are more closely related to industry trends than to the New York market itself," said Stewart Cohen, chief executive of Paragon Capital L.L.C., a Newton, Mass., lender to retailers that recently worked with the Wiz.
Mr. Bloomberg said that many of the large chain stores like the Wiz did well, at least initially, thanks to unsophisticated first-time buyers, but that even those customers had become more sophisticated in recent years.
"The consumer every year raises the bar -- the consumer is now much more empowered than it used to be," he said. "It used to be that they would accept poor service for low price or pay high price for good service. Now, they want a higher level of service and will not pay more for it."
And though it has been little publicized, returns appear to have been another factor in the demise of stores like the Wiz. "Most retailers are cutting back on their return policies," said Walter F. Loeb, senior retail senior analyst with Loeb Associates, a retail consulting firm and publisher of the Loeb Retail Letter.
Indeed, it was not unheard of for customers seeking, say, a video camera for a wedding or vacation to buy one at the Wiz and then return it a week or two later for a full refund. The stores then are often forced to resell the item at a discount because it is in an open box.
"People are now looking at that as one of the major problems that has ensued in the industry," Mr. Loeb said, "particularly in New York City, where people take advantage of everything."
Saul E. Burian, a lawyer representing the Wiz in the bankruptcy proceedings, said that the store would keep its liberal policy of allowing returns within 33 days of purchase on many items, except, perhaps, at stores that were closing and were holding close-out sales. He also said that all warranties on products bought at all the stores would be honored, as would its own credit card. "The court ordered that we can fully respect all customer obligations," he said.
Why does the Wiz think it fell on hard times?
"A variety of reasons," Mr. Burian said. "A general softness in the industry, no new product to generate sales, competition, saturation, an expansion program.
"It was a cruel combination."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL;
Jordan's Responsibility? Moving Fans and Moving Merchandise

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
I like Mike. It's nothing personal. I don't know the name of Michael Jordan's wife, how many children they have, whom he voted for in the last election (if indeed he did) and the role that religion plays in his life. I also don't care.
I do know that I would pay to see him play most any kind of game and that if I thought it would make me more like him I would even wear his sneakers and cologne. He is one of the most appealing entertainers in the world and one of the best-looking people; he deserves to be the highest-paid male model. 
 But does Jordan, who made one of his scheduled state visits yesterday and scored 24 points in a 100-92 victory over the Nets, have any more responsibility than staying in practice and looking good? I don't believe he does, and I don't want him to be a model of anything more than great performances and unnecessary consumer goods. That is why I'm troubled by the mounting criticism of his lack of social concern.
It's a distant drumbeat at the moment, but it will grow louder as the movement against Nike gains momentum and as Jordan comes to the end of his playing career. Jordan's carefully cultivated image as a charmer and company man, the antithesis of Latrell Sprewell, may not survive a looming contract war between the National Basketball Association and its labor pool.
If he sides with labor, he will lose the public relations machines and be more vulnerable to replacement by a younger, hungrier player (the "new Michael Jordan"). If he sides with management, he will be further exposed as the "moral jellyfish" of a smart screed in The Los Angeles Times by Dave Meggysey, Western director of the National Football League Players Association.
He is absolutely right about Michael's being a moral jellyfish for allowing his signature sports gear to be made by sweatshop labor. But the larger premise is wrong. As a former pro football linebacker with splendid progressive credentials, Meggysey shares not only the jock superiority complex but also a belief in the athlete's responsibility to be a model citizen.
I don't share that belief at all. I do not want Michael Jordan telling children how to conduct their lives -- even if he happens to be right -- any more than I want Sprewell or Coach Tom Osborne giving moral lectures. It is only through the moral laziness of parents, commentators and youth counselors and the greed of television and corporate executives that ordinary people with extraordinary talents become "role models." It doesn't just happen.
Asking Jordan to use his swooshy pulpit for worthy causes is buying into the mission of the Celebrated Church of Mutant Morphin Michael Barbies, which is to move units of products. This is a god that will always fail.
Sometimes, the role model turns out to be a human being and sometimes the shipment never arrives. At the annual dinner last week of my all-time favorite team so far, Martin Luther King Jr. High School's city soccer champions, my all-time favorite coach this year, Martin Jacobson, confided that after all the romance from a regional Nike rep, the promised balls, the turtlenecks and the shoes never arrived. Weren't consecutive titles, 38 straight victories, good enough?
That evening's keynote speaker was the spellbinding Doug Logan, the Major League Soccer commissioner and the circuit rider of the futbol sect. Perhaps the most important truth he told the team was that "luck" was as important as hard work and talent in becoming a champion; it was quiet call for humility in an age that does not usually reward it.
Logan easily became my favorite commissioner, even though he had not been invited to last month's "An Evening with the Commissioners" at the Bar Association. Paul Tagliabue of the N.F.L. thoughtfully described "the lynch mob mentality against athletes." It was an unfair open season, he felt. He was alluding to the unfair rush to judgment over the wrongful rape claim against the Dallas Cowboys' Michael Irvin, but his words later resonated through the Sprewell incident.
Meanwhile, at that legal gathering, David Stern, the crowd's perky, smug and very smart pet, waxed most eloquent about "protection of intellectual property," which included keeping control of the dissemination of games and of the image of the N.B.A. By the time Sprewell had acted out and the anti-Jordan boomlet began, one could begin to wonder if that property might be losing value again. Basketball has led the way in merchandising its stars, and when stars fall. . . .
Will soccer save us? The present attractions of the sport here -- the emphasis of finesse over violence, the lack of commercialism, the normal size of its players, the importance of the women's game -- may not survive success.
The game needs a Babe Ruth, an Arnold Palmer, a Michael Jordan, an athlete of overwhelming talent and charisma who is also willing and able to help the global economy move units. Does the new Mike also need to be a moral jellyfish?

HEADLINE: After Seeking Rate Cut, Suffolk Angers Pataki With Lilco Fight

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Dec. 19

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki went out on a limb this year when he pushed for a partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company. With Suffolk officials pleading for relief from Lilco's soaring electric rates, he set aside his aversion to big government to strike a deal that he said would be a boon to Long Island, a crucial Republican stronghold.
So it may be no surprise that politicians here say he is furious at the Republican-controlled Suffolk County Legislature, which was skeptical of the complex plan and is now leading the drive to scuttle it. Opponents of the plan say it would bail out Lilco stockholders at an exorbitant cost to electricity customers. 
 "The Governor remains very confident of his plan to cut rates by double digits, protect property owners from massive tax hikes and further stimulate the economy on Long Island," said his spokesman, Michael McKeon. Lilco's rates are the highest in North America.
Now, both sides on the Lilco issue are digging in for a prolonged struggle that will decide the plan's fate. Mr. Pataki's appointees on the state's Long Island Power Authority are pushing hard to get the required regulatory approvals in time to announce rate cuts and send refund checks to electric customers next year -- before the Governor comes up for re-election in November.
The Suffolk Legislature is fighting the plan on several fronts. It recently voted to spend $800,000 for lawyers and other consultants to oppose the plan before the regulatory agencies. The major hurdles are the Internal Revenue Service and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.
In addition, legislators are considering a suit to block the plan, and their aides are drafting an anti-plan referendum for 1998 to replace the one knocked off last month's ballot by a court challenge.
"We will utilize whatever means possible to stop a deal that has been characterized by national experts as the worst-case scenario," said the chairman of the Suffolk Legislature's Energy and Environment Committee, Michael J. Caracciolo.
Under the Pataki plan, the Power Authority would buy Lilco's power lines, customer services and business office but retain Lilco to run the operation, then open the management role to competitors in later years. Rates would initially drop 17 percent with the postponement of debt repayment and the use of tax-free bonds, with much of the money going toward debts on the never-opened Shoreham nuclear plant.
"We want to get this done as soon as possible so the people of Long Island can get their rates cut," said the Power Authority's chairman, Richard M. Kessel.
But critics like Jack Kulka of the Hauppauge Industrial Association in Suffolk contend that the promised savings are deceptive, that Lilco stockholders would be enriched, that Long Islanders would be saddled with more than $20 billion of debt and that Lilco's monopoly would be locked in for years as the rest of the nation moves to energy deregulation and competition.
Although Long Island has long been united by its disdain for Lilco's high bills, it has now split over Mr. Pataki's proposal. Unlike Suffolk, adjacent Nassau County has no organized opposition to the plan. In fact, the Nassau County Legislature's presiding officer, Bruce A. Blakeman, said officials there were preparing a formal endorsement.
Besides the actions by the Suffolk Legislature, another opposition move was announced on Wednesday by seven Assembly members, led by Paul E. Harenberg, a Democrat. Their bipartisan bill would force Lilco to absorb more Shoreham costs, cut rates and move quickly to energy competition.
On another front, a lawsuit seeking to block the plan claims that state officials failed to make a required environmental review. That case was filed by the New York Public Interest Research Group and the Citizens Advisory Panel, a court-appointed watchdog for Lilco.
Alternative plans have been offered by opposition groups like the Initiative for Competitive Energy and Ratepayers Against Lilco Bailout. But Mr. Kessel, the Power Authority chairman, dismissed their ideas as unworkable, saying that Lilco's agreement to the Pataki plan made it "the only viable solution."
Of all the opposition moves, Suffolk's actions have drawn the most intense interest.
"I have been somewhat surprised by Suffolk, given the fact that it has the most to gain from the proposal and the most to lose if it fails," said Matthew T. Crosson, president of the Long Island Association, the Island's leading business group, which supports the Pataki plan.
Mr. Crosson was referring to a potentially bankrupting court decision ordering local governments in Suffolk to refund $1.2 billion to Lilco customers for excess property taxes imposed for the Shoreham nuclear plant. The Pataki plan would reduce the refund by about half, which critics say shortchanges Nassau residents, and would finance the cost by reducing electric rates slightly less in Suffolk than in Nassau.
But the Suffolk Legislature has come up with its own solution to pay the refund, by authorizing a rise in the state and local sales tax to 8.5 percent, from 8.25 percent. The sponsor, Joseph Rizzo, the County Legislature's presiding officer, estimated that his approach would save $1.8 billion compared with the Pataki plan.
Suffolk's maverick stand comes despite personal pleas over the months from both Governor Pataki and Suffolk's Republican Party chairman, John Powell. County Executive Robert J. Gaffney tries to juggle the issue, supporting the Pataki plan but also saying he respects legislative independence.
"I have no idea why they're doing what they're doing in Suffolk, except they seem to think there is some political gain to be had by it," said John V. N. Klein, a lawyer and former county executive. He represented a developers' group that sued to throw the first referendum off the ballot.
Mr. Crosson noted that Suffolk "has a longer history, a tradition of organized opposition to Lilco," including the environmental advocates who climbed fences to protest the Shoreham plant's construction in Suffolk. Mr. Gaffney and others ran for office on anti-Lilco platforms.
Another factor in Suffolk's opposition is Suffolk Life, a widely distributed weekly newspaper that regularly attacks the Pataki plan.
"It's unfortunate," Mr. Kessel said, "that Suffolk is squandering almost $1 million of taxpayer money to fight rate cuts."

HEADLINE: Figures Show Budget Deficit Fast Shrinking

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The Government has released figures showing that the Federal budget deficit is falling much faster than official forecasts had reported, providing the first clear evidence that the budget could be balanced in this fiscal year or even show a surplus.
The figures prompted Speaker Newt Gingrich to suggest today that President Clinton speed up the plan to balance the Federal budget. 
 "If the President could come into the State of the Union address and propose a balanced budget by 1999, three years ahead of schedule, we'd be very responsive," Mr. Gingrich said in a telephone interview.
The White House greeted Mr. Gingrich's trial balloon coolly.
"The best way for us to reach a balanced budget sooner than expected is to maintain the fiscal discipline of the last five years, not to spend money we don't have yet," said Gene Sperling, who heads the National Economic Council.
President Clinton is likely to propose some small tax cuts in his budget proposals next month. They include providing incentives to reduce emissions of gases that cause global warming, and possibly tax cuts to promote greater access to child care.
The Administration is still considering how it would deal with the appearance of any large budget surpluses, and officials said that Mr. Clinton might be ready to provide an outline of his philosophy for dealing with such a situation in his State of the Union Message, also next month.
The Administration is not considering any plans for a large tax cut next year.
Though the Government's figures, released on Friday, are only early indicators of the nation's fiscal health, they are sure to intensify planning at the White House and in Congress for what to do if the Government finds itself with money left over at the end of the fiscal year.
The Clinton Administration continues to expect the deficit for the year ending next Sept. 30 to be higher than the $23 billion deficit the Government ran up in the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30. Under the schedule laid out in the balanced-budget legislation agreed to by the Administration and the Republican leadership this year, the budget would not be balanced until 2002.
The drive to eliminate the deficit could still be imperiled by any weakening of the economy or a reversal of a surprising surge in tax revenues. But the figures showed that for October and November, the first two months of the current fiscal year, the deficit was $24.4 billion lower than in the same period last year.
If the trend of the first two months continues, analysts said, there could be a big surplus.
Republicans have been pushing for tax cuts and more spending on the military. Democrats are talking about more spending on education and health programs. Lawmakers of both parties are looking at proposals to spend more on highways and at using any surplus to shore up Social Security and Medicare.
Mr. Gingrich said today that his priorities would be to achieve and maintain a balanced budget, then apply up to $30 billion a year toward the national debt. The Speaker said he would favor using any remaining surplus for an annual tax cut and to increase financing for science, transportation and national defense. He said he was still committed to a tax cut next year, staying within the balanced budget framework, by deferring certain spending.
For the first two months of this fiscal year, the Government ran a deficit of $53.3 billion, compared with $77.7 billion in the same period last year, the Treasury Department said. Big deficits in certain times of the year are offset during periods of heavy tax collection, particularly in April and September.
The results reflected both tax revenues that were greater than those in the same period last year and expenditures that were lower.

HEADLINE: Ignoring African Abuses Is No Foreign Policy;
Congo's Progress

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Dec. 16 news analysis of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's Africa tour suggests that Washington's new Africa alliances reflect foreign policies that "eerily mimic those of the past," when cold war imperatives led the United States to support dictatorial regimes. 
 No, history is not repeating itself. It is Ms. Albright's critics who are stuck in the past, trying to impose cold war labels of "undemocratic" or "authoritarian" on governments that are barely consolidated, struggling to reconstruct ruined societies and, to their credit, proclaiming themselves to be transitional.
In Congo, the new Government inherited a state infrastructure so decayed as to be nonexistent -- the legacy of 32 years of Mobutu Sese Seko's corruption. Moreover, remnants of Mr. Mobutu's army and assorted bandits in league with genocidal Hutu militias defeated by the new Government in neighboring Rwanda continue to threaten the security of Congolese citizens.
Despite these conditions, President Laurent Kabila has diversified the political base of both his Government and the army to include members from outside his movement.
The Government has implemented a two-year timetable for constitutional reform and eventual elections, reduced inflation through responsible monetary policies, and made significant strides against corruption.
 
ANDRE MWAMBA KAPANGA
Permanent Representative
of Congo to the United Nations
New York, Dec. 17, 1997

HEADLINE: The $25 Million Defeat

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: RIDGEWOOD

 BODY:
FOR years, the formula for passing the school budget here each spring has been simple: 1,800 "yes" votes are insurmountable and guarantee victory. On Dec. 2, ritual became myth.
That's when the school board, responding to pointed recommendations of the agency that accredits secondary schools, sought approval of something far more ambitious politically than most budgets: a $25.1 million bond issue to bring the high school -- flagship of one the state's premier school systems -- into the 21st century. 
 Without a new science wing, the latest computers, classroom and library improvements and, at long last, a pool and new gym complex, Ridgewood High School's place as one of the state's best could not be assured, the board felt.
But the bond issue went down with a resounding thud. Instead of the usual low turnout for budget votes -- perhaps 15 to 20 percent -- almost 40 percent of the voters went to the polls and defeated the plan, 3 to 2.
In Ridgewood, as in so many towns across the state, schools are the heart of the community and their health can be tied directly to the willingness of people to pay what in Ridgewood can often be $500,000 to well over $1 million for a house, not to mention steep property taxes.
So what happened on Dec. 2 gave a lot of people pause to consider why such a large number of their friends and neighbors decided not to pay an average of $240 a year more in taxes, and instead vote "no."
Ridgewood isn't alone.
Of 109 school bond issues proposed in the last two years around the state, 55 were defeated, as each community looked into its own soul and its own pocketbook.
People want their schools to be the best, but they don't always agree on how much the best costs or whether they want to spend the money in any case.
What happened in Ridgewood may not be unique, but it provides a window on how towns large and small, rich and poor, confront a basic need: education.
School officials rich and poor, confront a basic need: education.
School officials here were stunned by the breadth of the defeat, 3,535 to almost 2,400: the bond issue lost in all 19 of Ridgewood's election districts.
The turnout of 38 percent of the 15,207 registered voters was an enormous response in this town of 25,000, where even hotly contested budgets tend to pass easily and without so much involvement. Ridgewood has adopted nine of its last 10 budgets, the current one being $49 million.
 The wealthiest residents, who live in lavish older homes tucked into wooded hillsides on the west side of town, offered the most support. But even there the closest contest in the west side's 7 districts was still a 51.7 to 48.3 defeat in District 4.
Elsewhere, the voters' mood was far more sour. About 73 percent said no in a middle-class district, No. 15, east of Benjamin Franklin Middle School and Valley Hospital. And nearly 72 percent said no in a sprawling post-war development of Cape Cod homes in the southeastern part of town known as the Lawns.
 
An Aggressive Campaign To Combat the Board
 At the heart of the defeat was an aggressive, old-fashioned political campaign led by the Ridgewood Taxpayers Association and its president, Sally Brandes. The association blitzed homes with anti-bond fliers and phone calls and ran full-page ads in a local newspaper.
Board officials contended that the ads were full of misrepresentations and wound up spending some of their energy in counter-attack. The opposition campaign was aimed at all residents, particularly middle-class voters, including the elderly, in the election districts where, in the end, the no vote was the most overwhelming.
The board's campaign was more narrowly directed at parents of school children. And allies that it had counted on, including the Home and School Associations in the 9 schools and the Ridgewood Arts Council, ran quieter pro-bond campaigns than originally planned because of legal questions about their roles as vigorous advocates.
After the vote, critics called the school board aloof and presumptuous, contending that officials had not solicited residents' opinions about elements of the bond package during the drafting process.
In response to the vote last week, the superintendent, Dr. Frederick J. Stokley, said that in coming months the district would solicit residents' opinion in a telephone survey, come up with at least three new and scaled-down bond plans and then seek grassroots input on all of them before going before the voters again next September or October.
Besides the complaints about the board's attitude, critics argued that all $25.1 million was earmarked for the high school and nothing was set aside for the two middle schools and six elementary schools. They grumbled that financing $25 million was too expensive: $240 a year for 20 years for a home with the average assessment of $296,000. They focused animosity on the proposed physical education center, particularly its $1.9 million pool.
Advocates praised the pool as the new home of the high school's 40-member swim team, which now practices at 5 A.M. most days at the over-used pool at the local YMCA. They also hailed it as important to the well-being of elementary school children and said all residents could use it weeknights and on weekends.
But the center and the pool became a lightning rod for animosity, with critics denouncing the center as a spa and health club and the pool as superfluous and a luxury. None of the other elements generated as much opposition.
One major advocate, Wendy Schwehm, president of the town-wide Federated Home and School Association, said she had an inkling of trouble ahead when her husband returned from his weekly tennis game one night and said his three playing partners were mad about school taxes and complaining the package was excessive.
"That was the first time I realized there was a problem -- my husband's tennis group," Mrs. Schwehm said. "These are successful guys making good money and they were angry. I was surprised. I'm not sure my husband ever turned them around. I actually offered to go play tennis with them."
Throughout the fall, parties, meetings, and stores in the busy shopping district on East Ridgewood Avenue were abuzz with the pros and cons of the proposed bonds. "It was not a fun time in Ridgewood," said Mrs. Schwehm. Friends and neighbors split on the issue, and even now, nearly three weeks after the vote, some residents refuse to discuss their votes for fear of offending neighbors or colleagues.
Some of Ridgewood's oldest and grandest homes, valued in the high six figures and higher, are in the 4th district, sitting behind towering oaks and aged and sprawling rhododendrons on hilly cul de sacs and narrow roads. In some neighborhoods, the woodlands are countryside dense and blot out a semblance of Ridgewood as bustling suburb.
Robert J. Sommer, a computer salesman, and Thomas Fredericks, a bond trader, are friends and neighbors. Mr. Sommer voted no; Mr. Fredericks yes. Last weekend, they joked about their differences. "We fought in the middle of the road about it," Mr. Fredericks said, laughing.
He called the defeated issue a trial balloon and predicted a more modest version would pass. Of the defeated issue, he said: "You always place a high target and negotiate down to a level more reasonable to everyone." He said he backed the proposal, including the pool and bigger weight room, to keep the school from losing its competitive edge.
He said he believed in a balance between education and athletics, but said education "should be the top priority and focus."
"The money would be better spent on technology and chemistry and math -- that will drive the future and that's where it should be spent."
Like others, Mr. Sommer complained that school officials at one middle school had interrupted class time to show students the board's videotape about the bond and said that helped persuade him and his wife, a teacher, to vote no. He said the proposed bond issue had too much in it.
"We looked at the big lump and said they're trying to put the kitchen sink in there," Mr. Sommer said. "We felt like we were being slam-dunked."
In the southern part of the 4th, Stewart Massey, president of an investment banking company, said he voted yes because his three sons are the fourth generation of his family to attend Ridgewood schools. The benefits for the high school outweighed the cost of the bonds, he said, adding that the town's next two generations of students needed newer and more facilities.
"My kids are going to be playing in the same gym my mother did," he said.
He complained about the "hubris" of school officials and said they had failed to build a consensus for the issue. "This was a vote against the leadership of the school system," he said. "That's a shame because it puts the kids in the middle and that's the wrong place."
Across town, the 15th election district near Benjamin Franklin Middle School is a typical swath of upper middle class suburbia, comfortable two-story homes set on tidy yards. Peggy and Dan McGinley, parents of two elementary-school children and Ridgewood residents for two years, are in the 73 percent majority that voted no.
Mr. McGinley, a securities trader, said he agreed that parts of the high school were old and needed renovation. "But it was a lot of indebtedness to take on," he said. "I'm all for necesssary upgrading, but some things sounded extravagant. I think you've got to let the Board of Education know it doesn't have carte blanche."
Arthur Carpenter, another resident of the 15th, said he had some initial misgivings about the pool but decided to vote yes as he entered the voting booth, partly because three generations of his family, including his four children, had attended the school.
"I said it's a lot of money," he said, "but at today's prices it was something I could afford."
 
Assessing the Defeat: Weariness With Taxes
 In the aftermath, Dr. Stokley, the superintendent, said, without offering detail, that the bond package would be scaled down and that the community would have sufficient input in the drafting process, possibly including a community-wide meeting.
He attributed the defeat to residents' weariness with ever-increasing school taxes and a nationwide distrust of government dating to the Watergate era of the early 1970's.
He complained that because Ridgewood is a wealthy district and qualifies for little state education aid, it must finance 95 percent of its regular school costs with property taxes.
In a statement issued before a board meeeting last Monday, Dr. Stokley appealed for trust:
"The voting public, through information and education, must come to believe and trust that we know what needs to be done and how to do it."
 
Lovely to Look At But Growing Dowdy
 The high school, built in 1919 for $285,000 (after one bond issue failed), sits on a little bluff and is one of Ridgewood's most imposing buildings. Its facade and Gothic spire project an image of distinction, dignity and strength. Many have likened it to a classroom building on an Ivy League campus.
"Psychologically and physically, it's an image you hold of Ridgewood," said Arthur Wrubel, chairman of the town's Historic Preservation Commission. "The architects probably took their cue from people who lived here and their educational and social background."
But the impressive facade belies a cramped interior. There is no auditorium, the only theater seats about 200, the student center is too small to hold an entire class, let alone the entire student body of 1,400. The science wing, built in the 1960's, is outdated, with small classrooms and no water, gas or electricity at some lab stations.
The library seats only 70 students at a time. Art classes are held in the wood shop. Music classes, which enroll a quarter of the student body, are squeezed in here and there. The girls' locker room, circa 1919, is about 40 percent the size of the boys' locker room. Vice Principal Glenn Koegel said it probably violates the Federal law requiring schools and college to offer both sexes equal educational and athletic opportunities. The old gym above the locker, also circa 1919, is tiny, dimly lighted and has an exterior crack from roof to foundation.
In 1990, the Middle States Association of Schools and Colleges praised the education program but said the building needed major renovation to preserve the quality of the program and maintain morale of students and staff.
The proposed bond issue was the board's answer to the Middle States' criticism. The issue's theme: The curriculum had outgrown the building.
Some critics argued that the high school had about 600 more students in 1977 and all did fine. But school officials countered that students took about 5 courses a day then and 7 now. Course offerings, they said, are far broader now and the 21st-century technological demands of colleges and the workplace have become more costly. They also said that increased enrollment in kindergarten through third grade will mean the high school's enrollment would grow by perhaps 200 students 10 years from now.
The campaign produced chilled relations between school officials and Mrs. Brandes, head of the taxpayers association and a former school board member.
The association's campaign against the issue appeared to reach deeper into the community than the school board's efforts to get its messsage out through a videotape, a townwide mailing, meetings in schools, tours of the high school and a pamphlet sent home with elementary school children.
Some residents who said they had never been contacted before a school or local government election said they were called this time and urged to vote no.
After the vote, some officials called Mrs. Brandes and her colleagues chronic complainers who seldom found anything positive about the school system.
Mrs. Brandes, in turn, said school officials had lost touch with the community. She paused outside the district's offices last Monday and said: "This town is a group of professionals. They're not only housed in this building."
During the campaign, the board accused the association of circulating misrepresentations. In its full-page anti-bond newspaper ads, the association made some points about the size of recent increases in school taxes, long-range maintenance plans for all schools, financing repairs and the high school's declining enrollment.
In response, the board president, Michael J. Porro, charged in a letter to a local newspaper that the association's contentions were either incorrect or misleading.
As for arevised proposal, Mrs. Brandes said priorities should include renovating the science wing instead of building a new one, repairing the 1919 gym instead of tearing it down, and expanding the girls' locker room.
"They have to revamp the whole thing and look at the other schools and go after prioritized needs and not extravagant desires," she said. "We are supportive of necessary renovations for all schools and all kids."
 
The Voters Grow Wary
IN the 1990's, schools boards' reliance on long-term bonds to finance new schools or repair old ones has soared around the state, doubling to $3 billion since 1990.
But a recent survey suggests that many voters are becoming wary of adding this debt to their school tax bills. In the first report of its kind in the state, the New Jersey School Boards Association has issued a score card on all school bond referendums in the last two years. Of 109 placed before voters in 1996 and 1997, calling for spending of $1.5 billion, 55 were rejected and 54 approved, the association said.
Association officials said the state's dependence on property taxes to finance schools was most responsible for the rejections.
"New Jersey faces a multibillion-dollar need for new school facilities, and it's clear that local communities cannot foot the bill on their own," said Frank Belluscio, an association spokesman. "Our state needs a broad-based revenue source for school construction."
He said the association favors a cigarette tax to raise the money or a program of grants or revolving loans.
Differing voter responses to the bonds is starkest in Bergen and Monmouth counties. In Bergen, long settled and affluent, with an aging population and older schools, voters rejected 9 of 13 proposed issues in 1996 and 1997. In Monmouth, younger and affluent, and facing pressures from an influx of young families and dwindling school space, voters approved nine of 10 bond plans.
Monmouth County's superintendent, Michael A. Maddaluna, said Monmouth's open countryside is attracting new families eager for good schools, many from Staten Island.
"Monmouth is a desirable place in the eyes of a lot of people," Mr. Maddaluna said. "They're looking for perhaps better education, and they will be supportive."
The eight Monmouth towns that approved bonds ranged across the socio-economic spectrum, from Colts Neck, a wealthy town that approved bonds worth $5.7 million, to middle-class Freehold Borough, which agreed to spend $5.9 million. Two well-to-do communities had Monmouth's biggest successful packages: Middletown Township, $78.4 million, and Freehold Township, $26.9 million.
Some of Bergen's rejections came in both affluent towns -- Ridgewood ($25.1 million), Cresskill ($5.75 million) and Ho-Ho-Kus ($4.99 million) -- and blue collar communities -- Bergenfield ($2.5 million), Ridgefield Park ($5.99 million) and Rochelle Park ($4.5 million.) ROBERT HANLEY

HEADLINE: Living on $6 a Day

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Study Shows New York Has Greatest Income Gap" (front page, Dec. 17) points out that stagnation of welfare benefits is one cause for wealth disparity. New York has not raised the welfare basic allowance since 1990, despite a cost-of-living increase of 25 percent. Recipients struggle to survive, which detracts from efforts to stay healthy and pursue employment. 
 A typical family of three on assistance in New York City has, after rent, at most $6 a person a day in cash and food stamps to pay for food, clothing, utilities, transportation, school supplies and all other household needs. New York can afford a cost-of-living adjustment for public assistance. The caseload has fallen sharply, Federal spending has increased and public assistance is a tiny fraction of the state budget.
 
BICHHA PHAM
New York, Dec. 18, 1997
 
The writer is the policy coordinator of Hunger Action Network of New York State.

HEADLINE: Korea's New Democrat

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Koreans did not vote for Kim Dae Jung, a longtime pro-democracy campaigner, out of anger over the financial crisis and the International Monetary Fund reform package (front page, Dec. 19). He was elected because of overwhelming support in his home region of Cholla, disarray in the ruling camp and growing voter dissatisfaction with the status quo. 
 Concern over Mr. Kim's ability to address South Korea's financial crisis because of his populist leanings and connections to labor is misplaced. The root problem of South Korea's economy is not labor but the corrupt relationship between big business and government. As an outsider to the establishment, Mr. Kim may have the best chance of effecting the changes South Korea urgently needs to overcome the current crisis.
 
CHARLES K. ARMSTRONG
New York, Dec. 19, 1997
 
The writer teaches modern Korean history at Columbia University.

HEADLINE: When Public Needs Meet Private Money

BYLINE: By LAURIE FLYNN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21

 BODY:
The California State University system, the nation's largest network of universities, is enmeshed in a spirited battle over a proposal to recognize four companies as the exclusive providers of networking, telecommunications and computing technology.
The plan, one of the most ambitious partnerships ever forged between the private sector and public education, was proposed three months ago as a way to finance much-needed new technologies for the 23 campuses and the 330,000 students of the financially constrained system. 
 Since then, students and faculty leaders on nearly every campus have debated the plan, which would give the four companies the exclusive right to install high-speed networks within the campuses, and the right to provide E-mail and other network services, to maintain the computers used by the staff and administrators, to develop software and to provide training and support.
The consortium is led by the telecommunications giant GTE and includes Fujitsu, Hughes Electronics and the Microsoft Corporation. Under the proposal, called the California Educational Technology Initiative, or CETI, the four companies would invest more than $300 million to install and maintain computing and communications equipment.
Although top university officials have hailed the proposal as a boon for the campuses and the companies involved, a growing number of students and faculty members are attacking it as anti-competitive and a threat to the principles of higher education.
A rally protesting the initiative attracted about 200 students at San Francisco State University two weeks ago, said Nathan Newman, president of Net Action, one of the groups leading the drive against the initiative.
A similar protest took place at Humboldt State University and included a group of students who replaced the school's entrance signs with ones that read "Microsoft University." Mr. Newman said 600 students had participated in the Humboldt rally, though university officials said the crowd was much smaller.
Net Action has long been a vocal critic of Microsoft's business practices, and indeed, the involvement of the software giant is among the most controversial elements of the proposed deal.
Even before the protests, mounting public pressure had led the system's board to delay a vote on the proposal until after a special hearing by the State Assembly, which will be held on Jan. 6.
"Much more discussion needs to take place of the ethical dilemma of a public-private partnership in education," said Kenneth B. Peter, chairman of the academic senate at San Jose State University, which voted unanimously to oppose the current plan.
"The question is whether the values of the private sector and public education can work together," he added.
One concern, Mr. Peter said, is that public employees might participate, whether inadvertently or intentionally, in serving the business interests of the consortium's member companies.
Other skeptics, including the union that represents the majority of university staff members, are worried that the consortium could jeopardize jobs as work now being done by the university is transferred to the companies.
Furthermore, critics say, handing over the university's entire computing business to a single private entity could transform the schools into training grounds for the companies' products.
For example, they warn that the arrangement could promote the use of personal computers that run Microsoft's Windows operating system over those that run Apple's Macintosh system or could encourage use of Microsoft's Internet browser, Explorer, over the Netscape Communications Corporation's browser, Navigator.
A chief concern of critics is that the initiative's business plan calls for the partners to generate revenues as high as $3 billion over 10 years by marketing services like pager accounts, technical support and high-speed Internet access to students and faculty members, who would become a captive audience for the partners' products.
Mr. Newman of Net Action asserted that universities, as incubators of innovation, should be technologically neutral. The initiative could turn the campuses into training schools for Microsoft, he said, which in turn could help the company control standards.
This is particularly important at the huge San Jose State campus, in the heart of Silicon Valley, where many of the school's graduates find jobs in technology companies every year.
But the initiative's members and supporters insist that the critics are misinformed about how the consortium would work.
The deal does not require students and staff members to buy only consortium products, but the economies of scale will lead to lower prices, said William Cannon, the director of computing and telecommunications for Humboldt State and the school's representative for the initiative. Besides, Microsoft already is the leading supplier of software used by students, he said.
Mr. Cannon said much of the criticism stemmed from the secrecy of the negotiations, which he said was necessary because the deal involved the discussion of confidential business information and future products. And the pace of decision making, which took place at what he called "corporate speed," has made faculty and staff members uncomfortable because decisions of this magnitude typically take several years in academia.
Still, consortium officials argue, a public-private partnership is the only feasible solution for the university system, which this year faces a budget gap of $70 million to $100 million in its technology program as it tries to upgrade its infrastructure.
"People can say it's not right, but what is the alternative?" said Patricia Cuocco, the university system's senior director for information technology policy and analysis and a participant in the negotiations. "The State of California is not going to supply the funds."
Further, Ms. Cuocco said, there is nothing in the proposal that hands over control of how technology is used.
"People think the corporations will control intellectual property or educational content," Ms. Cuocco said. "But there's nothing in the agreement that would allow that." In fact, she said, the companies would be required to provide whatever technologies the campuses requested.
Much of the criticism of the initiative seems to focus on Microsoft's role rather than on the basic relationship between the private sector and public education.
Alluding to the investigation and antitrust lawsuit under way by the United States Justice Department, Mr. Peter said, "We're not sure we want to be partners with a company that may be guilty of antitrust violations."
Ms. Cuocco said that Microsoft had been chosen to participate in the consortium because its products were already widely used by students and faculty members. What is more, she said, Microsoft has not actively participated in the negotiations, leaving that to GTE, the lead partner.
The point, Ms. Cuocco said, is that the university system has no choice if it hopes to stay competitive in the development and understanding of new technologies and to enhance its network as new technologies are developed. The only alternative, she said, would be a bond measure that would have little chance of passing.
"Is the alternative leaving a future generation of students ill prepared for the knowledge-based society of the future?" Ms. Cuocco asked. "That's unacceptable."

SECTION: Section D; Page 10; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1308 words

HEADLINE: The Old-Fashioned Almanac Thrives in the Age of the Internet

BYLINE: By SREENATH SREENIVASAN 

 BODY:
In the library of Oak Hill Elementary School in the Kansas City suburb of Overland Park, Kan., one set of books gets used more than most: the almanacs.
"For class work and even for fun, the kids love to sit and read them for hours," said Sharon Coatney, the school's librarian. "Children are fascinated with trivia and new things. They love to ask each other, 'did you know such and such,' and almanacs give them a lot of such and suches." 
 Almanac publishers have counted on schools to introduce new generations of buyers to their books. Even in the era of CD-ROM's and the Internet, with their promise of vast storehouses of information, publishers remain enthusiastic about the business of almanacs, especially general-interest books like the World Almanac and Book of Facts and the Information Please Almanac.
Two big publishers entered the almanac market this year, bringing out The Wall Street Journal Almanac and The New York Times Almanac.
The economics of almanacs is appealing to publishers, because they can bring out new books every year at a relatively low cost. Although each year's edition will include new articles and other updated information, much of the data can be recycled from year to year. Moreover, although almanac sales are quite large by publishing standards, and there are no big-name authors demanding huge advances and royalties.
There is, of course, a wide variety of almanacs available, with some focusing mainly on sports or entertainment -- or on the weather as the Old Farmer's Almanac does. But the most popular are the general-interest almanacs, which compile hundreds of thousands of facts about a broad range of topics, from abortion to the zodiac. An estimated two million of these almanacs are sold each year, for less than $11 apiece.
And a large portion of those sales occur during the holiday season. The new almanacs dated 1998 appeared in bookstores in November and early December, and they are favored by some gift shoppers.
"These books are phenomenal sellers, especially during this season," said Robert Wietrak, a vice president of merchandise at Barnes & Noble. His stores sell 75 percent of their almanacs from November through January.
"Everyone likes almanacs and they make great stocking stuffers," he said. "We will sell about 300,000 almanacs altogether. That would make almanacs one of our top 10 nonfiction books for the year."
The giant in this category is the 130-year-old World Almanac, published by Primedia Reference Inc. It sells about 1.2 million copies each year, more than double the sales of its nearest competitor, the Information Please Almanac, published by Information Please L.L.C.
Now, Ballantine Books, a unit of Advance Publications that publishes The Wall Street Journal Almanac, and Penguin Reference Books, a subsidiary of Pearson P.L.C. that publishes The New York Times Almanac, are each betting that the name of a big national newspaper will provide a competitive edge.
"The almanac publishing business is a tough game," said John W. Wright, general editor of The New York Times Almanac. "To market against the World Almanac, you need another brand name, and that's where The Times comes in."
Ronald J. Alsop, editor of The Wall Street Journal Almanac, has a similar view. "Taking on the existing almanacs is not easy because you have to be truly distinctive to stand out," he said.
To that end, The Wall Street Journal Almanac has adopted some of the look and feel of the newspaper, with the articles and charts being provided by The Journal's staff.
Mr. Alsop, who is also a news editor at The Journal, which is owned by Dow Jones & Company, contended that his almanac was more forward-looking than its competitors. "Other almanacs have the history of the Liberty Bell," he said, "but is that really what people want to know? We have information that is relevant to people as we approach the year 2000. For example, we tell you what the fastest-growing occupations will be between now and 2005."
The New York Times Almanac, meanwhile, portrays itself as the "almanac of record," and Mr. Wright said the book reflected the newspaper's "thorough coverage of the U.S. and the world."
Unlike The Wall Street Journal Almanac, which was created from scratch, The New York Times Almanac has some of its roots in a prior book, the Universal Almanac.
Mr. Wright was previously the editor of the Universal Almanac. Its publisher, Andrews & McMeel, decided to discontinue the book with the 1997 issue. The Universal Almanac was well respected and comprehensive, but its sales were lower than those of its competitors.
But Mr. Wright owned the rights to the content of the Universal Almanac, so he approached The New York Times Company with the idea of creating a new almanac with the newspaper's name on it. Penguin was then brought in as the publisher.
The New York Times Almanac includes a good deal of information from the Universal Almanac, although Mr. Wright rejects contentions by rivals that the old almanac is merely repackaged. He noted that some members of The Times news staff contributed articles about the major news events of the year, as well as the maps in the book.
It is too early to tell whether the new books are making a serious dent in the market share of the older books. Ballantine said its first print run of The Wall Street Journal Almanac was 165,000 copies, while Penguin said it also printed 165,000 copies of The New York Times Almanac.
The World Almanac also traces its roots to the newspaper business. The first edition of the almanac was published by The New York World in 1868. That almanac ceased in 1876, but Joseph Pulitzer, who acquired The World in 1883, revived the book in 1886, and it has been published since then by various companies.
By most counts, almanacs tend to be impulse purchases that are not regularly repeated. According to Richard W. Eiger, publisher of the World Almanac, about 20 percent of his customers buy new almanacs every year, and about 50 percent buy new copies every two to three years.
Mr. Eiger said he was not overly worried by his new competitors. "We respect the competition and are alert to it," he said.
And Elizabeth Buckley Kubik, general manager of Information Please L.L.C., also showed little concern about the new almanacs. "We don't consider them players, because we are not sure if they are in it for the long run," she said. The Information Please Almanac, which has been published since 1947, is seeking a competitive advantage by providing a midyear update to book buyers who want it.
Regardless of the competition, Mr. Eiger said the World Almanac would maintain its $500,000 marketing budget. The others are estimated to spend at least $100,000 each.
He did point out, however, that the World Almanac did not raise its retail price from $9.95 a copy. The others are all $10.95 each.
Mr. Eiger said he was not surprised that almanacs sell well, even with competition from the Internet and CD-ROM's. "Our almanac allows you to get to specific information without trawling through dozens of Web sites to find it," he said.
Others have a similar view. "Finding information on the Internet can be a nightmare," said Barbara Berliner, coordinator of NYPL-Express, a fee-based research service of the New York Public Library. "With an almanac it's quicker, easier and more accurate."
Still, the almanac publishers are developing on-line projects. For example, Ms. Kubik of Information Please said her company had invested "a seven-figure sum" to open a World Wide Web site next month.
Meanwhile, at the Oak Hill Elementary School, the library is acquiring about 30 copies of the 1998 World Almanac. "As soon as the new books arrive, they are snapped up by the kids," Ms. Coatney said. "They will use them and use them until they fall clear apart."

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1616 words

HEADLINE: The Virtues of Addictive Games;
Computer Pastimes No Longer Viewed as Brain Poison

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash.

 BODY:
Inside a small room, the human guinea pig is picking up the pace, pointing and clicking. She hunches closer to the computer screen, moving the mouse quickly, up, down, left, left again.
She gazes intently at the scrambled pieces of a picture puzzle. The visual Rubik's cube -- if the pieces were all in place -- would be a landscape scene of an Egyptian pyramid. She moves the pieces swiftly to assemble the pyramid, brow furrowed and eyes fixed, trying one position after another. 
 Watching her from behind a one-way mirror, in a room next to the computer laboratory, Alexey Pajitnov smiles with satisfaction and pumps a fist in the air. "She's hooked," he declared.
This is the moment that game designers like Mr. Pajitnov, a bearded, genial 42-year-old at the Microsoft Corporation, labor endlessly to achieve -- the moment when curiosity turns to compulsion. It is an elusive goal that, according to Mr. Pajitnov, involves creating a game with an "emotional rhythm" that moves a player across a psychic border, alternating a sense of achievement and loss, pleasure and disappointment.
"You must tease the nerves," he explained.
Searching for the ingredients of compulsion remains the Holy Grail of the $4-billion-a-year business of computer and video games. It is a search that has become far more respectable in the last few years as a growing body of research suggests that playing computer games may actually be good for young minds -- a message that parents may find reassuring during the peak holiday sales season for the games.
Computer and video games, researchers say, can help children develop their skills of visualization, concentration and problem-solving, as well as help them acquire a fluency in technology. Some experts even point to the games as a possible contributing factor in the steady rise in I.Q. scores in developed nations.
In one study of 200 students in the United States and Italy, researchers found that playing video games developed spatial skills and informally prepared children for learning about science and technology. The study, published in the Journal of Applied Developmental Psychology in 1994, concluded that computer games "are not a waste of time."
Computer games, it seems, are a form of intellectual exercise. Strengthening the mental muscles used in these games, researchers say, will increasingly be an advantage in an economy where technology plays an ever-greater role.
"The same skills used in computer games are basic technology literacy skills," said Patricia M. Greenfield, a professor of psychology at the University of California at Los Angeles. "Those skills are extremely important in the modern world."
In Seattle, William D. Winn, director of the Learning Center at the Human Interface Technology Laboratory of the University of Washington, has found that young people "internalize" the ability to visualize the images they create on computers, often enhancing their ability to visualize people and events when they read.
In psychology, some academics have long been studying what is called flow, a state of deep concentration, total absorption and intellectual peak performance that is the mental equivalent of what athletes describe as being in the "zone." Research on flow has tended to focus on serious brain work like playing chess and software programming.
"But there is no question that you can experience flow by becoming immersed in computer games," said Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi, a professor of psychology and education at the University of Chicago.
Praising computer games was heresy years ago when parents, educators and researchers fretted about the dangers of electronic recreation. A generation of America's youth, by some accounts, seemed to have succumbed to the mindless addiction of computer games. C. Everett Koop, the former Surgeon General, once warned darkly that "children are into the games body and soul."
Today, there are still concerns about children being allowed to play violent adult games or spending endless hours hunched in front of a computer. Yet these problems are now seen mainly as matters best dealt with by parental guidance and common sense rather than as unique and unsettling threats to the mental health of young people.
"There has been a real shift from people being afraid that computer games would dry up kids' brains to the view that there are good things about them," said Idit Harel, a former research scientist at the M.I.T. Media Laboratory who has founded an Internet media company -- Mamamedia Inc. -- that produces educational games for children.
Ms. Harel attributes the more favorable attitude toward computer games partly to new research, but also to the human evidence. "The kids who grew up immersed in computer games are now in their 20's, and they are for the most part a generation of bright, thoughtful and successful young people," she said.
One of them, J. C. Herz, a 26-year-old Harvard alumna, wrote a personalized social history of computer and video games, Joystick Nation, published earlier this year.
Even the rapid rise of the Internet, Ms. Herz believes, owes a debt to the electronic playpen of early computer games. "They were training wheels for the Internet," she said. "The Net never would have spread as fast as it did without our generation being comfortable manipulating images on a screen."
The Russian-born Mr. Pajitnov, who joined Microsoft last year, introduced millions of people to a potent blend of skill, concentration and compulsion found in the best computer games. He designed Tetris, perhaps the most irresistibly habit-forming computer game ever. Tetris, an elegantly simple puzzle game requiring the player to reorder cascading geometric shapes, sold 40 million copies on every format from personal computers to Nintendo hand-held video-game players.
For Mr. Pajitnov to even approach his past success will be a long shot. So much has changed in the computer game industry since the late-1980's, when Tetris arrived. Today's hit games, like Myst, Quake and Civilization II, tend to be Hollywood-style productions with three-dimensional animations and elaborate musical scores.
At Microsoft, Mr. Pajitnov is laboring to revive the popularity of computer puzzle games, which ebbed during the 1990's as the industry focused mainly on action games. Even Mr. Pajitnov succumbed. After emigrating from Russia in 1991, he tried his hand at a couple of "shoot 'em up" games, but without great success.
"I keep coming back to the puzzles," he said. "I feel really good at them."
By the standards of today's action-game best sellers, the puzzle genre can seem a sleepy anachronism, slow moving and cerebral. The puzzle game renaissance he hopes to lead may well be slow work, Mr. Pajitnov conceded, saying that he came to Microsoft a year ago because it was a big company with patience and deep pockets.
In July, Mr. Pajitnov's first effort, Microsoft Entertainment Pack: The Puzzle Collection, a CD-ROM with 10 puzzles, hit store shelves. So far, sales have ranged from 2,500 to 5,000 copies a month -- not a hit, but probably a moneymaker, says Ann Stephens, president of PC Data Inc., a research firm in Reston, Va.
Mr. Pajitnov's current project, it seems, is another modest beginning. The picture puzzle game tested recently in Microsoft's computer lab is one offering in a collection of logic, word and image puzzles called Mind Aerobics. The collection was released earlier this month on the company's on-line service, which charges subscribers a monthly fee. Later, the puzzles may also be placed on a stand-alone Web site, available to anyone with Internet access.
The intent of Mind Aerobics is not to lure people into hour after hour of play but, as its name suggests, provide users with 20 or 25 minutes a day of intense "exercise for the brain."
One mental workout is a picture puzzle called Rotascope. It appears on the screen as a fractured circular image, fragments of a picture, scrambled in concentric rings. The player chooses from three levels of difficulty. At level three -- the hardest -- there are five concentric rings of distorted pieces of a picture.
One space is vacant, allowing the pieces to be moved, sorted and rearranged. It is straightforward at first, pieces slipping into place, points racking up. It seems simple. It is not. The path to completion can be torturous -- point, click, drag, faster and faster. Almost got it. No, not quite. Time's running out. . . . Welcome to the compulsive pleasure of puzzle games.
The puzzles are being offered on line because that is where the computing audience is heading. "Soon everyone who uses computers will be on the Net," Mr. Pajitnov said. "So if I want to establish the puzzle, expose as many people as possible to this intellectual pleasure, I have to get them on the Net."
The Internet is indeed seen as the future of gaming, and most experts agree that future will be far more than action games. By 2001, the number of on-line game players will nearly triple, to 18.4 million people, while revenues will surge twelvefold, to $1.6 billion, mostly from advertising, estimates Forrester Research Inc. of Cambridge, Mass.
Most of the growth, says Seema Williams of Forrester, is going to have to come not from the die-hard action-game audience of post-adolescent males but from increasing numbers of women and people of all ages who play games only a half-hour a week or so. Puzzle games do well with this wider audience.
"If the on-line game market is going to become mainstream, it is going to have to move beyond Quake to things like puzzles, the kinds of things that Alexey Pajitnov knows so well," Ms. Williams said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alexey Pajitnov watches people testing games through a one-way mirror. "You must tease the nerves," he said. (Robert Sorbo for The New York Times)(pg. D1)
 
Chart: "Pieces of a Successful Puzzle Game"
With the right ingredients, a game designer can make a player forget about everything else.
 
Within a minute, the player must understand how to play; within three, he must be immersed.
 
The player should be constantly prodded to take the next step; there should be no stopping point until the end.
 
Surfing the edge of that line between challenge and frustration is what great game design is about, says Kenn Lobb, development manager at Nintendo of America.
 
The chef's special stuff," as Microsoft's Alexey Pajitnov puts it. Game design is as much an art as a science. (pg. D14)
