HEADLINE: Poor Oversight Said to Imperil World Banking

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH and RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Three years ago, when Thailand and South Korea were still considered economic miracles and no one but currency traders paid attention to the baht and the won, the United States' top banking regulator saw a looming crisis in Asia.
Eugene A. Ludwig, the Comptroller of the Currency, noticed disturbing parallels between banking practices in fast-growing Asian economies and the mess created in the United States by the deregulation and subsequent collapse of savings and loan associations. Along with deregulation in both cases came a flood of new money, reckless lending and inadequate Government supervision -- a clear recipe for a costly disaster. 
 But Mr. Ludwig's concerns -- passed along informally to a World Bank official at a 1994 meeting in Madrid -- were rare flags of caution at a time when international barriers to the flow of capital were fast disappearing, and investors and financial institutions were pouring money into rapidly developing countries in Asia and elsewhere.
If there is one clear lesson from the turmoil that has so badly jolted Asia, it is that the financial systems in many fast-growing countries were no match for the huge, skittish pools of money they attracted.
As they examine what went wrong in Asia, officials around the world see obvious parallels to past experiences like the American savings and loan debacle as well as complicated new problems.
National systems intended to supervise banks in their home countries have proven unable to keep pace with the rapid development of a global financial marketplace that pays little attention to borders.
There is no international body able to play the role of global regulator, and an inability by the United States and other powers to impose changes on the often-reluctant governments and banks in nations at risk.
And efforts to bolster the soundness of financial systems in Asia and elsewhere by encouraging greater disclosure of financial data and by prodding large international banks to demand changes have so far yielded little if any success.
A result is that to a remarkable extent, individual nations and even the worldwide economy are suddenly more at risk because of the ineffectiveness of obscure banking regulators in far-off countries.
South Korea, Thailand and Indonesia are among the countries paying a steep price for the problems with their banks, and Japan is scrambling to avoid the same fate; just last week Japan unveiled a $77 billion plan to shore up its financial institutions. The ripples have crossed the Pacific, unsettling Wall Street, hurting exporters and potentially curbing economic growth in the United States.
"In the early 1980's the U.S. confused deregulation with supervision, and the same thing happened in Asia," said Charles Bowsher, the former head of the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress. "You pay a very big price, as we did in 1929 and the 1980's in this country, and what we're now seeing in Asia."
With the International Monetary Fund taking the lead, multinational organizations and national governments have pledged more than $100 billion to bail out countries in Asia, the largest international rescue in history. Yet, paradoxically, there is no global body with the ability or the mandate to manage the problem.
Individual countries monitor what their banks do at home and abroad, and what foreign banks do on their turf. But if central banks and national regulatory agencies can take individual snapshots, no organization is responsible for a global perspective.
The principal body for coordinating international bank regulation -- a committee of worldwide regulators operating under the Bank for International Settlements in Switzerland -- has made little progress until now in getting countries like Korea of Thailand to upgrade their standards.
Even the I.M.F., which has only recently been thrust into the front lines of the battle to shore up weakened banking systems, is a reluctant savior.
"The amount of detailed knowledge it takes to understand a system is beyond the capacity of a single multinational organization to deal with," said Stanley Fischer, the I.M.F.'s first deputy managing director.
The problem is not new. The collapse of big, international financial institutions like the Bank of Credit and Commerce International in 1991 and Barings P.L.C. in 1994 showed the vulnerabilities in the system of supervising multinational banks.
But the stakes now are often much higher, involving not individual banks but entire economies. And while the I.M.F., other multinational bodies and national governments are willing to come to the rescue, they lack the crucial power that usually goes hand-in-hand with status as lender of last resort -- the ability to demand changes, before crisis hits, in a bank's management.
"In the last few years we've come to realize -- and you may say it's late -- that banking system stability is more important for a wider range of countries," said Andrew Crockett, the general manager of the Bank for International Settlements.
"It's the public sector, whose money is on the line, that prevents a financial meltdown, so the public sector has to have a voice," Mr. Crockett said. "How can we get these countries to adopt these standards? The answer is you can't."
The limits of sovereignty concern bankers and others in the private sector, as well.
"National supervision of complex global firms and global markets is inadequate to meet the requirements of the times," said John G. Heimann, the chairman for global financial institutions at Merrill Lynch.
The solution, according to a recent study by private and public sector experts for which Mr. Heimann was co-chairman, is that major financial institutions, in cooperation with supervisors, must take the lead in reducing global financial risk.
"The speed and complexity of innovation in the markets, the supervisors' inevitable position 'behind the curve' and their real handicaps in competing for talented staffers all argue for private institutions to take on greater responsibility," the study found.
The study's conclusions, which were supported by top officials of some of the world's largest financial institutions, including Citibank, Deutsche Bank, Nomura Bank International and Credit Lyonnais, were made public just as the crisis in Asia was emerging this year. But it is unclear whether the private sector will take on such a crucial role.
In South Korea, for instance, large Japanese, European and American banks may have been part of the problem rather than part of the solution. They were among the financial institutions most exposed to huge losses by South Korea's woes, suggesting that they too missed warnings signs and are in some ways the beneficiaries of Korea's $60 billion bailout package.
Meanwhile, governments, including the United States', have been expending much political capital and exerting considerable effort to get other countries to open up their financial markets to the Merrill Lynches of the world.
Just recently the World Trade Organization, after long negotiations, concluded a financial services pact that further opens up the banking, securities and insurance industries in scores of nations. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin wrote the head of the W.T.O. in August to "underscore our view that financial liberalization and the maintenance of financial stability are mutually reinforcing."
Mr. Rubin wrote of the "need to develop and maintain strong supervisory regimes and regulatory infrastructures" as the Asian financial crisis was in its first stages.
Some Asians feel that such a message should have been delivered earlier and more forcefully.
The United States, acting at the behest of American banks, pressed South Korea to open its financial markets a few years ago, but Washington "didn't help the Korean Government prepare for these things -- it went too fast," said Yoon Dae Euh, a professor of international finance at Korea University and former member of Seoul's Monetary Board.
In some ways the United States may even have contributed to undermining the discipline of the international financial institutions that poured money into South Korea. Washington strongly backed the entry of South Korea in 1996 into the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the elite club of industrial nations. Membership is largely symbolic, but it carries with it certain perks, among them an assumption, under rules developed by the Bank for International Settlements committee, that bank loans to members carry no risk of default.
So South Korea's entry into the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development may have helped give the marketplace a false sense of confidence about South Korea, according to banking experts and an I.M.F. official.
Between 1994, when South Korea received its first green light for membership, and 1996, when it officially joined, foreign banks more than doubled their lending to South Korea, from $52 billion to $108 billion, according to Bank for International Settlements reports.
While organization membership requires open financial markets, it does not require sound financial supervision.
"We ought to strive for higher standards, maybe even hand in glove with O.E.C.D. membership," said Mr. Ludwig. Asia, he added, "shows that the importance of sound and good regulation is much more a factor today than it has ever been before."
But if governments and international organizations find it hard to strengthen such systems, the solution, according to policymakers like Mr. Rubin and regulators like Mr. Crockett, is to rely on market pressure.
However the problem gets addressed, no one thinks it will be a quick, easy task.
"This is not a one- or three-year job, it is a five-year or ten0-year job," Mr. Crockett said.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Berlin Wall, Part 2

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Watching the recent political developments in Southeast Asia reminded me of a conversation I had last month with an American executive in Moscow. The U.S. businessman told me he had been approached by a Russian who was interested in setting up a joint venture. The American asked the Russian one question: Do you pay your taxes? No? Well, said the American, if you don't pay your taxes, we can't be partners because we're a public company; if one of our subsidiaries doesn't pay its taxes, it shows in our annual audit. So the Russian now has a choice: pay his taxes in Moscow or miss out partnering with a cutting-edge U.S. firm.
The integration of global markets, information and standards has many downsides, and the financial contagion spreading through Asia today is one. But one of integration's most powerful upsides is its ability to foster political change, and that is also happening in Asia today. We are now witnessing Southeast Asia's equivalent of the fall of the Berlin wall. The Communists in Europe had to take their Berlin walls down to get into the globalization game. The capitalists in Asia are being forced to take their economic Berlin walls down to stay in the game. 
 The crony capitalism practiced in Southeast Asia -- with banks, bureaucrats and business linked together, directed from above and shrouded in secrecy -- had a certain Soviet quality, as the economist Paul Krugman first noted. It may have been useful for early development, but it became a liability as these countries integrated into today's global economy. In an increasingly fast, complicated and interconnected world, centralized control doesn't work so well. The center can't know enough to keep up, which leads to misallocated resources and inefficient practices.
So, at the depths of Asia's economic crisis, Thailand passes a new Constitution requiring more open decision-making, more accountability from ministers and more democratic governance. South Korea elects as its new President Kim Dae Jung, the country's leading pro-democracy crusader, who vows to "open a new age of democratic economic order that respects market mechanisms and competition." Malaysia's conservative, nationalistic leader, Mohamed Mahathir, has had to defer to his more liberal Finance Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, to get out of this crisis.
"The answer to this crisis" is to link Malaysia even more to global systems and standards, "not less," Mr. Ibrahim told me. "No other option can satisfy the needs and demands of Malaysia's people. We can't have a multi-media supercorridor here and then say that there should be no liberalization of our financial sector. We can't have an uncensored media and then say no to democracy. You can't reverse this game. We have opened our market, and lowered taxes, to encourage foreign investors to come in, and we have to deal with it. If we told people we were going back to subsistence life, there would be a revolution."
I call this phenomenon "Globalution." You have a generation coming of age in Southeast Asia who want affluence, but don't want to be corrupt, and who want more democracy, but are afraid to go into the streets. They doubt there will ever be revolution from above. They fear revolution from below. So their whole strategy is revolution from beyond. They want to link their countries in every way they can to the powerful forces of globalization -- from the Internet to global businesses and international human rights N.G.O.'s -- hoping that these forces will import change, and rule of law, which won't come from above or below. I wish everyone could come to democracy by reading Madison, but sometimes the push has to come from Merrill Lynch. Kim Dae Jung got his start in Korea fighting the secret police. But he just got elected President to fight the secret banks.
Are trade, financial integration and the Internet enough to produce democracy in these countries? Of course not. They are necessary, but not sufficient. Ultimately, you can't have democracy without democrats. But the fact is global markets today are demanding, in return for their investments, the rule of law, transparency, predictability, competition and pluralism in financial affairs. And it is precisely these pressures for better governance in finance that the democrats can build upon for their political goals. That's exactly what's happening in Thailand, Malaysia and Korea. Soon it will be China's turn.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
A Generous Country

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The immigration law passed by Congress in 1996 has had harsh effects on some individuals: visitors barred at our borders, aliens marked for deportation after living here legally for many years. I discussed the issues with the principal House sponsor of the law, Representative Lamar S. Smith, Republican of Texas.
"America should continue to be the most generous country in the world toward immigrants," Mr. Smith said. "I think they have much to contribute to this country." 
 The 1996 act, he said, was designed to deal with people who do not deserve to be here, such as those who enter illegally. But it was not intended to deny anyone fair treatment.
"There is no excuse for anybody being treated unjustly," he said. "Justice is one of the things that makes this country great, and rightly attracts people here, along with economic opportunity and freedom."
What about instances, I asked, where the Immigration and Naturalization Service has admitted that its officers mistreated individuals at the border? The Commissioner of Immigration, Doris Meissner, has said that about several cases described in this column in recent months.
"It's not the fault of the law," Mr. Smith replied. "It's the fault of the I.N.S.
"When you have hundreds of millions of entries every year, and you have human nature involved, there are inevitably going to be some lapses. That doesn't excuse them. I hope it won't be interpreted as rationalizing any kind of insensitivity. It is simply a comment on what is a fact of life."
One provision of the 1996 act, called "expedited removal," allows I.N.S. agents to keep out anyone they think is trying to enter the country improperly, even if the person has a U.S. visa, and bar him for five years. I asked whether that didn't encourage hasty, sometimes unfair decisions.
Mr. Smith said he had been to two border checkpoints in the last several months and found the border patrol agents "enthusiastic" about the provision. "I think on the whole it's reducing the abuses," he said, "the gaming of the system."
The new law's process for dealing with applicants for political asylum is also working well, he said. It requires someone who claims to be fleeing persecution first to persuade an asylum officer at the border that he or she has a "credible fear," then to have an asylum hearing before an immigration judge.
"The asylum officers are getting some good training," Mr. Smith said. "Almost 90 percent of people asking for asylum are being found to have a credible fear. When you have that high a level of initial acceptance of their claims, clearly the officers are giving people the benefit of the doubt."
Since it was human nature for the I.N.S. to make some mistakes, I asked, why had the new statute in many areas stripped away the right to judicial review of the agency's decisions?
"Judicial review," he said, "encouraged many of the people who are in this country illegally" by allowing them to contest their deportation endlessly. He said there were about five million, with the number growing by 300,000 a year.
The 1996 law also made legal immigrants deportable because of minor crimes committed years ago, and removed their right to seek a waiver of deportation. A notable case is that of Jesus Collado, a Brooklyn man who faces deportation because he slept with a 15-year-old girlfriend 23 years ago and was put on probation for contributing to the delinquency of a minor. He has lived a blameless life since and has an American wife and three children.
"In the vast majority of cases I think the crimes do justify deportation," Mr. Smith commented. "However, perhaps around the far edges the I.N.S. should have some discretion in these cases.
"First I'd like to be reassured that the Administration is serious about deporting hardened criminals. It has a program to deport those currently in prison when they finish their sentences, but it is deporting less than 50 percent."
The Collado case, he said, "obviously tugs at your heart. Clearly this is an instance where humanitarian considerations should be taken into account. I believe in redemption, and I believe it should be granted generously.
"The question is how you do that without creating a giant loophole through which thousands of others can escape deportation."

HEADLINE: U.S. Should Help Turkey Enter Europe

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Turkish Wrongs and Rights" (editorial, Dec. 18) attacks the European Union for hidden prejudice in rejecting Turkey as a member in the near future, although the rest of your editorial seems to sustain legitimate reasons for doing so. You say Turkey's human rights problems are solvable, and I agree. However, it seems wiser to delay making any commitments to admit Turkey. 
 The issue of what form Islam will take in Turkey's future is far from resolved. Will it be a modern form that accepts the separation of religion and state, or will it be a more classic form that requires a state legitimacy based on religion?
Will Turkey learn to practice real tolerance toward its Kurdish minority? Will it ever acknowledge the Armenian genocide? Will it end the partition of Cyprus? Will Turkey resolve its mineral and oil disputes with Greece?
Moreover, German concern about a large influx of Turks seems legitimate. Germany is suffering from unemployment over 10 percent and has yet to resolve the status of its minority groups. With a relatively high birthrate, Turkey could prove difficult for the E.U. to integrate without Turkey's achieving a higher living standard.
 
BILL MCMICHAEL
Oak Hill, Va., Dec. 18, 1997

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Unemployment in State Dips Below 5 Percent

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Fr the first time in more than seven years, New Jersey's unemployment rate dipped below 5 percent last month to 4.9 percent, according to a report released Friday by the State Department of Labor. 
 The unemployment rate, down from 5.2 percent in October, has not been as low since June 1990, before the state's economic recession began, said Kevin Smith, a spokesman for the department.
New Jersey gained 8,500 new jobs in November, reaching a new high of 3.7 million jobs, the report said.

HEADLINE: Joined for Life, and Living Life to the Full

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER 

DATELINE: READING, Pa.

 BODY:
LIKE many twins descended from a single egg whom the world has deemed "identical," Lori and Reba Schappell prefer to emphasize their differences over their similarities.
Lori is warm and boisterous and maternal. She wants to get married and have babies, she says, and at the age of 36, she wants to do it soon. Reba is quiet and self-contained, and she squirms whenever her sister hugs her in public or tells her that she loves her. Reba is focused on her fledgling career as a country singer. Earlier this month, she flew to California to accept an L.A. Music Award for best new country artist of the year. 
 Lori keeps her brown hair short, speaks with the broad-voweled accent of the Reading area, where the sisters have always lived, and loves strawberry daiquiris. Reba colors her wavy hair copper, has adopted a Nashville twang and is a teetotaler.
But there are certain things the sisters undeniably share. They are, literally, of one flesh. They are conjoined at the head, portions of their skull, scalp and blood vessels fused at the side in a mirror-image configuration, so that they face in opposite directions. And though they have two distinct brains, they are of one mind in their opinion about whether they would ever consider undertaking the risks of surgical separation.
"Our point of view is no, straight-out no," said Reba, for the moment not the "quiet" one. "Why would you want to do that? For all the money in China, why? You'd be ruining two lives in the process."
"And we'd miss the other one horribly if she were to die," Lori added.
Reba and Lori live a life that no singleton can imagine, and one that looks unbearably difficult. Where one goes, so must the other. Reba is short and cannot walk for herself, and so her sister wheels her around on a bar stool. They venture out in the world fearlessly, and the world never stops staring at the sight of them. But as they see it, their lives are no more difficult than all lives.
"There are good days and bad days -- so what?" says Reba. "This is what we know. We don't hate it. We live it every day. I don't sit around questioning it, or asking myself what I could do differently if I were separated."
Nor does Lori appreciate being held up as an exemplar of fortitude. "People come up to me and say, 'You're such an inspiration. Now I realize how minor my own problems are compared to yours.' But they have no idea what problems I have or don't have, or what my life is like."
The attitudes of the Schappell sisters are strongly felt, but not unique. As Alice D. Dreger, a historian of anatomy at Michigan State University in East Lansing, argues in a new and detailed analysis of the medical treatment of conjoined twins, the assumption among surgeons, the public and most parents, that life as a conjoined twin is not worth living, and that separation should be tried in nearly every case, whatever the risks, is an outsider's premise, and one in need of some serious scrutiny.
Writing in the current issue of a new journal called Studies in History and Philosophy of Science, Dr. Dreger reviews cases in which surgeons have aggressively sought to separate conjoined twins even when the distribution of shared organs resulted in the extreme disability or death of one. She points out that throughout history, conjoined twins who reached adulthood have expressed satisfaction with their linked lives.
 
An Ethical Dilemma
Sacrificing One To Save the Other
Consider the case of Mary and Eliza Chulhurst, one of the first documented examples of conjoined twins. Born fused at the lower back and buttocks in the year 1100, the Chulhurst sisters -- also known as the Biddenden Maids -- lived for 34 years in Kent, England. After the death of one sister, doctors urged the survivor to allow them to attempt surgical separation to save her. She refused, declaring, "As we came together, we will go together." She died several hours later.
Yet despite the testimony of twins themselves, Dr. Dreger argues, doctors persist in regarding conjoined twins -- also known by the now-disfavored term, Siamese twins -- as monstrously abnormal beings who must be individuated surgically, even if such standard mores of medicine as "first do no harm" are set aside to do so. She explores at length the disturbing ethics that surrounded the widely publicized case of Angela and Amy Lakeberg, born in 1993. The girls were attached breast to belly, sharing a liver and a single, six-chambered heart, rather than two four-chambered ones. Because the infants had no chance of survival in their conjoined state, the parents opted for a long-shot effort to save one of the twins at the expense of the other.
In an extraordinary operation, a team of surgeons at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia cut off circulation to Amy, deliberately "sacrificing" her to salvage the heart for Angela. The effort ultimately failed, and Angela died 10 months later, but the doctors involved, as well as many others, have maintained that it was better to try to rescue one twin rather than allow both to die.
Yet, as Dr. Dreger argues in her new report, if the twins had been born separate, and the health of both were failing, nobody would have proposed that one sickly twin should be killed and her organs harvested for the sake of the other's survival.
"That we would go so far as to intentionally asphyxiate a conscious head, and kill one of the twins in order to make a singleton out of them just astonished me," Dr. Dreger said in a telephone interview. "There was much ethical discussion at the time about the cost of the operation, but very little about whether or not this was morally right."
As Dr. Dreger sees it, the willingness in this case to forfeit one young life for another bespeaks society's extreme discomfort with its outliers, those who in the past would have been called freaks and exhibited at circus sideshows, but who today are often the objects of elaborate and heroicized surgical interventions. The implications of how conjoined twins are treated go beyond the rare condition, which occurs in about one in 50,000 to one in 100,000 births.
 
'The Treatment Train'
Easy to Hop On, Hard to Get Off
Dr. Dreger and others who share her views see parallels between medical attitudes toward conjoined twins, and toward those children born with other anomalies, including ambiguous genitals, dwarfism, congenital deafness, and the like. Such conditions have invited aggressive attempts at fixing, often through a long series of operations, medications and rehabilitations; and most have required that the therapies be performed on children too young to have a say in whether they want to be treated or not.
"There's an allurement called the treatment train," said Dr. David C. Thomasma, director of the medical humanities program at Loyola University Chicago Medical Center. "You hop on, but it's very hard to get off. The power of the medical model today to shape our decisions is enormous." Dr. Thomasma is an author of a paper that appeared last year in the Hastings Center report about the Lakeberg twin case. Like Dr. Dreger, he was disturbed by the ease with which Amy Lakeberg's life was taken. "I remember during all the debates how quickly people who wanted to intervene could move into the idea that one twin was like a parasite or an appendage -- language that makes one morally able to divide them."
The conjoined twins conundrum is part of a larger tension now underlying America's attitude toward what might be called "differency." On the one hand, antidiscrimination laws have had a real impact, allowing disabled people who might once have spent their lives in seclusion to work, take public transportation and just generally be visible. Moreover, several subcultures have arisen -- of people who were born deaf, or achondroplastic or intersexual -- who do not want to be regarded as handicapped and do not want to be "repaired."
At the same time, surgeons say that their techniques are better than ever, and that they can effectively correct many physical defects early enough that children will grow up never knowing they were outliers to begin with. And many doctors argue that the benefits of fitting in, while easy to pooh-pooh as adults, are hard to overstate for children and teen-agers.
In addition, the number of children born with obvious disabilities is declining as the resolution of prenatal ultrasound and other fetal diagnostic procedures improves, allowing parents to abort abnormal fetuses. "What we're seeing now with conjoined twins is a lot of termination of these pregnancies," said Dr. James A. O'Neill Jr., surgeon in chief at Vanderbilt University School of Medicine in Nashville.
In sum, the dominant culture appears to be moving in two contradictory directions: more accommodating of disabilities in adults, but less tolerant of imperfections in children. "I'm concerned that as more abnormal children are prevented through abortion and testing, we'll be less tolerant of abnormality," said Dr. Alan R. Fleischman, a bioethicist and senior vice president of the New York Academy of Medicine in Manhattan. "We'll blame families if they knew there would be an abnormal child but chose not to abort."
 
The Mystique
From Roman God To Barnum Freaks
Nobody knows what causes conjoining, but most experts assume it arises when a fertilized egg begins to split in two, as happens with identical twins, but then fails to complete the fission. The conjoining can occur at many points of the body, and result in a variety of configurations, from a major sharing of brain, heart, liver or intestines, as well as external limbs, to the development of two nearly complete individuals connected only by a minor bridge of flesh on the torso. For unknown reasons, about three-quarters of conjoined twins are female. All but 25 percent of conjoined twins are either stillborn or die soon after birth.
Those who survive have always been objects of fascination. Mythical creatures like the two-faced god Janus and the Centaurs are thought to have been inspired by conjoined twins. The most renowned of all conjoined twins were Chang and Eng Bunker, Chinese brothers who were born in Siam in the early 19th century and thus were called Siamese twins by P. T. Barnum, who was their manager for a time.
Attached by a round band of flesh extending from breastbone to navel, the Bunkers profited handsomely by exhibiting themselves to the public, and were able to become gentlemen farmers and slave owners in North Carolina. They married two daughters of a clergyman, set up two separate households, and between them fathered 22 children.
A musical now on Broadway called "Side Show" celebrates the lives of another famous set of conjoined twins, Daisy and Violet Hilton, who appeared in the classic 1932 movie "Freaks" and later ended up working in a supermarket.
What people find difficult to imagine about conjoined twins is how they negotiate such ordinary needs of the body as sex and excretion, and how they can stand doing everything together. The Bunker twins managed by taking turns every three days on who was in charge. Reba Schappell capitulated to Lori for a few years while Lori attended college and then worked in a hospital. Now Lori says it is Reba's turn to dominate, and she accompanies her sister to recording sessions and performances, at which she practices a kind of Zen detachment. "I'm just there, I'm not doing anything," said Lori. "I say hi to people, but then I let Reba get down to business."
Yet the sisters also engage in a constant and perhaps largely subconscious dance of intimacy: fixing a sister's stray lock of hair, or picking a bit of lint off the other's shirt. When they move through a shopping mall they look like young girls, best friends, heads bowed together, murmuring to each other, swept up in a realm of their own.
Doctors who have performed separation surgeries say that the apparent contentment of the Schappell sisters is just as well, for in their case separation is probably impossible, and would lead to mutual death by hemorrhaging. But surgeons say that each case of conjoined twins is unique, and that in many instances separation is possible, if difficult. They insist that even risky attempts are usually worth the effort, and that the hard truth is, yes, it may be better to end up with one reasonably normal singleton than to accept conjoined twins, whose shared organs may not be up to supporting them, and whose lives will be severely restricted.
In a paper that appeared recently in Pediatric Surgery International, Dr. John Raffensperger, a retired surgeon from Children's Memorial Hospital in Chicago, recounted two cases of separation surgery in which the stronger of the twins was given the bulk of the shared organs, and the weaker one eventually died. The survivors, now 16 and 12, appear to be "well-adjusted," Dr. Raffensperger writes, although one "has questions about why her sister died."
Dr. John M. Templeton Jr., formerly a pediatric surgeon and now president of the John Templeton Foundation, recalled the first separation surgery he performed, in 1974, with Dr. C. Everett Koop, on 13-month-old girls from the Dominican Republic who were connected from the liver to the lower pelvis. "We thought they would have tremendous anxiety when they were no longer conjoined, so we put their two beds side by side," he said. "To be honest, they seemed almost relieved to be separated."
The girls fared well after the surgery, but two years later, one of them choked to death on a bean. Her sister grew up and in 1994 gave birth to a normal baby boy.
For parents, the desire to give their children as normal a life as possible is so profound that it can override any fears they have about the dangers of separation surgery. Michelle Roderick said that after she gave birth in May 1996 to Shawna and Janelle, attached at the abdomen, she and her husband never considered keeping the girls conjoined.
"We felt that since the chances were so good that they'd come out of it as healthy individuals, we didn't think it would be fair not to try," she said. "If they'd stayed conjoined, they wouldn't have been able to walk normally or develop normally and it would have been pretty sad."
The surgery took more than seven hours, and at one point Shawna went into cardiac arrest and almost died, Ms. Roderick said. But today, the girls run around and talk a mad streak like any other toddlers, displaying their pencil-thin scars to all who care to see them.
Dr. Dreger said she was not immutably opposed to separation surgery, nor does she romanticize the state of being conjoined. What she does question is the presumption behind the most radical surgical pyrotechnics that a life conjoined is hopeless, absurd, no life at all. She argues that decisions about who is in pain and who should be fixed -- whatever their purported abnormality -- must go beyond mechanical or economic or even philosophical considerations, to include the voices of those who know best.
"We need to have people who live with a condition be allowed to describe for themselves what it's like," she said. "Otherwise we'll assume it's a living hell, and that we're doing the right thing by eliminating them."

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 4; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1307 words

HEADLINE: Hollywood Bets It All On Openings;
As the Cost of Films Rises, They Have Less and Less Time to Find an Audience

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
"Titanic," "Tomorrow Never Dies," "Scream 2," "Flubber," "Amistad" or "Anastasia." If you haven't been drawn to the blockbusters released since Thanksgiving, wait a day or two. Something new will come along: "As Good as It Gets," "The Postman," "Kundun." For even as the cost of making and marketing the typical big-budget film approaches $70 million, the window of opportunity each movie has to find an audience is shrinking.
"It's as if Procter and Gamble had to launch a new toothpaste every other week," proposed Frank Rose, author of "The Agency," a history of the William Morris talent agency. 
 Many people in the business are inclined to write off this make-it-or-break-it focus on the first weekend's box office gross as a self-destructive impulse from an industry notorious for chasing the flavor-of-the-month. But a closer look suggests that method lurks beneath the seeming madness that overtakes the film industry, especially at peak moviegoing times like Thanksgiving to New Year's.
The economics of marketing now powerfully favors nationwide openings in thousands of theaters over the traditional "platforming" approach, in which a movie opens in a few cities and builds. "Distributors are effectively forced to spend everything up front," said Howard Lichtman, executive vice president for marketing for the Cineplex Odeon theater chain.
The intensity of the drive for a big opening weekend has often produced accusations that studios inflate figures. Box office figures are based on the number of theaters showing a film, which is compiled in part by the studio. Yesterday, Miramax Films, owned by the Walt Disney Company, admitted that it had inflated ticket sales for the opening weekend of "Scream 2." Miramax said the film grossed only $33 million on its opening weekend (Dec. 12-14), not the $39 million at first reported, because Miramax miscounted the theaters where it was playing.
The revenues from domestic theatrical release are a shrinking share of the total income from the typical film aimed at a mass audience. The opening has thus become the fulcrum for selling everything from videos to foreign distribution to toys and popcorn. As an indirect result, shelf life on the big screen is shrinking.
To be sure, there are no absolutes in film marketing. Many movies, in particular foreign films and independent productions with modest budgets, still open in a handful of theaters and still rely on media reviews and word-of-mouth to create an audience large enough to justify the move to the multiplexes.
By the same token, $50 million-plus productions are occasionally shown in New York or Los Angeles in time to qualify for Academy Award nominations, then open nationally months later. And "sneak previews" are still sometimes used to create a buzz weeks before the publicity avalanche. But with big-budget movies, the trend toward betting it all on the opening weekend seems inexorable.
In the early 1970's a typical movie with broad appeal might open in 300 to 400 theaters. Today the seven major studios are releasing record numbers of films, 216 in 1996 compared with 134 in 1980. Yet the 2,000- to 3,000-screen opening, in an industry with a total of 29,000 screens, has become commonplace. On Thanksgiving weekend, for example, "Flubber" opened on 2,641 screens.
Television has played a key role in the change. While distributors have used local television spots for decades to supplement print advertising, Warner Brothers pioneered the use of network television as its principal advertising medium in the early 1980's, and others soon followed.
Today prime-time shows on Wednesday and Thursday are flooded with trailers for next weekend's movies. And for good reason. Despite the high cost, one studio executive said, national television delivers frequent moviegoers at the lowest price per person.
By the same token, it is widely accepted that an advertising blitz is more cost-effective than the same number of spots spread over a longer period. "There are too many mice running around the field where the elephants are dancing," concluded Peter Graves, president for marketing at Polygram Films.
 
Theater Profits Come From Popcorn
 While dependence on television drives the saturation opening, so too does the contemporary economics of movie exhibition. Between 1980 and 1996, the number of auditoriums increased by 69 percent while movie attendance rose just 31 percent, creating what is widely perceived as a glut in theater capacity.
It's not clear whether "glut" is the right word since, thanks to higher ticket prices, the total domestic box office gross rose 115 percent in the same period. But there's little doubt that theaters often strain to fill auditoriums at $6 to $8 a ticket and put a premium on booking first-run films studded with stars and special effects that draw audiences.
That fresh, glitzy product has become extremely expensive to generate. The average movie from the seven major studios cost $39 million to make last year, up from $9 million in 1980. And while every deal between distributors and exhibitors is negotiated, the split in box office revenues, typically 70-30 in the first few weeks of a run, heavily favors the distributors.
As a result, theaters are lucky to cover their costs on box office revenues, with the real profits coming from the young, junk-food-craving consumers at the concession stand. "They've become candy stores looking to move people in and out as fast as they can," explained Tom Sherak, vice president for marketing at 20th Century Fox.
The exhibitors' emphasis on the rapid turnover of first-run films is complemented by changes in the market for the Hollywood product. Two decades ago most of the revenue from most movies came from the domestic theatrical release. Since then theatrical revenues from Europe, Latin America and Asia have become increasingly important, often exceeding the domestic box office. Foreign revenues from "Men in Black," the film that outstripped the competition last summer, for example, are approaching $300 million.
 
VCR and Cable Make a Vast Market
 By the same token, the value of ancillary rights has exploded. The number of households with VCR's has grown from 1.8 million in 1980 to 78 million today, creating a market for 641 million recorded videocassettes in 1996. Pay-cable channels consume vast numbers of movies, and with 55 million subscribers, they have plenty of cash to bid up the value of the rights. Pay-per-view movies on television is a rapidly growing area, with an estimated 28 million households paying $603 million in 1997 for them.
As a result, says Marvin Antonowsky, the former head of marketing for Universal Pictures, the domestic theatrical release "has become part of the broader marketing campaign" to maximize the value of a film.
And much of the benefit to this broader campaign apparently comes from the validating effect of a smash opening weekend. "The media report box office scores like a horse race," said Mr. Lichtman at Cineplex Odeon. "If you're in first place, it's the stamp of approval" that pays dividends long after the movie leaves the theaters.
Each escalation in the competition for the hearts and wallets of consumers of filmed entertainment generates concern that specialized tastes will be given short shrift in the rush to satisfy the mass audience. But while the emphasis on producing blockbusters with a short theatrical life has created what Charles Cicchetti of Civic Economics, consulting group in Los Angeles, calls "a bimodal distribution of expensive and inexpensive films with few in the middle," it is hard to identify an audience that isn't being served as well as it was in the past.
"Movies no longer age like good champagne," agrees Mr. Antonowsky, but there are compensating virtues to freshness.

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 1; Style Desk; Fashion Page

LENGTH: 1454 words

HEADLINE: Design Houses Lament Asia's Faltering Economies

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
The visual rhetoric of fashion has always had a tenuous relationship with its actual business plan.
A few of those house-defining gowns depicted so lavishly in magazine advertisements do sell, but most fashion profits are raked in at the perfume and accessories counter. And while there certainly are affluent American customers for designer goods, roughly half the world's full-priced luxury purchases are made by Asians, either in their own countries or while traveling. 
 And so, many fashion companies have pegged their growth in recent years to the Pacific, mostly through the sales of handbags, perfumes and other goodies that fit in the overhead compartment of an airplane.
But this business reality is being severely tested these days as Asia suffers an economic upheaval that has severely injured the luxury retail business in Hong Kong, Korea and other nations and has caused many luxury-goods companies to rein in their growth plans, at least for now.
"The wealthy Asian consumer just went over the cliff and will probably stay quite depressed over 1998," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, the investment bank in New York. "Most of these high-end retailers that had been counting on Asian yuppies for their growth over the next 10 years are stuck with American yuppies for now."
Economic weaknesses throughout Asia have caused currencies and stock prices to plunge: Hong Kong, the hot spot of luxury goods sales, has taken a beating since October, and the Japanese economy has been in a protracted slump, with recent bank failures underscoring the seriousness.
At the same time, the currencies of a number of Southeast Asian countries -- spots that fashion has eyed for years -- have also weakened sharply during the last several months. And in South Korea, where the International Monetary Fund was recently forced to come up with a $57 billion financial-disaster bailout, there has also been a popular backlash against foreign luxury goods. If that mood continues, there could be long-term trouble ahead.
All these problems have meant one simple thing: There are far fewer people willing or able to shell out for leather handbags and spike-heeled shoes these days, let alone for the matched designer outfits the Asian customer favors.
Luxury sales in Tokyo have remained mostly steady, but foreign travel is down for the Japanese. And people are no longer flocking in such huge numbers to Hong Kong, where two-thirds of the economy has traditionally been based on consumer spending. Sales in luxury stores throughout the rest of Asia have ranged from spotty to downright miserable over the last few months, and the carnage is visible.
Shares of Gucci tumbled 18 percent this fall, and though they have recovered somewhat (they closed yesterday at $39.875 on the New York Stock Exchange), they are nowhere near their high of $73 last June. The picture is similar for LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, the largest luxury products company in the world, as it is for Dickson Concepts, a luxury goods producer and retailer based in Hong Kong: both have been hammered on their home stock exchanges since October.
It gets worse. Joyce Boutiques Holdings, which operates high-fashion stores in Hong Kong, said it lost $27.9 million Hong Kong (about $3.6 million United States) for the half year that ended Sept. 30. Business partners in Taiwan are taking longer to pay the French shoemaker Robert Clergerie; Calvin Klein has put its Korean and Hong Kong expansion plans on hold, and Donna Karan International is eager to sell its Japanese affiliate, company executives say.
In a poignant example of how the growth equation has shifted, DFS Group, the duty-free-store empire that has been on the leading edge of Asian expansion, is now angling to buy Barneys New York for a little American sales pop. And luxury goods merchants everywhere are now pinning hopes on Europe, until now regarded as anemic.
"In Europe, there are still a lot of markets for us," said Ippolito Etro, the chief financial officer at the Italian fashion house Etro. "And I see a lot of companies pushing toward the States, the only market which is still big and where you can still increase."
Asia accounted for 38 percent of the Italian company's growth last year: for 1997, it will be just 31 percent. The Asian economic crisis, "has kind of stopped our growth there," Mr. Etro said.
Domenico De Sole, chief executive of Gucci, said that all luxury companies have to focus on other markets in the short term. "It is pretty clear people have to change the focus of their business and gain strength in United States and Europe," said Mr. De Sole, whose company makes 10 percent of its sales in Asia and another large chunk in Hawaii, a prime tourist destination. "Balance is very important."
The Asian shopper is not only in the majority in stores from Milan to New York to Hong Kong, but also more geared to buying entire outfits than, say, her American counterpart, who might pair a Prada skirt with a Hanes T-shirt. So losing an Asian shopper is more serious.
"What is striking when you see consumers in Asia is their whole head-to-toe concept," said Faye Landes, a retail analyst at Smith Barney in New York. "They take a different view of the product, which is that they want it all. Showing that you made it is such an important concept to Asians, and luxury has meshed really well with that."
For a large publicly traded company like Gucci, the storm may be weathered by trying to focus on sales in other regions. But small companies with huge Asian exposure may find themselves in a typhoon.
Consider a company like Anna Sui, where at least 40 percent of the business comes from Asian clients, executives say.
The company has recently established a partnership with the Isetan Company of Japan to license and distribute its goods exclusively in Japan and some other Asian countries; it also has a relationship with Joyce in Hong Kong. "Over the last year, the plan we developed was to take a strong but measured approach to Asia," said Rod Kosann, the company's president. "From 1997 to 1998 we are looking for our business to grow 20 percent there. We look at what is going on and are concerned about it, but we think it is going to be a great market."
Indeed, more than a dozen fashion executives interviewed last week -- at companies ranging from Anna Sui to Bulgari -- said that they were cheery about Asia in the long term, or they bragged that their exposure was really quite limited after all. Others seemed to feel that the problems are those of their licensed partners.
But these arguments have flaws. "Only" 10 percent of Polo/Ralph Lauren's business is done in Asia, a spokesman said, but a big portion of its 10.2 percent growth in licensing revenue was made there in 1996, according to financial documents filed when the company went public. Conversely, many companies have saturated the American and European marketplace.
And even if licensees or retail partners are the ones that have to take the initial hit, those partners will be buying less merchandise or forcing vendors to mark it down.
"If Asia is big in their portfolio, their future is very difficult to assess," said Joyce Boutiques' president, Roberto Dominici, referring to fashion companies. He added that on the retail end, inventory budgets will fall.
For a tiny vendor that has depended heavily on Asian growth, the crisis could be a serious threat. But for companies with a cash cushion to carry them through or with strong sales elsewhere in the world, it makes no sense at all to leave Asia now.
"Producers have a longer time horizon when they think about production and market share," said Steve Radelet, an economist at the Institute for International Development at Harvard University. "And for people interested in the long term, Asia is where the action is. With 60 percent of world's population growing at 7 percent a year, you have to be there."
In the meantime, several fashion companies have made some moves to lessen the pain. Marc Jacobs, for example, is offering a few lower-priced products to Asian licensees. "I'll work with them," said Robert Duffy, Mr. Jacobs's business partner. He might make items that are "not as labor intensive or heavy," he said.
And for rich fashion vendors, there is even a silver lining. As prices fall in Hong Kong and elsewhere, some companies will be able to snatch up Asian real estate.
"The good news is that high-end vendors have the opportunities to buy stores very cheaply now if they have a long-term view," said Mr. Yardeni of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. "But they also have to recognize they have to have stamina."

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Constance C. R. White 

 BODY:

Tent Economics
Now that Seventh on Sixth is moving back to Bryant Park, the question is how the shows found themselves with a view of New Jersey to begin with. The answer may lie in the sweet deal the group got from Chelsea Piers. Seventh on Sixth was looking at a bill significantly lower than that incurred in Bryant Park. 
 Renting the piers space cost $150,000 to $200,000 a season, said Fern Mallis, executive director of Seventh on Sixth.
The tents -- with lighting, sound, seating and other accouterments -- are likely to ring up a bill closer to $2 million. That's about $500,000 more than it cost in the past. The extra cost, though not final, is a result of added tents.
"It costs significantly more to put up a tent than to move into an existing building," Ms. Mallis said.
Being in the tents will make the shows substantially more attractive to sponsors, some of whom had threatened to pull out of the unified shows at the piers.
Plans for the return of Seventh on Sixth are on the drawing board but there will no longer be a Gertrude tent, which seated close to 1,000, nor a Josephine Pavilion. Instead, three tent show spaces will be erected.
The largest will seat about 780, with a capacity of 1,030. A second multipurpose tent will accommodate between 550 and 700 guests, and the smallest tent, 150 guests. "Nobody wants those huge tents anymore," Ms. Mallis said. "In mid-January we'll present these plans to designers and get feedback."
The accessories exhibition, which had been housed in buildings near the park, will be in a fourth tent.
Additional space may be provided by TrizecHahn Office Properties, a real estate company that owns 1411 Broadway and 1114 Avenue of the Americas.
"We have a great investment in the the health of the apparel center in New York," said Doug Winshall, general manager of the New York region for TrizecHahn. "We're committed to helping Seventh on Sixth putting on the shows."
 
Samples, but Much More
The fashion industry may as well christen December sample sale season, with the plethora of fliers being handed out in midtown.
Both the known and the unknown -- those whose only claim to fame is often "get it below wholesale" -- have been staging sales aimed at capturing the Christmas shopper and clearing out industry goods.
Donna Karan, Rebecca Moses, Escada, Louis Feraud, Phat Farm, John Bartlett, Genny, Katayone Adeli, Fila, Showroom Seven and Onward Kashiyama, which represents ICB and Helmut Lang, have been sold directly by the manufacturer to the public in recent weeks.
What is mostly at work here is the large scale on which business is being done these days and the difficulty of selling clothes at retail prices. With more stores forcing designers to take back unsold goods, selling directly to the public even at below wholesale prices generates important cash flow for companies.
With outlet stores one of the fastest-growing retail segments, sample sales -- a misnomer, since so much more than samples is sold -- are but an extension of fashion companies handling their own markdowns.
For bargain seekers -- and who isn't? -- December sample sales are a way to say, "Happy holidays."
Saks Wed to Avant-Garde
Rosemarie Bravo is gone from Saks Fifth Avenue, but the strategy she initiated, turning the store into a destination for shoppers seeking avant-garde fashion, is in full swing.
For spring, Saks -- whose advertising leans toward Vogue and Architectural Digest -- will run an eight-page insert in Wallpaper and Interview magazines featuring designs by John Bartlett, Alberta Ferretti for Philosophi, Susan Lazar, Marc Eisen and Gianfranco Ferre for Gieffeffe.
"We're continuing to build that market segment," said Sheri Wilson-Gray, Saks's executive vice president for marketing. "A really serious fashion customer probably looks at a lot of different publications. For those who are narrow fashion customers, they really want to be into what other people are not doing."
The focus on what Saks calls advanced collections has yet to affect its bottom line, but the store believes it can lure this customer with the right emphasis. "We like 'advanced' better than 'young,' " Ms. Wilson said. "To be hip in your attitude or forward in your design attitude isn't necessarily about your age."

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 494 words

HEADLINE: Dangerous Inertia in Japan

 BODY:
Whether the financial turmoil in East Asia remains a regional problem or spreads across the world depends in no small measure on Japan. So far, Japan has barely been able to maintain its own balance. Instead of bold steps to deregulate financial institutions and disclose the extent of Japanese problems, Tokyo's bureaucrats have employed half-measures. Japan must set an example of reform, otherwise the rot in financial institutions throughout the area is not likely to be excised.
Japan, with the world's second-largest economy, dwarfs other Asian nations. Its problems -- failing banks, opaque bookkeeping and corrupt interlocking corporate relationships -- are equally great. Last week plunging Japanese stock prices and declines in the value of the yen forced Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto to stimulate the economy. Though opposed by the Finance Ministry, it was a welcome but inadequate step. 
 Japan has been hit before by economic blows, most notably the energy crises of the 1970's. But what worked in the past, including heavy government involvement in propping up businesses and banks, will not work now. This is no time for the Finance Ministry to adhere to its tradition of keeping the economy closed to outside scrutiny, or preventing bankruptcies of weakened corporations or banks by arranging for friendly partners to rescue institutions that should be allowed to fail. Recently the Ministry has allowed some businesses to go under, and Mr. Hashimoto has proposed a $70 billion plan to bail out depositors, but more aggressive steps are needed.
Japan has repeatedly rebuffed American suggestions for government action to spur domestic economic growth. The Finance Ministry's actions have raised fears that Japan will try to grow out of its downturn by expanding exports, aggravating trade deficits at a time when Americans are already suspicious of the dangers of increased trade. The package announced by Mr. Hashimoto last week consisted of about $45 billion in tax cuts and spending increases. Economists say it will not increase growth by much more than half a percentage point. Part of the problem is that the Hashimoto package was barely enough to offset the budget cuts and tax hikes that the Finance Ministry foolishly rammed through Parliament earlier this year.
Prime Minister Hashimoto needs to follow up his initial steps with other economic reforms. Previous actions to deregulate the telecommunications industry, for example, have brought an infusion of investment and expansion. The same can happen in transportation, construction, distribution and real estate. As for the weak Japanese banks, they could face more blows at the end of March, when tough new standards on capital requirements and disclosure go into effect. Rather than shrink from the prospect, Mr. Hashimoto should demand that Japan acknowledge and address its problems. Doing so would speed Japan's own recovery and set the right example for Asia.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises on New Evidence Of Weakness in Asia Markets

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the yen yesterday as Japanese stocks fell to their lowest level in more than two years amid fear of more corporate failures and continuing economic sluggishness in much of Asia.
The Nikkei index of 225 leading stocks dropped 3.37 percent, to 14,799.40, the first time the index had closed under the psychologically important 15,000 level since July 1995. 
 Currency traders seemed less than impressed by comments from an unidentified Japanese Finance Ministry official, who ruled out more near-term bank failures, insisting that Japanese banks were solvent.
The yen was also dragged lower by signs of fresh economic woes elsewhere in Asia as the International Monetary Fund reduced its combined growth forecast for Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines by 3.7 percentage points, to 1.7 percent, and predicted that Japan would grow 1.1 percent in 1998.
News that Moody's Investors Service had downgraded Government debt ratings for South Korea, Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand also weighed on the yen. But traders stopped short of taking the dollar significantly higher in thin, holiday-season trading, concerned that the Bank of Japan might be ready to resume large-scale purchases of yen in an effort to prop up the currency's value.
"There is still a fear of central bank intervention even though the dollar remains bid," said Ralph Del Zenero, vice president for foreign exchange at the First Chicago Bank.
The Japanese central bank is believed to have spent around $10 billion last week to buy yen, and traders said it might be waiting for another opportunity to surprise the markets. The exchanges will be closed in Japan today, and trading is expected to wind down in Europe and the United States.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar settled at 130.13 yen, up from 128.93 yen on Friday. It was quoted at 1.7810 German marks, up from 1.7753 marks. The British pound fell to $1.6633 from $1.6681.
In other trading, the dollar was up against the Canadian dollar, shrugging off a new attempt by the Bank of Canada to shore up its currency. The Canadian dollar eased to 69.81 United States cents, from 69.86 cents on Friday.

HEADLINE: Stocks Regain Ground, With Dow Up 63.02

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stock prices rose yesterday for the first time in four days, led by Intel and other computing shares that had recently lagged behind the market.
"Investors are moving into beaten-up stocks, particularly technology companies," said Tony Hitschler, president of Brandywine Asset Management, which oversees $7 billion. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 63.02, or 0.8 percent, to 7,819.31, led by Merck & Company. Merck rose 3 5/16to 105 15/16 , after receiving Government clearance to sell the first pill to treat baldness. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index rose 6.92, or 0.7 percent, to 953.70.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 7.32, or 0.5 percent, to 1,532.06. Intel, the most active stock in United States trading, rose 1 7/16 , to 71 7/16 . Intel, however, is still off 29 percent from its Aug. 20 high.
Other computing stocks gained. Dell Computer gained 3 5/16 , to 81 5/8, Compaq rose 1 1/8, to 54 5/8, and Hewlett-Packard advanced 2, to 63 1/8,
The gains came after Asian markets declined. Moody's Investors Service Inc. cut its investment ratings on South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand to junk, intensifying concern that a regional cash squeeze will drive companies into default.
Technology analysts at Goldman, Sachs & Company said in a report that while the economies of the United States and Europe remain healthy, "the current strength of the U.S. dollar and Asian situation will likely alter trading patterns over the near term, tempering U.S. exports."
Stocks were helped by acquisition announcements. Lukens Inc. jumped 4 1/2, to 28 1/2, after Allegheny Teledyne Inc. offered to acquire the steelmaker for $715 million in cash and assumed debt, topping the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's bid. Allegheny Teledyne rose 1 3/8, to 25 5/16 , and Bethlehem Steel gained 5/8, to 8 7/16 .
American International Group Inc. said it would pay $2.2 billion in stock and cash for American Bankers Insurance Group. American Bankers rose 1 7/16 , to 45 11/16 , and AIG rose 1 1/2, to 106 3/8.
The American Home Products Corporation rose 3/4, to 74 7/8, after Tyco International Ltd. said it would buy its Sherwood-Davis & Geck unit for about $1.8 billion, expanding Tyco's medical-products line. Tyco rose 1 15/16 , to 42 7/8.
The Central and South West Corporation gained 1 1/8, to 27 1/8 after the American Electric Power Company said it would buy the company for $12.2 billion in stock and assumed debt, in the biggest-ever acquisition of an electric utility. The combined company will serve more than 4.6 million customers in 11 states and 4 million customers outside the United States. American Electric fell 1 1/4, to 50 3/4.
The Baltimore Gas and Electric Company and the Potomac Electric Company canceled their $3.8 billion purchase agreement because regulators asked for too much in rate cuts from them. Baltimore Gas rose 11/16 , to 32 15/16 , and Potomac Electric fell 5/16 , to 23 1/8.
Xionics Document Technologies Inc. was the biggest decliner in United States markets, tumbling 6 9/32 , to 31 9/32 . The developer of software for office equipment said it expects net income for the fiscal second quarter of 2 cents a share, 8 cents below analyst forecasts. The company in part blamed "increasing uncertainty in the Asian market." The Capital One Financial Corporation rose 1 13/16 , to 50 1/4, after it said it expects its 1997 earnings to exceed analysts' expectations on marketing initiatives and improving credit outlook.

HEADLINE: 2 Ex-Dictators Leave Korea Jails, Pardoned After 2 Years

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 22

 BODY:
 The former military dictators Chun Doo Hwan and Roh Tae Woo walked out of prison today and returned home to warm welcomes with some brief but kind words for their former enemy, President-elect Kim Dae Jung.
The two former Presidents, wearing suits and overcoats, emerged from separate prisons and were taken by limousines to their homes in Seoul, where their families and hundreds of well-wishers waited with flowers and "welcome home" signs. 
 Mr. Chun had been sentenced to life in prison and Mr. Roh to 17 years for their roles in the 1979 military coup that brought Mr. Chun to power, for the violent suppression of a pro-democracy uprising in Kwangju in 1980 and for the collection of millions of dollars in bribes from businessmen.
But after spending only about two years behind bars, the two former generals were pardoned on Saturday after a decision by President-elect Kim, a former dissident whom they had once sentenced to death on false charges in 1980, and by President Kim Young Sam, another former opposition leader whom they had placed under house arrest.
As he left Anyang Prison south of Seoul, Mr. Chun told reporters that it was "fortunate" that such a "reliable" President had been elected. But he seemed less favorably inclined to the incumbent President, who had prosecuted him, saying he was surprised by the nation's economic crisis.
"I apologize for causing the Korean public anxiety," Mr. Chun said, adding in reference to the economy, "I believe that we can overcome the crisis because of the inherent strength of the Korean people."
Mr. Roh congratulated Mr. Kim on his election and said: "I expect that President-elect Kim Dae Jung will give all he has to save the economy, which has neared collapse. I also believe he will overcome all conflict, including regional tensions, to create unity."
The two former Presidents looked healthy, if somewhat thinner and grayer than when they entered prison.
When he arrived at his home in Seoul, Mr. Chun waved to the crowd and lifted one of his small grandsons into his arms. Mr. Roh stood outside his home with his wife, holding hands, and walked through the crowd shaking hands and apologizing for his actions. His eldest son, Roh Jae Hun, returned from the United States for the occasion.
Dozens of riot policemen were on hand, but there were no disturbances. At Mr. Chun's prison, however, a small group of people protested his release and were restrained by the police.
Kim Dae Jung agreed to the pardon to unify the country and allow it to concentrate on solving the economic crisis, which has led to the $57 billion-plus rescue by the International Monetary Fund.
Mr. Kim was elected with barely over 40 percent of the vote in a three-way race and has little support from the southeast part of the country, the home base of Mr. Chun and Mr. Roh.
Human rights groups protested the pardons, saying it was unfair to free the two former dictators while not doing the same for people who are still in prison under the strict national security law for having championed democracy or for sympathizing with North Korea.
Mr. Chun and Mr. Roh were restored to full rights as citizens, meaning they can re-enter politics if they choose. But their fines for bribery, which could amount to more than $100 million each, are still supposed to be paid.
Also freed today were 23 other men, most of whom were aides to Mr. Chun, who was President until 1988, or Mr. Roh, his handpicked successor, who served until early 1993.

HEADLINE: Racial Edge Sharpens Debate On South Africa's Gun Laws

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: LENASIA TOWNSHIP, South Africa, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The eyes of Frederick Mosila, a taxi fleet owner, were stiff and unblinking behind his dark glasses as he leaned on the counter of Lenasia Arms & Ammunition. He buried his wife this weekend. "She was in the hospital three weeks," he said. "She was joking and laughing, but she said her legs were paining her. I came back the next day -- and they said she had died at 7."
She had been shot in the back, he said, quietly miming how the bullet passed through her body as she opened their garden gate in Soweto. The killer ran away in the dark. Mr. Mosila assumes it was someone from a rival taxi company. 
 He was buying ammunition for his licensed 9-millimeter pistol, he said, to defend himself and his children. Someone shot at him several weeks before his wife was killed.
He had applied for gun licenses five times, he said, both under apartheid and under the new government. He was rejected the first four times.
South Africa, a country rife with crime, is in the midst of a fierce debate over gun laws. On paper, they are very strict, but enforcement is haphazard. There is a strong gun culture, but only in some segments of the fractionated population. Afrikaners, the white descendants of Dutch and French Huguenot settlers who fought their way up the continent in the 1800's, have a frontier gun-owning tradition. Blacks were long forbidden to own guns. There was illegal trafficking in guns, but those weapons mostly circulated among criminals. Then in the mid-1980's, the Soviet bloc issued thousands of AK-47's and pistols to anti-apartheid guerrillas and the police handed guns to opponents of the African National Congress. That infusion of weapons fostered political killings and the crime wave plaguing black townships that has given South Africa a murder rate estimated to be five times that of the United States.
Crime has created a desire among many blacks -- like those visiting Lenasia Arms, the closest gun shop to southern Soweto -- to own guns.
A gun-control movement was founded in 1994, about the same time the authorities began granting requests by blacks to own guns. The movement is growing, but it suffers a crucial weakness: Since its founders are white, it is sometimes portrayed as racist, an idea encouraged by the gun shop owners' lobby.
The founders of Gun-Free South Africa, the most prominent group, vehemently deny that, pointing out that they are veterans of the anti-apartheid movement and are supported by black church leaders and police officers. But there are those who say non-whites commit most of the country's crime and whites wanting guns already have them, so guns should now be tightly controlled to keep them out of non-white hands.
The new Constitution guarantees the right to life and "freedom and security of the person." It does not mention a right to bear arms. Existing laws, written under apartheid, differ sharply from American ones.
Here, it is easier to get a license for a pistol than for a shotgun, a weapon that can be bought over the counter in many American states. The hardest kind of license to get is for a .22-caliber rifle because the assumption here is that a pistol is for self-defense, but quiet small-caliber rifles are the tools of assassins and poachers. Farmers, a powerful lobby in the past, hate poachers.
While concealed weapons imply criminal intent in much of the United States, here guns must be hidden. The assumption is that a gun displayed is an attempt to intimidate.
To buy a gun, an applicant must fill out a four-page police form. Applicants generally must have a job, references and a clean criminal record. The applicant must also pass a gun safety course and a have a steel gun safe bolted to brick or cement at home. The process takes from one to three months.
"You make such a fuss in America about a five-day waiting period," said Adelle Kirsten, national coordinator of Gun-Free South Africa. "To us, that's crazy."
The process is often slipshod, she said. Few references are checked, false identity numbers are submitted, data bases of stolen weapons and criminal records are weak.
Ms. Kirsten said Gun-Free South Africa wants to tighten the laws, and get more money for the police to do better background checks.
"We have to get rid of the myth that guns make you safer," she said.
About 10,500 South Africans were killed with guns last year. Ms. Kirsten's group estimates that there are 7 million guns in the country. About 80,000 a year are stolen from private owners.
Although blacks were legally allowed to apply for licenses in 1983, almost none of their applications were accepted, gun shop owners say, until 1994, when Nelson Mandela led the African National Congress to victory in South Africa's first national elections open to all races.
Immediately, a large new market was created. In the 1980's, said Rajen Dukken, who is of Indian ancestry, some white gun shop owners wouldn't let him touch their wares even though he was in a shooting club. Now he is manager of Lenasia Arms.
"After 1994, many re-tuned themselves for the black trade," he said. "Now you feel like a real customer, because of the color of your money."
In the last year, gun shop owners said, police refusals of applications have increased.
Because of the "taxi wars," -- battles between taxi fleets over routes that have led to violence -- people who work in that business, like Mr. Mosila, are routinely turned down. So are the unemployed, for fear they will rob people, and squatter camp residents, because a safe can't be attached to a tin wall.
Illegal guns and poor police protection are most prevalent in the neighborhoods where law-abiding black citizens live. "They come right into your house and help themselves to your daughters," said Boy Mahlaba, a middle-aged Soweto resident.
The Government finds the issue just as difficult. Ms. Kirsten says she has had some lobbying success, but most of her support comes from women in Parliament and from law-enforcement officials upset at the high rate of killings of policemen.
But in the rank-and-file of the African National Congress, support is shaky. "We're not naive enough to think that the reason the majority of black people don't have guns is because they believe as we do," she said. "It's because they can't afford them."
