HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Outlook for Profits: Asia Is Clouding the Picture

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Every earnings season can hold nasty surprises for investors. But with the stock market swooning lately over reports of financial turmoil in Asia and every lowering of profit expectations by a major American corporation, some analysts are worrying that the shocks in early 1998 will be particularly unpleasant.
But, as they scour Asia for signs of where its economies -- and orders for American goods and services -- are going, analysts and corporate executives are warning of the difficulty of predicting the fallout from the spreading crisis there. "It's a very complicated issue," said Thomas Doerflinger, an investment strategist at Paine Webber. "Costs are being changed by shifts in currencies and demand flows in each country. It's tricky." 
 And many strategists are cautioning that the bad news from Asia will show up more sharply in the reports for the first quarter, which do not come out until spring, than in those that will be issued in January and February.
"What is coming up will give us some clues but not the final story," said Eric Miller, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in San Francisco. The shutting of factories, the impact of tighter credit and the mass layoffs will not be fully reflected in the fourth quarter, he said, adding, "The real pain is still ahead."
With American high-technology stocks showing greater volatility lately than those in many other industries, the efforts of two closely watched companies to assess the impact of Asia's economic woes on their earnings prospects show the uncertainty that investors face.
The Intel Corporation, the world's top maker of integrated circuits, says the impact has been negligible -- so far, that is, and as best as it can make out. Some of the worst-hit countries, like Indonesia, are not major markets for its products, the company says. And Japan, which has been limping along economically for years, had not been expected to generate significant new orders anyway.
As a result, said a spokesman, Howard High, Intel is keeping a close eye on China and India, trying to gauge whether their economies -- and their demand for Intel's chips -- will slow because of the fallout from the rest of Asia next year.
But, he said, it it is too early to tell if there has been any significant change in the company's prospects in those two countries. This means that Intel's fourth-quarter earnings report, due out in the second week of January, may not tell the full story.
The same uncertainty applies for investors in Applied Materials, the world's largest manufacturer of computer-chip-making equipment. Although the company surprised Wall Street with better earnings than analysts expected for its fiscal fourth quarter that ended in October, investors have since then pushed the company's stock price down 42 percent because the company does more than half its sales in Asia.
"The bottom line is that we don't know yet," said Jeff Lettes, a company spokesman. "Right now with what is going on in South Korea, our customers are trying to figure out in which direction they want to move. And we have to wait until those decisions are made."
For example, Korean chip makers may find it difficult to buy the next generation of chip-making machinery right now. But on the other hand, many analysts believe they will have to do so, whatever the cost, to stay competitive.
The turmoil in Asia, combined with signs that the American economy may be peaking after years of strong growth, has divided analysts on the earnings prospects for American industry as a whole.
Abby Joseph Cohen, co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company, remains upbeat. Ms. Cohen said that the fourth quarter "is the most difficult to parse for analysts" because the write-offs companies take at the end of the year are usually much larger than in any other quarter.
But, she said, "I think the whole quarter is going to be pretty good," adding that signs from some of the banks and financial companies that will lead off the reporting season are positive. Companies are saying that the Asia factor "will not be a big deal," she said.
Mr. Doerflinger of Paine Webber, by contrast, believes that current consensus earnings estimates in the low double digits for American industry in 1998 are too high.
No matter how the final earnings reports come out, the worry about Asia and the expectation of slower growth in the United States next year have led analysts to scale back their earnings projections for the last three months of this year. According to First Call, a Boston-based firm that tracks earnings estimates by analysts around the country, the forecast for the 500 companies in the Standard & Poor's index has been revised downward over the last five weeks, to an increase of 8.3 percent from a year earlier, compared with an earlier prediction of an 11.2 percent gain.
Chuck Hill, the director of research at First Call, said the downward adjustment was much sharper than usual and raised questions about the earnings outlook for the first quarter of next year and for all of 1998. Currently, analysts expect first-quarter earnings to rise by 17 percent from the first quarter of 1997; their projection for 1998 as a whole, however, has slipped in just the last week to a 14 percent increase over 1997 from an earlier guess of 14.4 percent.
In recent quarters, actual earnings have ended up matching analysts' original projections, and surpassing their more pessimistic subsequent revisions, because positive developments have offset any bad news that had dribbled out earlier. But Mr. Hill said that there was "no way" that would happen this time around.

HEADLINE: In Clinton's Words: Fight Hard for Peace

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech by President Clinton yesterday to residents of Sarajevo, Bosnia, as transribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company.
I come before you with a message for those in whose hands the future of Bosnia lies -- its leaders and its people. For in the end the future is up to you -- not to the Americans, not to the Europeans, not to anyone else.
Two years ago in Dayton, Ohio, the leaders of Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia and Serbia made a fateful choice for peace. But their responsibility and yours did not end there on that day. In fact, it only began. 
 Your responsibility is to turn the documents signed in Dayton into a living reality; to make good on the pledge to bring Bosnia together as one country, with two multi-ethnic parts, sharing a common destiny. Those who rise to that responsibility will have the full support of the United States and the international community. Those who shirk it will isolate themselves.
The world, which continues to invest in your peace, rightfully expects that you will do your part. More important, the people of this country expect results and they deserve them.
You have accomplished much, but there is much more to do. You have established the joint institutions of democracy. Now you must work within them, sharing power as you share responsibility. You have vowed to welcome back those displaced from their homes by war. Now you must vote for the return program so that they actually can come back with stronger protections for minorities and more job creation. You are working to restore Bosnia's economy. Now you must build up the laws to attract assistance and investment, and root out the corruption that undermines confidence in economies.
You have begun to turn the media from an instrument of hate into a force of tolerance and understanding. Now you must raise it to international standards of objectivity and access, and allow an independent press the freedom to thrive. You are taking the police out of the hands of warlords. Now you must help to reform, retrain and re-equip a democratic force that fosters security, not fear. You have pledged to isolate and arrest indicted war criminals. Now you must follow through on that commitment, both for the sake of justice and in the serving of lasting peace.
Most of all, the leaders here, you owe it to your country to bring out the best in people, acting in concert, not conflict; overcoming obstacles, not creating them; rising above petty disputes, not fueling them. In the end, leaders in a democracy must bring out the best in people. But in the end, they serve the people who send them to their positions.
And so to the people of Bosnia, I say today, you must make your desire for peace and a common future clear to the leaders of each group. And you must then give leaders the absolute support they need to make the hard decisions for a common future.
The people of Bosnia can make it happen. The example that ordinary citizens set among your neighbors, the standards that you demand from your leaders, will determine this nation's fate.
After such a hard war, fighting aggressively for peace is difficult. So many have lost mothers and fathers, husbands and wives, sons and daughters. So many wounds are deep and scars still fresh. Energy may be short at a time when an extraordinary effort of will is required to wrench yourself from the past and to begin to build a future together. . . .
I thank all of those who are making organized efforts to build a common future, especially those who are mobilizing women, because they know so painfully how important reconciliation and reconstruction are to your families and your children's future.
What I want all of you to believe today is that you can do it. In our time, from Guatemala to South Africa, from El Salvador to Northern Ireland, people are turning from conflict to conciliation. Still, the impulse to divide, if not to actually fight and kill over ethnic or religious or racial differences, runs deep in human nature across the globe. It seems to be rooted in a fear of those who are different from ourselves . . .
I think it is important that all of you remember and teach that the war did violence not only to Bosnia's people, but also to its history, its own tradition of tolerance. Just minutes from here, standing within yards from one another are a mosque, an Orthodox church, a Catholic church and a synagogue, reminding us that generations of Muslims, Orthodox Christians, Catholics and Jews live side by side and enrich the world by their example here; built schools and libraries and wondrous places of worship. Part of that population laid down their tools on Friday, part on Saturday and part on Sunday. But their lives were woven together by marriage and culture, by work and common language and a shared pride in a place all could call home. That past should be remembered. And you should do everything in your power to make it a prologue. History can be your ally, not your enemy.
I am persuaded, having served in this office for five years, that the real differences around the world today are not between Jews and Arabs; Protestants and Catholics; Muslims, Croats and Serbs. The real differences are between those who embrace peace and those who would destroy it; between those who look to the future and those who cling to the past; between those who open their arms and those who are determined to clench their fists; between those who believe that God made all of us equal and those foolish enough to believe they are superior to others just because of the color of their skin, of the religion of their families, of their ethnic background. This is a very small nation on an increasingly small planet. None of us has the moral standing to look down on another, and we should stop it. . . .
Well, they're still here, and they're still Muslims, Croats and Serbs. And to tell you the truth, I know the tuba players from the violinists, but I can't tell the Muslims from the Croats from the Serbs. The harmony of their disparate voices -- the harmony of their disparate voices -- is what I hear. It reminds me of Bosnia's best past and it should be the clarion call to your future.
Here at the dawn of the new millennium, let us recall that the century we are leaving began with the sound of gunfire in Sarajevo. And let us vow to start the new century with the music of peace in Sarajevo.
To the people of Bosnia I say, you have seen what war has wrought; now you know what peace can bring. So seize the chance before you. You can do nothing to change the past; but if you can let it go, you can do everything to build a future. The world is watching, and the world is with you. But the choice is yours. May you make the right one.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Pataki Agrees to $17 Million Deal To Protect Swath of Adirondacks

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki announced today that the state had reached a landmark agreement to buy nearly 15,000 acres of Adirondack wilderness that the Whitney family had planned to develop, while also protecting a tract twice that size for 10 years.
The $17.1 million deal opens a pristine stretch of forests, streams and lakes -- including Little Tupper Lake, regarded by naturalists as one of the region's jewels -- to the public for the first time since William C. Whitney, the industrialist, bought the land for a family retreat a century ago. 
 The acquisition will connect separate tracts of publicly owned forests in the Adirondacks, allowing canoeists and other adventurers to travel hundreds of miles without interruption. And by barring development on an additional 36,000 acres of Whitney land for the next 10 years, the state has been given time to find a way to preserve that land.
"This is a historic day for everyone who cares about the Adirondacks," the Governor said. "Through this agreement, we will preserve a uniquely valuable wilderness in the heart of the Adirondacks, insuring that future generations will be able to enjoy thousands of acres of undisturbed rivers, ponds and forests."
The Whitney family, headed by Marylou Whitney, had proposed subdividing the 14,717-acre plot and building luxury homes on it. But that plan drew bitter protests from environmentalists, who urged New York State to buy the property, which is about 35 miles southwest of Lake Placid.
Today, Mrs. Whitney, who inherited one of America's oldest fortunes from her husband, Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, spoke bluntly about how pained she was at having to give up a cherished family property for far less money than she had initially expected to get. The family has sold property around Little Tupper Lake for $1,917 to $9,000 an acre, but under the deal announced today, the family wound up selling the tract to the state for $1,161 an acre.
"Because of my love for this state and the memory of my late husband and his family, I have settled on a deal that I would normally not do," Mrs. Whitney said at a morning news conference in the State Capitol announcing the land sale. "Today, it is with a very heavy heart that I part with this portion of my land."
The deal drew praise from leaders of environmental groups, who described it as one of the most significant land purchases the state has made in the Adirondacks in several generations.
"The state has been buying land in the Adirondacks for years, but Whitney Park has always been the missing piece of the puzzle," said Neil F. Woodworth, a lobbyist for the Adirondack Mountain Club. "Now that we have this piece, the state's lands in the Adirondacks are finally linked."
But the deal also drew protests from business and community leaders in the Adirondacks, who believe that the state's drive to acquire land in the park is hurting the timber industry, the region's economic backbone. "We think that when New York State purchases the Whitney property and incorporates it into the forest preserve, we will lose a major resource that is used by people across the state and the nation, namely timber," said John Brodt, a spokesman for the Blue Line Council, a group that represents property owners and labor unions in the Adirondacks. "And you lose jobs."
For about a century, New York State has been acquiring property in Adirondack Park, which with six million acres within its borders is the largest public park in the contiguous United States. The state now owns 2.5 million acres of forest preserve that intermingles with more than 3 million acres of private land, including 110 villages, hamlets and towns.
But the state still faces huge hurdles in its efforts to preserve the Adirondack forest, including a recent decision by a timber company, Champion International Corporation, to sell off its 144,000 acres of North Country forest land. Environmental groups have lobbied the Governor to move quickly to preserve the land, either by buying it or working with Champion to find another timber company.
The state's last major land purchase in the Adirondacks was in 1988, when the administration of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo bought 15,419 acres from Lassiter Properties, a timber company. But that deal did not include a vast stretch of wilderness like the Whitney property. Rather, the state bought dozens of parcels scattered around six counties.
"The purchase of the Whitney property may be the most significant purchase of wilderness on the East Coast since World War II, when the state was buying up property in the high peaks of the Adirondacks," said Bernard Melewski, a lawyer for the Adirondack Council, a private group. "The Whitney property is, without question, the heart of possibly the greatest stretch of wilderness on the East Coast."
The Whitney property was once a vast estate three times the size of Manhattan. But over the years, small parts were sold off, and timber was taken from many stretches to pay taxes. Mrs. Whitney inherited the land four years ago with the death of her husband, a businessman who was a grandson of the original buyer of the land. Mrs. Whitney decided to subdivide and sell a nearly 15,000 stretch of the estate because property taxes had been mounting.
New York State intends to buy the property with money from two sources, the state's Environmental Protection Fund and the Environmental Bond Act that voters approved last year to pay for environmental projects around the state. The state will pay $13.9 million for a 14,700-acre tract that includes 10 lakes and ponds. It will also buy 80 acres of land on the north side of Little Tupper Lake that includes 26 buildings that are the headquarters for Whitney Industries. The sale is expected to be completed in June.
As part of the deal, a private group, the Adirondack Land Trust, will pay Whitney Industries $3 million in exchange for the company's pledge that it will not develop the remaining 36,000 acres for 10 years.

HEADLINE: Reversing Reservation's Pattern of Hard Drink and Early Death

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: PORCUPINE, S.D.

 BODY:
Cold winds as jagged as broken glass wail across barren fields and bumpy roads here in deepest South Dakota, an echo of the pain in the wretched, unforgiving land where Britton Kills Right, as a boy of 12, had burned two tattoos into his arms: "More Beer" and a sketch of the Grim Reaper.
"I wanted to drink," said Mr. Kills Right, now 22, "and I wanted to die." 
 But he has found reason to live. Sober now for nearly a year, Mr. Kills Right is part of a fast-growing sobriety movement among American Indians that uses healing programs, including sweat lodges, that are steeped in ancient ways.
At the same time, tribal officials have been aggressively promoting teachings that remind American Indians that alcohol was introduced to them by Europeans.
Tribal leaders say that the view of alcohol has changed starkly among the 26,000 residents of the American Indian Reservation at Pine Ridge, S.D., and on other reservations, especially among the young, with chapters of Students Against Drunk Driving growing rapidly. Here in Shannon County, politicians for tribal offices often post signs with the pronouncement, "A Sober Candidate."
But it is a fierce struggle. Indian children learn early that life is bitter, and brief, on the Pine Ridge reservation, one of the poorest places in the nation, where male life expectancy is 56.5 years, younger than anywhere else in the United States.
Burdened by poverty and suffering, their salvation from misery often comes in a bottle, ultimately a cruel hoax, as staggering rates of alcoholism contribute mightily to the early deaths.
Mr. Kills Right, who began drinking at 6, watched his 28-year-old mother die after being pushed through a window in a drunken brawl. He watched his grandmother drink herself into oblivion, night after night. A friend had a car accident while drunk, a wreck that left him brain dead, and another friend with a drinking problem committed suicide. He saw his father drink himself into a rage nightly, always looking for a fight, sometimes beating Britton.
"I drank beer, vodka, whisky, anything I could get, and when I didn't have any alcohol, I used mouthwash and cough syrup to get me drunk," Mr. Kills Right said. "And every day, I prayed for death."
He had been sitting in a jail cell, locked up for public drunkenness, when a man and a woman arrived and asked him whether he wanted to go with them, take a warm shower, eat a sandwich and drink a can of pop.
They were workers from Ampetu Luta Otipi, a treatment center whose name means "living in a red day," or "life in harmony with all things." There, Mr. Kills Right sat through a purification ceremony in a sweat lodge made of bended willow branches, prayed to the Creator, meditated and learned that great heroes like Crazy Horse had railed against drinking the white man's poison and warned that it would lead to devastation.
Richard Two Dogs, the medicine man at the treatment center, said young American Indians often assumed that drinking and despair had always defined their culture.
Many young men, Mr. Two Dogs said, have been taught to see intoxication as a rite of passage, that it takes a real man to be a hard drinker.
"I will ask a young man, 'What is Lakota?" Mr. Two Dogs said. "And he will reply, 'Lakota is to be poor. Lakota is to be alcoholic.' "
Then the medicine man will retort: "Lakota is a warrior! Lakota is proud!"
In other tribal lands, alcoholism treatment programs have been flourishing, sometimes run on a shoestring budget by volunteers, and sometimes financed with revenues from casino gambling.
The Oneida Tribe in Wisconsin, among others, used the casino windfall to build an alcoholism treatment center.
In South Dakota, civic leaders say that people who once saw drunkenness as an inevitable feature of life on the reservation have become more outspoken about the scourge.
"When you go to powwows or other public events," said Tim Giago, publisher of Indian Country Today, a Rapid City newspaper, "you just don't see open drunkenness like you once did. Our people are becoming more aware of our traditional ways and culture. And they're realizing that drunkenness was not part of it."
The success of such programs has yet to be measured. A recent Harvard University epidemiological study of life expectancy was based on 1990 figures. The study found that American Indian men in South Dakota die 15 years earlier than men elsewhere in the United States, who live to an average age of 71.66. American Indian women here live an average of 66.07 years, or nearly 14 years fewer than the national average.
Diabetes is common on the reservation, and some people live almost an hour's drive from a hospital. It seems that a vast majority smoke cigarettes. Fires kill the occupants of ramshackle homes with dangerous space heaters. People freeze to death alone in the darkness in winter.
Residents of Pine Ridge are more than four times likelier than people in the rest of the country to die in car accidents; a small minority use seat belts, and alcohol plays a part in most fatal wrecks.
Since the sale of alcohol on the reservation is forbidden, many people drive across the Nebraska border to a little town called Whiteclay, where liquor stores are crowded together and old rusted cars being stocked with liquor to take back to the reservation cause traffic jams.
Gene Thin Elk, an American Indian cultural adviser at the University of South Dakota and the leader of an alcoholism treatment program, said that there were some narrow, twisting roads on the plains that had become death traps for people who drink and drive.
"If you put up a wooden white cross for everyone that was killed on some of these roads," Mr. Thin Elk said, "it would look like a white picket fence for miles."
Mr. Thin Elk, whose Red Road to Recovery program has been used to help American Indians in 45 states and in Canada, said programs designed for other races often lost something in the translation for American Indians.
Even the use of the language differs in important ways, he said, when language, for Indians, shapes spiritual feelings and notions of wholeness. "When we meet someone, we say, 'Hello, cousin,' or 'Hello, Grandfather,' " Mr. Thin Elk said. "And this is not merely symbolic, but a reminder that we have a family."
The name of Mr. Thin Elk's program recalls the ancient meaning of two choices for native people: the black road, which leads to despair and death, and the red road, which leads to peace and harmony.
"Our trouble has been looking outward for solutions," said Mr. Thin Elk, 45, whose drinking cost him a marriage, but who said he had been sober for 17 years. "As a result, our people become lonely inside and disconnected with their people and customs."
Mr. Kills Right, who is unemployed, like more than half the Pine Ridge population, sat at a kitchen table in a modest ranch house built by the Government, with the winds howling outside and a dog barking under the stars.
"I had been to a white man's alcoholism treatment center at 16," said Mr. Kills Right, his jet black hair pulled back into a pony tail, his gaze intense and his fists clenched. "They had us do things like dance to Richard Simmons videos. They had us exercise to these songs I didn't know -- 'Sweating to the Oldies' -- that's what they called it."
A week after leaving the center, he was drinking again. He has been in jail dozens of times, usually for public drunkenness, sometimes for beating up white men.
It was a white man who pushed his mother through a window. And every time he saw a white man, he saw the face of her killer.
The Ampetu Luta Otipi treatment program, he said, was starkly different from the other alcoholism center.
"It felt like home," he said.
As he talked about his problems with workers at the center, they walked in the woods, meditated, prayed. They urged him to release his hatred against white people, against himself.
"Inside the sweat lodge, man, it felt like the safest place in the world," he said. "I cried. And I prayed. I said I don't want to drink no more. I don't want to feel bad no more. I want to prove I can be a good person. I cried and I cried hard."
These days, he said, he feels better than he knew possible. The medicine man, Mr. Two Dogs, and his wife, Ethleen Two Dogs, who is director of Ampetu Luta Otipi, have watched over him.
He said he no longer craved alcohol. One night, he sipped from a bottle of cola and filled out a job application to be a custodial worker at Pine Ridge Hospital.
"Now I am happy that I am here," Mr. Kills Right said. "I am grateful that I got to know who I am."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Debt Ratings Of 3 Nations In Asia Cut

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Asia's economic crisis deepened yesterday as one of the world's largest credit-rating agencies downgraded the sovereign debt of South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand to "junk" status, seriously impairing the countries' ability to raise the money needed to work through the region's wrenching downturn.
The downgrades from Moody's Investors Services Inc. hurt financial markets through most of Asia and helped push Japanese stocks to the lowest level since July 1995, but the worst damage was inflicted in South Korea, where stocks tumbled nearly 7 percent in early trading today and the currency, the won, tumbled nearly 15 percent, reaching a record low of nearly 2,000 to the dollar. 
 Those drops came after South Korean stocks fell 1.2 percent yesterday while the won fell 9.2 percent as news of the downgrades was first absorbed.
The reverberations from South Korea spilled into other Asia markets this morning, with stocks in Malaysia and the Philippines down nearly 2 percent. Markets in Hong Kong, Singapore and Indonesia were little changed.
In issuing the downgrades, Moody's said the region's prospects were further threatened by severe financial problems in Japan.
If Japan's economy was more robust, it might be able to play a stronger role in resolving the Asian turmoil. But, Moody's said, because Japan is also flailing, its consumers cannot provide a lift to Southeast Asian exports and its banks cannot increase the lending that is badly needed throughout the region.
Despite widespread relief that the International Monetary Fund and other international lenders have negotiated bailout packages with some countries, including South Korea, the downgrades are a numbing reminder that the troubles of Southeast Asia have deep roots and will not disappear soon.
More ominous, the downgrades mean the specter of wide-ranging and potentially disastrous defaults loom closer in a region that has gone from economic darling to financial pariah in a breathtakingly short period.
"One of the key things we have to recognize is that as they recover and try to issue new debt, these countries will be limited in the markets into which they can sell," said David Durrant, an analyst with IDEA, a financial consulting firm in New York.
The downgrades had been expected, but since the investment guidelines of most money managers prohibit them from holding junk-rated debt, the change in ratings caused a selloff of the debt yesterday.
The lowered ratings also mean that these big investors will not be buying new issues of such debt. South Korea, for one, had planned to issue $9 billion in new sovereign debt in January, but that plan is now threatened by questions over who would buy the securities and whether the interest rates would be prohibitively expensive for South Korea.
Moreover, while Moody's and other ratings agencies had issued less severe downgrades as the Asian crisis unfolded, this is the first time Moody's jointly downgraded a handful of countries in the region. Moody's also mildly downgraded Malaysia yesterday, while affirming ratings for China and Hong Kong.
To compound the pain, Moody's also lowered ratings on the corporate debt of banks, financial services concerns and other formerly blue-chip borrowers in South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand. Those actions included downgrading 5 Indonesian state banks; 11 Thai banks and financial services companies, and 20 Korean banks.
The Standard & Poor's Corporation, another large rating agency, added to the gloom by cutting South Korea's long-term foreign currency rating to junk status, saying that the country's liquidity position was "among the worst of rated sovereigns" and that the "external liabilities of the banking sector are twice the sector's external assets."
Although the world of debt ratings may seem arcane, the impact of a major downgrade is swift, unforgiving and very real. In much the same way that homeowners might have to cut back on groceries or scrimp on heating bills if forced to pay a higher interest rate on a mortgage, a country or a corporation is hurt when borrowing becomes more expensive. But such rate increases occur on a far-bigger scale and can quickly translate into defaults, bankruptcies, business closings and lost jobs.
The Korea Development Bank, the largest state-owned bank, recently canceled a $2 billion bond offering when it became apparent that potential investors would demand an interest rate of as much as 11 percent. But that rate, which seemed Draconian just a few weeks ago, now looks relatively cheap.
After the ratings cuts were announced, the interest rate on the Korea Development Bank's existing bonds due in 2006 shot up to about 12.7 percent, compared with about 11 percent on Friday. Some of the bank's bonds due in 2001 traded yesterday with interest rates ranging from 14.7 percent to 15.7 percent.
Even relative optimists have been quieted as Asia's financial drama plays out. Nancy Kimelman, chief economist for Thomson Financial Services Company, a Boston advisory firm, said she regarded the Asian situation as "guardedly good" because of the I.M.F.'s involvement, but, she added, "we haven't begun to see the termites in the woodwork."
Ms. Kimelman said she was particularly concerned about nonperforming loans, or those for which borrowers have stopped making payments. She said by some estimates as much as one-third of all loans in the region were nonperforming. Analysts said that in China alone, about 20 percent of all public and private loans were nonperforming.
Japan is by far the biggest source of loans to Asia, and defaults in the region pose the most dire threat to that country. Although only partial information is available, it appears that about half of all external debt in Southeast Asia is held by the Japanese, with a much smaller portion, between 10 percent and 20 percent held by lenders in the United States, according to Moody's.
Big American banks, with the exception of Citicorp, have a limited lending presence in Asia but offer only scattered disclosure about their exposure there. None of the banks would comment yesterday about their stance on reworking bad loans if Asia's economies deteriorated further and defaults increased. But even if overall exposure is limited, there are big loans in Asia that are proving troublesome for American banks.
For example, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the largest American bank, has a complex $600 million loan to the South Korean consumer electronics giant Hyundai Electronics Industry. The loan was described as "troubled" by bankers who have done business with the company; these bankers insisted on anonymity. Chase declined to comment.
One of the most difficult challenges facing those trying to rework problem debt in Asia is the number and diversity of lenders and governments involved. In the Latin American debt crisis of the 1980's, the lenders were mainly large United States banks. Lenders in Asia today include banks as well as mutual funds like those of the Fidelity Investments unit of the FMR Corporation.
Some analysts said the crisis was still in its infancy. "Our argument is that six to nine months from now we will still be very much in the middle of this," Mr. Durrant of IDEA said. "People view the worst as being over, but we think it's still early stage."

SECTION: Section D; Page 4; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 799 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Next South Korean Leader Concedes Jobs Will Be Lost

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Kim Dae Jung, the President-elect, partly reversed himself on Monday, conceding that workers at South Korean companies facing bankruptcy might lose their jobs.
Mr. Kim's changed stance seemed intended to appease foreign investors who fear that the pro-labor policies he championed to win the election last week could undermine the International Monetary Fund's financial rescue plan for South Korea. 
 Although Mr. Kim promised to support the I.M.F. plan late in the campaign, he said he preferred salary cuts instead of layoffs in any austerity measures. But the I.M.F.'s plan requires painful steps that are likely to put many debt-troubled Korean companies out of business. By some estimates, a million workers could lose their jobs.
"When businesses cannot save themselves from bankruptcy by reducing salaries, layoffs are inevitable," the President-elect said in a meeting Monday with David A. Lipton, the United States Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, who was here to discuss the South Korean financial crisis.
The meeting came against a backdrop of further deterioration in South Korea's economy and financial markets, as Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Services Inc. downgraded the nation's debt rating below investment grade, to junk bond status. Such downgrading make it far more difficult and expensive for South Korea to borrow.
Indeed, the main stock market index tumbled 7.50 percent, or 29.70 points at the close of trading today, to 366.36, after a 1.2 percent decline on Monday with the downgrading news. Stocks have lost more than 75 percent of their value in dollar terms so far this year.
The South Korean currency, the won, hemorrhaged further in midday trading, falling 12.68 percent to 1,964 to the dollar, compared with 1,710 on Monday and 1,550 on Friday. By comparison, it took 841 won to buy a dollar a year ago.
Seoul, fearing a default on its international debt that officials think would be catastrophic for the economy, would like expedited delivery of all $57 billion in loans that the I.M.F. has designated for relief. But the United States, the most influential member of the fund, has resisted that.
Mr. Lipton told the President-elect that his country's own rescue efforts should be stronger, according to Chang Che Shik, an economic adviser to Mr. Kim, who attended the meeting. Mr. Chang, a member of the South Korean Parliament, said the American official did not offer specific proposals. and Mr. Lipton could not be reached for comment.
In today's issue of The Chosun Ilbo, Mr. Kim, addressing a meeting of party officials on Monday, was quoted as saying, "We don't know whether we would go bankrupt tomorrow or the day after tomorrow. I can't sleep since I was briefed. I am totally flabbergasted."
A sense that other changes may be forthcoming to strengthen the aid package for South Korea was heightened not only by Mr. Lipton's arrival here, but also by that of Hubert Neiss, chief negotiator for the I.M.F. in the bailout agreement. Mr. Neiss said only that he was "working with authorities on the program."
An official at the South Korean central bank said Monday that usable foreign-exchange reserves were down to about $7 billion and that about $10 billion worth of debt denominated in foreign currency was payable by the end of this month.
The figures for both reserves and debt were lower than what Seoul had been reporting until now because some of the foreign exchange -- including $3.5 billion received from the I.M.F. since Friday -- had been used to pay down debt.
The central bank official said South Korea expected to receive $2 billion from the Asian Development Bank and perhaps $3 billion from the World Bank before the end of the month. In addition, he said, the maturity dates on some of the $10 billion due to foreign banks would be extended. That should allow the Koreans to avoid defaulting this month. But it would leave them with a few billion dollar of reserves in January, a dangerously low level, and more debt coming due then.
Seoul has been planning to raise money by issuing $10 billion in bonds. But with those bonds now carrying a junk rating, it will be much more difficult for the Government to find buyers, and it will have to offer very high interest rates to compensate for the riskiness.
To bolster its reserves to a level that can restore international confidence, Seoul is opening its markets wider to attract foreign capital.
Starting today, foreigners will be able to buy central and provincial government bonds as well as short-term corporate bonds with a maturity of less than three years.
A committee was formed on Monday to oversee the economy during the transition period until the new President takes office in February.

INTERNATIONAL A3-10
 
Clinton Urges Bosnians To Do Their Part for Peace
President Clinton urged Bosnian leaders in Sarajevo to do their part in creating peace in their war-ravaged country. He then visited a military base in Tuzla and praised American soldiers for their role as peacekeepers in an ongoing mission which he intends to extend. A1 

Czechs Are Cool on NATO
A new survey suggested that, despite the exhortations of President Vaclav Havel, fewer than half of Czechs surveyed support NATO membership for their country. The results, described by a Clinton Administration official as "not helpful," showed 42.8 percent of citizens supporting membership in the western alliance, 26.7 percent opposed and the remaining 30.5 percent undecided. A7
 
No Guest of Honor in Iraq
Iraq held a party at Saddam International Airport, closed under a United Nations embargo imposed in 1990 after the invasion of Kuwait. The festivities were planned to welcome Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, the eccentric Russian nationalist who was in Baghdad less than three weeks ago. He was expected to defy the embargo to bring a delegation from the Russian Parliament and a symbolic shipment of food and medicine. But the plane never arrived. A4
 
A Step Forward for Somalia
The leaders of rival Somali factions met in Cairo and approved a plan intended to restore a national government to Somalia for the first time since the overthrow of a dictator in 1991 gave way to civil war. Delegates representing Somalia's various clans will gather next month to choose an interim government. A3
 
Turkey Expels Greek Diplomat
The Government of Turkey said it was expelling a Greek diplomat accused of spying. Greek officials denied the charges and said they would expel a Turkish diplomat in retaliation. Turkish newspapers reported that the Greek diplomat had been caught photographing military bases and seeking information deemed of use to Kurdish rebels. A5
 
No Indictment of Italy's Prodi
An Italian judge declined to indict Prime Minister Romano Prodi for abuse of office in the 1993 sale of Cirio-Bertolli, a food company, when he ran Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale, a huge state holding company. A prosecutor said that the company had been sold at an artificially low price. Mr. Prodi has always defended his innocence. (AP)
 
Five Charged in Israel
Five Israelis were charged with negligent homicide in the construction of a footbridge that collapsed July 14 at the opening ceremony of the Maccabiah Games, a Jewish Olympic-style sporting event, killing four Australian athletes. The engineer who designed the bridge, two contractors involved in its construction, the director of a company involved in staging the event and the chairman of the Maccabiah organizing committee were all indicted. (AP)
 
NATIONAL A12-16
 
9 Charged With Smuggling Mexican Laborers to U.S.
Federal officials announced that they had broken a conspiracy in which Americans recruited hundreds of illegal Mexican workers and smuggled them into the United States to work in a T-shirt factory in Georgia. Officials from the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the Justice Department said they had indicted nine members of the ring. Federal officials said hundreds of Mexican workers, most of them unmarried young men, were smuggled across the border in at least the last three years. A1
 
F.D.A. Approves Baldness Drug
The Food and Drug Administration announced that it had given Merck & Company permission to sell a drug that, experiments show, either promoted the growth of hair or at least stopped its loss in 83 percent of men who took it. But the pill, which will be marketed as a prescription medicine under the brand name Propecia, can cause birth defects, blocking approval for women, and it carries a slight risk of impotence in men. It is useful only for the genetic condition known as male pattern baldness and it must be taken once a day, every day, for the rest of a bald man's life. A1
 
Vietnam Pullout Was Planned
Declassified Pentagon documents may renew the argument over whether President John F. Kennedy would have pulled United States forces out of Vietnam. The documents show that shortly before President Kennedy was assassinated, the nation's top military leaders were going forward with the President's plan to withdraw United States advisers from Vietnam. No one will ever know whether these plans would have been carried out had Kennedy lived. The United States had 16,300 advisers in South Vietnam at the time. By the end of 1968, it had more than 500,000 soldiers in the country. A12
 
Kaczynski Jury Chosen
Nine women and three men were selected as jurors in Sacramento, Calif., to determine whether Theodore J. Kaczynski was the Unabomber and, if he was, whether he should be put to death. The jurors are anonymous by order of the judge. A12
 
Indictment in Delaware Murder
A Delaware grand jury indicted a lawyer, Thomas J. Capano, formally accusing him of murdering the governor's scheduling secretary in June 1996. Mr. Capano, 48, has been held without bail in solitary confinement since his arrest on Nov. 12. Two of his brothers, Louis Capano Jr. and Gerard Capano, gave statements to the authorities leading to his arrest on a charge he murdered his mistress, Anne Marie Fahey. (AP)
 
Stampede at Used Car Sale
A promotion at an auto dealership in Hudson, Ohio, that offered to sell used cars as cheap as $5 ended with fistfights and several minor injuries when desperate customers, some of whom had waited overnight, stormed the lot. (AP)
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6
 
State Agrees to Purchase Major Tract in Adirondacks
Gov. George E. Pataki announced that the state has reached a landmark agreement to purchase nearly 15,000 acres of Adirondack wilderness that the Whitney family had planned to develop, while also protecting another tract twice that size for 10 years. The $17.1 million deal opens a pristine stretch of forests, streams and lakes -- including Little Tupper Lake, regarded by naturalists as one of the region's jewels -- to the public for the first time since William C. Whitney, the industrialist, bought the land for a family retreat a century ago. A1
 
Schools Still Run on Coal
More than a year after voters authorized the state to spend $125 million to replace 100 antiquated coal furnaces in schools, most of them located in New York City, not a single boiler has been converted to oil or gas. Officials from the New York State Power Authority said the designing and engineering had been time-consuming and cumbersome, and that the first 22 schools would be weaned off coal in time for next winter. Six hundred items of Kennedy-era memorabilia will go on the auction block at the Park Avenue Armory March 18 and 19. Guernsey's, the small auction house conducting the sale, is billing the auction of Kennedy artifacts as second only to that of the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis estate sale at Sotheby's this year, which was valued at $34.4 million for the 1,200 lots sold. A woman who was injured when balloons went out of control at the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade has regained consciousness after having spent nearly a month in a coma, her lawyer said. B3

Asian Debt Downgraded

HEADLINE: T-Shirt Company Is Charged In Plot to Smuggle Mexicans

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Federal officials announced today that they had broken up a conspiracy in which Americans recruited scores of illegal Mexican workers and smuggled them into the United States to work in a T-shirt factory in Georgia.
Officials from the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the Justice Department said they had indicted nine members of a smuggling ring, including Fred Lee Parrish, the president of Atlantic Finishing Inc., the American manufacturing company that agents said was importing the illegal workers. 
 Federal officials said that Mexican workers, most of them unmarried young men, were smuggled across the border over at least the last three years to work for Atlantic Finishing but that they did not know precisely how many.
The indictment said each Mexican paid the smugglers $1,000 each to be brought across the border and sent to Georgia.
Federal agents said the case was the first in which they had charged a company with conspiracy for bringing illegal workers from Mexico to a specific company in the United States. They said they believed that recruitment of workers in Mexico for sweatshops in the United States was not uncommon but that they had never before had evidence that linked all the pieces of such an operation.
Federal officials said they did not know how much the workers in this case had been paid or the conditions under which they worked. Those officials emphasized that the importance of the case was not to expose sweatshop conditions, but to expose business that trafficked in humans.
Mr. Parrish, reached at his home tonight in Chattanooga, Tenn., said of the charges, "They're totally false. Other than that, I can't say anything else."
Atlantic Finishing is based in Trenton, Ga., just across the state line from Chattanooga, and has a second plant in nearby Henagar, Ala. The company makes T-shirts for wholesalers, but the Government would not disclose the names of the company's customers beyond saying they had sold their wares to nationally known retailers.
Bill Marshall, president of the Chamber of Commerce in Dade County, Ga., where the plant is situated, said the company contracted with Kmart, among other retailers. He said that the plant had employed as many as 200 people, making it the county's second-largest employer but that in recent years it had had trouble finding people to sew. Mr. Marshall said employment was now down to about 50 people.
The case provided a rare window for law enforcement agents to observe the traffic in low-skill, low-wage workers, their recruitment, their being smuggled across the border and hidden in homes and motels and their transport across the South and their employment at substandard wages.
"We rarely have an opportunity to see the spectrum from start to finish of economic activity and the social pressures that exist in this country that serve to create the phenomenon that we are all so familiar with," said John J. Kelly, United States Attorney for the district of New Mexico, who announced the indictments in a conference-call news conference originating in Albuquerque.
Mr. Kelly said the case illustrated the basic law of demand and supply -- demand, in this case, for U.S. companies to manufacture goods cheaply to compete with those from overseas. He said the situation "has the effect of luring and recruiting Mexican and Latin American nationals across the international border into the United States."
Officials in the Union of Needletrade, Industrial and Textile Employees, the nation's largest union of garment workers, said they were unfamiliar with Atlantic Finishing, but they said many apparel factories employed illegal aliens.
Harris Raynor, the union's Atlanta-based assistant director for the southern region, said: "It's our belief that this kind of case is only the tip of the iceberg. In the current economic situation, the pressure on manufacturers to provide low-cost goods encourages sweatshop situations."
Mr. Raynor blamed the competitive economic market and American trade agreements for encouraging such activity.
"Ultimately," Mr. Raynor said, "if retailers don't take responsibility along with consumers for policing these issues, and as long as our Government -- through programs like Nafta, with no worker or environmental protections -- keeps pushing the edge of the economic envelope, we will see more and more of these situations."
Federal agents were tipped off to the ring a year ago, when they stopped a Ford van crammed with 11 illegal aliens at a checkpoint near Hatch, N.M., about 40 miles north of El Paso.
The investigation that ensued was labeled "I-25 Confederation/Dixie Junction," referring to the interstate that many immigrants travel north through New Mexico, and involved agents from several offices, including the Border Patrol, the Internal Revenue Service and the United States Marshal's Office.
Once the workers for Atlantic Finishing reached Albuquerque, they were housed and smuggled east along Interstate 40 through Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas, agents said.
William Veal, chief of the border patrol for the El Paso section of the border, said that his agents had caught 61,000 illegal immigrants last year crossing the border into New Mexico and that many of them were headed for the "interior" of the United States, suggesting that work was available for them.
"Make no mistake about the people involved," Mr. Veal said of the current case. "They are involved in the business of exploitation." He called this an example of the increasing sophistication of smugglers, who are ever more eager to supply American companies with low-wage workers.
"I've never seen a case that took people from recruitment to a pre-determined destination with jobs lined up," Mr. Veal said.
Officials said their investigation included wiretaps and undercover agents.
The indictment said Mr. Parrish, 49, recruited the workers and paid others who actually smuggled them across the border. It said the company hired them under false names and instructed them into how to fill out employment documents using assumed names.
The Chattanooga Region Manufacturers' Directory for 1997 said the company was established in 1987 and employed 160 workers in 40,000 square feet of space.
Mr. Parrish was arrested on Thursday at his factory in Trenton and released on bond. He was charged with conspiracy to transport and harbor illegal aliens, which carries a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison and a fine of $250,000.
The maximum fine for the company, also named as a defendant, is $500,000. His relatives said he was to appear in court in New Mexico on Dec. 29.
In addition to Mr. Parrish, those indicted were: Barbara Lee Blevins of Henagar, Ala.; Linda Sue Barrett of Trenton, Ga.; Saul Resendiz-Cortes of Dalton, Ga.; Esau Ocampo-Cortes of Dalton, Ga.; Abisneigo Resendiz-Cortes of Trenton, Ga.; Rachel Resendiz of Dalton, Ga.; Josie Reyes of Las Cruces, N.M., and Francisco Lopez-Garcia of Rodey, N.M.
They were all charged with conspiracy to transport and harbor illegal aliens, and some face additional charges. Some are Americans, some are illegal aliens and some are legal permanent residents.

HEADLINE: New Poll Finds Czechs' Support for NATO Stays Below 50%

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Fewer than half the Czechs support NATO membership for their country, even though President Vaclav Havel has often spoken about the importance of the Western alliance, according to a survey released here today.
The survey suggests that Czechs are more concerned with their economic well-being, which they feel is threatened by domestic political upheavals, than with any external threat that NATO is intended to thwart. 
 This was the third of four surveys this year by the Factum polling company that showed less than 50 percent support for membership in the alliance; today's results showed 42.8 percent.
The results, which a Clinton Administration official described today as "not helpful," came two months after Washington told the Czech Government that it was dissatisfied with its preparations for NATO.
Enthusiasm for NATO membership has been muted in the Czech Republic all along, and lagged behind the level of support in the two other Central European countries, Poland and Hungary, that have been invited to join.
The Clinton Administration considers the embrace of the three formerly Communist countries by NATO as the centerpiece of its European policy but has been nervous about the lethargic attitude in the Czech Ministry of Defense. This has been particularly difficult for the Administration to deal with because Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who was born in Czechoslovakia, has made no secret of her aspirations for the Czech Republic.
During several visits by high-level Pentagon officials in October, the Government was told to sharpen its preparation for membership. Debate on the expansion of NATO began in the United States Senate in the fall, and the issue is expected to be voted on next spring. A two-thirds majority is necessary for passage in the Senate, and approval by the parliaments of the 15 other NATO members is also needed before enlargement can move ahead.
Administration officials warned the Czechs that tepid public opinion and an ill-prepared military would not help their cause in the Senate.
To please the Administration, the Government of Vaclav Klaus, who was forced to resign as Prime Minister last month, increased military spending this fall. The Defense Ministry also made personnel changes.
But Mr. Klaus and his other ministers rarely discussed the importance of NATO with the public.
The results of today's survey showed that President Havel, virtually the only passionate proponent of NATO membership among Czech officials, has had little impact on public opinion. Jan Herzmann, managing director of Factum, said in an interview today that the results reflected "lack of discussion of NATO."
Those who remain undecided are still a substantial group -- 30.5 percent -- and 26.7 percent said they were opposed to the expansion, Mr. Herzmann said. The margin of sampling error for all four polls is plus or minus 2 percent.
A survey conducted in the spring showed peak support of 50.1 percent, Mr. Herzmann said. A survey in April showed 39.9 percent support, and in June support dipped to a low of 37.4 percent.
In a recent interview the Deputy Defense Minister, Jaromir Novotny, said: "For the first time in this century, the geographical position of the Czech Republic is to our advantage. People feel safe."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Technology Stock Rebound Helps Stop Four-Day Slide
Stocks in the United States ended higher for the first time since Dec. 16 despite fears about the consequences of Asia's worsening financial crisis. Renewed interest in technology stocks and buying related to a number of new corporate takeover deals helped arrest the market's decline. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 63.02 points, to 7,819.31. The Nasdaq composite index, heavily weighted with technology stocks, rose 7.32 points, or half of 1 percent, to 1,532.06, led by a 2 percent gain in Intel. But the company's shares are still down 29 percent from their Aug. 20 peak. Page D8.
 
In Japan, stocks fell to the weakest level since July 1995 yesterday on growing alarm over the economic frailties in the country and broader Asia, particularly the threat of defaults on debts that could hurt Japanese banks. Financial markets in Japan are closed today for a national holiday. D4.
 
Korean Leader Now Sees Layoffs
Kim Dae Jung, the President-elect of South Korea, partly reversed himself and conceded that workers in companies facing bankruptcy might lose their jobs. Mr. Kim's changed position seemed intended to appease foreign investors who feared that his pro-labor policies would subvert the I.M.F.'s rescue plan for South Korea. D4.
 
Luxury goods makers have been severely hurt by the problems in Asia, which up until a few months ago was a major source of demand among the affluent for items ranging from Clergerie shoes to Luis Vuitton handbags. While luxury sales in Tokyo have remained mostly steady, sales in the rest of Asia have ranged from spotty to downright miserable over the last few months. Shares of Gucci, maker of the dress at left, have fallen 45 percent since June. B7.
 
28th Acquisition for Tyco
Acquiring companies almost as fast as others have been shedding them, Tyco International agreed to buy the medical products unit of American Home Products for $1.77 billion in cash. It was the 28th acquisition announced or completed this year by Tyco. D2.
 
American International Group, seeking to increase sales to individual customers in the United States and Latin America, said it would purchase American Bankers Insurance Group for $2.2 billion. D3.
 
Nasdaq Plans New Ways to Trade
Investors would have new ways to buy and sell stocks under a plan filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the National Association of Securities Dealers, parent of Nasdaq. The plan, known as Next Nasdaq, would mark the latest in a series of changes to sweep over the Nasdaq market, home to the stocks of many small companies. D2.
 
Merck's Baldness Drug Approved
The Food and Drug Administration gave Merck & Company permission to sell Propecia, which experiments show promoted growth of hair or stopped hair loss in 83 percent of men who took it. A1.
 
French Cousin for Coke's Fanta
Coca-Cola is purchasing Orangina, the carbonated orange soft drink made by Pernod-Ricard of France for $840 million, the first major acquisition for the company since Douglas Ivestor became chief executive two months ago. Orangina, less sweet than Coke's Fanta brand, has been a strong rival to the leading soft-drink maker in the French market but is not widely sold in the North American market. D3.

Big Stakes in Box Office Madness
Hollywood's emphasis on making a film a success in its first weekend at the box office may seem like madness. The economics of marketing, however, now powerfully favors nationwide openings in thousands of theaters instead of gradually building a movie's following a few cities at a time. E1.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 2; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk

LENGTH: 2232 words

HEADLINE: London Pubs Sip The Tonic Of Youth

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
WITH platform shoes, warm-up pants, a head wrap and a tie-dyed T-shirt knotted at the waist, the goateed and mustachioed waiter at the Engineer, one of London's new-wave pubs, was making a fashion statement aimed directly at his customers.
On a mild evening, the street in front of the pub in Primrose Hill was jammed with young people drinking their pints and chardonnays. Inside, waiters and waitresses were rushing or sauntering through the dining room carrying the most unpublike food: not a cheese roll in sight, but plenty of grilled chicken, polenta and fish cakes with Thai seasoning, as well as a curious combination of watermelon chunks and feta cheese. 
 The chef, it turned out, was an American -- Robert Greenway, from Philadelphia -- but meals at five similar pubs proved that the nationality of the cook was of no importance: London's hip young chefs are trying a little bit of everything, from Greece and China to India and the United States, with a bit of kangaroo thrown into the mix.
In other words, modern British. The working man used to nursing a pint of ale at a grotty pub with sticky carpets and soot-covered ceilings is finding that the carpets are new, the ceilings painted and in his place are young men in double-breasted pinstripes or torn T-shirts (sometimes on Rollerblades) and women in minimalist granny dresses. In London-speak the gastro-pub has been taken over by trustafarians: rich young people dressed down or up. The Time Out Guide to Eating and Drinking in London reports: "The pub revolution has swept through the capital with such speed it's not uncommon to find distressed pubgoers returning from holiday to find their old local no longer looking local. Someone has put up a blackboard wine list where the dartboard used to be, the new landlord is half the age of the previous one, and the place is now full of the sort of people that swore they'd never be seen dead in a pub."
Bad bangers and mash and soggy steak-and-kidney pie are things of the past, beaten down by Mediterranean, Pacific Rim and fusion cooking.
The word on the street is that hotels and fancy restaurants are having trouble finding help, as young chefs have been choosing to cook in their own informal surroundings instead of spending years in someone else's kitchen.
No one knows how many of London's 6,000 pubs qualify as gastro, but politics has played a significant role in their rejuvenation.
In 1988, the Government ruled that a few large breweries owned too many pubs, and those that had more than 2,000 in Britain were forced to sell half of the number over 2,000 by the end of 1992. It was the middle of a recession, and real estate prices were low, so there were a lot of good buys.
Today, the pubs that were sold off are owned by individuals and pub operating companies, and they are changing the ambiance rapidly. Even those pubs still owned by breweries are hiring managers who know something about good food (though the selection of beers may be limited to the brewery brands). Along with the sell-off, the opening hours for pubs were extended.
The Government's deaccession decision came at just the right moment in British food history.
During the previous 10 years, British chefs had begun to throw off their reputation for boring, overcooked nursery food and had taken their places in the culinary firmament with pricey, world-class restaurants. Now, they were ready to improve the lot of those more or less well off.
Pubs for lease or sale in areas that were being gentrified, like Notting Hill, northwest of Kensington Gardens, were just the ticket for young chefs who could not afford the $150,000 it takes to open a restaurant from scratch. Pubs come with bars, tables and chairs and some sort of kitchen, even if all it was ever used for was heating up frozen steak-and-kidney pies.
For around $45,000, David Eyre, a self-taught chef, and his partner, Michael Belbin, took over an 1890's Victorian pub and opened the Eagle, keeping the pubby look with traditional raised-pattern wallpaper, large, uncurtained windows and bare floors. The dishes and cutlery are mismatched; so are the tables and chairs.
"Seven years ago, we took a terrible risk," said Mr. Eyre, 36. "It was about the only thing we could afford. I used a credit card for a down payment, and shortly after, they took it away from me. Now it's a normal thing for people our age to get the money together and open a pub. Seven or eight years ago in the pub business, all you needed to do was serve something decent."
The standards, said Mr. Belbin, 45, "were so low because the pub was the only place you could get a drink without having to order food, so they didn't have to bother with food."
Now there is plenty of competition, and gastro-pubs are on the increase. It isn't just their food that makes them so appealing; it's their prices: half or less of what a similar meal would cost in a decent restaurant, or $35 to $40, with a glass a wine.
At the Eagle, which is on Farringdon Road in Clerkenwell, where warehouses are turning into lofts and art galleries are thriving, the accent is on the Olive Oil Belt, with the best pappa al pomodoro I have ever eaten.
The secret to this hearty tomato-bread soup is all in the kind of canned tomatoes you use, Mr. Eyre said, adding, "What we're really good at is robust, fairly crude, big-flavored food."
What none of these pubs is particularly good at is order.
Roderick Marley, a camera technician, finds the service at the Anglesea Arms near Hammersmith "quite chaotic." He remembers waiting so long for dinner that he and his companion consumed two bottles of wine. "You have to be patient, but it's very good value," he said.
The pub serves new and old-fashioned cafe food like a foie gras and pigeon terrine, grilled sardines and couscous and a quite nice polenta cake served with berry juice and ice cream.
Most pubs do not take reservations, and particularly at lunch, would-be diners cruise the room looking for empty seats at already occupied tables. Between noise from the kitchen, which is often part of the dining room, and the canned music, the decibels are pretty high. The system of ordering food at the bar and then being served at a table adds to the confusion, especially since the serving staff is not what would be called highly trained. With lots of people shouting to be heard over the din and the cloud of blue-gray smoke that hangs over the room (a growing number of pubs are either smoke-free or have no-smoking areas), those looking for a quiet leisurely meal should choose to eat elsewhere.
Seated at a table at the Anglesea Arms, Mr. Marley's wife, April, a fashion buyer for the Harvey Nichols department store, said: "We've been coming since it opened. After a hard day at work, it's certainly easier than cooking at home."
In response to the frequent complaint about reservations, the next phase in gastro-pubs has already begun: at the Engineer reservations are not only accepted but advisable. The Ladbroke Arms, which has been serving good food in Notting Hill Gate since 1990, has plans for a new dining room that will accept reservations. Does that mean the Ladbroke Arms will be just another restaurant?
"No, no," said Ian Mackenzie, who owns this and three other pubs. "I like the environment of a traditional British pub -- warm and welcoming. Pubs are inherently lovely. This is the sort of place I would take my grandmother to."
The accent at the Ladbroke is definitely Mediterranean, with a superb rendition of three Greek favorites (taramosalata, tzatziki and hummus); a meltingly warm goat cheese salad with chutney on toast and bright, crisp greens, and the very British banoffi pie, a gooey mix of toffee and banana in a fine crust. As three of us poured cream over it, we repeated the same mantra: "Ummm. I'm glad I didn't like it." And promptly polished it off.
 
PAN-FRIED CHICKEN BREASTS WITH CRISPY POLENTA, GUACAMOLE AND TOMATO SALSA
 
Adapted from the Engineer, London
 Total time: 40 minutes
 
 1 1/2 cups instant polenta
 4 tablespoons unsalted butter
 1/2 cup coarsely grated Parmigiano-Reggiano
 Salt and freshly ground black pepper
 3 small ripe avocados, skinned and pitted
 4 tablespoons lime juice
 1 small red onion, finely diced
 2 jalapeno or serrano chilies, seeded and minced
 2 tablespoons fresh coriander leaves plus 4 coriander sprigs
 1 tablespoon olive oil
 4 large chicken breasts, halved
 8 ripe plum tomatoes
 4 scallions, finely chopped
 2 large heads arugula.
1. Bring 6 cups of water to a boil. Carefully whisk in the polenta to prevent lumps from forming. Reduce the heat, and continuously stir the mixture until it thickens (just a couple of minutes). Remove from the heat, and stir in the butter and cheese. Season with salt and pepper. Spoon into a greased 9-by-13-inch baking dish, and spread evenly with a spatula. Allow to cool. Refrigerate, if making ahead.
2. For the guacamole, puree the avocados with the lime juice in a food processor. Stir in the onion, a quarter to a half of the minced chilies and the coriander leaves. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Refrigerate, if making ahead.
3. When ready to serve, heat the olive oil in a large nonstick pan. Add the chicken, skin-side down, and brown over high heat. Turn, and brown on the other side. Reduce the heat to medium-high, and cook the chicken until it is done, a total of about 20 minutes. Season with salt and pepper.
4. Meanwhile, make the salsa. Trim the tomatoes, quarter them and place in the food processor along with the coriander sprigs, scallions and the remaining minced chilies (or less to taste). Process until coarse. Season with salt and pepper.
5. When ready to brown the polenta, preheat the broiler. Turn out the polenta from its dish onto an oiled baking sheet, and place under the hot broiler until the surface begins to puff and brown, 3 to 5 minutes. The polenta can broil while chicken is cooking.
6. In center of a plate, place a pool of salsa. Place the polenta on top of the salsa. Arrange a few arugula leaves on the side; place a piece of chicken on the arugula, and top the chicken with guacamole.
Yield: 8 servings.
Note: Because of the lime juice, the guacamole will not brown, so it can be made a day ahead, along with the polenta.
 
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 555 calories, 30 grams fat, 145 milligrams cholesterol, 175 milligrams sodium, 50 grams protein, 20 grams carbohydrate.
 
PAPPA AL POMODORO
 
Adapted from the Eagle, London
Total time: 1 hour
 
 4 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil, plus additional oil for topping (optional)
 4 large cloves garlic, crushed
 1 2-pound-3-ounce can best-quality Italian tomatoes
 8 ounces stale Italian or sourdough bread, torn into 1-inch pieces
 6 cups chicken or vegetable stock
 30 or more basil leaves
 Sea salt and freshly ground black pepper.
1. Heat the olive oil in a large pot, and saute the garlic for about 30 seconds, just until it colors. Do not let it burn.
2. Add the tomatoes, and cook over medium-high heat, stirring occasionally, for 10 to 15 minutes, until the mixture thickens.
3. Add the bread and stock, and cook slowly for 30 minutes longer. The mixture should be lumpy and thick.
4. Add the basil, remove from the heat and allow to sit for at least 10 minutes. Season with salt and pepper.
5. Serve warm in winter and at room temperature in summer. Pour the soup into bowls, and top with additional oil, if desired.
Yield: 5 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 325 calories, 15 grams fat, 8 milligrams cholesterol, 745 milligrams sodium, 10 grams protein, 35 grams carbohydrate.
 
GRILLED SWORDFISH WITH PESTO-LEMON-CAPER SAUCE
 
Adapted from the Lansdowne, London
 
Total time: 25 minutes
 
 1 1/2 large bunches flat-leaf parsley
 3/4 cup extra virgin olive oil
 Juice of 1 lemon
 Grated rind from 2 lemons
 1 tablespoon Dijon mustard
 1 cup diced red onion
 2 tablespoons capers
 1/3 cup chopped cornichons
 8 anchovy fillets, dried on paper towels
 6 swordfish steaks, 1-inch-thick
 Olive oil for grilling.
1. In the bowl of a food processor, combine all of the ingredients except the swordfish and the olive oil for grilling, and process until coarsely chopped.
2. Rub the swordfish with olive oil, and grill on both sides until cooked, following the Canadian rule: measure at thickest point, and allow 8 to 10 minutes to the inch, turning once. Serve topped with the pesto-lemon-caper sauce.
Yield: 6 servings.
Note: This dish is also delicious with grilled chicken breasts.
 
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 550 calories, 35 grams fat, 95 milligrams cholesterol, 635 milligrams sodium, 45 grams protein, 5 grams carbohydrate.

HEADLINE: Middle-Class Education

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Joseph L. Bruno, the New York Senate majority leader, wants to return New York State's 1998 budget surplus in the form of an array of tax cuts estimated at close to $1 billion (news article, Dec. 17). Better Mr. Bruno look to plug a wallet-drainer that affects thousands of college students and middle-income parents: skyrocketing public college tuition costs. 
 New York public tuition costs have risen by more than 150 percent in the last decade, the fastest growing in the country, while critical financial aid has been whittled down. If Mr. Bruno really wants to improve New York's economy and quality of life, he should seek to invest the surplus in education, the best bet for a better future, by reducing the cost of higher education.
 
MICHAEL LIVERMORE
New York, Dec. 17, 1997
 
The writer is chairman, New York Public Interest Research Group.

HEADLINE: Talk of Japan Intervention Depresses Dollar

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar declined against the yen yesterday on speculation that the Japanese central bank would sell dollars to strengthen the yen in coming days, taking advantage of thin holiday trading. The dollar also eased against European currencies.
Analysts estimate that the Bank of Japan spent between $5 billion and $10 billion last week defending the yen, which is down 11.5 percent against the dollar this year. 
 "There is speculation of B.O.J. intervention over the next two, three days," said Richard Gilhooly, a strategist for Paribas Capital Markets. "They can push the market any way they want in thin trading. So for people holding dollars over the holiday, there's a risk."
While most markets will be closed tomorrow for Christmas, Japan's will remain open.
In New York trading yesterday, the dollar settled at 129.22 yen, down from 130.13 yen late Monday. The dollar cost 1.7755 German marks, down from 1.7810 marks. It declined, as well, against the British pound, which sold at $1.6656, compared with $1.6633 on Monday.
Despite yesterday's declines, many in the currency markets expect the dollar to rise because of worsening financial crises in Asia, including a severe cash shortage in South Korea and the prospect of more corporate failures in Japan.
"The bankruptcy news is bad for the yen, not to mention that Korea collapsed," said Richard Koss, market strategist at MFR Inc., a money management and consulting firm.
