HEADLINE: Chinese Democracy Campaigners Push for Free Labor Unions

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 23

 BODY:
A loose-knit group of veteran democracy advocates has started a campaign to promote independent labor unions among China's workers, who face vast layoffs as the Government strives to close money-losing enterprises.
The advocates, some in China and some in exile, hope to use Beijing's recent signing of a United Nations covenant insuring the right of workers to organize as a wedge against a Government that has suppressed all efforts to form unions outside its grip. 
 In a letter sent this week to foreign news organizations, the campaigners say workers now have a clear right to set up new unions to fight for their interests in this period of drastic downsizing, mergers and sales of state-owned industries. Currently, unions not sponsored by the Communist Party are illegal, and the Government has given no sign that it will relent, United Nations covenant or not.
The proposals in the letter go to the heart of China's most explosive political challenge: how to cope with the legions of victims as it unleashes market forces to streamline the bloated, often bankrupt Communist economy.
In recent months, there have been numerous reports of small-scale worker protests around the country over such concerns as nonpayment of wages or pensions, fear of job losses after corporate takeovers, and conflicts over dismissals and severance pay.
The dislocation of millions of industrial workers is occurring even as the growing private and semiprivate sectors bring new prosperity to millions of other Chinese -- a visible gap that only adds to the tensions.
"Workers in state-owned enterprises, especially, should immediately form their own unions to monitor their leaders and prevent leaders from engaging in bribery or stealing public properties," said the letter, signed by four leaders of the 1979 "Democracy Wall" movement, each of whom has served time in prison. "Only by depending on ourselves can we fight those who punish workers arbitrarily or fire workers without reason."
In a telephone interview from Cambridge, Mass., Wang Xizhe, one of the signers, said: "China's workers don't understand that China has agreed to this international agreement. We're going to use every method we can to educate them about it."
Mr. Wang, 49, who spent 15 years in prison for earlier pro-democracy activities, fled China last year under threat of arrest after he signed a letter calling for impeachment of President Jiang Zemin.
The agreement in question is the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights of 1966, which China's United Nations representative, Qin Huasun, signed in New York on Oct. 26, just before President Jiang visited the United States. The covenant is one of two that Washington had urged China to sign to improve its human rights record.
The covenant guarantees "the right of everyone to form trade unions and join the trade union of his choice." But the agreement adds that the right is subject to restrictions "prescribed by law and which are necessary in a democratic society in the interests of national security or public order or for the protection of the rights and freedoms of others." China could easily cite these loopholes.
Because of tight Government control of the press, few people here may learn directly about the pro-union letter, which is dated Dec. 20. But Mr. Wang said many people around China were spreading the message through the Internet and private channels. He said the group also hoped that foreign radio news broadcasters, who are widely listened to here, would take note.
Mr. Wang added that the signers were only trying to raise awareness, not organize unions, something he said workers must do themselves.
The distinction may be a crucial one for the two signers inside China, Qin Yongmin in Wuhan and Xu Wenli in Beijing, who have served long prison terms in the past. Reached by telephone today, both declined to expand on the letter. The fourth signer, Lu Siqing, lives in Hong Kong.
"Organizing a labor union is no longer an internal affair of China," Mr. Wang asserted. "It is an internationally protected right," a suggestion that the glare of global oversight might deter Government crackdowns.
In a nod to the Government's problems, the letter expresses firm support for economic restructuring and blames earlier Maoist policies for causing the current muddle. It says workers need to accept inevitable hardships to create a sounded economy and should resort to protests and strikes only as a last resort.
Official statistics put urban unemployment at less than 4 percent, but tens of millions more workers are effectively unemployed, sent home to receive perhaps $20 or $25 a month. Some bankrupt industries have failed to meet even those obligations.
Western experts say the effective rate of unemployment in many large cities ranges above 20 percent, although many former workers retain heavily subsidized housing.
The Government is struggling to build new unemployment insurance, welfare and pension programs to replace the old "iron rice bowl," the guarantee of lifelong security for state employees.
But as it tries to create a less costly safety net, the Government has also taken to hectoring workers to lower their expectations. An article last week in People's Daily, the official Communist Party paper, said laid-off workers needed to learn from the example of migrant peasants, who have flooded into cities often to perform menial jobs like collecting garbage, selling food in the street and washing windows.
"These new job explorers in the cities, these former farmers, have actually brought new concepts to urban workers who got used to eating from one big pot under the old system," the article said. "So some experts say that urban workers should learn from their rural counterparts in looking for jobs."

HEADLINE: Economic Data Suggest a Slowing Trend

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
More evidence of slackening economic growth emerged today even as the Government reported that orders for relatively costly factory goods posted the biggest gain in almost five years in November.
The surge in orders was concentrated in commercial aircraft and military hardware, produced over extended periods. But new orders for items other than transportation equipment were lower for the second consecutive month. 
 "We're going to see a profound slowing in the economy in early 1998," said Richard B. Berner, chief economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
He and other analysts said financial and economic turmoil in Asia had dimmed prospects for American exports to that region while making Asian products cheaper here.
Indeed, today's Commerce Department report of a 4.8 percent jump in orders for durable goods also showed that orders for machinery used in production, about half of which are sold abroad, fell 2 percent in November after a 2.1 percent October decline.
This category, which excludes planes and the military, is considered a good gauge of corporate America's view of business prospects.
Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, said the November decline in orders for capital goods "may be among the first signs that the Asian crisis is hitting home."
In another sign of weakness, the University of Michigan told subscribers to its survey of consumer confidence that it had lowered the index reading for December to 102.1 from an initial 103, deepening the already sharp drop from 107.2 in November. The expectations component, now 96.1, has been particularly weak in the last two months.
In a second report by the Commerce Department, the Government lowered the economy's growth in the third quarter to an annual rate of 3.1 percent. This is still a bit higher than most analysts think is sustainable but less than the 3.3 percent pace calculated last month and the 3.5 percent initially estimated in October.
The reduction in the growth rate of the gross domestic product -- the total output of goods and services within the nation's borders -- reflected a trimming of most major components.
For example, personal consumption, which accounts for two-thirds of the nation's $7.2 trillion annual G.D.P., grew at a 5.6 percent rate, a still-torrid pace but down from the 5.8 percent estimated a month earlier.
Corporate profits, however, were revised higher. The increase in profits from current production for the summer quarter is now put at $32.2 billion, or 4 percent, instead of a gain of $21.1 billion, or 2.7 percent, initially reported last month. The bulk of the revision reflected higher foreign earnings, initially estimated as far weaker.
"While profits are likely to slow in coming quarters -- both domestic and foreign -- a collapse is unlikely as long as domestic growth holds up," said James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at Morgan Guaranty.
The tally of orders for durable goods -- everything from camcorders to artillery pieces, all intended to last at least three years -- showed a 20.3 percent advance for transportation equipment. Without that, orders would have declined two-tenths of 1 percent.
Orders for primary metals climbed 3.2 percent last month but those for electronic and electrical equipment were virtually unchanged and those for industrial machinery and equipment dropped 1.6 percent.
Orders for military goods, much of them also counted in transportation, leaped 24.9 percent, more than offsetting a 13.5 percent October drop.
Shipments of durable goods eased four-tenths of 1 percent in November, to $182.9 billion, the third decline in four months, the report showed. Unfilled orders rose 2.4 percent, the sixth increase in seven months.

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "Real Economic Growth" tracks the annual rate of change in the value of the gross domestic product, based on seasonally and inflation-adjusted figures for the quarter, from the second quarter of 1993 through the third quarter of 1997. "Durable Goods Orders" tracks manufacturers' total new orders for durable goods, in billions of dollars, seasonally adjusted, from June 1996 through November 1997. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Merrill Settles With County for $1.9 Million

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., Dec. 23

 BODY:
Merrill Lynch agreed today to pay $1.9 million to settle a securities fraud class-action suit brought on behalf of Orange County, Calif., bondholders in the wake of county bankruptcy in 1994.
The suit charged Merrill and other firms with misleading investors about the financial health and risks of the county investment pool. 
 Orange County suffered the nation's largest municipal bankruptcy, accumulating roughly $1.6 billion in losses by making wrong bets on the direction of interest rates, using highly leveraged transactions.
"All of the bonds in which we were involved have been fully repaid," a spokesman for Merrill Lynch said today. "It made more sense to resolve the case for a reasonable sum than to continue the expense and distraction of further litigation."
Other defendants who agreed to settle the suit and their payments included Credit Suisse First Boston, $990,000; KPMG Peat Marwick, $225,000, and Leifer Capital, $30,000.
A hearing on the settlement has been scheduled on Feb. 16 before Judge William McDonald in California Superior Court here.
The suit covers investors who purchased the bonds, notes or other securities between July 1, 1992, and Dec. 6, 1994, issued by the county or other public entities that invested in the county's investment pool.

HEADLINE: There's Been No Rush for Medical Savings Accounts, but Idea Is Gaining Favor

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Republicans believe medical savings accounts are a sensible way to cut health insurance costs for the Government and private employers, to provide more affordable coverage for those who are uninsured and to help consumers save money.
Democrats, though, see these accounts -- which involve tax-free savings and low-cost, high-deductible medical insurance -- as a tax break for the healthy and wealthy and a potential trap for unwary workers and some of the elderly. 
 Unable to resolve their differences, President Clinton and Congress agreed in 1996 to begin a four-year pilot project this year to determine how medical savings accounts would work in practice, as opposed to theory. Beginning next year, the project will be expanded to include a limited number of retirees covered by Medicare.
The test in the private market has been under way for a year, and the early returns are in. They show that far fewer people than Republicans hoped or Democrats feared have decided to participate. But there is evidence the idea may be picking up steam.
"Expectations of rapid growth may simply have been unrealistic," concluded the General Accounting Office, the auditing arm of Congress. But in a draft of a report that was sent to Congress this month but has not been made public, the auditing agency added, "Insurers indicated that sales have been steadily increasing over the past few months."
Here is how medical savings accounts work:
Consumers buy (or their employers or the Government, in the case of Medicare, pay for) relatively inexpensive medical insurance that covers them fully against very expensive illness or injury. But this medical insurance pays nothing for as much as the first $2,250 in annual medical expenses for individuals or $4,500 for families.
Edwin Hustead, an actuary here who studies medical insurance, said that the premiums for such policies were generally about 25 percent lower than premiums for conventional insurance with low deductibles or managed-care plans.
For some, the saving may be even more. Joan Jacobson, an employee benefits consultant in San Francisco, said that for a single person under 30 in her area, a high-deductible plan cost only $51 a month, 40 percent less than the $85 a month for a Blue Cross policy.
Part of the money saved from the lower premiums is placed in a tax-free account in the consumer's name, somewhat like an individual retirement account or a 401(k) retirement plan.
The money in the account can be invested and allowed to accumulate from year to year. It can be withdrawn without owing taxes to meet uncovered medical expenses -- not just doctor and hospital bills up to the deductible, but even the cost of treatments like cosmetic surgery, dental care and psychological counseling not covered by ordinary medical insurance.
Consumers can also withdraw the money for nonmedical purposes, but then it is taxed and subject to an additional 15 percent penalty.
Such accounts could be a good deal for healthy people or those affluent enough that they do not have to worry about unexpected out-of-pocket medical costs. Government statistics show that each year about 10 percent of Americans incur 70 percent of all medical expenses. Even among the elderly, 17 percent of those covered by Medicare in a typical year do not file a single claim.
But people who are less well-off could be devastated if they took the risk that they would not get sick and were hit with doctor and hospital bills that were several thousand dollars more than what had accumulated in their savings account.
And some experts in the economics of health care worry that if enough healthy people sign up for medical savings accounts, the result would be much higher premiums for people and companies that stick with ordinary insurance policies.
When lawmakers set up the test program last year, the White House feared that so many people might sign up that the Government would suffer a significant loss of tax revenue, so strict limits were imposed.
The only people eligible are those who are self-employed or who work for companies with fewer than 50 employees. The law specified that no more than 525,000 medical savings accounts would be allowed nationally in the first six months of this year.
Many fewer people than that have signed up. The Internal Revenue Service found that only 22,051 accounts had been set up by June 30. Of those, 3,670, or 17 percent, were opened by people who had not previously been insured.
The General Accounting Office found that consumers had been cautious because of "the complexity of the product and a lack of understanding" about how medical savings accounts worked. The audit also discovered that many insurance brokers and agents were not selling the policies aggressively because the sales pitch for a new product took time and because commissions on low-premium insurance are less than commissions on conventional policies.
But proponents have taken heart in the fact that twice as many accounts were opened in May and June as in the first four months of the year. Many more have been opened since then. American Banker magazine reported last month that its survey had found that about 100,000 accounts had been opened nationwide.
A spokesman at Golden Rule Insurance Company of Indianapolis, the leading underwriter of high-deductible medical insurance policies, said that its customers alone had opened 19,000 medical savings accounts this year.
The company is a big financial supporter of Republican politicians. In the 1996 election campaign, Golden Rule, its executives and its employees donated more than $480,000 to the Republican Party and Republican candidates, according to the Committee for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan watchdog group.
No one knows yet the characteristics of those who are opening the accounts -- whether they are primarily wealthy professionals, as Democrats suspect, or mostly people with modest incomes who are looking for a way to cut their insurance costs, as Republicans believe.
That will be studied, a Treasury Department official said, after 1997 income tax returns are filed in April.
One of the main Congressional advocates of medical savings accounts, Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said in an interview that he was encouraged by the pilot project.
"As is customary with any new product, the start was relatively slow," Mr. Archer said, "but demand is increasing as the sellers and the individuals covered learned more about it."
But Representative Pete Stark of California, the top Democrat on the Ways and Means panel's health subcommittee, said he expected the pilot project to be the death knell for medical savings accounts.
"It's a whacky idea," Mr. Stark said, "and they will be sold only to people who are bamboozled by slick insurance salesmen."

HEADLINE: Dime Says Bond Sale Will Reduce Earnings

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Dime Bancorp said yesterday that it would sell $1.4 billion in mortgage-backed bonds, resulting in a fourth-quarter after-tax loss of $15 million, as it moves to dispose of low-yielding investments.
The sale will reduce fourth-quarter per-share earnings by about 1 cent, a company spokesman said. 
 Proceeds from the sale will be used to pay down debt. Dime, the New York-based parent of Dime Savings Bank, also said it would repurchase three million, or 2.5 percent, of its common shares over an unspecified period.
These actions will "help us in our efforts to improve the quality of our earnings and our interest rate profile," Lawrence Toal, Dime's chief executive, said in a statement.
The $1.4 billion of bonds are part of $3.6 billion in securities Dime made available for sale. The company had no immediate plans for the remaining $2.4 billion worth of securities.
The security sales will reduce shareholder equity by about $31 million, according to Dime, one of the country's largest thrifts with $19.4 billion in assets.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices End Day Higher; Stock Loss and Asia Crisis Cited

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended slightly higher yesterday, lifted in part by a late tumble in the stock market.
Also helping bond prices were growing expectations that falling demand from Asia will slow United States economic growth. 
 "Bond investors are anticipating a slowdown," said Denny Niedringhaus, who manages $300 million of fixed-income assets at Southwest Bank of St. Louis in Clayton, Mo.
And Treasury prices continue to get a boost from international investors buying United States assets to escape shaky overseas markets, particularly in Asia.
In South Korea yesterday, stocks, bonds and the currency all plunged to record lows when the Standard & Poor's Corporation joined Moody's Investors Service in cutting the country's credit rating to below investment grade. A late drop in the Dow Jones industrial average drove some investors into the relative safety of the Treasury market.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond edged up 1/32, to 103 19/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, slipped to 5.87 percent, from 5.88 percent on Monday. In the second part of its monthly note auction, the Treasury sold the five-year notes at a yield of 5.685 percent yesterday, below the 5.694 percent yield expected. Demand was above the average of the last 10 monthly 5-year note auctions -- with more than $2,600 bid for every $1,000 of securities sold.
Some traders said the better-than-expected result was a sign of investors' confidence in current yields. "It makes me a little more optimistic on the market," said Rick Schwarz, head of government bond trading at Zions First National Bank Capital Markets in Salt Lake City.

HEADLINE: A Master's Degree in Philanthropy Teaches the Business of Doing Good

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS

 BODY:
Dwelling on matters of morals and conscience, the graduate students sat behind desks arranged in a square, perhaps so they could look one another in the eye as they parsed the Gospel of St. John.
The Bible study was not for ecclesiastical purposes, as the professor put it, but to "foster explorations of our own lives." 
 The students are learning to be professional do-gooders. If they stick with it, they will have the parchment to prove it: master's degrees in philanthropy. It is one of the fastest growing fields in academia, and more than 75 American graduate schools now offer advanced degrees in philanthropy, nearly a fivefold increase since 1990.
Most philanthropy students plan to manage nonprofit organizations or help them raise money. Other students hope to sit on boards for various good causes -- the heart fund, for example, or the local symphony. Still others hope to become teachers in the field or scholars in the general science of do-goodism.
The national big daddy of do-good research is the Indianapolis campus of Indiana University-Purdue University, which has a Center on Philanthropy with 64 faculty members from 28 academic departments and two master's degree programs.
One master's candidate, Kathy Kraus, 28, said that friends sometimes looked puzzled when she told them about her graduate work.
"They'll say, 'You're getting a master's degree in what?' " Ms. Kraus said.
It is a reaction, no doubt, repeated by more than a few parents.
But Robert Payton, the head of the Center on Philanthropy, insists that the nonprofit economy accounts for 12 percent of the American work force and demands rigorous academic examination. Besides that, Mr. Payton said, somebody has to learn how to run these nonprofit organizations.
"This is a big deal," Mr. Payton, a former president of Hofstra University, added. "What makes this intellectual set of issues less worthy of critique than politics or business?"
His ambition is to make philanthropy centers "examine the social and moral health of society."
In a study of the academic field of philanthropy, Naomi Wish, who directs the Center for Public Service at Seton Hall University in New Jersey, said that 80 percent to 85 percent of students taking such graduate courses already had jobs with nonprofit groups and many were taking courses so they could move up in the field. Although the driving force may be ambition, pay is not, Ms. Wish said, noting that jobs in the nonprofit sector generally paid two-thirds of the salaries of comparable jobs in private business.
A vast majority of philanthropic courses are designed for practical marketplace applications: how to write grants, manage a nonprofit organization and draw up a set of ethical guidelines for a board.
Ms. Wish said that these programs had helped make universities more aware of the real-life problems around them.
"Universities have long been ivory towers," she said, "and these centers have pushed them to examine the quality of life" outside the classroom walls.
Most academic philanthropic centers in the United States are financed by foundations like the Kellogg and Eli Lilly Foundations and the Pew Charitable Trusts. Some academics have raised questions about the independence of doing scholarly research on the very foundations that pay for the work. Ms. Wish's own study was financed by a Kellogg grant.
But Ellen Condliffe Lageman, an educational historian at New York University who recently completed a study of the Indiana program that was financed by Eli Lilly, said scholars of philanthropy had little choice.
"Who else is going to support it?" Ms. Lageman asked. "We're living in an age where government funding is drying up for all kinds of things."
As a formal academic study, a philanthropy program at Yale University in the 1970's was a pioneer. The Indiana program, established in 1987, was a relative latecomer.
Kathryn Stallings, a graduate of the University of Virginia, where she majored in French and anthropology, said she wanted to earn a master's in philanthropy here at Indiana before she went to medical school.
"This will help me look at the practice of medicine very differently than I might otherwise," said Ms. Stallings, a Boston native whose parents founded and operate a program to help emotionally troubled children.
"For example, what is the appropriate level of medical care that we should expect in this country?" Ms. Stallings asked. "How do we decide when to intervene in other people's lives? What is the effect on society? These are questions that people in philanthropic studies are trained to ask."
The Philanthropic Studies Library here, named in memory of Mr. Payton's sons, who died at ages 18 and 31, is stocked with books intended to promote good, from "Saving the Earth" to a biography of Florence Nightingale.
At the law school, where pictures of Dan and Marilyn Quayle, class of '74, hang in the lobby, students gathered for a class called Legal Aspects of Philanthropy, where a lecturer warned about the direction of the road paved with good intentions.
Speaking about fiduciary responsibilities and the prudent-investor rule, the lecturer, Dave Bahlmann, who is also the president of Ball State University in Muncie, Ind., noted that people on charitable boards could be sued individually.
"It's not only about doing good," Mr. Bahlmann said as the overhead projector whirred. "You must also do well."

HEADLINE: For Brilliant Brothers, Joining Mathematics Faculty Is a Quantum Leap

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
In a cluttered apartment on the West Side of Manhattan about 10 years ago, Gregory V. and David V. Chudnovsky used a homemade supercomputer to calculate pi to hundreds of millions of decimal places, an effort to make sense of the basic mathematical ratio that most school children know as 3.14. By two billion or so decimal places -- a world record at the time -- they had found no discernible pattern, so they turned their attention to other problems in number theory, mathematical physics and computers.
But another long and daunting quest by the two mathematicians has yielded better results. Two decades after leaving the Soviet Union, the Chudnovskys -- authors of scores of papers and books, theoreticians, tinkerers, freelance thinkers and devoted partners -- have finally landed faculty positions at an American university. 
 Thanks to a small group of business executives and philanthropists who banded together to raise money for them, they have joined the faculty at Polytechnic University in Brooklyn, where a supercomputer center has been established for them and they have been teaching a course on the mathematics of computer graphics.
The road from boyhood brilliance in Kiev to the faculty of a small commuter college in Brooklyn seemed at times as unpredictable as the endless digits of pi. There was the help from Andrei D. Sakharov in leaving the Soviet Union; a MacArthur Foundation grant for Gregory in 1981; years of effort and obscurity in Gregory's apartment crammed with stacks of papers and mail-order computer parts; a mix of pity and puzzlement from fellow mathematicians; a long profile in The New Yorker that brought some notice, but still no permanent jobs.
Fellow mathematicians have difficulty explaining exactly what kept the Chudnovskys from being snapped up by a top university after they arrived in the United States 20 years ago. They are widely respected by their peers, with assessments of their work ranging from solid to brilliant. In 1986, Herbert Robbins, a Columbia mathematician, wrote the National Academy of Sciences calling the Chudnovskys' difficulties "a personal and scientific tragedy."
Some have questioned whether their range of interests -- from applied physics and computers to more theoretical topics like number theory -- made them hard to place in an academic world geared to specialization. Others saw it more as a matter of personal chemistry. In any case, there was no question that the brothers were a tough pair to accommodate. Gregory has myasthenia gravis, a debilitating neuromuscular disease that keeps him in bed most of the time, making it difficult for him to carry a regular teaching load.
Moreover, the brothers were unwilling to leave New York, and insisted on being hired together. Not only does David help his brother in and out of his wheelchair and tend the computer when it breaks down, but the brothers have also been close professional collaborators since their teen-age years, anticipating each other's thoughts, completing each other's sentences, writing joint research papers.
Usually Gregory is presented as the genius. He solved Hilbert's 10th Problem (which had stumped mathematicians for more than half a century) at the age of 17, and later won the MacArthur grant. But the brothers simply say they work in close partnership.
Although each is married and they live in different boroughs -- David is in Manhattan, and Gregory has moved to Queens -- they are rarely far apart during the day. Gregory, 44, is slight and rumpled, his silver hair and beard bristling out from his thin face, his body sunk deeply into a wheelchair. David, 50, is more substantial, dressed in a white button-down shirt and tweed jacket, his gray hair closely clipped.
When the brothers arrived in the United States, they were given unpaid research titles, medical benefits and a housing subsidy from Columbia University, where they brought in millions of dollars in research grants. But their goal of becoming regular members of a university faculty with regular students proved elusive. Instead, they worked largely alone in the West Side apartment where Gregory then lived, supported by grants, consulting jobs and their wives' earnings (David's wife, Nicole Lannegrace, is a political affairs officer at the United Nations; Gregory's wife, Christine Pardo Chudnovsky, is a lawyer). They built a supercomputer from mail-order parts and pursued the patterns in pi and other projects, using a meat thermometer to make sure the machine did not overheat.
They might still be working there but for the 1992 New Yorker article about their search for pi, and the attention it drew from a few wealthy people. One was Jeffrey H. Lynford, a New York real estate executive, whose wife, Tondra, read the article aloud to him on an airplane trip to Los Angeles.
"My wife and I thought they were a resource wasting away," Mr. Lynford said. "We wondered how could we replant them, nourish them, and help them blossom."
He began to try to find faculty positions for the Chudnovskys and to raise money to endow chairs for them. He sought help from Richard Preston, who wrote the New Yorker article, and from others who had been drawn to the brothers by the article, including Mort Meyerson, chief executive of Perot Systems Corporation, and Walter F. Rosenberry 3d, a Denver philanthropist who typically supports human service organizations like women's shelters and said he had to take algebra twice to pass it.
"This is a visceral thing," Mr. Rosenberry said, adding that he liked the idea of being able to help "creative people in our overly organized society."
The brothers were surprised and moved that strangers had taken such an interest in them. "The story is how people have been willing to put in so much effort for us," Gregory said. "It's just amazing what they have done."
Despite the interest, no suitable prospects materialized until three years ago, when the chairman of the mathematics department at Polytechnic, Deane Yang, heard of the Chudnovskys' situation and called them.
The fit seemed perfect. Polytechnic was trying to build momentum. The brothers were prominent names. But there was still a hurdle: Polytechnic had little money, and its officials knew they needed to raise some before they could give the brothers endowed faculty slots. The university hoped Mr. Lynford could find it.
Mr. Lynford and some other backers put up money themselves. With Polytechnic's help, he lined up support from Borough President Howard Golden and from Brooklyn Union, which put up $100,000.
This summer they began moving boxes of computer parts to their new office in Brooklyn, and meeting with students. More than $2.5 million is now in hand, but Mr. Lynford and Polytechnic are aiming to double it. In the meantime, the brothers are writing new research proposals and teaching.
Landing the Chudnovskys is a coup for Polytechnic, as David C. Chang, its president, enthusiastically acknowledged at a dinner in their honor at the Rainbow Room this fall. "They're inspirational," he said. "They typify what our university should be. They go beyond pure science into things that help economic development. That may be less important to an Ivy League school or a comprehensive university, but for us, that is the challenge."
The Chudnovskys are equally enthusiastic. Polytechnic is not Princeton or M.I.T., but they are grateful for the positions, and comfortable with the gritty focus of the small 143-year-old commuter university, whose main campus is at Metrotech Center in Brooklyn.
"It's a university that wants to do something," Gregory explained. "The beauty of Poly is that it is a clearly defined school with a purpose."
The brothers are also taken with the students, many of them immigrants like themselves, who work full or part time and are seeking tools they will find useful on Wall Street and in industry.
"Most of the kids in Poly are working, so you not only get kids who know what they want to do, but they have a great attitude," Gregory said.
And so it was that on a Thursday evening this fall, they were conducting a computer graphics course on how to construct the mathematical models that allow the billions of bits of information representing images to be stored in powerful computers. The ideas were sophisticated, the approach down to earth.
"If you do it the stupid way, you will have to do it again," Gregory Chudnovsky warned the dozen students in the class, as David changed the slides in the overhead projector.
Gregory admits he is worn out by the teaching, but the brothers are happy. They have space. They have research support. They have students.
The students are happy, too.
Fatih Porikli, a Ph.D. student from Turkey who was drawn to the Chudnovskys' seminar by a modest flier on a bulletin board, said he had been astonished at the richness of the teaching, the brothers' ability to sketch the relations between computer vision and medieval art, bond markets and physics.
"I wasn't looking at my watch for the end of the lecture any more," he said. "These guys are the best teachers I have. I am lucky, right?"

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1114 words

HEADLINE: A Despised U.S. Envoy Stands Proud

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Dec. 20

 BODY:
After nearly five years, the United States Ambassador, Peter W. Galbraith, will leave Zagreb next month, reviled by the Croatian press, which once granted him celebrity status; under a cloud in Washington for his role in the clandestine delivery of Iranian weapons to the Bosnian Muslims, and ostracized in Government circles here as President Franjo Tudjman's most dogged critic.
In the course of his career, Mr. Galbraith, a political appointee with close ties to the Democratic Party, often chose to "make policy first and inform Washington later," in the words of a diplomat in his embassy. 
 Mr. Galbraith -- who is 45 with unruly black hair, the disheveled look of a high school English teacher and permanent half-moons under his eyes -- often speaks of his work in terms most diplomats would eschew.
"I decided from the time I came here that this was an opportunity to save lives," he said in an interview in his office, "and I would do the best I could for that goal."
Human rights officials, while praising the Ambassador for his recent calls for the return of exiled Serbs, condemn him for failing to denounce the mistreatment of the Serbs until most of them had been expelled. These critics argue that his close relationship with President Tudjman -- which earned him the nickname "the governor" -- along with his celebrity status, blinded him to the pernicious nature of Mr. Tudjman's nationalist Government until it was too late.
"He cared a lot more for Franjo Tudjman in the early days than he did for human rights," said Ivan Cicak, the head of the Croatian Helsinki Committee for Human Rights.
Mr. Galbraith disagreed with this assessment, saying he was as vigorous in pursuing human rights early in his tenure as he was later.
The political landscape changed drastically on Aug. 8, 1995, when Croatian troops, having taken the Serbian-held Krajina region in a lightning assault, began driving a quarter-million Serbs out of the country. The Ambassador, with journalists in tow, hopped on a departing tractor carrying a Serbian family along a road lined with rock-throwing Croats and angrily denounced the expulsions.
He would spend the rest of his time in Croatia leading a quixotic campaign for the return of the approximately 500,000 ethnic Serbs driven from Croatia. His championing of the exiled Serbs deeply angered President Tudjman, whom he had once seen almost daily, and led to vicious attacks against him in the state-run press.
In 1996 President Tudjman, after returning from a trip to Washington, derisively referred to him in a speech as "the tractor diplomat."
The Ambassador calls the tag, now commonly used here, "the greatest compliment of my career."
"What I did not anticipate was that after the military action, the Croatian army and police would preside over the systematic looting of every house in the Krajina and the burning of maybe a third of them," he said, "or that the Croatian Government could so strongly resist the idea that people could return to their own country."
Even his harshest critics mark the tractor ride as a watershed.
"The policies of Franjo Tudjman finally became clear to him," Mr. Cicak said. "It was also clear that he, because of his support for Tudjman, was partly responsible for what happened to the Serbs."
With Croatian troops massing along the edge of the last Serbian-held enclave in Eastern Slavonia in late 1995, Mr. Galbraith and his staff worked feverishly to achieve an agreement for a peaceful transition. The agreement put the enclave under United Nations control until Jan. 15, 1998, in an effort to foster a gradual reintegration with Croatia.
Most ethnic Serbs in exile, however, have not been allowed to return to their homes in Croatia as the agreement stipulates. And Croats expelled by the Serbs six years ago have refused to go back to Eastern Slavonia until Zagreb takes control. It is unclear to many diplomats how tolerant the new Croatian authorities will be with the remaining Serbs or if the agreement will work.
Croatia is not the first place where Mr. Galbraith -- the son of John Kenneth Galbraith, the economist -- has courted controversy.
As a staff member on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee from 1979 to 1993, he left northern Iraq in 1991 just ahead of Iraqi troops advancing to crush the Kurdish uprising. He visited the United States-backed rebels in Afghanistan and was instrumental in organizing Congressional pressure in 1984 to free the imprisoned Pakistani opposition leader, Benazir Bhutto, his former Harvard classmate.
The Ambassador, who will move to Washington and take a job as a senior official in the Agency for International Development, was instrumental in one of the most contentious Bosnia policy decisions made by the Clinton Administration.
Mr. Galbraith lobbied in April 1994 to allow Iran to transfer weapons through Croatia to the Muslims, who were outgunned by the Serbs and under siege in Sarajevo. President Clinton's agreement to look the other way as Iran and Croatia openly violated the United Nations arms embargo, however, was never relayed to the C.I.A. or the Pentagon.
"The President's decision not to object to the flow of weapons sustained the alliance between the Bosnians and the Croats, which at the time was in a very fragile condition," the Ambassador said, referring to the alliance brokered by Washington, which ended nearly a year of fighting between the Croats and Muslims. "If the Croatians had refused to permit the Bosnians to be armed, the alliance would have broken down. The arms shipments allowed the original victims of the aggression to, in a very short time, reverse the military situation on the ground. This paved the way for Dayton."
The planeloads of weapons, which began arriving in Zagreb and Pula, led the C.I.A. station chief in Zagreb, who thought the arms deliveries were a rogue operation, to report secretly on the Ambassador's activities and conversations.
Mr. Galbraith, who married a Norwegian anthropologist a year ago and has a baby daughter, was called last year to testify at Congressional hearings about the arms shipments. He is still being investigated by the House in connection with allegations that he made two secret trips to the Middle East to arrange for weapons for the Muslims, trips he insists never took place.
The secret arms program forged close links between Teheran and the Sarajevo government, as many in the C.I.A. had feared. These links, which include the presence of least 150 Iranian intelligence operatives now in Bosnia, have bedeviled Washington's efforts to build a multi-cultural, secular state, critics of the arms deal contend.

HEADLINE: Political Prisoner to President

 BODY:
In the days since his election, Kim Dae Jung has shown that he intends to govern South Korea in the same courageous spirit that marked his long, often painful effort to fight repression and one-party rule in his homeland. One of his first decisions was to endorse the pardon of two former Korean military rulers, including one who tried to have him killed. That gesture of reconciliation set the tone for the President-elect.
Mr. Kim's most important new initiative was to call for direct talks leading to an early summit meeting between the two Koreas. North Korea recently agreed to peace talks with the South in a format that also includes Washington and Beijing. The clear interest of both the United States and South Korea is to ease the tensions in North Korean society through diplomacy, humanitarian aid and economic cooperation. Washington should strongly encourage these new overtures to the North, which are still resisted by some of South Korea's conservative establishment. 
 Mr. Kim also faces an urgent challenge on the economy. He must restore plummeting international confidence without bringing on a needlessly severe contraction. He sensibly pledged to honor the loan agreement negotiated between the current Government and the International Monetary Fund. But that agreement, now in danger of being overwhelmed by new capital flight, would unreasonably squeeze the entire Korean economy to compensate for the financial recklessness of major banks and conglomerates. The fund should help Mr. Kim by loosening its unrealistic inflation targets.
Mr. Kim's most dramatic move, in human terms, was his agreement to the pardon of former Presidents Chun Doo Hwan and Roh Tae Woo, after two years' imprisonment for military mutiny and amassing political slush funds. As President, Mr. Chun orchestrated the trumped-up conviction and death sentence imposed on Mr. Kim after a 1980 popular rebellion against military rule. Mr. Kim was spared execution only after strenuous American intervention.
Kim Dae Jung has the moral standing to make the pardon of Mr. Chun, and his close collaborator Mr. Roh, acceptable. But the new President should balance this act of forgiveness by repealing South Korean military rule's most damaging legacy, a National Security Law that permits harsh prison sentences for peaceful political dissent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

As Korean Crisis Worsens, U.S. Seeks to Limit Damage
South Korea is slipping steadily deeper into an economic morass despite an international effort to restore stability. As a result, the United States and other lenders are debating whether a second bailout of South Korea is needed even while acknowledging that such further loans may be politically impossible.
More signs of the deteriorating situation came yesterday and today. The World Bank released $3 billion to South Korea, while banks are negotiating with the Seoul Government in hopes that it would convert billions of private debt into debt owed by the nation itself. And Korean stocks continued to slide, falling more than 4 percent early today after tumbling 7.5 percent yesterday. Page A1. 

Stocks Tumble in Late Selloff
A late selloff pulled stocks down sharply. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 127.54 points, or 1.63 percent, with most of the loss coming in the last 30 minutes of trading. Banking and technology shares led the decline. While traders could not point to any specific cause, many said the steep drop highlighted investor concerns about corporate profits and a lack of stability in Asia. D6.
 
Treasury prices edged up, helped in part by the selloff in stocks. The yield on the benchmark Treasury bond slipped to 5.87 percent, from 5.88 percent. D6.
 
Strong Gain in Durable-Good Orders
Orders for durable goods jumped 4.8 percent in November -- the biggest gain in almost five years. But the surge in orders was concentrated in commercial aircraft and military hardware and was not seen as evidence of a pickup in economic growth. D3.

Orange County Settlement
Merrill Lynch agreed to pay $1.9 million and Credit Suisse First Boston agreed to pay $990,000 to settle a securities fraud class-action lawsuit filed by Orange County bondholders after the California county's 1994 bankruptcy. D7.
 
AT&T to Sell Unit for $625 Million
AT&T plans to sell its customer relations business to Cincinnati Bell for $625 million. Cincinnati Bell will fold the unit, AT&T Solutions Customer Care, into its own telephone services unit. D3.
 
An Uncertain World for Utilities
The promise of utility deregulation has proved frustrating to both utility companies and state regulators. Two events this week -- California's postponement of a start to degulation and the termination of a huge utility merger -- illustrate the current uncertain state of deregulation. Market Place. D6.
 
F.D.A. Approves Lung Product
The Food and Drug Administration approved an inhaled version of an antibiotic to help cystic fibrosis patients fight off deadly lung infections. The new product, Tobi, is manufactured by Pathogenesis. A14.

German Developer Gets Prison Term
Jurgen Schneider, a German developer, was sentenced to six years and nine months in prison for fraud that led to Germany's largest corporate bankruptcy. D2.
 
True North-Publicis Fight Escalates
A Delaware court granted True North a preliminary injunction that continues to enjoin Publicis from interfering with True North's proposed acquisition of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt. D4.

HEADLINE: Critics Say United Way Plan Can't Meet Goals for Children

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER and DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Since United Way of New York City announced an ambitious campaign last month to raise $50 million to help 250,000 disadvantaged children, an unusual amount of contention has developed about whether the charity can achieve its goals.
Critics say that $50 million cannot possibly provide services to as many children as United Way said it would. Moreover, the critics -- including several leaders of charities and children's advocacy groups -- contend that United Way and its co-sponsors in the effort, the Chase Manhattan Foundation and the New York Community Trust, failed to line up the backing they needed to turn their plans into reality. 
 "Nobody I know in child care had even heard about this" until the day it was announced, said Judy Ennis, special projects coordinator at Child Care Inc., "which makes me think that United Way, the Community Trust and Chase thought it up themselves." Her agency is one of the city's five major nonprofit child care referral agencies.
Questions about the plan have arisen since the president of United Way of New York City, Ralph Dickerson Jr., announced the campaign at a breakfast on Nov. 18. Gen. Colin L. Powell and more than 800 business and civic leaders attended the event, which was held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Mr. Dickerson said the campaign, Caring Adults and Safe Places, would make New York a "world-class city for children" by mobilizing 100,000 volunteers and distributing the money -- to be raised over five years -- to nonprofit groups for after-school care, counseling, summer jobs or other services.
In two recent interviews, Mr. Dickerson acknowledged that the services would cost more than $50 million, and said that the program would require vast infusions of government money. But he said the significance of his speech was in the vision he set forth. "This isn't about money," Mr. Dickerson said. "This is about helping children."
But critics assert that the campaign, billed as a response to General Powell's highly publicized volunteerism summit in Philadelphia, appeared to be hastily conceived, poorly planned and based on unrealistic cost assumptions. Even if it meets its goal of raising $50 million, that amount could benefit only a fraction of the 250,000 children Mr. Dickerson said it would, they contend.
Some people also complained that the effort had failed to include some important community leaders, and they questioned the campaign's own leadership.
Mr. Dickerson and others involved in getting the campaign started conceded that many details were still being worked out. Joyce Bove, vice president of the New York Community Trust, one of the campaign's three co-sponsors, acknowledged that the group had been divided over whether to announce a specific fund-raising target. "We had different advisers who said if we said that we need to raise $500 million, which might be a more realistic number, it would sound so unapproachable that no one would listen," she said.
With the ambitious goals of the campaign and the fanfare surrounding it, the stakes are high for the United Way of New York City. Like many other United Way organizations, it has suffered a significant erosion in donations since the revelations in 1992 that William Aramony, the president of United Way of America, had stolen charity funds. National fund raising for United Way has yet to recover, and total contributions for United Way of New York City, adjusted for inflation, have fallen more than 17 percent since 1991, according to the group's own figures.
But some charity officials not involved in the campaign say that in its haste to capitalize on the publicity General Powell's visit to New York for the breakfast could generate, the task force organizing the United Way effort failed to adequately address basic issues about the plan.
The task force had not yet drafted a tentative budget or a fund-raising plan, or requested advance commitments from major donors, a standard step for most charities before announcing major fund-raising initiatives.
And several officials pointed to the enormous cost of the vast web of services outlined by Mr. Dickerson. One executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, estimated that the cost could be 10 times the stated figure of $50 million; another pointed out that the Pittsburgh United Way has set a $60 million goal for a five-year program that at its peak year will help just 7,600 children.
Still others have questioned the campaign's leadership, saying it was unclear how much backing the effort has from the Chase Manhattan Foundation. The foundation has repeatedly declined to comment on any aspect of the campaign.
Mr. Dickerson and his aides say that for their campaign to succeed, it needs generous support from major Jewish philanthropies, because of their prominence in New York. But Mr. Dickerson acknowledges that he did not call a single Jewish philanthropic leader before he made his speech.
Officials of the New York Federation-United Jewish Appeal, the city's largest Jewish philanthropy, noted that they could not attend the original Philadelphia summit because it was held during Passover. "From the get-go, you've made it difficult for the Jewish community to get behind this," said Stephen D. Solender, the Appeal's executive vice president.
Mr. Dickerson said last week that he had since had several conversations with Mr. Solender and that the United Way would be reaching out to other Jewish organizations. He also said the campaign was backed by more than 300 New York groups representing "top-level faith, community, corporate, philanthropic and youth leaders."
While competition for charitable contributions is intense in New York, it is highly unusual for leaders of nonprofit groups to criticize or raise questions about another organization's efforts.
Michael Clark, president of the nonprofit Citizens Committee for New York City and head of the task force overseeing planning for the United Way campaign, strongly defended the effort. The group included a broad range of people, he said, and spent "many, many hours" preparing an 18-page "strategic plan" laying out "our best effort at this point to cost out the services we hope to provide."
Mr. Clark conceded that the plan was "a work in progress," but asked, "When was the last time anyone sought to mobilize this contentious city around a common set of goals?"
Several managers of nonprofit organizations said they had warned United Way that the campaign's cost estimates and other assumptions were unrealistic. But they said they were ignored or overruled.
Seana Anderson, executive director of One to One, the Mentoring Partnership of New York City, pointed out that the plan to provide mentoring services for 50,000 children would by itself consume a significant chunk of the entire projected budget for the campaign. United Way said mentoring would cost $250 per child, a figure Ms. Anderson said was reasonable. That comes to $12.5 million over five years, or a fourth of the announced costs.
But mentoring is one of the less expensive of the broad range of services promised by Mr. Dickerson, who is the highest paid United Way executive in the country, with salary and benefits worth about $375,000 a year. In his speech, he proposed after-school care for 6,000 children, which at market rates would cost at least $18 million a year -- but which Mr. Dickerson said could be provided for less than $4 million by relying on volunteers.
Mr. Clark explained that the task force derived its cost estimates by averaging the cost of the most intensive to the least intensive programs it surveyed. But both he and Mr. Dickerson said they hoped the campaign would ultimately raise more than its $50 million target, especially since they are counting on a substantial contribution from government.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani agreed just before the breakfast last month to serve as honorary chairman for the campaign, but he did not offer any city funds for the effort and was not asked to do so.
Spokesmen for some New York nonprofit groups that the United Way said were involved in General Powell's volunteerism effort said they knew almost nothing about the local campaign.
Edward Phelan, president of the Highbridge Community Life Center, which provides social services to about 10,000 New Yorkers in the Bronx, is listed as a task force member and sent a delegate to General Powell's Philadelphia summit. But his group had not been involved since then. Ruth Avrin, the local Jewish Federation's executive director for leadership development who is also listed on the task force, said that she could not attend the one breakfast she had been invited to because it fell on Saturday, the Jewish sabbath.

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
Pro-Government Gunmen Kill 45 Indian Refugees
A band of pro-Government gunmen charged into a mountain hamlet in Mexico, spraying rifle fire and swinging machetes, killing 45 Indian refugees, Red Cross officials said. It was the bloodiest violence in the southern state of Chiapas since Indian rebels launched an uprising there nearly four years ago. A1 

'Carlos' Gets Life in Prison
The international terrorist who calls himself Carlos was convicted in Paris and sentenced to life in prison for the murder of two French police agents and a Lebanese informant in a shooting 22 years ago. A1
 
Push for Chinese Labor Unions
A loose-knit group of veteran democracy advocates has started a campaign to promote independent labor unions among China's workers. The advocates, some in China and some in exile, hope to use Beijing's recent signing of a United Nations covenant insuring the right of workers to organize as a wedge against a Government that has suppressed all efforts to form unions outside its grip. A3
 
Netanyahu Tours West Bank
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu led members of his Cabinet on a helicopter tour of the West Bank, apparently to dramatize their commitment to Israeli security while they wrestle with American demands for a "credible" withdrawal. A5
 
Russians Free Accused Spy
An American technician who was arrested in Rostov, Russia, nearly a month ago as a spy was given permission to go home for the holidays, according to an executive of his company. Richard L. Bliss, an employee of Qualcomm, a telecommunications company based in San Diego hired to install a state-of-the-art telephone system in Rostov, was temporarily released on the assurance that he would return in January to resume cooperating in the investigation. A8
 
Ebola Outbreak Fear in Kenya
The World Health Organization and local medical officials are dispatching a team of doctors to northeastern Kenya to investigate an outbreak of a mysterious disease with symptoms similar to those of the deadly Ebola fever. Government officials in the Garissa region say they have received unconfirmed reports that at least 143 people have died from an unknown disease this month in flooded villages throughout the region on the border with Somalia. A6
 
Former Nazi Leaves Hospital
The former Nazi officer Erich Priebke, who is serving a sentence for taking part in Italy's worst World War II massacre, was taken from Rome's military hospital and moved to a friend's home, his lawyer said, after a court ruled he could serve the remaining three months of his sentence under house arrest. The former SS officer was found guilty in July of participating in the 1944 mass execution of 335 men and boys in Rome in retaliation for an attack on German occupying forces. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL A10-14
 
Terry Nichols Found Guilty Of Conspiracy in Bombing
Terry L. Nichols was convicted of conspiring to bomb the Oklahoma City Federal Building, but in a nuanced verdict, a Federal District Court jury in Denver acquitted him of actually committing what was the worst terrorist act on United States soil. He was found guilty of involuntary manslaughter but was acquitted of the far more serious charge of murder. Still, the conviction on the conspiracy count could bring Mr. Nichols the death penalty and the jury will convene again on Monday to begin deciding his fate. A1
 
In finding Mr. Nichols guilty of conspiracy and involuntary manslaughter but not first or second degree murder, jurors essentially decided that he acted recklessly and in a manner that he should have known could cause death, but that killing was not clearly his intention, legal experts said. A12
 
Rape Case to Be Retried
An Alabama prosecutor said he planned to retry two brothers who spent nearly 14 years in prison before being freed this month after DNA tests indicated that they were wrongfully convicted of rape in 1984. A10
 
Fat Linked to Fewer Strokes
A long-term study has found that men who eat more fat, including more saturated fat, are less likely than men on lower-fat diets to suffer a stroke. The finding, which is supported by two earlier studies in Japan and Hawaii as well as by experiments in laboratory rats, is the
latest in a series of conflicting
reports in recent years about how
much and what kinds of fats are most healthful. A14
 
Cystic Fibrosis Drug Approved
The Food and Drug Administration approved an inhaled antibiotic to help cystic fibrosis patients fight off deadly lung infections. A14
 
Haitian Refugees Win Reprieve
President Clinton delayed the deportation of up to 40,000 Haitians who fled to the United States while an abusive military junta ruled their island nation. Mr. Clinton also promised to work with Congress to provide the Haitians long-term legislative relief of the kind provided earlier this year to Central Americans who also fled civil strife. A11
 
Use of Medical Accounts Grow
Medical savings accounts -- seen by Republicans as a sensible way to cut health insurance costs and by Democrats as a tax break for the healthy and the wealthy -- have been tested in the private market for a year with few participants. But there is evidence that the idea may be picking up steam. A11
 
Gap in Bridge to Be Sealed
Engineers will seal a gap next to the pedestrian walkway on the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco after a 2-year-old girl plunged to her death in a freak accident on Sunday, officials said. The girl, Gauri Govil of Fremont, Calif., was pronounced dead after slipping slipped through a 9 1/2-inch gap near the northern end of the bridge and fell about 170 feet to the ground below. (Reuters)

Speech Rights Upheld For Street Performers

At least 14 live-animal markets in New York City have been quarantined -- or temporarily closed -- since mid-November after state inspectors turned up chickens for sale that were infected with a strain of influenza found only in poultry. B5

BUSINESS DAY D1-16
 
New Options for Korea
Faced with overwhelming evidence that a two-month long attempt to restore stability to South Korea's economy is failing, the Clinton Administration is scrambling to find other options to contain the country's financial meltdown. In a sign of the increasing desperation surrounding South Korea's problems, the World Bank released $3 billion to Seoul, saying that although the money was originally intended to reshape the banking system, it could be used immediately to help pay off the country's short-term loans. A1
 
Microsoft Faces Backlash
Microsoft's stubbornly hard-line position that it cannot follow a Federal judge's order earlier this month to unbundle its World Wide Web browser software from its popular Windows operating system -- at least not without damaging recent versions of Windows -- may be stirring a public backlash against the company. D1
 
State Fines Oxford Health
The New York State Department of Insurance released a harsh critique of Oxford Health Plans' management and fined the company $3 million for violating state insurance regulations. The insurance department also ordered the company to refund roughly $500,000 to some of its customers. D1
 
Economic Growth Slows
More evidence of slackening economic growth emerged even as the Government reported that orders for big-ticket factory goods in November posted the biggest gain in almost five years. The surge was concentrated in commercial aircraft and military hardware, produced over extended periods, leaving new orders for items other than transportation equipment lower for the second month. D3
 
U.S. Stocks Fall at Close
An unexpected late day selloff in stocks dropped the Dow Jones industrial average 127 points to its lowest level in more than a month. D6

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
WITH KOREA CRISIS WORSE, U.S. SEEKS WAY TO LIMIT HARM

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Faced with devastating evidence that a two-month-long attempt to restore stability to South Korea's economy is failing, the Clinton Administration is scrambling for other options to contain the country's financial damage.
In a sign of the increasing desperation surrounding the South Korean problems, the World Bank released $3 billion to Seoul today, saying that although the money was originally intended to reshape the nation's banking system, it could be used immediately to help pay short-term loan obligations. 
 At the same time, commercial banks owed billions by South Korean companies and banks are negotiating with the Seoul Government in hopes that it would convert that private debt into debt owed by the nation itself.
Such a change would create the basis for repayment negotiations similar to those used to save Brazil and Argentina in the Latin American debt crisis of the 1980's. But it is far from clear that such talks would succeed. And a day after two big credit-rating agencies, Moody's and Standard & Poor's, lowered South Korean debt to junk bond status and sent its financial markets plunging, officials in Washington conceded that they faced no easy choices.
"The whole idea now is to buy a little time -- maybe two or three months -- until the new South Korean Government is in place," said a participant in three-way talks between the Governments in Seoul and Washington and South Korea's lenders on three continents.
They do not have the luxury of time, judging from the descent of the Korean stock market, which fell a record 7.5 percent today, and with the currency, the won, worth about half its value a few months ago.
 In Seoul on Wednesday, stocks closed down a further 4.07 percent, but the value of the currency rose to a spot rate of 1,852 to the dollar, compared with 1,962 late Tuesday.
Investors' anxieties have not been eased by the next South Korean leader, President-elect Kim Dae Jung, who proclaimed in Seoul today that he was stunned by the severity of the crisis and that "we don't know if we will go bankrupt tomorrow or the day after tomorrow."
For all practical purposes, the United States and other lenders to South Korea are debating a second bailout because it has become clear that the first effort, a $57 billion financial aid package announced 19 days ago by the International Monetary Fund, is inadequate.
The hope had been that the declaration of such an enormous amount of loan aid would persuade private investors that their money was safe and that they could continue to lend South Korea the cash it needed to avoid defaulting.
The opposite has happened, however. The Korean financial situation has soured so quickly in the last two weeks that the country's credit rating has fallen precipitously. The junk bond status now assigned to Korean debt has made it far harder and more expensive for the country to obtain loans at the moment it needs them most.
At the same time, the major trading nations, including the United States and Japan, say it is politically impossible for them to lend South Korea the tens of billions of dollars required to piece the world's 11th-largest economy together again. The Clinton Administration has said it will not do in Asia what it did in Mexico -- take the lead with a bailout plan that puts American taxpayer dollars at risk.
So far, the United States has committed $5 billion to the Korean rescue effort but said it would only make the money available after South Korea had exhausted loans from the I.M.F. and others. There is growing pressure on Washington to release that money in the next few weeks, a step that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who is on vacation this week, declined to take two weeks ago when South Korea first requested it. This week, American officials hinted they may be reconsidering.
 But a senior American diplomat in Seoul said on Wednesday that the United States thought Korea could make it into January and that it did not plan to release the $5 billion before then.
President-elect Kim, a former dissident who won a narrow victory over the ruling-party candidate last Thursday, has said he will abide by the terms of the I.M.F. agreement, and he dropped his campaign promise to prevent job layoffs, which would have undermined the painful I.M.F. steps that will close money-losing banks and businesses.
But his inexperience in an economic crisis was evident today, when his "go bankrupt" remark helped aggravate the slide in South Korean markets. Mr. Kim may have been speaking for dramatic effect, as his aides insisted after they watched the markets' reaction. In volatile financial situations, investors do not use the word "bankrupt" lightly, and with rumors swirling that South Korea's short-term debts might be far greater than believed, his words were taken seriously.
"Somebody is going to have to teach the President-elect how to talk to the markets," a senior American official said today. "He doesn't quite have the language down yet."
 In Seoul early on Wednesday, Mr. Kim said he believed that the crisis was "surmountable," apparently trying to tone down the alarm his earlier statement aroused.
Mr. Kim's remarks today may have simply accelerated a flight from the the South Korean currency that was already well under way. It is a measure of the failure of the "stabilization plan" that the won is now 38 percent cheaper against the dollar than when the I.M.F. bailout was announced on Dec. 3.
Markets have been rattled by the apparent inability of the Korean Government to determine exactly how much companies owe in short-term debts -- those due in the next year. The figure is said to exceed $100 billion, far higher than Seoul initially estimated, and may be greater still. One official said that the Federal Reserve and the I.M.F. had sent representatives to Seoul "to get a handle on those numbers."
The strategy now is to get South Korea through the next several weeks with a combination of money from the I.M.F., the World Bank, bridge loans from the Japanese Government and agreements from private banks to renegotiate their loans as they come due. But many lenders, particularly Japanese banks, are not permitted to hold junk bond debt.
The $3 billion released to South Korea by the World Bank today was the first installment in a planned $10 billion program. The World Bank has been negotiating a deal with Seoul intended to improve the country's banking system; break some of the chummy ties between the Government, the big conglomerates and the banks, and bolster social welfare programs to insure that the country can help workers who lose their jobs.
But World Bank officials acknowledged at a news conference here that the most pressing use for the money would be to help deal with the looming debt-repayment crisis. Restoring financial stability, they said, is a condition for attacking the underlying problems in the banking system.
"We make no bones about the fact that we're contributing to market confidence and that there is a stabilization aspect to this loan," said Mark Malloch Brown, the World Bank's head of external affairs.
 To address the underlying problems, the senior diplomat said, David A. Lipton, the United States Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, and the I.M.F. have been negotiating moves -- like relaxing interest rates and controls on foreign exchange transactions -- to further open markets and attract foreign capital.
Bank officials said they were also willing to go to great lengths to help South Korea -- the $3 billion was wired to Seoul almost instantly on approval by the bank's board today -- because they do not want the crisis to erase the remarkable economic gains made by the Koreans over the last three decades or to threaten other Asian economies.
"We're not prepared to see that success story go down the tubes," Mr. Malloch Brown said.
Commercial bankers in the United States say they are discussing restructuring South Korea's debt, using the Latin American crisis as a model. But the talks hinge in part on whether the Seoul Government will guarantee repayment of all debts, public and private. Those debts would then be sold as one large package to international investors.
 South Korean news reports said Wednesday that Citicorp was in talks with Seoul about leading a consortium to lend $3 billion. Citicorp declined to comment, but United States bankers called the reports false.
Asked about any debt-rescheduling negotiations with commercial banks, Danny Leipziger, the World Bank's team leader for South Korea, replied, "We've heard those discussions are going on."
It is unclear whether repackaged debt would receive additional guarantees from foreign governments like the United States, as occurred in Latin America.
Unlike the Latin debt crisis, the Asian troubles involve lenders worldwide, with European and Japanese banks facing much larger potential losses than American banks.

HEADLINE: Street Musician's Fee Is Ruled Excessive

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN WEISER 

 BODY:
Calling music a form of expression protected by the First Amendment, a Federal district judge in Manhattan has ruled that the New York City Police Department violated the free-speech rights of a street musician by charging excessive permit fees.
The ruling was praised by some of the city's ubiquitous street musicians, who have been hampered by the city's crackdown on quality of life complaints as they compete for scarce handouts. 
 In the ruling, which was issued on Friday and made public on Monday, Judge Shira A. Scheindlin said that the $45 fee charged for a one-day permit to play amplified music on the streets far exceeded the Police Department's cost of processing the permit, and constituted an unreasonable curb on free speech. However, she did not say what a reasonable fee would be.
The street musician, Robert Turley, who plays a "treble bass," an unusual 10-string electronic bass guitar, said by telephone that he was pleased with the judge's ruling.
"It will make it more affordable to be heard," he said, shortly before heading out to play at one of his regular locations, the northwest corner of 47th Street and Broadway.
Mr. Turley's lawyer, Robert T. Perry, said that the ruling applied not only to street musicians, but also to preachers and others who seek to amplify their music or voices electronically.
The city's Acting Corporation Counsel, Jeffrey D. Friedlander, said he believed that Judge Scheindlin's decision was "wrong on the law," and that "taken as a whole, these fees bear a reasonable relationship to the cost of processing the applications."
He said his office had advised the Police Department to stop charging the permit fee until the city decides whether to appeal the ruling.
Mr. Friedlander defended the formula by which the Police Department arrived at the fee, which took into account the salaries of personnel involved in handling the applications and other costs.
Street musicians across the city applauded the judge's ruling, saying the economics of public performance, with or without an amplifier, simply could not support hefty fees -- or the even heftier tickets issued by the police.
Julio Cesar Diaz, who dances salsa with a rag doll named Lupita, has been fined three times in the last two months for using an amplifier without a license in the Times Square subway station. The tickets cost $50 -- a sum he considers an excessive penalty on his livelihood.
"I've never held out the hat," he said yesterday. "I owe everything to this doll -- my rent, food for the children and everything."
The judge's ruling came in a lawsuit in which Mr. Turley had also asserted that the police harassed him when he tried to perform on street corners and traffic islands, usually around Times Square.
"I would sooner lose my powers of speech than to not be able to play in front of people," Mr. Turley told a jury last May. The city denied the accusation at trial, saying the police were properly enforcing rules on street noise, a major complaint from the public.
The jury awarded Mr. Turley $37,000, but after Judge Scheindlin ordered a new trial on the issue of damages, the city agreed to settle with the musician for $150,000, his lawyer, Mr. Perry, said.
Some performers, like Carlos Mesa, an acoustic-guitar player who serenaded commuters in Grand Central Terminal with a medley of contemporary jazz, were unaware of the fees in the first place. "I've never asked for a permit, the police never asked me to pay, and I wouldn't want to pay," Mr. Mesa, 39, said yesterday. "Why should I pay? Look what I made all day!"
He pointed to the open guitar case on the ground before him. In four hours, he had made roughly $8 in loose change.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Turley played electric bass at Times Square on Monday night, happier after a Federal judge said the $45 cost of his permit was excessive and amounted to an unconstitutional denial of free-speech rights. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)
