HEADLINE: Three Hospitals Plan Units for Children

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
Montefiore Medical Center announced this week that it had raised a quarter of the $100 million it needs to build a new children's hospital in the Bronx, in what would be the third new major medical complex for children planned in a region that has few pediatric hospitals.
Unlike other large cities in the United States, New York has largely incorporated its pediatric services into huge medical institutions, which are a prime engine of the local economy. Now, Montefiore and Westchester County Medical Center have plans for separate and expensive children's hospitals at a time of little construction in the medical industry. 
 Babies Hospital at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center is also planning a $70 million building to replace its aging children's hospital at Broadway and 168th Street in Manhattan.
Health care experts say there is no single reason for the three projects, but rather intersecting trends: To a large extent, experts say, hospitals are trying to find a niche for themselves, as managed care has increased competition for patients. Also, experts say, expanded state and Federal programs for uninsured children have helped guarantee a steady flow of money to care for children.
Moreover, several hospital officials said the New York area could accommodate more separate pediatric hospitals, given the size of the population and the success of similar complexes in Boston and Philadelphia.
"A couple of us have been pushing it hard," said Dr. Steven P. Shelov, chairman of pediatrics at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, which is planning a $10 million upgrade of its pediatric unit. "It has taken a combination of a clear recognition that children's services have not been what they are in other parts of the country with the fact that children, when they get to hospitals, have more complex needs." Until recently, Dr. Shelov had been at Montefiore helping to plan its children's hospital.
The plans are all similar in that they will provide health care specifically for children and will permit families to become more involved in their care. There will be more play areas, beds for parents to stay overnight and rooms oriented toward the hustle and bustle of the hospital, which officials said would make children feel safe.
"It will go way beyond just making the families comfortable and family-friendly," said Dr. Irwin Redlener, who is the director of community pediatrics at Montefiore and who is in charge of construction of the hospital. "Parents should be active partners with the medical team in organizing and following up the health care of their children."
Montefiore's plans, the most expensive of the three, have largely been kept under wraps in recent months as hospital officials solicited the first major donations. Most of the seed money came from two members of the hospital's board, Lionel L. Pinkus, chief executive of the financial services firm E. M. Warburg & Company, and Martin S. Davis, who was raised in the Bronx and who is chief executive of Wellspring Associates, a private investment company. Each donated $10 million. In addition, $1 million was given anonymously, and the Children's Health Fund, a nonprofit children's health program founded by Dr. Redlener and the singer Paul Simon in 1987, donated $4 million.
The Montefiore Children's Hospital, which is expected to be completed in 2002, will be on the hospital's main campus on Bainbridge Avenue in the Bronx. Dr. Redlener said the new hospital, with about 100 beds, would be the hub in a larger health care system for children in the Bronx. Montefiore already has 35 clinics in the borough whose operations would be integrated into the children's hospital, with more routine cases being treated at the clinics and more severe cases at the hospital.
He said he expected that the hospital would also draw patients from around the region.
At Columbia-Presbyterian, officials have already received approval from the State Department of Health for a pediatrics building at Broadway and 165th Street, a site that is now a parking lot. The 120-bed Babies Hospital, along with Schneider Children's Hospital-Long Island Jewish Medical Center, is one of the few separate children's hospitals in the region.
Dr. William T. Speck, a pediatrician and top hospital official there, said the need for an up-to-date children's center had become evident during the recent merger between Columbia-Presbyterian and New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He said the center would serve pediatric cases referred through the new hospital system's dozen hospitals around the city. He said he expected construction to be completed by 2000.
In Westchester, the Westchester County Medical Center, soon to become a quasi-private, nonprofit institution, is planning a 110-bed children's hospital on the main campus in Valhalla, said Bruce K. Komiske, executive director of the Children's Hospital Foundation, who oversaw the building of the Hasbro Children's Hospital in Providence, R.I.
Officials at all three hospitals stress that only a few new beds will be added in the new construction, which they characterized more as a consolidation of existing beds for children under better conditions. So, the officials said, they doubted that there would be much competition among them for patients, although Montefiore and Westchester may draw from the same area in southern Westchester, and Montefiore and Babies may face some competition in the Bronx because of hospitals affiliated with Babies in that borough.
John Billings, director of the Health Research Program at the Robert F. Wagner School for Public Service at New York University, said he thought that children's hospitals could face more serious competition in the suburbs of New Jersey and southern Connecticut. Overall, Mr. Billings said, he felt there were more pressing medical needs in the region for the huge amounts of money being spent on these three projects, like renovating Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn, and he labeled the new hospitals basically marketing efforts to keep competitive.
He said, however, that he thought there were enough sick children to keep them all in business.
"Do we need children's hospitals?" Mr. Billings said. "Probably not. Will it be better patient care? Probably."

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
U.N. Rejects U.S. Plea For a Decrease in Dues

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 23

 BODY:
The United States has succeeded in keeping the United Nations budget at the rate Congress had demanded but failed to get its dues lowered.
In negotiations that ended with General Assembly resolutions late on Monday, the United States, which owes more than $1.3 billion to the United Nations, received a commitment that the dues issues would be revisited next year, providing that it paid its debt. 
 European diplomats said today that Washington would never get its dues lowered to 20 percent of the United Nations budget, as Congress once visualized, and would be lucky if they were reduced from the current 25 percent cap to 22 percent.
The chief United States delegate to the United Nations, Bill Richardson, conceded that because of the huge debt, "American interests have been compromised." He added that, "Clearly it has cost us credibility."
The three-year assessments adopted by the assembly show no rise for China as Mr. Richardson had wanted. China, a permanent member of the Security Council, will pay less than 1 percent of the budget for the foreseeable future. And dues for Russia, another permanent member, will be reduced.
Those carrying the largest burden are Japan and the 15 European Community members. Japan's contribution will rise from 17.9 percent in 1998 to 20.5 percent in 2000, bringing it close to the United States despite its much smaller economy. Germany is third, with 9.6 percent.

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefs;
Unemployment Rate Drops in New York

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
New York City's unemployment rate fell in November below 9 percent for the first time in more than a year, to 8.7 percent, caused by a surge in seasonal hiring and a decrease in the number of people searching for jobs, the New York State Department of Labor said yesterday.
The city's seasonally adjusted jobless rate was 9.1 percent in October. It reached a peak of 10 percent in June and has fallen, in fits and starts since then, though November's was one of the biggest monthly drops. The statewide rate, also adjusted for seasonal fluctuations, fell to 6.2 percent, from 6.4 percent in October, the state said. 
 The Labor Department said that employers in the city added about 3,000 new jobs during November, a bit off the average pace for the first 10 months of the year.
A reduction in the numbers of people estimated to be actively searching for jobs was also a major contributing factor, said Jeffrey Weissenstein, a labor market analyst for the state. Mr. Weissenstein said that above and beyond the longer-term business cycles of job creation, unemployment in New York typically falls toward the end of the year, then rises again in January as short-term seasonal jobs end. KIRK JOHNSON

HEADLINE: Public Eye

BYLINE: By Phil Patton 

 BODY:
FEW phrases can more quickly strike terror into the heart of the average American parent, hunkered down under the Christmas tree, than this: "Some assembly required." Worse, as is the case with Compaq computers, the Bose Wave radio, most furniture from Ikea and many toys, if the instructions bear few words or none, only pictures.
Once, I gloried in object assembly. Stranded at home with the measles in the second grade, I put together a dozen airplane models, learning detail and sequence from the complex instructions. In my half-literate state, I relied mostly on the pictures. 
 Today, it seems, more and more instructions have been reduced to pictures alone. Wordless instructions are found on camera and telephone paperwork, as well as airline safety cards, chopstick wrappers, orange juice containers and Heimlich maneuver posters at restaurants. "It's a global economy," investors and designers alike chant; visual instructions circle the globe and avoid the perplexities of different languages.
The Boy Scout handbook has long avoided text when dealing with things like tying knots. Icons on dashboards or cameras -- the snowflake for heat, the mountain for long focus -- are simple instructions, as is the arrow for "play" on tape machines.
More and more, the words have shrunk to a precious few, in six or seven increasingly less familiar languages. Children seem happier with visual instructions than do adults, who may feel they are watching a film with no soundtrack. Ikea has found that Americans seem more verbal than its European customers and therefore are less comfortable with visual instructions. (Europeans long ago got used to international road signs and other hieroglyphics.)
The more intimidating the device, the more intense the effort to make assembly simple through images. Computer manufacturers now brag about what they refer to as the "out of the box experience." Apple, Compaq, Acer and Packard Bell print their instructions as a mostly wordless poster, replacing such designations as "serial port" with pictures of coded connectors. Krzystof Lenk and Paul Kahn, information consultants in Providence, R.I., created a life-size map for assembling the I.B.M. Thinkpad: pieces of the computer fit onto it precisely.
Richard Saul Wurman, the author of "Follow the Yellow Brick Road: Learning to Give, Take and Use Instructions" (Bantam, 1972), emphasizes the need to tailor instructions to the audience -- and to the use. He cited Harold R. Booher's research with military personnel that concluded that pictures were good for speed, words for accuracy. The best instructions seem to include a diagrammatic inventory of parts and numbers to indicate the assembly sequence. But, as Mr. Wurman noted in an interview last week, "there are no hard-and-fast rules."
"You have to figure out what is appropriate," he said. "It is inappropriate on an airplane to have to read a safety card if the plane is crashing."
There is evidence that men (generally considered right-brainers who prefer pictures) and women (left-brainers who prefer words) respond to different sorts of instructions, and the drift toward wordless instruction sheets may well result from the idea that this is men's work.
Ikea's furniture is all shipped flat, and it is up to the buyer to assemble the chairs, tables and lamps at home. Ikea's instructions say, "Follow me," and then picture the parts: a fastener, for instance, and the notation "x 12" if a dozen of them are needed. Details of fasteners are shown at larger scale, leaping out from the diagram in little circles.
Several years ago, my daughter, then 8, put together an Ikea bookcase, unintimidated by the absence of words. But many adults are scared off by Ikea's diagrams. Groucho Marx, confronted with some task touted as "so simple any 8-year-old can do it," is said to have replied, "Quick, run out and find me an 8-year-old."
If designers want to make instructions simple enough for an 8-year-old to use, perhaps the real target should be someone a little older.

GRAPHIC: Diagram: FOLLOW ME -- A step in Ikea's dresser-assembly guide. (Ikea)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Up Against the Yen, But Eases vs. Mark and Pound

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar edged higher against the Japanese yen yesterday as the announcement of accelerated aid to South Korea failed to instill much confidence in Asian economies.
The Christmas holiday today and early market closings in the United States yesterday kept foreign-exchange activity to a minimum, and traders said the dollar's movements were generally uneventful. "Liquidity is so thin that you couldn't do anything if you wanted to, and if anybody is going to react to news they'll probably wait to do it over the next few days," said Tom Hoge, vice president for corporate trading at the Bank of New York. 
 In New York yesterday, the dollar settled at 129.85 yen, up from 129.22 on Tuesday. It slipped to 1.7735 German marks from 1.7755 marks. And the dollar eased against the British pound, which rose to $1.6703 from $1.6656.
Traders said the dollar was static after the International Monetary Fund said it would speed up $2 billion of its promised $57 billion package for South Korea, sending the money by the end of the year. Donor nations pledged a further $8 billion in January. The Korean currency, the won, rose for the first time in five days.
And the Japanese Finance Ministry said it would postpone penalties against banks whose capital-to-asset ratios did not meet minimum standards. The Government, which had planned to impose sanctions against such banks by April 1, is concerned that a decline in bank lending will lead to more business failures.
The yen was also put on the defensive yesterday after the Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its credit ratings on Sanwa Bank Ltd. and Sakura Bank Ltd..
The dollar's strength was limited, though, by continuing speculation that the Japanese central bank would intervene in the currency markets, selling dollars for yen, as it did in large amounts last week.
In other trading, the Canadian dollar strengthened after the Bank of Canada extended a series of interventions on behalf of its currency. The Canadian dollar rose to 69.7 United States cents, from 69.58 cents on Tuesday. But many analysts expect Canada's currency to resume weakening toward an all-time low of 69.13 United States cents, which was recorded in February 1986.

HEADLINE: Malnutrition's 20-Cent Treatment

 BODY:
Four years ago, scientists putting together studies from around the world realized that giving children with vitamin A deficiency a 2-cent capsule two or three times a year cut their death rate from diarrhea and other infectious diseases by a quarter. Today, 60 percent of the world's children get vitamin A. At a cost of about 20 cents or less to deliver each capsule, this is one of the most cost-effective methods of preventing disease ever found. The vitamin A project is one of several nutrition programs detailed in this year's report on the State of the World's Children from Unicef. Every year, says Unicef, nearly 12 million children under 5 die, more than half because of malnutrition. Fortunately, many proven, cheap ways to prevent malnutrition are in use, and Unicef's report gives them needed attention.
Malnutrition is growing only in sub-Saharan Africa, due largely to the debt crisis and its accompanying poverty. But wealth is not the only cure. In Latin America the poverty rate has changed little since 1970, but malnutrition has dropped by two-thirds, mainly because of better access to health care and a gain in the status of women. In South Asia half of all children are malnourished, largely because women are overworked, underfed and undereducated. 
 Unicef argues that fighting malnutrition is an investment, as the disease, disability and low I.Q. caused by malnutrition reduce some nations' economies by 5 percent. A small investment here can yield a large return. More than 100 million young children have diets that lack vitamin A, crucial for preventing blindness and strengthening the immune system. In combination with zinc supplements, vitamin A also helps children resist malaria. Mothers can benefit as well. Giving pregnant women one low-dose vitamin A or beta carotene capsule a week (high doses can damage the fetus) cuts the maternal mortality rate by nearly half. Numerous studies suggest that taking vitamin A during pregnancy can also reduce the rate of H.I.V. transmission from mother to child. Supplements of iron, zinc and folate also protect mothers and children.
In addition to supplements, health officials are trying to fortify common foods with nutrients and diversify diets to include more nutrients. Switzerland and the United States have put iodine in salt since the 1920's to prevent mental retardation, but this was not done on a widespread basis until the 1990's. Now nearly 60 percent of the world's edible salt is iodized, much of it paid for by the Kiwanis International Club, which is planning to raise $75 million to end iodine deficiency.
The United States Congress, which has been supportive of child health, allocates $25 million a year to the purchase and delivery of micronutrients. It could usefully spend more. Fifteen years ago, many scoffed when Unicef began a campaign to vaccinate the world's children. But today, most governments conduct mass immunizations, which reach 80 percent of children and save three million lives a year. Micronutrients are cheaper, require no refrigeration and can piggyback on existing vaccination programs. They should be able to save even more children from an early death.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Income Rose In November, U.S. Reports 0.8%

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Personal income rose eight-tenths of 1 percent during November, the biggest gain since June 1996 and double the size of the month's increase in consumer spending, the Commerce Department said today.
"There's not much inflation out there," said Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass. "With all the sales we're seeing, there's no rush to buy because the price might be better tomorrow than it is today." 
 Because consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic output, trends in income and consumption can be an indication of future business activity and provide clues about the Federal Reserve's inflation stance.
The November report is also a gauge of consumer spending at the beginning of the holiday shopping season. Earlier this month, the Government reported that retail sales had increased two-tenths of 1 percent in November, less than expected.
November was the 13th consecutive month in which personal income increased. The gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent was larger than October's revised increase of six-tenths of 1 percent.
Spending, meanwhile, rose four-tenths of 1 percent in November after increasing half a percent in October. November was the 17th consecutive month in which spending increased.
However, income gains are likely to taper off in the months ahead, analysts said. "The economy is moderating, and it's likely to continue to slow, with the consumer sector losing momentum," said James Glassman, chief United States economist at Chase Securities Inc. in New York. That is likely to mean that the Federal Reserve will leave interest rates unchanged in the first part of 1998, he said.
"The Fed's on hold for now, with a prospect for easing in the second half of the year if inflation stays low," Mr. Glassman said.
In the third quarter, consumer spending grew at a 5.6 percent annual rate, the strongest pace in five years. Analysts at Merrill Lynch & Company expect spending to slow to a rate of between 2.5 percent and 3 percent in the current quarter and in 1998.
In today's report, the Commerce Department also said that disposable income, the money left over after taxes, increased seven-tenths of 1 percent in November, faster than October's gain of half a percent. The savings rate rose to 4 percent, from 3.8 percent in October. Interest payments to businesses, which are counted separately from the spending figures, increased by six-tenths of 1 percent.
Separately, the Labor Department said the number of people applying for state unemployment benefits fell more than expected last week. First-time jobless claims declined by 13,000, to a seasonally adjusted 307,000. In the previous week, claims rose a revised 6,000.
The four-week average for jobless claims, a less volatile gauge of employment conditions than the weekly figures, rose to 315,750 in the latest week from 315,000 the previous week.

HEADLINE: Nasdaq Reports 2.1% Rise In Uncovered Short Sales

 BODY:
December has been a cruel month for technology stocks, and some investors appear to have bet that the news will get worse.
Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq market, which is heavily weighted with technology stocks, rose 2.1 percent, to a record 1.79 billion shares as of mid-December, the market said yesterday. Figures reflect trades reported through Dec. 10 and settled as of Dec. 15. 
 Uncovered short sales are essentially bets that stock prices will fall, and technology stocks were clearly the favorites of short-sellers in the last month.
The Quantum Corporation, whose stock plunged 25 percent earlier this month when it warned that falling prices for its hard drives would depress third-quarter earnings, showed the largest rise. Its short position climbed more than 8 million shares, to almost 19.9 million shares.
Several other technology companies, including Sun Microsystems, saw large increases as well. But the Intel Corporation saw its short position fall more than 5 million shares from mid-November, to 31.5 million.
Part of the reason may be that Intel, the world's largest maker of integrated circuits, has said that it does not expect to be severely affected by the problems in Asia's economies. Intel's shares, which plunged earlier this month, have been recovering. It still holds the second-largest short interest position on Nasdaq, though.
While high short-interest positions have been considered an indicator of bearish sentiment, they can also result from complex trading strategies involving options, futures and other stock-related derivatives.
 
SHORT SALES TABLES EXPLAINED

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Fall in Price

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell in a shortened session yesterday, the first decline in bonds in five sessions.
Bonds were pressured after South Korea said it was able to pay its immediate debts and will get $10 billion in international aid sooner than expected, damping demand for the safety of United States assets. 
 "The news that the bailouts are being lined up means maybe we're getting to the end of the immediate crisis" in Asian financial markets, said Livingston Douglas, who helps manage $1.3 billion at Kiewit Investment Management Corporation in Omaha. "It may be that the flight-to- quality trade is coming to an end," he said.
The news from South Korea is "hurting U.S. bonds by alleviating a little of the stress in Asia," said Andrew Brenner, head of global fixed-income trading at Fimat USA Inc.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 19/32, to 103. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.91 percent, from 5.87 percent on Tuesday. The Treasury market ended early yesterday and will be closed today for Christmas. The market will also have a shortened session tomorrow.
Bond prices barely budged after the Government said the number of workers filing for unemployment benefits last week fell to 307,000, lower than the 316,000 analysts had expected.
Other economic data released yesterday also had little impact. The Commerce Department said personal income rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, while spending rose four-tenths of 1 percent.
Some investors said that they did not expect bonds to move much until the market gets more information on the economy's health and the effectiveness of the aid to Asia.
"It looks like we are kind of frozen here for a while," said Robert Alley, who manages $2.5 billion at the Houston-based AIM Advisors.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Korean Aid Is Accelerated As U.S. Changes Strategy
The United States joined other leading industrial nations in supplying South Korea with $10 billion in emergency aid. The move is an about-face for the Clinton Administration. Two weeks ago, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, left, rejected a request by South Korea to speed up aid. Now, the United States will lend $1.7 billion by the second week of January.
In return for this latest cash infusion, Seoul has agreed to further open its markets. Six large United States banks, meanwhile, have agreed to come up with a plan to help South Korea, prodded along by the Administration and the Federal Reserve. A1. 

The dollar ended slightly higher against the yen, as the announcement of accelerated aid to South Korea failed to inspire much confidence in Asia's economies. D5.
 
Nasdaq Price-Fixing Settlement
Thirty brokerage firms, including some of the biggest names on Wall Street, agreed to pay about $900 million to end a class-action lawsuit that accused the firms of scheming with each other for years to fix prices on the Nasdaq stock market. The settlement would be one of Wall Street's biggest, in terms of money and the number of brokerage firms involved. A1.
 
Big Gain in Incomes Last Month
Personal income rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, double the increase in consumer spending for the month, the Commerce Department said in a report that reinforced expectations of continued low inflation. D2.
 
Japan Delays Bank Sanctions
The Japanese Finance Ministry postponed for a year the imposition of penalties on banks that do not meet its standard of financial soundness. The sanctions would have taken effect on April 1, but the Government was concerned that a decline in bank lending would lead to more business failures. D3.

Modest Declines in Stocks
Stocks fell in an abbreviated trading session. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 31.64 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent. Merck and Disney led the decline in the Dow. D6.
Treasury prices weakened for the first time in five sessions. The 30-year Treasury yield rose to 5.91 percent from 5.87 percent. D13.
 
Health Groups Join Fight on Patent
Health care organizations have pledged support to Kaiser Permanente, which has filed a suit seeking to invalidate a patent used to demand millions in royalties from providers of a common prenatal test for birth defects. D2.
 
BellSouth Application Rejected
BellSouth's application to enter the long-distance telephone business in South Carolina was rejected, as expected, by the Federal Communications Commission. The Justice Department had recommended that BellSouth's application be blocked. D2.
 
Platinum Surges on Russia Cutback
Platinum and palladium futures prices surged on word that Russia had halted shipments in a dispute with Japanese customers. D5.
 
Tourism Slumps in Egypt
The massacre that claimed the lives of 58 tourists in a 2,500-year-old temple in Luxor last month is having a profound impact on the Egyptian economy. The sharp falloff in the number of tourists since the attack may shrink the economy's rate of growth by as much as one-third, according to one estimate. Tourism has been the country's most important source of foreign exchange. D3.

Spying for Profit
The first commercial spy satellite, built by Earthwatch of Colorado, was launched from Russia. The company said customers would pay $300 to $725 an image. A16.
 
Markets Closed
All financial markets and banks in the United States will be closed today for Christmas. Most overseas markets will also be closed. Many financial markets in the United States will have abbreviated trading sessions tomorrow and will resume normal hours on Monday.

HEADLINE: Survey Finds Wide Range of Fees for Checking Accounts

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
When Citibank last month raised by 200 percent the minimum balance it requires for free checking, it sparked criticism from New York City officials and state legislators.
State Senator Nellie Santiago, a Democrat of Brooklyn, denounced the bank as interested only in doing business with the wealthy. The city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, Jose Maldonado, promptly issued a survey that found that some bank customers pay more than $200 a year for basic checking services. He called the survey's findings "quite disturbing." 
 Unknown to many, though, there are several lesser-known banks that offer free checking, with no minimum balance required, and sometimes even free withdrawals from automated teller machines -- a package that to deal-hungry New Yorkers, long accustomed to being nickel-and-dimed by everyone in town, seems as rare as a vacant rent-controlled apartment.
"You have to shop around," Mr. Maldonado said. "Consumers don't have to be held captive by the exorbitant fees that some banks charge."
At Citibank, depositors must maintain a balance of $6,000 in all accounts, including loans, to avoid a monthly fee of $9.50, up from its previous requirement of $2,000 in checking accounts alone or $6,000 in all accounts excluding loans.
"What really bothers me," said Senator Santiago, the ranking Democrat on the State Senate Banks Committee, "is not so much the 200 percent increase in minimum balance requirements, but the message it sends that Citibank only really wants to do business with wealthy people and corporations."
Responding to the survey, a Citibank spokeswoman, Susan Weeks, said, "We offer a range of services and products, and these services are expensive."
Other banks that had the highest fees, according to the survey by the Consumer Affairs Department, were Bank Leumi USA, which requires a minimum balance of $5,000 to avoid a $15 monthly fee and a 50-cent charge on each check or each withdrawal from an A.T.M., and Chase Manhattan Bank which requires balances of $3,000 to $4,500 to avoid a monthly fee of $9.50 and a 50-cent charge on checks and A.T.M. withdrawals.
The least expensive banks were Independence Savings Bank and Fourth Federal Savings Bank, which both offer free checking with no minimums and with no-fee A.T.M. cards.
"I was so amazed when I met with an account representative and I asked if there was any fees or any minimum, and they said, 'No,' " said Cat Jackson, a resident of Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, who opened a checking account at Independence Savings. "I thought for sure they would squeeze me somewhere."
Terence J. Mitchell, an executive vice president at Independence Savings Bank, said the bank could afford to offer free checking because it had a lower level of risk in its loan portfolio than other lenders. "We run a tight ship," he said.
Banks analysts said free checking, a phenomenon that died in the early 80's but appears to be making a small comeback at neighborhood banks, is often a marketing strategy many smaller banks employ to compete with the bigger banks.
Dimitri Papadimitriou, the executive director of the Jerome Levy Economics Institute in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., said that at smaller banks, the primary customers for loans are low-to-moderate income people who are particularly price sensitive and are attracted to perquisites like free checking accounts.
But small banks are also not the most convenient. Independence, for example, has 38 branches, but only one in Manhattan, at 34th Street and Lexington Avenue. Chase Manhattan was ranked first in the Consumer Affairs department's "most convenient" category, with 278 branches and 1,200 A.T.M.'s in the city. Bank Leumi, the city's most expensive bank, was also its least convenient, with only two city locations.
"We decided several years ago to leave the retail market and gradually sold most of our branch network," said Ilene Moskowitz, first vice president and director of strategic marketing and planning at the bank. She said that was the reason for the bank's high minimums, as well. "Bank Leumi USA serves specialized segments, middle-market companies and internationally oriented businesses," she said.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Falling Bodies

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Thinking about the economic crisis in Southeast Asia reminds me of that joke about being on the 30th floor of a hotel, looking out your window and suddenly seeing a man falling past your room. "How you doing?" you ask him as he sails by. "Fine," he says. "So far." And so it is with the Asian economies. This crisis has just begun. Korea and its neighbors are still far from having hit bottom. Their crises are still confined largely to stock markets and currencies. But soon bankruptcies will mount, real estate prices will plummet and the real economy, real jobs and real people will hit the pavement. Even then the story won't be over. Because what's happening in Southeast Asia today is also a China crisis, an education crisis and a political crisis.
The China Crisis: A Thai businessman summed it up for me in one sentence: "China can make everything we do now -- only cheaper." China's low wage structure doesn't really threaten America because China doesn't make the high-end products America specializes in. But China helped trigger this latest crisis by using its cheap wages and cheap currency to undersell its neighbors. 
 Tom Banker runs Gemessence, a gem-cutting business in Bangkok. "The Chinese are now doing the cutting the Thais used to do," he told me. "Because the Thai currency was pegged to the dollar, my labor costs tripled from 1987 to 1997 without a tripling in productivity. I was trying to keep 220 Thai employees busy, but as labor costs kept going up, I couldn't justify cutting cheap stones here. My average worker here gets $200 a month. In China it's $50 a month. So I cut my staff here to 68 people, who only do the most sophisticated work. The rest I moved to China."
The Education Crisis: If Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand are to keep ahead of China, they must move up the knowledge ladder, so they can produce more sophisticated products and leave the low end for China. The problem is that Thailand has compulsory education only up to sixth grade. Worse, the education systems in Southeast Asia do not encourage innovation, creativity or independence of thought. They can mimic Bill Gates, they can consume Bill Gates, but they can't create Bill Gates. Or to paraphrase a recent analysis in The Economist magazine: In Japan and Southeast Asia the nail that stands up gets hammered. In America that same nail is driving a Ferrari in Silicon Valley.
Norani Othman, a Malaysian Muslim intellectual told me in Kuala Lumpur last week: "There is a jingle that runs after the news here that celebrates Information Technology -- IT. It says: 'Love IT; learn IT; IT is the only way to our future.' But it's just a mantra. The Government is not educating a generation that can indigenize real information technology, authenticate it and reproduce it themselves. Students learn by rote, like a bunch of robots."
The Political Crisis: Chanokphat Phitakwanokoon, a 40-year-old Thai-Chinese woman, sells cigarettes and Bao Chinese dumplings at a sidewalk stall off Bangkok's Wireless Road. How's business? I asked the other day. Down 30 percent, she said. I asked if she knew what a stock market was. "Yes," she answered without hesitation. "I own shares in Bangkok Bank and Asia Bank. My relatives were all buying, so I bought too. They are not worth much now." This is a dumpling seller with a fifth-grade education and no shoes on -- but she owns stocks. Yes, this crisis reaches very deep.
Will people like Chanokphat Phitakwanokoon lead a backlash against leaders who tell them the only way out of this crisis is more bitter I.M.F. medicine and more globalization? Hard to know. If this were the Middle East, demonstrators would have already burned down I.M.F. offices. But people here tend to be more pragmatic. The initial reaction is to cut back, save more, work harder. But for how long? The falling bodies still haven't hit the pavement.
This next six months is the most critical political moment for Southeast Asia since decolonization. If the liberal democrats now taking over in Korea and Thailand can turn things around quickly, great. But they're going to have to break some powerful forces -- the crony capitalists, politicians and bankers who benefited from the old system. If the pain of reform cuts too deeply and too widely, you could get a merger (as happened in Iran against the Shah) between the crony capitalists and the urban underclass against the liberal democrats. That's the danger.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Call for Environmental Study Delays Plan for a Florida Airport

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 24

 BODY:
In a new setback for the city of Homestead, one of the areas hardest hit by Hurricane Andrew five years ago, the Federal Government has ordered the city to postpone building an airport on the site of a closed Air Force base until an environmental study can determine whether the project would damage the Everglades and protected coastal areas.
The study, which is expected to begin next month, will be conducted by the Air Force and the Federal Aviation Administration. 
 The city's plan would use the existing Air Force runway and build a terminal, hangars, warehouses and cargo areas.
Officials in Miami-Dade County, where Homestead is located, estimate that the airport will cost $20 million. Politicians have lobbied since 1992 for the construction of an airport to lift the town's economy.
Three years ago, the Air Force conducted an environmental impact study, but after planners revised the original proposal, it decided to commission a new review.
The proposed changes included an increase in the number of cargo flights and the possibility of adding a runway.
"After five years of studies, negotiations and environmental cleanup, there has been no gain for South Dade," where Homestead lies, Mayor Alex Penelas of Miami-Dade County said. "This decision represents another severe blow to the economic recovery of this community."
Officials have argued that they should be allowed to begin building the airport while the study is in progress.
For environmental groups, however, the Government's decision, which was announced on Tuesday, signaled a small victory in a protracted battle involving politicians, Federal agencies and wildlife advocates.
The environmental groups have long argued that a new airport and its accompanying noise could threaten the health and reproductive ability of wildlife in the Everglades National Park, which lies 12 miles west of the 1,300-acre airport site, and the coastal Biscayne National Park, two miles to the east.
The decision by the White House to postpone construction for the study "was a victory for our national park system," said Alan Farago, the political conservation chairman of the Sierra Club in Miami, adding that it was "time to take a big step back from this massive airport."
Still, Mr. Farago said, the new environmental impact study does not assure the sanctity of both parks. County officials have drafted tentative plans for a second runway and other expansion by about 2015 that, officials estimate, could cost as much as $2.2 billion, he noted.
If the second phase is completed, Homestead, a city of about 28,000 people, could turn into a bustling, international thoroughfare.
"This is no small airport," Mr. Farago said. "They are trying to hide an elephant with a mouse."
The controversy has also pitted some members of the Cuban-American community in South Florida against critics who contend that large donors of the Democratic Party are serving as a powerful force to sway Washington to their side.
Before 1992, Homestead Air Force Base contributed an estimated $400 million to the local economy. After Hurricane Andrew struck South Florida in August 1992, the base was closed and 11,000 jobs were lost.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Hidden in the Glitter of a Bountiful Economy, Problems Remain

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Joblessness is lower than it has been for a quarter-century. Inflation is less than 3 percent and appears to be falling. Corporate earnings have been powering a sustained boom in the stock market that has added trillions of dollars to the wealth of the middle class.
But before succumbing entirely to the warm and fuzzy spirit of the holidays, it is worth noting that all is not perfect in the New Economy. Indeed, there is no compelling reason to believe the problems that stirred predictions of doom and gloom a decade ago are any closer to solution. 
 PRODUCTIVITY -- Yes, microprocessors are ubiquitous, revolutionizing everything from inventory control to movie animation. Yes, the globalization of trade and investment has left America's service industries at the top of the heap. Yes, Wall Street leads the world in financing invention and spreading risk.
But all that gee-whiz technology and organizational change has yet to make a dent in the measured growth in output per hour of work. Productivity growth in the sustained boom of the 1990's has averaged a bit more than 1 percent, about the same as the sluggish 1970's and 1980's and less than half the pace of the 1950's and 1960's.
Perhaps the measurements are light-years off -- perhaps the bean counters haven't captured the full value of surfing the net, repairing wayward genes or eating farm-grown salmon. But similar arguments could have been made about direct-dial long-distance calls in the 1950's, jet travel in the 1960's or heart bypass surgery in the 1970's.
Truth is, economists don't have a clue to why productivity is apparently in the doldrums, or whether the winds of progress will soon freshen. Yet in the long run, nothing is more important to economic well-being.
INFLATION VS. EMPLOYMENT -- In the 1980's economists were convinced that 6 percent unemployment was "natural" in the sense that a lower rate would lead to competition for workers that yielded unsustainable wage gains. Today, unemployment is 4.6 percent and the worry-of-the-month is deflation. Surely that's progress.
Maybe. For one thing, evidence from the past suggests that wage pressures build slowly. For another, world commodity prices have been falling sharply and the dollar has strengthened against other major currencies -- anti-inflationary benefits that cannot last and may well reverse.
Even if the trade-off between inflation and employment has permanently improved, the widely offered explanation is hardly reassuring. America workers, the reasoning goes, were so traumatized by downsizing, outsourcing and the globalization of production over the last decade that they are afraid to ask for raises.
SAVINGS -- Like productivity, private savings are difficult to measure. And, as with productivity, the anecdotal evidence of recovery from lean times in the 1980's has yet to be matched by the hard numbers.
There has been progress on a related front. The Government has pulled up its socks, transforming budget deficits that subtracted two to three percentage points from the national savings rate in the 1980's into projected surpluses. But those socks may well slip again. Indeed, unless Washington cuts deeply into the cost of Medicare, deficits that would embarrass even Ronald Reagan are virtually guaranteed.
Private savings in aggregate are, of course, the sum of individual savings. Thus if Americans were prepared to let retired baby boomers subsist on Spaghettios, the savings issue could be ignored. But most of those future retirees are somebody's parents. And the fact that they are currently squirreling away just half of what they need to sustain their current living standard will soon be everyone's problem.
INCOME INEQUALITY -- Between 1974 and 1994, families in the upper 5 percent of the distribution enjoyed an average annual gain in income of 1.2 percent. But those in the bottom fifth saw their incomes shrink.
The change is not quite as depressing at it appears. The cost of living has probably not risen as fast as the Consumer Price Index, implying that the real incomes of all groups has probably gone up. Moreover, America's real (if somewhat oversold) social mobility does allow the most tenacious to move up the ladder.
But those who wonder how anyone can raise a couple of kids on the after-tax proceeds from an $8-an-hour job will have a hard time finding the silver lining. Most of the evidence suggests that the lion's share of gains from productivity is going to those with talent. And even if training were readily available to all, tens of millions of Americans would still be condemned to work for less than a living wage.
Is this the best of possible economies? Certainly it is looking good compared with stagnant Europe and crisis-ridden Japan.
Face it, though: Dr. Pangloss is a poor excuse for Santa Claus.

HEADLINE: Pangs of Poverty at a Joyous Time

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
He woke up at 3:45 in the morning on Christmas Eve, threw on jeans, a parka and construction boots and trudged across the 135th Street Bridge from Harlem to the Bronx because he did not have $1.50 for the bus. His nickname is Popeye, and that's the only name he would give because he did not want everyone to know how bad Christmas would be.
His last construction job ended seven months ago, and he said he was hoping to get on with a construction company in the Bronx so that his 8-year-old son, the youngest of his six children, would find a Nintendo 64 video game waiting for him today. "I didn't get it," he said, as he lined up yesterday afternoon with dozens of Harlem residents for a free meal. 
 They came with little money, big appetites and the drawn faces of desperation to the Salvation Army's Harlem Temple at Lenox Avenue and 137th Street, where free turkey dinners were being served. "I feel bad when my kids ask for something and I can't give it to them," Popeye said. "And I don't want to make false promises I can't produce. That's the worst feeling in the world."
In the more privileged precincts of the city, there were signposts of a more jubilant holiday season. On the Upper West Side, the lines were a half-block long outside Zabar's and Citarella.
At the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, on Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, the story of Christmas was told in scriptural readings and carols, accompanied by organ music and choristers. "This is an oasis of tranquillity," said Kurt Slamer-Calbera, 38, of Brooklyn. "I come here every Christmas."
At the Central Presbyterian Church, at Park Avenue and 64th Street, New Yorkers took cats, dogs, turtles, parrots and ferrets to the annual blessing of the animals.
Andrea Stagoff's 8-year-old wire terrier, Kimberly, and 5-year-old bichon frise, Teter, sat quietly on her lap. "I think this is a wonderful outpouring of love for the animals," Ms. Stagoff said. "It shows just how much people bond with their pets. They personify the holidays because of the joy they bring to us all year round."
But at the Salvation Army's Harlem outpost, there was a wealth of hard-luck stories.
Marshell Gibson, a homeless, 38-year-old grandmother of three, sat down for a meal of turkey, stuffing, corn bread, mashed potatoes, ham and mixed vegetables. She had just come from Christmas shopping at a discount store on Lenox Avenue. She showed off a black doll she bought for $1.99 for her 5--month-old granddaughter, Ant; a $2.99 police car for her grandson, Ravon; a $4.99 race car for her granddaughter, Unique, and a $3.99 trinket for her 39-year-old niece.
"I've been saving up for the gifts," she said, beaming. An unemployed home-care attendant, Ms. Gibson has been sleeping at a Harlem shelter since September, when her five-story walk-up building on 121st Street was condemned. "I'm homeless but not helpless," she said. "Every morning when I wake up, I praise God. I tell him what I want to accomplish, but first I praise him."
Ms. Gibson has been able to earn a little money running errands for shelter residents.
Her only child, Nadine, 21, lived on the second floor of her building. She, too, is homeless, pregnant again and staying in a midtown shelter with her children.
At the Harlem Salvation Army Center, Priscilla Singh, 36, and Steve Gilmore, 43, looked lovingly at each other between bites of turkey. The couple, who met eight months ago, plan to get married. They sleep where they can.
Ms. Singh, who is recently divorced, says she used to have a drug problem, but no longer does. Old friends are the only people who will take them both in. It is hard to find co-ed shelters, they say.
"We can't be separated," said Mr. Gilmore, a father of five who is separated from his wife of 14 years. "We're going to get married."
Two months ago, Mr. Gilmore was working as a medical assistant. He is looking for another job. So is Ms. Singh, whose only clothes are those on her back: a Hard Rock Cafe T-shirt, black ski pants, a dungaree jacket and a corduroy coat. Her last job was as a store clerk, but now she says she has health problems.
Still, they are thankful they have each other. Last Christmas, both say they were better off financially, but miserable emotionally. They were with their respective spouses, but were not as happy as they are now. "We're going to rough this period out," he said. "But we're believing in God for something better."

HEADLINE: Big Year Allows Port to Cut Fees and Challenge Rivals

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
Sometimes good news begets more good news. Business in the Port of New York and New Jersey has been very, very good this year -- container traffic rose 13 percent through September compared with the same period in 1996. And that, in turn, has helped shippers in the port continue to tackle the high labor costs that for years hobbled the port's attempts to compete with others.
The New York Shipping Association, with the approval of the longshoremen's union, made a deep round of cuts last week in the shipping fees that pay for longshoremen's fringe benefits. The cuts, which take effect Jan. 1, could decrease the total cost of shipping a container through the port to inland cities by about $20, or more than 2 percent, an industry analyst said, without taking money out of the longshoremen's pockets. The cuts are expected to provide a powerful weapon in the port's effort to woo business away from other East Coast ports. Fees for containers -- which can hold anything from VCR's to toys to beer -- bound for local destinations will be cut even more. 
 "These are whopping cuts," said Randy Brown, a transportation economist at Paul F. Richardson Associates, a consulting firm based in Holmdel, N.J. "In this business, people die for two or three dollars. If you can come up with a $20 reduction in this industry, that's huge."
The cuts were made possible by three factors. One is that increased volume means fewer idle longshoremen, who, according to their contract, must be paid when they do not work from a kitty financed by the shipping fees. Now, with more work, that kitty can be reduced. Another is a simple economy of scale: more tons of goods mean that the fee per ton can be decreased. The last is that the total number of longshoremen, which has been dropping steadily since the advent of containerized shipping in the 1960's, when there were about 20,000, is continuing to decline -- there are now about 2,700. This has led to lower health care and pension costs, which are also paid out of the fringe benefits fund.
"For the first time in three decades, the supply and demand of labor are in equilibrium," said Ed Harrison, manager of port marketing and labor for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "For three decades, there was a snowball effect that drove cargo out of here," he said, referring to the cost of paying thousands of idle dockworkers. "The snowball is now going in reverse."
James A. McNamara, the spokesman for the International Longshoremen's Association, said the union had no problem with the cuts. "It's not a question of concessions by the union," he said. "It's that expenses are getting lower."
Combined with other moves expected to make the port more competitive -- progress on dredging channels to accommodate larger, modern ships, better rail connections, increases in longshoremen's productivity due to automation and the imminent breakup of Conrail's rail monopoly in and out of the Ports of Newark and Elizabeth -- port officials say the fee cuts should help continue the port's turnaround after decades of decline.
Already this year, the port's share of container cargo bound for the Midwest has increased to 17 percent among East Coast ports, from 12 percent, said Mr. Brown's boss, Paul F. Richardson. In all, the port moved more than 1.28 million container units, which are 20-foot truck containers or their equivalent, during the first nine months of 1997, up from 1.14 million units through the same period last year.
The fee cuts include a decrease in the assessment charged to containers being imported to or exported from American cities more than 260 miles from New York, to 50 cents a ton from $1 a ton; a reduction in the fee charged on cargo starting from or going to cities within 260 miles, to $2.50 a ton from $2.90 a ton; a drop in the assessment on cars to $2 per vehicle from $3; and a 63 percent cut in the charge for moving empty containers, to $15 per container from $40.
The shipping association, which represents 70 waterfront employers, has been chipping away at the fees for a decade. In 1987, the fee on shipments to inland cities, for which competition between ports is fierce, was $5.85 per ton. It has fallen 91 percent since then.
Mr. Brown said that with the current round of cuts, the port and overland cost for moving a 40-foot container bound for Europe from Kansas City onto a ship in New York Harbor has dropped to $1,016, from $1,033. The same shipment through one of its chief East Coast competitor, Norfolk, Va., would cost $1,030, Mr. Brown said. He added that the difference between the shipping costs from either East Coast port to Europe was negligible.
Conrad Everhard, the chairman of Cho Yang America, one of the biggest ocean carriers in New York Harbor and a major presence in Norfolk also, said the cuts would tempt him to move more containers through the company's dock in Bayonne, N.J. "This was a very smart move for the port," he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
IN A SHIFT BY U.S., AID WILL BE SPED TO SOUTH KOREANS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
In an about-face, the Clinton Administration joined other major industrial nations today in supplying South Korea with $10 billion in emergency aid and in asking major commercial banks to extend the deadlines by which Korean banks must repay their debts.
While American officials sought to cast the decision today as an acceleration of aid already committed to South Korea, it appeared to represent a failure of the Clinton Administration's original approach to the Asian financial crisis. 
 Two months ago, just before the Korean markets began to plunge, the Administration was privately warning officials in Seoul to get their house in order.
When a $57 billion bailout plan was announced under International Monetary Fund leadership on Dec. 3, Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin said that American taxpayer dollars would only be used as as part of a $5 billion "second line of defense" if South Korea exhausted funds provided by the I.M.F. and the World Bank.
Two weeks ago, Mr. Rubin summarily rejected a request by the South Korean Finance Minister to speed up aid, saying he thought that the step was unnecessary.
Today he did just that.
The United States has now agreed to lend $1.7 billion to Seoul by the second week of January, and such loans may yet prove necessary to stabilize the South Korean currency, the won, which has fallen 37 percent in value this month alone.
For its part, South Korea has agreed to further open its markets in return for this latest cash infusion.
"This decision is overwhelmingly in our economic and national security interest," Mr. Rubin told reporters today, justifying a decision that the Administration fears could renew debate in Congress over the use of American funds to bail out failing foreign economies and banks. "If you have economic instability, you run the risk of political and social instability." And South Korea, he said, is a country where "there are still enormous security concerns for the United States."
The new money for the Koreans will come from the Emergency Stabilization Fund, a currency reserve fund under the control of the President and the Treasury Secretary.
Created by the Administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt in the 1930's to support the American dollar, the fund was tapped during the bailout of Mexico two and a half years ago, and disbursements do not require Congressional approval. But while Mexico agreed to put up the revenue it reaped from oil production as collateral for the $12 billion it borrowed -- all of which has since been repaid, with interest -- South Korea is offering nothing except its word.
There was no immediate reaction from Congressional leaders or from junior members who complained most bitterly about the Mexican bailout. Most of their offices were closed for the holidays.
American officials said they were not concerned about repayment, citing the "deep relationship" of the United States with South Korea, an allusion to the more than 35,000 American troops stationed there as a defense against the Communist leadership of North Korea. The unstated assumption is that Seoul would pay any debts to its critical military ally before it repaid other lenders.
"The uncertainty of getting paid back," Mr. Rubin said, "is very low."
For the Treasury Secretary, however, today's announcement is an admission that his strategy for containing the Asian economic crisis -- and keeping it from leaping to Japan and other big industrial nations -- has so far failed to work.
Cutting short a Christmas week bone-fishing expedition, he returned to a frenzy of meetings at the White House that have included Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen; President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger; the White House chief of staff, Erskine Bowles, and at times the President.
Yet Administration officials said they were unsure whether the bailout plan would persuade private investors and lenders to resume lending to the South Koreans.
"We always recognized there was some risk the stabilization plan wouldn't work," Mr. Rubin said today. "It was a good program that should have worked." But the flight of money out of South Korea and the relentless selloff of its currency continued unabated, he noted. The new plan, he said, "should work," though he acknowledged that "there are no guarantees."
Korean markets were mixed today, with stocks losing a little more than 4 percent but the currency improving to an exchange rate of 1,836 won to the dollar.
American and Japanese officials characterized the emergency aid as an effort to buy time. While South Korea has enough cash to repay debts due by the end of next week, it is likely that its banks would default in January. The rapid $10 billion infusion -- including $3.3 billion from Japan, $2 billion from the I.M.F. and contributions from a variety of European nations -- is something of a stopgap while American, Japanese and European banks negotiate a way to relieve South Korean banks -- and thus Korean industry -- of $30 to $40 billion in short-term debt.
That effort began even as Mr. Rubin was announcing his decision. Six major American banks met today at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and agreed to come up with a plan to help the Koreans, prodded along by the Administration and the Federal Reserve. The banking companies included J. P. Morgan, Bankers Trust, BankAmerica, the Bank of New York, Chase Manhattan and Citicorp. Of those, Citicorp has lent the most to South Korea, though American banks are far less exposed to the Korean crisis than banks in Japan and Europe.
"The idea here was to show some American leadership because the American banks are the healthiest," said a senior Administration official involved in the negotiations, which are beginning to resemble how the Latin American debt crisis was resolved in the 1980's. On Thursday, a similar meeting of Japanese banks is expected in Tokyo.
While the United States and Japan are casting the negotiations between South Korea and the private banks as voluntary, it is clear that this is part of the package Mr. Rubin has assembled with the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and their Japanese counterparts.
The fact that the meeting today took place at the New York Federal Reserve -- which handles most international transactions for the Fed -- seemed to emphasize that the whole package of government and private aid was being carefully orchestrated.
The choices for private bankers range from agreeing to extend their loans, to forgiving some portion of the debt and writing it off as a loss, to finding ways to raise new money for South Korea that could ultimately insure repayment of the old money.
Another possibility, officials said, is for the Seoul Government to guarantee some of the debt of the private banks. But that would run counter to an American objective to insure that the rescue plan forces weak banks and weak Korean companies to go bankrupt, purging the economy and forcing the losses on foreign and domestic investors who provided those banks with cash.
Indeed, today's action opens the Administration to criticism that in the the name of bailing out South Korea it is also bailing out investors -- including major American, Japanese and European banks that made bad investments.
Only a few months ago, Mr. Rubin was warning of the "moral hazard" created by such bailouts, because private investors around the world would come to expect that if huge investments in an emerging market like Korea went bad, the United States and the I.M.F. would ride to the rescue.
"Look, I wouldn't spend a nickel to bail out investors or creditors," Mr. Rubin insisted to reporters today. "The purpose of this is not to help creditors; the purpose is to help Korea."
But he acknowledged that it was virtually impossible to save the country from default without saving those who invested in it.
American officials said that the South Korean President-elect, Kim Dae Jung, a onetime dissident who last week became the first opposition leader to be elected to run the country, had agreed to a number of concessions in return for the fast help.
Korea had agreed to dropping a series of restrictions on imported goods and on foreign investment there, both issues that American trade negotiators have sweated over for years. For example, Seoul is to lift the restrictions on foreign acquisition of Korean companies, if the takeovers are friendly mergers. It has also lifted the ceilings on foreign investments in bonds issued by Korean companies.
Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, told reporters that Seoul had also agreed to stop providing cheap, dollar-denominated loans to banks to pay off their debts. A new, high interest rate on such loans puts pressure on the weakest banks to pay off their debts or close their doors. President-elect Kim has also agreed to allow Korean companies to lay off workers, ending one of the practices that has kept companies bloated.
That agreement could easily turn into a major political problem for Mr. Kim. South Korea's enormously strong labor unions have already promised street demonstrations to protest layoffs, and American officials are concerned that much of the anger will be directed at the United States.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
New Convention Center Is Backed by Whitman

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Economically depressed Wildwood got a present from the state yesterday, when Governor Whitman signed a bill paving the way for construction of a new $58 million convention center. 
 The project will be financed through a 2 percent local tax on tourism, a $10 million low-interest loan from the State Economic Development Authority, and bonds to be sold by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. The 72,000-square-foot convention center will be operated by the sports authority, which also runs the new $318 million, 610,000-square-foot convention center in Atlantic City.
The two centers will be marketed together and are not expected to be in competition with each other because of the difference in size.

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH: Marvin Smith;
The Heartbeat of a Photogenic Life

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
THE narrow hallway of Marvin Smith's Harlem apartment is stacked with bubble-wrapped works of art: pictures by Romare Bearden, etchings by friends and an oil portrait of an art teacher Mr. Smith painted when he was just a sharecropper's son from Kentucky, newly arrived with his twin brother to see what New York City was all about.
"It was September of 1933, and when we got off that bus, we landed in Times Square," said Mr. Smith, 87, the living half of the duo of Morgan and Marvin Smith, photographers. "We looked and looked, and then we asked, 'Where are all the black people?' " 
 They were directed to Harlem.
They couldn't have come at a better time. The brothers, striking looking men in their 20's, were not only talented artists, but also identical twins. "The twinness of them was the charm -- at least part of the charm," Eartha Kitt said in a recent documentary on the Smiths. "I think they used it very well."
Decked out in the white ties and black tailcoats that were de rigueur for so many soirees in the 1930's, they were ceaselessly photographed themselves, whether surrounded by laughing chorines or posing for a liquor advertisement. Gordon Parks Sr. photographed them, both in plaid shirts, looking pensive.
Eventually, the Smiths set up shop a few doors down from the Apollo Theater, on 125th Street, where for three decades they photographed the city's African-American aristocracy. Their images of Fats Waller and Jackie Robinson are heroic; their picture of the swing-era Lindy Hoppers, heart-stopping.
When they arrived in the midst of the Depression with less than $100 between them, the brothers found jobs as park laborers. "We went to the state unemployment office and applied," Mr. Smith recalled. "Since we did have construction and gardening backgrounds, they did give us jobs in the Parks Department, cleaning cobblestones they took from Riverside Drive, to re-use." In their spare time, they took art classes. They shared an apartment on West 140th Street, eventually landing in two adjoining ateliers on 125th Street, with a placard outside that read: M. Smith Photo Studio -- Portraits of Quality.
In an exhibition of the Smiths' photography, "Harlem: The Vision of Morgan and Marvin Smith" at the Schomburg Center, Malcolm X Boulevard and 135th Street, through March 29, there is a room devoted to the Smiths' paintings, sculpture and surroundings. Photographs show their studio as a huge place with distinctive decor: Chinese vases turned into lamps, a fine velvet-covered settee, an ebony coffee table with legs in the form of elephant heads -- and an unusual pair of bookends, plaster casts of Joe Louis's fists. All those objects -- and more, collected over the years -- can be found in Mr. Smith's current home, a one-bedroom co-op in a massive red brick apartment house on Riverside Drive.
MARVIN Smith stood in his doorway, looking warily at a visitor. "Come in, come in," he said, standing aside, then smiling shyly. At 87, Mr. Smith is 6 feet 2 inches tall and speaks with the dignity of a Shakespearean actor. On this afternoon, he was dressed in a striped red shirt. Around his neck, he wore a tightly woven narrow kinte-cloth scarf he designed in burgundy, black and green.
These days, Mr. Smith walks slowly, and a trifle -- just a trifle -- unsteadily. "It's Parkinson's, but it's not too bad," he said. "People keep trying to do things for me," he said, "but I like to do for myself. Would you like some tea while I'm up?"
Mr. Smith doesn't spend a lot of time reminiscing. He is polite. He is succinct. He is not a rambler. He described Harlem in the early 1940's: "The War had sort of begun and a lot of friends were going away, and they were being photographed -- the families wanted pictures of their loved ones. It was very exciting. It's just that my number came up." Mr. Smith joined the Navy and became the first African-American to attend the Naval Air Station School of Photography and Motion Pictures in Pensacola, Fla.
Who were the celebrities he hung out with before the War?
"Lucky Millinder, Count Basie, Duke Ellington, Cab Calloway," he said. "We went to parties with them, went to hear them play, mostly at the Savoy," he recalled. "Harlem was at the very center of New York life."
The brothers went everywhere with cameras. Sometimes they were paid. If they were, Morgan Smith once said, "it amounted to about $1.50 for a picture."
Their day-to-day work was commercial, mostly set-up studio portraits, but there were also news shots: Adam Clayton Powell Jr., leading a campaign against lynching; Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, and Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia. The brothers became famous, at least in Harlem.
Gordon Parks Sr., in his introduction to the exhibition catalogue, describes the Smiths' business in the Depression: "The brothers' hearts were all future as they knocked upon the door of every major social event as well as those occasions involving problems of the impoverished and the dispossessed."
These days, Mr. Smith remembers only what it pleases him to remember. "The Depression? I am amazed how comfortable we were," he said. "The times that others considered bad, we didn't know anything about the Depression. In fact, we even had people in to eat! Dinner parties. Of course, people would bring things, but that was the practice at that time. The Depression was something in which we found ourselves -- a time in history." He paused. "We had everything we needed."
After the war, which brought prosperity, Mr. Smith traveled to Paris on the G.I. Bill of Rights to study painting with Ferdinand Leger, coming back to Harlem in 1954. In 1950, his brother had married a classically trained singer from Jamaica, and the couple lived in the second-floor studio. Mr. Smith took an apartment above them. When Morgan Smith and his wife had a baby, they moved out, and Marvin Smith moved back.
Starting in 1954, the brothers tried television: Morgan became a freelance sound engineer, Marvin a freelance set decorator for programs like the Molly Goldberg Show. Luxurious claret-colored velvet portieres with gold tassels over Mr. Smith's bedroom door came from a set.
In 1967, they gave up their lease on the photography studio. Eight years later, they retired from television, and Marvin Smith started his next career. With the 1970's had come macrame and crocheted vests; he began designing crocheting patterns for McCall's magazine. "Times change," he said, with a wisp of a shrug.
MORGAN and Marvin Smith were born in 1910 in rural Kentucky, in Nicholasville, near Lexington. "We lived in the country, and I guess we were a handful," Mr. Smith said. They were the first of their family to graduate from high school, and they found a series of mentors who encouraged their interest in art. One socialite introduced Marvin Smith to a Lexington artist, a woman who traded painting lessons for chores.
"Back then, you know, we couldn't be sitting here in the same room, a black person and a white person," he said. "I could use that lady's studio because I was working for her. We weren't considered equals."
The twins left Kentucky by bus. "After a slight disagreement, we went to the back of the bus," he said. "We really didn't have a choice."
Immediately inside the front door of Marvin Smith's apartment is a family photograph, taken during a visit to Kentucky, the year after they moved to New York. "Those are the girls, the girls we met at our art classes," Mr. Smith said with some embarrassment, gesturing to a pair of young women with identical plaid frocks. The two sisters -- identical twins -- had taken a fancy to the brothers. On the train ride home to Kentucky, he added, the young women persuaded the Smiths to have a double wedding. "But it didn't work -- we hadn't really had any time to, uh, to explore," Mr. Smith said. Three years later, on the same day, the couples divorced.
In the living room, there are more traces of his family. Over the couch is his painting of his parents on their one trip to New York. Mr. Smith added to the painting the family Bible "because they were both religious," he noted.
"I didn't have time to really finish it," said Mr. Smith, whose other paintings seem more polished, and as a result perhaps less appealing. "They weren't here very long."
The living room, which has a balcony that overlooks the Hudson River and, lately, the Fairway zipper sign advertising grocery deals of the week, is packed with memorabilia. He made the coffee table himself, laying glass atop a Victorian elephant head base. He hunted down a bronze elephant head in an antique shop and sat it on the desk in front of three glass panels he painted to look like stained glass. At the other end of the living room is a Jacobean-style bookcase with the casts of Joe Louis's fists that Mr. Smith made.
"At the time, Joe Louis was training up at Pompton Lakes, in New Jersey, and my brother and I used to go up there," he said. "Of course, when we went, we took models with us -- so we didn't need an introduction!"
The walls are laden with paintings. There is an autographed picture of Picasso, whom Mr. Smith met in the South of France after the war. There is a Haitian painting and, below it, a painting on glass by the sculptor James Denmark. On the back are papers about the painting, including the price when he bought it in 1975: $85. "I keep the papers there for my niece," he explained, referring to his brother's daughter, Monica. "In case something happens to me."
ALTHOUGH Mr. Smith likes his home, he is seldom there during the day. When he's not volunteering at the Hamilton Grange Nutrition Program, he's taking a foray to Fairway or showing people around the Schomburg Center exhibition. "I mean, it's kind of only fair of me," he said. "To share with people what I can, to tell them about the photographs." In all of the exhibitions, the photographs are attributed to both twins. "Sometimes I held the camera, sometimes he did," Mr. Smith explained.
The "discovery" of the twins and their photography started in 1992, the year before his brother died of cancer. They were honored by their home town, and a documentary was begun that was broadcast on PBS in 1995. A few months after Morgan Smith died, the University of Kentucky staged an exhibition; others followed. Their work was prominent in a Harlem photography show at the Smithsonian. "I've enjoyed it," Mr. Smith said.
Then it was time for a television interview, and he softly excused himself. "I only wish Morgan were standing right beside me, the way he always did," he said, and hesitated. "We were a real team."

A picture caption yesterday about Marvin Smith, a photographer who documented Harlem, and his late twin brother, misstated the brother's given name. As the article noted, he was Morgan Smith, not Melvin.

HEADLINE: Let Western Water Flow

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "U.S. Acts to Meet Water Needs in the West" (news article, Dec. 19): There is no shortage of water in the West -- only a shortage of political will to let the free market set its price. Decades of government control of distribution and pricing have created a situation that defies economics and common sense. 
 Across the West, a relative handful of rich farmers grow thirsty crops like alfalfa and cotton in a desert climate while millions of city dwellers are told they are the problem because they water their tiny lawns or flush their toilets too often. If the United States was serious about meeting the water needs of Western states, it would remove price controls and let water flow to its highest and best use.
 
MARC BEAUCHAMP
Falls Church, Va., Dec. 20, 1997

HEADLINE: Improving Mass Transit

 BODY:

To the Editor:
There are too many cars in Manhattan for too few streets, but simply raising tolls and lowering transit fares won't solve the problem ("Economy Purrs in High Gear, but Traffic Idles in Gridlock," front page, Dec. 22). Attitudes have to be changed to make transit the mode of choice, not just a reluctant option. Only through quality transit, day and night, can the need for a second car -- or even a first one -- be reduced. 
 Bus service is erratic on traffic-clogged streets. Light-rail efforts lag the rest of the world. Subways now have less rush-hour service than in the 1960's. Commuter trains may look modern, but their operations are stuck in the past.
Most of all, the region has a collection of lines, with mismatched schedules and fares, not an integrated whole.
 
STEPHEN B. DOBROW
Woodside, Queens, Dec. 22, 1997
 
The writer is a professor of engineering at Fairleigh Dickinson U.
