HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Many Shows and Many Indias

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER

 BODY:
If you like New York City, chances are you'll like India. Midtown Manhattan at lunchtime and an Indian village on market day are surprisingly alike. Cars and bikes charge by; personal space is at a premium; the noise level is high, the sheer variety of people exhausting. There are days when it's just too much, and you'd rather be anywhere else. But when you leave, if you leave, you can't wait to return.
The comparison has seemed particularly apt over the last year. The 50th anniversary of the independence of India and Pakistan from British rule arrived in August, and celebration surrounding the occasion has brought a steady flow of cultural riches to New York, including an unprecedented concentration of Indian art, old and new. 
 Two of the year's most spectacular exhibitions are on view, side by side, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. One, "King of the World: A Mogul Manuscript From the Royal Library, Windsor Castle," is a traveling show of the painted page from a single renowned 17th-century book. The other, "Flowers Underfoot: Indian Carpets of the Mogul Era," organized by the Met, is a gathering of some of the most beautiful rugs imaginable and, given the fragility of the work, a once-in-a-lifetime event.
To this list one must add "Mandala: The Architecture of Enlightenment," at the Asia Society, a much-anticipated show that, top-heavy with Tibetan material, ends up being a disappointingly incomplete study of its subject. Still, it offers some gorgeous objects, a few Indian in origin, all of them ultimately Indian in inspiration.
Perhaps the real news of the season, though, lies in the local appearance of contemporary art either from or about India in three recently opened exhibitions: "Out of India: Contemporary Art of the South Asian Diaspora" at the Queens Museum of Art," "Women Artists of India: A Celebration of Independence" at A Gallery in Chelsea, and "Francesco Clemente: Indian Watercolors" at the Met.
Widely varied in scale, content and polish, the shows together define the very different meanings that "Indian" can have. And they give at least a hint of the groundswell of creative activity not only on the subcontinent but also within its vast and widening sphere of influence abroad.
"Out of India" at the Queens Museum is by far the most ambitious show. Astutely selected and shaped by the curator, Jane Farver, it is a hybrid international showcase. Of its 27 artists, the majority were born in India, though fewer than half live there now. Others, Indian by descent, are from Myanmar (formerly Burma), Uganda, Ireland and the United States. Most take India as the subject of their work, but far less as a specific place than as a symbol, sometimes political but more often personal. Only one of the artists, Homai Vyarawalla (born 1913), actually witnessed the drama of August 1947. She was then a leading photojournalist in India, and her images of Jawaharlal Nehru addressing a jubilant crowd in Delhi, and of the body of Mohandas K. Gandhi being prepared for cremation, give a vivid sense of the mood of a nation whose self-image was cast in a romantic epic mold.
Much has happened since -- sectarian violence, economic upheaval, the extended medical emergency of AIDS -- to eat away at that initial tragedy-shadowed optimism. And the heightened, even exultant mood that runs through Ms. Vyarawalla's pictures is nowhere to be found in the work of her younger colleagues.
For example, in the photographs by Satish Sharma (born 1951), which hang across the gallery from hers, political figures appear not in person but as spectral public icons. A sculptured bust of Nehru crumbles from neglect; the face of Rajiv Gandhi peers out from a torn poster under a commercial sign reading "dynasty."
The work of Ayisha Abraham moves further back in time: her enlarged details of colonial-era photographs catch the uneasy social disparities of the English-Indian world of the Raj. Dayanita Singh, by contrast, turns her lens to the present to capture India's rapidly growing urban middle class, in whose lives Western and non-Western styles merge with a kind of surreal aplomb.
The Delhi-based journalist Pablo Bartholomew takes a similarly documentary approach in his pictures of Indians in the United States, from a Jain holy man enjoying tacos in upstate New York to hundreds of South Asian Muslims praying in the park that surrounds the Queens Museum. But other artists more clearly assume a critical, outsider stance.
Allan deSouza -- born in Kenya, now living in Los Angeles -- shoots the chilly, empty interiors of the arrival areas in American and European airports, which are often an immigrant's first glimpse of a new home. Sunil Gupta's grainy photomontages suggest the subjugated but vivifying Indian presence in England today.
And then there is work that invites ambivalent readings. Such is the case with Zarina Bhimji's illuminated transparency of what might be taken as the forbidding interior of a power station. It is actually a shot of the stacks of the British Library, where both Gandhi and Karl Marx formulated their ideas. Mohini Chandra's framed photographs may appear to be blank, and they are, in fact, the backs of snapshots, creating a hidden family portrait.
Portraiture, of the self or others, is a repeated theme in the show. Shani Mootoo, for example, creates a composite image of herself as a kind of nature spirit, half man and half woman, framed by panoramic views of wilderness in Canada, where she lives. And Chila Kumari Burman contributes a terrific collage of dozens of pictures of her own face in a Pop-flavored, kaleidoscopic play of identities.
(Ms. Burman, incidentally, along with Mr. deSouza, Mr. Gupta and several other British artists of Indian descent, is also included in "Transforming the Crown: African, Asian and Caribbean Artists in Britain, 1966-96," a three-part exhibition at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, the Franklin H. Williams Caribbean Cultural Center/African Diaspora Institute in Manhattan and the Studio Museum in Harlem, where the installation, by Jorge Daniel Veneciano, is especially good.)
Role-playing is also the essence of Poulomi Desai's series of portraits of Indian transvestites, which she titles "Shakti Queens." Shakti is a Sanskrit term for feminine spiritual energy. One senses this subversive energy, too, in the immense sculpture of a female head by Ravinder G. Reddy, in which the face has the features of a low-caste village woman but the golden skin of a goddess.
Apart from Mr. Reddy's work, sculpture in the show takes the form of installation. Rina Banerjee comes through with a packed, dangerous-looking environment of found materials and sari cloth; Vivan Sundaram with a walk-in paper house with a video image of a cooking fire; N. N. Rimzon with a snaking line of earthenware pots and brooms, an allusion to the status of the so-called untouchables, who were required to sweep the ground they walked on, and Shaheen Merali with an atmospheric video piece accompanied by his own music.
And some print work is included: chalky gray etchings by the New York-based artist Zarina showing the floor plans of homes she has lived in in Asia, Europe and the United States, Vijay Kumar's silhouetted crowds of figures set against newspaper reports of religious violence. But it is in the medium of painting that one finds some of the best entries.
This is certainly true of the three small pieces by Shahzia Sikander, the young artist (born in 1969 in Pakistan) now living in Houston, who was a standout at the recent Whitney Biennial and whose strong solo show closed last week at Deitch Projects in SoHo.
In Pakistan, Ms. Sikander studied the traditional art of miniature painting, a convention-bound art form requiring the use of hand-ground pigment and burnished paper and now often geared to the tourist market. She has revamped it in extremely imaginative ways by taking its signature image, the figure of the endlessly available woman awaiting the arrival of a lover, and setting it on a collision course with the psychic chaos of the contemporary world.
A piece like "Uprooted Order Series 3, No. 1," which is only inches high, interweaves Hindu, Islamic and personal emblems. The central woman grasping the branch of a tree is an ancient Indian symbol of fertility, but the cordlike roots dangling below her body seem to cripple rather than sustain her. The slightly raw, disjunctive, unfinished quality of the some of the work becomes part of its power.
Interestingly, "Out of India" introduces a second Pakistani artist, Miriam Ishaque, also in her 20's and a recent graduate of the Whitney Independent Study Program. Using egg tempera on panel, she adapts the precisely limned female figure of the miniature tradition but isolates it against a bare or lightly gridded flesh-pink ground. The effect is subdued, almost hesitant, but Ms. Ishaque is an artist to watch.
The show's selection of paintings is rounded out by two artists who live and work in India. The stainlike, calligraphic watercolors of Nalini Malani, 51, offer deliberately generalized scenes of coercion and violence within a patriarchal society. Atul Dodiya's semi-realistic oil-on-canvas paintings depict a polluted Bombay and the many-armed goddess Durga, who is usually shown holding a weapon in every hand, in the form of an airport metal detector.
 
Modernism Preserved
Ms. Malani's work also appears in the show at A Gallery, an exhibition originally organized by Mary-Ann Milford-Lutzker for Mills College Art Gallery in Oakland, Calif., last fall. It arrives in New York in radically truncated form and in an overcrowded installation. It is worth seeing, however, not only for its fine and influential artists but also because it touches on stylistic aspects of Indian art only glancingly addressed in the Queens show.
In the decades after independence, many vanguard painters, breaking away from both British academic models and traditional Indian styles, adopted Western modernism as the appropriately progressive style for a new nation. And in the form of a versatile, readily personalized, often semi-abstract figuration, it maintains its currency in India today, though its cachet has faded in the West.
It is the style practiced by several of the artists in the A Gallery show, among them Arpana Caur, Jayashree Chakravarty, Suruchi Chand, Kanchan Chander, Anupam Sud, Vasundhara Tewari, Gogi Saroj Pal and Rekha Rodwittiya. The results, inflected with specific Indian content, require a carefully judged presentation to look persuasive in trend-conscious New York. Unfortunately, they don't get that here.
Even under the circumstances, though, some things shine through. They include Ms. Malani's touching figure of a child dressing, Nilima Sheikh's lightly touched depictions of childbirth in tempera on handmade paper, and aquatints by Naina Dalal, two of which address the vulnerable status of unwanted female infants in India. Also worth seeking out are early abstract paintings by Arpita Singh, whose first New York solo show has been extended into January at Bose Pacia Modern Gallery in SoHo.
 
Inspiring an Italian Artist
If modernism was an import to the subcontinent, Indian art has, in its turn, been an inspiration for several Western artists. One is the Italian-born painter Francesco Clemente, represented in a small show of 19 watercolors organized by Holliday T. Day for the Indianapolis Museum of Art and now installed at the Metropolitan.
Since 1973, Mr. Clemente has spent part of every year in the southern city of Madras, and the big, grid-divided paintings in this show incorporate many Indian images: the elephant-headed Hindu god Ganesh, Buddhist lotuses and wheels, tantric configurations. In characteristic fashion, Mr. Clemente abstracts them slightly, smoothing and sweetening them in the process, as if to insure their viability as universal emblems.
Whether the results look too smooth, particularly when placed beside the densely textured, emotionally urgent paintings of Ms. Sikander (or those of Bhupen Khakhar, born in 1934, for whom a New York solo is long overdue) is a question. Mr. Clemente's work at the Met looks too easygoing for its own good, but he has produced far more provocative things, particularly when giving visual embodiment to the intensely erotic implications of Hindu devotional poetry.
In any case, the internationalist, crossover example he has consistently set is important, particularly in New York, where the most "advanced" art too often carries the whiff of a hermetic art-school parochialism. He has helped establish the climate for the reception of Indian work here and has undoubtedly given certain younger artists in India itself reason to believe they would find an audience abroad.
That audience is still, it is true, relatively small, but it will grow. At the moment Ms. Sikander must bear the unenviable burden of being a breakthrough figure, with work dynamic enough to capture the attention of viewers who have little direct knowledge of her sources. But there are other artists waiting in the wings to join her in an art world that is now global.
That's the basic message of "Out of India," and it is summed up in the work of the conceptual artist Navin Rawanchaikul, the show's youngest participant. Born of Indian parents in Thailand in 1971, he lives in Japan. In the conceptual piece created for the show, he has asked members of the Indian temple in his home city in Thailand to send postcard greetings to the show (many of the responses are on view) and invites visitors to the Queens Museum to send cards back in reply. (Just fill them out; the museum does the mailing.)
It's a simple gesture of reciprocity but a liberatingly expansive one, in which everyone is an artist and far-flung corners of the world become a common ground.
 
Where They Are
 
Here are the exhibitions discussed in the art review.
 
"Out of India: Contemporary Art of the South Asian Diaspora" remains at the Queens Museum of Art, New York City Building, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens, (718) 592-9700, through March 22. The exhibition is sponsored by Bell Atlantic.
"Women Artists of India: A Celebration of Independence" remains at A Gallery, second floor, 521 West 23d Street, Chelsea, (212) 206-8350, through Jan. 5.
 
The following shows are at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710: "Francesco Clemente: Indian Watercolors" (through Feb. 8); "Flowers Underfoot: Indian Carpets of the Mogul Era" (through March 1); "King of the World: A Mogul Manuscript from the Royal Library, Windsor Castle" (through Feb. 8, after which it travels to the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (Feb. 26-May 17), the Kimbell Art Museum, Fort Worth (May 31-Aug. 23) and the Indianapolis Museum of Art (Sept. 6-Nov. 29).
"Transforming the Crown: African, Asian and Caribbean Artists in Britain, 1966-96" remains on view at three locations through March 15: the Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse at 165th Street, (718) 681-6000; the Franklin H. Williams Caribbean Cultural Center/African Diaspora Institute, 408 West 58th Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-7420, and the Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500.
Arpita Singh remains on view at Bose Pacia Modern Gallery, 580 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-3224, through Jan. 17. The gallery is open Tuesdays through Saturdays, 12 to 6 P.M.

PUB-DATE: December 26, 1997

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 47; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 6502 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums
 
"ART ON THE EDGE: FRAMING 19TH-CENTURY AMERICA," National Academy Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880 (through Jan. 11). An imposing frame, preferably gilded, was an important part of the "sell" of a 19th-century painting. The right frame in which to dress a painting for its all-important easel display was a must for artists, who purveyed works to patrons directly from their studios. Often, they designed their own frames. This selection, ranging from 1860 to the 1890's, presents a variety from the collection of Eli Wilner & Company, makers of period frames. They range from elaborate Barbizon-style models used to echo natural forms in paintings, to those reflecting the taste for Moorish designs in the 1880's, to a classically ornamented gilt frame by Stanford White with an outer shadow box of wood. But the show, pegged to the rising interest in frame connoisseurship, could use much better labeling about the how and why of these elaborate mounts, and especially the design elements that went into them. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 P.M.; Fridays to 8 P.M. Admission: $5; $3.50 for children under 16, students and the elderly (Grace Glueck). 

ROSA BONHEUR: "ALL NATURE'S CHILDREN," Dahesh Museum, 601 Fifth Avenue, at 48th Street, (212) 759-0606 (through Feb. 21). The painter Rosa Bonheur (1822-1899) was a legend in her own time, thanks not only to her skill at painting animals but also to her gender-flouting behavior. This show does not include her best-known canvas, the gigantic "Horse Fair" (1853), permanently on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But it has preparatory sketches for the work, as well as paintings and sculptures of sheep, deer, fox, cows, bulls and Buffalo Bill, rendered from life astride his horse. Although uninventive, Bonheur's work was technically proficient and diligently observed, thanks in part to the considerable menagerie she kept at her estate near Fontainebleau. She got the anatomy right: her sheep are properly ovine and her dogs convincingly doggy, particularly the thoroughly unthoroughbred-looking hound named Barbaro in a lively 1870 painting that depicts the dog cooling down from a hunt. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Free admission ( Glueck).
"A DECADE OF COLLECTING: RECENT ACQUISITIONS IN CONTEMPORARY DRAWING," The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, (212) 708-9480 (through Jan. 13). Nearly half the museum's 200 works on paper made in the 1980's and 1990's are on view, so the exhibition adds up to a fair index of institutional preferences in this area and, by default, a snapshot of one aspect of recent art. There are few surprises, but piece by piece, and given the inevitable ups, downs and lacunas (a show five times the size would still only graze the surface of what's out there), the choices are good, and a handful (by Paul McCarthy, David Moreno, Patti Smith, Paul Thek) are refreshingly offbeat. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays, to 8:30 P.M. Admission: $9.50; $6.50, students and the elderly (Holland Cotter).
"FOUR ACTS IN GLASS: INSTALLATIONS BY CHIHULY, MORRIS, POWERS AND VALLIEN," American Craft Museum, 40 West 53d Street, Manhattan, (212) 956-3535 (through Jan. 18). Aiming to reveal the more dynamic uses of art glass beyond the making of unique objects, this uneven four-person show promises more than it delivers. The centerpiece is the best: a flamboyant glass tree by Dale Chihuly that rises almost floor-to-ceiling in the museum's atrium, thrusting out myriad "leaves" of snaky glass ampuls. An additional exhibit surveying Mr. Chihuly's work from 1965 to the present reveals his skill at coaxing glass into brilliant efflorescent shapes of dazzling color. The Swedish glass designer Bertil Vallien presents a regimented array of glass heads on pedestals, meant to evoke the 32-year trance of an injured schoolgirl who, on awakening, described visions of "great darkness and blue men." William Morris presents artifacts of blown glass, from animal skulls to prehistoric vessels, lined up on mural-size panels. Pike Powers's contribution is a kitschy mini-rendition of Coney Island sideshows, replete with figures of babies in bottles and freaky creatures in glass bell jars. But does this show "challenge our conception of the relationship of glass to its surroundings," as a wall label suggests it will? Nope. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays, to 8 P.M. Admission: $5; students and the elderly, $2.50; children under 12, free (Glueck).
HOWARD GILMAN GALLERY, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710. The inaugural exhibition (through Feb. 1) of the museum's new suite devoted exclusively to photography includes not only works by some of photography's early giants (William Henry Fox Talbot, Gustave Le Gray, Julia Margaret Cameron and Nadar), but also some odd specimens, including a picture of a crocodile dissection and a daguerreotype of a blind man. An intimate and relaxed show, this is a reflection of the random and urgent beginnings of photography, as well as the Gilman collection's luxurious depth. Hours: Fridays and Saturdays, 9:30 A.M. to 8:45 P.M.; Sundays, and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M. Suggested admission: $8 for adults; $4 for students and the elderly (Sarah Boxer).
* "NEW CONCEPTS IN PRINTMAKING 1: PETER HALLEY," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, (212) 708-9400 (through Feb. 8). From a famously intellectual 80's art star who hasn't been too visible lately, a big, jazzy installation that shows his signature cell image -- variously interpreted as a jail, a battery or a power plant -- exploding or melting down. Its demise is clocked in a nine-panel comic-book sequence that recurs in several kinds of prints, including acres of wallpaper hung with art, a la Warhol. A wall painted radioactive yellow adds to the nuclear-accident tone. In addition, prints, illustrations and maps from the artist's collection -- for example, an 18th-century diagram of a sewer system -- further explicate his interests and inspirations. This is one of Mr. Halley's best efforts and certainly his most revealing. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays, to 8:30 P.M. Admission: $9.50; $6.50, students and the elderly (Roberta Smith).
MONA HATOUM, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Feb. 22). This survey of work by the artist Mona Hatoum -- born in Beirut of Palestinian descent, now living in London -- was to celebrate the New Museum's reopening after a major interior expansion. Things happen; the refurbishment isn't finished. But the show is in place, and Ms. Hatoum's spare, evocative sculptures and installations look good. This is deeply emotional art that often speaks quietly but hides little: the body is relentlessly explored; the psychological wounds of lost childhood and of adult displacement probed. The vision is of a world at war, even when the battle is private and internal. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 P.M.; Thursdays through Saturdays, noon to 8 P.M. Admission: $5; $3 for artists, students and the elderly; free for those 18 and under (Cotter).
THE FURNITURE OF GEORGE HUNZINGER: INVENTION AND INNOVATION IN 19TH-CENTURY AMERICA, the Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, (718) 638-5000 (through Feb. 15). This 40-object exhibition, accompanied by an exhaustive catalogue, is the first in-depth look at one of the great proto-modern designers of 19th-century America. Hunzinger, who was German-born, helped develop designs and techniques now basic to modern life, like the folding chair and the use of interchangeable parts. Most importantly, he cultivated structural leanness and truth in materials that shunned 19th-century revivalism and predicted the work of Josef Hoffman and Charles Rennie Mackintosh. Quite a bit of this is spelled out in Hunzinger's alternately forward-looking and not-so-forward-looking designs, most of them for chairs, which show furniture shedding its Victorian padding like a butterfly emerging from its chrysalis (Smith).
"MASTER HAND: INDIVIDUALITY AND CREATIVITY AMONG YORUBA SCULPTORS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through March 1). African art is usually viewed as the anonymous product of a "tribal" entity. But in presenting the work -- masks, free-standing figures, containers and architectural elements -- of some 30 male and female master artists of the Yoruba culture in Nigeria, the Met establishes that they had their own individual styles that were recognized and esteemed by their countrymen. This is not Africa's most sophisticated art, but some outstanding exhibits include a case full of striking performance masks for the Gelede and Egungun cults, a poignant display of small memorial carvings of departed twins, and a veranda post depicting a royal personage by Olowe, a Yoruba master. Hours: Fridays and Saturdays, 9:30 A.M. to 8:45 P.M.; Sundays, and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M. Suggested admission: $8 for adults; $4 for students and the elderly (Glueck).
"MEDIEVAL BEST SELLER: THE BOOK OF HOURS," Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, Manhattan, (212) 685-0610 (through Jan. 4). Drawing on the Morgan's stunning manuscript collection, this show is a systematic tour through the most popular devotional book of medieval and Renaissance Europe. One moves from a well-thumbed 15th-century starter "Book of Hours" for children, to the urbane grandeur of the "Farnese Hours," to the charming figures of Yolande de Soissons and her cat-size dog glancing up to see a statue of the infant Jesus waving at them from an altar. In this sociable exchange between the human and the divine, a whole universe of hope and belief comes to life. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays, to 6 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Suggested admission: $6; $4 for students 12 and over and the elderly; under 12, free (Cotter).
"MONET AND THE MEDITERRANEAN," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 18). Yet another Monet show, this one with 65 mostly lesser-known paintings inspired by several trips he took, the first in 1883 to the Riviera, the last to Venice in 1908. In general, these Mediterranean views have been overshadowed by his other paintings for a reason. They're pretty, and occasionally boring, though one sees Monet adjusting to a new landscape, contriving a palette appropriate to the warm, enveloping southern light and to the tropical locale and pushing toward the sort of serialism that was to be his most creative reaction to Seurat and the other Post-Impressionists. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Sundays, 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. Holiday hours: today, Sunday, Jan. 2 and Jan. 4, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M.; Jan. 1, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $8; $4, students; $2, the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).
"NEW PHOTOGRAPHY 13," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, (212) 708-9480 (through Jan. 13). This low-key show includes work by Rineke Dijkstra, Vik Muniz, Kunie Sugiura and An-My Le. Ms. Le's pictures of her homeland, Vietnam, with all overt traces of war removed, are especially moving. But Mr. Muniz is the alchemist of the group, incorporating sugar, chocolate and dirt into his work and giving them a witty symbolic spin. (A solo show of Ms. Sugiura's work is at Leslie Tonkonow Artworks and Projects, 601 West 26th Street, in Chelsea, through Jan. 10.) Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays, to 8:30 P.M. Admission: $9.50; $6.50 for students and the elderly (Cotter).
"ON THE EDGE: CONTEMPORARY ART FROM THE WERNER AND ELAINE DANNHEISSER COLLECTION," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, (212) 708-9400 (through Jan. 20). This important gift includes more than 80 works by artists like Bruce Nauman, Jeff Koons, Joseph Beuys, Sigmar Polke, Cindy Sherman and Robert Gober, filling out the Modern's accounting of recent art with often-challenging works in sculpture, video, installation art and large-scale photography. The relentless adherence to anointed names, however, gives an impersonal, predictable feeling to the collection and doesn't do much to change the Modern's own blue-chip orientation. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays, to 8:30 P.M. Admission: $9.50; $6.50, students and the elderly (Smith).
RICHARD POUSETTE-DART, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Feb. 22). Considered one of the best of the lesser-known Abstract Expressionists, Pousette-Dart (1916-1992) painted imposingly physical and mythically charged pictures. But he was more a symbolist than an Expressionist, and his art was driven less by darkness and conflict than by light, harmony and spiritual optimism. This could produce painting of vacuous prettiness, but it led as well, especially in the later phase of his career, to works of powerful emblematic presence, as can be seen in this 33-painting retrospective. Hours: Fridays and Saturdays, 9:30 A.M. to 8:45 P.M.; Sundays, and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M. Suggested admission: $8; $4 for students and the elderly (Ken Johnson).
* "THE PRIVATE COLLECTION OF EDGAR DEGAS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 11). This unusual and handsome though overly large show proves that in the 1880's and 90's Degas was not entirely the old misanthrope he is said to have been. He was out buying art with a voraciousness to rival high rollers of the 1980's, but he had intelligence and taste. By his death in 1917 he had acquired a museum's worth of paintings, drawings and prints by Ingres, Delacroix, Manet and others. Around 300 are here, including Degas's Degases, a prime selection. The collection speaks to his own art. He bought 21 drawings and oil sketches related to Ingres's "Apotheosis of Homer," for example, and clearly grasped the episodic quality of these fragmentary images, which he turned into potent metaphors for modern life. He didn't acquire the greatest works by artists, but the ones that meant something particular to him, which, after all, is the right way to collect. And his passion for it should cause people to think twice about the common gripe that he is a chilly artist. Hours: Fridays and Saturdays, 9:30 A.M. to 8:45 P.M.; Sundays, and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M. Suggested admission: $8; $4 for students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
ERNESTO PUJOL: "THE PICNIC," Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse (at 165th Street), the Bronx, (718) 681-6000 (through March 15). This single room-size piece pulls together references to the artist's Cuban heritage, Joshua Logan's film "Picnic" (of William Holden and Kim Novak fame), American nostalgia for frontier life, patriarchal culture and adolescent sexual confusion. That's a lot to tackle, but luckily Mr. Pujol comes through with a spare, carefully worked-out and amusing installation, which captures the eye, then gradually releases ideas. Hours: Wednesdays, 3 to 9 P.M.; Thursdays and Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 6 P.M. Suggested donation: $3, $2 for students, $1 for the elderly (Cotter).
* "ROBERT RAUSCHENBERG: A RETROSPECTIVE," Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 7); Guggenheim SoHo, 575 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 4). An extraordinary, imperfect and larger-than-life show by this extraordinary, imperfect and larger-than-life artist, now 71, the first great ecumenical figure of postwar American art and perhaps the only person with the energy to make it through the exhibition without the works eventually blending together. However much you may reject it, it still seems there for you and for the rest of the world, like a Saint Bernard, big, irrepressible and good-natured. At the same time, the show reveals what has tended to be overlooked: a delicate sense of loss in Mr. Rauschenberg's art that is revealed, for example, in his photographs of forlorn places and his images of single figures rapt in thought. Much of the work of the last 20-odd years doesn't match the inventive brilliance of the early years, so it's best to pick and choose. Hours uptown: Sundays through Wednesdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, to 8 P.M. Hours downtown: Wednesdays through Fridays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Saturdays, to 8 P.M. Admission: $15; $10 for students and the elderly; includes admission to both parts of the retrospective (Kimmelman).
* "EGON SCHIELE: THE LEOPOLD COLLECTION, VIENNA," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, (212) 708-9480 (through Jan. 4). Schiele, who was born in Austria in 1890 and died there at age 28, has been in vogue over the last few decades. But his work, with its X-rated subject matter, is only sporadically seen in bulk. This gathering of nearly 150 paintings and works on paper amounts to a total-immersion experience. The work -- virtuosic, narcissistic, corrosive, slight -- has a hectic feel, like a fever accompanied by chills, and it lines up in intriguing ways with the current trends in contemporary art. Schiele is one of modernism's more exotic honorable mentions, but he gives off a surprising heat. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays, to 8:30 P.M. Admission: $9.50; $6.50 for students and the elderly (Cotter).
* RICHARD SERRA: "TORQUED ELLIPSES," Dia Center for the Arts, 548 West 22d Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-5912 (through June 14). After seeing the oval volumes of Borromini's Church of San Carlo in Rome, Richard Serra wondered what it would be like to make a sculpture in the form of a torqued ellipse: imagine a wall of steel forming an oval enclosure, twisting so that its top and bottom are not aligned. It took a year for him to make one of these. Three are on view, and they're amazing (though oddly colored) works of architectural sculpture; each is slit so that it can be entered. The shapes are weirdly impossible to resolve in the mind: to walk around the outside of one doesn't tell you what the inside is like, and vice versa; one searches in vain for the best place to stand. The unsettling effect recalls being exposed in a field when a storm approaches, an odd comparison with multi-ton sculptures, but the amazing thing here is how so much bulky metal can expand the space it occupies and set it in motion. Hours: Thursdays through Sunday, noon to 6 P.M. Admission: $4; $2, students over 10 and the elderly (Kimmelman).
* "TAINO: PRE-COLUMBIAN ART AND CULTURE FROM THE CARIBBEAN," El Museo del Barrio, Fifth Avenue at 104th Street, (212) 831-7272 (through May 3). When Columbus landed on the island that is now Haiti and the Dominican Republic, the Caribbean was home to the Taino, a people who had a complex culture and a distinctive art. This exhibition, the first comprehensive presentation of Taino work in North America, is a landmark achievement. It includes carved ceremonial stools, utensils associated with the ritual use of hallucinogenic drugs and mysterious triangular carved stones that compress human and animal anatomy into near-abstract forms. The show's centerpiece is a sacred figure made of materials from Africa, Europe and the New World, ingredients that virtually define the meaning of Hispanic as it is applied to a large segment of America's population today. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: $4; $2, students and the elderly (Cotter).
* "TRANSFORMING THE CROWN: AFRICAN, ASIAN AND CARIBBEAN ARTISTS IN BRITAIN, 1966-1996," Franklin H. Williams Caribbean Cultural Center/African Diaspora Institute, 408 West 58th Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-7420. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M, Saturdays, noon to 5 P.M.; donation: $2. Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse, at 165th Street, the Bronx, (718) 681-6000. Hours: Wednesdays, 3 to 9 P.M., Thursdays and Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 6 P.M.; suggested donation: $3, $2 for students, $1 for the elderly. Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 6 P.M.; admission: $5, $3 for students and the elderly, $1 for those under 12. (All through March 15.) Much of the work in this sprawling exhibition is political, and how could it be otherwise? Almost all of the artists are British citizens but with cultural roots elsewhere: subjects of the Crown but with the critical perspective of outsiders. Like any survey, the show has its ups and downs and problems with focus. But it's packed with terrific artists, many showing in the United States for the first time, and it projects a unified force field of energy as palpable as it is hard to define (Cotter).
"THE WARHOL LOOK/GLAMOUR STYLE FASHION," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Jan. 18). Andy Warhol remains one of the most provocative American artists of the postwar years. It is almost impossible not to have complicated feelings about him, but his impact has been immense. Unfortunately, little of his importance is conveyed in this tame, patchy exhibition, organized by the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh, which sets out to examine how fashion influenced Warhol and how he influenced it. Elaborately installed, this is basically a show of ephemera rather than of art. But no encounter with Warhol can be without interest, and this one has its moments: the section on drag is good; the Factory-era material in general is great. Hours: Wednesdays, and Fridays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays, 1 to 8 P.M. Admission: $8; $7, students and the elderly; free on Thursdays, 6 to 8 P.M. (Cotter).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
ANDREAS FEININGER, Bonni Benrubi, 52 East 76th Street, (212) 517-3766 (through Jan. 24). Mr. Feininger sampled a variety of modernist strategies during the 1930's before lighting out for America and going to work as a staff photographer for Time-Life. This selection of vintage prints from that era ranges from moody Parisian street scenes to almost completely abstract studies of nocturnal city lights, to technical experiments like a Rayogram of dandelion seeds or a reticulated negative print that atomizes and irradiates a female nude (Johnson).
MARKUS LUPERTZ, Knoedler & Company, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550 (through Jan. 10); Michael Werner Gallery, 21 East 67th Street, (212) 988-1623 (through Jan. 10). A German artist promoted in the early 1980's as part of the international Neo-Expressionist movement, Mr. Lupertz has come a long way from his work's early involvement with rebellion against German postwar prosperity. At Werner Gallery, he shows three monumental bronze figures that echo classical Greek sculpture and also Picasso. Rough and ungraceful, unprettily painted, they deliberately reveal the scars of their making. Their anti-heroic, existentialist stance is oddly compelling. His new landscape and still-life paintings at Knoedler & Company are less so. In them, he marries recognizable imagery with abstract passages, often using the device of a painting within a painting. In one, for instance, a dense black crow, reminiscent of Picasso's birds, flanks a vignette of netted and latticed lines. In another, traditional still-life props -- a skull, a bird, a vase -- are backed by an overall Pollocklike splatter of abstract forms. The show comes off as a disappointingly amiable homage to 20th-century masters (Glueck).
CY TWOMBLY, Gagosian, 980 Madison Avenue, at 76th Street, (212) 744-2313 (through Jan. 10). Ten bronzes by an artist better known for painting and drawing. Things like cardboard boxes, boards, tree branches, flowers, wire and plaster are precariously joined, cast in bronze and given a chalky patina. The resulting works seem to exist as nostalgic reveries. Crude wheels attached to one end of an elongated triangle made of rough planks create a clumsy yet oddly delicate toy chariot, a memorial, perhaps, to childhood lost (Johnson).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
RICHARD BAKER, Washburn, 20 East 57th Street, (212) 397-6780 (through Jan. 17; closed Dec. 25 through Jan. 1). In many of Richard Baker's small, richly painted pictures, a single tulip or rose floats against a spacious sky. Pieces of miniature landscape are vignettes along the edges of the canvas. Set as they are against such celestial views, the flowers seem cosmic, although they are painted with a vivid, almost sculptural solidity. It's as though Mr. Baker were concentrating on Chardin while being haunted by the spirit of Blake (Johnson).
* BURGOYNE DILLER, "The Third Dimension: Sculpture and Drawings, 1930-1965," Michael Rosenfeld Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 247-0082 (through Jan. 17). A touching exercise in bittersweetness, this museum-quality show implies that the best American painter to fall under Mondrian's spell may actually have been a sculptor manque. It includes spare neo-plastic sculptures and wall reliefs from the early 1940's and bolder, more original works from the 1960's that relate to minimal art, along with dozens of purposeful drawings that brim with new ideas, most of them never realized (Smith).
* EGON SCHIELE, "1890-1918: Master Draftsman," Galerie St. Etienne, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 245-6734 (through Jan. 3). A concentrated examination of the artist's preferred medium, timed for the Museum of Modern Art's retrospective, this illuminating exhibition contains 75 drawings that span Schiele's brief career. Smaller and more succinct than the Modern's show, it reflects the gallery's 50-year involvement with Schiele's work and brings the viewer into unusually close contact with his febrile virtuosity. The sense of unremitting scrutiny and intensifying engagement with both the medium and the artist's models make this show enormously compelling (Smith).
TREVOR WINKFIELD, Tibor de Nagy Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, (212) 262-5050 (through Jan. 3). With near-perfect compositional pitch, Mr. Winkfield orchestrates a harmonic convergence of formalism, Surrealism and Pop. His flat, brightly colored, sharply outlined pictures produce a jazzy, Stuart Davis-like modernity. But in the layering and scrambling of all sorts of curiously archaic images from ancient, medieval, Victorian and early modern sources, they look like game boards designed by an addled English visionary (Johnson).
ANDREW WYETH, David Findlay Jr., 41 East 57th Street, (212) 486-7660 (through Jan. 8). If you're not a Wyeth lover, this high-quality selection of watercolors from five decades won't change your mind, but you may be impressed by how fresh his deft and loose works of the late 30's look. In "Winter Visitor" (1939), the crinkly play of pure-hued transparencies creates a bright, crisp winterscape; you can practically feel the bracing cold (Johnson).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
BRYAN CROCKETT, Fotouhi Cramer Gallery, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 431-1304 (through Jan. 15). In his first solo exhibition, Mr. Crockett, whose monstrous balloon sculpture was one of the hits of the last Whitney Biennial, shows only one fully realized balloon work along with various high-tech procedures to which he subjects his sculptures. He records their deflation on video, he makes Rayograms of them, and he puts one under glass in a vacuum machine (Johnson).
MELISSA MEYER: THE GARNER TULLIS PROJECT, Devon Golden Fine Art, 16 Mercer Street, SoHo, (212) 334-3124 (through Jan. 24). In these bright, gestural paintings on paper, Melissa Meyer skirts the muddiness that sometimes plagues her work. Her materials here are encaustic on heated paper (made available by the Gardner Tullis Workshop, which usually specializes in printmaking). The medium has improved the message, enabling Ms. Meyer's layered, variously colored, contrasting calligraphies to coexist with unusual stroke-by-stroke clarity (Smith).
* BEATRIZ MILHAZES, Edward Thorp Gallery, 103 Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 431-6880 (through Jan. 10; closed until Jan. 6). Ms. Milhazes, who lives in Brazil, has come through with a dazzling second New York solo show of abstract paintings. Her forms, often circular, seem to derive from textile patterns, architectural ornaments and the lacelike halos and vegetal filigree found in the colonial-period Baroque religious art of the Americas. Her surfaces, which suggest stamping, embossing and collage, deliberately keep the artist's personal touch at a slight remove, but only slight: the result is a sense of exhilarated, erotic concentration (Cotter).
"PARIS, CITY OF LIGHT: PHOTOGRAPHS BY BRUCE CRATSLEY, TODD WEBB AND ANDRE KERTESZ," Yancey Richardson Gallery, 560 Broadway, SoHo, (212) 343-1255 (through Jan. 3; closed until Jan. 2). The Todd Webb photos of Paris from the 1940's and '50's are lovely. But big attractions are Mr. Cratsley's lush black-and-white images. Several are of objects in Paris museums: Harry Houdini's top hat and wand in a vitrine at the Louvre, an upright bronze saint's hand, a 13th-century French tomb carving. Others are carefully edited studies of architecture. The effect is of an intense but restrained romanticism, as if the pictures were holding their breath (Cotter).
ROBERT WILLIAMS, Tony Shafrazi, 119 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 274-9300 (through Jan. 31; closed until Jan. 2). The former underground comic artist Robert Williams paints elaborate, tasteless allegories about modern times. They are supposed to be wild and shocking, but they are really just sophomoric and tediously complicated. The banal illustrator's style looks like that of Norman Rockwell's evil but less talented twin (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
JANET CARDIFF AND GEORGE BURES MILLER: "DARK POOL," Morris-Healy Gallery, 530 West 22d Street, Chelsea, (212) 243-3753 (through Jan. 3). In a dimly lit, chaotic installation intended to invoke a dusty, musty 19th-century library or study -- maybe even a second-rate mind -- two artists have crammed old books, clothes, shoes, plates of food remnants, plastic tubing, a vintage typewriter, boxes, trunks and other kitsch, even a feathery pigeonlike thing that rattles on a spring when you approach it. Old-fashioned phonograph horns, triggered by sensors as you approach them, give out snatches of prosy "poetic" talk. There's nothing much more to be said about this work except that it's the kind of thing the Russian assemblagist Ilya Kabakov does a lot better (Glueck).
GEORGE CONDO AND WILLIAM BURROUGHS, "Collaborations 1988-1996," Pat Hearn Gallery, 530 West 22d Street, Chelsea, (212) 727-7366 (through Jan. 17). No doubt George Condo, the post-modernist painter, and William Burroughs, the Beat writer, had fun fooling around together in the studio, but you wouldn't know it from their paintings, which look like an assortment of works you might find in an undergraduate studio class. There are a couple of smallish homages to the painter Francis Bacon; some mixtures of cartoon imagery and abstract splatter, and several essays in action painting, some made with a toilet plunger (Johnson).
ANDREAS GURSKY, Matthew Marks Gallery, 523 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 243-0200 (through Jan. 3; closed Dec. 25 through Jan. 1). The large, handsome photographs converse with all kinds of other art, from Jackson Pollock to Damien Hirst. The results are best when the dialogue is internalized, as in pictures of the gargantuan and deserted atriums of two hotels: portraits of the alienating spectacle of modern life so weirdly masquerading as hard-edge abstraction (Smith).
YAYOI KUSAMA AND ANDY WARHOL, D'Amelio Terras, 525 West 22d Street, Chelsea, (212) 352-9460 (through Jan. 31). An inspired curatorial coup brings together two silvery, pneumatic works of sculpture by two scenemakers of the 1960's. Andy Warhol's "Silver Clouds," big, metallic, helium-filled pillows shown in New York for the first time since 1966, bump around the ceiling or hover magically in midair; in the next room, Yayoi Kusama's "Snake" (1974), a 22-foot line of clustered, stuffed phalli, hugs the floor (Johnson).
GILES LYON, Alexandre de Folin, 529 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-3434 (through Jan. 10). This painter, based in Houston, produces humorous, visually enthralling abstractions. In the most compelling, a symmetrically double-sided tangle of gnarly, tubular lines fills most of the medium-large canvas. Outlined cartoon-style and painted in Sunday funnies colors, these spacey yet slimy-looking networks look like cosmic visions from a psychedelic comic book (Johnson).
JOAN MITCHELL AND JOHN CHAMBERLAIN: A JUXTAPOSITION, Cheim & Read, 521 West 23d Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-7727 (through Jan. 10). These two second-generation Abstract Expressionists, the painter Joan Mitchell (1926-1992) and the assemblagist John Chamberlain, were close in age and shared much in the way of cultural background. Each was addicted to color, using it to exuberant, explosive effect. The pairing of their works in this show is salubrious. Mitchell's passionate, lyrical canvases were impelled by the forces of nature; Chamberlain's cool assemblages of crushed auto parts are derived from man-made materials. Yet the shapes and colors used by each are remarkably compatible. The works play off one another with great panache (Glueck).
JAMES SIENA, Cristenrose Gallery, 529 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 206-0297 (through Jan. 10; closed until Jan. 6). Space under pressure is the operative concept in these meditative, delicately wrought enamel-on-aluminum abstractions. They perform optical tricks and bends without being at all tricky, partly because excellent use is made of the vagaries of the human hand, partly because the artist's materials add a cool sense of perfection and partly because Mr. Siena is unusually adept at translating the mental into the visual. His paintings think as good as they look (Smith).
 
Galleries: Other
 
"DESERT CLICHE: ISRAEL NOW -- LOCAL IMAGES," Grey Art Gallery and Study Center, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780 (through Feb. 4; closed until Jan. 6). Questioning the platitudes of Israeli life as perceived at home and abroad, 18 younger Israeli artists present often subversive and sometimes witty views on everything from the military to the "blooming" of the desert. A photographer, Gilad Ophir, shows the desert blooming with creeping suburbanization. The military is satirized by Nir Hod, whose glamorous photographs of soldiers are of ambiguous gender. The uneasy relationship between Arabs and Jews is symbolized by an Arab artist, Asim Abu-Shakra. He paints the tough desert cactus known as the sabra -- a name claimed by both Arabs and Israelis to designate a native of the country -- held captive indoors, his perception of the political situation of Arabs in Israel. Some of the ambivalent observations of these artists don't translate all that well, but at best the show takes sharp aim at Israeli and diaspora fancies about the land of milk and honey (Glueck).
INTIMATE SCULPTURE: ART SMITH AND HIS CONTEMPORARIES, MODERNIST JEWELRY, 1940-1965, Gansevoort Gallery, 72 Gansevoort Street, West Village, (212) 633-0555 (through Jan. 10). This ingeniously installed exhibition surveys the inventive "body sculpture" of Art Smith (1917-1982), a studio jeweler who had a shop in Greenwich Village from the late 1940's to the late 70's. Daring in both their structural clarity and use of the body as a living armature, Smith's designs are seen against the backdrop of his unusually talented generation of metalsmiths, including Ed Weiner, Paul Lobel and Sam Kramer (Smith).
SUSPENDED INSTANTS, Art in General, 79 Walker Street, lower Manhattan, (212) 219-0473 (through Jan. 10). The downtown half of a joint exhibition with the Sculpture Center (whose portion is now closed), this exhibition of sculptures and installation pieces by young artists from Brazil and New York examines their common interest in slight, ephemeral materials, or various semblances of levitation. Some manifestations of this interest are better than others, most notable being Seong Chen's delicate sculpture of crocheted paper printed with words, and Carla Guagliardi's wall piece, in which thin rods of iron are suspended in clear polyethylene tubes filled with water, which is reducing the iron to beautiful powdery rust (Smith).
 
Last Chance
 
THE ARTIST'S EYE, National Academy Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880 (through Sunday). For the National Academy's biennial series, Will Barnet, a member, has selected a motley show of 50 portraits from the academy's permanent collection. Highlights include a great self-portrait by Thomas Eakins, a horrific self-portrait by Ivan Albright, a small but richly painterly self-portrait by Lois Dodd and an etched self-portrait of fuzzy little dots by Chuck Close. Also on view are nine of Mr. Barnet's distinctively linear paintings. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 P.M.; Fridays, noon to 8 P.M. Admission: $5; $3.50 for the elderly (Johnson).
"CELEBRATING CANALETTO," Italian Cultural Institute, Park Avenue at 68th Street, (212) 879-4242 (through Wednesday). These etchings from the collection of the Arthur Ross Foundation mark the 300th anniversary of the birth of Giovanni Antonio Canal (1697-1768), better known as Canaletto, and the Italian Cultural Institute is raising a modest cheer in the form of this charming show of 30 of his prints. They include vistas of the lush, humid Italian countryside and postcard-ish views of Venice with "Grand Tour souvenir" written all over them. Certain scenes invented by the artist have the look of stage sets: neat as a pin, with shadows falling just so (Cotter).
I. RICE PEREIRA, Andre Zarre Gallery, 48 Greene Street, (212) 966-2222 (through tomorrow). The painter Irene Rice Pereira (1907-1971) had her first New York solo show in 1933 and a retrospective at the Whitney in 1953. This exhibition consists of a series of medium-large drawings made in the 1960's. Arabesque gestures in charcoal, accented by watercolor, delineate abstracted figures that look vaguely like Asian deities (Johnson).

PUB-DATE: December 26, 1997

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 50; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2413 words

HEADLINE: WEEKEND EXCURSION;
The Aura of History Spans the Delaware

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM

 BODY:
The editorial page of The New Hope Gazette carries a feature called "It's Been Said . . ." Among the latest republished sayings was this one, "The average tourist wants to go to places where there are no tourists." Surely this gentle bit of sarcasm is not lost on the local readers.
New Hope, Pa., is awash with tourists, as is Lambertville, N.J., its sibling and more sedate rival just 300 yards across the Delaware River. If the river could be drained and paved, the towns would become the largest outdoor pre-Revolutionary shopping mall in the Northeast. 
 But the prospect of recreational shopping wasn't the real reason why I spent a weekend in Bucks County, Pa., and Hunterdon County, N.J., one night in each camp. Despite the cheek-by-jowl glut of antiques shops, gift stores and restaurants, there is the smell of history along the river there, only a few minutes' drive upstream from the Pennsylvania ferry dock where General Washington and his ragtag flotilla set out on Christmas night 1777 to overrun a barracks of boozy Hessians at Trenton.
History in these parts is everywhere, still visible and accessible, once you filter out the parking meters and the "We Sell Herbal Ecstasy" sign in downtown New Hope. What once was, in most cases, still is. And at this time of year, all you need is a warm jacket, a good pair of walking shoes, a map and an imagination.
Other seasons offer ferry rides, the shad festival in April (Lambertville) and performances at the Bucks County Playhouse (April through December). But after the fall colors have faded and before the snow flies, there is a slightly quieter time -- not a lull, exactly -- that slows the reflexes of voracious antiques hunters and reminds the towns' publicans to ignite the logs in their hearths. Is there anything more inviting at this time of year than the smell of wood smoke? It's not shirt-sleeve weather anymore, but with Polartec, goose down and Thinsulate to protect you, who cares?
This is Americana at a comfortable remove and at your own pace, through architecture and geography. Hundreds of buildings are National Historic Landmarks, and even the most unambitious stroller will find that the present and the past coexist peacefully. Walk into the tidy stucco New Hope tourism headquarters, on Main Street, and you'll find that it was built as the first Village Hall, in 1790. The two public toilets, the man behind the desk said, were the original jail cells.
A short walk across the street is Martine's, a snug tavern for lunch or dinner near the riverbank. It dates to the mid-18th century, when its owners sold salt to preserve meat. It's just a few steps from one of the original ferry docks, which are pivotal to the history of the two towns. Lambertville and New Hope had the good fortune to be on the main stagecoach route between New York and Philadelphia. A formidable obstacle was the river, so one of the earliest settlers, Emanuel Coryell, established a ferry to link New Jersey with Pennsylvania.
The Coryells were able boatmen but lackluster politicians. John Lambert, a descendant of another early family and a United States Senator from 1809 to 1815, persuaded the Federal Government to designate the local post office as Lambertville. Since then, the Coryells have had to be content to see their name on street signs.
You don't have to look hard to find two other significant aspects of the area's early economic development: the mule-barge canals and the railroad.
In Lambertville, it's the Delaware and Raritan Canal, which ran from Bull's Island (north of Lambertville) to Trenton, linking up with the main canal that carried commerce east to the Raritan River and eventually New York. In New Hope, it's the Delaware Canal, which ran between Easton and Bristol. Both were augmented and eventually supplanted by rail, the Reading line in New Hope and the Belvidere & Delaware, a branch of the Pennsylvania Railroad, in New Jersey.
But before we go further, a suggestion. This is not a theme park. Small children will not have a good time, unless they really like to walk what will seem to them long distances and go in and out of stores that sell sweaters, antiques and wine. There is a good ice cream shop in New Hope (Gerenser's) and a store in Lambertville devoted solely to toys (the Five and Dime), but the toys are the toys you owned: Howdy Doody wind-ups, Dinky military vehicles, Tinkertoys. Do yourself a favor: leave the younger ones at home. (Teen-age girls, however, will find the shopping totally awesome. Trust me on this.)
I had originally planned to come alone, maybe even get some reading done in late evening after dinner. But then Kate, my 16-year-old, made arrangements to visit a friend in Moorestown, about an hour's drive south. So I invited her to come along on Friday after school. We left northern New Jersey at 5 P.M., got caught in weekend rush-hour traffic and made the 90-minute, 75-mile trip in two and a half hours.
Our first sight of Lambertville was Bridge Street, the narrow two-lane, east-west link between the towns, and it made the tedious drive worthwhile. Even in the dark, we could clearly see the old facades and the care the borough had taken to preserve a sense of decorum that capitalism could have shattered long ago. Kate came right to the point; she liked the quaintness a lot, but she liked capitalism even more.
We oohed and aahed at the neat Federal and Victorian houses and shops and rolled past the stately Lambertville House, a recently restored 1812 inn where I would stay on Saturday night.
We pushed on, across the bridge and into New Hope, where we turned left onto Main Street, which runs parallel to the river. After settling in at the New Hope Inn, we backtracked to Lambertville and the mid-19th-century railroad station, which is now a restaurant.
Walking past a horse-and-carriage for hire, we entered the restaurant lobby. We sat at a window table and looked out at twinkling lights and the old Belvidere & Delaware track, now used only for excursion trains.
Kate never got to go shopping. We turned in early, and the next day she was off to visit her friend. I spent Saturday in Lambertville and Sunday in New Hope, wandering at random. One of my first stops was a cozy bookstore, the Rivergate, at 7 Lambert Lane along the river, which carries a nice selection of everything, including local guidebooks. One, a Lambertville cookbook, is published by the Kalmia Club, a women's civic organization that started as a reading circle a century ago, taking its name from the mountain laurel (kalmia latifolia) that bloom on the hillsides.
Across the street was the casually named Jim's Antiques. Jim, it must be said, has eclectic taste and is not afraid to charge for it. There's some serious French, English and American furniture as well as lots of outlandish decorative stuff. I was drawn to the twin skeleton chairs, at $5,500 each, made of wood in white lacquer and resembling seated human skeletons. And the Louis XVI-style sedan chair (circa 1780-1820), for $6,900. The pair of African elephant tusks (from a 1930's safari) goes for $16,000.
A final touch: on the front lawn stands a life-size bronze elk, Jim's tip of the hat to the Elk's Club, the previous tenant.
One of my last stops of the day was a wine tasting at the Tomasello Winery shop on North Union Street. The winery, in Hammonton in Atlantic County, N.J., was established in 1933 and turns out some surprisingly tasty, inexpensive varieties, including a large selection of dessert wines.
One Lambertville regret: I had only a muffin and coffee at a Bridge Street luncheonette called Sneddon's. It is a classic short-order restaurant, basically one big room with tables, and a counter with a dozen or so stools. At the long griddle, a small army of men and women prepare omelets, flapjacks and waffles till 11:30 A.M., and then start on lunch. It is the busiest and most unpretentious place on either side of the river.
The newly refurbished Lambertville House, where I spent Saturday night, was probably as much luxury as I was likely to find in the area. And once I figured out how to turn off the state-of-the-art water jets in the bathtub, I could really relax. The inn provided a wonderfully complete breakfast (cereal, quiche, muffins, fruit and coffee), after which I checked out and drove over to New Hope. Weary of parking meters (25 cents a half-hour), I pulled into an all-day lot for $5.
The lot, it turned out, abutted the old Reading tracks that serve the New Hope & Ivyland Railroad, an excursion line that ventures about 10 miles into Bucks County, a kind of steam cruise to nowhere. In wintry weather, the station is warmed by a cast-iron potbelly stove, stoked with coal. The sweet sulfury smell is distinctive. (If you ever went through basic combat training in the winter, you'd remember stoves like these heating huts on the rifle range.)
Sense memories were abundant. Colonial America, only a block away, at the railroad crossing, had become early 20th-century America.
As I moved closer to the warmth, thick clouds of steam from a sleek black engine, old No. 40, made at the Baldwin works in Philadelphia in 1925, washed up onto the platform and over the roof, momentarily obscuring the ticket window and the clamoring passengers. Time stopped. I caught the 11:30.
 
Maybe Washington Didn't Sleep There, But Now You Can
 
Places mentioned in the article on New Hope, Pa., and Lambertville, N.J., along with some additional suggestions for visitors and travel tips.
 
Where to Stay
 
Many inns, bed-and-breakfast establishments and motels require a minimum two-night stay on weekends. Some will not accept children under 10 or 12. It's best to inquire.
 
NEW HOPE INN, 36 West Mechanic Street, New Hope, (215) 862-2078. Thirty-three rooms and suites, some with fireplaces and Jacuzzis. Continental breakfast. One-night stays available on weekdays; weekends vary according to the time of year. Free parking. Children welcome. Rates: Monday to Thursday, $75 to $140; Friday to Sunday, $85 to $150.
LAMBERTVILLE HOUSE, 32 Bridge Street, Lambertville, (609) 397-0200. Elegantly restored 25-room inn, circa 1812; originally a tavern and hotel kept by the Lambert family. Rooms include fireplaces, jetted tubs. Continental breakfast. Open year round. Free parking. Rates: $159 to $269.
 
Where to Eat
 
LAMBERTVILLE STATION, 11 Bridge Street, Lambertville, (609) 397-8300. A Victorian train station and a decidedly American menu of fish, fowl and meat with some nicely updated touches. Monday to Saturday, lunch 11:30 to 3. Sunday brunch, 10:30 to 3. Dinner, Monday to Thursday and Sunday, 4 to 9:30 P.M.; Friday and Saturday till 11 P.M. Lunch entrees from $6.50; dinner entrees from $10.95.
SNEDDON'S LUNCHEONETTE, 47 Bridge Street, Lambertville, (609) 397-3053. Basic food and plenty of it. Open Monday through Saturday, 6 A.M. to 2 P.M., breakfast served till 11:30 A.M.; Sunday, breakfast all day. Friday, 6 A.M. to 8 P.M.
MARTINE'S, 7 East Ferry Street, at Main Street, New Hope, (215) 862-2966. Mid-18th century salt store converted to a pub. Lunch, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M; dinner, 5 P.M. to 10:30 P.M. Open every day.
 
Attractions
 
BUCKS COUNTY PLAYHOUSE, 70 South Main Street, New Hope, (215) 862-2041. Performances Tuesday through Sunday, April through December.
NEW HOPE MULE BARGE COMPANY, (215) 862-2842. An hour's ride on the Delaware Canal. Resumes in May. Call for times and ticket prices.
STEAM TRAVEL. In New Hope, the New Hope & Ivyland Railroad, 32 West Bridge Street, (215) 862-2332. A 10-mile excursion into Bucks County. May through October, with a special Santa Claus train throughout December. In Lambertville, Black River and Western Railroad, (908) 782-9600. Excursions between Lambertville and Ringoes. May through October. Call for times and ticket prices.
SHAD FESTIVAL. A Lambertville arts and crafts festival revolving around the annual return of the shad, a migratory fish, to the Delaware. The shad was virtually wiped out decades ago, but the festival continues and includes demonstrations of shad hauling and, of course, shad dinners.
 
Getting There
 
BY CAR: From the New York City area, take Route 78 West to Route 278 South to 202 South to 179 South, which goes directly into Bridge Street in Lambertville.
BY BUS: Trans-Bridge buses leave from the Port Authority Bus Terminal, Eighth Avenue and 42d Street in Manhattan, Mondays through Fridays, eight times daily, from 7:30 A.M. until 8:15 P.M.; Saturday and Sundays, four times daily, from 10:15 A.M. until 8:15 P.M. The bus ride is under two hours. . Round-trip tickets: $22.60; children 11 and under, $11.30.
BY TRAIN: Amtrak and N.J. Transit provide train service from Penn Station in Manhattan to Trenton, 10 miles from Lambertville. Amtrak trains run daily, 25 times a day. The train ride is about an hour. One-way tickets: $26 to $44; children 15 and under, half-price when traveling with an adult. N.J. Transit trains run Mondays through Fridays. 4:49 A.M. to 1:40 A.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 5:32 A.M. to 1:40 A.M., about every hour. One-way tickets: $9.45; children 5 to 11, half-price; 4 and under, free. In Trenton, N.J. Transit Bus No. 608 runs to Lambertville, Mondays through Fridays, two times daily, at 7:11 A.M. and 5:16 P.M. The bus ride is about 40 minutes. Buses return from Lambertville to Trenton at 8:30 A.M. and 6:18 P.M. Tickets: $2.05; children 5 to 11, half price; 4 and under, free.
 
Tourist Information
 
LAMBERTVILLE CHAMBER OF COMMERCE. A call to the chamber, (609) 397-0055, at 4 South Union Street, will bring a small manila envelope filled with useful brochures, especially Lambertville's own information booklet and map and a walking tour that includes 22 major historic buildings. The chamber will also send the latest edition of The Area Guide Book for Bucks and Hunterdon Counties, which includes brief histories of dozens of towns, maps and local advertising.
THE NEW HOPE CHAMBER OF COMMERCE. It also has a handy pamphlet guide to lodging, restaurants and activities. The New Hope Information Center is at 1 West Mechanic Street, at Main Street, (215) 862-5880. For $4.50, you can purchase a delightfully idiosyncratic map, guide and walking tour put out by Robert V. Gerenser, whose family name appears on signs here and there, as well as on the town's best-known ice cream store. CHARLES STRUM

HEADLINE: Growth in Film and T.V. Jobs Seen for L.A.

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 25

 BODY:
Growing demand for films and television shows is forecast to create an additional 16,000 entertainment industry jobs in Los Angeles County in 1998, a 12 percent increase that is more than five times the county's overall growth rate.
The projected new jobs in the $20-billion-a-year industry, disclosed in a forecast from the Los Angeles County Economic Development Corporation, will represent nearly a fifth of all new employment positions created in the region next year. 
 Jack Kyser, the development agency's chief economist, said product demand was driving the sector's growth. Mr. Kyser said production of television commercials was also growing in the region.
The entertainment industry's growth rate is expected to be a little slower than 1997's 17 percent gain, which saw 20,000 new jobs created.
The survey also projected creation next year of 12,900 jobs indirectly related to show business like entertainment accountants, lawyers, caterers and tailors, giving the category 137,300 jobs over all.
The county's job rate growth for 1998 over all was forecast at 2.1 percent, or 81,000 new jobs, pushing the total to nearly four million. That also represents a slight slowing from the 1997 gain of 2.3 percent, or 89,000 jobs.

HEADLINE: RETAILERS FINDING SALES DISAPPOINT FOR THE HOLIDAYS

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
A sparkling economy, record-low unemployment and fatter paychecks failed to translate into the strapping holiday selling season American retailers were counting on.
Although industry sales figures will not be released until Jan. 8, retailers and those who watch them estimated that sales in stores open at least one year rose a scant 2 percent to 3 percent in December from a year earlier -- half the gain some analysts had been touting at the start of the season. 
 This lackluster performance was the third in a row for retailers, despite the strength of the American economy and the wealth-generating gains in the stock market. Analysts said it underscored the harsh necessity for retailers to come to grips with the diminishing role of Christmas-season sales and to find more creative ways to get people to part with their dollars.
"It took stores years to learn that Easter had disappeared as a selling holiday," said Peter Schaeffer, a retail analyst at Dillon Read. "And after three years in a row of weakness, they have to realize that you can't count on Christmas anymore either. In all honesty, it is much more profitable to get sales in October than in December these days."
Indeed, even where sales were strong, profit margins were often weak. From the day after Thanksgiving on, sweater racks were decorated with 25-percent-off signs in many women's clothing shops. Department stores mailed coupons to shoppers offering extra savings, while computer merchants rang up strong sales only by lowering prices.
"We started off with a bang, and then had a lull, and, unfortunately, the final weekend sales were not what we had hoped for," said Bruce Van Kleeck, vice president of the National Retail Federation. "Mainstream department stores were struggling. Discounters did reasonably well, as did luxury stores, but even the discounters said they saw weekend sales declining."
The last blockbuster Christmas for retailers was 1992, when the biggest merchants' sales rose 8 percent over the previous year as the economy strengthened. Since then, sales gains have rarely exceeded the inflation rate; even in 1994, when big chains' sales rose 4.5 percent, profit margins were slim and stores were busiest during after-Christmas clearances.
Economists and analysts have attributed that tepid performance to rising levels of consumer debt, the diminishing tendency of extended families to gather around the Christmas tree and the simple exhaustion of working couples who cannot muster the energy to go to the mall. Merchants have struggled to find any explanation at all.
This year, even Hanukkah, which tends to give the season a lift -- at least in cities with large Jewish populations -- has not provided the kick that retailers hoped for, perhaps because the holiday began late this year, not until Tuesday evening.
"What I want to know is, where did Hanukkah go?" asked Michael Gould, chief executive of Bloomingdale's, a unit of Federated Department Stores Inc., which has stores in the New York and Los Angeles areas. "You just didn't see that pop this year." The new shopping pattern, he added, is that "there really is more giving all year long now."
Many themes that have defined the holiday selling season in recent years resurfaced this year.
Generally, stores that serve the wealthy seemed to fare better than those that cater to the middle slices of the market. Neiman Marcus and Saks Fifth Avenue executives boasted about sales of fancy party dresses, jewelry and cashmere, but merchants that compete on price were less than happy.
"While the last few days were better, sales were overall below plan," said Duncan Muir, a spokesman for J. C. Penney. "There are so many theories out there as to why, but I think you have to consider credit-card debt." Personal bankruptcies have hit an all-time high, and consumer installment credit totals $1.2 trillion, half again as much as just four years ago.
The hot products of the season were oddly familiar, too, as if Americans have decided that it just is not the holidays without chenille sweaters, velvet bras, men's golf shirts and Dentist Barbies. Items for the home, from bread makers to scented candles to Tuscan platters, continued to be huge draws. In the last week, traffic in housewares stores like Pottery Barn, a unit of Williams-Sonoma Inc., and Crate and Barrel, a unit of Euromarket Designs, was much heavier than in stores selling apparel.
How hip were housewares? The actress Gwyneth Paltrow was spotted this week in a Williams-Sonoma store in Chelsea buying last-minute gifts.
Perhaps most important, from the standpoint of the season's profitability, major markdowns are now as integral to holiday shopping as mistletoe, dreidels and Salvation Army bell ringers.
"This Christmas selling season was one big bargain hunt," said Kurt Barnard, publisher of Barnard's Retail Trend Report, a trade publication.
Small, ominous symbols of the season's sluggishness were everywhere. CompUSA was handing out free videocassette recorders with computer purchases. The hottest toy was a doll that snores. And retailers who traditionally looked to the Friday after Thanksgiving for their biggest sales day are now hoping that today, when shoppers go hunting for even better bargains, will give them a final sales lift.
"The day after Christmas should be powerful," said Mr. Van Kleeck of the National Retail Federation. "It should be absolute bedlam in the mall."
Sears, Roebuck & Company executives said that after-Christmas shopping is as important as the entire month of December. "Our holiday season embraces the first week of January," Jan Drummond, a spokeswoman for the company, said.
The issues dogging the retail industry range from the secular to the sociological, and the challenges may take years to work through.
More than ever, department and specialty stores that cater to middle- and lower-income shoppers compete with discounters like Target Stores, a unit of Dayton Hudson, and Wal-Mart Stores in selling goods from toasters to electronic toys to basic apparel, like turtlenecks and stretch pants.
Families are more dispersed now; people are more likely to spend the holidays in smaller groups scattered around the country than as one large family unit, which cuts down on buying. Shoppers consider it too much effort to run out to the mall after a 10-hour workday to buy and mail gifts to a dozen people, or they may have no idea what to buy for a teen-age nephew they never see.
"A lot of people are drawing names now instead of buying for all their siblings," said Audrey Gusky, a marketing professor at Duquesne University in Pittsburgh. "People have such a limit on their time and have so many other things to think about in two-career families, it is just as easy to go get a gift certificate." That way, she said, "all you have to do is stick a little envelope in the mail."
Indeed, many retail executives said that gift certificate sales have risen sharply in the last three years. And that, of course, means more consumers are taking advantage of ever-bigger post-Christmas sales.
The slump in holiday shopping is clearly not caused by a lack of money to be spent. Personal income rose eight-tenths of one percent last month, the 13th consecutive monthly gain and the largest since June 1996.
But consumers, increasingly, have demonstrated a penchant for spending their money on things other than store-bought merchandise, such as travel and personal services. Affluent baby boomers, apparently having run out of things to buy, are indulging in mud masks at the spa and trips to St. Kitts; travel industry revenues are soaring while retail sales stagnate.
"I think there is some relationship between Christmas sales and the aging baby boomers," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. "Years ago, they were just starting to have kids and they splurged on them. But that novelty wears off."
Rather than help retailers, in some ways the strong economy has hurt. For example, low unemployment forced merchants this year to entice seasonal help with higher pay and better perks. "If anyone is going to get squeezed by a tight labor market and minimum-wage increases, it is going to be people doing seasonal hiring, and they don't see it coming back in terms of big revenue gains," said David Blitzer, chief economist at the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
And there is no threat of inflation to scare shoppers into making purchases sooner rather than later.
"People are not going to rush out and buy because they think it will cost more money next week," said Mr. Blitzer. "And that means that price cuts, when you take them, really hurt."
Going forward, retailers may stop looking at leading economic indicators as a crystal ball for holiday sales. "For years and years, you could base your predictions on history," noted Mr. Van Kleeck of the National Retail Federation. "We are rewriting history season by season now."
