HEADLINE: Philosophers Find the Degree Pays Off in Life And in Work

BYLINE: By CAROL MARIE CROPPER 

DATELINE: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.

 BODY:
What can you do with a philosophy degree?
In an age of M.B.A.'s and computer scientists, more than 4,000 American college students graduate each year with a bachelor's degree in the ancient discipline. Sometimes their parents and friends wonder what will happen to them. 
 One thing is certain: Not many of them will go on to make a living as philosophers. Even those who persevere through a doctorate may wind up doing something else. More than 1,000 people with Ph.D's in philosophy applied for the 448 openings listed in the last year in "Jobs for Philosophers," said Eric Hoffman, executive director of the American Philosophical Association. And many of those jobs were temporary or nontenure-track teaching positions.
Yet students majoring in philosophy -- the study of the principles underlying conduct, thought and knowledge -- seem passionately unconcerned.
Shaharyar Khan, a philosophy major at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, is one of a handful of seniors selected to live in the early 19th-century academic village designed here by Thomas Jefferson. He awakens each morning in a dormitory room that opens onto the university's mist-covered lawn, with the rotunda that Jefferson modeled on the Pantheon rising to his left.
"We look at what we do, how we justify things," the 22-year-old said of his philosophy classes. "In that there is sublimity and nobility."
Mr. Khan plans to go to medical school -- if he is not seduced by an academic career. He considered majoring in a science but decided he would get enough of that later. Philosophy was his personal luxury. "This was something I could do for myself," he said.
But what of other philosophy majors? What do they do when confronted with the real world, where there are groceries to buy and mortgages to pay? How do they compete for jobs with all those sensible accounting and engineering majors?
For all the jokes about them, philosophy majors appear to do remarkably well. That, at least, is the conclusion one can draw from an unscientific survey, 20 years after graduation, of the class of 1977 at four schools: Princeton University, the University of Virginia, the University of Nebraska and Texas A & M University.
These 40-somethings fell in love with philosophy almost by accident and went on to careers in other fields. But for the most part they are convinced that their studies, which covered logic and ethics among other topics, helped them in their jobs and their lives.
Their professional success may stem from the fact that philosophy students seem more likely than those with other degrees to attend graduate or professional school. Of 20 philosophy majors interviewed from the four universities, only four had not added a graduate or professional degree.
"I suppose I'm lucky I got into medical school," said Joseph P. Bruner, who graduated from Nebraska. "I would have probably wound up parking cars otherwise."
Or maybe not. Jorge Secada, director of undergraduate studies in philosophy at Virginia, said his students almost always found jobs -- though not in philosophy. "We are doing better in finding employment for graduates than most majors in the arts and sciences area," he said. "Apparently people in the real world think philosophy majors are well trained. They are trained to think, to analyze. They express themselves well. They write."
At Texas A & M, philosophy majors -- like math and music students -- are benefiting these days from a job market desperate for computer scientists, said Dr. Leigh Turner, director of the university's career center. Students with such majors are thought to have an aptitude for technology jobs, she said.
In the early days of this century, philosophy was thought of as fundamental to a well-rounded liberal arts education, Mr. Hoffman of the American Philosophical Association said. Considered more than just the teachings of Socrates, Aristotle and Plato, philosophy was regarded as a broad search for knowledge, encompassing the latest scientific and social theories.
But that was before those concerns became independent fields of study, leaving philosophy with a narrower focus. And it was before college-age baby boomers gave way to a baby bust. Cash-starved colleges started looking for departments to trim. And students, watching the cost of a college education at selective private schools soar, turned into pragmatic consumers weighing the economic value of a diploma that could put them in debt by more than $100,000.
By 1994, one survey found that a philosophy course was required at only 18 percent of colleges, Mr. Hoffman said. Between 1992 and 1996, more than 400 standalone philosophy departments disappeared, according to the Directory of American Philosophers. Schools offering a major in the subject slipped from 683 to 660; those offering even scattered courses plummeted from 947 to 606.
All this occurred despite the fact that philosophy, in the last 20 years, has taken a more marketable turn as the issues faced in industry and the professions have grown more complex.
Dr. Bruner's career hints at the changes. He heads a medical team, including two ethicists, at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville that developed a surgical procedure for repairing spina bifida in fetuses. The procedure raised several ethical issues -- whether, for instance, it is appropriate to perform an operation that could kill a fetus incapable of giving consent to repair a condition that is not life-threatening.
"We've published almost as many articles on the ethics issues as on the medical issues," Dr. Bruner said.
While so many other schools were cutting back, Princeton has maintained what is widely considered one of the best philosophy departments in the country. Its famous graduates include Carl C. Icahn, the financier, who earned his B.A. in 1957; his senior thesis was titled "The Problem of Formulating an Adequate Explication of the Empiricist Criterion of Meaning." Philosophy majors in the class of 1977 have spent the last two decades building striking resumes -- just not in philosophy.
Jay M. Behmke, 42, did what so many philosophy majors do: He became a lawyer. But he built a practical career with a twist. After a few years in corporate law, followed by a year teaching in France as a Fulbright Scholar, Mr. Behmke returned to American wine country and became the chief financial officer at a winery. He then opened a law practice in Sonoma County, Calif., representing vineyards.
"Some days I'm sorry I didn't go on as a professor, because I did have some things to say," said Mr. Behmke, who taught undergraduate philosophy courses at Yale while attending law school there. "I have a fantasy of making a fortune and retiring early and teaching philosophy."
More men than women study philosophy; Nanci Heller McAlpin, a freelance writer in Manhattan, was the lone female philosophy major in Princeton's class of 1977. She knew from the start that she was not earning a practical degree.
"When we entered the department, we were handed a paper and it said, 'Why not to go to graduate school in philosophy,' " Ms. McAlpin recalled.
Such discouragements by Princeton and other schools apparently worked. The number of students earning doctorates in philosophy dropped to 298 in 1995 from 382 in 1976 and dipped as low as 215 in 1984, according to various studies.
But almost 92 percent of those with doctorates in philosophy were employed full time in 1995, compared with 85 percent of those with music Ph.D.'s and 87 percent with Ph.D.'s in art history, according to a study by the National Research Council. The median income for philosophy Ph.D.'s that year was $46,800, compared with median 1995 earnings of $48,100 for engineers and $124,000 for family doctors.
Unlike students who choose a major with a career in mind, philosophers typically fall into the subject by taking a class they enjoy, said Mr. Secada of the University of Virginia. One recent day here, students listened as Prof. James Cargile lectured on the utilitarian theory of justice, which holds that justice can be arrived at by weighing such things as the total happiness an act produces. But if that makes sense, he asked, should the person who enjoys wealth the most have more of it than others? In another class, Richard Rorty, one of the nation's best-known philosophers, discussed Nietzsche's thoughts on homosexuality and celibacy.
Like Princeton's, Virginia's class of '77 produced its share of lawyers, but graduates also headed for such typical philosophers' occupations as medicine and computing. And some who chose law came to it circuitously.
After graduation, Ralph Gilbert 3d turned to a profession of which Jefferson would have approved. He raised soybeans, sheep and pigs on his family's North Carolina farm for five years before drought, corn mold and mounting debt drove him from farming into law.
Mr. Gilbert, who is 45, said he still read philosophy and enjoyed philosophical discussions with a friend who is an Episcopal minister. He toys with the idea of going back to school for a divinity degree. But he credits philosophy with helping him neither in farming nor law; it has only improved his life.
"I think it influences the way I go about doing things," Mr. Gilbert said. "I think it's given me a sense of the complications that we face as human beings. It gives me a sense of the beauty and wonder of life. It helps me understand people in dire circumstances."
Of all the gifts that his philosophy degree has given him, said Dr. Bruner, the Nebraska graduate, creativity is probably the most important. Those who majored in science, then headed straight for medical school and years of practice can have a narrow outlook, he said.
"They don't have enough raw data outside their scientific training to provide those insights, those flashes of creativity," he said.
Philosophy has many strains, of course -- not all of them quite so evocative of those moments of Romantic inspiration. Briggs Myrick, a 1977 Texas A & M graduate, became a sales clerk and manager at a hardware store after college. But within three years -- and without further training -- he was programming computers at the university. The leap was easy, he said: A lot of the early computer scientists were philosophers.
"In philosophy, we study logic," he said. "We have a very mathematical way of going about it. Computers are a lot like that as well."
Both philosophers and computer programmers use Boolean logic, Mr. Myrick explained, though philosophers are more likely to call it Aristotelian logic. "Any assertion is either true or false," he said. "If it is true or false, it can be on or off. And it can be a switch. And computers have a lot of little, tiny switches."
Of course, philosophy majors work in fields other than law, medicine and computer science -- especially if they set out into the working world with just a bachelor's degree.
One Princeton graduate shelved books in libraries to support his interest in acting before returning to school years later for a master's degree in library science. One 1977 Virginia graduate sells herbs and flowers; another owns a service station.
Some 1977 philosophy graduates earn less than $30,000 a year; the herb seller expects to clear $6,000 in 1997. But more common are incomes of $50,000 or $60,000, and a few earn more than $200,000.
Money aside, Dr. Bruner figures that his philosophy degree helped make his medical career possible -- though there were moments of doubt. The 44-year-old obstetrician still recalls sitting before the admissions panel at the University of Nebraska College of Medicine, scrambling to explain why he wanted to be a doctor after majoring in philosophy.
"I told them that I could get a medical degree and still, to some extent, practice philosophy," he said. "But if I stayed in philosophy and tried to practice medicine, they'd probably try to put me in jail.
"Not one of them cracked a smile."

He is now a surgeon at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville, bottom, where he has used his training in ethics. (Anne Rayner for The New York Times)(pg. D4)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

NBC Losing 'Seinfeld' At the End of the Season
The most popular television comedy of the 1990's, "Seinfeld," will shut down production at the end of this season. The decision by the show's creator and star, Jerry Seinfeld, is a blow to NBC, which has seen its prime-time strength weaken this season. 
 "Seinfeld" has anchored Thursday night programming at NBC since 1993, leading the network, which is owned by General Electric, to its No. 1 position. "Seinfeld" alone has made more than $200 million a year in profits for NBC, according to advertising industry estimates. The network had offered a deal that would have been the richest in television history if Mr. Seinfeld had agreed to continue the show for just one more year. Page A1.
 
Holiday Sales Are Lackluster
Despite the strong economy and gains in the stock market, retailers estimate that sales this holiday season were up just 2 percent to 3 percent, about half the increase expected by industry experts. A1.
 
A Call for Extending Korean Loans
Japanese officials pressured Japanese banks to support the international rescue package for South Korea by extending loans as they come due next week. D2.
 
Bausch Focuses on Eye Care
Bausch & Lomb, which has decided to focus on eye care, has acquired Storz Instrument, a maker of ophthalmic instruments and drugs, and Chiron Vision. Both purchases are meant to bolster earnings. Market Place. D5.
 
Video Game Ads Draw Fire
Children's advocates say TV commercials for video games aimed at youths and young adults are getting violent, but producers argue that they are not very graphic and are meant to amuse, not provoke. Advertising. D5.
 
Japanese Company in Debt
A Japanese golf course operator, Nitto Life, has sought court protection from creditors along with its owner, Nitto Kogyo. Nitto Life claimed liabilities of about $532 million. D6.
 
U.S. Markets Reopen
Financial markets in the United States and in some other countries reopen today after being closed yesterday for Christmas. The New York Stock Exchange will close at 1 P.M. and bond trading will end around 2 P.M. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 19/32 , to 103 Wednesday. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.91 percent Wednesday (as shown above) from 5.87 percent Tuesday. As the last week of the year approaches, long-term interest rates are close to levels that investors have not seen for almost 30 years. Whether yields fall to that 5.75 percent range will depend on how quickly the robust United States economy, which grew at a pace of nearly 4 percent through the third quarter, begins to slow.

HEADLINE: Lack of Work Made Suspect Snap, Friends Say

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: DENVER, Dec. 25

 BODY:
A dismissed postal employee who held seven people hostage at a regional mail center on Christmas Eve may have snapped because he had been unemployed for 18 months, some who knew him said today.
The suspect, David Lee Jackson, 42, made a brief appearance in court today and was held on a $1 million bond on investigation of kidnapping, felony menacing and burglary. 
 Armed with a shotgun and dressed in camouflage and body armor, Mr. Jackson walked into a huge mailing center in Denver on Wednesday and held his hostages for nearly 10 hours, the police said. No one was hurt.
Negotiators said Mr. Jackson got tired and finally asked, "How do I get out of this mess?"
The police believe Mr. Jackson was seeking revenge over his dismissal for threatening a supervisor.
Robert Thompson, who knew Mr. Jackson, said he had never shown signs of violence.
"He might have snapped or something, but this wasn't like D.J.," Mr. Thompson said.
Johnny Peevy, whose wife, Paula Peevy, was a hostage, recalled meeting Mr. Jackson several years ago. Mr. Peevy said Mr. Jackson was "a pretty low-key individual, and he and my wife got along fine."
Some of Mr. Jackson's friends said he was being treated unfairly by the Postal Service's appeal process.
But another former co-worker, Bill Schmeiser, said: "Last time I saw him, he stated to me, 'If I ever step inside this building again, you better step aside, because I'm going to take care of business, and you know I got the weapons to do it.' "
The lawyer who represented Mr. Jackson last year in his employment case said he was bewildered by the incident.
"We weren't happy with the results," said the lawyer, John Evangelisti. "But he wasn't agitated about it."
Postal service officials would not comment on Mr. Jackson's employment record.
For the families of the five men and two women held hostage, their freedom was the gift they were praying for.
"It's the best I could ever ask for," Ken Martinez said after he was reunited with his wife, Jacqueline Tenorio.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Presses Banks to Give Koreans Time

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 26

 BODY:
Japan's Finance Ministry and central bank are putting pressure on commercial banks to support the latest international rescue effort for South Korea by extending loans as they come due next week.
Financial analysts here indicated on Thursday that they expected most Japanese banks to indeed roll over their existing loans to the Koreans, and their apparent willingness to do so increased the chances that an expedited rescue package would succeed for now. 
 Japanese banks are the biggest lenders to South Korea, with what is believed to be more than $23 billion outstanding to Korean borrowers -- nearly $14 billion of that due within a year. But the Japanese are also being pushed to the wall by their own financial crisis, and any concessions to South Korea could aggravate the banks' problems here.
With the Koreans thought by many to be close to default, the United States, Japan and other big industrial nations agreed on Wednesday to speed $10 billion to Seoul on an emergency basis in the next few weeks, besides urging commercial banks to ease their credit demands.
The new pledges came after a $57 billion rescue package led by the International Monetary Fund early this month seemed to prove inadequate in stopping the Korean financial hemorrhaging. Officials in Washington and Tokyo are concerned that defaults by South Korea could provoke world repercussions and conceivably spread Asian financial crises.
In Seoul today, the value of the Korean currency, the won, soared nearly 22 percent against the dollar, its largest one-day gain, with the advance attributed to the faster rescue effort. Around midday, the won traded at 1,505 to the dollar, compared with 1,836 late Wednesday.
Despite the tentative optimism, a few Japanese banks may be inclined to call in some loans because they are trying hard to pare exposure to South Korea as a step toward cleaning up their own balance sheets.
Most Japanese banks reached this morning would not comment on their plans, though some said they were evaluating their Korean lending.
Haruhiko Kimura, a Sanwa Bank spokesman, said: "In general, if there is a possibility of default, we have a responsibility to collect the loan because we have a responsibility to our stockholders and our depositors. So we can't just easily decide on the rollover or something like that without any assurance."
Loans to South Korean institutions make up only a small part of the overall assets of Japanese banks, which have a combined $217 billion in bad debt, according to latest official figures from the Finance Ministry. So the banks would not likely be crippled by their Korean exposure, even if all those loans were to go into default.
But the Japanese banks have been under extreme pressure to trim assets -- potential bad debts, in particular -- to meet capital-adequacy requirements and stricter banking codes soon to take effect.
Moreover, there is concern that the stock market here is so jittery about the potential for bank insolvencies that if Korean borrowers defaulted on loans, this could lead to greater instability in the Japanese securities markets.
"It will be another hit," said a Japanese financier, speaking on condition of anonymity, of the prospect of South Korean defaults.
The Korean central bank governor, Lee Kyung Sik, met this week with his Japanese counterpart, Yasuo Matsushita; Vice Finance Minister Eisuke Sakakibara, and several Japanese bank executives in an effort to persuade them to extend loans. In return, Mr. Matsushita expressed "strong expectations Japanese banks will roll over their loans on a voluntary basis," said Takashi Anzai, executive director of the central bank here.
The pressure on the banks from Mr. Sakakibara and Mr. Matsushita followed similar efforts by United States officials, who met with executives of six big American banks on Wednesday in New York.
"We don't think they need the money actually," a Japanese central bank official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "They are not in such a desperate position to use it, but this is to show our cooperative spirit."
South Korean banks and companies, however, certainly do seem to need cash quickly. Auto plants have halted production, and exports are stalled, with most transactions needing to be done on a cash basis.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles

LENGTH: 1229 words

HEADLINE: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/International;
Asia Aftershocks in U.S. Showrooms

BYLINE: By NOELLE KNOX

 BODY:
WANDERING the Kia or Hyundai showrooms at the Plaza Auto Mall in Brooklyn, a potential buyer sees no signs that the Korean auto industry is being shaken to its foundations. Sales in the United States are growing and so are cash payments from manufacturers to dealers to pump up sales.
"You can get up to $3,000 off a Kia Sephia, which makes it about the most affordable car in America, for around $8,000," said John Bruno, vice president and general manager of Plaza, which is in Brooklyn's Midwood section. 
 But it may not be long before American car shoppers start seeing some effects from the Korean financial crisis. Last week, the Hyundai Motor Company dismissed 31 people, or 7 percent of the staff at its American headquarters in California, including the vice president of product planning. The Daewoo Corporation, South Korea's third-largest auto maker, canceled its plans for an American debut next week at the Greater Los Angeles Auto Show, stirring speculation that the company will again postpone its entry -- for the sixth time -- into the United States market. And then there is Kia -- bankrupt, under control of the Korean Government and a likely takeover target.
The crisis that has consumed the South Korea economy has caused turmoil at most of the nation's leading companies, and the four domestic auto makers are no exception. With thousands of Koreans suddenly out of work and interest rates soaring, the country's auto sales are expected to drop 10 percent next year. The auto industry, already burdened by excess capacity at its plants, is staggering under the weight of huge loans.
"This is going to put them years behind where they wanted to be," said Michael L. Schmall, managing partner for the Planning Edge, a firm in Troy, Mich., that does consulting for auto companies.
The Korean auto makers, while still a relatively small force in the United States, had grand plans of becoming big global competitors. Hyundai, Daewoo, Kia and Samsung all borrowed heavily over the last 10 years to expand production and turn South Korea into the world's fourth-largest automobile market, behind North America, Western Europe and Japan.
Corporate bravado and Government subsidies built a national auto industry with three times as much plant capacity as the country needs. Today, the Koreans are capable of building more than 4 million cars and trucks a year, while domestic demand can sop up only 1.6 million vehicles. In 1996, Korean car exports totaled just 1.1 million.
"They never realized there would be a downturn," said Richard J. Pyo, an auto industry analyst in Seoul for Credit Suisse First Boston. "Now we're sitting on huge capacity and not enough domestic demand."
With Korean sales sagging and plants running at 80 percent of capacity, the auto makers are finding it harder and harder to pay interest on their loans. Eight industrial conglomerates, including Kia, have collapsed; the Korean currency has lost half its value, and the Government is seeking the largest international bailout in history.
So risky is the financial health of Hyundai, Daewoo and Samsung that on Monday Moody's Investors Service lowered their credit ratings to junk-bond status, making it difficult and expensive for them to borrow more.
The weakness of the Korean auto makers and parts suppliers has started a wave of mergers and acquisitions. Among the first deals, Daewoo snapped up the Ssangyong Motor Company (pronounced sang-YOUNG), a deeply indebted maker of sport utility vehicles.
Last week, John F. Smith Jr., chairman of the General Motors Corporation, told a small group of shareholders that he expected only Hyundai and Daewoo to survive, leaving Kia and Samsung to collapse or be sold. Mr. Smith said he had sent a team to Korea to scout for ailing auto parts companies to buy.
The Ford Motor Company is also watching Korean developments closely, partly because Ford and its Japanese affiliate, the Mazda Motor Corporation, already own about 15 percent of Kia. Ford's chairman, Alexander Trotman, said recently that he was interested in increasing Ford's stake. But some industry analysts say the Korean Government is unlikely to give Ford or any other foreign company control over an auto maker. Instead, these analysts speculate that Kia will eventually be sold to Samsung.
By acquiring Korean auto makers, American companies may be able to gain better access to the highly protected Korean market, and build cars with cheaper parts. The Clinton Administration is also trying to force the Korean Government to open its borders to American products by tacking free-trade conditions to its share of the International Monetary Fund's $57 billion loan package.
"Obviously, we want them to open their markets," said Andrew H. Card Jr., president of the American Automobile Manufacturers Association, a lobbying group for U.S. car makers. Mr. Card asked the Clinton Administration last summer to impose sanctions on South Korea for failing to comply with an automotive trade agreement signed by the two countries in 1995. "They should comply with that agreement whether there's an I.M.F. loan or not," Mr. Card said.
The fall in the value of the won, however, has worsened the situation by making imports from the United States more expensive. Last month, Ford, G.M. and Chrysler sold a total of just 268 vehicles in Korea, their worst showing in a year.
But for American consumers, the crisis may provide some good news. Trade officials are bracing for a flood of cheaper Hyundai Accents and Sonatas and Kia Sephias. Kia's United States sales jumped 74 percent in November, and Hyundai's rose 4 percent from a year earlier. While both companies say they have no plans to cut prices immediately, they are giving dealers larger incentives to help sell more vehicles.
"Kia's operations in America are crucial to the success of Kia Motors Corporation," said Geno Effler, a spokesman for Kia's American subsidiary, which is based in Irvine, Calif. "Right now we account for 25 percent of their exports. We are the No. 1 export market for Kia. I think there's a lot of room for us to grow."
Kia, which entered the United States market in 1993, opened 100 dealerships this year, including a total of 32 in New York, northern New Jersey and southern Connecticut. The company plans to sign up another 200 dealers in New England and the Midwest in 1998.
For Hyundai, higher sales volume is just what the company needs. American sales have stagnated for five years.
"Our operations are running at a loss," said Christopher L. Hosford, a spokesman for Hyundai's American subsidiary, based in Fountain Valley, Calif.
Part of the problem in the United States is that many consumers are not familiar with the products of Kia and Hyundai -- or worse, have bad memories of Hyundai's dreadful quality problems of a decade ago. The two companies' United States sales are expected to total about 160,000 this year, with Hyundai accounting for two-thirds of those.
"I don't know the public is really aware" of the companies' troubles in Korea, said Mr. Bruno, general manager of the Plaza Auto Mall, which sells both Korean brands. But he said he was not worried about his dealership. "These takeovers happen all the time. It's just part of business in general."
He added, "I think Korean car companies are going to be around a long time."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Silicon Alley on the Road

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
Like a startup hunting for cash, Silicon Alley, Manhattan's new-media district, will take a roadshow to Silicon Valley in California, or close to it, on March 16 and 17 for a conference intended to link West Coast investors with promising Internet entrepreneurs.
The conference, in San Francisco, is called "The Alley to the Valley," and it is sponsored by the city's Economic Development Corporation, the Information Industry Association and The Alleycat News, a newsletter for the Internet industry in the New York metropolitan region. At the conference, 24 New York companies are scheduled to present business plans. 
 "There is a natural fit between the Alley and the Valley," the publisher of The Alleycat News, Janet Stites, said."Many smaller New York area companies are seeking investors with resources and specific experience in technology, many of which are on the West Coast. Conversely, West Coast investors are looking outside of their region for high-impact investment opportunities."
Other sponsors include L. M. Ericsson A.B., KPMG Peat Marwick, Middleberg & Associates, the law firm of Morrison & Foerster L.L.P., Nationsbank Montgomery Securities Inc., the Nasdaq Stock Market, Prospect Street Ventures and the Silicon Valley Bank. NICK RAVO

HEADLINE: Giuliani Lashes Out at Critics of Traffic Plan

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Those who dislike Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's new plan to barricade pedestrians from several intersections in midtown Manhattan might want to avoid crossing his path for the next few weeks.
Departing from his customarily expansive holiday mood, the Mayor unleashed a barrage of withering sarcasm yesterday on critics of the plan to hasten automobile traffic that has had to sit idling while throngs of tourists and city residents cross the street. Opponents of the plan are "anticar" and have become "hysterical" about an experiment still in its infancy, he said. 
 "It's only been two days," he said. "It's only been two days. People thought that the whole situation with removing squeegee operators and aggressive panhandlers wouldn't work also. I remember that, four years to the day. And they were all certain it wouldn't work, and I would have to cancel it in a week or two weeks."
Under the new traffic pattern, pedestrians will not be allowed to cross north-south avenues at 10 intersections on 49th and 50th Streets in midtown, where holiday foot traffic has been the heaviest. To allow motor vehicles to turn without yielding to walkers, the Police Department is setting up large barricades manned with police officers, who instruct pedestrians to cross an adjacent street before crossing an avenue.
The traffic pattern began Tuesday, but, apparently anticipating criticism, the city did not announce it until a day later. It will last until Jan. 5, when the Police Department will evaluate how well it worked before deciding whether to continue it.
The plan was suspended yesterday because of pedestrian crowds and light holiday traffic, but is to resume today, said Officer Olga Mercado, a police spokeswoman.
Although drivers like the restrictions, pedestrians have assailed them as a surrender to the dark forces of petroleum. Advocates of mass transit and foot power have been particularly upset about the move, laced as it is with symbolic implications about who is winning a primal New York contest.
The Mayor has for four years demonstrated a famously low tolerance for criticism of his initiatives, and yesterday he seemed exasperated that so many people had run down the idea, which originated with the Police Department.
"I think instead of being cynical critics immediately, they should give this plan a chance to work," he said. "It's a pilot program. Don't get so frightened by it. It's really amazing. There are these people that, when any change happens, they immediately become hysterical about it. 'Oh my God, this is going to happen; that's going to happen.' "
Those people should get used to the idea that cars are here to stay, he said, and are essential to Manhattan's economic vitality. The "new spirit of New York," he said, is to try something innovative and see if it works. "If it doesn't work, we quietly slip away from it, and try something else," he said.
The Mayor's comments were made at a news conference held just after his annual visit to Merrill Lynch's Christmas Calls program, which allows senior citizens from around the city to make free long-distance calls to friends and relatives worldwide.
It was a typically mercurial performance by Mr. Giuliani, ranging widely across the various moods he displays in public.
He began by sorrowfully announcing the death of a girl, whose parents are police officers, in a Queens house fire. Then he puckishly described the various ties and games he gave and received for Christmas after attending midnight Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral with his wife, Donna Hanover, and their two children -- one of the few public appearances he has made in recent months with his entire family. (One of the gifts he received was a computer game simulating the Battle of Gettysburg.)
He then showed a little invective on the subject of pedestrian traffic, and got in a few digs at his two predecessors in office, who will not attend his inauguration next week.
He ended the event with a warm tribute to Pope John Paul II, whom he praised for acknowledging the roots of Christianity within Judaism in a holiday homily.
"He understands the religion he presides over is derived from Judaism," Mr. Giuliani said. "Giving that demonstration and that sense of unity is a wonderful thing, and hopefully it will help to bridge some of the other gaps that were there."

HEADLINE: Big Gift for a Small-Town Library

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: DAMARISCOTTA, Me., Dec. 20

 BODY:
When she closes her eyes, Barbara Cooney sees the library of her dreams: the yard in front of the sturdy white clapboard building with black wooden shutters is a garden with lilac bushes and an apple tree whose blossoms occasionally fall on a reader's open book.
Inside children read at pint-sized desks and experiment on computers while the literary club discusses Tolstoy upstairs and visitors on the main floor leaf through genealogy books or sit in overstuffed chairs reading the history of this town, 50 miles up the coast from Portland. 
 A wealthy longtime resident of Maine and an award-winning author of 109 children's books, Ms. Cooney acknowledges that she has always been a dreamer. But at the age of 81, she decided that she could no longer wait for Damariscotta's 2,000 residents to scrape together the $2 million needed to make her dream come true. So she has donated $550,000, the largest gift in the town's history, on condition that the town raise at least $250,000 to help build a new library.
While Ms. Cooney has given generously to colleges and other causes, she has abandoned her preference for quiet giving in this case to encourage others to support their public libraries. Many Americans do not realize, she said in her crisp, emphatic style, that such contributions are tax deductible.
Ms. Cooney is not alone in favoring donations to her local library. Many of the nation's 9,000 public libraries, 90 percent of which serve populations of fewer than 50,000 people, had tough times in the early 1990's because of the recession and budget cuts by state and local governments.
But total library budgets rose by 6.4 percent in 1996, while budgets for books and other materials rose 7.1 percent, matching the 7 percent increase in 1995, according to The Library Journal, which is published by the American Library Association.
Several local libraries, moreover, have reported receiving unusually large gifts this year, often from the estates of people who were loyal users. In November, the public library in Hickory, N.C., received a $1 million gift from the family of Patrick Beaver, a 17-year-old who was killed in a boating accident this year. His father, Don, said that partly because of the library, his son had overcome a reading disorder and received straight A's.
In May, the Fairfax County Public Library in Virginia received a $1 million gift, the largest in the state's library system. The money was pledged by Orrin W. Macleod, who died of leukemia in 1994 at the age of 58. An avid reader, Mr. Macleod never went to college but wisely invested the money he received as a baggage handler and member of the ground crew of Eastern Airlines in Washington. The money is for the books-on-tape program, which he relied on after his vision became impaired.
The estate of Elinor Vidrine, a retired government worker who used material she read in the New Orleans public library to help her invest the money that quietly made her a millionaire, repaid her debt in November with a $780,000 gift. And in June, the Community Foundation of New Jersey committed $400,000 to the Montclair Public Library's capital campaign, the largest single award in its history, from an anonymous donor, who is matching every new dollar that the library raises, up to $400,000.
More than a third of all public libraries that seek public gifts have formed special units for this purpose in the last five years, said the American Library Association, which represents 57,000 public school, academic and special libraries from its headquarters in Chicago.
Thanks to Ms. Cooney's efforts, the Skidompha Public Library in Damariscotta recently bought the house next door for $300,000, and it has already raised more than $90,000 of the matching funds needed for the expansion and renovation, scheduled to begin in spring. Architects are being invited to submit competing designs. And Ms. Cooney, who had been considered an outsider because she came from Waldoboro, eight miles away, has suddenly become the town's heroine.
Ms. Cooney's rescue effort comes none too soon, said Ellen Welsh, the head librarian and another outsider, a former Bostonian who has worked at the library since 1972. The Skidompha Public Library, which grew out of a social literary club in the 1880's, has been located since 1922 in a house built in 1803.
The Skidompha, whose name is an acrostic based on the first letters of the club's original members, is cramped and deteriorated. The roof leaks; its plastered walls are peeling; and its carpet is threadbare. The card catalogue of its 30,000 books is not computerized, and its sole computer for the public broke down again recently. The seven-seat reading room is damp and drafty. So is the wing for children, built in 1974, which also has seven seats. A rickety staircase leads to the dilapidated second floor, where literary clubs still meet despite the fire marshal's edict that the area is unsafe.
Ms. Welsh said that last year was a struggle just keeping the library open six days a week for 38 hours with a staff of three, one of whom works part time, to accommodate those who made 33,800 visits.
The Skidompha, with an annual operating budget of about $90,000, received $500 from the state in 1997. Damariscotta and Newcastle, sister towns across the Damariscotta River and both served by the library, appropriated $16,790. Sales of secondhand books raised an additional $9,000. A library movie club generated $6,000. The rest came from income from the library's $200,000 nest egg, a reflection of wealthier times, and from donations to the $30,000 annual fund-raising drive.
This year, Ms. Welsh said, although town residents have generously supported the expansion project, only $24,000 has been raised for operations.
"We're not likely to make our goal this year," she said. "The romance is in giving to a new building."
The town desperately needs a bigger library. Because of its beauty, the town is growing, said Charles Ault, the chairman of Damariscotta's three selectmen, who manage the municipal affairs. For the last few years, it has been attracting people who adore the town's quaint drug store with its original soda fountain and rows of flavored colas but who are also accustomed to libraries and espresso bars like the River Cafe, which sells rugs from Turkey and Afghanistan and violins that its owner refurbishes.
As a result, Mr. Ault said, the Skidompha will probably not have much difficulty raising the $250,000 for Ms. Cooney's challenge grant or the rest.
"My bank is making a substantial contribution," he said, referring to Bath Savings, which he manages, one of five in the area.
Ms. Cooney insisted that the new library be built downtown as a condition of her donation, one of the few restrictions she placed on the gift. Another gives her "esthetic" approval of the new structure.
But she has not asked that the building be renamed in her honor, nor for any of the other public acknowledgments that are routine in the ego-driven world of philanthropy.
She said she was more than satisfied with her books, her four children and many grandchildren. Ms. Cooney, who was born in Brooklyn to wealthy parents who spent their summers in Maine, has twice won the Caldecott Medal for her children's books, which she writes and illustrates. A tiny, fit woman with wide blue eyes and a thick braid across her impeccably groomed silver-white hair, she shows no signs of slowing down.
"I think they're afraid I'll die before the project is finished," Ms. Cooney said of the library development committee, of which she is co-chairwoman. "But I'm planning on living to 100, and I usually do what I set my mind to."

HEADLINE: As Korea Faces Economic Crisis, Emigrants Feel a Sad Vindication

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Heung Choi and her husband, Eung, came to America in 1974, long before South Korea's economic miracle. Then, as they struggled and built a new life running a small bookstore in Manhattan, they saw South Korea blossom with sudden riches, and found themselves wondering about the immigrant's path they had chosen.
"In Korea, people would say, 'Immigrants are beggars,' " Mrs. Choi said. "So it became hard to say 100 percent that we made a good choice to come over here." 
 But now, as South Korea tries to dig out from a staggering crisis in its currency and economy, the tables have turned again. Although the Chois say they are full of sorrow, rage and shame about the plight of their homeland, their lives in America have suddenly taken on a new meaning. The burdens of immigrating -- and learning a new culture and language -- were not a mistake, after all.
"I am so relieved to be here," Mrs. Choi said.
The story of South Korea's economic crisis is for the most part a global tale of multinational corporations and geopolitics, but it is also an American story, intimate and personal -- and full of emotions that are far more complicated than old-fashioned sympathy.
In Korean neighborhoods in New York and across the nation, the spasm of austerity and patriotic self-denial that has gripped much of South Korea has found its mirror image in a sense of complicated, ambiguous victory.
From greengrocer workers in Manhattan to shoppers in the strip malls of Koreatown in Los Angeles, Korean-Americans said the humbling of their homeland had produced an unexpected flush of vindication -- sometimes expressed openly, sometimes only quietly, almost guiltily: A poorer South Korea makes the sacrifices of immigrants in America easier to justify.
But at the same time, many said they were tortured and distressed and ashamed at South Korea's economic humiliation, and they have thrown themselves into various local efforts to show solidarity with the austerity drive back home.
Answering an appeal by the Korean Association of New York to "send $100 home," immigrants have stood in long lines at Korean-owned banks to transfer money to relatives. Christmas parties have been canceled. The tradition of taking co-workers and clients to dinner has become muted, hurting restaurants from Flushing to Fort Lee, N.J. Store owners on Union Boulevard, the main Korean commercial strip in Flushing, say that shoppers are simply not buying.
The monetary crisis has had more direct consequences as well -- especially in areas tied to tourism, which has fallen off sharply. That has hurt restaurants, hotels and travel agencies, particularly in New York and Los Angeles, which have the two largest Korean communities in the nation.
In Los Angeles, the annual holiday influx of Koreans flying in to visit relatives -- or to continue on to the gambling tables of Las Vegas -- simply did not materialize this year. Export sales to South Korea have stalled.
"Deals that were supposed to close in recent weeks didn't," said Y. B. Kim, who heads the Korean-American Family Services Center, a social services agency based in Los Angeles. "It's almost impossible to do business with Korea at this point."
But to a greater degree, by embracing the spirit of austerity, Korean-Americans have hurt themselves.
"They're not spending money -- they're sending it home," said David Kim, the owner of Ace Golf Shop in Flushing, which was empty and silent on a recent afternoon.
The South Korean economy, meanwhile, has continued its wild ride. On Tuesday, the nation's currency, the won, hit another low against the dollar, rising slightly on Wednesday. The stock market in Seoul fell 7.5 percent on Tuesday and 4 percent more on Wednesday. (The markets were closed on Christmas Day.) Political uncertainty and speculation run rampant about what policies President-elect Kim Dae Jung will follow when he takes office in February.
Almost as unsettling, in the Koreatowns of America at least, is the seething question of blame.
Through much of the 1990's, as South Korea grew rich, immigrants began to resent the lavish spending habits of their newly affluent Korean cousins back home, and to bridle at what they said were the sometimes patronizing attitudes about the American immigrants' life and the often backbreaking work it demanded. The immigrants predicted that dire consequences would result from the profligacy and arrogance they witnessed. Now they say the crisis has proven them right, but at a terrible cost.
"In a way, I think Korean immigrants are relieved by what has happened," said Pyong Gap Min, a professor of sociology at Queens College who immigrated in the early 1970's. "They can say, 'My choice to immigrate was better.' "
"But feelings are very conflicted," he added. "On the one hand, they are relieved. On the other hand, it's their home country, so they are concerned."
Mr. Kim at the Ace Golf Shop in Flushing said he thought everything was changing -- what it meant to be Korean and to be American and how to live between those worlds. When he last visited South Korea in 1993, he said that people would meet him and say, "There's an American beggar, let's buy him a beer."
"I think a lot more Koreans might prefer the American dream now," he said.
Indeed, in many ways there are two completely different American dreams for Koreans in New York. One became familiar through the 1970's and 1980's as immigrants entered the fruit and vegetable business. Families working together through endless days in tidy shops became a symbol of immigrant success. Since 1980, the Korean-American population in the New York metropolitan area -- immigrants and their American-born children -- has doubled, to about 400,000, according to the Korean Association of New York.
Growing wealth in South Korea in the 1990's pushed a second wave of arrivals, this time with money in their pockets. At Columbia University's American Language Program, for example, which costs more $30,000 a year for an English-language immersion program, South Korea overtook Japan in the last few years as the country with the most foreign students.
The rising wealth in Asia also encouraged many South Korean companies to expand in America, but experts on the New York Korean community said that relatively little money flowed back the other way. Few Korean-Americans in New York have been hurt by, say, falling real-estate values in Seoul -- though travel agents report many would-be investors from New York flying there now to look for bargains.
At the Chois' bookstore, the economic effects are decidedly mixed. The price of books shipped by Korean publishers has fallen because of the shifts in currency exchange rates. But publishers, frantic for dollars, are demanding immediate payment on everything they ship, and that more than cancels out any benefit.
"I thought nothing would affect here," Mrs. Choi said. "But here and there is all connected, I see now. Everything is a circle."
But many attitudes and perceptions that have divided Koreans and Korean-Americans still persist. At a meeting of Korean-born and American-born Korean students arranged for a reporter at a Columbia University dormitory, one student, Brian Chang, sputtered about the "disgusting" examples of waste, like expensive cars, on which some South Korean students had spent their parents' money.
"In some ways, I think Korea got too rich too fast and couldn't handle the responsibility," said Mr. Chang, the son of Korean immigrants, who is studying engineering management. Then he hastened to apologize to Korean-born friends in the room who, he stressed, were not at all like that.
Ivy Kim is not so apologetic.
"The foreign students, they need this knock in the head," said Ms. Kim, a 23-year-old clerk in her mother's clothing store in Flushing, which is called Rainbow Fashion. But she is also not without compassion. One of her best friends, she said, is a foreign student -- a senior at the New York Institute of Technology, who was one semester from graduation when the crisis in South Korea struck.
Ms. Kim has been trying to talk her friend into living with her in Queens, saving the $1,500 a month in Manhattan rent she is paying now, and finishing her degree. The only other alternative for her friend, Ms. Kim said, is to return to Korea immediately. Though her friend's family is still sending money, it doesn't go far enough now to pay the bills.
Some students, from both wealthy and more humble circumstances, have already left, or decided that they cannot stay.
Eunsook Jee, a 22-year-old college student with a shy smile and clunky black-framed glasses, came to America last spring with no greater ambition than to learn English. She took a job in a Korean restaurant by night and studied English by day at Queens College. But her family has told her she must return home, three months early, and this week she sat in a travel agent's office in Flushing, checking prices.
The reasons are at least partly financial, Ms. Jee said, especially the nearly doubled cost of her expenses in America. But perhaps from pride, or to save face, her parents have offered another explanation as well, she said.
"They say they miss me," Ms. Jee said.
Mrs. Choi, at the bookstore, said the crisis reinforced her belief that dependable, solid looking surfaces can lie.
"We thought we were doing so well,' she said. "Now all of sudden, for nothing, there is no money in the bank -- we don't know how these things happen," she said, referring to the South Korean economy. "I feel so, so, embarrassed, and so annoyed -- very mixed."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
In Quiet Session, Dollar Rises Against Yen but Dips vs. Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the yen yesterday amid mounting worries about the Japanese economy and fears of a brewing credit shortage.
The dollar slipped against the German mark in thin trading volume in a quiet post-Christmas holiday session. 
 Many European markets, particularly in London -- the chief foreign-exchange center -- were closed yesterday. And currency traders in New York wrapped up business soon after the early closing of the Treasury and currency futures markets.
The dollar settled in New York at 130.41 yen, up from 129.85 yen on Wednesday. The dollar was also quoted at 1.7725 marks, down from 1.7735 marks. And the pound rose to $1.6779 from $1.6703, its highest level against the dollar since Nov. 24. Markets in the United States and Europe and some Asian markets were closed on Thursday for Christmas.
The dollar rose against the yen after a sharp drop in Japanese stocks. The Nikkei index of 225 issues tumbled 3.25 percent yesterday, ending below the psychologically important 15,000-point level.
"The Nikkei below 14,000 is going to be very scary," said Chris Melendez, senior dealer at Sanwa Bank California. "Some banks will no longer be able to meet the Bank of International Settlements' capital adequacy minimums."
Japanese regulations allow banks to hold part of their capitalization in equities. At the end of the Japanese fiscal year on March 31, Japanese banks must show on their books the diminished value of their holdings of equities. The Asian financial crisis has put Japanese banks on heightened guard against extending risky loans, resulting in a brewing credit shortage, analysts said.
In other bearish news, Japan's retail sales were reported down 4.7 percent in November, compared with figures from the month a year earlier, for the eighth consecutive monthly decline.
Traders expected the focus on the dollar-yen exchange rate to intensify next week as the market remained divided between hopes of dollar strength and fears of further Bank of Japan intervention. The Bank of Japan intervened last week, selling $10 billion in dollars to prop up the yen after it slumped to a 67-month low against the dollar.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Venezuelan Growth Put at 5.1% in 1997

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 26

 BODY:
Venezuela's economy grew 5.1 percent this year, fueled by an expansion of the oil sector and increases in consumer spending and foreign investment, the Government said today.
The robust growth followed the contraction of the economy last year after President Rafael Caldera imposed austerity measures to foster free markets. 
 Much of the 1997 expansion was a result of an 8.8 percent gain in the oil sector, the central bank's president, Antonio Casas Gonzalez, said.
Venezuela, the main foreign supplier of oil to the United States, increased its daily oil exports by some 300,000 barrels, to 3.065 million barrels a day in 1997, the central bank said. That put it well over its quota of 2.583 million barrels a day in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
For the first time in two decades, the Government has decided to allow foreign companies to invest in Venezuela's state-controlled oil sector.
Preliminary figures show that direct foreign investment reached $4.346 billion this year, mostly directed toward the oil sector and the privatization of state-run banks, Mr. Casas said. Direct foreign investment in 1996 was $1.575 billion.

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Move Higher, Helped by Slow Holiday Sales

BYLINE: By Bridge News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended slightly higher yesterday in very light trading.
Talk of disappointing holiday retail sales and the dollar's advance against the Japanese yen helped bonds yesterday, but traders said the moves were meaningless because they occurred on such thin trading volume. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 5/32 , to 103 5/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, slipped to 5.90 percent from 5.91 percent on Wednesday. The Treasury market was closed on Thursday for Christmas, and it closed early yesterday as it did on Wednesday.
About $14.8 billion of securities changed hands yesterday, about one-fifth of the volume during normal trading sessions, according to the GovPx bond pricing service.
Prices moved lower during the Asian trading session, where there was reportedly some foreign selling. Many European markets were closed yesterday, and trading in New York got off to a slow start.
Late in the morning, prices began to do a little better, and Charles Reinhard, a market strategist at the ABN-Amro Chicago Corporation, said the activity showed that traders were still interested in buying on dips.
He said another factor might have been the newspaper reports yesterday that holiday sales had failed to meet retailers' expectations for the third consecutive year, and he said the dollar's gains against the yen might have played a role as well.
The Treasury market will turn its attention next week to the December survey from the National Association of Purchasing Management on Friday. Traders will watch Wednesday's December report from the Chicago purchasing managers for clues to the national survey.
Analysts are expecting a slightly weaker December national purchasing managers' reading at 53.9, compared with 54.4 in November. The report's reading on new export orders could give some sense of how much impact Asia's problems have had on United States economic activity.

HEADLINE: Outlook Is Mixed for Orange County

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., Dec. 26

 BODY:
The recent upgrading of Orange County's credit rating was good news for the county, which filed for bankruptcy three years ago, but the move will not cure its immediate financing problems.
County officials and bond industry experts say the strengthened rating represents an important step that along with other improvements, could result in more money for county projects in two or three years. 
 In the meantime, however, everything from jail construction to property maintenance remains on hold because of the financial collapse.
Moody's Investors Service said last week that the county had made enough progress with its finances since the December 1994 bankruptcy to earn "investment grade" ratings on most of its bonds.
Since the bankruptcy, the county's debt had carried "junk bond" status.
The improved rating means the county will be able to borrow without the inflated interest and insurance costs it now must pay.
The county is in the process of drawing up a comprehensive long-term financial plan that tries to forecast future county income and expenses, as well as project the costs of 30 high-priority projects.

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 372 words

HEADLINE: Flawed Day-Care Plans

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is drawing up plans to increase day-care subsidies for working parents as a central element of next year's domestic agenda. The goal is worthy, but only if the subsidies are directed where needed -- to low-income families.
The Administration no doubt agrees, but it is trapped by a Republican leadership that has no intention of going along. So the White House is thinking of including a tax cut for working parents. The cut would direct very little relief to the truly needy, but the Administration hopes that it will help sell more worthwhile parts of the package. This is a risky strategy because it invites the G.O.P. to pile on tax cuts of its own, forcing Congress to trim other domestic spending programs. 
 Day-care subsidies help low-wage workers keep more of what they earn and help parents place children in the best environment. Many low-wage parents ask relatives to care for children, often with unsatisfactory results. Targeted subsidies would allow them to purchase better day care.
The Administration is also considering increased grants to states, more money for after-school programs, model day-care centers and training for day-care workers. These are useful ideas. The tax cuts are not. One would cut taxes for corporations that create day-care centers -- despite the fact that many corporations are already creating centers, without any nudge from Washington, as a recruiting device in a tight labor market.
The other would expand a provision in the current tax code that provides up to $1,400 in tax credits for day-care expenses for a family with two or more children. But few families collect anywhere near the maximum benefit because most of them are too poor to owe much tax in the first place. The expanded tax credit would mainly help families earning $30,000 or more a year.
The bigger danger is that the White House will inadvertently create a launching pad for more tax cuts. The cuts could conceivably be paid for by temporary surplus revenues that flow from a hot economy. But when the economy slows, Congress is far more likely to cut already strained discretionary programs that are essential to poor families than it is to eliminate the new tax breaks.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Euro to Ignite Merger Boom, Analysts Say

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Even European multinational companies do not quite grasp what is coming -- but the creation of a common European currency just over a year from now, analysts say, will set the stage for a wave of consolidations in banking and industry over much of the Continent.
Eleven of the European Union's 15 members are expected to adopt the euro on Jan. 1, 1999, establishing a single-currency economic zone with more than 280 million people, slightly more than the United States, and a gross product of $6.7 trillion, rivaling the more than $7 trillion economy of the United States. 
 With national currencies expected to be transformed into fractions of the euro, banks and corporations in the monetary bloc will be able to make acquisitions, sell subsidiaries and initiate other financial transactions free of European exchange-rate risks, in the way that American companies now do throughout the 50 states.
Monetary union is expected to result in broader and more liquid capital markets, with the prices of stocks and bonds all denominated in euros. It is likely to push interest rates generally lower over the longer term, according to participants at a series of recent conferences in Manhattan on the monetary future of Europe.
The result, analysts say, is likely to be a cross-border merger spree. The 270 or so banks in European Union countries could eventually consolidate into "five or six major players, like in New York," said Philippe Ithurbide, chief economist of the capital markets division of the French bank Societe Generale.
Mr. Ithurbide, speaking at a conference organized by Niche Systems Inc., a software company that helps computers function in euros, predicted that a boom in mergers and acquisitions would also reduce the number of small and medium-sized publicly traded companies in European Union nations to roughly 350 from about 1,200 today.
"Europe has too many small caps at present because the market is fragmented and opaque," he said, referring to public companies with relatively small market values. "A single currency will end that and promote a wave of consolidations. U.S. investment will also increase, and that will promote consolidation, too."
The new euro zone is also expected to be a more competitive place, with the emerging mega-banks ruthlessly trimming back inefficient operations, some believe. Patrick Poncelet, an executive with the Swift clearing system of Brussels, which handles $3 billion worth of cross-border financial transactions daily, predicted that an "overbanked banking sector" in Europe would shrink by 30 percent over the next five years.
"The euro will have a dramatic effect on banking and cross-border transfers, increasing competition and accelerating consolidation," Mr. Poncelet said at a symposium organized by the New York Law School.
For all the impact the euro is likely to have on their operations, most European businesses are surprisingly unprepared for its debut, according to Gonzalo Perez-Piaggio, an economist at KPMG Management Consulting in London. A KPMG survey of the 300 largest European companies, he told the New York Law School conference, found that "just 2 percent were fully prepared, while fully two-thirds had no idea what its introduction would cost them."
Eleven nations -- Germany, France, Italy, Spain, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Ireland, Finland, Austria and Portugal -- plan to join the new monetary system on New Year's Day, 1999.
Three others -- Britain, Sweden and Denmark -- have opted out of the early stages, and Greece has been excluded for failing to meet the economic and financial criteria for membership.
Paris and Frankfurt are expected to emerge as the financial capitals of the new Europe. But the Bank of England believes that London's status as a world financial center will assure it most of the international business in euro dealings.
"Increased euro activity in Paris and Frankfurt means more activity in London, which will be the euro's interface with the world," Len Berkowitz, the Bank of England's legal adviser, told the New York Law School meeting. "London likes deep, liquid markets and sees the euro as an opportunity, not a threat."
While monetary union is expected to bolster the region's economies, business casualties are likely, as well. Foreign-exchange dealers will be the first, in Mr. Poncelet's view. With the need to trade French francs for German marks or Italian lira for Spanish pesetas disappearing, he predicted that banks across Europe would lose $5 billion in commissions and trading profit from 1999 to 2004.
"Paris and Madrid will be worst hit because half their trading volume is in vanishing currencies," he added.
But at the Niche Systems conference, Neal George, chief economist at the Mercantile Bank of St. Louis, forecast that banks would make up lost currency profits with fees from the expected wave of mergers.
"Deal makers will do well during the euro's early years," he said.
A single currency will also make it harder for multinational companies to charge different prices in national markets. Mr. Perez-Piaggio of KPMG said that pharmaceutical producers would be particularly squeezed because their prices commonly varied by as much as 60 percent among national markets. Catalogue retailers may do well, however, since the single currency will make their prices easily comparable with local shops throughout Europe.
The big unanswered question is how the euro will fare against the dollar. Because of the expected strong influence of Germany in a new European central bank that will control monetary policy, some analysts believe that the euro will be a strong currency.
Others, though, noting the likely entry of traditionally high-inflation southern European countries like Italy and Spain, worry that the euro could flounder.
Such disparate forecasts were on display at a conference sponsored by the Brussels-based European Finance Convention Foundation. David L. Abramson, an economist at the Bank Credit Analyst Research Group in Montreal, said the euro needed to be "weak but not soft" to avoid increasing unemployment and stimulating protectionism.
And he warned that the value of the United States dollar could plunge against the euro if the new central bank quickly sold a lot of its excess dollars.
At the same conference, Prof. Peter Kenan of Princeton University predicted that the European central bank would act decisively to create a strong euro in order to establish its credibility. He stressed that the bank would be run exclusively by people who now occupy positions of authority in European central banks, and noted that the governors of the southern European central banks, who will sit on its council, were all "anti-inflation hawks."
At the New York conferences, there was broad agreement that the euro would only gradually challenge the dollar's role as the world reserve and invoicing currency.
"There will be great inertia here," predicted Jean-Pierre Patat, general manager of the foreign department of the Bank of France. Dollar markets, he added, will seem "safer and more homogeneous" for a long time.
Then there is the question of what happens to contracts written in currencies that are to disappear. European legislation already makes them enforceable in euros, and laws being enacted in New York State, Illinois and California should cover more than 90 percent of financial dealings between the European single-currency countries and the United States.
"I think U.S. courts will see the euro as the replacement for vanished currencies and uphold contracts written in them," said Daniel P. Cunningham, a partner at the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore.
Of course, the repercussions of European monetary union will not be known until after the 1999 startup. The only near-certainty, said Sydney M. Cone, a professor at New York Law School and the organizer of the conference there, is that a single currency is coming to Europe after decades of hoping and planning.
"It is going to happen," Professor Cone said. "We don't know all the consequences. But we can at least alert the business, financial and legal communities to what it might imply."

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 19.18, to 7,679.31, As Gains in Korea Spill Over

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
An overnight rally in South Korea's ravaged stocks contributed to mild gains in the United States stock market yesterday, but many investors stayed away from a shortened post-Christmas trading session that was the slowest of the year. The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 19.18 points, or a quarter of 1 percent, at 7,679.31, narrowing its loss for the week to 76.98 points.
In the broader market, advancing issues led decliners by 1,470 to 1,220. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 154.9 million shares in a trading session that ended three hours early at 1 P.M. It was the slowest day in 1997, falling below the previous low of 189.70 million shares set on Nov. 28, the day after Thanksgiving. 
 "The overseas markets, particularly in Korea, had a reasonably good night, and that provided us with the impetus to rally at the open," said Phil Orlando, chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management. "But nothing came out of our own market to sustain it."
There was no economic news, and many traders were still away for a long Christmas weekend.
"The market has found its footing here on the lower side," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company. Nonetheless, he said, "I don't think you can read too much into today's action."
South Korea's main stock index rose 6.74 percent yesterday as investors concluded the worst of the financial crisis may have passed with word that economic assistance from the International Monetary Fund would be accelerated.
American depository receipts of Asian stocks traded higher in New York as Seoul's optimism spilled over. Korea Electric Power gained 1 1/16 , to 11 1/4.
Stocks also were buoyed by a rebound in technology stocks. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index rose 11.85 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,511.38.
Microsoft, which tumbled to a six-month low on Wednesday, regained some ground. The stock, which topped the most-active list on the Nasdaq, rose 1 13/16 , to 120 3/4.
The Dow average was bolstered by I.B.M.'s gain of 2 9/16 , to end at 101 11/16 . A rebound in shares of Merck, another Dow component, also helped. The big pharmaceutical company's shares rose 2 1/4, to end at 103 1/2.
Big bank stocks also rose as worries over their earnings exposure to South Korea eased. Citicorp was up 1 9/16 , to 121 15/16 . Chase Manhattan Bank was up 2 5/16 , to 106 11/16 , and BankAmericaclimbed 1 9/16 , to 70 13/16.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Jockeying For Position In South Korea

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
About a dozen of the country's most influential commercial and investment banks will huddle with Federal Reserve officials in New York on Monday morning, discussing ways to shore up South Korea's ailing borrowers.
United States lenders, as well as their counterparts in Europe and Japan, are being pressured by regulators to roll over problem loans until the South Korean economy stabilizes. But what if the economy does not stabilize? 
 Despite the emotional relief that has accompanied the South Korean bailout, there are strong signs that financiers and diplomats are still extremely anxious about the fate of the country and they are scrambling to avoid what will certainly become a series of more serious financial measures should the South Korean economy continue to stall.
Although the South Korean stock market rebounded about 7 percent yesterday after steep declines the previous two days, many analysts say the economic crisis is still in its infancy. Japan, which remains an economic wild card, was battered by a 3.25 percent stock market drop yesterday. And the grim financial statistics from South Korea suggesting the possibility of corporate defaults soon may take on a more human face -- one scarred by layoffs and personal bankruptcies.
To stanch the hemorrhaging, the International Monetary Fund and other institutions have devised a $10 billion rescue package to be delivered to South Korea in early 1998.
Amid the rescue effort, American companies, while not the biggest creditors in Southeast Asia, appear to be positioning themselves in a show of support for the region's long-term prospects -- and in the process snap up some corporate bargains.
The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the General Electric Company, the General Motors Corporation, and J. P. Morgan & Company are all said to be looking at ailing companies in the region, while Merrill Lynch & Company has confirmed that it plans to take over 50 branches of the Japanese brokerage firm Yamaichi Securities. Chase, G.E., G.M., and J. P. Morgan all declined to comment on the speculation.
Monday's Fed meeting will be followed by a more broadly attended gathering of financial institutions later in the day at J. P. Morgan. The second meeting will not include regulators. Both meetings are expected to produce some sort of additional private financing for South Korea, and it is clear from the list of companies involved in the meetings that it is no longer only banks that are being asked to ante up.
The invitation list for the Fed meeting originally included only commercial banking giants like Chase, Citicorp, BankAmerica, J. P. Morgan, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation and the Bank of New York Corporation. It has now grown to include some of the country's largest investment banks as well. Invitees include Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Smith Barney Inc., which have been hired as financial advisers to the South Korean Government and are said by bankers to be leading candidates to underwrite a planned $9 billion debt offering by South Korea early next year, as well as Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company.
If any of this hurried financial maneuvering by the I.M.F. and the financial giants fails to stop the hemorrhaging in South Korea, financiers and politicians are considering the possibility of repackaging all of the country's bad debt -- both public and private -- as sovereign debt guaranteed by the South Korean Government, according to bankers and American officials close to the talks.
The amount of debt that would have to be consolidated in South Korea is hard to pin down, but there is no question that the number is enormous and would be far larger than any comparable amount of bad debt that was amassed in a single Latin American country during that region's lending crisis a decade ago. South Korea's short-term external debt as of mid-December may have stood at about $60 billion, according to a recent report by the Institute of International Finance, a trade group representing hundreds of the world's largest financial institutions.
Another issue presented by consolidating all of the bad debt is the impact it would have on the balance sheets of lenders. American banks, for example, have noted that their exposure to South Korea is relatively limited and far less than that of the Japanese. Banks, however, engage in significant amounts of so-called "off-balance sheet" financing in South Korea that are not completely captured in their public filings. These include such products as interest-rate and currency swaps, and other derivatives. If South Korea's debt is consolidated, those figures would have to be disclosed and the level of off-balance sheet activity would quickly become apparent.
"It wouldn't surprise me at all to find the overall exposure to a catastrophic event in South Korea is greater than the banks have disclosed, but I don't think it's anything on the order of magnitude of what occurred in the 1980's in Latin America," said Diane Glossman, an analyst with Lehman Brothers Inc.
