HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Fire Sale to Foreigners Expected in South Korea
Already humbled by an international bailout, South Korea is now confronting another serious blow to its national pride: the prospect that American and other foreign companies will snap up valuable domestic companies that took generations to build. 
 The nation's weakened stock market and currency, combined with eased rules for foreign ownership, are making many South Korean businesses extremely attractive takeover candidates. Even the singer Michael Jackson is getting into the act, negotiating to buy a ski resort from a bankrupt South Korean underwear maker. Page A1.
 
Mild Post-Christmas Rally in Stocks
The stock market ended higher in the slowest trading of the year, with prices helped by overnight gains in the South Korean market and a rebound in some technology stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 19.18 points, or 0.25 percent, to 7679.31, narrowing its weekly loss to 76.98 points. D10.
 
Dollar Rises vs. Yen on Japan Fears
Anxiety about the consequences of a credit shortage in Japan and broader fears about the Japanese economy helped the dollar rally back above 130 yen yesterday, but the dollar slipped against the mark. D11.
 
Japan's jobless rolls swelled by 160,000 people in November to 2.28 million, the biggest jump since July 1996 and the seventh consecutive increase, leaving the overall unemployment rate stuck at a record high of 3.5 percent, the Government reported. D3.
 
Japanese Firms Punished
Daiwa and Nikko were penalized for their involvement in paying off racketeers. Regulators fined Daiwa a total of $1.46 million and Nikko $1.15 million, and the Finance Ministry suspended both from conducting some types of securities transactions for more than three months. D3.
 
Britain Unwelcome in Euro Talks
Britain's decision to keep the pound at least until 2002 has made it unwelcome at increasingly intimate discussions about European monetary union held by 11 other countries planning to meld their currencies into a single denomination, the euro, in January 1999. The British Government is not pleased that its key European trading partners are excluding it from these policy meetings. D2.
 
Bonds Strengthen in Light Dealings
Treasury bonds ended higher on talk about disappointing holiday retail sales and the dollar's advance against the yen. But trading was extremely light, and dealers did not ascribe much significance to the bond market's behavior. D10.
 
Nissan Reducing Development Time
The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's No. 2 auto maker, will spend more than $300 million to upgrade a computer-aided design system aimed at cutting costs and the amount of time it takes to develop models, from 19 months presently to 12 months. If successful Nissan would be the fastest Japanese auto maker in the design and creation of new vehicles, industry analysts said. D3.
 
Calpers May Seek Board Seats
The California Public Employees' Retirement System is drafting a policy that would allow the nation's biggest pension fund to seek board seats on corporations in which it is a major stockholder. Such a change would reflect the increasingly involved role the $127 billion pension fund has taken in recent years, particularly regarding companies it regards as underperformers. D14.
 
A Barbie Sets Off a Debate
Mattel introduced Puerto Rican Barbie as part of the company's Dolls of the World line last January, and the doll has been popular in Puerto Rico. But the doll has also caused a heated debate among Puerto Ricans in the United States, many of whom find her objectionable on several counts, from her light skin to her colonial-style dress to the history lesson on the back of the doll's box. Puerto Rican Barbie has long, wavy brown hair and coffee-colored eyes in contrast to the blue-eyed version, above, introduced by Mattel in 1959. A1.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
As Market Turmoil Eases, Korea Shifts Focus to Labor

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Dec. 27

 BODY:
With fears of imminent default receding and the markets rebounding in his nation, President-elect Kim Dae Jung turned his attention on Friday to another potentially explosive problem: labor.
Widespread layoffs look ever more inevitable, so Mr. Kim met with the nation's top labor leaders to try to persuade them to accept the increasingly grim economic reality that is settling over South Korea. In a nation with an intensely militant labor force, however, any talk of layoffs opens the door to deep uncertainty, even when options seem few. 
 "If things do not improve within the next couple of months or so, there is nothing else we can do but to cut loose redundant employees," Mr. Kim said after the meeting. "We should work together to prevent this unfortunate situation."
As a first step, aides to Mr. Kim said, new procedures will allow banks and other financial institutions to dismiss workers if needed to help expedite a merger or acquisition. Until now, South Korean banks have essentially been barred by law from dismissing workers except when bankruptcy looms or after intricate negotiations with union representatives.
Yet it remains unclear whether the drastic situation in South Korea will cause a fundamental shift in labor practices, like abandoning virtually sacrosanct job security, or will simply instill resentment among workers.
On Friday, South Korea's stock and currency markets reversed the downward spiral of recent weeks, surging in reaction to the decision late Wednesday by the United States, Japan and Europe to expedite $10 billion of emergency loans to avert possible default.
It took 1,498 South Korean won to buy a dollar on Friday, a 22.6 percent increase in the currency's value from Wednesday, when the exchange rate was 1,836 won to the dollar.
Stock prices in Seoul rose 6.7 percent, and long-term interest rates, a barometer of investor confidence and inflation fears, fell to 27 percent from 29 percent.
The stock market was flat in abbreviated trading today. The market closed up 1.16 points, or three-tenths of a percent, at 376.31.
"The mood is much better than it was two days ago," said Lee Han Ggoo, president of the Daewoo Economic Research Institute here. "We don't have to worry about the supply of foreign exchange any more, just the price."
Mr. Kim helped send the markets diving earlier this week when he expressed surprise at finding out just how serious South Korea's debt problems were, though he may have been trying to lower expectations about any quick recovery or fixing blame on his predecessor, President Kim Young Sam.
Kim Dae Jung apparently had some success convincing labor leaders that attracting foreign investment was a precondition of stabilizing the labor market.
Park In Sang, president of the Federation of Korean Trade Unions, said after the meeting that he would write letters to the International Monetary Fund and to international bankers to assure them that his unions would respect the $57 billion I.M.F. agreement to help rescue South Korea, including the requirements that Seoul loosen labor practices and open financial markets.
"Layoffs must be the last option," Mr. Park said. But he added, "Members of labor unions rely on Kim's philosophy of highly regarding a stable labor market."
Mr. Kim, who had pledged during his presidential campaign not to allow corporate layoffs, said that if layoffs had to occur in the financial sector, only later would they come to manufacturing industries.
One of his aides described the outlook more bluntly.
"We are preparing for massive layoffs at manufacturing companies as well as banks," said Chang Che Shik, who serves on an economic task force dealing with the financial emergency. "Such moves still require more discussion and some concessions by labor unions."
That is the kind of talk that seems to terrify other labor leaders, one of whom warned that grave difficulties might arise if workers were dismissed unfairly or precipitously.
"If the proper procedures are not followed, there will be problems," said Yoon Young Mo, international secretary of the Korean Coalition of Trade Unions. "It would set off a downward spiral, losing confidence. There will be wide discontent throughout our society."
Mr. Yoon estimated that of the 13 million people formally counted in the South Korean work force -- not including small, family-run businesses -- perhaps one million were likely to lose their jobs in the coming year. He said that 120,000 workers had been dismissed in the last month, though the Ministry of Labor has not officially confirmed it.
Yet he also predicted that street demonstrations, very common in South Korea in recent years, were less likely because so many people fear for their jobs, if they still have them.
"Many workers are frightened," Mr. Yoon said. "They will accept layoffs if there is a process in place that shows them there is some control. If there is not, it is hard to predict what will happen."
Mr. Kim apparently decided to set an example in his office, announcing this week that he plans to cut in half the number of personal secretaries for the president's office. Mr. Kim, who was elected last week, is scheduled to be sworn in on Feb. 25.
South Korean courts took a step toward greater strictness with the nation's financial institutions, rejecting applications from the Coryo Securities Corporation and the Dongsuh Securities Company to seek bankruptcy protection. They will probably be sold or closed instead.
The South Korean Government has promised to force insolvent finance companies out of business as part of the package arranged by the I.M.F. In the past, no Korean brokerage firm has ever been permanently closed down.

GRAPHIC: Photo: With the prospect of huge layoffs, worries of possible labor unrest in South Korea grow. Unions have clashed with Seoul before: In 1989, a strike at Hyundai Heavy Industries ended when riot police stormed the shipyard. (Agence France-Presse)(pg. D3)

HEADLINE: Wrong Turn on City Traffic?

 BODY:
Strolling past Rockefeller Center on the day after Christmas delivers a walloping reminder about New York City. More people want to be there than the laws of time and space permit. Workers who did not qualify for a long weekend vied for control of the sidewalks with gawkers admiring the fabled Christmas tree, tourists determined to take each other's pictures in the center of the pedestrian traffic flow, a man playing "Jingle Bells" on a flute for spare change, and skateboarders trying to execute a curbside flip. Except for the skateboarders, whom we would sacrifice in a second, who is to say which claims for turf have the top priority?
Rather than throw in his lot with any of the above, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has taken the side of the motorist against them all. Earlier this week, city police blocked off crosswalks at 10 intersections of 49th and 50th Streets so that cars and trucks would find it easier to make turns. The forces of footpower instantly howled in protest. The Mayor labeled his critics "hysterical" and "anti-car." 
 A great many people in New York City are indeed anti-car, and for good reason. Most people there do not own automobiles, and rely on subways, buses and cabs. The antagonism between pedestrians and motorists is as venerable as the hatred between landlords and tenants, and as puzzling to visitors from other parts of the country. Mr. Giuliani spent his formative years on Long Island, and perhaps his perception of traffic matters still bears a suburban perspective. While defending his new policy, the Mayor launched into a lecture on the importance of the automobile in which he suggested that making life easier for private motorists was necessary to the city's economic development. But the scene yesterday along Fifth Avenue showed exactly how misguided that idea can be. One great engine of economic growth in midtown Manhattan is tourism, and the tourists come to walk the city's streets, not drive on them. When the competition between people on foot and people behind the wheel reaches a crisis point, the city's economic future may demand that the Mayor defend the sidewalk contingent, not dismiss it.
Nevertheless, there is no great harm in conducting a two-week experiment to see if closing off a few crosswalks greatly improves traffic flow during the holidays. The number of people walking near midtown tourist attractions this time of year is so high that only one or two vehicles can make a turn through the crosswalks during each light change. No one benefits if buses, cabs and delivery trucks are trapped in perpetual gridlock. Forcing pedestrians to walk out of their way to cross the street in order to ease the seasonal crush is a trade-off worth studying.
But for the Mayor to unveil what is basically an anti-pedestrian initiative, then suggest it might be duplicated in other parts of midtown and couple that with a pep talk on the rights of motorists is the wrong turn to take. No wonder what looked like a modest traffic control experiment raised an outcry.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Minorities Flock to Cause Of Vouchers for Schools

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: DENVER, Dec. 26

 BODY:
A new class-action lawsuit here underscores the depth of support among black and Hispanic parents nationwide for a favorite cause of the conservative movement: publicly financed vouchers to send children to private and parochial schools.
"It is only natural that African-Americans and Hispanics would sign on," said Joe Rogers, a conservative black lawyer who helped organized the lawsuit. "They are among the most affected by public education in this country." 
 Recruited at black churches and Spanish grocery stores, nearly 3,500 mothers and fathers of public school students had joined the case by the time Mr. Rogers closed the rolls of plaintiffs last month. "If we had kept going, we would have had 10,000 plaintiffs," he said.
Indeed, two national polls this year indicate that blacks favor vouchers more than whites. In a Gallup poll in the summer for Phi Delta Kappa, a professional education association, 72 percent of black respondents favored vouchers, while the general population split evenly on the issue, with 48 percent for vouchers and 48 percent against them. In a second survey, support for vouchers ranged from 65 percent of Hispanic respondents to 56 percent of blacks to 47 percent of whites. The poll was conducted in the spring for the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a Washington research group that specializes in black issues.
"It's common sense; the poorest people want help," said Janie Perry, administrator of the Watch-Care Academy, one of two all-black private schools that opened here recently. "Minority children are the ones doing the worst in public schools. But parents have no money for alternatives."
Although court challenges are legion, voucher proposals are being prepared in about half of the nation's 50 states. The plans run the gamut from bills in state legislatures to proposals for state constitutional amendments to initiatives by local school boards.
Only a handful of voucher programs have been established. The nation's two largest, in Milwaukee and Cleveland, serve low-income, largely black and Hispanic children.
The program in Cleveland covers 3,000 children, while the Milwaukee program, launched in 1990, covers 15,000. Reading and math scores have improved for children participating in both programs. Last summer, Harvard University researchers surveyed parents of children receiving vouchers in Cleveland and reported that two-thirds were "very satisfied" with the program.
In the black community and in civil rights organizations, vouchers appear to be deepening a generational and income divide between the older, more affluent leadership and the younger, more impoverished rank and file. Last summer, for example, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People voted to oppose vouchers.
But, in the poll for the Joint Center, vouchers for private and parochial education were supported by 86 percent of black respondents between the ages of 26 and 35. In contrast, only 19 percent of blacks 65 and older supported vouchers. The greatest support for vouchers came from poor blacks -- 70 percent of those earning less that $15,000 advocate such plans. Support dwindled to about 50 percent among those making over $35,000.
Undaunted, the N.A.A.C.P., teachers' unions and Democratic politicians have led anti-voucher rallies around the nation. They argue that vouchers will drain public funds and the best students from already beleaguered public schools.
"Instead of abandoning our schools, we should continue to support proven reform efforts," President Clinton warned in September before the Senate voted to block a voucher experiment for the District of Columbia. "I will veto any legislation that damages our commitment to public education."
But some Democrats are breaking ranks. Representative Floyd Flake, a New York Democrat and member of the Congressional Black Caucus, was a vocal supporter of efforts to create a $7 million voucher program for 2,000 poor children in Washington.
Fueling some black dissatisfaction is the end of busing to promote integration, and the resegregation of many public schools.
"There has been a fundamental fear that has existed among black folks," said Mr. Rogers, who went to public schools here in the 1970's. "I said, 'O.K., if I send my kid across town, they'll be likely to put money in. But if the schools are resegregated, they will be less likely to put in resources.' "
In Denver, the end of busing two years ago coincided with a perception of general decline in academic performance in public schools.
Last month, the first districtwide reading and writing scores for 4,700 fourth graders illustrated just how low minority achievement is in the schools. The results showed 58 percent of white students were proficient in reading and 31 percent were proficient in writing. Among black and Hispanic students, 24 percent were proficient in reading and 10 percent in writing.
Even before those scores were released, the parents of black and Hispanic students, who account for three-quarters of the 68,000 in the system, were widely dissatisfied.
A survey of Denver voters in May by Ciruli Associates found that 93 percent of blacks and 80 percent of Hispanic respondents agreed that "some children in the Denver public school system are receiving a substandard education."
Despite Denver's reputation for high education levels, the high school dropout rates are 34 percent for Hispanic students, 23 percent for blacks and 16 percent for whites.
Anger over the situation is aiding the voucher movement.
Last week, proposed language for an amendment to the State Constitution that would permit vouchers was submitted to a legislative review council by Tom Tancredo, president of the Independence Institute, a conservative policy group here.
Opponents of vouchers, who argue that they would undermine public schools, are quick to point out that in 1992 Coloradans rejected, by a 2-to-1 ratio, an amendment to give $2,500 to each child in the state to spend on the school of choice, public or private. The new proposal gives the Legislature two years to create "one or more pilot programs designed to empower parents to choose among the widest array of quality educational opportunities."
The Republican-controlled Legislature seems increasingly open to alternatives. Two weeks ago, faced with a request for an increase in the education budget, Tony Grampsas, chairman of the Joint Budget Committee, described the fourth-grade reading results as "really, really pathetic."
Last week, State Education Commissioner Bill Moloney threatened to withdraw accreditation from public schools that did not raise their reading and writing test scores.
In political circles, some critics say Mr. Rogers, a Republican, is trying to create a wedge between the Democratic Party and black and Hispanic voters, traditional supporters of the party. They say that by signing up 3,483 plaintiffs, he is furthering a hidden agenda: building a base for his campaign next year for lieutenant governor. Mr. Rogers dismisses those accusations, saying his sole motive in bringing the suit is poor conditions in the schools.
The suit, filed in Denver District Court against the city's school system, calls for vouchers and transportation for any students who want them, but it seems to have little chance of winning without a change in the State Constitution.
Mr. Rogers appears to be sowing fertile ground. In October, a "tax credit" for school choice was supported by 71 percent of 400 Colorado voters surveyed by Public Opinion Strategies, a national polling company.
Anti-voucher forces are unmoved.
"Creating a system of vouchers is not going to solve the reading problem," said Beverly Ausfahl, president of the Colorado Education Association, a teachers' union.
The best students would be skimmed from the public schools, Ms. Ausfahl said, while the poorest of the poor would not be able to afford private schools.
The Denver School Superintendent, Irving Moskowitz, argues in favor of strengthening public schools rather than helping finance private institutions. He said the district's student-teacher ratio is low at 22 to 1, that it has placed reading aides in the first and second grades and that it inaugurated mandatory summer school reading classes last summer for 3,200 students.
In addition, Mr. Moskowitz said, 20 percent of the students exercise choice by attending charter schools or magnet schools outside their neighborhoods.
"Realistically," he asked, "how many spots will there be in Denver private schools?"
Nationally, 11 percent of the 52 million elementary and high school students attend private schools. Denver is roughly in line with this trend.
Arguments like Mr. Moscowitz's do not sway Vivian Wilson, administrator of the Union Baptist Excel Institute, an all-black private school where discipline and a back-to-basics curriculum are underscored by plaid uniforms that all students wear. The school charges slightly less than half the $4,700 that Denver pays to educate each public school student.
"Everyone should have the right to choose, whether they are poor or not," said Mrs. Wilson, who waives her school's $52-a-week fee for one-third of its 179 students. "If you have the free-market system for education, you can't hold black or Hispanic people against their will."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Phillip Hunt, a first grader, worked on a mathematics problem earlier this month at Union Baptist Excel Academy in Denver. Private school costs have poor parents trying to work out math problems of their own. (Kevin Moloney for The New York Times)(pg. A7)

SECTION: Section A; Page 11; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 704 words

HEADLINE: Journal;
Soak the Rich

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
"Did people really give each other the finger in 1912?" asked a skeptical teen-age film critic as we emerged, highly satisfied customers, from "Titanic." Well, in truth, that gesture was hardly the only deviation from historical verisimilitude in Hollywood's $200 million re-creation of the century's most beloved spectacle of mass death. My favorite was a painting in a stateroom that looked much like Picasso's "Les Demoiselles d'Avignon." If it indeed went down with the ship, then the picture at the Museum of Modern Art is the curatorial hoax of the century.
But such errors inevitably creep into movies like this. In the immortal Liz-and-Dick "Cleopatra," the Most Expensive Epic Ever Made in my youth, a Roman bath boasted a rubber sponge then ubiquitous in suburban American kitchens. The point of the grandest Hollywood period extravaganzas -- especially if they aspire to be box-office blockbusters -- is not to find the truth about whatever past is being re-created but to hit upon a crowd-pleasing sentiment about the present that will enthrall the movie's contemporary audience. 
 The Titanic has been the subject of roughly 20 movies to date, and, as Steven Biel demonstrates in his invaluable cultural history of the disaster, "Down With the Old Canoe," each reflects the mood of its own time. As the most popular Titanic movie until now, "A Night to Remember," expressed 1950's nostalgia for the pre-nuclear age, so our own "Titanic" was destined to be truer to 1997 than 1912, no matter how faithfully the director, James Cameron, reproduced every last brandy snifter of the White Star Line.
It's Mr. Cameron's screenplay, not just the special effects, that holds us for more than three hours, and it's very much a 90's take on the familiar Titanic themes of gender and class. His "Titanic" is driven by a feminist heroine who defies her stuffy First Class compatriots to take up with a guy in steerage. And that guy in steerage -- the movie's hero -- is, of all things, a penniless artist who draws nudes.
Mr. Cameron's villains, meanwhile, are rich men, who rarely fare well in Titanic retellings but do spectacularly poorly in this rendition. (They're even anachronistically damned as "masters of the universe," Tom Wolfe's 1980's phrase.) Along with the reliably skunky ship's owner, J. Bruce Ismay, there's a new, fictional tycoon who's a still bigger blackguard. The only prominent rich character who's not hateful is an earthy woman, Molly Brown, a democrat if not necessarily a Democrat.
Given the economic boom in America right now, it might seem surprising that the rich-bashing populism of "Titanic" would go down so easily. But the gap between the wealthy and everyone else is still with us, and Mr. Cameron, a prescient artist, sees past smooth seas better than the Titanic's captain did. While Americans generally do admire self-made millionaires who play by the rules, they can turn quickly, and rabidly, on those who abuse their power. George Soros, yes; Michael Milken, no.
After the Titanic sank in 1912, the radical labor leader Mother Jones gave speeches decrying the supposed gallantry of its wealthy passengers, most notably John Jacob Astor. In 1997 the movie "Titanic" has been released just as our own Astor, Bill Gates, is receiving the harshest criticism of his career as a consequence of Microsoft's thumbing its nose at a judge's order in its antitrust case. The new issue of Mother Jones, the present-day magazine, echoes its namesake's rhetoric about Astor when it likens Mr. Gates to "greedy" monopolists of the past. It's not the only publication taking that line.
When the ship sinks in Mr. Cameron's movie, tears are shed only for the poor. The wealthy are presented as ripe for comeuppance; though the most evil villain survives, we're quickly reassured that he will meet a grisly end anyway, appropriately enough in the crash of '29. Should Mr. Gates, or any other potentially hubristic baron of the New Economy, have any doubts about how a tycoon's arrogance plays in the court of American public opinion then or now, he'd be wise to join the mobs of moviegoers cramped like passengers in steerage to watch the sold-out shows of our new "Titanic."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
KOREAN COMPANIES ARE LOOKING RIPE TO FOREIGN BUYERS

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
South Korea, already humbled by having to accept an international bailout, is facing what could be another blow to its national pride: a wave of takeovers of its companies by American and other foreign corporations.
The nation's plummeting stock market and currency have made Korean companies potential bargains for foreign companies, just as the International Monetary Fund's economic rescue is forcing the nation to open up to foreign investment. 
 Moreover, most of South Korea's family-owned conglomerates are either bankrupt or reeling under heavy debts and are being forced to sell parts of their treasured empires.
The insolvencies are piling up fast. Just today, Chonggu Group, one of South Korea's biggest construction companies, sought court mediation to reschedule debts of more than $1.1 billion after banks demanded immediate repayment.
"The country is about to see a fire sale of some of its major assets, but that's the only way out," said Senator Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, who dined with Korean business leaders in Seoul earlier this month. "There is a feeling of regret, that because of failures of business judgment, they are losing assets that took generations to acquire."
The expected acquisition spree is just beginning, and only a few concrete proposals have come to light. For instance, Bowater Inc., a manufacturer of newsprint in Greenville, S.C., is negotiating to buy a stake and gain some management control of the Halla Pulp and Paper Company and its huge new plant built with German technology, according to Halla. The paper company is owned by the Halla Group, which defaulted on its loans this month.
The troubled Hanwha Group, meanwhile, is negotiating to sell its oil refining company to a foreign buyer, reportedly Royal Dutch/Shell Group. It has already sold its half of a joint venture in chemicals to its partner, BASF of Germany, and is looking to sell 25 percent of its securities unit.
Even the American singer Michael Jackson is getting into the action, negotiating to acquire a ski resort from its owner, a bankrupt Korean underwear maker.
But these could be just the tip of the iceberg. Seoul is awash in "industrial tourism" as businessmen and financiers shop for properties.
"Anybody and everybody with money is looking at Korea," said an executive at the Seoul branch of an American investment bank. "Everybody seems to be doing their homework right now."
The Korean Stock Exchange's composite index has fallen 42 percent this year, near its 10-year low, while the Korean currency, the won, has lost nearly half its value against the dollar. Combining these declines, stock prices have fallen about two-thirds this year in terms of dollars.
Samsung Electronics, the world's largest producer of computer memory chips, now has a market capitalization -- the value of all its shares outstanding -- of $2.4 billion, about what it would cost to build one of its state-of-the-art factories.
Korean Air Lines, with a fleet of more than 100 jets, has a market capitalization of $240 million, less than the price of two Boeing 747's. As an anti-takeover precaution, employees' year-end bonuses are being used to buy 4 percent of the company's stock on behalf of the employees.
But the cheap market values can be deceptive because they ignore the sometimes enormous debt an acquirer might have to take on. Samsung has 11.9 trillion won, or $7.9 billion, in debt. The debt of Korean Air Lines is more than $5 billion.
Still, the prospect of foreign acquisitions has elicited some fear and anti-foreign sentiment in fiercely nationalistic South Korea. The Hankook Ilbo, a daily newspaper, illustrated an article with the headline "The Coming Corporate Hunting Typhoon" with a picture of a bald eagle, its wings spread wide, swooping down on Seoul.
But attitudes are already starting to change, as best exemplified by Kim Dae Jung, the nation's President-elect. During the campaign, Mr. Kim attacked the I.M.F. agreement, in part because it would lead to takeovers of Korean companies.
"Now foreign investors can freely buy our entire financial sector, including 26 banks, 27 securities firms, 12 insurance companies and 21 merchant banks, all of which are listed on the Korean Stock Exchange, for just 5.5 trillion won," or about $3.7 billion, he said at a news conference on Dec. 5, two days after the bailout was announced.
But on Dec. 19, the day after he was elected, Mr. Kim declared: "I will boldly open the market. I will make it so that foreign investors will invest with confidence."
Driving the change, of course, is the desperate need to attract foreign capital to avert a catastrophic default on South Korea's mostly private foreign debt. But some businessmen say that besides money, Korea could also use a dose of Western management and efficiency to make companies more competitive.
So, driven in part by the I.M.F., South Korea is dismantling rules that have made the country one of the hardest in the world for foreigners to invest in and do business in.
The amount of stock in a Korean company that a single foreign investor can hold was raised this month to 50 percent from 7 percent, allowing a foreign individual or company to get control of a Korean company in some cases. With an agreement reached this week, even that limit will be lifted soon for friendly acquisitions.
Even before this round of changes, however, it has been possible for a foreign company to buy a Korean company in a friendly deal approved by the Government. Hostile takeovers are banned, though that might change under the I.M.F. rescue.
Still, some analysts say that foreign companies will not move quickly, thinking that prices can still go lower and that the economy will sink deeper into recession. In addition, buyers and sellers are disagreeing on the appropriate price.
"Most of the people coming in have the attitude that everything is bargain basement" said Jeffrey D. Jones, a lawyer with the Seoul law firm of Kim & Chang. But Korean owners, according to Mr. Jones and other analysts, are not looking at market value, which they see as temporarily depressed, but at the higher figure of book value, which reflects what they invested.
Another factor discouraging potential buyers is that companies are often part of bigger conglomerates, making it difficult for a buyer to pry the shares loose. It would also be difficult in South Korea to do what acquirers often do in the West -- lay off workers and sell off unneeded parts of the operation. Some of those restrictions, however, are being eliminated as part of the I.M.F. agreement. And as one of the concessions it made as part of the latest round of international aid, Seoul agreed to ease the rules governing layoffs at banks and financial institutions to make these entities more attractive to suitors.
Buying will also not be limited to foreigners, as seen by the acquisition of troubled Ssangyong Motors by Daewoo Group, accomplished largely by Daewoo's agreement to assume $1.3 billion in debt.
The Government is moving to relax rules that hinder conglomerates from making acquisitions or owning more than 4 percent of a bank. The conglomerates are complaining that it is unfair and foolish to allow Korean companies and banks to be taken over by foreigners while locking other Korean companies out.
So far, the foreign acquisitions have tended to involve industrial companies buying out Korean partners in ventures..
For instance, Coca-Cola in November bought its main Korean bottler from the Doosan Group for 430 billion won, about $450 million at the time but now about $290 million. Procter & Gamble bought control of Ssangyong Paper Company from the Ssangyong conglomerate for $69 million when the deal was announced.
Rumors are flying about other potential deals. One report centers on the Ford Motor Company buying Kia Motors, the automobile company that declared bankruptcy last summer. Ford has declined to comment.
Ford and its Mazda subsidiary together already own more than 17 percent of Kia. The question is whether, to protect that investment, Ford might increase its stake in Kia to gain management control, as it did last year with money-losing Mazda.
Alexander Trotman, Ford's chairman, told reporters recently that Ford was not interested, according to Bloomberg News. But he said that if asked by the Korean Government to consider a takeover, "I'd react by buying a plane ticket and go see them to negotiate."
General Motors and two German companies, Robert Bosch and Sachs A.G., are said to be interested in buying Mando Machinery, Korea's largest maker of automobile parts.
Mando, which is part of the Halla Group, has a fundamentally strong business. But it guaranteed some loans to Halla's ship-building subsidiary, which defaulted, forcing Mando to seek court protection from creditors.
Another possible buyer is Ford, which has several joint ventures with Mando to make car air-conditioners and other components in Korea and elsewhere. It is already planning to increase its stake in one of the ventures, in Canada.
Foreign automobile companies, which have been virtually locked out of the Korean market, might be interested in buying the dealer network of Ssangyong Motor, which is likely to be put up for sale by Daewoo, which already has its own network.
In the financial sector, the Government has indicated it will sell at least one troubled bank to a foreign concern. Citibank and Chase have been rumored to be interested in buying something in Korea, though Citibank has denied it.
Despite the interest, Korean rules and sensitivities also might make some buyers think twice before acquiring national flag-bearers like Samsung Electronics and Korean Air. And it will be a long time before Seoul sees the rough-and-tumble takeover battles of the United States.
"I don't think you're going to have T. Boone Pickens or Carl Icahn dropping in to look around for cheap assets and launch a junk bond takeover," said Richard Samuelson, head of research at SBC Warburg Dillon Read in Seoul.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

INTERNATIONAL A3-6

Laotian Refugees Suffer After Food Aid Is Denied
The United States Department of Agriculture's decision to cut off food stamps to the families of Laotian veterans of the Vietnam War has led to despair and suicides among these refugees in the few weeks the cutoff has been in effect. A1 

Arafat Plans Peace Overture
Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat announced that he would present his own plan for peace with Israel when he meets with President Clinton next month. The plan includes a proposal to station international peacekeeping troops between Israel and the West Bank, maps for the next Israeli withdrawal and a concept for final status negotiations. The plan follows weeks of debate within the Israeli Government over which parts of the disputed West Bank should be retained by Israel. A3
 
Iraq Sees U.S. Plot
Iraqi leaders accused the United States of planning air strikes to plant false evidence of chemical or biological weapons in their country. They met to discuss the continuing crisis over Iraq's refusal to allow inspectors to examine some sites for signs of weapons of mass destruction. The White House immediately dismissed the charge as "ridiculous." A3
 
Flu Transmission in Hong Kong
International health workers reported the first evidence of probable human-to-human transmission of a new viral strain of influenza in Hong Kong. The transmission was detected from recent blood tests in a physician who cared for a 3-year-old boy, the first known human case of the strain, who became sick in May and later died. According to health officials, the virus was transmitted by physical contact and did not spread beyond the doctor. A4
 
Tibet Referendum Proposed
The International Commission of Jurists called for a United Nations-supervised referendum on the future of Tibet. It stated that the cultural rights of Tibetans have deteriorated sharply since a Chinese forum was held three years ago to study the Tibetan question. The commission has been following events in Tibet since the 1959 Chinese attack that forced the Dalai Lama into exile. A4
 
French Party Leader Convicted
Jean-Marie Le Pen, the far-right leader of the French National Front party, was convicted of violating a 1990 French law that made it a crime to deny the magnitude of the Holocaust. After he dismissed the gas chambers of World War II as a "detail in history," French civil rights groups filed a complaint against him, winning a judgment that will require him to pay $50,000 to publish the text of the decision in French newspapers. A5
 
Struggle for Candor in Chiapas
Mexican officials announced they had charged 16 men with first-degree murder in the killing of 45 people in a tiny village in southern Mexico on Monday. Attorney General Jorge Madrazo Cuellar said the case was in its "earliest stages." A6
 
NATIONAL A7-9, A12
 
Minority Parents Seeking Publicly Financed Vouchers
A new class action suit in Denver underscores the depth of support among black and Hispanic parents nationwide for a favorite cause of the conservative movement: publicly financed vouchers to send children to private or parochial schools. Joe Rogers, a black conservative lawyer who helped organize the suit, recruited nearly 3,500 mothers and fathers of public school students at black churches and Spanish grocery stores before he closed the rolls of plaintiffs last month. A1
 
A New Barbie Controversy
Puerto Rican Barbie was an instant hit when the doll was introduced in Puerto Rico in January by Mattel Inc. as part of the company's "Dolls of the World" line. But Puerto Rican Barbie has caused a heated debate among Puerto Ricans in the United States. Many on the mainland find her objectionable on several counts, from her light skin to her colonial-style tiered dress. They also bristle at the history lesson on some editions of the doll's box. A1
 
Bowles Considers Leaving
Erskine B. Bowles, President Clinton's chief of staff, has made no secret of his desire to leave the grind of Government service early next year -- after having made no secret of the fact that he wanted to leave last fall. But Mr. Clinton has made clear that he would prefer that Mr. Bowles leave later rather than sooner, in part because he does not have an obvious candidate to take his place at the White House. A1
 
Judicial Activism Challenged
A murder case in Pennsylvania has reopened the debate over whether Federal judges should be able to bar retrials of controversial cases on the state level. Pennsylvania's senior Senator, Arlen Specter, and two of its Congressmen have introduced legislation that would strip Federal judges of the power to ban many state retrials. A1
 
Web Sites Track Unabom Case
A series of Internet sites dedicated to coverage of the trial of Theodore J. Kaczynski, who is charged with the Unabomber attacks, is reviving one of the oddest images of the interactive age: Web sites filled with information about the man prosecutors say was the most notorious anti-technology zealot in this century. A7
 
2d Christmas Fire for Builder
Seven years after a fire destroyed a Dallas homebuilder's house on the day after Christmas in 1990, he faces the same painful task again this year, after the replacement was destroyed on Christmas Eve. No one was home when the four-alarm fire broke out about 8:30 P.M. Wednesday. It took 68 firefighters more than an hour to put out, authorities said. The cause of the fire was being investigated but the owner said there had been recent problems with squirrels chewing through electrical wiring in the attic. (AP)
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-5
 
6 Officers Suspended In Inquiry of Bar Brawl
Six New York City police detectives have been suspended for failing to report their role in a Crown Heights bar brawl last week with a man who died beneath the wheels of a subway train less than two hours later, the police said. While the exact circumstances of the man's death remain undetermined, investigators have found a series of irregularities in the way police officers responded to the bar fight. B2
 
Mourning the End of 'Seinfeld'
Fans of "Seinfeld," the most popular television comedy series of the decade, were stunned at the news that Jerry Seinfeld had decided to stop producing his homage to single life in the city at the end of this season. So they did what Jerry and his pals, Elaine, George and Kramer, would do in similar straits: they went to a coffee shop, Tom's Restaurant at 114th Street and Broadway, which provides the outside facade for the show's usual hangout. B1

Scholars Debate 'New' Gospels
Mass market publishing of ancient texts that were excluded from the new testament are highlighting a disagreement among some scholars over the value of these nonbiblical gospels and what they reveal about early Christianity's development. Taking a provocative stance, a few scholars even talk about creating a new canon. Publication of the new texts could for some end up blurring the line between what the church considers to be revealed truth and what it does not. B7
 
CNN Readies Its 'Cold War'
"Cold War," with a budget of nearly $15 million, is the most ambitious television series in CNN's 18-year history. It is scheduled to begin running on Sunday nights next Sept. 13. Forty writers, researchers and editors are laboring in a cluttered office in London to assemble the final 3 episodes of a 24-part series. B7

BUSINESS DAY D1-14
 
Sale Prices in South Korea
South Korea, already humbled by having to accept an international bailout, is facing what could be another blow to its national pride: a wave of takeovers of its companies by American and other foreign corporations. The nation's plummeting stock market and currency have made Korean companies potential bargains for foreign firms, just as the International Monetary Fund's economic rescue is forcing the nation to open up to foreign investment. Moreover, most of South Korea's family-owned conglomerates are either bankrupt or reeling under heavy debts and are being forced to sell parts of their treasured empires. A1
 
Kim Broaches Layoff Taboo
President-elect Kim Dae Jung of South Korea met with the nation's top labor leaders to try to persuade them to accept the possibility of layoffs in the increasingly grim economic reality that is still settling over the country. In a nation with an intensely militant labor force, however, any talk of layoffs opens the door to deep uncertainty, even when options seem few. D1
 
Banks Pressured on Loans
About a dozen of the United State's most influential commercial and investment banks will huddle with Federal Reserve officials in New York on Monday morning, discussing ways to shore up South Korea's ailing borrowers. United States lenders, as well as their counterparts in Europe and Japan, are being pressured by regulators to roll over problem loans until the South Korean economy stabilizes. D1
 
Dow Rises 19 Points
An overnight rally in South Korea's ravaged stocks contributed to mild gains in the United States stock market, but many investors stayed away from a shortened post-Christmas trading session that was the slowest of the year. The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 19.18 points, or 0.25 percent, at 7,679.31, narrowing its loss for the week to 79.98 points. D10
